projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: I do Allow of the Reprinting of The≈øe Four Parts of Leonards Reports.
REPORTS AND CASES OF LAW: Argued and Adjudged in the Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter, In the Times of the Late QUEEN ELIZABETH, AND KING JAMES.
In Four Parts.

p.hi: The Second Impre≈ø≈øion, carefully Corrected, with the Addition of Many Thou≈øand of References, never before Printed.

div.p: Collected by a Learned Profe≈ø≈øor of the LAW, WILLIAM LEONARD, E≈øquire, Then of the Honourable Society of GRAYS-INN.
Publi≈øhed by William Hughes of Grays-Inn, E≈øquire.

p.hi: With Alphabetical TABLES of the Names of the Ca≈øes, and of the Matter contained in each Part.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by William Rawlins, Samuel Roycroft, and Miles Fle≈øher, A≈ø≈øigns of Richard and Edward Atkins, E≈øquires.
For H. Twyford, H. Herringman, T. Ba≈ø≈øet, R. Chi≈øwell, B. Griffin, C. Harper, T. Sawbridge, J. Place, and S. Keble, MDCLXXXVII.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: THe≈øe Ca≈øes were Collected and taken in the French Tongue, by William Leonard E≈øquire, ≈øometimes of the Honourable Society of Grays-Inn; a Learned Profe≈ø≈øor and Practi≈øer of the Common Law, in the time of the Reign of the late Queen Elizabeth: One Copy of ≈øome of the≈øe Ca≈øes (many years pa≈øt) came into the hands of Sir Robert Hitcham Knight, afterwards Serjeant at Law; Another Copy of other of the≈øe Ca≈øes came then into the hands of Humphry Davenport Serjeant at Law; afterwards Sir Humpry Davenport Knight, late Lord chief Baron of the Court of Exchequer; Both which ≈øaid learned per≈øons approved of them, and made u≈øe of them in the cour≈øe of their ≈øeveral Practice. Some other Copies of ≈øome of the≈øe Ca≈øes are now di≈øper≈øed abroad, and are in the hands of divers Practi≈øers and Students of the Law, who make the like u≈øe of them. The Originals them≈øelves of all the≈øe Ca≈øes (among≈øt many others of the ≈øaid Mr. Leonards collecting) all of them under his own hand-writing, are now in my hands, having been delivered to me by a worthy Gent. of the ≈øaid Society of Grays-Inn, who had them out of the Library, ≈øomtimes belonging to the ≈øaid Mr. Leonard. The≈øe Ca≈øes having been lately, truly and carefully Tran≈ølated by me out of the Original French Copy into Engli≈øh, have ≈øince the Tran≈ølation thereof, been peru≈øed and approved of by many Eminent Profe≈ø≈øors of the Law. Wherefore I finding that the ≈øame do contain many excellent Matters and Points of Law, which have not heretofore been Printed, or publi≈øhed, do here offer the ≈øame unto thy Judgment upon a ≈øerious con≈øideration, hoping they may be of ≈øome u≈øe and benefit to thee, in the like cour≈øe of thy ≈øtudy and practice of LAW.

closer.dateline: From my Study at Grays-Inn, Novemb. 20th. 1658.

div.head: REPORTS AND Ca≈øes of Law, Argued and Adjudged in the Time of Queen Elizabeth, From the twenty fourth to the three and thirtieth year of Her Reign.

I. Borneford and Packingtons Ca≈øe.
Hill. 25. Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpas, It was found by ≈øpecial verdict,Cu≈øtom of Free-Bench. That the Defendant was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of B. whereof the place where is parcel, demi≈øed and demi≈øeable by Copy, &c. And that B. the Granfather of the Plaintiff was ≈øei≈øed of the place where, &c. according to the cu≈øtom of the ≈øaid Manor, in Fee-≈øimple, and that within the ≈øaid Manor there is this Cu≈øtom, That if any Copy-holder dieth ≈øei≈øed, his Wife over-living him ≈øhall hold all the Land during her Widowhood as Free-bench, and ≈øhall be admitted Tenant to the Lord,2 Brownl 21. and that the Heir ≈øhall not be admitted to it during the life of his Mother: And found al≈øo another Cu≈øtom within the ≈øaid Manor, That if any Copy-holder be convicted of Felony, and the ≈øame be pre≈øented by the Homage, that then the Lord might ≈øeize, &c. And it was further found, that the Grandfather of the Plaintiff took a Wife, and died ≈øei≈øed, having i≈ø≈øue A. Father of the Plaintiff. The Wife is admitted to her Free-bench, A. is convicted of Felony, and that is pre≈øented by the Homage; and afterwards A. died, after which the Wife died, &c. It was argued by Atkin≈øon, that A. is not within the danger of this Cu≈øtom, for during the life of his Mother, who by a Claimer is Tenant to the Lord, and admitted to it, ≈øhe is Copy-holder; and it is not like to the Ca≈øe lately adjudged of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øio fratris, without admittance, for there the party was admittable, and ≈øo he was not here: And al≈øo it appeareth by the Cu≈øtom as it is found, That the Lord upon ≈øuch matter ≈øhall ≈øeize, and therefore we ought to make con≈øtruction that this Cu≈øtom doth not extend to Ca≈øes where the Lord cannot ≈øeize; but in the Ca≈øe at Bar, the Lord cannot ≈øeize by rea≈øon of this Free-bench; And we ought not by any con≈øtruction to extend a Cu≈øtom beyond the words in which it is conceived, but it ≈øhall be taken ≈øtrictly, and not be ≈øupplyed by Equity with a Cu≈øtom in the place of a Sei≈øure. But notwith≈øtanding all this, afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head: II. Hill. 25 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: A Copy-holder doth ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of one A. upon tru≈øt, that he ≈øhall hold the ≈øaid Land until he hath levyed certain monies, and that afterwards he ≈øhall ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of B; the monies are levyed, A. is required to make ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of B. he refu≈øeth, B. exhibits a Bill to the Lord of the Mannor again≈øt the ≈øaid A. who upon hearing of the Cau≈øe decrees again≈øt A. that he ≈øhall ≈øurrender; he refu≈øeth, now the Lord may ≈øeize, and admit B. to the Copy-hold, for he in ≈øuch Ca≈øes is Chancellor in his own Court, per totam Curiam.

div.head:
III. Wade and Bemboes Ca≈øe.
Hill. 25. Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN a Writ of Error by Wade again≈øt Bembo upon a Iudgment given in the Court of the City of Bri≈øtol, the Ca≈øe was, That Bembo was Plaintiff in the ≈øaid Court again≈øt Wade in an Action of Covenant, and declared of a Covenant made by word by the Te≈øtator of Wade with Bembo; and declared al≈øo, that within the ≈øaid City there is a Cu≈øtom, That Conventio ore tenus facta, ≈øhall bind the Covenantor as ≈øtrongly as if it were made by writing: And it was holden by the Court, that that Cu≈øtom doth not warrant this Action, for the Covenant binds by the Cu≈øtom the Covenantor, but doth not extend to his Executors, and a Cu≈øtom ≈øhall be taken ≈øtrictly, and therefore the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head: IV. The Lord Paget and Sir Walter A≈øhtons Ca≈øe. 25 Pa≈øch. 25. Eliz. in the Kings Bench,
div.p:
THe Lord Paget brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Sir Walter A≈øhton, who ju≈øtified becau≈øe he is ≈øei≈øed of three Me≈ø≈øuages to him and his Heirs, and that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath, &c. have had the Woodward≈øhip of the Forre≈øt of C. within which, the place where, &c. and al≈øo have had within the ≈øaid Forre≈øt E≈øtovers without number: And that one Rowland Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfield was ≈øei≈øed of the Forre≈øt afore≈øaid in the right of his Church, and by Indenture betwixt him and Sir Edw. A≈øhton his Ance≈øtor, who≈øe Heir he is, ≈øetting forth that divers debates had been betwixt the ≈øaid parties concerning ≈øome profits within the ≈øaid Forre≈øt; It was agreed betwixt them, that the ≈øaid Sir Ed. A≈øhton ≈øhould relea≈øe unto the ≈øaid Rowland all his right in the ≈øaid Office and E≈øtovers, and that the ≈øaid Rowland ≈øhoud grant de novo unto the ≈øaid Edw. and his Heirs the ≈øaid Office, and one hundred loads of E≈øtovers per annum out of the ≈øaid Forre≈øt: After which the ≈øaid Ed. according to the ≈øaid agreement, did relea≈øe to the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop ut ≈øupra, after which the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop by Indenture reciting the ≈øaid former Convenants in compl. Indenturae praedict. Convent. did grant to the ≈øaid Sir Ed. the ≈øaid Office and E≈øtovers pro ea≈øiamento dicti Edwardi, & haered. ≈øuorum by a≈ø≈øignment of the Officers of the ≈øaid Forre≈øt; and if the a≈ø≈øignment he not made within ten days after reque≈øt, that then the ≈øaid Ed. and his Heirs ≈øhould cut dow wood where they plea≈øed; and averred, the things relea≈øed were of as great value as the things granted: And upon this matter the Plaintiff did demurr in Law, and it was adjuded for the Plaintiff, for here no Inheritance in the things granted pa≈ø≈øed to the ≈øaid Sir Ed. but only an Intere≈øt for his own life;1. In≈øt. 148. a. 398. b. ib. Dy. 253. 1 Cro. 644. for the grant was to Sir Ed. only without the word, Heirs; and the reference to the Indentures, by which the Bi≈øhop hath covenanted to grant the Inheritance, nor the words in the grant imply an e≈øtate in Fee, s. pro ea≈øimento dict. Ed.
& haered. ≈øuorum, and that in default of A≈ø≈øignment it ≈øhould be lawful for Sir Ed. and his Heirs, ≈øhall not ≈øupply the defect of the words in the grant.

div.head:
V. Gilbert and Sir George Harts Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25 and 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: GIlbert brought Debt upon E≈øcape again≈øt Sir George Hart Sheriff of Kent, and declared,E≈øcape. 1. Cro. 188. 271. That he recovered a certain debt again≈øt A. who was taken in Execution, &c. And the Ca≈øe was, That the ≈øaid A. was taken in Execution in the time of the old Sheriff, and e≈øcaped al≈øo then: and afterwards the Defendant being Sheriff, the Plaintiff again ≈øued a Scire facias again≈øt the ≈øaid A. upon the Iudgment afore≈øaid, upon which Execution was awarded by default, and thereupon i≈ø≈øued a Capias ad ≈øatisfaciendum, by which A. was taken, and e≈øcaped: And by the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices, the Defendant in this Ca≈øe ≈øhall be charged; for notwith≈øtanding that A. was once in Execution, which was determined by e≈øcape in the time of the old Sheriff, yet when Execution was now awarded again≈øt him upon his default in the Scire facias, the ≈øame ≈øhall bind the Sheriff out of who≈øe cu≈øtody he e≈øcaped.

div.head:
VI. Moor and Farrands Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25 and 26 Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p: MOore lea≈øed Lands to Farrand upon condition that he,1. Cro. 26. Condition where ≈øhall not bind Admini≈øtrators. 1. Ander≈ø. 123. Dy. 6. 1 Cro. 26. 757 3. Len. 67. his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhould not alien without the leave of the le≈ø≈øor; Farrand died inte≈øtate, his Wife took Letters of Admini≈øtration, and aliened without leave, and by Periam Iu≈øtice, ≈øhe is not within the penalty of the Condition, for the Admini≈øtrator is not meerly in by the party, but by the Ordinary: And by Meade and Periam, If a Lea≈øe for years upon ≈øuch a Condition be extended upon a Recogni≈øance, the ≈øame is not an alienation again≈øt the Condition: But if feme le≈ø≈øee for years upon ≈øuch Condition taketh a Husband and dieth, the Husband is within the danger of the Condition, for he is A≈ø≈øignee: If the King grant to a Subject bona & catalla felonum, and the le≈ø≈øor for years upon ≈øuch a Condition be out-lawed, upon which the Patentee enters, Now by Periam the Patentee is not bound by the Condition. Meade contrary, for the Condition ≈øhall go with the Land.

div.head:
VII. Maynyes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25 and 26 Eliz. in the Exechequer.
div.p:
MAyney ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Fee, took a Wife,Co. 1. In≈øt 41. ‚Ä¢ . made a Feoffment to a ≈øtranger, committeth Trea≈øon, and thereof is attainted, and hath a Charter of Pardon and dieth. It was moved by Plowden in the Exchequer, if the Wife of Mayney ≈øhall have Dower again≈øt the Feoffee:Dower. Manwood Chief Baron, by rea≈øon of this Attainder Dower cannot accrue to the Wife, for her title begins by the Enter-marriage, and ought to continue and be con≈øummated by the death of the Husband, which cannot be in this Ca≈øe; for the Attainder of the Husband hath interrupted it, as in the Ca≈øe of Elopement:Attainder where an E≈øtoppel. And this Attainder is an univer≈øal E≈øtoppel, and doth not run in privity only betwixt the Wife and him to whom the E≈øcheat belongs, but every ≈øtranger may bar her of her Dower by rea≈øon thereof; for by the Attainder of her Husband the Wife is di≈øabled to demand Dower as well as to demand his Inheritance; and he cited the Re≈øolution of all the Iu≈øtices of England in the Ca≈øe of the Lady Gates, 4. Ma. Dyer. 140. and the Pardon doth not help the matter, for the ≈øame extends but to the
life of the Offender, but doth not take away the Attainder by which ≈øhe is barred to demand Dower during the ≈øaid Attainder in force: See the Statute of 5. E 6. cap. 11. Vid. Fitz. Dower 82. 13. E 3. 8 E 3. Dower 106 Fitz. Utlag. 49.

div.head: 8 Mich. 25, and 26 Eliz. in the Exchequer.
div.p: 4. Len. 117. Lea≈øes for three lives of Copy-hold e≈øtate are not within Stat. 41. Eliz.IN the Exchequer it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, That the Guardians and Chanons Regular of Otlery, were ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of O, &c. and that 22 H 7. at a Court holden there, granted the Lands in que≈øtion to W. and W. his Son for their lives by Copy, according to the Cu≈øtom of the ≈øaid Mannor, and that afterwards 30 H 8. They lea≈øed the Lands by Indenture to H. rendering the ancient and accu≈øtomed Rent, and afterward ≈øurrendred their Colledge, &c. and afterward W. and W. dyed: And if that Lea≈øe ≈øo made during the cu≈øtomary e≈øtate for life, notwith≈øtanding the Statute of 31 H 8. be good or not, was the Que≈øtion, being within a year before the ≈øurrender, &c. It was argued by Egerton Sollicitor, that the ≈øaid Lea≈øe is void by the Statute; the words of which are (whereof or in the which any e≈øtate or intere≈øt for term of life, year, or years, at the time of the making of any ≈øuch Lea≈øe, had his being or continuance, and was not then determined fini≈øhed, or expired) and therefore we are to ≈øee, if that right or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion which W. had at the time of the making of the Lea≈øe were an intere≈øt, or an e≈øtate for life: And as to this word (e≈øtate) it is nothing el≈øe than mea≈øure of time, for an e≈øtate in Fee-≈øimple is as much as to ≈øay, an intere≈øt in the Lands for ever, and the like of other e≈øtates, and therefore here W. and W. had at the time of the making of this Lea≈øe an e≈øtate for life in the thing demi≈øed: And although ≈øuch cu≈øtomary Tenants are termed in Law Tenants at will, yet they are not ≈øimply ≈øo, nor meerly Tenants at will, but only Tenants at will, ≈øecundum Con≈øuetudinem Manerii, Copy-holde ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Intere≈øt. which Cu≈øtom warrants his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion here for his life, and therefore it is a more certain e≈øtate than an e≈øtate at will, for the Copyholder may ju≈øtifie again≈øt his Lord, ≈øo cannot a Tenant at will, who≈øe e≈øtate is determined at the will and plea≈øure of his Le≈ø≈øor: And although this e≈øtate is but by Cu≈øtom, and by no Conveyance the e≈øtate is rai≈øed; it is as material, ≈øo as it be an e≈øtate: and this e≈øtate being ≈øupported by Cu≈øtom is known in Law an e≈øtate and ≈øo accounted in Law; and the Law hath notably di≈øtingui≈øhed Copy-hold Tenancies by Cu≈øtom, and Tenancies at will by the Common Law; for a Copy-holder ≈øhall do Fealty, ≈øhall have aid of his Lord in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, ≈øhall have and maintain an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt his Lord, his Wife ≈øhall be indowed, the Husband ≈øhall be Tenant by the Curte≈øie without new admittance: and it was adjudged in the Common Pleas, 8. Eliz. That if a Copy-holder ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of another for years, the Le≈ø≈øee dieth, his Executors ≈øhall have the re≈øidue of the Term without any admittance, M 14. and 15. Eliz. a Copy-holder made a Lea≈øe for years by Indenture warranted by the Cu≈øtom, it was adjudged that the Le≈ø≈øees ≈øhould maintain Ejectione firm. although it was objected, that if it were ≈øo, then if the Plaintiff doth recover,Po≈øt 16 2 Len. 119. he ≈øhould have Habere facias po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem; and then Copyholds ≈øhould be ordered by the Laws of the Land, 10 Eliz. Lord and Copy-holder for life, the Lord grants a Rent-charge out of the Mannor, whereof the Copy-hold is parcel, the Copy-holder ≈øurrenders to the u≈øe of A. who is admitted accordingly, he ≈øhall not hold it charged, but if the Copy-holder dieth ≈øo that his e≈øtate is determined, and the Lord granteth to a ≈øtranger de novo to hold the ≈øaid Lands by Copy, this new Tenant ≈øhall hold the Land charged: and ≈øo was it rated and adjudged in the Common Pleas. It was adjorned.

div.head: IX. The Lord Paget and the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Leichfields Ca≈øe. Mich. 25. & 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
X. Stonley, and Bracebridges Ca≈øe. Mich. 25 & 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN Ejectione firmae, by Stonley again≈øt Bracebridge, the ca≈øe was,P ‚Ä¢ o. Com. 417. 418. Thomas Bracebridge Father of the Defendant was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Kingsbury, to him and to the heirs males of his body, and 32 H. 8. Lea≈øed a Field called Stalling, parcell of the ≈øaid Mannor, to Tho. Coke for years, and afterwards, 4 E. 6. Lea≈øed the ≈øaid Field (the fir≈øt Lea≈øe being
in e≈ø≈øe) to Sir Geo. Griffith for ≈øeventy years, who a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øame to A. Bracebridge Brother of the Le≈ø≈øor, and to Joyce Wife of the Le≈ø≈øor, and afterwards, 5 E 6. the ≈øaid Tho. Bracebridge, the Le≈ø≈øor, by his Deed Indented, gave the ≈øaid Mannor to the ≈øaid Sir George by the≈øe words (dedi, conce≈ø≈øi, barganizavi, & vendidi) Provi≈øo, and upon condition, That the ≈øaid Sir George, ≈øhould pay to the ≈øaid Thomas Bracebridge, within fifteen days after, ten hundred pounds, and if he fail of payment thereof, that then after the ≈øaid fifteen days, the ≈øaid Sir George ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed of a Tenement, parcel of the ≈øaid Mannor of the yearly value of three pounds (now of ≈øate in the occupation of Thomas Smith) to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Thomas Bracebridge for his life, and after to the ≈øaid Sir George, until he had levyed five hundred pounds for the payment of the debts, and the education of the children of the ≈øaid Thomas Bracebridge, and after to the u≈øe of the Defendant in tail: And of the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid Mannor, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Tho. Bracebridge, and of the ≈øaid Joyce his Wife for their lives, &c. Tho. Bracebridge, made livery to the ≈øaid Sir George, in one place parcel of the ≈øaid Mannor, which was in his own occupation in the name of the whole Mannor: the fifteen days incur without payment of the ≈øaid ten hundred pounds, the Indenture is enroled, Coke attorns, Joyce dyes, Tho. Bracebridge grants the Lands to a ≈øtranger by Fine, and before Proclamations, Thomas his Son and Heir apparent, within age, enters in the name of the Feoffees by rea≈øon of the forfeiture, Proclamations are made, Tho. Bracebridge the Father dyeth, the Term of Coke expireth, A. enters, and lea≈øeth to the Plantiff, who enters, upon whom Tho. Bracebridge the Son enters, upon which Entry the Action is brought, it was argued by Beamount the elder: Although here in the Indenture of bargain and ≈øale, there is not an expre≈øs con≈øideration ≈øet down in the common form of a con≈øideration, yet becau≈øe the con≈øideration is implied in the condition, it is good enough (≈øee the Provi≈øo and condition, ut ≈øupra, that the ≈øaid Sir George ≈øhould pay, &c.) As if I bargain and ≈øell to you my Land, Provi≈øo that you pay to me for the ≈øame at ≈øuch a day one hundred pounds, that con≈øideration ≈øet down in the form of a condition is as effectual, as if it had been formally expre≈ø≈øed in the u≈øual Terms. As to the ≈øecond payment, Where a man bargains and ≈øells his Lands by Deed indented to be enroled, and before enrolment he makes Livery to the Bargainee, and afterwards the Indentur is enroled, the Court di≈øcharged Beamount from the arguing of that Point,Live ‚Ä¢ y, where it prevents operation of an Enrolment. for by Wray, the Livery doth prevent the operation of the Enrolment, and Sir George ≈øhall be accounted in by the Livery, and not by the bargain and ≈øale; for Livery is of more worth, and more worthy ceremony to pa≈øs e≈øtates, and therefore ≈øhall be preferred: and then the Livery being made in ≈øuch part of the Mannor, which was in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Feoffor in the name of the whole Mannor, no more of the Mannor pa≈ø≈øeth but that which was then in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Feoffor: And the Rever≈øion of ≈øuch part of the Mannor which was in Lea≈øe ≈øhall not pa≈øs without Attornment, but when the Enrolment cometh, now the whole pa≈ø≈øeth, and then the Rever≈øion being ≈øetled by the Enrolment, the Attornment coming afterwards hath no relation: See 48 E. 3. 15, 16. The Iury here have found the default of payment, whereby the conditional u≈øe which pa≈ø≈øed by the bargain and ≈øale, upon the condition broken, ≈øhall be reduced to the Bargainor without any Entry,1. Cro. 382. and then the u≈øes limited after are void, for an u≈øe limited upon an u≈øe cannot ri≈øe; quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum per totam curiam: Then Bracebridge the Father, having the Inheritance of the ≈øaid Mannor in his own right, and the intere≈øt de futuro for years in the right of his Wife joyntly with the ≈øaid A. when he ≈øells the ≈øaid Mannor by Deed indented and enroled now thereby the intere≈øt for years which he hath in the Right of his Wife doth not pa≈øs, for a bargain and ≈øale is not ≈øo ≈øtrong a conveyance as a Livery. As if I have a Rent-charge in the right of my Wife, out of the Manor of D. which Manor
afterwards I purcha≈øe, and afterwards by Deed indented and enroled, I bargain and ≈øell the ≈øaid Manor, &c. the Rent ≈øhall not pa≈øs. Then the ≈øaid Thomas Bracebridge the Father having the ≈øaid Right of an entail to him and to the Heirs Males of his body, and being Tenant for life, by his own conveyance, the Remainder in tail to his Son and Heir apparent, the now Defendant, when he levyeth a Fine, and the Son enters for forfeiture before Proclamations pa≈øs, and his Father dyeth, in that ca≈øe the Defendant is not remitted unto the fir≈øt entail, although after Proclamations pa≈øs in the life of the Father, and ≈øo he ≈øhall not avoid the Lea≈øes; for notwith≈øtanding that the I≈ø≈øue in tail by that Entry hath defeated the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion which pa≈ø≈øed by the Fine, yet as to the right of the old entail, the Fine doth retain its force, and ≈øo he entred, quodam modo, in a≈ø≈øurance of the Fine: As if Tenant in tail doth di≈øcontinue and di≈ø≈øei≈øeth the Di≈øcontinuee, and levieth a Fine with Proclamations, and the Di≈øcontinuee enters within the five years, now although the Fine as to the Di≈øcontinuee be avoided, ≈øo as the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion which pa≈ø≈øed by the Fine is defeated, yet the right of the entail doth continue bound: Egerton Solicitor contrary: and he conceived, that all the Mannor doth pa≈øs by the Livery to Sir George, and nothing of it by the Enrolment, and that the meaning of the parties was, that all ≈øhould pa≈øs by the Livery, for if the a≈ø≈øurance ≈øhould enure by the bargain and ≈øale, then the ≈øecond u≈øes limited upon default of payment, ≈øhould never ri≈øe; for an u≈øe upon an u≈øe cannot ri≈øe, and then the ≈øaid u≈øes limited for the payment of the debts of the Feoffor, &c. ≈øhould be defeated; and al≈øo where at the begining of the a≈ø≈øurance, the condition was entire, the warranty entire, &c. and if ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhould be allowed, here ≈øhall be a divided condition, a divided warranty: And al≈øo the meaning of the parties that the whole Mannor ≈øhould pa≈øs, by ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhould be di≈ømembred, and part pa≈øs by the Livery, and part by the bargain and ≈øale, and we ought to make ≈øuch con≈øtructions of Deeds, that things may pa≈øs by them according to the meanings of the parties; as if I be ≈øei≈øed of a Mannor to which and Advow≈øon is appendant, and I make a Deed of Feoffment of the ≈øame Mannor, cum pertinencijs, and deliver the Deed to the party, but no Livery of ≈øei≈øin is had, the Advow≈øon ≈øhall not pa≈øs, for then it ≈øhould be in gro≈øs, whereas the meaning of the parties was, that it ≈øhould pa≈øs as appendant, and that in ≈øuch ca≈øe cannot be, for there is no Livery, therefore it ≈øhall not pa≈øs at all, and ≈øo it hath been adjudged: So if I bargain and ≈øell my Mannor of D. and all the Trees in the ≈øame, and I deliver the Deed, but it is not enrolled, the Trees ≈øhall not pa≈øs, for the intent of the parties was, that the Trees ≈øhould pa≈øs, as parcel of the Free-hold and not as Chattels. And as to the remitter, I conceive, that the Heir entring as Heir, by the Law is remitted, but where the Entry is given by a ≈øpecial Statute, there the Entry ≈øhall not enure further than the words of the Statute; As Land is given to the Husband and Wife, and to the Heirs of the body of the Husband, the Husband levieth a Fine and dieth, the wife entreth, this Entry ≈øhall not avail to the i≈ø≈øue in tail, for the Entry is given to the Wife by a ≈øpecial Law: And he cited Sir Richard Haddons Ca≈øe, the Husband aliened the Lands of his Wife, they are divorced, the Husband dieth, the Wife ≈øhall not enter by 32. H. 8. but is put to her Writ of Cui in vita ante divor. And afterwards the ≈øame Term the Iu≈øtices having con≈øidered of the Ca≈øe, delivered their opinions upon the matters by Wray chief Iu≈øtice, viz. That the one moyety of the Lea≈øe was extinct by the Livery, viz. the moyety of Ioyce the Wife of the Le≈ø≈øor; and as to the other moyety it is in being, for here is no remitter; for if any remitter had been in the Ca≈øe, it ≈øhould be after the u≈øe rai≈øed, which is not as yet rai≈øed, for the Land ought to remain in Sir George until the ≈øaid five hundred pounds be levyed, and that is not found by the Verdict, and therefore for the ≈øaid moyety, the Plaintiff had Iudgment.

div.head:
XI. Tre≈øhams Ca≈øe.
Mich 25 & 26 Eliz. in the Exchequer.
div.p:
SIR John Tre≈øham ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. holden of the King in Capite by Knights ≈øervice, 4 H. 7. enfeoffed Edmund Earl of Wilts and N. Vaux Knight, who gave the ≈øaid Manor to the ≈øaid Sir John in tail, upon condition that he ≈øhould not alien, &c. quo minus, &c. John Tre≈øham dyed ≈øei≈øed, by who≈øe decea≈øe the Manor de≈øcended to Tho. Tre≈øham, who entred,2 Len. 55, 56. and 18 H. 8. aliened with licence, by recovery, &c. N. Vaux the ≈øurviving Feoffee died, having i≈ø≈øue W. Lord Vaux; the purcha≈øor died ≈øei≈øed, his Son and Heir 14 Eliz. levied a Fine Sur Conu≈øans de droit, &c. and that Fine was levied to the u≈øe of the Conu≈øee, &c. and that without licence: The Lord Vaux within five years after the Fine levied, entred for the condition broken: and now i≈ø≈øued forth a Scire facias again≈øt the Conu≈øee for that alienation without licence, who made default, whereupon i≈ø≈øued proce≈øs to ≈øeize the Lands; whereupon came Sir Tho. Tre≈øham, Fine for Alienation without Licence. and ≈øhewed the whole matter afore≈øaid, and prayed to be di≈øcharged. It was ≈øaid, that this Prerogative to have a Fine for alienation without licence, had lately beginning upon the original creation of Seignories, ≈øo as this prerogative is as it were paramount the Seignory, and ≈øhall go paramount the Condition, as well as the Condition is paramount the Alienation, but if the di≈ø≈øei≈øor of the Tenant of the King maketh a Feoffment in Fee, now upon the entry of the di≈ø≈øei≈øee, the per≈øon of the Feoffee ≈øhall be charged with a Fine, but the Land by the re-entry of the di≈ø≈øei≈øee is di≈øcharged: and ≈øuch is the opinion of the Lord Frowick, in his Reading upon the Statute of Prerogativa Regis, and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the di≈ø≈øei≈øor is not Tenant to the King, and ≈øo when he aliens, it cannot be ≈øaid an Alienation by the Kings Tenant. See 45 E. 3. 6. If the Tenant of the King in chief ≈øea≈øeth for life with licence, and afterwards grants the Rever≈øion over without licence,Entry for Condition, what acts it ≈øhall defeat. the Tenant for life is not bound to atturn in a Quid juris clamat; wherfore it ≈øeems, that if ≈øuch Tenant doth attorn, the King ≈øhall ≈øeize pre≈øently. This Entry for the Condition broken is not to have ≈øo violent a retro≈øpect to the fir≈øt livery to which the Condition was annexed, that it ≈øhall defeat all things mean between the Creation and the breach of the Condition, but it ≈øhall defeat all mean things which ri≈øe upon the act of the party, as Rent, Dower, &c. But charges which accrue by rea≈øon of Tenure, do remain, notwith≈øtanding the Entry for the Condition broken: As if ≈øuch a Tenant of the King maketh a Feoffment in Fee upon condition, which is broken, the Feoffee dieth ≈øei≈øed, his Heir of full age, the Feoffor re-entereth, this re-entry by force of the condition broken hath not ≈øo avoided the de≈øcent, but the King ≈øhall have Relief upon the ≈øaid de≈øcent, for the Relief is paramount the Livery, and the condition. So if a Feoffee upon condition di≈øclaim in Avowry,Condition ≈øhall not avoid an Intere≈øt ve≈øted. by which the Lord brings a Writ of Right Sur Di≈øclaimer, and hath Iudgment; the Feoffee entreth for the condition broken, the ≈øaid re-entry ≈øhall not avoid the intere≈øt of the Lord by the Iudgment on the Writ of Di≈øclaimer, but he may enter at his plea≈øure; and it was moved by Plowden who argued for Tre≈øham, that if the Tenant of the King, being Non Compos mentis, makes a Feoffment in Fee, and dieth, his Heir entring upon the Feoffee ≈øhall not pay a Fine for the Alienation of his Father, but the per≈øon of the Father ≈øhall be charged with it. And at the end of this Term, after many Arguments and Motions, Iudgment was given for the Queen, that ≈øhe ≈øhould ≈øeize the Land and hold the ≈øame for the Fine, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould not be driven to ≈øue the per≈øon of the Feoffee or Conu≈øee: And by Manwood chief Baron, at the Commom Law in many Manors, Tenant in
≈øoccage upon every alienation ≈øhall pay a Fine, nomine relevii, a fortiori, in the Kings ca≈øe, and therefore he was of opinion, That this Prerogative to have a Fine for alienation without licence is by the common Law, and not by any Statute.

div.head:
XII. Caters Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25 and 26 Eliz. in the Exchequer Chamber.
div.p:
A Bill of Intru≈øion was in the Exchequer again≈øt Cater, Intru≈øion. 7 Co. 12. 1 Ander≈ø. 95. who pleaded the Grant of the Queen, the Plaintiff replicando ≈øaid, that before the Queen had any thing, &c. Sir Francis Englefield was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor, of which, &c. and he being beyond the Seas, the Queen ≈øent her Letters under the Privy Seal, Quod ip≈øe in fide, & legeanti√¢ qu√¢ dictae Reginae tenebatur, indirecte rediret in Angliam, praedict. tamen Franci≈øcus (≈øpretis mandatis dict. Reginae) venire recu≈øavit, for which a Certificate was by the ≈øaid Queen into the Chancery, Quod dictus Franci≈øcus in portibus tran≈ømarinis ≈øine licentia dict. Reginae reman≈øit: And thereupon a Commi≈ø≈øion was awarded to ≈øeize the Lands of the ≈øaid Sir Francis, which was entred in the Replication in haec verba, reciting al≈øo the Queens Privy Seal, and that the ≈øaid Sir Francis did ≈øtay there (≈øpretis mandatis, &c.) for which the Queen ≈øei≈øed and granted to the Plaintiff: And afterwards the Statutes of 13 and 14. Eliz. were made: after which the ≈øaid grant was made to the Defendant, upon which matter there was a Demurrer and Iudgment given for the Plaintiff.Error. And now Cater brought a Writ of Error in the Exchequer Chamber, and it was fir≈øt a≈ø≈øigned for Error, becau≈øe that the Record is entred Inter Johannem Cater pre≈øent. hic in Curia by I.S. Attornatum ≈øuum, and that cannot be, for it is oppo≈øitum in objecto, that one can be pre≈øent in Court and al≈øo by Attorney, ≈øimul & ≈øemel, for the Attorney is to ≈øupply the default of the per≈øonal pre≈øence. To which it was ≈øaid by Wray, Ander≈øon and Periam, that the matter a≈ø≈øigned was no Error, for there are many Pre≈øidents in the Exchequer of ≈øuch Entries, which were openly ≈øhewed in Court. 48 E 3. 10. R 2. 20 H 7. 20 H 8. And by Manwood chief Baron it is not ≈øo ab≈øurd an Entry as it hath been objected, for if one hath an Attorney of Record in the Kings Bench, and he him≈øelf is in the Mar≈øhal≈øey, there is an Action again≈øt him, he is pre≈øent as Pri≈øoner, and al≈øo by Attorney; and by them, notwith≈øtanding that here appeareth a contrariety, for ≈øuch Entry properly is (pre≈øentem hic in Curia in propri√¢ per≈øona ≈øua) yet becau≈øe many proceedings are according, it is the more ≈øafe cour≈øe to follow them, for if this Iudgment be rever≈øed for this cau≈øe, many Records ≈øhould be al≈øo rever≈øed, which ≈øhould be very perillous: An other Error was a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe it is not alledged in the Replication, of what date the Privy Seal was, nor that any notice of the ≈øaid Privy Seal was given to Sir Francis; to which it was ≈øaid, that the Privy Seal need not any date, e≈øpecially in this ca≈øe, for the matters which are under the Privy Seal are not i≈ø≈øuable. See 2 Eliz. Dyer. 177.Privy Seal. nor any traver≈øe can be taken to it; and this Privy Seal is not as other Writs and Praecipes are, returnable in any Court, but the Queen her ≈øelf from whom originally it came ≈øhall receive it, and al≈øo the Me≈ø≈øage upon it, and ≈øhe her ≈øelf in ≈øuch ca≈øe is Iudge of the contempt, and no Record of that Privy Seal doth remain in any Court, but the Queen her ≈øelf ≈øhall keep it, and then when the Queen is informed of the contempt, ≈øhe makes a Warrant ≈øomtimes to the Chancellor to award a Commi≈ø≈øion, ≈øomtimes to the Trea≈øurer and Barons of the Exchequer to the ≈øame purpo≈øe to ≈øeize the Lands, and that Warrant is ≈øigned, with the Seal manual of the Queen, and the Queen may certifie, and ≈øet down the cau≈øe of ≈øuch ≈øeizure in ≈øuch Warrant, and no other Certificate is made by the Queen, and the Queen may certify the ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øion by word of mouth, and if the other party will ≈øay that the Queen hath not certified it, he ≈øhall be concluded by the commi≈ø≈øion which is under the great Seal; and diver≈øe
Pr≈øidents were ≈øhewed openly in Court to that effect. And all the matter afore≈øaid, was agreed by the Chancellor, Trea≈øurer, and the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices, and no certificate at all needs to be in the Ca≈øe, and then a ≈øuperfluous Certificate being nought, ≈øhall not hurt: for Nugation is ≈øurplu≈øage. Another matter was to con≈øider, what intere≈øt the Queen hath in the Lands of Fugitives by the common Law; And as to that they were all clear of opinion,Fugitives. that the Queen in ≈øuch ca≈øe as afore≈øaid may ≈øeize, and a≈ø≈øign her intere≈øt over: And that ≈øuch A≈ø≈øignees may grant Copy-holds, parcel of the Manor a≈ø≈øigned, which grants ≈øhall bind him who cometh in after, cum manus Domini regis amoventur; and al≈øo when the Statutes of 13 and 14 Eliz. come,Dy. 375 b. the Statutes do not amend the e≈øtate of the Queen, but the e≈øtate of the Queen doth continue as before, and all the E≈øtates under it. And there was ≈øhewed unto the Court divers Pre≈øidents of ≈øeizures in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, 18 E 2. Edmond de Wood≈øtock, Earl of Kent, went beyond Sea without Licence of the King, and he went with Robert de Mortimer, and the King did certifie the ≈øame into the Chancery, reciting that he had ≈øent his Privy Seal, &c. but that the ≈øaid Edmond (≈øpretis mandatis no≈øtris redire recu≈øavit) upon which i≈ø≈øued a commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øeize, &c. And it was holden that the Queen having ≈øei≈øed hy force of the common Law, and making a grant of a Copy-hold out of it, now when the Statutes of 13 & 14 Eliz. are made, ≈øhe hath not any e≈øtate thereby, for ≈øhe had ≈øuch intere≈øt before, and this new ≈øei≈øure after the Statutes works nothing, and nothing accrues to her thereby, whereof ≈øhe can make a ≈øei≈øure: For ≈øhe hath departed with the whole before, See 23 Eliz. Dyer 376. And note, that the grant of the Queen in the ca≈øe at Bar was, quamdiu in manibus no≈øtris fore contigerit. And afterwards Iudgment was given, that judicium praedictum in omnibus affirmetur.

div.head: XIII. Sutton, and Dow≈øes Ca≈øe. Ter. Mich. 25 & 26 Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p:
SUtton, Vicar of Long≈øtoke, Libelled again≈øt Dow≈øe in the ≈øpiritual Court,Tithes. and ≈øhewed in his Libel, that upon the Erection and Endowment of his Vicaridge, four quarters of Corn were a≈ø≈øigned to the Vicar out of the Granary of the Prior of B. of the Tithes of the Par≈øon of Long≈øtoke, and that the Par≈øon or Fermor of the ≈øaid Rectory of Long≈øtoke, had always paid the ≈øaid four Quarters of Corn to the ≈øaid Vicar and all his Predece≈ø≈øors, and alledged further, that the Lord Sands was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Rectory, and lea≈øed the Barn and Tithe-Corn parcel of the ≈øaid Rectory, to the ≈øaid Dow≈øe, his Wife and Son, Habendum to Dow≈øe for Term of his life, the Remainder to the Wife for Term of her life, the Remainder to the Son for life: And ≈øhewed further, that the ≈øaid Dow≈øe had covenanted with the ≈øaid Lord Sands, to render the ≈øaid four Quarters of Wheat to the Vicar and his Succe≈ø≈øors, upon which Dow≈øe procured a Prohibition, and Sutton prayed a Con≈øultation, and it was moved in ≈øtay of the Con≈øultation that the Vicar had Libelled upon a Covenant wherein Dow≈øe is taxed to pay the ≈øaid Corn, and that is a lay Title, and determinable by the Law of the Land, and not in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court: But as to that the opinion of the Court was, that the Libel is not grounded upon the covenant, as the ≈øole Title to the ≈øaid Corn again≈øt Dow≈øe, but upon the Endowment of the Vicaridge, and the Lea≈øe by which Dow≈øe is become Fermor of the Rectory. Another matter was moved, becau≈øe that upon the Libel it appeareth, that the Lea≈øe afore≈øaid made by the Lord Sands was made to Dow≈øe his Wife, and his Son, joyntly, in the Premi≈ø≈øes, Habendum ut ≈øupra, in which ca≈øe it was objected, that Dow≈øe his Wife, and his Son, are all three Fermors of the ≈øaid Barn and Tithes joyntly in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, again≈øt all whom Sutton
ought to have Libelled, &c. and not again≈øt Dow≈øe only, for the Habendum hath not ≈øevered their e≈øtates which were joynt before,Co. 1 Iu≈øt. 783 l. qund tota curia negavit, for the Habendum hath ≈øevered the joynt e≈øtates limited by the Premi≈ø≈øes, and hath di≈øtingui≈øhed it into Remainders, but if the Habendum had been Habendum ≈øucce≈ø≈øive, the e≈øtate had remained joynt: Another matter was moved, becau≈øe it appeareth upon the Libel, that the Par≈øon, or Fermor of the ≈øaid Rectory ought to pay to the Vicar the ≈øaid Corn, and al≈øo it appeareth upon the matter that Dow≈øe is not Par≈øon, nor Fermor of the ≈øaid Rectory, for the Lord Sands had lea≈øed to Dow≈øe and his Son, only the Barn and the Tith-Corn parcel of the ≈øaid Rectory; ≈øo as Dow≈øe is Fermor but of parcel of the Rectory, and the re≈øidue of the Rectory doth remain in the Lord Sands, in which the ≈øaid Sut. ought to have Libelled again≈øt the Lord Sands, and Dow≈øe, and not again≈øt Dow≈øe only; And for that cau≈øe the Con≈øultation was denyed. And in this ca≈øe it was further agreed by the Court, that if upon a Libel in the ≈øpiritual Court, the Defendant makes a ≈øurmi≈øe in Banco to have a Prohibition, if ≈øuch ≈øurmi≈øe be in≈øufficient, the other party needeth not to demur upon it, and to have it entred upon Record, but as amicus Curiae, he ≈øhall ≈øhew the ≈øame to the Court, and the Court ≈øhall di≈øcharge him.

div.head: XIV. Pun≈øany, and Leaders Ca≈øe. Mich. 25 & 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: OSmond Pun≈øany brought an Action upon the ca≈øe again≈øt Leader, and declared,Pre≈øcription of Foldage. that one Bedingfield was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. and that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath in the ≈øaid Manor time out of mind have had Libertatem Faldagij & cur≈øum Ovium, in the Town of D. & pro meliori pa≈øturatione omnium Ovium ≈øuorum, the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Town having any Lands within the ≈øaid Town, every ≈øecond year left their Lands to lye fre≈øh and untilled, and pre≈øcribed further, that the Tenants of the Lands within the ≈øaid Town might erect Herdals in in their Lands, with the Licence of the Lord of the ≈øaid Manor, and not otherwi≈øe: and further declared, that the ≈øaid Bedingfield had let to him the ≈øaid Manor, and that the Defendant had erected Herdals upon his Lands without Licence, ≈øo as the profit of his Foldage is impaired by it: And all this matter was found by Verdict: And it was objected in ≈øtay of Iudgment, that the pre≈øcription is not good, for it is again≈øt Law and common right to abridge the Subject of the profits of his Lands: But the whole Court was clear of opinion, that the pre≈øcription is good enough, as 15 E 2. Pre≈øcription 51. Pre≈øcription to have common appendant in other Land afte that the Hay is cut, and v E. 1. Pre≈øcription, 55. A. ≈øei≈øed of Lands may Plow it and Sow it, and cut and carry away the Corn, and afterwards when the Corn is carried, B. by pre≈øcription may have the ≈øaid Land as his ≈øeveral, and the other who ≈øowed it cannot meddle with that land, but to plow and ≈øow it in ≈øea≈øon, &c. And the Cattel cannot eat and pa≈øture in the Land when they come to plow or ≈øow it, or to carry it away, nor have any profit but the Corn, and yet the Free-hold of the Land is in ≈øuch per≈øon, &c. and that was holden a good Pre≈øcription, and a difference was taken by the Court, where one doth pre≈øcribe to take away the whole intere≈øt of the Owner of the Land, and where a particular profit is re≈øtrained: And here this pre≈øcription doth not extend but to re≈øtrain the Ter-tenant to erect Herdals, which is a rea≈øonable pre≈øcription, See 1 H 7 24. The Lord of the Town doth pre≈øcribe to have free Foldage of the Bea≈øts of his Tenants in D. and ≈øee there, that libera Falda is not any other, but to hav the Bea≈øts of the Tenants to manure the lands of the Lord, &c. And afterwards Pun≈øany the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover.

div.head: XVI. Mich. 25 & 26 Eliz. at Serjeants Inn.
div.p:
IN the Dutchy Chamber, the ca≈øe was, that King E 6. lea≈øed for years certain lands parcel of his Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, rendring rent, with clau≈øe of re-entry, and that a lea≈øe was made to one Bunny; It was found by Office that the Rent was arrear, and by another Office, that the Servant of the ≈øaid Le≈ø≈øee, had tendred the rent in his ab≈øence, and by the commandment of his Ma≈øter, and that afterwards one I. S. Receiver General of the Dutchy, received the ≈øaid Rent, and had accounted for it, and upon his account it was allowed; And this matter was opened at Serjeants Inn in Fleet-≈øtreet, before Wray, Ander≈øon, Manwood, Clench, Rhodes, Plowden, and Stanhop; and it was argued by Shuttleworth, that in this ca≈øe of rent re≈øerved upon a Lea≈øe for years, made by the King of Dutchy-Land,The King not bound to demand Rent. the King is not bound to demand it, but he may for default of payment of it, re-enter without demand, and that the Le≈ø≈øee is tied to tender it at his peril, as well as if the Queen had been ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid land in the right of her Crown; and as to that payment, the Statute of 1 H 4. is to be con≈øidered, by which it is enacted, that the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Dutchy Taliter, & tali modo, & per tales officiarios & mini≈øtros in omnibus remaneant, deducantur, & gubernentur ≈øicut remanere, deduci, & gubernari debui≈ø≈øent, ≈øi ad culmen Regis Dignitatis a≈ø≈øumpti non fui≈ø≈øemus, and the≈øe words ought to be intended of things which concern the Lands them≈øelves; but this Act of demand is a per≈øonal thing, and concerns the per≈øon of the King, and toucheth the Maje≈øty, and dignity of the King, and in all ca≈øes of the Dutchy the per≈øon of the King ≈øhall hold his priviledge, notwith≈øtanding that the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land be carried in the cour≈øe of a private per≈øon: And therefore if the Queen will alien Lands parcel of her Dutchy, ≈øhe ought to make Livery, for now ≈øhe meddles with the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion it ≈øelf: but if the Queen will ≈øue for parcel of her Dutchy, non omittas ≈øhall be in the Writ, for ≈øhe cannot ≈øue but as Queen, and the Queen hath ≈øuch Prerogative, that none ≈øhall execute her Writs at her own ≈øute, but the Officer of the Crown, 21 E 4. 60. for Livery, if it be not Land within the County Palatine, and for the re≈øidue, See 10 H. 4. 7. 3. Eliz. 216, 217. Plowden, Le≈ø≈øee for years of Lands of the Dutchy, ≈øhall have aid of the King before I≈ø≈øue joyned, &c. And if the King make a Feoffment of Lands of his Dutchy out of the County Palatine, to hold of him in Capite, the Feoffee ≈øhall hold it ≈øo, and a Feoffment of ≈øuch Lands upon condition that the Feoffee ≈øhall not alien is a good condition, and Lap≈øes ≈øhall not bind the Queen in ca≈øe of an Advow≈øon which the Queen hath in the right of the Dutchy, and if the Villain of the Queen in the right of the Dutchy purcha≈øeth Lands in Fee, and aliens, yet the Queen ≈øhall ≈øei≈øe, and that hath been adjudged in the Exchequer Chamber; and if the Queen make a Lea≈øe of ≈øuch Land, and afterwards makes another Lea≈øe of the ≈øame Land without recital of the fir≈øt Lea≈øe, it hath been adjudged that the ≈øecond Lea≈øe is void. It was argued contrary by Beamount the younger, that this condition which goeth to the realty, to reduce the Land again, ought to be ordered and governed by the Queen, as it ought to be by a Subject; and therefore, if the Queen will take advantage of this condition, ≈øhe ought to make a Letter of Attorney under the Dutchy Seal, to her own Officer, authorizing him thereby to make demand of the ≈øaid Rent, &c. And by Shuttleworth here be two Offices, the one contrary to the other, the be≈øt ≈øhall be taken for the Queen, 14 E 4. 5. in Skreens Ca≈øe in the end of it: And if the Rent of the Kings Farmor be behind, now although that after the Receivor of the Dutchy doth receive it, yet the ≈øame doth not purge the forfeiture, as if the Bayliffs of a Manor receive rent of a new Feoffee, the ≈øame will not change the Avowry of the
Lord without notice given to him, 41 E 3. 26. And if a Copy-hold e≈øcheat, the Steward without a ≈øpecial Warrant cannot grant it over de novo.

div.head: XVI. Rearsbie and Rearsbies Ca≈øe Intrat. Trinit. 25 Eliz. rot. 746. Mich. 25 and 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: REplevin by W. Rearsbie again≈øt A. Rearsbie, and L. Rearsbie, who avow the di≈øtre≈øs, becau≈øe that one W. Vava≈øour was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Deniby, whereof the place where, &c. is parcel in his Deme≈øne as of Fee, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed gave the ≈øaid Manor to one L. Rearsbie Father of the Plaintiff, and of the Avowants and Jane his Wife, and to the Heirs of Lyonel, who by his Will devi≈øed unto A. Rearsbie a Rent of four pounds out of the ≈øaid Manor, with clau≈øe of di≈øtre≈øs, for his childs part, to be yearly paid, Lyonel the Father died 3 Eliz. and afterwards, 22 Eliz. Jane died, and for the arrearages of the ≈øaid Rent encurred mean between the death of Loynel and Jane his Wife, &c. upon which Avowry the Plaintiff did demurr in Law, for the Rent doth not begin in effect, but after the death of the Wife of the Devi≈øor,Con≈øtruction of Devi≈øe. for ≈øuch con≈øtruction ought be made of the Devi≈øe, as not to charge the Inheritance with the whole arrearages, &c. and it was argued to the contrary, that the Defendant might well avow the di≈øtre≈øs for the≈øe arrearages; for if he in the Rever≈øion upon a Lea≈øe for life grant a Rent charge after the death of the Grantor, the Grantee ≈øhall di≈øtrein for all the arrearages encurred after the grant, etiam, during the life of the Grantor,Di≈øtre≈øs. quod Curia conce≈ø≈øit: and it was ≈øaid by the Council of the Avowant, that the Ca≈øe at Bar is a ≈øtronger Ca≈øe, for this Rent, as it appeareth by the words of the Devi≈øe, was devi≈øed to the Avowant for his livelihood, and for his childs part, which words imply a pre≈øent advancement, and the≈øe words yearly to be paid are ≈øtrong & pregnant to that intent. It was adjourned.

div.head: XVII. Hill. 25 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Earl of Northumberland brought debt upon arrearages of Accompt, the Defendant ≈øhewed that before the Accompt,Account. the Plaintiff of his own wrong did impri≈øon the Defendant, and a≈ø≈øigned Auditors to him being in pri≈øon, and ≈øo the Accompt was made by dure≈øs of impri≈øonment: And the ≈øame was holden a good Plea by all the Iu≈øtices of both the Benches. And Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: XVIII. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. Forman and Bohans Ca≈øe.
div.p:
REplevin by Forman again≈øt Bohan, Replevin. the Defendant avowed for a Rent charge, and ≈øhewed, that one Wingfield was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of We≈øham, whereof the place where, was parcel: And 33 H 6. made a Feoffment in Fee of the place where, &c. to one Orlow, rendring Rent and Sute at the Court of the ≈øaid Manor, and that the ≈øaid Wingfield was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Rent and Sute accordingly, and died thereof ≈øei≈øed, and that the ≈øame de≈øcended to Anthony Wingfield as Son and Heir,1 Cro. 39. &c. who was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Rent as parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, and that the ≈øaid Anthony, ≈øo ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor and Rent, bargained and ≈øold the ≈øaid Manor and Rent, 26 H 8. to Nicholas Bohan Father of the Avowant, by the≈øe words; Manerium de We≈øham, & omnes omnimodos redditus, reputed, deemed, or adjudged part or parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, who entred, and died ≈øei≈øed, and the ≈øame de≈øcended to the now Avowant, as Son and
Heir, &c. and averred, that the ≈øaid Rent at the time of the bargain and ≈øale afore≈øaid, & diu ante, was reputed parcel of the Manor afore≈øaid: Vpon which Avowry, the Plaintiff did demur in Law, and it was argued by Gawdy Serjeant for the Plaintiff, and he took an Exception to the Avowry, becau≈øe the Avowant ≈øheweth, that Anthony Wingfield 26. H 8. bargained and ≈øold the ≈øaid Manor to Bohan, Virtute Quar. bargaine & venditionis, & vigor. cuju≈ødam Actus Parliamenti 27 H 8. de u≈øibus, &c. the ≈øaid Bohan was ≈øei≈øed, &c. where he ought to have ≈øaid; by force of which bargain and ≈øale the ≈øaid Anthony Wingfield was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor afore≈øaid, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Bohan, and that afterwards by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Statute of 27 H 8. the ≈øaid Anthony then ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid Bohan was ≈øei≈øed in his Deme≈øne as of Fee: For it might be for any thing appearing in the Avowry, that before the ≈øaid Statute of 27 H 8. Anthony Wingfield had made a conveyance upon con≈øideration to him who had not notice of the u≈øe, ≈øo as the u≈øe being ≈øu≈øpended, when the Statute came, it could not be executed, for there was not any ≈øei≈øin to the u≈øe, and to that purpo≈øe he cited the Ca≈øe of 7 H 7. 3. where a gift of Trees by Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe is pleaded, without alledging that the Feoffors were ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of the Donor at the time of the gift: To that Exception it was an≈øwered by Popham Attorney General,Averment. That there is a difference betwixt the Ca≈øe at Bar, and the Ca≈øe of 7 H 7. for where a man entitles him≈øelf by Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, he ought to maintain ≈øuch title by every nece≈ø≈øary Circum≈øtance, which the Law without expre≈ø≈øing will not intend; but where a man alledgeth a matter, which is but a conveyance, there needs no e≈øpecial recital; as if a man will pretend the grant of a Rever≈øion, and that the le≈ø≈øee for years did attorn, he needs not to ≈øhew, that at the time of the Attornment the Grantor was ≈øei≈øed,1 Cro. 746. ‚Ä¢ 4 ‚Ä¢ . &c. and he cited the Ca≈øe of 10 E. 4. 18. In Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Plaintiff by way of Replication made to him a title, that A. was ≈øei≈øed and lea≈øed to him at Will, by force of which the Plaintiff was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, until the Defendant did the Tre≈øpa≈øs, and Exception was taken to it, that the Plaintiff in his Replication had not averred, that A. was alive at the time of Tre≈øpa≈øs, and it was not allowed, for the ≈øub≈øequent words (by force of which the Plaintiff was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed until the Defendant did the Tre≈øpa≈øs) do amount unto ≈øo much, for the Plaintiff could not be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by force of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe at Will if A. were not alive. So here, Bohan could not be here ≈øei≈øed by force of the ≈øaid Statute, if the ≈øei≈øin of the u≈øe which was rai≈øed by the bargain and ≈øale had not continued until the coming of the ≈øaid Statute: As to the matter in Law, Gawdy conceived that the averment in the perclo≈øe of the Avowry is contrary to the matter of the Avowry, for the creation of the Rent ≈øet forth in the Avowry proves, that the Rent is not parcel of the Manor, but a Rent in gro≈øs, and then the general averment, that the Rent is parcel of the Manor, without ≈øhewing how, again≈øt the ≈øpecial matter of the Avowry, is not receivable.Reputation. And al≈øo nothing can be by reputation parcel of a Manor which in rei veritate cannot be parcel of a Mannor, but a Rent charge cannot be in rei veritate parcel of a Manor, ergo, nor by reputation: Popham contrary; That the averment is not contrary to the matter of the Avowry, for the matter di≈øclo≈øed in the Avowry proves, that it is not rei veriate parcel of the Manor, but it doth not exclude Reputation, and the Averment doth not extend ad veritatem facti, which is ≈øet forth in the Avowry, but only to reputation, and ≈øo both ≈øtand together well enough:Rent charge parcel of a Manno ‚Ä¢
And that a Rent charge may be parcel of a Manor, ≈øee 22 E 3. 13. 31. E 3. 23. in the Lord Tiptofts Ca≈øe, where it is ruled, that title made to a Rent charge as parcel of a Manor is a good title, and the A≈ø≈øize awarded upon it, and in our Ca≈øe the Reputation is enforced by the ≈øute at the Court, which was al≈øo re≈øerved upon the ≈øaid Feoffment together with the ≈øaid Rent, ≈øo as the intent of the parties to the Feoffment was, that this Rent ≈øo re≈øerved and accompanyed with the ≈øaid
≈øute ≈øhall be e≈øteemed a Rent ≈øervice, and ≈øo parcel of the Manor; and as to the continuance of Reputation it ≈øufficeth, if at the time of the bargain and ≈øale afore≈øaid, which was 26 H 8. it was by many reputed parcel of the Manor, and he cited the Ca≈øe of the Marque≈øs of Winche≈øter: The King gave to his Ance≈øtor the Manor of Dale and all lands then antea reputed parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, and in a Bill of Intru≈øion again≈øt the ≈øaid Marque≈øs he pleaded the grant with averment, that the Land then antea reputed parcel Manerii praedict. And becau≈øe he did not ≈øhew certainly at what time the Land was reputed parcel of the Manor, Iudgment was given for the Queen; for it might be for any thing in his Plea, that the ≈øaid Land was reputed parcel of the ≈øaid Manor before time of memory, which Reputation would not ≈øerve: but ≈øuch Reputation ought to be within time of memory and under≈øtanding: He cited al≈øo the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Leice≈øter. King Edward the ≈øixth ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Clibery, of which a Wood was parcel, granted the ≈øaid Wood in Fee, which afterwards e≈øcheated to the King for Trea≈øon; Queen Mary granted the ≈øaid Wood to another in Fee, who granted it to the now Queen, who granted the ≈øaid Manor & omnes bo≈øcos modo vel ante hac cognit. vel reputat. ut pars, membr. vel parcel. Maner. praedict. to the Earl of Leice≈øter, and it was re≈øolved in the Exchequer, that by that grant the ≈øaid Wood did pa≈øs to the Earl, and Iudgment was given again≈øt the Queen,Dy. 362 ‚Ä¢ . for it was part of the Manor in the time of E 6. at which time (ant' hac) without the word (unquam) ≈øhall be extended ad quoddamcunque tempus praeteritum. And Reputation needs not ≈øo ancient a Pedigree for to e≈øtabli≈øh it; for general acceptance will produce reputation: As the hou≈øe of the Lord Trea≈øurer now called Tibould was of late a private Manor, but now hath a new name by which it is known, and that within the≈øe twenty years, which is not ≈øo long a time as we have alleged for our Reputation, and would pa≈øs in a conveyance by ≈øuch name; ≈øo None-≈øuch. But as to Reputation, I conceive that Reputation is not what this or what that man thinketh,Reputation. quid. but that which many men have ≈øaid or thought, who have more rea≈øon to know it; & quaenam e≈øt inter illos reputatio, There was a Ca≈øe ruled in the Exchequer 13 Eliz. in a Bill of intru≈øion; the Ca≈øe was, that King Hen. 6. was ≈øei≈øed of a Manor, to which a Neif was regardant, who purcha≈øed Lands, which the King ≈øei≈øed, and let by Copy as parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, and ≈øo continued until the time of E 6. who granted the ≈øame to Allice Hardwick, and all Lands, Tenements, reputed parcel of the ≈øaid Manor; And it was adjudged, that the ≈øaid Land ≈øo purcha≈øed by the ≈øaid Neif, and demi≈øed by Copy, did pa≈øs by the ≈øaid grant to Hardwick. And afterwards, the ≈øame Term, the Iu≈øtices, without any ≈øolemn Argument, ≈øhewed their opinions in the principal Ca≈øe, viz. That this Rent did not pa≈øs by the bargain and ≈øale made as above, by Anthony Wingfield, to Bohan father of the Avowant; for here in the premi≈ø≈øes of the Avowry is not any matter ≈øet forth importing Reputation, or by which it may appear that the Rent in que≈øtion was ever reputed parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, but rather to the contrary; and the bare averment of Reputation in the conclu≈øion of the Avowry is not ≈øufficient to induce Reputation. But if the Avowant had ≈øet forth in his Avowry any ≈øpecial matter to induce the Court to conceive a Reputation upon the matter of the Avowry, as to ≈øhew that the Bayliffs of the ≈øaid Manor had always received the ≈øaid Rent as parcel of ≈øaid Manor, and as Bayliffs of the ≈øaid Manor had accounted for it, as parcel of the Manor, and that the Le≈ø≈øees of the ≈øaid Manor had enjoyed the ≈øaid Rent as parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, the ≈øame had been good matter to induce a Reputation, & to have incorporated the ≈øaid Rent with the ≈øaid Manor: and ≈øo judgment was given again≈øt the Avowant; and
of ≈øuch opinion (as was affirmed by Wray) was Ander≈øon, chief Iu≈øtice of the Common Pleas, and Manwood, chief Baron of the Exchequer.

div.head: XIX. Cham and Dovers Ca≈øe. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p: Ejectione firmae.IN an Ejectione firmae, the Ca≈øe was, that one Michel was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. within which diver≈øe parcels of Land, part of the ≈øaid Manor, where cu≈øtomary Tenements demi≈øed and demi≈øable by copy, &c. according to the Cu≈øtom of the ≈øaid Manor for one, two or three lives, within which Manor there was a Cu≈øtom, ≈øcil. that the Lord of the Manor, for the time being, might grant Copy-hold e≈øtates for life in Rever≈øion; The Lord granted ≈øuch Lands for life by copy in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, took a wife, and granted the ≈øame Copy-hold to a ≈øtranger in Rever≈øion for life, and died, the Copy-holder in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion died, the Land demi≈øed by copy is (inter alia) a≈ø≈øigned to the Wife for her Dower, who had Iudgment to recover in a Writ of Dower, who entred and made a Lea≈øe thereof to the Defendant, who entred, again≈øt whom, the Le≈ø≈øee of the Copy-holder brought Ejectione firmae, Cu≈øtom ad pa≈øturandum, non ad colendum. and all this matter was found by Verdict, and further found, that every Copy-holder of the ≈øaid Manor, might Lea≈øe his Copy-hold for a year, ad pa≈øturandum, ≈øed non ad colendum, and that the Lea≈øe made to the Plaintiff was for a year, ad pa≈øturandum. 1. Cro. 469. Wells ver≈øus Partridge. Po≈øt 100. Popham Attorny General, of Council with the Defendant, took exception to the Declaration, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had declared a Lea≈øe at the common Law, and the Iury have found a Lea≈øe by the cu≈øtom, which cannot ≈øtand together: And ≈øuch a Verdict doth not maintain the Declaration, as if the Plaintiff had declared upon a Lea≈øe for years of Lands, and the Iury found a devi≈øe for years, &c. but the exception was di≈øallowed by the Court. As to the matter in Law he argued, that the Tenant in Dower ≈øhould hold the Land di≈øcharged of the Copy-hold for her life, and he put this ca≈øe, If the Lord of ≈øuch a Manor taketh a Wife, a Copy-holder for life dieth, the Lord grants a Rent-charge out of the cu≈øtomary land, and afterwards grants the ≈øaid land by copy for life, & dieth, the wife ≈øhall hold the land di≈øcharged of the Rent, but the Copy-holder ≈øhall be charged; and he put a difference where the Lord grants ≈øuch Copy-hold in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and where in Rever≈øion, for in the fir≈øt ca≈øe the Wife ≈øhall hold charged, but contrary in the la≈øt: And he cited the Ca≈øe of one Slowman, who being Lord of a Manor (ut ≈øupra) by his Will devi≈øed, that his Executors ≈øhould grant e≈øtates by Copy,2. Len 109. and died having a Wife, the Executors make e≈øtates accordingly,Dower di≈øcharged of a grant of Copy-hold. the Wife in ca≈øe of Dower ≈øhall avoid them: Plowden contr. the Lord of ≈øuch a Mannor is bound by recogni≈øance, and afterwards a Copy-holder for life of the ≈øaid Mannor dieth, the Lord grants his Copy-hold, de novo, the ≈øaid new Grantee ≈øhall hold his Copy-hold di≈øcharged of the Recogni≈øance, which Gawdy Iu≈øtice granted; and by Wray, if the Lord of ≈øuch a Manor grants a Copy-hold for three lives, & takes a Wife, the three lives end, the Lord enters and keeps the lands for a time, and afterwards grants them over again by copy, and dieth, the copy-holder ≈øhall hold the Land di≈øcharged of the Dower, and this is a clear ca≈øe, for the copy-holder is in by the cu≈øtom which is paramount the title of Dower and the Sei≈øin of the Husband; and by him in the ca≈øe of the Earl of Northumberland, 17 Eliz. Dyer 344. That the grant of a copy-hold in Rever≈øion by the Earl of Northumberland, doth not make ≈øuch an impediment as was intended in the condition there, for it is by the cu≈øtom, and not by the act of the party; And afterwards, the ≈øame Term Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, that he and his Le≈ø≈øor ≈øhould hold the lands di≈øcharged of the Dower.

div.head: XX. Fringe and Lewes Ca≈øe. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.

XXI. Sir John Smith, and Peazes Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
SIr John Smith brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Peaze, who pleaded, that the Bond was upon condition to perform covenants contained in an Indenture, and ≈øhewed what, and that he had performed them, the Plantiff a≈ø≈øigned the breach of one covenant, that where the Plaintiff had lea≈øed to the Defendant for years, certain me≈ø≈øuages by the ≈øame Indenture, the Defendant by the ≈øame Indenture, did covenant to repair all the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuages,Covenant alia quam quae appunctuatae forent divelli per ≈øcript, dicti Johannis Smith, and ≈øhewed further, that the Defendant had not repaired the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuages to him demi≈øed as afore≈øaid, and averred that the ≈øaid hou≈øe in which the breach of the covenant is a≈ø≈øigned, non fuit durante termino praedicto appunctuata divelli, and upon that matter of reparation they were at I≈ø≈øue, and found for the Plaintiff: It was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, that the Averment in the Replication was not ≈øufficient, for the Lea≈øe was made in November to begin the Michael. after,Averment. and it might be that the Me≈ø≈øuage, in the not repairing of which the breach of the covenant is a≈ø≈øigned, was appointed to be pulled down, ≈øcil. divelli, before the Term for years began, and then the Defendant is not bound to repair it, and then the breach of the covenant is not well a≈ø≈øigned, and ≈øo the Averment
doth not an≈øwer the exception, and becau≈øe this clau≈øe (alia quam) is in the body of the Covenant, it ought to be ≈øatisfied by him who pleads it, ≈øcil. by him who a≈ø≈øigns the breach in the Covenant, in which the exception is contained; As by the Lord Dyer in his argument, in the argument of Stowels Ca≈øe, reported by Plowden 376. Where a man pleaded the Feoffment of Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, he ought to plead, that Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, at the time of the Feoffment was of full age, ≈øanae memoriae, &c. for that is within the purview, contr. upon the Statute of 4 H. 7. in pleading of a Fine, for that is in a clau≈øe by it ≈øelf, which conceit of Plowden, the Lord Wray denyed to be Law, for he ≈øaid, he that pleads the Feoffment of Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, or a Fine according to the Statute of 4 H. 7. ≈øhall not be driven to ≈øhew that the Feoffor, or Conu≈øor at the time of the Feoffment, or Fine levyed was of full age, &c. but he who comes in by ≈øuch Fine,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ 21, or Feoffment ≈øhall ≈øhew the ≈øame for his own advantage. And at la≈øt after many motions it was re≈øolved by all the Iu≈øtices,Averment ‚Ä¢ here ≈øuper
‚Ä¢ luous. that the Averment afore≈øaid was ≈øuperfluous & ex abundanti, for it had been ≈øufficient for the Plaintiff to have a≈ø≈øigned the breach of the Covenant in the not repairing the Me≈ø≈øuage without any Averment, de non appunctuando, and if the hou≈øe in the not repairing of which the breach of Covenant is a≈ø≈øigned, was appointed to be pulled down, the ≈øame ≈øhall come in on the defendants part to who≈øe advantage it trencheth, for ≈øuch appointment doth di≈øcharge the Covenant as to that: In the ≈øame plea, it was moved in ≈øtay of Iudgment that one Sharp, Solicitor of the ≈øaid Sir John in the ≈øaid ≈øuit, had given eight ≈øhillings to the Iurors, mean betwixt the Charge and their Verdict, and that matter was te≈øtified by the oaths of two men, upon which the Court examined the ≈øaid Sharp, who upon his oath denied the matter, and al≈øo the Foreman of the Iury to whom the mony was ≈øuppo≈øed to be given, who upon his oath denied the ≈øame: And it was moved, if receipt of mony by any of the Iurors ≈øhould make the Verdict void; and by Wray it ≈øhall not, for it is but a Mi≈ødemeanor, which is puni≈øhable on the per≈øon of him who takes the mony: But Gawdy and Ayliff Iu≈øtices, the Verdict is void. See 24 E 3. 24. 14 H. 7. 1. 20 H. 7. 30. And for that cau≈øe the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head:
XXII. Cordall and Gibbons Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. Intr. Trin. 25. Eliz. Rot. 492. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Ejectione firmae, upon not guilty pleaded the Iury found the ≈øpecial matter, viz. that one Hierom Heydon was ≈øei≈øed of two Me≈ø≈øuages, whereof the Action is brought, and came to Cordall the Plaintiff, and prayed him to ≈øend him ten pounds; Cordall asked him, what a≈ø≈øureance he would give him for the re-payment of it; he an≈øwered, that he would mortgage to him the ≈øaid two Me≈ø≈øuages, whereupon Cordall lent him the mony, and afterwards they both went to the ≈øaid two Hou≈øes, and being before the doors, of them, Heydon called, Tenants at will of the Hou≈øes, and ≈øaid to them, Sirs, I have borrowed of this Cordall ten pounds upon the≈øe Hou≈øes, and if I pay this mony at Michaelmas next, I mu≈øt have my Hou≈øes again, and if not, then I bargain and ≈øell the≈øe Hou≈øes to Cordall; and my Will is, that you become his Tenants, after which Heydon put the ≈øaid Cordall into the Hou≈øes, and ≈øeeing him in the Hou≈øes, he put in the Keys of the ≈øaid Cordall, by the Windows, &c. And it was adjudged by the whole Court, that this conveyance, by word of mouth, was good enough to pa≈øs the e≈øtate, ut ≈øupra, and the words of bargain and ≈øale in this Ca≈øe, are as ≈øtrong, as of gift and grant, See 38 E 3. 11. 43 E 3. 11. 27 E 3. 62. 28 E 3. 11.

div.head:
XXIII. Richards and Bartlets Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. Intr. Mich. 25 & 26 Eliz. Rot. 72. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: DOrothy Richards Executrix of A. her former Husband,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon a promi≈øe again≈øt Humfrey Bartlet, and declared, that in con≈øideration of two weighs of Corn delivered by the Te≈øtator to the Defendant, he did promi≈øe to pay to the Plaintiff ten pounds, to which the Defendant ≈øaid, that after the A≈ø≈øump≈øit the Plaintiff in con≈øideration, that the ≈øaid two weighs were drowned by Tempe≈øt, and in con≈øideration that the Defendant would pay to the Plaintiff for every twenty ≈øhillings of the ≈øaid ten pounds three ≈øhillings four pence, ≈øcil. in toto thirty three ≈øhillings four pence, did di≈øcharge the ≈øaid Defendant of the ≈øaid promi≈øe, and averred further, that he hath been always ready to pay the ≈øaid ≈øum newly agreed, upon which there was a demurrer. And the opinion of the whole Court was clearly with the Plaintiff, fir≈øt becau≈øe that here his not any con≈øideration ≈øet forth in the Bar, by rea≈øon whereof the Plaintiff ≈øhould di≈øcharge the defendant of this matter, for no profit but damage comes to the Plaintiff by this new agreement, and the Defendant is not put to any labour or charge by it, therefore here is not any agreement to bind the Plaintiff, See 19 H. 6. Accord, 1. 9 E. 4. 13. 12 H. 7. 15. See al≈øo Onlies Ca≈øe, 19 Eliz. Dyer, then admitting, that the agreement had been ≈øufficient, yet becau≈øe, it is not executed, it is not any Bar: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: XXIV. Lendall, and Pinfolds Ca≈øe. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking of his Clo≈øe, by Lendal again≈øt Pinfold, Tre≈øpa≈øs. the Ca≈øe was, that two brake the Clo≈øe and entred, and did the Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Owner of the land brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt one of them, and had Iudgment, and execution accordingly, and afterwards brought Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt the other,Bar. 1 Cro. 667. 2 Cro. 73. 1 Cro. 30. 31. and declared upon the ≈øame Tre≈øpa≈øs: And by Ayliff Iu≈øtice, it is a good Bar, and he likened it to the ca≈øe of one Cobham, who brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs of A≈ø≈øault and Battery, and recovered and had execution, and afterwards brought an Appeal of Mayhem again≈øt the ≈øame per≈øon upon the ≈øame matter, the ≈øaid Recovery and execution is a good Bar, &c. ≈øo here as to the breaking of the clo≈øe, but not as to the Entry: But by Wray, it is a good Bar for the whole, and he likened it to the ca≈øe of Littleton, Pl. 376. A Relea≈øe to one of the Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øers, ≈øhall di≈øcharge both. Gawdy agreed in opinion with Ayliff.

div.head: XXV. Kempe, and Hollingbrooks Ca≈øe. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae for Tythes, the ca≈øe was upon the Statute of 18. Eliz. Cap. 6. By which it is enacted, that no Ma≈øters,Tithea. and Fellows of any Colledge in Cambridge, or Oxford ≈øhall make any Lea≈øe for life or years of any Farm, or of any their Lands, Tenements, or other Hereditaments to the which any Tythes, arable Land, Meadow, or Pa≈øture doth, or ≈øhall appertain, unle≈øs the third part at lea≈øt of the accient Rent be re≈øerved, and payed in Corn for the ≈øaid Colledges,
&c. otherwi≈øe every Lea≈øe without ≈øuch Re≈øervation ≈øhall be void, &c. If now, the ≈øaid Statute ≈øhall be con≈øtrued to extend to Lea≈øes of ≈øuch extraordinary pecuniary Tithes which are not natural or paid in kind. It was argued, that the ≈øaid Statute is to be intended of Tithes in kind, and al≈øo of ≈øuch things to be demi≈øed which render Corn, Hay, &c. But the Tithes in London which is the thing demi≈øed in our ca≈øe, doth not render any ≈øuch thing,Tithes in London. but only mony according to the decree made for payment of Tithes in London in the time of E. 6. And although the words of the Statute be (other Hereditaments) to the which any Tithes, &c. Yet the ≈øaid Statute doth extend to Tithes in gro≈øs, but they ought to be ≈øuch Tithes which are of ≈øuch nature as Tithe-corn, and Tith-hay: And Manwood chief Baron held clearly, that the Lea≈øe of the≈øe Tithes is good enough, notwith≈øtanding the defect by the ≈øpecial Re≈øervation which is limited and appointed by the Statute, and ≈øo by him, a Lea≈øe of a Hou≈øe, Rent, Mill, Ferry, &c. are out of the ≈øaid Statute: And as to the Tithes, notwith≈øtanding the words of the Statute are general, any Tithes; yet he conceived, the Statute ought to be intended of Tithes of common Right, and not of ≈øuch cu≈øtomary Tithes as tho≈øe of London are, and therefore, if all the Pari≈øhoners pre≈øcribe in modo Decimandi, ≈øcil. to pay a certain ≈øum of mony for all manner of Tithes, upon demi≈øe of ≈øuch a Rectory, ≈øuch ≈øpecial Re≈øervation is not nece≈ø≈øary, for the≈øe are Tithes again≈øt common Right, and no Tithes are within the purview of the ≈øaid Statute but tho≈øe which are annual, and therefore a Lea≈øe of Tithe-wood is out of the meaning of this Statute, for non renovantur in annum; and he ≈øaid that upon a Lea≈øe of the Tithes of Chery Trees, a rent ought to be re≈øerved according to the Statute, and the Farmer may bring his Cheries to the Market, and buy Corn. Shute Iu≈øtice contrary, for the words of the Statute are general. And note, that this Lea≈øe was of the Rectory of Saint Lawrence in the City of London. There was another matter moved in this ca≈øe, becau≈øe the lea≈øe whereof the Action is brought, was made by the name of Ma≈øter or Guardian, and the Fellows, whereas the true name of their Colledge is Ma≈øter and Fellows.Mi≈øno≈ømer. And it was argued by Atkin≈øon, that the ≈øame is not ≈øuch a Mi≈øno≈ømer which makes the Lea≈øe void, for (≈øive cu≈øtos) are words of ≈øurplu≈øage, v. 7 H. 6. 13. And al≈øo the ca≈øe of the Cooks, 20 Eliz. Plow. 531. The Corporation was by the name of Ma≈øters or Governors and Comonalty, my≈øterii coquorum, &c. And they made a conveyance by the name of Ma≈øters or Governors, and Comunalty, artis ≈øive My≈øterii, &c. the ≈øame is no ≈øuch Mi≈øno≈ømer as ≈øhall make void the conveyance, for Art and Mi≈øtery are both of one ≈øen≈øe.

div.head: XXVI. Harvey, and Harveys Ca≈øe. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Con≈øultation. CLare Harvey, one of the Daughters of Sir James Harvy Alderman of London Libelled in the Spiritual Court again≈øt Seba≈øtin Harvy, Son and Executor of the ≈øaid Sir James, for a Legacy bequeathed to her by her Father; Seba≈øtian did not appear, for which he was excommunicated and taken by a Writ of excommunicat. capiendo, and impri≈øoned; and afterwards he came into this Court, and ≈øurmi≈øed to the Court, That the ≈øaid Sir James in his life had given to the ≈øaid Seba≈øtian all his Goods and Chattells, and was al≈øo bound unto the ≈øaid Seba≈øtian in a Statute-≈øtaple of two thou≈øand pounds, whereupon he had prohibition, and now the Plaintiffs coun≈øel prayed a Con≈øultation, quatenus non agitur ad validitatem facti, aut Statuti. And Egerton Solicitor of Coun≈øel with the Plaintiff cited a Iudgment given in the like Ca≈øe betwixt Lodge and Luddington, where ≈øuch a ≈øpecial Con≈øultation was granted: But Wray put a difference betwixt the ≈øaid Ca≈øe and the Ca≈øe at Bar, for here in this
Ca≈øe is a gift by the Te≈øtator him≈øelf, but in the Ca≈øe cited, the gift was by the Executor; and al≈øo here is a Statute of two thou≈øand pounds, in which Ca≈øe the Obligations which could not pa≈øs by the deed, ≈øhalll be ≈øubject to the ≈øaid Statute.

div.head:
XXVII. The Duke of Northumberlands Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p: THe late Duke of Northumberland ≈øei≈øed of five Me≈ø≈øuages in the Pari≈øh of St. Sepulchres London, in the Tenure of W. Gardiner, Bargain and ≈øale. 3 Co. 9. by deed intented and enrolled for money bargained and ≈øold to I. L. all his Tenements ≈øituate in the Pari≈øh of St. Andrews in Holborn in the Tenure of W. Gardiner, to have to the ≈øaid I. L. for life, the remainder to K. his Daughter in Fee. Atkin≈øon, The bargain and ≈øale is void by rea≈øon of the Mi≈øno≈ømer of the Pari≈øh, notwith≈øtanding the truth of the Tenure, for by the grant and bargain and ≈øale of all his Tenements in the Pari≈øh of St. Andrews nothing pa≈ø≈øeth, and the truth of the Tenure ≈øub≈øequent ≈øhall not help it: And by Manwood chief Baron, the ≈øale is utterly void, for the fal≈øity doth preceed the truth and certainty: And it was argued, that I. L. entring by colour of the ≈øame bargain and ≈øale is a di≈ø≈øei≈øor; as the Ca≈øe is betwixt Croft and Howel, 20. Eliz. Com. 537. Yet if he was but Tenant at Will when he made the Lea≈øe for years, the ≈øame was a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin to the ≈øaid Duke; and then the Duke being di≈ø≈øei≈øed, he is attainted of trea≈øon, 10. Mariae.
