And now we are to ≈øee what things accrue to the Queen by the ≈øaid Attainder: and as to that it was ≈øaid, that at the Common Law a Right of Entry ≈øhould E≈øcheat, but not without office found thereof, no more than Lands in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: And by the Statute of 26 H. 8. it is enacted, that every per≈øon attainted of high trea≈øon, ≈øhall forfeit all his Lands and Tenements which he had of any e≈øtate of Inheritance, by which Statute a Bi≈øhop, Abbot or Tenant in tayl in ≈øuch Ca≈øe ≈øhall forfeit even without Office: But in the Statute of 33 H. 8. there is a ≈øaving to every other per≈øon all ≈øuch right, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øo as in that Ca≈øe by that Statute the King ≈øhall not be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion without Office, but ≈øhall have a right, but cannot enter before Office or after. And he is to have Sci. facias again≈øt him, who hath the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and he ≈øhall make his defence as well as he can; and the words of the ≈øaid Statute, That the King ≈øhall be in actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued to extend to an actual and ab≈øolute po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but ≈øuch a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, only which he had at the Common Law after Office found, ≈øo as the Statute doth not give to the King a larger po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion but an ea≈øier, without the circum≈øtance of an Office: And of that opinion was Manwood chief Baron, and Shute ≈øecond Baron: And then it was moved further by Cook, becau≈øe that the Quen by the Attainder hath but a Right, and the Queen makes the grant of the Me≈ø≈øuages them≈øelves, the ≈øame grant is void. And he granted that the Queen might grant a real Action, and a Right of Entry; but ≈øuch a grant ought to be conceived in ≈øpecial words, as to ≈øay, That the Duke of Northumberland was ≈øei≈øed of five Me≈ø≈øuages, and by ≈øuch a one di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and after the Duke was attainted, and ≈øo granted; for the Queen may grant ≈øuch a Right by rea≈øon of her Prerogative, and therefore the ≈øame ought to be granted by ≈øpecial words, as in the Ca≈øe of Mynes in the Commentaries, and according to that was the opinion of the Iu≈øtices in Cromers Ca≈øe, 8 Eliz. which Ca≈øe ≈øee reported by Coke in the Ca≈øe of the Marque≈øs of Winche≈øter.

div.head:
XXVIII. Dayrel and Thinns Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Error. EDward Dayrel brought a Writ of Error again≈øt Sir John Thinn upon a Iudgment had by the Defendant again≈øt the Plaintiffs Father of the Manor of Mexden: And Error was a≈ø≈øigned for want of warrant of Attorney. And the Plaintiff prayed one Certiorare to the chief Iu≈øtice of the Common Pleas, and another Certiorare to the Cu≈øtos Brevium, both which returned, non inveni aliquod warr. and now Sir John Thinn being dead, the Plaintiff brought another Writ of Error by Journeys accounts again≈øt John Thinn Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Sir John Thinn, 3 Cro. 91. 2 Cro. 13. 597. 396. 5 Co. Pag. 36. b. 446. who appeared and alledged Diminution, in hoc, that the Warrant of Attorney is not certified, and prayed another Certiorare unto the chief Iu≈øtice of the Bench, and another to the Cu≈øtos Brevium, and it was argued by Clark, that in this Ca≈øe Certiorare ought not to be granted, for a Certificate is in the nature of a tryal, which ≈øhall not be cro≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Action; but the parties to the Action, and their Heirs ≈øhall be bound by it, e≈øpecially when the matter is certified by one who is Iudge of the Record, and that Certiorare ≈øued at the prayer of the Plaintiff ≈øhall be as peremptory, as if it had been ≈øued at the prayer of the Defendant, for the Plaintiff may alledge Diminution as well as the Defendant, 7 E 4. 25. by Yelverton. And a man cannot have Certiorare of a thing which is contrary to the Record, which is certified, 11 E 4. 10 by Laicon: So Diminution cannot be alledged in this Warrant of Attorney, becau≈øe it hath been certified here, that no Warrant of Attorney is to be found, &c. 9 E 4. 32. by Billing; Egerton Sollicitor, contrary: For the Certiorare obtained at the ≈øute of the Plaintiff, ≈øhall not prevent the Defendant. And the cour≈øe of proceeding in a Writ of Error, when Error is a≈ø≈øigned out of the Record, and not of a thing within the Record, is ≈øuch: After Error a≈ø≈øigned, before that a Sci. fac. i≈ø≈øueth again≈øt the Defendant ad audiendum errores, the Plaintiff may pray a Certiorare to the Cu≈øtos Brevium, in who≈øe hands ≈øuch collateral thing remain, for the Plea Roll doth remain in the cu≈øtody of the chief Iu≈øtice, but the Original Writs, E≈ø≈øoins and Warrants of Attorney remain in the hands of the Cu≈øtos Brevium; and ≈øuch a Certiorare the Court may grant to the Plaintiff, without making the Defendant privy to it. And notwith≈øtanding that the Defendant hath pleaded, in nullo e≈øt erratum, and ≈øo hath affirmed the Record to be ≈øuch as is certified, yet the Court ex Officio, ≈øhall award a Certiorare to a≈øcertain them≈øelves if there be any ≈øuch Warrant of Attorney or not: which ≈øee 9 E 4.Certiorare. 32. by Billing, and therefore the Certiorare being awarded ex Officio, ≈øhall not prejudice the Defendant; and to this purpo≈øe he cited the Ca≈øe betwixt the Lord Norris and Braybrook in a Writ of Error, where the Lord Norris being Plaintiff prayed a Certiorare to the Cu≈øtos Brevium, to certifie an Original Writ, upon which a common Recovery was had, and had it, and the Cu≈øtos Brevium certified, that there was no Original; and afterwards the Defendant prayed another Certiorare, and had it: and ≈øo in our Ca≈øe here e≈øpecially, becau≈øe the Defendant was not party to the Record, nor hath day in Court, at the time that the ≈øaid Certiorare was granted, for the Defendant is not party before the Sci. facias ad audiendum errore ‚Ä¢
be i≈ø≈øued forth again≈øt him: and therefore he comes timely enough to pray a Certiorare. See 28 H. 6. 10. and 11. And I grant that the Certificate upon a Certiorare which was awarded after a Sci. fac. ad audiendum errores is peremptory and final, but contrary where it is granted before the awarding of ≈øuch Scire facias: See Book of Entries 271. The Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigneth Error in the Original Writ, & petit br. Domini Regis Cu≈øtodibus Brevium, &c. ad breve illud origin. certificand. and upon
the return of the Certiorare, the Plaintiff prayed a Scire facias ad audiendum errores. And ≈øee there 293. where it appeareth, fol. 272. that Certiorare i≈ø≈øued at the ≈øuit of the Defendant in Error after he had alledged Diminution: and that is after Scire facias ad audiendum errores returned; and ≈øee Certiorare before Sci. facias awarded 271, &c. and this Certiorare is only ex officio, and awarded only to enform the Court: And in re≈øpect of the Certiorare the chief Iu≈øtice of the common Pleas, to whom the Certiorare is directed, is but a Mini≈øter, and not a Iudge. And as to the Ca≈øe of 9 E 4. 32. before cited, he could not have a Certiorare, Diminution. for he could not alledge Diminution, becau≈øe he had pleaded in Nullo e≈øt erratum, by which Plea he had confe≈ø≈øed the Record which is certified to be a full and perfect Record, and fully certified, and again≈øt that matter he ≈øhall not alledge Diminution: And in our Ca≈øe there is not any ≈øuch contrariety as hath been objected, for the return of the Certiorare is, Non inveni aliquod warrant. not preci≈øely, quod non habetur aliquod warrantum; And therefore if the Court now at the prayer of the Defendant grant another Certiorare, upon which is a Retorn (quod habetur warr. Attornat.) the ≈øame is not contrary to the return of the fir≈øt Certificate, but they may both ≈øtand together, for upon further ≈øearch ≈øuch Warrant of Attorney may be found: ≈øo upon the matter the Court ≈øhall not be enveigled by any ≈øuch contrariety, for (non inveni aliquod warrant.) returned upon the fir≈øt Certiorare, and (inveni quoddam warr.) upon the ≈øecond Certiorare are not meer contrary; And it ≈øeemed to Wray chief Iu≈øtice, that it would be hard to grant a new Certiorare in this Ca≈øe, but if any variance could be alledged it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe, as it was adjudged in the Ca≈øe of one La≈ø≈øell, who certified no Warrant of Attorney, and afterwards it was moved for another Certiorare, as it is here, and becau≈øe the Original was inter Johannem La≈ø≈øels ar. executor. Te≈øti. &c. where he was not named Executor in the fir≈øt Certiorare; upon that matter a new Certiorare was granted.

div.head:
XXIX. Withy and Saunders Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: WIthy libelled again≈øt Saunders in the Spiritual Court,Tithes will not pa≈øs by grant without deed and now came Saunders and ≈øurmi≈øed, that Withy had libelled again≈øt him for Tithe-gra≈øs, and ≈øhewed, that all the claim that Withy had to the ≈øaid Tithes was by a grant without deed, and by the Law ≈øuch things would not pa≈øs without deed; And al≈øo that the Spiritual Court would not allow of this Plea, and therefore prayed a prohibition: And the Court upon the fir≈øt Motion conceived a prohibition ≈øhould pa≈øs, for if the grant be without deed, nothing pa≈øsed, and then hath not Withy cau≈øe to claim the≈øe Tithes again≈øt the ≈øaid Saunders. And notwith≈øtanding that Tithes are quodam modo ≈øpiritual things, and ≈øo demandable in a Court of that nature, yet now in divers re≈øpects they are become a Lay-fee, and lay-things, for a Writ of A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Mortdaunce≈øter, and an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of novel di≈ø≈øei≈øin lyes of them, and a Fine may be levyed of them. But it hath been doubted, whether Tithes be devi≈øable by Will: But at another day the matter was moved, and the Court was clear of opinion, that a Con≈øultation ≈øhould be awarded, for whether Withy hath right or not right to the≈øe Tithes, Saunders of common right ought to pay his Tithes, and he ought to ≈øever them from the nine parts, and who≈øoever takes them, whether he hath right to them or no right, Saunders is di≈øcharged: But Saunders may pre≈øcribe in modo decimandi, without making mention of any ≈øeverance, and may ≈øurmi≈øe, that the Tithes do belong to I. S. with whom he hath compounded to pay ≈øuch a ≈øum for all Tithes, and afterwards a Con≈øultation was awarded.

div.head:
XXX. Stacy and Carters Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p:
STacy brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking his Clo≈øe again≈øt Walter Carter, And declared of a Tre≈øpa≈øs in Somers-Land in Tunbridge; The Defendant pleaded, that heretofore he him≈øelf brought an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Novel di≈ø≈øei≈øin again≈øt the now Plaintiff, and ≈øuppo≈øed him≈øelf to be di≈ø≈øei≈øed of his Free-hold in Lee juxta Tunbridge, and the Land where the Tre≈øpa≈øs ≈øuppo≈øed to be done was put in view to the Recognitors of the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and further averred, that the Land where, &c. and the Land then put in view is one and the ≈øame, &c. upon which there was a Demurrer: Exception was taken to the form of the Demurrer, becau≈øe in the perclo≈øe and conclu≈øion of the Demurrer the≈øe words are omitted,Averment. Et hoc paratus e≈øt verificare. But as to that, it was ≈øaid by the Court, that the Demurrer was well enough, with or without ≈øuch Averment in the conclu≈øion of it, which ≈øee oftentimes in the Commentaries, &c. and in the Book of Entries 146. the greater part of the Demurrers have not any ≈øuch conclu≈øion. Another Exception was taken to the bar, becau≈øe the Defendant pleads, that heretofore Walter Carter had brought an A≈ø≈øi≈øe again≈øt the now Plaintiff, &c. and that the Land put in view to the Recognitors of the A≈ø≈øi≈øe per praefatum Warrhamum Carter, &c. and the Land where, &c. is all one, &c. here is Warrhamum for Walterum, and notwith≈øtanding that it was after demurrer, and not after verdict, it was adjudged amendable; and as to the matter of the bar, it was ≈øaid by the Defendants Council, that recovery of Lands in one Town, by Praecipe quod reddat, is not a bar for Lands in another Town; but where the recovery is by A≈ø≈øi≈øe it is otherwi≈øe,
„Äà1 paragraph„Äâ
for there the Plaint is general De lib. tenÃÑto, and the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover per vi≈øum Juratorum, and the view is the warrant of the Iudgment and Execution. And therefore if a recovery in an A≈ø≈øi≈øe be pleaded in bar, Not compri≈øed, is not any Plea again≈øt it, as in the Ca≈øe of recoveries upon a Praecipe quod reddat; but not put in view, and ≈øo not compri≈øed, &c. which proves that the Record doth not guid the recovery, but the view of the Iurors. See 26 E 3. 2. A≈ø≈øi≈øe brought of Lands in D. the Tenant ≈øaith, that he holdeth the ≈øaid Lands put in view joyntly with A. not named in the Writ, &c. and ≈øheweth the deed of Ioynttenancy, which ≈øpeaks of Tenements in B. and the plea holdeth good, becau≈øe he alledgeth the Ioynt-tenancy and the Lands put in view: See 24 E 3. It was ≈øaid on the Plaintiffs ≈øide, that recovery in Lee juxta Tunbridge could not extend to Lands in Tunbridge, no more than a recovery of Lands in one County can extend to Lands in another County: See 23 E 3. 16. A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Novel di≈ø≈øei≈øin brought of Lands in N. the Defendant pleads recovery in A≈ø≈øi≈øe, &c. brought before by him again≈øt the now Plaintiff of Lands in H. and the ≈øame Lands put then and now in view, and adjudged no bar. See al≈øo 16 E 3. 16. in an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Tenements in W. the Tenant pleads a Recovery of the ≈øame Lands agai≈øt one A. by A≈ø≈øi≈øe brought of Tenements in C. which was found by the A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and that C. is a Hamlet of W. and the Plaintiff notwith≈øtanding that recovery ≈øo pleaded had Iudgment, for a recovery of Lands in one Town ≈øhall not be a bar in an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Lands in another Town. See Br. Tit. Iudgment 66. 10 E 3. And the whole Court was clear of opinion, that the plea in bar was not good, for in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe which is pleaded in bar in the principal Ca≈øe, the Tenant there, who is now Plaintiff in this Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, pleaded Nul tort nul di≈ø≈øei≈øin, which is no plea, as to the Free-hold in Lee juxta Tunbridge, and therefore it cannot be like to the Ca≈øe which hath been put of 26 E 3. for there the Tenant pleaded, that he held
the ≈øaid Lands put in view joyntly, for there he agreeth with the Plaintiff in the Lands demanded, the which Lands are put in view; but if in the Ca≈øe at bar the Defendant being Plaintiff in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe, the now Plaintiff being then Tenant, had pleaded to the Land put in view in bar, and the Plaintiff in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe had recovered, now in this Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs the Plantiff in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe being Defendant in the Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, might well plead this Recovery in bar, for by his plea in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe he hath tyed him≈øelf to the view, and to the Land put in view, but it is not ≈øo in the Ca≈øe at Bar, where the Tenant in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe pleads, nul tort, nul di≈ø≈øei≈øin, for there he doth not plead expre≈øly to the Land put in view, but to the ≈øuppo≈øal of the Plaintiff, ≈øc. de libero tenemento in Lee juxta Tunbridge: afterwards Wray, with the a≈ø≈øent of the other Iu≈øtices awarded, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould recover his damages: See by Wray, 44 E 3. 45. in A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Tenements in B. the Plaintiff pleads, that he him≈øelf brought an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of the ≈øame Tenements, and his plaint was of Tenements in E. and the ≈øame Tenements put in view, and recovered, and holden a good Plea, becau≈øe the Tenant hath ≈øaid, that the ≈øame Tenements were put in view, and that took by A≈ø≈øi≈øe, upon which the Plaintiff ≈øaid, not put in view, and ≈øo not compri≈øed.

div.head:
XXXI. Benicombe and Parkers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs the Iury found this ≈øpecial matter, that the Grandfather of the Plaintiff was ≈øei≈øed, and made a Feoffment to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, the remainder to the u≈øe of John Father of the Plaintiff in tail, the Grandfather died, the Father entred,Feoffments and by Indenture by words of bargain and ≈øale, without any words of Dedi & conce≈ø≈øi, conveyed the Lands to the u≈øe of A. in Fee, and in the ≈øame Indenture was a Letter of Attorney to make Livery, which was made accordingly; and the ≈øaid A. by the ≈øaid Indenture covenanted, that if the ≈øaid John ≈øhould pay before ≈øuch a day to the ≈øaid A. forty ≈øhillings, that then the ≈øaid A. and his Heirs would ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, &c. to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid John and his Heirs; and if the ≈øaid John did not pay, &c. then if the ≈øaid A. did not pay to the ≈øaid John within four days after ten pounds, that then the ≈øaid A. and his Heirs from thenceforth ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid John and his Heirs, &c. and the ≈øaid John covenanted further, by the ≈øaid Indenture, to make ≈øuch further a≈ø≈øurance as the Council of the ≈øaid John ≈øhould advi≈øe. Each party failed of payment. John levied a Fine to A. without any con≈øideration; it was adjudged upon this matter a good Feoffment well executed by the Livery,Hob. 151. Dyer 361. a More 194. Po≈øt. 195, 196, 197. More 35. b. notwith≈øtanding that the words of the conveyance are only by bargain and ≈øale; and that the Covenant to be ≈øei≈øed to the new u≈øes upon payment, and not payment being in one and the ≈øame deed, ≈øhould rai≈øe the u≈øe upon the contingency, according to the limitation of it; and Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff accordingly.

div.head:
XXXII. Bedows Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action of Debt upon a Bill ≈øealed again≈øt one Bedow; he demanded Dyer of the Bill, which was, Memorandum that I John Bedow have agreed to pay to R. S. the Plaintiff twenty pounds, and thereupon there was a Demurrer, fir≈øt, that the Deed wanted the words In cujus rei te≈øtimonium, &c. but notwith≈øtanding that the Court held the Deed good, and ≈øaid ≈øo it was lately adjudged: Another matter was
becau≈øe the words of the contract are in the preter Ten≈øe, I have agreed; but notwith≈øtanding that exception the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover, as by Wray, the≈øe words dedi & conce≈ø≈øi, according to the Grammatical ≈øence imply a gift precedent, but yet they are u≈øed as words of a pre≈øent conveyance, & Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
XXXIII. Mar≈øh and Smiths Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 27. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
1 Cro. 38. 39. GEorge Mar≈øh brought a Replevin again≈øt Smith and Paget, who make Conu≈øans as Baylies to Ralph Bard, and upon the pleading the Ca≈øe was, That Sir Francis Askew, was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Ca≈øtord in his Deme≈øne, as of Fee, which Mannor did extend unto Da≈øton, North-kel≈øey, Grants. Mannor. 2 Len. 41, 42. South-kel≈øey D. and C. and had deme≈ønes and ≈øervices, parcel of the ≈øaid Mannor, in each of the ≈øaid Towns, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, granted totum manerium ≈øuum de North-kel≈øey in North-kel≈øey, to the ≈øaid Bard and his Heirs, and granted further, all his Lands Tenements, and Hereditaments, in North-kel≈øey; and to that grant, the Tenants in North-kel≈øey did attorn; And the Land in which the ≈øaid Di≈øtre≈øs was taken is in North-kel≈øey; the only que≈øtion in the ca≈øe was, if, by this grant to Ralph Bard, a Mannor pa≈ø≈øed, or not: And the ca≈øe was argued by the Iu≈øtices; And Periam Iu≈øtice argued, That upon this grant no Mannor pa≈ø≈øed, for before the grant, there was no Mannor of North-kel≈øey, or in North-kel≈øey, therefore no Mannor can pa≈øs, but the Lands and ≈øervices in North-kel≈øey ≈øhall pa≈øs as in gro≈øs, for they were not known by a Mannor, but for parcel of a Mannor: And a Mannor is a thing which cannot be ≈øo ea≈øily created,Mannor, what it is. for it is an Hereditament which doth con≈øi≈øt of many real things, and incorporated together before time of memory; common reputation cannot be intended of an opinion conceived within three or four years, but of long time; And appendancy cannot be made pre≈øently, but by a long tract of time: As an Advow≈øon in gro≈øs cannot be made by an Act appendant, and the Queen her ≈øelf by her Letters Patents cannot make a Mannor at this day, √† multo fortiori a ≈øubject cannot, and the Queen cannot by her Letters Patents without an Act of Parliament annex a Mannor to the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, which ≈øee 1 Ma. Dyer 95. And where it is u≈øual, that the Queen doth grant Lands,Reputation. tenendum de manerio ≈øuo de Ea≈øt Greenwich in communi ≈øoccagio, if upon the death of ≈øuch a Grantee without heir, the ≈øaid Land doth revert unto the Queen in point of E≈øcheat, the ≈øaid Land ≈øhall not be parcel of the ≈øaid Mannor, for the Land was not parcel of the Mannor in truth, but in reputation: And he cited a ca≈øe, that the Lord Sturton was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Quincamore, and was al≈øo ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Charleton which was holden of the ≈øaid Mannor of Quincamore; The Lord Sturton was attainted of Felony; and afterwards Queen Mary gave the ≈øaid Mannor of Quincamore to Sir Walter Mildmay cum omnibus ≈øuis juribus & parcellis, it was adjudged that the Mannor of Charleton did pa≈øs, for it is now become parcel of the Mannor of Quincamore; and I grant, that things which go with the Land ≈øhall pa≈øs well enough: As if the Queen grant to three Coparceners of three Mannors,1 In≈øt. 122. a 32 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 6 11. the liberty of Warren in all the ≈øaid three Mannors, they afterwards make partition ≈øo as each Coparcener hath a Mannor, and the one of them grants her Mannor, the Grantee ≈øhall have Warren:Grants of the King. But if the Queen grant a Leet (ut ≈øupra) and the Coparceners make Partition, and each of them hath a Mannor, ≈øhe ≈øhall not have al≈øo a Leet, but the Leet which was grantted doth remain in common, and there ≈øhall not be there, upon ≈øuch partition, ≈øeveral Leets: And al≈øo I grant that in the ca≈øe of two Coparceners of a Mannor, if to each of them upon partition be allotted
demeans and ≈øervices, each of them hath a Mannor, for they were compellable to make partition by the common Law being in by de≈øcent, See 26 H. 8. 4. 9 E. 4. 5. contrary of Ioynt-tenants, for they are in by purcha≈øe, and were not compellable by the common Law to make partition, and therefore upon partition betwixt them a Rent cannot be re≈øerved for the equality of the partition: And in every Manor a Court is requi≈øite, for a Court Baron is incident to a Manor,Court Baron. but a Court cannot at this day be founded or erected, but it ought to be of long time: And in our Ca≈øe, no Court hath ever been holden in North-kel≈øey: And if I be ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of B. which extends into C. and B. and I grant my Manor of B. in D. now a Manor pa≈ø≈øeth, and doth extend into D. and the re≈øidue which is in C. ≈øhall remain in me in gro≈øs, v. 9 E. 4. 17. Catesby; And if I be ≈øei≈øed of a Manor which doth con≈øi≈øt of ≈øervices, and of twenty Free-holders, and one hundred Acres of Deme≈ønes, and I grant the ≈øervices of my twenty Free-holders, and forty or twenty Acres of the ≈øaid one hundred Acres, a Manor ≈øhall pa≈øs, although it was not granted by the name of a Manor; but if I grant the ≈øervices of three, four, or five of my Free-holders, and forty or twenty of the ≈øaid one hundred Acres, upon ≈øuch a grant no Manor ≈øhall pa≈øs: Windham Iu≈øtice contrary, We are not here to ≈øpeak of the creation of a Manor, that is a forraign matter, but we are here to con≈øider upon the divi≈øion, and apportionment of a Manor. They that have argued in this ca≈øe at the Bar, have ≈øtood much upon the words of the Conveyance, manerium ≈øuum de North-kel≈øey, and that Sir Fr. Askew at the time of that a≈ø≈øurance, had not any Manor of North-kel≈øey, or in North-kel≈øey, but that is not any rea≈øon, for if Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe (mean between the Statute of 1 E. 3. & 27 H. 8.) will make a Feoffment of the Manor which was in u≈øe, by the≈øe words, manerium ≈øuum, the ≈øame had been good, and yet it is not manerium ≈øuum, but the Manor of the Feoffees, but it may be ≈øaid ≈øuum, by receiving of the profits according to the tru≈øt and confidence repo≈øed in the Feoffees; ≈øo in our ca≈øe, in as much as Sir Fr. Askew had before this grant a≈øwell deme≈ønes as ≈øervices in North-kel≈øey, it may collaterally be ≈øaid a Manor there, and notwith≈øtanding that tempore conce≈ø≈øionis (proprie loquendo) no Manor was in North-kel≈øey, yet now upon operation of the Law, upon this grant a new Manor ≈øhall ri≈øe, for in divers ca≈øes where a thing which was not in e≈ø≈øe before, upon a grant may ri≈øe; As if I grant unto you out of my Land a Rent de novo; And al≈øo a thing which was not in e≈ø≈øe before, may upon a grant take upon it a new nature; As if I. ≈øei≈øed of a great Wood, grant to you E≈øtovers out of it, they were not before in me but as Woods and Trees, now by this grant they are become E≈øtovers in the Grantee, ≈øo as they are in the Grantee in another nature, than they were in me: So in our ca≈øe, although North-kel≈øey was not a Manor in Sir Fr. Askew, yet now upon the grant it is a Manor in Bard, 9 E. 4. 17. And as to the matter which hath been objected, becau≈øe a Court cannot now begin, the ≈øame is not any rea≈øon, for the Court Baron is incident to the Manor, and al≈øo to every part of the Manor, and tran≈øitory through the whole Manor, and if Sir Fr. Askew had ≈øold all the dem≈ønes of the Manor in Ca≈øtord, where the Court Baron for the ≈øaid Manor had always been held and not el≈øe-where, yet ≈øuch a Court might be holden in any part of the Demeans in any other of the ≈øaid Towns: The Lord Ander≈øon, to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, It hath been argued of the other ≈øide, that the Manor doth not pa≈øs, becau≈øe the grant is in the≈øe words, manerium de North-kel≈øey, in North-kel≈øey, I conceive that the≈øe words, (de North-kel≈øey) are void, as matter of ≈øurplu≈øage, and the grant ≈øhall be con≈øtrued as if the words had been manerium ≈øuum in North-kel≈øey: And a Manor is ≈øuch a thing, as may be determined, divided, and ≈øu≈øpended: As if the Lord of a Manor lea≈øeth for years all the Demeans of the Manor, the Manor is ≈øu≈øpended during
the term for years, as lately it hath been adjudged. And a warranty may be divided, as if a Feoffment in Fee be made to two with warranty, and the one of them relea≈øeth the warranty: vide L. 5. E. 4. 103. A. ≈øei≈øed of a Manor which extendeth in four Towns, B. C. D. and E. and he gives his Manor in B. C. and D. by this gift the Manor and all that is in the ≈øaid four Towns pa≈ø≈øeth. And he cited al≈øo a Ca≈øe 21 E. 4. 3. The Lord of a Manor erected a Chapel within his ≈øaid Manor as a Chapel of Ca≈øe, &c. and afterwards it is a Pari≈øh-Church, now it is become pre≈øentable; an Advow≈øon appendant, as the ≈øoil upon the which the Church is built is parcel of the Manor. See 32 H. 6. 9. One Manor may be parcel of another Manor, as A. holdeth of B. twenty acres of Land, as of his Manor of C. which Manor B. holdeth of D. as of his Manor of E. B. dieth without Heir, ≈øo as his Manor of C. is e≈øcheated unto D. now the twenty acres are holden of the Manor of C. as they were before, and the Manor of C. is by the E≈øcheat become parcel of the Manor of E. and by Lea≈øe of the Manor of E. it ≈øhall pa≈øs.Po≈øt. 32. And I do not know any difference between the Ca≈øe of Parceners, and the Ca≈øe of Ioynt-tenants, for now they are both equally compellable to make partition: And he cited the Ca≈øe of one E≈øtopp. lately adjudged, viz. the Queen was ≈øei≈øed of the Rectory of D. which extended into the Counties of Lincoln and York, and the Queen granted her Rectory of D. in Lincoln, the≈øe are ≈øeveral grants, and now upon the matter they are become ≈øeveral Rectories. And as to that which hath been objected concerning a Court Baron which ought to belong to this new Manor, and that ≈øuch a Court cannot now at this day be erected, and therfore here cannot be a Manor; here needs not the erection of any new Court, but fora≈ømuch as the Court Baron before this grant might be by Law holden in any place within the Manor: therefore every part of the Demeans of the Manor is capable of a Court to be holden there. As where one is ≈øei≈øed of a Manor to which an Advow≈øon is appendant, now is the Advow≈øon appendant not only to the ≈øaid Manor, but to every part of it; for if he alien an acre, parcel of the Manor with the Advow≈øon, the Advow≈øon is now appendant to the ≈øaid acre: See 43 E. 3. 26. So in the Ca≈øe at Bar, becau≈øe this liberty and franchi≈øe of a Manor is throughout the whole Manor, and in every part of the Services and Deme≈ønes upon this grant of the Services and Deme≈ønes in North-kel≈øey, and of his Manor in North-kel≈øey, a Manor pa≈ø≈øeth; which Windham al≈øo granted and agreed unto. Note at this time there were but three Iudges in this Court: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Defendant.

div.head:
XXXIV. Alington and Bales Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench, Rot. 584.
div.p:
1 Cro. 660. 661. ALington and others, Executors of Sir W. Cordel late Ma≈øter of the Ro≈øs, brought an Action Debt again≈øt Bales: The Ca≈øe was this, One Bream being ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands, by Indenture bargained and ≈øold the ≈øame to one Platt by the≈øe words (give, grant, bargain, ≈øell) and by the ≈øaid Indenture covenanted with Platt, that the ≈øaid Platt and his Heirs ≈øhould quietly enjoy the ≈øaid Lands without interruption of any per≈øon or per≈øons: And afterwards certain controver≈øies ri≈øing betwixt them concerning the ≈øaid Lands,Arbitrament. the ≈øaid Bream and Platt ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to the award and arbitrament of Sir W. Cordel, to whom they were bounden ≈øeverally for the performance of ≈øuch award, the which Sir W. among≈øt other things awarded, that the ≈øaid Platt and his Heirs ≈øhould enjoy quietly the ≈øaid Lands, in tam amplo modo & forma, as the ≈øaid Land is conveyed and a≈ø≈øured by the coveyance and a≈ø≈øurance afore≈øaid: And the truth was, that the ≈øaid Bream at the time
of the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øurance was bounden in a Recognizance of ≈øix hundred pounds to one More, 15. Eliz. and afterwards More 16 Eliz. ≈øued a Sci. fac. upon the ≈øaid Recognizance; and 18 Eliz. the bargain and ≈øale afore≈øaid was made; and afterwards 19 Eliz. More ≈øued forth Excution by Elegit, and the moyety of the ≈øaid Land a≈ø≈øured to Platt was delivered in Execution to More. And if upon the whole matter the Arbitrament was broken was the que≈øtion. It was argued by Godfrey, that the Plaintiff ought to be barred; and fir≈øt,1 Hob. 35. Mor. 175. 3 Len. 43. Po≈øt. 93. Po≈øt. 179, 279. 1 In≈øt. 366. a. b. 388. Dy: 42. he conceived that the≈øe words in the Indenture (give and grant) did not help the Action, for the Lands pa≈ø≈øed with a charge, and the general words Dedi & conce≈ø≈øi, do not extend to this collateral charge, but to the direct right of the Land only; but if a ≈øtranger had put out the bargainee, there upon ≈øuch general words, an Action would lie, but as the Ca≈øe is, they do not give any cau≈øe of Action, for the Recognizance was a thing in charge at the time of the A≈ø≈øurance: and yet ≈øee 31 E 3. Br. Warr. Chartae, 33. A. enfeoffeth B. with warranty, who brings a Warrantia Chartae, and recovers pro loco & tempore, and afterwards a ≈øtranger doth recover again≈øt him a Rent charge out of the ≈øaid Land, and it was holden, that upon the matter B. ≈øhould have execution: the ≈øpecial words of the Aribitrament, upon which the Action is brought, are, that the ≈øaid Platt and his Heirs ≈øhould enjoy the ≈øaid Lands in tam amplo modo & forma, as it was a≈ø≈øured and conveyed to the ≈øaid Platt; ergo, not in more ample manner:1 Cro. 660. 661. Owen Rep. 65. 2 Cro. 571. 1 Roll. 425. and the ≈øaid Land was conveyed to Platt, chargeable to the ≈øaid Recognizance, therefore if Platt enjoy it charged, there is no cau≈øe of Action: And as to the Covenant in the Indenture, that Platt and his Heirs ≈øhould enjoy quietly the ≈øaid Lands without interruption of any per≈øon, the ≈øame is a Collateral ≈øurety; and the words of the Award are, that Platt ≈øhall enjoy it in tam amplo modo & forma, as it is conveyed and a≈ø≈øured by the a≈ø≈øurance afore≈øaid without interruption, the≈øe are not words of a≈ø≈øurance, for the a≈ø≈øurance doth con≈øi≈øt in the legal words of pa≈ø≈øing the e≈øtate: ≈øcil. bargain, ≈øale, Dedi, conce≈ø≈øi, and in the limitation of the e≈øtate, and not in the words of the Convenant: And therefore it hath been adjudged, that if I. be bounden to A. in an Obligation, to a≈ø≈øure to him the Mannor of D, &c. if A. tender to me an Indenture of bargain and ≈øale, in which are many Covenants, I am not bound upon the peril of my Bond to ≈øeal and deliver it. Al≈øo here doth not appear any interruption again≈øt the Covenant in the Indenture, for here is not any lawful Execution, for it appeareth here, that More hath ≈øued Execution by Elegit 4 years after the Iudgment in the Scire facias, in which ca≈øe he ≈øhall be put to a new Scire facias, for the Sheriff in this Ca≈øe ought to have returned, that the Conu≈øor after the Recognizance had enfeoffed divers per≈øons, and ≈øhewed who, and upon that matter returned, the Conu≈øee ≈øhould have a Sci. facias again≈øt the Feoffees, vide F. N. B. 266. And the Court was clear of opinion again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
XXXV. Floud and Sir John Perrotts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
FLoud recovered again≈øt Sir John Perrot, 1 Cro. 63. Po≈øt. 264. 3 Len. 240. in an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon a promi≈øe, eighty ≈øix pounds, again≈øt which Floud and Barlow affirmed a Plaint of Debt in London, and attached the ≈øaid moeny in the hands of the ≈øaid Sir John, and had execution according to the cu≈øtom of London. And now the ≈øaid Floud ≈øued a Scire facias again≈øt the ≈øaid Sir John, who appeared, and pleaded the ≈øaid Execution by attachment; upon which Floud the Plaintiff did demur in Law: And it was adjudged no plea, for a duty which accrueth by matter of Record cannot be attached by the cu≈øtom of London. And notwith≈øtanding that the cu≈øtom of London be layed generally in aliquo debito, and damages recovered are quoddam debitum, as it was urged by the Council
of the Defendant: Yet the Law is clear, that Iudgments given in the Courts of the King ought not,Judgments in the Kings Courts not to be defeated by particular cu≈øtom of places. nor cannot by ≈øuch particular cu≈øtoms be defeated and avoided, as it was lately adjudged in a We≈øtern Ca≈øe, Damages were recovered, the Sheriff by virtue of a Fieri facias levyed the money, which one to whom the Plaintiff was endebted, did attach by the cu≈øtom, in the hands of the Sheriff; but it was adjudged the attachment was not good, for the cu≈øtom of attachment cannot reach upon a thing of ≈øo high a nature as a Record is; the ≈øame Law of Debt upon a Recognizance and Statute, &c. and it was affirmed by Wray chief Iu≈øtice, that upon great deliberation it was agreed, by Bromley Lord Chancellor him≈øelf, the Lord Ander≈øon, Mead and Periam Iu≈øtices, that where a Merchant, having in an Action recovered certain damages, became Bankrupt, upon which i≈ø≈øued an Commi≈ø≈øion upon the Statute of 13 Eliz. of Bankrupts, that ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øioners could not entermeddle with ≈øuch damages, to di≈øpo≈øe of them to the Creditors, according to the ≈øaid Statute: But now ≈øee the Statute of 1 Jacobi. The Commi≈ø≈øioners have power to di≈øpo≈øe of ≈øuch debts, &c.

div.head:
XXXVI. Sir Walter Hungerfords Ca≈øe.
Trin. 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Grants of the King.IN a Replevin by Sir Walter Hungerford, the Ca≈øe was this, the Queen being ≈øei≈øed of a great Wa≈øte called Rudde≈ødown in the Pari≈øh of Chipnam, granted to the Mayor and Burge≈ø≈øes of Chipnam, the moyety of a Yard-land in the ≈øaid Wa≈øte, without certainty in what part of the Wa≈øte they ≈øhould have the ≈øame, or the ≈øpecial name of the Land, or how it was bounded, and without any certain de≈øcription of it. And afterwards the Queen granted to the ≈øaid Sir Walter the ≈øaid Wa≈øte, and afterwards the ≈øaid Mayor and Burge≈ø≈øes by warrant of Attorney under the Common Seal, authorized one A. to enter in the ≈øaid Wa≈øte, and in the behalf of the ≈øaid Mayor and Burge≈ø≈øes to make election of the ≈øaid moyety,Election. &c. who did ≈øo accordingly. And upon this matter gives in evidence the parties did demur in Law, and the Iury were di≈øcharged.12 Co. 86. 87. Dy. 372. b. 281. Noy. 29. And it was holden and re≈øolved by the whole Court, that the grant to the Mayor, &c. was utterly void for the incertainty of the thing granted: And if a common per≈øon do make ≈øuch a grant it is good enough, and there the Grantee may make his choice where, &c. and by ≈øuch choice executed, the thing ≈øhall be reduced into certainty: which choice the Grantee cannot have again≈øt the Queen, which difference was agreed by the whole Court: And it was further holden, that this grant was not only void again≈øt the Queen her ≈øelf, but al≈øo again≈øt Sir Walter Hungerford her Patentee. It was further holden by the Court, that if a common per≈øon had made ≈øuch a grant, which ought to be reduced to certainty by Election, and the Corporation to whom the grant was made (ut ≈øupra) ≈øhould not make their election by Attorney, but after that they were re≈øolved upon the Land, they ≈øhould make a ≈øpecial warrant of Attorney, reciting the grant to them, & in whih part of the ≈øaid Wa≈øte their grant ≈øhould take effect, Ea≈øt, We≈øt, &c. or by buttals, &c. according to which direction the Attorney is to enter, &c.

div.head:
XXXVII. Watts and Jordens Ca≈øe.
Trin. 27. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN Debt by Watts again≈øt Jorden, proce≈øs continued until the Defendant was Out-lawed, and upon the Capias utlagatum he appeared and pleaded to i≈ø≈øue, which was found for the Plaintiff, and Iudgment given
accordingly. And now came Jourden and ca≈øt in a Writ of Error,Error. and a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that he appeared upon the Capias utlagatum, and pleaded to i≈ø≈øue, the Original being determined, and not revived by Scire facias, upon his Charter of pardon; Ander≈øon Iu≈øtice was of opinion, that it was not Error, for the Statute of 18 Eliz. had di≈øpen≈øed with it, being after verdict; for the words of the Statute are, For want of any Writ Original or Iudicial. Windham Iu≈øtice contrary, for the Statute doth not extend, but where the Original is imbe≈øelled, but in this Ca≈øe it is not imbe≈øelled, but in Law determined, and at la≈øt the Writ of Error was allowed:

div.head: XXXVIII. Trin. 23 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was, A. ≈øei≈øed of Lands by his Will devi≈øed,3 Len 119. that his Excutors ≈øhould ≈øell his Lands, and died, the Executors levy a Fine thereof to one F. taking mony for the ≈øame of F. If in title made by the Conu≈øee to the Land by the Fine, It be a good plea again≈øt the Fine to ≈øay, Quod partes ad finem nihil habuerunt, was the que≈øtion.Fines levyed. Ander≈øon conceived that it was: But by Windham and Periam, upon Not-guilty, The Conu≈øee might help him≈øelf by giving the ≈øpecial matter in evidence, in which Ca≈øe the Conu≈øee ≈øhall be adjudged in; not by the Fine, but by the Devi≈øe: As by Windham. A. devi≈øeth,Devi≈øe. Co. 1 In≈øt. 113. a. that his Executors ≈øhall ≈øell a Rever≈øion of certain Lands, of which he dieth ≈øei≈øed; they ≈øell the ≈øame without deed, and good; for the Vendee is in by the Devi≈øe and not by the conveyance of the Executors: See 19 H. 6. 23. And by Periam the Conu≈øee may help him≈øelf by pleading, as he who is in by the Feoffment or grant of Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe by the Statute of 1 R. 3.

div.head:
XXXIX. Albany and the Bi≈øhop of St. A≈øaphs Ca≈øe.
Trin. 27 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
ALbany brought a Quare impedit again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of St. A≈øaph, 1 Cro. 119. who ju≈øtified for Lap≈øe: The Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaid that before the ≈øix months expired, he pre≈øented to the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop one Bag≈øhaw, Quare impedit. a Ma≈øter of Arts and Preacher allowed, &c. The Defendant by way of Rejoynder ≈øaid, that the Church upon the pre≈øentment to which the Action is brought is a Church with Cure of Souls, and that the Pari≈øhioners there are homines Wallici, Wallicam loquentes linguam & non aliam. And that the ≈øaid Bag≈øhaw could not ≈øpeak or under≈øtand the Welch Language, for which cau≈øe he refu≈øed him, and gave notice to the Plaintiff of ≈øuch refu≈øal, and of the cau≈øe of it, &c. upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. And fir≈øt it was agreed and re≈øolved by the whole Court, that in the computation of the ≈øix months in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, the Reckoning ought not to be according to the Kalender, January, February, &c. but Secundum numerum ≈øingulorum dierum, Co. 2 In≈øt. 361. Co. 6. 61. b. Yel. 100. 2 Cro. 141. Departure. allowing eight and twenty days to every month: Walme≈øley Serjeant argued for the Plaintiff, and he took exception to the Rejoynder; for in that the Defendant had departed from his Bar; for in the Bar the Defendant intitles him≈øelf to the pre≈øentment by rea≈øon of Lap≈øe, and in the Rejoynder he confe≈ø≈øeth the pre≈øentment of the Plaintff, and pleads his refu≈øal of his Clark, and ≈øhewes the cau≈øe of it; ≈øc. the want of the Wel≈øh Language, which is a Departure: And he cited divers Ca≈øes to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, 27 H 8. 3. In forfeiture of Marriage, the Defendant pleaded the Feoffment of the Ance≈øtor of the Heir to divers per≈øons, ab≈ø
que hoc, that he died in the homage of the Plaintiff; the Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaid, that the ≈øaid Feoffment was made to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Ance≈øtor and his Heirs: The Defendant by Rejoynder ≈øaith, that
the ≈øaid Ance≈øtor did declare his Will of the ≈øaid Lands, the ≈øame was holden a Departure, for he might have pleaded the ≈øame in Bar, and 21 H. 7. 17, 18. & 37 H 6. 5. in Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant pleaded, that I. S. was ≈øei≈øed of the Land where, &c. being Land devi≈øable, and devi≈øed the ≈øame to him and his Heirs; the Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaid, that I. S. at the time of the devi≈øe was within age, &c. The Defendant by Rejoynder ≈øaid, that the cu≈øtom there is, that every one of the age of fifteen years might devi≈øe his Lands, &c. the ≈øame was holden a departure: But to this Exception the Court took not much regard: But as to the matter in Law, it was argued by Walme≈øley, that the defect of the Wel≈øh Language a≈ø≈øigned by the Defendant in the pre≈øence of the Plaintiff is not a ≈øufficient Cau≈øe of refu≈øal; for notwith≈øtanding that it be convenient that ≈øuch a Pre≈øentee have the knowledge of ≈øuch Language, yet by the Law of the Land, ignorance of ≈øuch Language, where the party hath more excellent Languages, is not any di≈øability; and therefore we ≈øee, that many Bi≈øhops in Wales, who have the principal Cure of Souls, are Engli≈øh-men; and the Wel≈øh Language may ea≈øily be learned in a ≈øhort time by conver≈øe with Wel≈øh-men: And the Statute of 1 Eliz. which e≈øtabli≈øheth the Book of Common Prayer, ordaineth, that the ≈øaid Book of Common Prayer ≈øhall be put in u≈øe in all the Pari≈øh Churches of Eng. and Wa. without any provi≈øion there for the tran≈ølation of the ≈øaid Book into the Wel≈øh Language. But afterwards by a private Act it was done, by which it is enacted, That the Bi≈øhop of Wales ≈øhould procure the Epi≈øtles and Go≈øpels to be tran≈ølated, and read in the Wel≈øh Language, which matter our Pre≈øentee might do by a Curate well enough: And he conceived, that by divers Statutes, Aliens by the Common Law were capable of Benefices. See the Statute of 7 H 2. Cap. 12. 1 H 5 Cap. 7. 14 H 6. Cap. 6. and before the ≈øaid la≈øt Statute Iri≈øh-men were capable of Benefices. Gawdy Serjeant contrary: and he confe≈ø≈øed, that at the Common Law the defects afore≈øaid were not any cau≈øes of refu≈øal; but now by rea≈øon of a private Act made, 5 Eliz. Entituled, An Act made for the tran≈ølating of the Bible, and of the Divine Service into the Wel≈øh tongue, the ≈øame defect is become a good cau≈øe of refu≈øal; in which Act the mi≈øchief is recited, viz. That the Inhabitants of Wales did not under≈øtand the Language of England, therefore it was Enacted, That the Bi≈øhops of Wales ≈øhould procure ≈øo many of the Bibles and Books of Common Prayer to be imprinted in the Wel≈øh Language, as there are Pari≈øhes and Cathedral Churches in Wales, and ≈øo upon this Statute, this imperfection is become a good cau≈øe of refu≈øal. And he likened it to the Ca≈øe of Coparceners and Ioynttenants,Ante 28. who now, becau≈øe that by the Statute of 32 H 8. Ioynt-tenants are equally capable to make partition as Coparceners were by the Common Law; Now Partition betwixt Ioynt-tenants within age is as ≈øtrong as betwixt Parceners within age. But as to that point it was ≈øaid by the Lord Ander≈øon, that it is very true, that upon the ≈øaid Statute the want of the Wel≈øh Language in the Pre≈øentee is now become a good cau≈øe of refu≈øal; but becau≈øe the ≈øaid Act being a private Act hath not been pleaded by the Defendant, we ought not to give our Iudgment according to that Act, but according to the Common Law. Another matter was moved, becau≈øe here appeareth no ≈øufficient notice given to the Patron after the ≈øaid Refu≈øal, for the Plaintiff did pre≈øent the thirtenth of Augu≈øt (the Church voyding the fourteenth of March before) the nine and twentieth of Augu≈øt the ≈øix months expired; the fourth of September the Defendant gave notice to the Patron of the refu≈øal, and the fourteenth of September was the Collation; and it was ≈øaid by the Lord Ander≈øon, that it appeareth here, that there are two and twenty days between the Pre≈øentment and the Notice, which is too large a delay: And the Defendant hath not ≈øhewed in his Plea any cau≈øe for the ju≈øtifying or excu≈øe of it
and therefore upon his own ≈øhewing we adjudge him to be a di≈øturber: See 14 H. 7. 22. 15 H. 7. 6. and note by Periam, it was adjudged in the Ca≈øe of Mollineux, if the Patron pre≈øent, and the Ordinary doth refu≈øe, he ought to give notice to the per≈øon of the Patron thereof, if he be re≈øident within the County, and if not, at the Church it ≈øelf, which is void.

div.head: XL. Mich. 27 & 28 Eliz. At Serjeants Inn.
div.p: THis Ca≈øe was referred by the Lords of Council to the Iu≈øtices for their opinions, I.S. by Indenture between the Queen of the one part, and him≈øelf of the other part, reciting that where he is indebted to the Queen in eight hundred pounds, to be paid in form following, twenty pounds at every Fea≈øt of St. Michael, until the whole ≈øum afore≈øaid be paid, covenanted and granted with the ≈øaid Queen, to convey unto the Lord Trea≈øurer, and Barons of the Exchequer, and to their Heirs, certain Lands to the u≈øes following, viz. to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid I.S. and his Heirs, until ≈øuch time as the ≈øaid I. S. his Heirs Executors or Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall make default in payment of any of the ≈øaid ≈øums; and after ≈øuch default, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Queen, her Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, until her Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhall have received of the i≈ø≈øues and profits thereof ≈øuch ≈øums of money parcel of the ≈øaid debt as ≈øhall be then behind and upaid, and after the ≈øaid debt ≈øo paid and received, then to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid I.S. and his Heirs for ever. I.S. levyeth a Fine of the ≈øaid Land to the ≈øaid Lord Trea≈øurer and the Barons, to the u≈øes afore≈øaid; and afterwards being ≈øei≈øed accordingly, by deed indented and enrolled bargains and ≈øels the ≈øaid Land to a ≈øtranger: default of payment is made, the Queen ≈øeizeth, and granteth it over to one and his Heirs, quou≈øque the money be paid, and after the money is paid: And upon conference of the Iudges among≈øt them≈øelves at Serjeants Inn, they were of opinion, that now I.S. again≈øt his Indenture of bargain and ≈øale, ≈øhould have his Lands again, for at the time of the bargain and ≈øale he had an e≈øtate in Fee, determinable upon a default of payment, ut ≈øupra, Po≈øt. 93. 3 Len. 43. Owen. Rep. 6. 1 In≈øt. 49. 2 which accrued to him by the fir≈øt Indenture and the Fine, which e≈øtate only pa≈ø≈øed by the ≈øaid Indenture of bargain and ≈øale, and not the new e≈øtate which is accrued to him by the latter limitation after the debt paid, for that was not in e≈ø≈øe at the time of the bargain and ≈øale; but if the conveyance by bargain and ≈øale had been by Feoffment or Fine, then it had been otherwi≈øe, for by ≈øuch conveyance all u≈øes and po≈ø≈øibilities had been carried by rea≈øon of the forcible operation of it.

div.head:
XLI. Taylor and Moores Ca≈øe.
Hill. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: TAylor brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Moore, Debt. Error. who pleaded in Bar, upon which the Plaintiff did demurre, and the Court awarded the Plea in Bar good, upon which Iudgment the Plaintiff brought a Writ of Error, and a≈ø≈øigned Error in this, that the Bar upon which he had demurred, as in≈øufficient, was adjudged good: Vpon which now in this Writ of Error the Bar was awarded in≈øufficient, and therefore the Iudgment rever≈øed: But the Court was in a doubt what Iudgment ≈øhall be given in the Ca≈øe, viz. whether the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover his debt and damages, as if he had recovered in the fir≈øt Action, or that he ≈øhall be re≈øtored to his Action only, &c. And Wray cited the Ca≈øe in 8 E. 4. 8. and the Ca≈øe of Attaint 18 E. 4. 9. And at la≈øt it was awarded, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould recover his debt and damages: See to that purpo≈øe 33 H 6. 31. H 7. 12, 20. 7. Eliz. Dyer 235.

div.head:
XLII. Higham and Harewoods Ca≈øe.
Hill. 28. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: More Rep. 221. 3 Len. 132.IN an Ejectione firmae the Ca≈øe was, that one Butty was ≈øei≈øed of the Land where, &c. and al≈øo of a Me≈ø≈øuage, with which Me≈ø≈øuage the ≈øaid Land had been u≈øually occupied, time out of mind, &c. and being ≈øei≈øed and lying ≈øick, commanded a Scridener to be brought to him, and the ≈øaid Scrivener being brought to him, he gave him In≈øtructions to make his Will, and among≈øt other things declared unto him, that his meaning was, that the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, and all his Lands in We≈øterfield ≈øhould be ≈øold by his Executors; and the Scrivener in making of the Will penned the matter in this manner: I will that my hou≈øe, with all the appurtenances, ≈øhall be ≈øold by my Executors; Butty died, the Executors ≈øell forty acres of the ≈øaid Land to the Def. and all this matter was found by ≈øpecial verdict, and it was moved by the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel, that the ≈øale of this Land by the Executors is not warranted by the Will: Another matter was moved, ≈øcil. admitting that the Executors have authority by the Will to ≈øell the Land, if the ≈øale of parcel of the Land be good and warrantable: As if I make a Charter of Feoffment of ten acres, and a Letter of Attorney to make livery of them to the Feoffee, if the Attorney makes ≈øeveral liveries of the ≈øeveral acres the ≈øame is void: But by Cook the Ca≈øes are not like, for in the Ca≈øe put he hath a ≈øpecial Commi≈ø≈øion, in which the party to whom, and all the other circum≈øtances are ≈øet down certainly, contrary in the Ca≈øe at the Bar, there the Commi≈ø≈øion is general, &c. and peradventure the Executors ≈øhall never find a Chapman who will contract with them for the whole.More Rep. 222. Co. In≈øt. 113. a. And afterwards upon conference among≈øt the Iudges, Clench, Gawdy, and Wray, it was re≈øolved, that by this devi≈øe the Lands do pa≈øs by the ≈øale of the Executors to the Defendant, which ≈øale al≈øo by proce≈øs is warranted by the Will, for by Wray, the≈øe words, with all the appurtenances are effectual and emphatical words to enforce the devi≈øe, and that doth extend to all the Lands e≈øpecially; becau≈øe it is found, that the Te≈øtator gave to the Scrivener his In≈øtructions accordingly: And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff. See 3 Eliz. Plowd. 210. Betwixt Sanders and Freeman, there the Devi≈øe is pleaded in this manner, Me≈ø≈øuagium cum pertinentiis ad illud ≈øpectantibus in perpetuum in villa de Arthingworth.

div.head:
XLIII. Watkins and A≈øtwicks Ca≈øe.
Trin. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
1 Cro. 132.IN an Ejectione firmae, it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that one Maynard was ≈øei≈øed, and made a Feoffment in Fee upon condition of payment of mony on the part of the Feoffor by way of Mortgage at a certain day, before which day the ≈øaid Maynard dyed, his Son and Heir being within age,Tender to redeem a Mortgage. afterwards at the day of payment limited by the Mortgage, a ≈øtranger at the in≈øtance and reque≈øt of the Mother of the Heir tendred the money to the Mortgagee in the name of the Heir being within age, who refu≈øed it. And it was re≈øolved by the whole Court, that the ≈øame is not a ≈øufficient tender to redeem the Land, according to the Mortgage, for it is found by the Iury, that the Heir at the time of the tender was within age,2 Len. 213. generally, not particularly of ≈øix or ten years, &c. then it might well ≈øtand with the verdict, that the Heir at ≈øuch time was of the age of 18 or 19 years, at which age he is by the Law out of the Ward of his Mother, or any other prochein amy, in which
Ca≈øe it is pre≈øumed in Law, that he hath di≈øcretion to govern his own affairs: and in this Ca≈øe the Mother is but a ≈øtranger, for the Law hath e≈øtranged the Mother from the government of the Heir; but if the Iury had found that the Heir at the time of the tender was of tender age, viz. within the age of fourteen years, in which Ca≈øe by Law he ought to be in Ward, in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the tender had been good.

div.head:
XLIV. Leput and Wroths Ca≈øe.
Trin. 28. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
A Replevin by Lepur again≈øt Wroth, 6 Co. 33. Replevin. 3 Len. 132. and declared upon a tortious taking in Burnham in the County of E≈ø≈øex; the Ca≈øe upon the pleading was, that Robert Earl of Su≈ø≈øex was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Burnham in Fee, and lea≈øed the ≈øame to the King for one and twenty years, and afterwards the ≈øaid Earl died, by which the ≈øaid Manor de≈øcended to Thomas late Earl of Su≈ø≈øex, and he being ≈øei≈øed, 4 and 5 Phil. and Mary it was Enacted by Parliament, That the Lady Frances, Wife of the ≈øaid Earl, by virtue of the ≈øaid Act of Parliament ≈øhould have, hold and enjoy; &c. during the widowhood of the ≈øaid Frances, for and in con≈øideration of the Ioynture of the ≈øaid Frances the ≈øaid Manor: Provided always, and it is further enacted,Con≈øtruction of Statutes. That it ≈øhould be lawful for the ≈øaid Earl, by his writing indented, dimi≈ø≈øionem vel dimi≈ø≈øiones facere pro termino 21. annorum vel infra de eodem Manerio pro aliquo redditu annuali, ita quod ≈øuper omnes & ≈øingulos huju≈ømodi dimi≈ø≈øionem & dimi≈ø≈øiones antiquus redditus & con≈øuetus vel eo major & amplior re≈øervaretur, and that every ≈øuch demi≈øe ≈øhould be of force, and effectual in Law again≈øt the ≈øaid Frances for term of her life, if the ≈øaid term ≈øhould ≈øo long continue: And further the ≈øaid Act gave to the ≈øaid Frances, Di≈øtre≈øs, Avowry, Covenant, &c. again≈øt ≈øuch Le≈ø≈øee, and for the ≈øaid Le≈ø≈øee again≈øt the ≈øaid Dame; And afterwards the ≈øaid Thomas, the ≈øaid former Lea≈øe not expired, lea≈øed the ≈øaid Manor to Wroth the Defendant for one and twenty years, to begin at the Fea≈øt of Saint Michael next following (and note the Lea≈øe was made the third of April before) rendring three hundred and forty pounds per annum, which was redditus amplior antiquo & u≈øuali. Popham Attorney general argued, that the ≈øaid Lea≈øe did not bind the ≈øaid Lady Frances, and that for two Cau≈øes: 1. becau≈øe it is to begin at a day to come: 2. becau≈øe it was made, a former Lea≈øe being in e≈ø≈øe; and he argued much upon con≈øtruction of Statutes to be made not according to the letter, but according to the meaning of them: And he cited a Ca≈øe upon the Statute of 2 H 5. 3. by which it is Enacted, that in no Action in which the damages do amount to forty marks, any per≈øon ≈øhould be admitted to pa≈øs in trayl of it, who had not Lands or Tenements of the clear yearly value of forty ≈øhillings, yet the ≈øaid Statute ≈øhall not be by con≈øtruction extended, where in an Action between an Engli≈øh-man and an Alien, the Alien prayeth medietatem linguae; and yet the Statute is general. So in our Ca≈øe, although this private Act doth not ≈øeem to provide expre≈øly but for two things: 1.Lea≈øes. the number of the years, 21, & non ultra: 2. antiquus redditus vel eo amplior, yet in rea≈øon and good under≈øtanding we ought to think, that the intent of the Act was, that the ≈øaid Manor ≈øhould now come to the ≈øaid Lady Frances ≈øurcharged with Lea≈øes in Rever≈øion, or to begin at a day to come, for if by this Act the ≈øaid Earl might make a Lea≈øe to begin three months after, by the ≈øame rea≈øon he might make a Lea≈øe to begin twenty years after, and al≈øo to begin after his death. It hath been objected, that the Lord Trea≈øurer had a Commi≈ø≈øion to make Lea≈øes of the Queens Lands, and that by virtue thereof he made Lea≈øes in Rever≈øion: I know the contrary to that, for every ≈øuch Lea≈øe is allowed by a Bill a≈ø≈øigned, and not by the ordinary Commi≈ø≈øion afore≈øaid,
the words of our Act are, Dimi≈ø≈øiones facere pro termino 21. annorum, that ≈øhall be meant to begin pre≈øently: As if I lea≈øe to you my Lands for one and twenty years, it ≈øhall be intended to begin pre≈øently; and he cited the Ca≈øe betwixt Fox and Collier upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. cencerning Lea≈øes made by Bi≈øhops: That four years of a former Lea≈øe being in being, the Bi≈øhop lea≈øed for one and twenty years, the ≈øame was a good lea≈øe, notwith≈øtanding the former lea≈øe, for the lea≈øe began pre≈øently betwixt the parties. And it hath been adjudged, that a lea≈øe for years by a Bi≈øhop, to begin at a day to come, is utterly void. And he cited the Ca≈øe of the late Marque≈øs of Northampton, who by ≈øuch an Act of Parliament as ours was enabled to make lea≈øes of the Lands of his Wife for one and twenty years, and of the ≈øaid Lands an ancient lea≈øe was made before the ≈øaid Act, which was in e≈ø≈øe, and before the expiration thereof he made a lea≈øe by virtue of the ≈øaid Act to commence after the expiration of the former lea≈øe, and that lea≈øe was allowed to be a good lea≈øe warranted by the ≈øaid Statute, becau≈øe that the fir≈øt lea≈øe, which was in e≈ø≈øe, was not made by force of the ≈øaid Act, but if the ≈øaid former lea≈øe had been made by virtue of the ≈øaid Statute, the ≈øecond lea≈øe had been utterly void.

div.head: XLV. Trin. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Copy-hold. Surrender by Attorney not good. A Copy-holder of the Manor of the Earl of Arrundel did ≈øurrender his cu≈øtomary Lands to the u≈øe of his la≈øt Will, and thereby devi≈øed the Lands to his younge≈øt Son and his Heirs, and died, the younge≈øt Son being in pri≈øon makes a Letter of Attorney to one to be admitted to the Land in the Lords Court in his room, and al≈øo after admittance to ≈øurrender the ≈øame to the u≈øe of B. and his Heirs, to whom he had ≈øold it for the payment of his debts: And Wray was of opinion, that it was a good ≈øurrender by Attorney, but Gawdy and Clench contrary:3 Cro. 218. 9 Co. 75. and by Gawdy; If he who ought to ≈øurrender cannot come in Court to ≈øurrender in per≈øon, the Lord of the Manor may appoint a ≈øpecial Steward to go to the pri≈øon and take the ≈øurrender, &c. and by Clench; Le≈ø≈øee for years cannot ≈øurrender by Attorney, but he may make a deed purporting a ≈øurrender, and a letter of Attorney to another to deliver it.

div.head:
XLVI. Troublefield and Troublefields Ca≈øe.
Trin. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Dy. 337. b. Co. 1 In≈øt. 15. 2. b. 52. 245. b. 252. 6. Po≈øt. 51. Entry.THe Ca≈øe was, that a Copy-holder did ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of his Will and thereby devi≈øed the Land to his Wife for life, the remainder over to his ≈øon in tail, and died, the Wife entred, and died, a ≈øtranger did intrude upon the Lands, and thereof made three ≈øeveral Feoffments to three ≈øeveral per≈øons, he in the Remainder entred upon one of the ≈øaid three Feoffees in the name of all the Lands ≈øo devi≈øed, and made a lea≈øe of the whole Land: And by Clench and Wray it was a good Entry for the whole, and by con≈øequence, a good lea≈øe of the whole, Gawdy contrary: Note, all the Lands were in one County: See 16 Eliz. Dyer 337. 9 H. 7. 25.

div.head:
XLVII. Parmort and Griffina's Ca≈øe.
Trin. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Debt upon an Obligation by Parmort again≈øt Griffina a Merchant-≈øtranger, the Defendant pleaded,Debt. that the Obligation was made upon condition for the performance of certain Covenants contained within certain Indentures, and ≈øhewed what, &c. and alledged further, that in the ≈øaid Indenture there is a provi≈øo, that if aliqua lis, vel controver≈øia oriatur impo≈øterum, by rea≈øon of any clau≈øe, article, or other agreement in the ≈øaid Indenture contained, that then, before any ≈øute thereupon attempted the parties ≈øhall choo≈øe four indifferent per≈øons for the ending thereof, which being done, the Indenture and Obligation ≈øhall be void: And in fact ≈øaith, that Lis & controver≈øia, upon which the Action is brought, groweth upon the ≈øaid Indenture, upon which there was a demurrer in Law. And becau≈øe the Defendant hath not ≈øhewed ≈øpecially upon what controver≈øie or ≈øtrife, and upon what article certain: The Court was clear of opinion, that the Bat was not good: And al≈øo the Court was of opinion,Provi≈øo taken ≈øtrictly. that the ≈øaid Provi≈øo did not extend to ≈øubject and ≈øubmit the breach of every Covenant or Article within the ≈øaid Indenture to the Arbitrament of the ≈øaid four per≈øons, but only where ≈øtrife and controver≈øie doth ari≈øe upon the con≈øtruction of any Covenant, &c. within the ≈øaid Indenture; ≈øo as the Defendant ought to have ≈øhewed ≈øuch matter which fell within the Arbitrament, by the meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture; and Iudgment was given again≈øt the Defendant.

div.head:
XLVIII. Partridge and Partridges Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN Dower by Partridge again≈øt Partridge, the Ca≈øe was,Dower. that Land was given to the Father for life, the rever≈øion to his Son and Heir for life, the remainder to the right Heirs of the body of the Father: The Father and Son joyn in a Feoffment to the Vncle in Fee, ≈øcil. to the Brother of the Father. The Vncle takes a Wife, the Father dieth, the Son being his Heir in tail, the Vncle dieth without i≈ø≈øue, ≈øo as the Land de≈øcendeth to the Son, as Heir to his Vncle, again≈øt whom the Wife of the Vncle brought Dower: It was moved, if the Son being Herein can to his Father, and Heir al≈øo to his Vncle, for the Fee de≈øcended, be now remitted? for then no Dower accrueth to the Wife of the Vncle, for the e≈øtate of which ≈øhe demands Dower is gone: but if the livery in which the Son joyned with his Father be the livery of the Son,Remitt ‚Ä¢
the ≈øame lies in his way in the impediment and preventing of the Remitter, ≈øo as during his life he ≈øhall be adjudged ≈øei≈øed of the Lands in Fee≈øimple by de≈øcent from his Vncle: Then Dower lyeth, for the ≈øame e≈øtate is inherited, of which the Wife demandeth her Dower: And the Court doubted, if it were the livery of the Son or not. And note, that the Feoffment was without deed. See Dyer 16 Eliz. 339.

div.head: XLIX. The Queen again≈øt the Lord Vaux and others. Mich. 28 & 29 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
A Bill of Intru≈øion was brought for the Queen again≈øt the Lord Vaux, Rich. Vaux, & Hen. Vaux, Intru≈øion. ≈øuppo≈øing to have intruded into the Rectory & Par≈øonage of Ethelborough in the County of Northampton, & ≈øhewed
that in the time of Hen. the fourth, the Colledge of Saint Peter of Ethelborough was founded at We≈øtmin≈øter, in the County of Midd. by the name of Decani & capituli; and ≈øhewed further, that the Rectory of Ethelborough, was appropriated to the ≈øaid Colledge, and that afterwards by the Statute of 1 E. 6. the ≈øaid Colledge was di≈ø≈øolved, and the ≈øaid Rectory, among≈øt other po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Colledge, came to the hands of the King, and that the Defendants, 1. Eliz. intruded into the ≈øaid Rectory, and took one thou≈øand Sheep, one thou≈øand Calves, and one thou≈øand Loads of Corn, bona & catalla dictae Dominae Reginae provenientia ex decimis rectoriae praedict. apud We≈øtm. predict. The Defendants pleaded, &c. That the ≈øaid Colledge of Ethelborough was founded in Ethelborough, Foundation. &c. per nomen Decani, canonicorum, & fratrum, &c. who lea≈øed the ≈øaid Rectory ≈øo appropriated to one Clark for forty ≈øix years, in Anno 30 H. 8. who a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øame to the Defendants, by force of which they ju≈øtified the taking at Ethelborough, ab≈øque hoc, that the ≈øaid Colledge of Saint Peter in Ethelborough, was founded, per nomen Decani & capituli Eccle≈øiae Sancti Petri de Ethelborough, at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, & ab≈øque hoc, that they took the ≈øaid Sheep, &c. at We≈øtmin≈øter, &c. Vpon which the Queens Attorny did demur in Law. Manwood chief Baron argued; that Iudgment ought to be given for the Queen: Exception hath been taken to the Information, becau≈øe mention is made in it of a Colledge, and it is not ≈øhewed what per≈øon was the Founder: And al≈øo an appropriation is alleadged of the Rectory afore≈øaid to the ≈øaid Colledge, and the Appropriation is not ≈øhewed certain, who was Patron, Ordinary, &c. as to that he argued that the alledging of the Appropriation and foundation, is but matter of ≈øurplu≈øage, and therefore the in≈øufficiency of alledging the ≈øame ≈øhall not prejudice the Queen, for it had been ≈øufficient to ≈øay, That the ≈øaid Colledge of St. Peter, was ≈øei≈øed of the Rectory afore≈øaid, and then to ≈øhew the Statute of Chauntries, 1 E. 6. and the ≈øame is a good title for the Queen, The po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Colledge, and the Di≈ø≈øolution of it by the Statute: For this Bill of intru≈øion is but in the Nature of a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øory action,Colledge in Reputation. as an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, in which ca≈øe it is ≈øufficient to make title to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion only, without relying upon the right; but as to the curious and exact pleading of an appropriation, or a foundation, it needs not in this ca≈øe; for admit that the Colledge were not well and duly founded, yet ≈øuch pleading is ≈øufficient, for a Colledge in Reputation is within the Statute of 1 E. 6. and where the party claims by or under ≈øuch Foundation, there the Foundation ought to be certainly ≈øhewed, not preci≈øely but conveniently,General pleading. not as we plead a common Recovery, but as we plead the creation of a Bi≈øhop, ≈øcil. debito modo praefectus, without ≈øhewing the particulars of the creation, ≈øo if an Abbot will plead in di≈øcharge of his Hou≈øe of a Corody, he ought to ≈øhew the Foundation, and convenient certainty, which ≈øee L. 5. E. 4. 118. Robert Milam founded the Abby of Leice≈øter, and conveyed the right of Patronage and founder≈øhip to the King by Attainder, and the ≈øame was good pleading, without ≈øhewing the particulars of the Foundation ≈øpecially, ≈øo 3 H. 7. 6. in the Ca≈øe of the Priory of Norwich, the pleading is, quod Prioratus de Norwich e≈øt de fundatione Epi≈øcoporum Norwich, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe, refert quis ≈øit Fundor, ≈øo the King be not Founder; but in our ca≈øe, non refert quis fit Fundor, for who≈øoever be Founder, whether the King, or a Subject, all is one, the Statute in both Ca≈øes gives the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to the King: And as to the ca≈øe of Appropriation, the pleading thereof is well, if it be conveniently ≈øhewed, in ca≈øe where the party who ≈øhews it claimes by ≈øuch Appropriation, as 6 H. 7. 14. 11. H. 7. 8. Concurrentibus his quae de jure, &c. without ≈øhewing the particulars of the Appropriation. Now in our ca≈øe, the Queen is meerly a ≈øtranger to this Appropriation, and ≈øhe doth not claim by it, but the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Colledge is the title of the Queen, by the Statute of 1. E. 6. and therefore it ≈øufficeth for the Queen to ≈øhew that the Colledge was ≈øei≈øed, &c.
without making mention of the manner of the Appropriation: And as to the traver≈øe of the County, he conceived, that the County, is not traver≈øable in this ca≈øe, for when the Tithes are ≈øevered from the nine parts, they are pre≈øently ve≈øted in the party who hath right,Traver≈øe. and they are things tran≈øitory, and al≈øo the taking of them, for the party may take them in any place as well as in his own Pari≈øh, ≈øcil. as well at We≈øtmin≈øter, where the Queen ≈øuppo≈øeth the taking, as at Ethelborough where the Defendant doth ju≈øtify, &c. and in ≈øuch ca≈øes the place where is not traver≈øable. See ‚Ä¢
H. 6. 62, 63. by Babbington, 35 H. 6. 5. In Tre≈øpa≈øs of Goods taken in the Pari≈øh of Saint Clements, in the County of Midd. the Defendant did ju≈øtify by buying in open Market in the County of E≈ø≈øex, there needs no traver≈øe, for the Defendant hath made title by an open Market, 34 H. 6. 15, 16. In Tre≈øpa≈øs of Battery at D. in the County of E≈ø≈øex, the Defendant pleaded, that the Plaintiff made an a≈ø≈øault upon him at B. in the County of Kent, and the Defendant fled, and the Plaintiff pur≈øued him continually unto D. afore≈øaid, at which place the Defendant did defend him≈øelf, and ≈øo the hurt which the Plaintiff had was of his own a≈ø≈øault, and demanded Iudgment if Action, the ≈øame is a good Plea without traver≈øing of the County, for a Battery may be continued from one County to another. And it was ob≈øerved by Manwood in citing of that ca≈øe, that although, prima facie mirum videri pote≈øt that a Battery may be continued from E≈ø≈øex into Kent, becau≈øe the River of Thames is betwixt them, and yet, re intellecta, it is plain, for one parcel of Land containing thirty Acres of Lands of the Coa≈øts of E≈ø≈øex is within the County of Kent, See al≈øo 34. H. 6. 5. by Pri≈øot, In Tre≈øpa≈øs of Goods taken at Coventry, the Def. doth ju≈øtify the taking becau≈øe the Plaintiff gave the ≈øaid Goods to the Defendant at London, by force of which he took them at London, ab≈øque hoc, that he took them at Coventry, and that traver≈øe not holden good, for the Defendant by ≈øuch a gift might ju≈øtify the taking of the Goods in any place as well as in the place where the gift was made; but if in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Defendant had pleaded, that the Plaintiff delivered the ≈øaid goods to him at London to deliver them over to A. by force of which he took them at London, and delivered them over accordingly, in ≈øuch Ca≈øes the Defendant may well traver≈øe the place ≈øuppo≈øed by the Declaration, for by his Plea he hath confe≈ø≈øed an immediate delivery of the ≈øaid goods to him by the Plaintiff; and the delivery and the taking all at one time and at one place, and it had not been a good plea for the Defendant to ≈øay, that the Plaintiff delivered to him the ≈øaid goods at London, by force of which he took them at Coventry, for the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is confe≈ø≈øed by the fir≈øt delivery of the goods at London; and the ≈øuppo≈øal of the Plaintiff of a taking in Coventry, and the ju≈øtification of the Defendant of a taking by rea≈øon of a delivery at London, cannot ≈øtand together. But if the Defendant plead, that the Plaintiff gave to him the goods in London, by force of which he took them there, there he may take traver≈øe to the place ≈øuppo≈øed by the Declaration, for by the gift it is lawful to the Defendant to take the goods in any place. So ≈øee 19 H. 6. 35. In fal≈øe Impri≈øonment ≈øuppo≈øed in the County of W. the Defendant doth ju≈øtify as Sheriff of the County of B. by force of a Writ to him directed to attach the Plaintiff, and ≈øo he attached him and impri≈øoned him at C. in the County of B. there the Defendant traver≈øed the County ≈øuppo≈øed by the Declaration, for otherwi≈øe he doth not meet with the Plaintiff, and the authority of the Defendant doth not extend to the County ≈øuppo≈øed by the Declaration. See al≈øo to the ≈øame purpo≈øe 22 E. 4. 39. by Hu≈ø≈øy, where the difference is taken when ju≈øtification is by rea≈øon of a Warrant to take goods in any place what≈øoever, and where in a place certain, as to the traver≈øe of the Foundation, ab≈ø
que hoc, quod praedict. Collegium fundatum fuit per nomen Decani, & Capituli Eccle≈øiae colleglatae Sancti Petri de Ethelborough apud We≈øtm. he hath
here traver≈øed that which was not alledged, for the placing of the la≈øt words of the traver≈øe, ≈øcil. apud We≈øtmin≈øt. in the end of the traver≈øe ≈øeems by common con≈øtruction to be intended thereby, that there is no ≈øuch Colledge at We≈øtm. and not that the Colledge was not founded at We≈øtm. for then the traver≈øe ≈øhould be, ab≈øque hoc, quod collegium praedictum fundatum fuit at We≈øtmin≈øter, per nomen, &c. But the mo≈øt proper traver≈øe, that the Defendant could have taken in this ca≈øe had been, ab≈øque hoc, quod Decanus & Capitulum Eccle≈øiae collegiat. de Ethelborough was ≈øei≈øed; for the Corporation mentioned in the Bill, and that which is mentioned in the Bar, are not all one, but differ in this manner, ≈øcil. in the Bill the Dean and Chapter, &c. in the Bar the Dean, Cannons, and Bretheren, and perhaps there are two ≈øuch Corporations, and then both cannot be ≈øei≈øed, and therefore upon the ≈øei≈øin of one of them, the traver≈øe ≈øhall be taken: And afterward Iudgment was given for the Queen.

div.head:
L. The Queen, again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of London, and Scot.
Mich. 28 & 29. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Quare Impedit. 3 Len. 175.THe Queen brought a Quare impedit again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of London, and Scot, and the Ca≈øe was, that A. ≈øei≈øed of an Advow≈øon in gro≈øs, holden of the Queen in chief, aliened the ≈øame by Fine without Licence; the Church became void, the Conu≈øee pre≈øented; The Queen without office found, brought a Quare impedit, the que≈øtion was, if the Queen without office found,Office trove. ≈øhould pre≈øent; And it was argued by the whole Court, that if the Alienation had been by Deed only, that there the Queen without office found ≈øhould not have had the pre≈øentment, for upon ≈øuch an Alienation by matter in fact, without Licence no Scire facias ≈øhould i≈ø≈øue without office found of the Alienation,Scire facias. but upon an Alienation without Licence by matter of Record, a Scire facias lyeth before office, which was granted by the whole Court: And in the la≈øt ca≈øe the Queen ≈øhall have the mean profits from the time of the Scire facias returned, but in the fir≈øt ca≈øe from the time of the office found, See for that Stamford Prerogative, fol. penult. 8 E. 4. 4. It was al≈øo moved, if the Queen intituled to the pre≈øentment as above, pardoneth to the Conu≈øee all Alienations without Licence, and Intru≈øions, if the e≈øtate of the Incumbent be thereby confirmed, but the Court would not argue that point; but it was adjorned until another day.

div.head:
LI. Braybrooks Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28 & 29. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Pines levyed.THe Ca≈øe of one Braybrook was moved, which was, Land was given to A. for life, the Remainder to B. for life, the Remainder to the ≈øaid Braybrook in Fee: B. being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion levyed a Fine to a ≈øtranger, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit come ceo &c. A. dyed, if now Braybrook might enter for the forfeiture was the que≈øtion: And it was agreed by the whole Court, that by that Fine the Remainder in Fee is not touched, or di≈øcontinued,Co. 1 In≈øt. 251, b. 252. 2 Forfeiture. 9 Co. 104. Po≈øt. 211, 212. 1 Cro. 219. 220. but becau≈øe B. had done as much as in him lay for the di≈øpo≈øing of Fee-≈øimple by the Fine, and hath taken that upon him, the ≈øame amounts to a forfeiture: And it was al≈øo agreed by Ander≈øon and Periam, that if Tenant for life in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion leveyeth a Fine, &c. if the Le≈ø≈øor doth not enter within five years after, he ≈øhall be bounden: Windham contrary, for by him it is in the election of the Le≈ø≈øor to re-enter immediatly for the forfeiture, or to expect the death of the Le≈ø≈øee.

div.head:
LII. Will≈øhalge and Davidges Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Exchequer Chamber.
div.p: WIll≈øhalge brought Error in the Exchequer Chamber,En ‚Ä¢ r. upon the Statute of 27 Eliz. Cap. 8. again≈øt Davidge, upon a Iudgment given in the ‚Ä¢ ings Bench, Hill. 28. Eliz. and a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that where Davidge had heretofore brought Debt again≈øt the now Plaintiff, and declared upon diver≈øe Contracts, ≈øcil. that he had ≈øold to Will≈øhalge ≈øuch Merchandizes for ≈øo many Portugues, and ≈øuch Merchandizes for ≈øo many Ducats, which in toto amounted to ≈øeven hundred pounds Sterling, which ≈øum he demanded, ≈øcil. in Sterling many,2 Cro. 88. 3 Cro. 536. Yel. 80. 135. 136. and not in Ducats and Portagues, according to the Contract; And upon the Declaration the ≈øaid Will≈øhalge had demurred in Law, and the Court gave Iudgment for the Plaintiff, for it is in his election to demand his debt in which of tho≈øe Coyns he plea≈øed, either in the proper Coyn of the Contract, or of Sterling, ≈øcil. in currant mony. And afterwards the ≈øaid Iudgment was affirmed.

div.head:
LIII. Henly and Broads Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p: HEnly brought Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Broad in the Kings Bench,3 Len. 77: Tre≈øpa≈øs. and declared, that the ≈øaid Defendant ≈øimul cum quodam I. S. clau≈øum ≈øuum fregit, &c. The Defendant pleaded to I≈ø≈øue, and it was found for the Plaintiff, and it was objected in ≈øtay of Iudgment, that the count was not good, for it appeareth therein, upon the ≈øhewing of the Plaintiff him≈øelf, that the Action ought to be brought again≈øt another al≈øo, not named in the Writ,Counts. and becau≈øe the ≈øame appears of the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing, the Declaration was not good, and notwith≈øtanding that ≈øaid Exception, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff. Vpon which Broad brought a Writ of Error, and a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øame matter for Error; And there the Ca≈øe of 2 H. 7. 16. 17. was cited,Error. where a difference is taken, where the Plaintiff declares, that the Defendant with one B. did the Tre≈øpa≈øs, him naming in certain, and where the Declaration is, that the Defendant, cum quibu≈ødam alijs ignotis, &c. See 8. H. 5. 5. And at length all the Iu≈øtices of the common Pleas, and Barons of the Exchequer were clear of opinion, that by the common Law the Declaration was not good, for the rea≈øon, and upon the difference afore≈øaid: but if in Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt one, who pleads that the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done by him≈øelf and one B. to whom the Plaintiff hath relea≈øed, and the Plaintiff traver≈øe the Relea≈øe, in that ca≈øe, for as much as the matter doth not appear upon the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing, but comes in on the part of the Defendant, and not denied by him, the Declaration is good enough: And it was further agreed by them all, that now this defect after Verdict is helped by the Statute of 18 Eliz. for it doth not concern ≈øub≈øtance but only form: And afterwards the fir≈øt Iudgment was affirmed.

div.head:
LIV. Wood and Fo≈øters Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.

LV. Carters Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: CArter brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt I.S. and declared,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. that A. was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of certain Lands for years, the Inheritance thereof being in the Wife of the Plaintiff, upon which Lea≈øe a Rent was re≈øerved: The Defendant, in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff would procure the ≈øaid A. to a≈ø≈øign the ≈øaid Lea≈øe to the Defendant promi≈øed to pay the ≈øaid Rent to the Plaintiff for all the re≈øidue of the Term: It was objected that upon this matter the Action doth not lie, becau≈øe that the Plaintiff hath a higher remedy, ≈øcil. an Action of Debt or Di≈øtre≈øs; but the opinion of the whole Court was that the Action did lie, for here upon the promi≈øe an Action is given to the Husband alone in his own right, whereas the Rent is due to the Husband in the right of his Wife in its nature, and the Rent is al≈øo to be paid for the Land.
