But upon this A≈ø≈øump≈øit it is payable to the per≈øon of the Husband. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
LVI. Kimpton, and Bellamyes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.

LVII. Knights Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: KNight brought Debt again≈øt three Executors, and now ≈øurmi≈øed by his Coun≈øel, that one of the Executors is dead, pendant the Writ;Debt. and prayed the opinion of the Court, if the Writ ≈øhould thereby abate or not; for by ≈øome it is not like where a Writ is brought again≈øt two Executors,Abatement of Writ. for there if any of them dieth, pendant the Writ, it ≈øhall abate, for now the plural number is gone, for there is but one Executor, but in our Ca≈øe the plural number continues: But notwith≈øtanding that, the Court was clear of opinion, that the Writ ≈øhould abate: Wherefore the Plaintiff ≈øeeing the opinion of the Court, prayed that upon his ≈øurmi≈øe afore≈øaid, he might have a new Writ by Iourneys Accounts, which was granted to him.

div.head: The Queen and Middletons Ca≈øe. Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Quare Imped.THe Queen brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt Middleton, and counted, that W. Lord Say was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Bedington in the County of Hertford, to which Manor the advow≈øon of the Church was appendant, & ad Eccle≈øiam praedict. prae≈øentavit Coo Clericum ≈øuum, and afterwards died ≈øei≈øed, having i≈ø≈øue two Daughters, Mary married to the Earl of E≈ø≈øex and Ann to the Lord Mountjoy, who make partition, and the ≈øaid Manor of Bedington, inter alia, was allotted to the ≈øaid Mary for her part; and afterwards the ≈øaid Earl and Mary died, having i≈ø≈øue Ann, who took to Husband the Marque≈øs of Northampton, and afterwards 33 H. 8. a Fine was levyed of the ≈øaid Manor inter &c. Querent. and the ≈øaid Marque≈øs and Ann Deforceants,
by which Fine the ≈øaid Manor was granted and rendred to the ≈øaid Marque≈øs for term of his life, the remainder to the ≈øaid Ann his Wife in tail, the remainder over to Hen. the eighth in Fee; the Marque≈øs is attainted of High Trea≈øon, by which the King ≈øei≈øed, and afterwards Ann died without i≈ø≈øue, after which in the ≈øei≈øin of the Queen that now is the Church voided, by which it belonged to the Queen to pre≈øent; The Defendant did confe≈øs the ≈øei≈øin of the Lord Say, and the whole matter contained in the Count until the Attainder; and pleaded further, that after the ≈øaid Attainder Queen Mary lea≈øed the ≈øaid Manor with the advow≈øon to Roche≈øter and Walgrave for forty years, if the ≈øaid Marque≈øs ≈øhould ≈øo long live, who were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed accordingly, and in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the Church became void, to which Avoidance one Twiniko did pre≈øent the Defendant, who upon his pre≈øentment was in≈øtituted and inducted: Vpon which Plea the Queens Serjeant did demur in Law. It was argued by Serjeant Shuttleworth for the Queen, That the counter-pleading of the title of the Queen by the Incumbent, without ≈øhewing title in his own Patron could not be good, nothwith≈øtanding the Statute of 25 E. 3. Cap. 7. before which Statute, the Incumbent could not plead any matter which went to the right of the Patronage, but only in di≈øcharge or excu≈øe of the di≈øturbance, and therefore we ought to ob≈øerve the words of the ≈øaid Statute, ≈øc. the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor ≈øhall be received to counter-plead the Kings title, and to have his An≈øwer, and to defend his Right upon the matter, although he claim nothing in the Patronage; upon all which words taken together it appeareth, that the Incumbent ought not only to counter-plead the title of the King, but al≈øo to ≈øhew and defend his own right, and that hath not the Defendant done here; For Twiniko, of who≈øe pre≈øentment he is in the Church, doth not claim under the lea≈øe made by Queen Mary to Roche≈øter and Walgrave, but during their ≈øaid Lea≈øe and their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it, by u≈øurpation pre≈øented the Defendant, 46 E. 3. 13. by Finchden, The King brought a Scire fac. upon a Recovery in a Quare Impedit, the Defendant being Incumbent pleaded, that after the ≈øaid Iudgment the King had pre≈øented to the ≈øaid Church I.S. his Clerk, who was admitted accordingly; and exception was taken becau≈øe the Defendant did not ≈øhew a title in him≈øelf to maintain his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but it was not allowed; for a difference is taken betwixt a Plea in a Quare Impedit, and a Plea in a Scire facias, Where in pleading the party mu≈øt make title to him≈øelf. for in a Scire facias it is ≈øufficient to extort the Plaintiff of execution without any title, contrary in a Quare impedit: And it is a general Rule, that in all Ca≈øes where an Office is to be traver≈øed, none ≈øhall be received to traver≈øe the title of the King, without making a title to him≈øelf, which ≈øee 38 E. 3. 18. So in the Ca≈øe of the Lady Wingfield, 3 H. 7. 14. and Stamford 63, 64. And it is true in Actions real it is ≈øufficient to traver≈øe the title of the Demandant, without making title to the Tenant him≈øelf: As in a Formedon, Ne dona pas; But in Actions per≈øonal it is otherwi≈øe, as 2 H. 4, 14. In Ravi≈øhment of Ward, it is not ≈øufficient to traver≈øe the title of the Plaintiff, but the Defendant ought al≈øo to make title to him≈øelf. Fenner Serjeant contrary: who took exception to the Writ,2 Len. 5 ‚Ä¢ . becau≈øe it is brought again≈øt the Incumbent only without naming the Patron or Ordinary: For here the Defendant hath pleaded, that he is Par≈øon imper≈øonee of the Church afore≈øaid of the pre≈øentment of the ≈øaid Twiniko, and that he is admitted, in≈øtituted and inducted, and hath continued in his Church ≈øo many days and years, in which Ca≈øe the Writ ought to have been brought as well again≈øt the Patron and Ordinary, as again≈øt him the Incumbent: But in ≈øome Ca≈øes it is ≈øufficient again≈øt the Incumbent only, as upon a Collation by Lap≈øe, 9 H. 6. 32. by Babbington: So where the Defendant is di≈øturber without any pre≈øentment, 7 H. 4. 93. ≈øo where the Defendant was deprived, and kept him≈øelf in 4 E. 4. 18. So where the Pope makes Provi≈øion, 11 H. 4. Quare Impedit 120. So a Scire facias upon a Recovery
in a Quare Imped. ≈øhall be brought again≈øt the Incumbent only 1 H. 5. 8. for by the Iudgment in the Quare impedit, the right of the Patronage is bound; and the Scire facias is only for the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which concerns the Defendant only, and no other. And to prove that by the Common Law, a Quare Impedit lay not (but upon ≈øuch ≈øpecial matter) again≈øt the Incumbent alone, it is clear upon the ≈øaid Statute of 25 E. 3. For before the ≈øaid Statute the Incumbent could not plead any matter which did trench to the right of the Patronage, and therefore we ought not to pre≈øume that the common Law was ≈øo unrea≈øonable to give an Action again≈øt a ≈øingular per≈øon, who could not by the Law ≈øhew and defend his own right, nor traver≈øe the right of the other party: And as to the plea here, he conceived that the ≈øame plea which the Patron might have now after the Statute of 25 E. 3. the Incumbent ≈øhall have; but he who is only a di≈øturber not in by pre≈øentment, &c. he ≈øhall not plead any matter but in di≈øcharge or excu≈øe of the di≈øturbance, 47 E. 3. 8. The King in a Quare Impedit counted, That King H. was ≈øei≈øed, and pre≈øented one A. King H. died, and the Advow≈øon de≈øcended to King E. 3. A. died, the now King pre≈øented B. and now B. is dead, ≈øo it belongs to the King to pre≈øent; that the Defendant being Incumbent traver≈øed the in≈øtitution and induction of B. without making title to him≈øelf. So 44 E. 3. 19. in a Quare Impedit the King declared that he him≈øelf was ≈øei≈øed and pre≈øented one B. who at his pre≈øentment was received, &c. B. died, by which it belonged to the King to pre≈øent; to which the Defendant being Incumbent pleaded, that the ≈øaid B. is yet alive, and that plea was allowed without other title made to him≈øelf. Note, that at the fir≈øt Argument of this ca≈øe, that the Court was of opinion again≈øt the Defendant, becau≈øe he had not in his plea any intere≈øt in the Advow≈øon; and by Periam the Patron him≈øelf could not have had ≈øuch plea if he had been party to the Writ, therefore not the Incumbent; and it is no good pleading in any Action, to di≈øcover in pleading any wrong, as force, di≈ø≈øei≈øin, u≈øurpation. But at length, Mutata opinione, all the Iu≈øtices were agreed, that Iudgment ≈øhould be given again≈øt the Queen: And the Lord Ander≈øon ≈øhewed openly the rea≈øon of their Iudgment, for here is not bare u≈øurpation pleaded again≈øt the Queen, but al≈øo an e≈øtate, ≈øcil. a Lea≈øe for years in the ≈øaid Advow≈øon derived from Queen Mary, and that the Avoidance upon which the Action is brought falleth within the ≈øaid Term, ≈øo as the Queen who is Plaintiff is encountred with the Lea≈øe of her Ance≈øtor, again≈øt which ≈øhe cannot make title to pre≈øent, without ≈øpecial matter; wherefore Iudgment was given again≈øt the Queen.

div.head:
LIX. Kynters Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Debt. KYnter brought debt upon an Obligation, the condition was, that whereas the Plaintiff had bought of the Defendant a Ship, if then the Defendant ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øaid Ship, with all the furniture belonging to the ≈øame without being di≈øturbed for the ≈øaid Ship or any furniture appertaining to it; that then, &c. and the Ca≈øe was, that after the ≈øale of the ≈øaid Ship a ≈øtranger ≈øued the Plaintiff for certain monies due for certain Balla≈øt bought by the Defendant for the ≈øame Ship and put into the ≈øaid Ship before the ≈øale of it, and in the ≈øaid ≈øuit the Plaintiff obtained a Iudgment and Execution, and thereupon the ≈øaid Ship was ≈øei≈øed, and all the matter was, if Balla≈øt be furniture of a Ship or not; And it was moved by Serjeant Gawdy, that it was; for Balla≈øt is as nece≈ø≈øary to a Ship as a Sail; but the Court was again≈øt him, for ≈øomtimes a Ship may ≈øail without Balla≈øt, for it may be laden with ≈øuch Merchandizes which are convenient Balla≈øt in them≈øelves, as Coals,
Wheat, &c. Periam at the fir≈øt doubted of it: and by him, if I be bound upon condition, ut ≈øupra, I am bound to deliver the Guns being in it at the time of the ≈øale, but yet he conceived, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould be barred becau≈øe he had not ≈øpecially ≈øhewed, that at the time of the ≈øale the Balla≈øt was in the Ship.

div.head:
LX. Pendleton and Gun≈øtons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: PEndleton informed again≈øt Gun≈øton upon the Statute of 13 Eliz. Cap. 5. for that, where the ≈øaid Pendleton had before brought a plaint of Debt again≈øt I.S. in the Guild-Hall of Norwich; upon which i≈ø≈øued out of the ≈øaid Court an Attachment again≈øt the ≈øaid I.S. by which the Sheriff of Norw. being ready by virtue of the ≈øaid proce≈øs to attach the ≈øaid I. S. by his goods, there, the now Defendant in di≈øturbance of the ≈øaid proce≈øs and the execution of it, did publi≈øh and ≈øhew to the Sheriff a conveyance, by which he claimed the ≈øaid goods as conveyed to him by the ≈øaid I. S, &c. and averred the fraud, &c. and it was moved by Serjeant Snagg, that the matter of which the Defendant is charged is not within the ≈øaid Statute, becau≈øe the avowing of the ≈øaid conveyance doth not go in delay of the execution; for no Iudgment is given but only in delay of proce≈øs; but the Court was clear of opinion to the contrary, and that by rea≈øon of the Statute and the words of it, ≈øcil. delay, hinder, or defraud Creditors of their ju≈øt and lawful Actions, ≈øutes, &c. for here is a delay; for want of ≈øerving the ≈øaid Attachment, the Appearance of I.S. to the ≈øute of the Plaintiff is delayed, which mi≈øchief is within the remedy of the ≈øaid Statute. And Periam and Rhodes Iu≈øtices conceived, that ≈øuch avowing of ≈øuch conveyance, where no ≈øute is depending is within the ≈øaid Statute, which Ander≈øon doubted. See the pleading of this Ca≈øe reported in the ≈øecond Book of Entries, 207, 208. 30 Eliz. per quod ≈øecta impedita fult, &c.

div.head: LXI. Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: FEnner Serjeant moved this Ca≈øe.4 Len. Alien, Purcha≈øor. An Alien purcha≈øeth Lands in Fee; The Queen confirms it to the Alien, Office is found, if the confirmation ≈øhall bind the Queen; and it ≈øeemed to ≈øome that it ≈øhould, for by the Lord Ander≈øon, Confirmation. when an Alien is enfeoffed he receiveth by the Livery the Fee-≈øimple, of which he ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed, until Office be found; and a Praecipe quod reddat lyeth again≈øt him. And by Fenner an Alien and Denizen Ioynt-tenants are di≈ø≈øei≈øed, they both ≈øhall joyn in A≈ø≈øize, vide 11 H. 4. 26. and by him, the Kings Nief being an Inheritrix takes a Husband, and hath i≈ø≈øue, Office is found, the Husband ≈øhall be Tenant by the Curte≈øy, which ≈øee 33 E. 3. Traver≈øe 36. It was argued of the other ≈øide, that the e≈øtate of the Alien is ≈øo feeble that a confirmation cannot enure upon it; for an Alien cannot take but to the u≈øe of the King, and cannot be enfeoffed to another u≈øe; and if he be, ≈øuch u≈øe is void, for there is not a ≈øufficient ≈øei≈øin in the Alien to carry an u≈øe. And it hath been adjudged in the Ca≈øe of one Forcet, that where an Alien and the ≈øaid Forcet were Ioynt-purcha≈øors, and the Alien died, Forcer had not the whole by the Survivor, but that upon an Office found, the Queen ≈øhould have the moyety: See Dyer 11 Eliz. 283.

div.head:
LXII. Sir Roger Lewknor and Fords Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
1 Cro. 17. Co. 5. Rep. 12. b.SIr Roger Lewknor ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Wallingford, lea≈øed the ≈øame to A. for years, and died, after which it was Enacted by Parliament, That the ≈øaid Manor ≈øhould from henceforth be deemed and reputed in the Heirs of the body of the ≈øaid Sir Roger, begotten upon Eliz. his Wife, the ≈øaid Sir Roger having three Daughters only, without any other i≈ø≈øue: The Daughters married Husbands and had i≈ø≈øue: A. a≈ø≈øigned his entere≈øt in the ≈øaid Manor to B. C. and D. and al≈øo to one Shelley; B.C. and D. a≈ø≈øigned their intere≈øt to one Sponer, one of the Defendants, and Shelly a≈ø≈øigned his fourth part to Ford another of the Defendants, excepting the Woods and Vnderwoods. Wa≈øt is committed; one of the Daughters having i≈ø≈øue dieth, living her Husband, the two ≈øurviving Si≈øters and their Husbands, the Term being expired, brought a Writ of Wa≈øt, leaving out the Husband of the third Si≈øter, who was Tenant by the Curte≈øy, again≈øt Shelley and Sponer, who Tenuerunt. Shuttleworth Serjeant took Exception to the Writ: ≈øcil. praedictus Rogerus cujus haeredes ip≈øae funt, which ≈øhall be intended Heirs general, and by the Declaration it appeareth, that the Daughters have to them by Act of Parliament an e≈øpecial inheritance as Heirs in ≈øpecial tail, and that by a ≈øpecial conveyance: and therefore the Plaintiffs ought to have brought a ≈øpecial Writ, according to their Ca≈øe, as where Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, maketh a lea≈øe for years by the Statute of 1 R. 3. and the Le≈ø≈øee committeth Wa≈øt, now the Feoffees ought to have a ≈øpecial Writ of Wa≈øt, according to their Ca≈øe, 26 H. 8. 6. but that exception was di≈øallowed, and the ca≈øe cited out of 6 H. 8. is upon another rea≈øon, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe the e≈øtate of the Le≈ø≈øee for years is created by the ≈øaid Statute. Another Exception was taken to the Writ, for the Writ is tenuerunt, which ≈øhall be intended prima facie, conjunctim tenuerunt, and in the Declaration it appeareth, that one of the Defendants is a≈ø≈øignee of three parts of the Lands demi≈øed, and the other Defendant of the fourth part, and ≈øo ≈øeparatim tenuerunt, but that Exception was al≈øo di≈øallowed, becau≈øe originally it was one and intirely demi≈øed intere≈øt and e≈øtate, and ≈øo it remaineth as to the Plaintiffs, although it be devi≈øed by the Le≈ø≈øee him≈øelf. Another Exception was taken to the Writ, becau≈øe here it appears upon the Plaintiffs ≈øhewing, that Sir Roger Lewknor had three Daughters, and that they have all taken Husbands, and that they have i≈ø≈øue, and that one of the ≈øaid Daughters is dead, living her Husband, who is not named in the Writ, for which cau≈øe the Writ ≈øhall abate: See 22 H. 6. 24, 25. But that Exception was al≈øo di≈øallowed; for as this Ca≈øe is, there is not any rea≈øon, that the Tenant by the Curte≈øy ≈øhould joyn in this Action, for no judgment ≈øhall be given here, that the Plaintiffs ≈øhall recover the place wa≈øted, for the term is expired, as it appeareth by the words of the Writ, ≈øcil. quas tenuerunt, and the Tenant by the curte≈øy is in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and where Tenant by the curte≈øie and the Heir joyn in an Action of Wa≈øt, Tenant for life ≈øhall have Locum va≈øtatum, and the Heir the damages, which ≈øee 27 H. 8. 13. As unto the matter of Law, upon the Exceptions of Woods and Vnderwoods, it was argued by Shuttleworth, that the Action of Wa≈øt was not well brought again≈øt Ford, &c. for the A≈ø≈øignment made by Shelley to Ford was with an exception of all Woods and Vnderwoods, and therefore Shelley remained Tenant, and he ought to an≈øwer for the Wood and the Vnderwood in the Action of Wa≈øt, for upon every demi≈øe of Lands the Woods there growing are as well demi≈øed as the Land it ≈øelf, for ≈øo it appeareth by the Writ of Wa≈øt in domibus & bo≈øcis dimi≈ø≈øis ad terminum annorum, &c. which proves, that the Trees are parcel of
the demi≈øe, and ≈øo may be execepted: See Dyer 28 H 8. 19. by Shelley and Baldwin. A man lea≈øeth a Manor, except Woods and Underwoods, the Le≈ø≈øee cuts the Trees, an Action of Wa≈øt doth not lie again≈øt him for the ≈øame, for the thing in which the Wa≈øt is ≈øuppo≈øed to be committed was not demi≈øed, &c. and therefore the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall be puni≈øhed as a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor and not as Farmer: Fenner Serjeant contrary, and that the Exception of the Woods and Vnderwoods is meerly void; for Shelley who a≈ø≈øigns his intere≈øt with the ≈øaid Exception, hath not any ≈øuch intere≈øt in the Woods and Vnderwoods, ≈øo as he can make ≈øuch exception, for he had but an ordinary intere≈øt in them as Farmer, viz. Hou≈øe-boot, Hedge-boot, &c. which intere≈øt cannot by any means upon an A≈ø≈øignment be re≈øerved to the A≈ø≈øignor, in gro≈øs of the e≈øtate, no more than if one hath common appendant to his Land, and he will make a Feoffment of the Land, re≈øerving, or excepting the common. And he who hath the inheritance of the Land, hath an ab≈øolute property in the Trees, but the Le≈ø≈øee hath but a qualified intere≈øt, and therefore 21 H 6. 46. the Le≈ø≈øor during the term for years may command the Trees to be cut down: and 10 H. 7. 3. Le≈ø≈øee for years hath not any intere≈øt in the Trees, but for the loppings, and for the ≈øhadow for his Cattle: And in the Ca≈øe cited, where Le≈ø≈øee for life and he in the Rever≈øion make a Lea≈øe for life unto a ≈øtranger, and wa≈øt is committed,Co. 1 In≈øt. 42. 2. and they bring an Action of Wa≈øt, the Le≈ø≈øee for life ≈øhall have the place wa≈øted, and he in the Rever≈øion the treble damages, for in him was the true and very property of the Trees, and therefore the treble damages do belong unto him, and not to the Le≈ø≈øee for life, who joyneth with him; and the rea≈øon wherefore the Le≈ø≈øee for life or years ≈øhall recover treble damages again≈øt a ≈øtranger who cuts down any Trees growing upon the Land to him demi≈øed, is not in re≈øpect of any property that the Le≈ø≈øee hath in the Trees cut down, but becau≈øe he is chargable over to his Le≈ø≈øor in an Action of Wa≈øt, in which he ≈øhall render damages in ≈øuch proportion. So ≈øee 27 H. 6. Wa≈øt. 8. A lea≈øe for life is made without impeachment of wa≈øt, a ≈øtranger of his own wrong cuts down Trees, again≈øt whom the Le≈ø≈øee brings an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs; in ≈øuch Ca≈øe he ≈øhall not recover treble damages, not for the Trees, but only for the breaking of the Clo≈øe, and the loppings, for he is not chargeable over to his Le≈ø≈øor for the ≈øame, becau≈øe that his Lea≈øe was made without impeachment of Wa≈øt; and if the Le≈ø≈øee hath ≈øuch a ≈ølender intere≈øt in the Trees where his Lea≈øe is without impeachment of wa≈øt, his intere≈øt is le≈øs, where it is an ordinary lea≈øe without any ≈øuch priviledge: And the property which the Le≈ø≈øee for years hath in the Trees in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, is ≈øo appropriated to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, that it cannot be ≈øevered from it. Windham and Ander≈øon Iu≈øtices were of opinion, that the Exception above is meerly void: For Ford the A≈ø≈øignee of Shelly is now Termer and Farmer, who alone can challenge intere≈øt in the Trees again≈øt all but the Le≈ø≈øor, and Shelley after his A≈ø≈øignment, is meerly a ≈øtranger. The intere≈øt of the Le≈ø≈øee, and al≈øo of his A≈ø≈øignee in the Trees is of nece≈ø≈øity, and follows the Farm and the Land as the ≈øhadow doth the body; And by him, where Le≈ø≈øee for years by rea≈øon of his lea≈øe is to have Wind-fals, yet he cannot imploy them but to the benefit and profit of his Farm, for if he ≈øell them or ≈øpend them el≈øewhere he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed. Rhodes and Periam Iu≈øtices, that the exception is good, as the fruits of the Trees, Shovelers, &c. And afterwards the Ca≈øe was adjudged upon another point in the pleading, ≈øo as the matter in Law did not come to Iudgment: See Saunders Ca≈øe. 41 Eliz. Where Le≈ø≈øee doth a≈ø≈øign, excepting the Timber Trees, it is a void Exception.

div.head:
LXIII. Gray and Jeffes Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 55. Action of a≈ø≈øault and Batterry.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe by Gray again≈øt Jeffe, the Plaintiff declared, that where he had placed his Son and Heir apparent with the Defendant, to be his Apprentice, and to learn of him the Art of a Tailor: That the Defendant had ≈øo beaten his Son with a Spade, that he thereupon became lame, by rea≈øon of which he could not have ≈øo much with his Son in marriage of him as otherwi≈øe he might have, becau≈øe the ≈øame lamene≈øs is a di≈øparagement to his ≈øaid ≈øon: And further ≈øhewed, that he him≈øelf might ≈øpend twenty pounds per annum in Lands. Haulton argued for the Plaintiff. The Action Quare filium & haeredem cepit & abduxit, is given to the Father in con≈øideration that the marriage of his Son and Heir doth appertain to him by the Law, and here by the Battery the Son is become ≈øo ≈øame, that he is not ≈øo commendable to a Marriage as before, and if the Father had lo≈øt the whole marriage, then the Father ≈øhould have had the Action Quare filium & haeredem, &c. but here he hath not lo≈øt the whole marriage, but the marriage is le≈ø≈øened by it, and therefore he ≈øhall have this Action. Tanfield contrary; I confe≈øs, that the Father ought to have the marriage of his Son and Heir ≈øo long as he is ≈øub pote≈øtate patris; but here the Father hath committed all his intere≈øt, power and authority in his Son to the Defendant his Ma≈øter, with whom he hath bound his Son Apprentice for ≈øeven years, during which term the Father hath not any thing to do with his Son or his Marriage. Wray: The Action Quare filium & haeredem, &c. is not given to the Father, becau≈øe his marriage belongs to him, but becau≈øe of the Education; and ≈øuch was the opinion of Clench Iu≈øtice, and the marriage doth not belong properly to the Father: For if the Son marrieth him≈øelf without the leave of the Father there is not any remedy for the Father. And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
LXIV. Bullers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ evin. EDmund Buller brought a Replevin again≈øt two, who make Conu≈øans as Baylies to A. for rent arrear re≈øerved upon a lea≈øe for life, To which the Plaintiff in Bar of the Conu≈øans pleaded, that two ≈øtrangers had right of Entry in the place where,2 Len. 196. &c. and that the ≈øaid two Defendants by their Commandment entred, &c. and took the Cattle of which the Replevin is brought, damage fea≈øant, ab≈øque hoc, that they took them as Baylies to the ≈øaid A. and upon that Traver≈øe the Defendants did demur in Law.2 Len. 216. Po≈øt. 327. Shuttleworth Serjeant; the Traver≈øe is not good, for by that means the intent of the party ≈øhall be put in i≈ø≈øue, which no Iury can try, but only in Ca≈øe of Recaption. See 7 H. 4. 101. by Ga≈øcoign. If the Bayly upon the di≈øtre≈øs ≈øhews the cau≈øe and rea≈øon of it, he cannot afterwards vary from it, but the other party may trice him by Traver≈øe; but if he di≈øtrain generally without ≈øhewing cau≈øe, then he is at large to ≈øhew what cau≈øe he will, and the other party ≈øhall an≈øwer to it.
‚Ä¢ Co. 7 ‚Ä¢ . And it was ≈øaid by the Court, that when a Bayly di≈øtreins, he ought, if he be required, to ≈øhew the cau≈øe of his di≈øtre≈øs, but if he be not required, then he is not tied to do it. Ander≈øon. We were all agreed in the Ca≈øe betwixt Lowin and Hordin, that the Traver≈øe, as it is here, was well taken. The Number Roll of that Ca≈øe is M. 28, & 29 Eliz. 2494.

div.head:
LXV. Hud≈øon and Leighs Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: HUd≈øon recovered again≈øt Leigh in an Action of Battery, for which a Capias pro fine i≈ø≈øued again≈øt Leigh; and al≈øo a Capias ad Satisfaciendum, returnable the ≈øame Term at one and the ≈øame Return:Proce≈øs. As to the Capias pro fine the Sheriff returned Cepi, and as to the Capias ad Satisfaciendum, non e≈øt inventus: And for this contrariety of the Return, the Court was of opinion, that the Sheriff ≈øhould be amerced; but it was moved by the Council of the Sheriff,Return of the Sheriff. that the awarding of the Capias pro fine was meerly void, for the Fine is pardoned by the Parliament. And it is al≈øo Enacted, That all proce≈øs awarded upon ≈øuch Fines ≈øhall be void; and then the Capias pro fine being void, it matters not how or in what manner it be returned, for the Court ≈øhall not re≈øpect ≈øuch proce≈øs, nor any return of it, and then the Court not having re≈øepect to that Return, there is not any contrariety, for the Capias ad Satisfaciendum only is returned, and not the Capias pro fine. And at another day it was moved again; the Battery was ≈øuppo≈øed: Junij 1586. and Iudgment given the thirteenth of February the ≈øame year, upon which i≈ø≈øued Capias pro fine, E≈øcape. 5 Co. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . and before the Return thereof the Parliament ended, which pardoned ≈øuch Fines and made all proce≈øs thereupon void: And it was ≈øaid by the Court, that if the Sheriff in ≈øuch Ca≈øe takes the party by a Capias pro fine, now upon that taking he is in Execution for the party, and if the Sheriff let him go at large, he ≈øhall an≈øwer for the e≈øcape: And in that ca≈øe the Capias pro fine was well awarded, and the Court ought to regard it, and the Defendant lawfully taken by virtue of it, and al≈øo in execution for the party in Iudgment of Law; and afterward, when the Parliament came and Enacted ut ≈øupra, although the proce≈øs be made void thereby, the ≈øame ought to be meant as to the intere≈øt of the King in the Fine, and the vexation of the Subject by it, but not as to the Execution of the party, but the Sheriff ≈øhall an≈øwer for that.Execution. And it was al≈øo holden by the Court, that if the Plaintiff ≈øueth an Elegit, then upon the Capias pro fine executed, the Defendant ≈øhall not be adjudged in Execution for the party, for he hath made his Election of another manner of Execution, ≈øcil. of the Land, and he ≈øhall never re≈øort to an Execution of the body, 13 H 7. 12. And as our ca≈øe is there was an Elegit obtained, but it was not on Record, nor any Record made of it, and therefore the election of the Execution remained to the Plaintiff. And as to the point afore≈øaid, that ≈øuch proce≈øs ≈øhall be void as to the King only, not as to the party: See now 5 Ja. C. 6. part. 79. Sir Edward Phittons Ca≈øe.

div.head:
LXVI. Potter and Stedals Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN Trepa≈øs by Samuel Potter again≈øt Stedal the Ca≈øe was,Tre≈øpa≈øs. Tenant for life of Land lea≈øed parcel thereof to hold at Will, and being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the re≈øidue, levyed a Fine of the whole, the Le≈ø≈øor entred into the Land which was let at will in point of forfeiture, in the name of the whole; it was holden the ≈øame is a good entry for the whole:Ante 56. But if the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor lea≈øeth for years part of the Land, whereof the di≈ø≈øei≈øin was committed,Entry. 1 In≈øt. 252. and the di≈ø≈øei≈øee afterwards entreth into the Land which continueth in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor in the name of the whole, the ≈øame Entry ≈øhall not extend to the Land lea≈øed, for here the Le≈ø≈øee is in by title, but in the other Ca≈øe not, for when Tenant for life lea≈øeth it at will, and afterwards levies a Fine, the ≈øame is a determination
of the Will. 16 Eliz. Dyer 377. 1. In the ≈øame plea it was holden, that if there be le≈ø≈øee for life, the remainder for life, the remainder in fee, Le≈ø≈øee for life in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion levyeth a Fine Sur Conu≈øans de droit, &c. to his own u≈øe, upon that Fine a Fee-≈øimple accrues.

div.head:
LXVII. Leigh and Hanmers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Debt upon a Recognizance THomas Leigh E≈øquire brought an Action of Debt upon a Recognizance in the nature of a Statute Staple again≈øt John Hanmer E≈øquire, before the Mayor and Aldermen of Lond. in Camera Guild-hall Civitatis pr ‚Ä¢ ed. and demanded 1500 pounds, upon ≈øuch Recognizance acknowledged 20 November 20 Eliz. and upon default of the ≈øaid Hanmen, Owen 25. according to the cu≈øtom of London u≈øed in cour≈øe of Attachment, attached ≈øix hundred pounds in the hands of one W. Bolton of Grays-Inn, in part of ≈øatisfaction of the ≈øaid debt of one thou≈øand five hundred pounds; and now within the year came the ≈øaid Hanmer, & ad di≈øonerandum debitum praedicti had a precept of Scire facias again≈øt the ≈øaid Thomas Leigh, and after pleaded, and demanded Dyer of the ≈øaid Recognizance, and had it, & quod ip≈øe re≈øtitutionem of the ≈øaid 600 pounds, in manibus dict. W. Bolton attachiat. habere debet: And upon the whole Record the Ca≈øe was thus: Rowland Leigh E≈øquire, being ≈øei≈øed of certain Manors and other Lands in the County of Gloce≈øt. had i≈ø≈øue Eliz. his Daughter and Heir inheritable to the ≈øaid Lands, and by Indent. dated 20 Maii 19 Eliz. granted Cu≈øtodiam, regulam, gubernationem, educationem, maritagium dict. Eliz. to the ≈øaid Thomas Leigh, after which the ≈øaid Thomas Leigh by Indenture 14 Martii 29 Eliz. granted and a≈ø≈øign ‚Ä¢ d the ≈øaid cu≈øtody,Dyer 190, 191. rule, government, education, and marriage, and all his intere≈øt therein, and the ≈øaid Indenture, to Sir John Spencer, after which the ≈øaid Sir John Spencer and Thomas Leigh, by their Indenture the 26. of Augu≈øt 20 Eliz. granted and a≈ø≈øigned to the ≈øaid John Hanmer the ≈øaid cu≈øtody, rule, government, education and marriage o ‚Ä¢ the ≈øaid Eliz. and all their intere≈øt in the ≈øame, and all the recited Indenturs; by which la≈øt recited Indenture 29 Augu≈øt, the ≈øaid John Hanmer covenanted with the ≈øaid Leigh, that Thomas Hanmer Son and Heir apparent of the ≈øaid John Hanmer, maritaret & in uxorem duceret dictam Elizabetham: ad vel antequam dicta Eliz. & dictus Tho. Hanmer perimplerint, ≈øuas ≈øeparales aetates 14 annorum, ≈øi dicta Eliz. ad id conde≈øtendere & agreare vellet; and afterwards before the ≈øaid Tho. Hanmer and the ≈øaid Elizabeth, ≈øuas ≈øeparales aetates 14 annorum, perimplevi≈ø≈øent, ≈øc. 8 die Sept. 20 Eliz. the ≈øaid Tho. Hanmer took to wife the ≈øaid Eliz. the ≈øaid Tho. Hanmer then being aetatis 13 annorum and no more, and the ≈øaid Eliz. then being of the age of nine years and no more, and Tho. Hanmer afore≈øaid over-lived, &c. And pleaded further, that the ≈øaid Tho. Hanmer after he attained his full age of fourteen years, and before any agreement or a≈ø≈øent by the ≈øaid Tho. Hanmer to the marriage afore≈øaid betwixt the ≈øaid Tho. Hanmer and the ≈øaid Eliz. had, at or after, idem Thomas Hanmer came to his age of fourteen years, ≈øcil. 10 die Sept. Anno 22 Eliz. ad dictum matitagium di≈øagreavit, & maritagium illud renunciavit; and all this matter was pleaded in Bar, as performance of the Covenant contained in the Indenture of defeazance made upon the Recognizance, whereupon the Action is brought. And concluded his plea, unde petit, judicium ≈øi dictus Tho. Leigh actionem ≈øuam praed ‚Ä¢ ct &c. Et quod ip≈øe idem Johannes Hanmer re≈øtitutionem dict. 600 li ≈øc. ut praefert a ‚Ä¢ achiat habere valeat. And all the que≈øtion here was, if this marriage had by this manner, and afterwards renounced as is afore≈øaid, be ≈øuch a marriage as is intended in the Covenant, ≈øo as the ≈øaid Covenant be ≈øatisfied by it. And it was argued before the Mayor Recorder, and Aldermen of
London, in their Guild-Hall by Angier of Grays-Inn, on the part of Leigh the Plaintiff; and he in his Argument did much rely upon the definition of marriage, by Ju≈øtinian in his In≈øtitutions. Nuptiae maris & faeminae conjunctio individua continens viae ≈øocietatem; and the marriage here in que≈øtion is not according to the ≈øaid difinition, for the per≈øons, parties to this contract, are not per≈øons able by Law to make ≈øuch contract, becau≈øe that non attigerunt annos nubiles, Ergo nuptiae e≈ø≈øe non po≈ø≈øunt, but only ≈øpon≈øalia, a ≈øtep unto marriage; And there is al≈øo rendred one rea≈øon of the ≈øaid definition upon the word individua, individuam dico, quia non ni≈øi morte aut divortio ≈øeparandum, but the marriage now in que≈øtion might be di≈ø≈øolved without death or divorce, as it is in our ca≈øe by di≈øagreement: And ≈øee Juri≈øprudentiae Romanae, Lib. 1. Cap. 33. Societas & con≈øortium omni vita inter marem & faeminam ad concubitum, which is ≈øocietatis hujus con≈øummatio; And as every Act doth con≈øi≈øt upon three things, 1. Inceptio, 2. Progre≈ø≈øio, 3. Continuatio, ≈øo is it in the Ca≈øe of marriage; but in this ca≈øe when Thomas Hanmer took the ≈øaid Eliz. to Wife, that is but an inception, but the progre≈ø≈øion and con≈øummation of it is cut off by the di≈øagreement; and he much relyed upon the words of the Covenant, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ dicta Eliz. ad id conde≈øcendere & agreare vellet, ≈øo as there is not any liberty left to the Defendant for the agreement or di≈øagreement of the Son, but he ought, to agree at the peril of his Father; but if Eliz. will not agree, then the Defendant is not at any mi≈øchief, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Covenant doth not extend to him; and al≈øo here the Father is bound that his Son, a ≈øtranger to the Obligation ≈øhould marry the ≈øaid Elizabeth, which he ought to procure at his peril, or otherwi≈øe he ≈øhall forfeit his Bond. Egerton Solicitor of the Queen argued to the contrary; This marriage as much as concerns this Covenant, is to be con≈øidered according to the rea≈øon of the common Law, and not according to the rules and grounds of the Canon or Civil Law, not as a marriage to right, but as a marriage in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and marriage in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is ≈øufficient always in per≈øonal things and cau≈øes, e≈øpecially where the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Wife is in que≈øtion,2 Roll. 585. but where the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Husband is in que≈øtion, there marriage in right ought to be, and where marriage in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion fals in averment, there it ≈øhall not be tried by the Bi≈øhop, as in the Ca≈øe of a marriage of right, where, never accoupled in loyal matrimony, is pleaded, but by the Country, for in ca≈øe of Wife in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, never accoupled in matrimony, is no Plea,Po≈øtea. 181. 12 Len 170. 171. ‚Ä¢ 3 Len. 129. but not his Wife, which ≈øee 12 E. 3. br. 481. A. brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt B. and C. B. pleaded that C. is Wife of the Plaintiff, and demanded Iudgment of the Writ; the Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaid, never accoupled in Lawful matrimony, but it was not allowed, but was driven to ≈øay, not his Wife, for if C. was the Wife of the Plaintiff in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or by Reputation, it is ≈øufficient to abate the Writ: ≈øee al≈øo 49 E. 3. 18. by Belknap, the right of the E≈øpou≈øal is always to be tried by the Bi≈øhop, but the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the marriage‚ñ™ not as in A≈ø≈øize by A. and K. his Wife‚ñ™ the Tenant demanded Iudgment of the Writ upon ≈øpecial ≈øhatter and concluded, ≈øo is the ≈øaid K. our Wife, and not the Wife of A. So in a Cui invita by B. and C. his Wife, the Tenant pleaded, never accoupled in loyal matrimony, the ≈øame is no an≈øwer to the Wife, for ≈øhe demanded in her own right, and if he who aliened was her Husband in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the Wife could not have other Action, for A≈ø≈øize doth not lie, becau≈øe he was her Husband in fact at the ≈øaid time in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. And ≈øee al≈øo 50 E. 3. 20. adjudged according to the opinion of Belknap: And ≈øee al≈øo 39 E. 3. As to the marriage in right, as the ca≈øe in que≈øtion is; for upon ≈øuch marriage, if the Husband be murdred before di≈øagreement, the Wife ≈øhall have an Appeal of Murder, and a Writ of Dower: ≈øo where Appeal is brought of the Rape of his Wife, although ≈øhe be his Wife but in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and not in right, 11 H. 4. 13. by Hulls 168. and by Littleton, if the Wife be of the age but of nine years, ≈øhe
≈øhall have Dower, which ≈øee al≈øo 35 H. 6. and yet Dower ≈øhall never accrue but in ca≈øe of marriage in right, for there, never coupled in marriage, is a good Plea, See 12 R. 2. Dower 54. In Dower the Tenant pleaded, that the Husband at the time of his death was but at the age of 10 years, and the Demandant now but 11 years, and yet Iudgment was given for the Demandant, for by Charleton the ≈øame was a marriage in right until di≈øagreement, See 22 Eliz. Dyer 369. A woman at full age marrieth a Husband of 12 years, who dieth before the age of con≈øent, the ≈øame is a good marriage, and ≈øo ought to be certified by the Bi≈øhop; and 7 H. 6. 11. by Newton, a woman married within age of con≈øent may bring an Action as a feme ≈øole, and the Writ did abate. Stamford Prerogat. 27. 19 E. 3. Judgment 123. In a Writ of Ward, the Iury found, that the Infant was of the age of 10 years, and no more, but they did not know whether ≈øhe was married or not, but de bene e≈ø≈øe, if ≈øhe be married, a≈ø≈øe≈øs damages one hundred pounds, and if not, five pounds; upon which it appeareth that marriage at ≈øuch an age is ≈øuch a marriage upon which the Lord ≈øhall recover damages; See 13 H. 3. gard. 148. ≈øuch marriage in the life of the Ance≈øtor, infra annos nubiles, if there be no di≈øagreement ≈øhall bind the King: And after the death of the Ance≈øtor, the heir ≈øhall remain in cu≈øtodia Domini Regis, u≈ø
que ad aetatem ut con≈øentiat, vel di≈ø≈øentiat, 45 E. 3. 16. In a Writ of Ward, the Infant was found of the age of 12 years, and the Iurors gave damages 300 marks, if he were married, and 27 H. 6. gard. 118. & 47 E. 3. Br. Tre≈øpa≈øs 420. and Fitz. Action upon the Statute 37. Tre≈øpa≈øs de muliere abducta cum bonis viri, where the wife is within the age of con≈øent: and if I be bounden unto another in an Obligation, upon condition to pay a ≈øum of mony upon the marriage day of I S. now, if I S. be married within the age of con≈øent, I am bound to pay the mony the ≈øame day, although afterwards the parties do di≈ø≈øent, and the Wife after ≈øuch marriage ≈øhall be received in a Plea real upon the Default of her Husband; and the words, ≈øi dicta Eliz. ad id conde≈øcendere & agreare vellet, are to be under≈øtood of an agreement at the time of the marriage, and here the time is limited for the ≈øolemnization of the marriage, ≈øcil. at or before they ≈øhall have accompli≈øhed their ≈øeveral ages of 21 years, makes the matter clear; For it is in the election of Hanmer the Father, to procure this marriage, ≈øcil. that his Son ≈øhall take to Wife the ≈øaid Elizabeth, at which of the two times he will, ≈øcil. at or before, &c. to the marriage before &c. is as effectual in re≈øpect of the performance of this condition, as if the marriage had been had after; and as the ca≈øe is, the condition could not be better performed, for if the marriage had been ≈øtayed till after 14 years, &c. although the marriage doth not en≈øue, yet the Obligation had been forfeited, and that the marriage be ≈øolemnized ju≈øt at the age of both of 14 years, was impo≈ø≈øible, for Thomas Hanmer was the elder by 2 years than the ≈øaid Elizabeth, and therfore they ought to be married at ≈øuch time which might ≈øtand with the condition, and the ≈øame is done accordingly: And as to that which hath been objected, That now by di≈øagreement the marriage is determined, we ought to ob≈øerve that Hanmer was bounden for the performance of the Covenant, and that his ≈øon and heir apparent maritaret, & in uxorem duceret dictam Eliz. ud vel ante, &c. which is executed accordingly, and he is not bounden for the continuance of the ≈øaid marriage, but the continuance of the ≈øame ought to be left to the law, which giveth to the parties liberty to continue the marriage by agreement, or to di≈ø≈øolve it by di≈øagreement: And therefore if I am bounden to you, that I S. (who in truth is an Infant) ≈øhall levy a Fine before ≈øuch a day, which is done accordingly, and afterwards the ≈øame is rever≈øed by Error, yet notwith≈øtanding the condition is performed, &c. and afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
LXVIII. The Earl of Warwick and the Lord Barkleys Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: AMbro≈øe Earl of Warwick and Robert Earl of Leice≈øter brought a Writ of Partition again≈øt the Lord Barkley, Partition. Challenge. in which the parties pleaded to i≈ø≈øue. And now at the day of the Enque≈øt the Defendant did challenge, that in the whole Pannel there were but two Hundreders; and at the fir≈øt it was doubted by the Court, if upon the Statute of 27 Eliz. cap. 6. by which it is Enacted; That no further challenge for the Hundred ≈øhall be admitted if two ≈øufficient Hundreders do appear, the Enque≈øt ≈øhall be taken: But at length the whole Court was clear of opinion, that the ≈øaid Statute did extend but to per≈øonal Actions; but this Action of Partition is a real Action; and Summons, and ≈øeverance lieth in it, but not proce≈øs of outlawry, and therefore here four Hundreders ought to be returned; ≈øo in an Action of Wa≈øt, although it be in the per≈øonalty: and therefore the Council of the Plaintiffs prayed a Tales.

div.head:
LXIX. The Archbi≈øhop of York and Mortons Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Archbi≈øhop of York recovered in an A≈ø≈øize of Novel di≈ø≈øei≈øin again≈øt one Morton before the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize;3 Len. 159. Error upon recovery in A≈ø≈øize. upon which Iudgment Morton brought a Writ of Error before the Iu≈øtices of the Common Pleas, and after many motions at the bar, it was adjudged that a Writ of Error upon the ≈øaid Iudgment did not lie in the ≈øaid Court. 18 Eliz. Dyer 250. F. B. 22. That upon Erronious Iudgment given in the Kings Bench in Ireland, Error ≈øhall be brought in the Kings Bench in England, 15 E. 3. Error 72. Fenner who was of Council with the Archbi≈øhop demanded of the Court how, and in what manner the Record ≈øhall be remanded to the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize, ≈øo as the Archbi≈øhop might have execution; To which the Court ≈øaid, that the ≈øure≈øt way is to have a Certiorare out of the Chancery into the Common Pleas directed to the Iudges there; and then out of the Chancery by Mittimus to the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize. But Fenner made a difficulty of it to take ≈øuch cour≈øe for the remanding of it, for doubt they would not allow it to be a Record where it is not a Record, for upon the matter the Record is not removed, but remains with the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize. Then Ander≈øon ≈øaid, Sue Excution out of the ≈øaid Record; but becau≈øe the Record came before us by Writ of Error, it ≈øhall be al≈øo removed and remanded by Writ: and ≈øo it was.

div.head:
LXX. Kempe and Carters Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
THomas Kempe brought Tre≈øpa≈øs,Copyhold. for breaking of his Clo≈øe again≈øt Carter: and upon pleading they were at i≈ø≈øue, if the Lord of the Manor afore≈øaid granted the ≈øaid Lands per copiam rotulorum curiae manerii praedict: ≈øecundum con≈øuetudinem manerii praedict. and it was given in Evidence, that within the ≈øaid Manor were divers cu≈øtomary Lands, and that the Lord now of late at his Court of the ≈øaid Manor granted the Land, &c. per copiam
rotulorum curiae, where it was never granted by copy before: It was now holden by the whole Court, that the Iury are bound to find, Dominus non conce≈ø≈øit, for notwith≈øtanding that de facto Dominus conce≈ø≈øit per copiam rotulorum curiae, yet, non conce≈ø≈øit ≈øecundum con≈øuetudinem manerii praedict. for the ≈øaid Land was not cu≈øtomary, nor was it demi≈øable, for the cu≈øtom had not taken hold of it. In the ≈øame Ca≈øe it was al≈øo ≈øhewed, that within the ≈øaid Manor ≈øome cu≈øtomary Lands are demi≈øeable for life only,Evidence of cu≈øtoms. and ≈øome in Fee; and it was ≈øaid by the Lord Ander≈øon, that he who will give in Evidence the≈øe ≈øeveral cu≈øtoms, ought to ≈øhew the ≈øeveral limits in which the ≈øeveral cu≈øtoms are ≈øeverally running, as that the Manor extends into two Towns, and that the Lands in one of the ≈øaid Towns are grantable for lives only, and the Lands in the other in Fee, and he ought not to ≈øhew the ≈øeveral cu≈øtoms promi≈øcu√® valere through the whole Manor: And he remembred a Ca≈øe of his own experience: ≈øcil. The Manor of Wadhur≈øt in the County of Su≈ø≈øex con≈øi≈øted of two ≈øorts of Copy-hold, ≈øcil. Sook-land and Bond-land, and by ≈øeveral cu≈øtoms di≈ø≈øeverable in ≈øeveral manners: As if a man be fir≈øt admitted to Sook-land, and afterwards to Bond-land, and dieth ≈øei≈øed of both, his Heir ≈øhall inherit both; but if he be fir≈øt admitted to Bond-land, and afterward to Sook-land, and of them dieth ≈øei≈øed, his younge≈øt Son ≈øhall inherit, and if of both ≈øimul & ≈øemel, his elde≈øt Son ≈øhall inherit; But if he dieth ≈øei≈øed of Bond-land only, it ≈øhall de≈øcend to the younge≈øt: and if cu≈øtomary Land hath been of ancient time grantable in Fee, and now of late time for the ≈øpace of forty years hath granted the ≈øame for life only; yet the Lord may if he plea≈øe re≈øort to his ancient cu≈øtom and grant it in Fee. It was al≈øo moved in this ca≈øe, If cu≈øtomary Land within a Manor hath been grantable in Fee, if now the ≈øame E≈øcheat to the Lord, and he grant the ≈øame to another for life; the ≈øame was holden a good grant and warrantable by the cu≈øtom, and ≈øhould bind the Lord, for the cu≈øtom which enables him to grant in Fee ≈øhall enable him to grant for life: and after the death of the Tenant for life, the Lord may grant the ≈øame again in Fee, for the grant for life was not any interruption of the cu≈øtom, &c. which was granted by the whole Court.

div.head:
LXXI. Walker and Nevils Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Dower. WAlker and his Wife brought a Writ of Dower again≈øt Jervice Nevil, and judgment was given upon Nihil dicit, and becau≈øe the fir≈øt Husband of the Wife died ≈øei≈øed, a Writ of Enquiry of Damages was awarded, by which it was found, that the Land which ≈øhe ought to have in Dower, the third part was of the value of eight pound per annum, and that eight years elap≈øerunt a die mortis viri ≈øui proxim√® ante inqui≈øitionem & a≈ø≈øident damna to eight pounds; and it appeared upon the Record, that after Iudgment in the Writ of Dower afore≈øaid the Demandants had execution upon habere facias ≈øei≈øinam, Damages. ≈øo as it appeareth upon the whole Record put together, that damages are a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for eight years, where the Demandants have been ≈øei≈øed for part of the ≈øaid eight years, upon which the Tenant brought a Writ of Error, and a≈ø≈øigned for Error, becau≈øe damages are a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed untill the time of the Inqui≈øition, where they ought to be, but to to the time of the Iudgment; but the Exception was not allowed; Another Error was a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe that where it is found, that the Land was of the value of eight pounds per annum, they have a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed damages for eight years, to eighty pounds, beyond the Revenue; for according to the rate, and value found by verdict it did amount but to ≈øixty four pounds: but that Error was not al≈øo allowed; for it may be, that by the long detaining of the Dower, the Demandants have ≈øu≈øtained more damages than the
bare Revenue, &c. Another Error was a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe Damages are a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for the whole eight years after the death of the Husband, where it appeareth, that for part of the ≈øaid years the Demandants were ≈øei≈øed of the Lands by force of the Iudgment and execution in the Writ of Dower; and upon that matter the writ of Error was allowed.

div.head: LXXII. Archpool again≈øt the Inhabitants of Everingham. Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Statute of Winche≈øter of Huy and Cry by Archoopl again≈øt the Inhabitants of the Hundred of Everingham, the Iury found, that the Plaintiff was robbed 2 Januarii po≈øt occa≈øum ≈øolis, ≈øed per lucem diurnam, and that after the Robbery committed, the Plaintiff went to the Town of Andover, and adverti≈øed the Baylies of the ≈øaid Town of the ≈øaid Robbery; and further found, that the ≈øaid Town of Andover is not within the ≈øaid Hundred of Everingham, and that there is another Town nearer to the place where, &c. the Robbery was done, than the ≈øaid Town of Andover within the ≈øaid Hundred, but the ≈øaid Town of Andover was the neare≈øt place where, &c. by the Kings high-way: It was moved that upon this matter, the Plaintiff ≈øhould not have judgment, for that he hath not made his Fre≈øh ≈øute according to the Law, for he ought to have begun his Fre≈øh ≈øute within the Hundred where the Robbery was done: and it was al≈øo objected, that the Robbery was done po≈øt occa≈øum ≈øolis, in which Ca≈øe the Hundreders are not to pur≈øue the Malefactors. And Walm≈øley Serjeant cited a Ca≈øe out of Bracton: Si appellatus ≈øe defenderit contra appellantem tota dle u≈øque ad horam in qua Stellae incipiunt apparere, recedat quietus de appello, and it is not rea≈øon to drive the Hundreders to Follow felons at ≈øuch a time,1 Cro. 270. when for want of light they cannot ≈øee them. And all the Iu≈øtices were clear of opinion, that if the Robbery was done in the night time, the Inhabitants are not bound to make the pur≈øute: And by Rhodes, if in a Praecipe quod reddat of Lands, the Sheriff ≈øummons the Demandant upon the Land in the time of night, ≈øuch a ≈øummons is meerly void.

div.head:
LXXIII. Wi≈øeman and Wi≈øemas Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Intrat. Trin 28. Rot. 1458.
div.p:
IN an Action of Debt by Wi≈øeman again≈øt Wi≈øeman, the Ca≈øe was,Debt. 1 And. 160. Owen 140. that one Wi≈øeman was ≈øei≈øed of the Lands, and by his Will devi≈øed, 1. I will and bequeath unto my Wife B. acre for the Term of her life, the remainder to my Son Thomas in tail: Item I will and bequeath unto my Son Thomas, Devi≈øes. all my Lands in D. and al≈øo my Lands in S. and al≈øo my Lands in V. Al≈øo I give and bequeath unto the ≈øaid Thomas my Son all that m ‚Ä¢ I≈øland or Land enclo≈øed with water which I purcha≈øed of the Earl of E≈ø≈øex: To have and to hold all the ≈øaid la≈øt before devi≈øed premi≈ø≈øes unto the ≈øaid Thomas my Son, and the Heirs of his Body: The only matter was, If the Habendum ≈øhall extend to the I≈øland only, in which Ca≈øe Thomas ≈øhall have but for life in the Lands in D. S. and V. or unto the I≈øland, and al≈øo to the Lands in D. S. and V; 2 Roll. 60. Roph. 126. in which Ca≈øe he ≈øhall have Fee-tail in the whole. And it was argued by Fenner, that the Habendum ≈øhould extend to the I≈øland only; as he ≈øaid, the opinion of the Iu≈øtices of this Court was in 4 Eliz. in another Ca≈øe. I devi≈øe my Manor to D. my elde≈øt Son, and al≈øo my Land in S. in tail, in that Ca≈øe the entail limited for the Land in S. ≈øhall not extend to the1 Roll. 844.
≈øaid Manor, and of ≈øuch opinion was We≈øton, Wel≈øh, and Dyer; Brown contra, that the Son hath tail in both. But if the words of the devi≈øe had been, I devi≈øe my Manor of D. and my Lands in S. to my Son in tail, here the Son had an e≈øtate tail in both. So it hath been adjudged, that if I devi≈øe Lands to A. B. and C. ≈øucce≈ø≈øively as they be named, the ≈øame is good by way of Remainder. Walme≈øley contrary, and he relied much upon this, that the words of the Habendum are in the plural number,2 Bul≈øt. 180. 181. All the la≈øt before devi≈øed premi≈ø≈øes, whereas the thing lately devi≈øed by the Will was an I≈øland in the ≈øingular number, which cannot ≈øatisfie the Habendum, Extent of an Habendum. which is in the plural number, and therefore to verifie the plural number in the Habendum, the Habendum by fit con≈øtruction ≈øhall extend to all the Lands in D. S. and V. and ≈øo upon his motion made at another day, it was re≈øolved by all the Iu≈øtices, that the Habendum ≈øhould extend to all the ≈øaid Lands, and the Habendum ≈øhould not ≈øtreighten the Devi≈øe to the I≈øland only.

div.head:
LXXIV. Fullwood and Fullwoods Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Bail renders him≈øelf in Court.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Defendant put in bail to the Court to an≈øwer to the Action; and now Iudgment being given again≈øt him, he came into Court and rendred him≈øelf, and prayed, that in di≈øcharge of his ≈øureties, that the Court would record the rendring of him≈øelf, which was granted: And the Court demanded of the Plaintiff, if he would pray execution for the body again≈øt the Defendant, who ≈øaid, he would not, whereupon the Court awarded, that the ≈øureties ≈øhould be di≈øcharged; and the Rule was entred, that the Defendant offered him≈øelf in di≈øcharge of his ≈øureties, and Attornatus Querentis allocatus per curiam, &c. dixit ≈øe nolle, &c. Ideo con≈øideratum fuit per curiam, quod tam praedict. defend. quam praedict. Manucaptores de recognitione praedict. & denariis in eadem contentis exonerentur.

div.head: LXXV. Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was, He in the Rever≈øion upon a Lea≈øe for years, makes a Charter of Feoffment to divers per≈øons to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life,Feoffments. and after to the u≈øe of his elde≈øt Son in tail; and the words of the Charter were, Dedi, Conce≈ø≈øi, Barganizavi, & Feoffavi, and he ≈øealed and delivered the deed, but no livery of ≈øei≈øin was made; and afterwards he came to his Le≈ø≈øee for years, and ≈øaid to him, that he had made a Feoffment, and ≈øhewed al≈øo the u≈øes, but did not ≈øhew to whom the Feoffment was made; to whom the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øaid, you have done very well, I am glad of it:Attornment. And if that were a good Attornment was the Que≈øtion: It was ≈øaid, that that was the Ca≈øe of one Arden. And Gent, and Manwood were of opinion, that the ≈øame was no Attornment, becau≈øe it was not made to the Feoffee, ≈øcil. to the Grantee of the Rever≈øion; and ≈øo it was ruled in this Ca≈øe, for Attornment ought to be to the Grantee him≈øelf, and not to Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe.

div.head: 1 Cro. 251. Tythes, and where the ≈øpiritual court ≈øhall have juri≈ødiction of them. LXXVI. The Par≈øon of Facknams Ca≈øe. Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
THe Par≈øon of great Facknam brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt the Par≈øon of Hannington, and the Ca≈øe was, If the Par≈øon of one Pari≈øh claim by pre≈øcription a portion of Tythes out of the Pari≈øh of
another, if the Spiritual Court ≈øhall have the Iuri≈ødiction, for the tryal of it: And the opinion of the whole Court was clear, that it ≈øhould, becau≈øe that the matter is betwixt two ≈øpiritual per≈øons, and concerning the right of Tithes. As 35 H. 6. 39. I. Vicar of B. brought Tre≈øpa≈øs for taking away of forty loads of Beans, &c. The Defendant pleaded, that he is Par≈øon of the ≈øaid Church of B. and the Plaintiff is Vicar, &c. and before the Tre≈øpa≈øs, &c. the Beans were growing in the ≈øame Town, and ≈øevered from the nine parts, and he took them as belonging to his ≈øaid Church, and demanded Iudgment of the Court, &c. The Plaintiff ≈øaid, that he and all his Predece≈ø≈øors Vicars, &c. time out of mind, &c. have u≈øed to have the Tithes of ≈øuch a Clo≈øe, &c. belonging to his Vicaridge, and within the ≈øaid Clo≈øe the Beans were growing and were parcel of his endowment; and that at the time of the taking they were ≈øevered from the nine parts, whereupon he took them. And it was holden by A≈øhton and Danby, becau≈øe it is confe≈ø≈øed on both ≈øides that the Beans whereof, &c. were Tithes, the Right of which would come in debate betwixt the Par≈øon and the Vicar, and both are ≈øpiritual per≈øons, that the tryal thereof doth belong to the Spiritual Court. See 6 E. 4. 3. 22 E. 4. 23. 24. in ≈øuch a matter betwixt the Par≈øon and Vicar there the Temporal Court was ou≈øted of the Iuri≈ødiction. See al≈øo 31 H. 6. 11. betwixt the Par≈øon and the Servant of another Par≈øon. 7 H. 4. 102. In Tre≈øpa≈øs by a Par≈øon again≈øt a Lay-man, who ≈øaid, that one A. is Par≈øon of a Church in a Town adjoyning to a Town where the Plaintiff is Par≈øon, and that A. let to him the Tithe, and demanded Iudgment, &c. and pleaded to the Iuri≈ødiction, and by Ga≈øcoigne, the Plaintiff may recover his Tithes in the Spiritual Court.

div.head: LXXVII. Bunny again≈øt Wright and Stafford. Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN Tre≈øpa≈øs the Ca≈øe was this:Lea≈øes within 1 Eliz. and 32. 7, 8. made by Bi≈øhops. Grindal Bi≈øhop of Lond. lea≈øed parcel of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of his Bi≈øhoprick for one and twenty years, and afterwards ou≈øted the Le≈ø≈øee and lea≈øed unto another for three lives, rendring the antient and accu≈øtomed Rent, which was confirmed by the Dean and Chapter. And afterwards Grindal is tran≈ølated: Cook argued, That the Lea≈øe is warranted by the Statute of 1 Eliz. At the Common Law a Bi≈øhop might make an Alienation in Fee-≈øimple being confirmed by the Dean and Chapter: But by 32 H. 8. cap. 28. Bi≈øhops without Dean and Chapter, or their confirmation may make a Lea≈øe for one and twenty years, but with the confirmation of the Dean and Chapter may make a Lea≈øe for one thou≈øand years.Co. 1. In≈øt. 45. 2. More 107. 1 Ander≈øon 65. But by the Statute of 1 Eliz. the power of Bi≈øhops in that right is much abridged, for now with confirmation or without confirmation they cannot di≈øpo≈øe of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions but for one and twenty years or three lives; and this Lea≈øe is in all points according to the Statute of 1 Eliz. for fir≈øt it begins pre≈øently upon the making of it: Secondly, the antient rent is re≈øerved payable yearly during the term; for although here be an old Lea≈øe in e≈ø≈øe, yet the Rent re≈øerved upon the ≈øecond Lea≈øe is payable during the ≈øecond term, for payable is a word of power and not of action, as 1 H. 4. 1. 2. 3. Lord, Me≈øne, and Tenant, the Me≈øne gives the Me≈ønalty in tail, rendring Rent, it is a good Rent, and well re≈øerved, although here be not a pre≈øent di≈øtre≈øs; yet it may be the Tenancy will e≈øcheat, and then the Donor ≈øhall di≈øtrein for all the Arrearages: And ≈øo the Rent is payable by po≈ø≈øibility. And 10 E. 4. 4. A. lea≈øeth for years, and afterwards grants the Rever≈øion to a ≈øtranger, if the Bea≈øts of the ≈øtranger come upon the Lands during the term; A. may di≈øtre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for the Arrearages incurred, and if he happen ≈øei≈øin, he ≈øhall have a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
A≈ø≈øi≈øe during the continuance of the fir≈øt term. And he cited a Ca≈øe lately adjudged in the Exchequer. A Le≈ø≈øor entred upon Le≈ø≈øee for years, and made a Feoffment rendring Rent with clau≈øe of Re-entry, the Le≈ø≈øee re-entred, claiming his Term, and afterwards during the ≈øaid Term for years, the Rent re≈øerved upon the Feoffment upon demand of it is behind: Now hath the Le≈ø≈øor regained the Rever≈øion: And ≈øo a Rent may be demanded although not di≈øtreinable. And all that was affirmed by Egerton Solicitor General: And ≈øee the words of the Statute of 32 H. 8. cap. 28. Rent re≈øerved yearly during the ≈øaid Lea≈øe due and payable to the Le≈ø≈øor, &c. ≈øuch Rent, &c. and yet by the ≈øaid Statute, ≈øuch Lea≈øes may be good, although there be a former intere≈øt for years in being, if the ≈øame ≈øhall be expired, ≈øurrendred, or ended within one year after the making ≈øuch new lea≈øe, and ≈øo not expre≈øly payable in rei veritate, annually during the Term.

div.head:
LXXVIII. Bonefant and Sir Rich. Greenfields Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Sale of Lands by the Executors of the Devi≈øor. BOnefant brought Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Sir Rich. Greenfield, and upon the general i≈ø≈øue, this ≈øpecial matter was found: Tremagrie was ≈øei≈øed of a Manor, whereof the place where, &c. was parcel, in his Deme≈øne as of Fee, and by his Will devi≈øed the ≈øame to his four Executors, and further willed,Po≈øt. 260. that his ≈øaid Executors ≈øhould ≈øell the ≈øame to Sir John Saintleger for the payment of his debts, if the ≈øaid Sir John would pay for it one thou≈øand one hundred pounds at ≈øuch a day, and died, Sir John did not pay the mony at the day; One of the Executors refu≈øed Admini≈øtration of the Will, the other three entred into the Land and ≈øold it to the Defendant for ≈øo much as it could be ≈øold, and in convenient time. It was moved, that the ≈øale was not good, for they have not their authority as Executors, but as Devi≈øees, and then when one refu≈øeth, the other cannot ≈øell by 21 H. 3. Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe Wills, that is Executors ≈øhall alien his Land, and dieth, although the Executors refu≈øe the Admini≈øtration, yet they may alien the Land. 19 H. 8. 11. 15 H. 7. 12 Egerton Solicitor argued, that the ≈øale is good by the Common Law, and al≈øo by the Statute 49 E. 3. 16, 17. Devi≈øe, that his Executors ≈øhall ≈øell his Land, and dieth, and one of the Executors dieth, another refu≈øeth, the third may ≈øell well enough,1 And. 145. and the ≈øale is good. See Br. Devi≈øe 31. 30 H. 8. 39 E. 3. Br. A≈ø≈øi≈øe 356. And he put a difference where an Authority is given to many by one deed, there all ought to joyn; contrary, where the Authority is given by Will; And if all the Executors ≈øeverally ≈øell the Lands to ≈øeveral per≈øons, ≈øuch ≈øale which is mo≈øt beneficial for the Te≈øtator ≈øhall ≈øtand, and take effect: And here it is found by verdict, that one of the Executors, recu≈øavitonus Te≈øtamenti, Ergo, he refu≈øed to take by the Devi≈øe, for it was devi≈øed unto him to the intent to ≈øell, therefore if he refu≈øeth to ≈øell, he doth refu≈øe to take, and ≈øo it is not nece≈ø≈øary that he who refu≈øeth joyn in the ≈øale, and although we are not within the expre≈øs words of the Statute, yet we are within the ≈øen≈øe and meaning of it. And afterwards it was adjudged, that the Condition, for the manner of it, was good.

div.head:
LXXIX. Gamock and Cliffs Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Ejectione firmae. EJectione firmae was brought by Gamock again≈øt Cliff of the Manor of Hockly, in the County of E≈ø≈øex, and upon the evidence the ca≈øe was:
That the King and Queen, Philip and Mary, ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor of Hockley, ≈øea≈øed the ≈øame to Edmund Terrel for years, exceptis & Re≈øervat. gro≈ø≈øis arboribus ≈øuper praemi≈ø≈øis cre≈øcentibus & exi≈øtentibus; Provi≈øo, Conditions. that if the ≈øaid Le≈ø≈øee his Executors, or A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhall do any voluntary Wa≈øt in any of the Premi≈ø≈øes before demi≈øed, that then the ≈øaid demi≈øe ≈øhall be void and accounted none in Law; the ≈øaid King and Queen after that lea≈øe grant the Rever≈øion to the Lord Rich and his Heirs, the Le≈ø≈øee cuts down certain great Trees, which at the time of the demi≈øe were not great, but little Trees, but after, tractu temporis became great, and at the time of the cutting down were great, upon whom the Lady Rich, Wife and Widow of the ≈øaid Lord Rich, being Tenant in Dower, the ≈øaid Manor (inter alia) being a≈ø≈øigned to her in Dower, did enter, for the condition broken: It was moved; If the exception did extend to the trees which at the time of the demi≈øe were but little trees, but afterwards at the time of their cutting down were become great; for if the exception do extend to ≈øuch Trees, then upon the matter they were not demi≈øed, and if ≈øo, then wa≈øt cannot be a≈ø≈øigned in the cutting down of them, and then by the cutting of them, the condition is not broken: But if the exception ≈øhall be con≈øtrued to extend to ≈øuch Trees only which were great Tempore dimi≈ø≈øionis, then tho≈øe Trees in which, &c are demi≈øed, and by the cutting down of them, the condition is broken. And the Lord Ander≈øon was of opinion, that the exception did extend to Trees, which at any time dimi≈ø≈øionis praedict. became great,Where the Tenant in Dower ≈øhall take advantage of a condition. although at the time of the demi≈øe they were but little, ≈øo as upon the matter, ≈øuch Trees were never demi≈øed, and ≈øo the condition doth not extend to them; otherwi≈øe it ≈øhould be if the words had been modo cre≈øcentibus & exi≈øtentibus. Another matter was moved, becau≈øe if the Lady Rich, being Tenant in Dower, and ≈øo in by the Law, not by the party, and ≈øo not privy, nor as A≈ø≈øignee, could enter for the condition broken: And the Court was clear of opinion, that becau≈øe, that the words of the condition are, Quando dimi≈ø≈øio praedict. erit vacua, &c. and no clau≈øe of reentry is re≈øerved, ≈øo that privity is not requi≈øite, the Lady Rich ≈øhall take advantage of the condition, 11 H. 17. Where the words of a Lea≈øe are, that upon the not going to Rome, that the Lea≈øe ≈øhall cea≈øe; it was holden that the Grantee of the Rever≈øion by the common Law ≈øhould take advantage of ≈øuch a condition; contrary where the condition is conceived in words of re-entry, 21 H. 7. 12. It was moved further, that here is not any voluntary wa≈øt in the Le≈ø≈øee as to the condition,Dyer 281. Owen 93. becau≈øe done by a ≈øtranger, and not by the Le≈ø≈øee him≈øelf, and for that the condition is not broken, only the Le≈ø≈øee is ≈øubject unto an Action of Wa≈øt; otherwi≈øe, if the Le≈ø≈øee had expre≈øly commanded the Vendee to cut them down, or had given to him expre≈øs authority. The ≈øale was, All his Woods growing, &c.

div.head:
LXXX Gill and Harewoods Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: GIll brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Harewood, and declared,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. that where the Defendant was endebted to the Plaintiff in ≈øuch a ‚Ä¢ um, and ≈øhewed how; the Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff, per parvum tempus deferret diem ≈øolutionis, &c. did promi≈øe to pay, &. And, upon Non A≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, it was found for the Plaintiff, and it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that here is not any con≈øideration, for no time is limited for the forbearance, but generally, parvum tempus, which cannot be any commodity to the Defendant, for the ≈øame may be, but punctum temporis, &c. But the exception was not allowed, for the Debt in it ≈øelf is a ≈øufficient con≈øideration.

div.head: LXXXI. Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: 2 Co. 74. 5 Co. 38. 8 Co. 155. FEnner Serjeant would have drawn a Fine which was by Dedimus Pote≈øtatem, and the Fine was to two, and their heirs, but the Court would not receive ≈øuch Fine for the incertainty of the Inheritance, which always in ca≈øe of Fine ought to be repo≈øed in a per≈øon certain, and not left to uncertainty of the Survivor, and the ≈øaid Serjeant prayed pre≈øently, that the ≈øaid Fine be received at the peril of the Conu≈øees, but the ≈øame was denied him by the whole Court.

div.head:
LXXXII. Ma≈øcals Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29, & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Covenant. 2 Cro. 644. MA≈øcal lea≈øed a Hou≈øe to A. for years by Indenture, by which A. covenanted with Ma≈øcal to repair the Hou≈øe Lea≈øed, and that it ≈øhould be lawful for Ma≈øcal his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns to enter into the Hou≈øe to ≈øee in what plight for matter of Reparation the ≈øaid Hou≈øe ≈øtood, and if upon any ≈øuch view, any default ≈øhould be found in the not repairing of it, and thereof warning be given to A. his Executors, &c. Then within four months after ≈øuch warning, ≈øuch default ≈øhould be amended: the Hou≈øe in the default of the Le≈ø≈øee became ruinous: Ma≈øcal granted the Rever≈øion over in Fee to one Carre, who upon view of the Hou≈øe gave warning to A. of the default, &c. which is not repayred, upon which Carre, as A≈ø≈øignee of Ma≈øcal, brought an Action of Covenant again≈øt A. It was moved by Fenner Serjeant, that the Action did not lye, becau≈øe the Hou≈øe became ruinous before his intere≈øt in the Rever≈øion; But the opinion of the whole Court was again≈øt him, for that the Action is not conceived upon the ruinous e≈øtate of the Hou≈øe, or for the committing of Wa≈øte, but for the not repayring of it within the time appointed by the Covenant, after the warning, ≈øo as it is not material within what time the Hou≈øe became ruinous, but within what time the warning was given, and the default of the Reparation did happen.

div.head: LXXXIII. Mich. 29, & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
Dower.IN a Writ of Dower, brought by a Woman of the third part of certain Lands, &c. The Tenant pleaded; That the Lands of which Dower is demanded, are of the nature of Gavel-kind, and that the cu≈øtom of ≈øuch Land is, that Dower ought to be demanded of the moity of it, and not of the third part, upon which the Demandant did demur: And the opinion of Windham and Ander≈øon Iu≈øtices was; That ≈øuch a Woman of ≈øuch Land might at her plea≈øure demand her Dower either according to the Cu≈øtom,1 Cro. 825. Poph. 133. or according to the common Law; for by Ander≈øon, the common Law was before the Cu≈øtom, quod quaere, And by Windham, if the Demandant here recover her Dower according to the common Law, yet if ≈øhe taketh another Husband, ≈øhe ≈øhall lo≈øe her Dower as if ≈øhe had been endowed according to the Cu≈øtom. Coke, an Apprentice the of Inner Temple being at the Bar, when this Ca≈øe was moved, ≈øaid unto Serjeant Shuttleworth, that the Ca≈øe had been adjudged again≈øt the Demandant, and Scot Prothonotary did affirm, that the Lord Dyer was of opinion, that the Woman ought to be endowed according to the Cu≈øtom, and not otherwi≈øe. And Sayer one of the Clarks of Nel≈øon,
chief Prothonotary ≈øaid, that it was adjudged accordingly, 16. Eliz. and that the Ca≈øe was betwixt Gelbrand Demandant, and Hunt Tenant.

div.head:
LXXXIV. Beverlie and Cornwals Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
BEverlie brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt Cornwal, Quare Imped. 2 Roll. 805. Out-lawry pleaded. and had Iudgment to recover upon a Demurrer in Law: Which ≈øee Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. And now the Queen brought a Scire facias upon the matter, That the ≈øaid Beverly after the ≈øaid Iudgment was out-lawed in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs at the ≈øute of I. S. and upon that a Scire facias i≈ø≈øued, ad re≈øpondendum Quare dicta Domina Regina, ≈øhould not have execution of the Iudgment afore≈øaid, by rea≈øon of the Out-lawry afore≈øaid, and declared in all as afore≈øaid: And further, that the ≈øaid Cornwal had re≈øigned. Vpon which Beverlie did demur in Law. And this Term it was argued by Puckering Serjeant for the Queen, that by that Out-lawry the Intere≈øt to pre≈øent is tranferred to the Queen. Which ≈øee 5 H. 5. 3. Tenant at will of a Manor, to which an Advow≈øon is appendant, is out-lawed in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs; the Church voided; by award of the Court it belongs to the King to pre≈øent: And ≈øee 8 R. 2. ≈øcil. Quare Imped. 200 A. ≈øei≈øed of an Advow≈øon, the Church becomes void. A. is Out-lawed in a per≈øonal Action; the King ≈øhall have a Quare Impedit in that Ca≈øe. And as to the Exception taken, becau≈øe the Out-lawry is not ≈øufficiently layed in the Writ, but only generally, viz. utlagatus in Com. Lincoln, ad ≈øectam. J.S. in placito tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis, without ≈øhewing the Out-lawry at large There is a difference where an Out-lawry is pleaded by way of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r, and di≈øability of the per≈øon, &c. and where it is ≈øet down in a Writ, for a Writ ought ≈øhortly and compendiou≈øly to comprehend the cau≈øe of the Action, e≈øpecially judicial Writs which are not tied to any form certain, e≈øpecially becau≈øe that the Out-lawry ≈øet forth in the Writ is a Record of the ≈øame Court: For the perclo≈øe of the Scire facias is, prout per recordum hic in curia plenius apparet: And that Record being in the Court the party cannot plead Nul tiel record, as if the Record had been in any other Court: But he ought to demand Dyer of the Record: Which vide 5 H. 7. 24. Walme≈øley Serjeant contrary. By Out-lawry in an Action per≈øonal, the King cannot ≈øei≈øe Land, but only take the profits of it, 9. H. 6. 20. 21 H. 7. 7. And as our ca≈øe is, nothing doth accrew to the Queen by this Out-lawry, for the Queen her ≈øelf is ≈øei≈øed of the Advow≈øon, becau≈øe ≈øhe, u≈øurpando pre≈øentavit, and her Clerk admitted; and although Beverlie hath recovered in a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Pre≈øentee of the Queen; yet becau≈øe he is not removed by a Writ to the Bi≈øhop, the Queen continues Patron, and nothing remains in Beverlie that may be forfeited. But Rhodes and Periam contrary, for by Periam if after ≈øuch Recovery the Incumbent dieth, the Patron ≈øhall pre≈øent, for by the Iudgment in the Quare Impedit for Beverlie, the Patronage is rev ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ted in him without any other execution: And by Rhodes, If after ≈øuch Iudgment the Patron dieth, his Executors ≈øhall have a Writ to the Bi≈øhop. And by Walme≈øley, the Scire facias doth not lie for the Queen, for that Writ always runs in privity of the Record upon which it is grounded, to which Record the Queen is a ≈øtranger, and by Out-lawry in an Action per≈øonal no Action real ≈øhall e≈øcheat, and therefore this Scire facias being in the nature of a Quare Impedit upon which it is grounded, which is a real Action, or at lea≈øt a mixt, ≈øhall not be forfeited; and al≈øo it ≈øhall be ab≈øurd to grant now a Writ to the Bi≈øhop for the Queen; whereas Iudgment was given again≈øt the Queen, as in our ca≈øe it hath been. And in no Ca≈øe the Iudges ≈øhall re≈øpect the title of the Queen, being a ≈øtranger to the Writ: But where a title for the Queen doth appear
upon the pleading or otherwi≈øe within the Record, 11 H. 4. 224. by Hankford. If a clear title for the King be confe≈ø≈øed by the parties upon pleading, a Writ to the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue for the King; ≈øo if ≈øuch matter appear in Evidence,3 Cro. 427. &c. the Land in que≈øtion is ≈øei≈øable into the Kings hands. See 9 H. 7. 9. 16 H. 7. 12. ≈øo 21 E. 4. 3. by Choke and F.N.B. 38. e. In a Quare Impedit betwixt two ≈øtrangers if title doth appear to the Court for the King, a Writ to the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue forth for the King; but in our Ca≈øe nothing is within the Record to intitle the Queen, but all the matter upon which a Writ to the Bi≈øhop is prayed for the Queen is out of the Record, and a foreign thing. And as to the Out-lawry, he conceived it is not ≈øufficiently alledged; for he ought to have made mention of the Exigent and of all the proceeding upon it, and the Iudgment of the Coroners, and for defect of that no title is given to the Queen; and of that opinion was the Lord Ander≈øon, and that it ought to be ≈øet forth in the Writ in what Term the ≈øaid Beverly was out-lawed, and the Number Roll al≈øo, ≈øo that if Beverly had demanded Dyer of the Record, the Court might know it: And by Nel≈øon chief Prothonotary, the Term in which the Out-lawry was, ought to be compri≈øed in the Scire facias. Vide Book of Entries 485. where in a Quare Impedit for the King upon ≈øuch a title, the King ≈øhewed in his Count, that A. was ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch an Advow≈øon, and granted the next Avoidance to B. and that afterwards one C. impleaded the ≈øaid B. in a Writ of Account in ≈øuch a Court, where Nihil was returned upon the ≈øummons, upon which i≈ø≈øued forth a Capias, upon which is returned, Non e≈øt inventus, &c. upon which an Exigent, upon which the Sheriff did return, quod ad com. tent. &c. & ad v. comitat. tunc prox. praecedent. the ≈øaid B. exactus fuit, & non comparuit, & quia ad nullum eorundem comitat. apparuit, utlagatus fuit, and after the the Church voided, and that by rea≈øon thereof it did belong to the King to pre≈øent: vide ibid. 196. accordingly. And as to the Scire facias all the Iudges agreed, that upon the matter the Writ lay well enough: And it is good di≈øcretion in the Court to grant ≈øuch a Writ: And by Rhodes, If two Coparceners of an Advow≈øon make compo≈øition to pre≈øent by turns, and afterwards one of them dieth, her Heir within age, and in Ward to the King; The Church voideth, and the King is di≈øturbed in his pre≈øentment, he ≈øhall have a Scire facias upon ≈øuch compo≈øition, notwith≈øtanding that he be a ≈øtranger to it: See F.N.B. 34 H. And by all the Iu≈øtices, if one recover in Debt upon a ≈øimple contract, and before execution the Plaintiff is out-lawed in an Action per≈øonal, the King ≈øhall ≈øue execution: And ≈øee 37 H. 6. 26. Where in Debt upon an Obligation it was ≈øurmi≈øed to the Court, that the Plaintiff was out-lawed: And the Kings Attorney prayed delivery of the Obligation, &c.

div.head: LXXXV. Moile and the Earl of Warwicks Ca≈øe. Mich. 29, & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
Quare Impedit. A Quare Impedit was brought by Walter Moile again≈øt Ambro≈øe Earl of Warwick, and the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury. And now came the Serjeanes of the Queen, and ≈øhewed an Office, to entitle the Queen to have a Writ to the Bi≈øhop, containing ≈øuch matter, viz. That one Guilford was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. to which the Advow≈øon of the Church was appendant, and that Manor was holden in chief by Knights ≈øervice, and that Guilford and his Wife levied a Fine thereof to the u≈øe of them≈øelves for their lives, the remainder over in tail to their elde≈øt Son, and that Guilford is dead, but who is his next Heir, ignorant: And it was ≈øhewed by the Council of the other ≈øide, that the truth of the Ca≈øe was, that the ≈øaid Guilford was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor in the right of his Wife, and ≈øo levied the Fine, in which Ca≈øe the ≈øaid coveyance is not within the Statute
of 32 H. 8. for it was for the advancement of the Husband, not of the Wife, which Ander≈øon granted. Vide Dyer 19 Eliz. 354. Caverlies Ca≈øe, but that is not in the Office: And it was moved at the Bar, that the Office is imperfect, becau≈øe no Heir is found. But Ander≈øon, the Office is ≈øufficient for the King to ≈øei≈øe, although it be in≈øufficient for the Heir, &c. And it was agreed by the whole Court,Office trove. that the Court ought not to receive the Office, although one would affirm upon oath, that it is the very Office, but it ought to be brought in under the Great Seal of England; and al≈øo the Court ≈øhall not receive it without a Writ; and yet Nel≈øon Prothonotary ≈øaid, that the Statute of Huy and Cry of Winche≈øter was brought into the Court without a Writ under the great Seal,A Record not to be brought into Court without a Writ. 63. and that was out of the Tower: And in that Ca≈øe al≈øo the Iu≈øtices held, that if a Record be pleaded in the ≈øame Court where it abides, the other party again≈øt whom it is pleaded may plead Nul tiel Record, as if the ≈øaid Record had bin remaining in another Court, which all the Prothonotaries denied, & that always it had been u≈øed to the contrary. At another day the Ca≈øe was moved again.
