The Plaintiff in the Quare Impedit counted, that Richard Guilford was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor, &c. in the right of Bennet his Wife, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, they both levied a Fine thereof to a ≈øtranger, Sur Conu≈øans de droit come ceo, who rendred it to the Husband and Wife for their lives, the remainder to the Heirs of the body of the Husband, the remainder to the right Heirs of the Husband; and they ≈øo being ≈øei≈øed, the Husband alone levied a Fine to a ≈øtranger, Sur Conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. and by the ≈øame Fine the Conu≈øee rendred to the Husband and Wife in tail, the remainder to the Heirs of the body of the Husband, the remainder to the right Heirs of the Husband, the Husband died ≈øei≈øed, the Wife entred and lea≈øed the ≈øaid Manor to the Plaintiff, and then the Church did become void: And now the Queens Serjeants came and ≈øhewed unto the Court an Office, which came in by Mittimus: In which Writ the perclo≈øe is, Mandamus vobis quod in≈øpectis, &c. pro nobis fieri faciatis quod ≈øecundum leges & con≈øuetudinem Regni no≈øtri Angliae faciend. Statuetis; And the Office did purport, that the ≈øaid Richard was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor, and held the ≈øame of the Queen, as of her Ca≈øtle of Dover, by Knights ≈øervice in chief, and levied the Fine, ut ≈øupra, and that the ≈øaid Richard died, ≈øed quis ≈øit propinquior haeres dict. Ric. penitus ignorant; and upon that Office prayed a Writ to the Bi≈øhop for the Queen: And two Exceptions were taken to the Office, Fir≈øt becau≈øe it is not found by the ≈øaid Office that the ≈øaid Richard died ≈øei≈øed,1 Cro. 895. in which Ca≈øe it may be for any thing that appeareth in the Office, that the ≈øaid Richard after the ≈øaid Fine had conveyed his e≈øtate in the ≈øaid Lands unto others, or that he was di≈ø≈øei≈øed, &c. See 3 H. 6. 5. If it be not found of what e≈øtate the Tenant of the King died ≈øei≈øed, the Office is in≈øufficient. But ≈øee there by Martin, that ≈øuch an Office is good enough for the King, but not for the Heir to ≈øue his Livery upon it. And by Ander≈øon, Periam, and Rhodes, that defect in the Office is ≈øupplyed by the Count, for there it is expre≈ø≈øly alledged, that the ≈øaid Richard died ≈øei≈øed. Secondly, becau≈øe no Heir is found by the ≈øaid Office. To which it was ≈øaid by the Lord Ander≈øon, that peradventure at the Common Law the ≈øame had been a material Exception. But we ought to re≈øpect the Statutes of 32 and 34 H. 8. of Wills. And therefore as to the Wife the Queen is entitled to Primer ≈øei≈øin, becau≈øe the conveyance was made for her advancement. And by Windham, the Queen in this Cale ≈øhall not have Primer ≈øei≈øin, for by the Statute the Queen ≈øhall not have Primer ≈øei≈øin, but in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, where, if no conveyance had been made, the Queen ≈øhould have had Primer ≈øei≈øin; but in this Ca≈øe for any thing that appears before us, if this conveyance had not been made the Queen ≈øhould not have had Primer ≈øei≈øin, fora≈ømuch as no Heir is found, and if he died without Heir there is no Primer ≈øei≈øin, becau≈øe there is not any in rerum natura to ≈øue livery. Rhodes, Periam, and Ander≈øon contrary; Admitting
that Richard died withou Heir, the Queen ≈øhall have Primer ≈øei≈øin again≈øt the Wife of Richard, notwith≈øtanding the e≈øcheat. Walme≈øley Serjeant, If the Tenant of the King by Knights ≈øervice in chief dieth ≈øei≈øed of other Lands holden of a common per≈øon by Knights ≈øervice, without Heirs, the King ≈øhall not have Primer ≈øei≈øin of ≈øuch Lands holden of a Subject, which Windham granted: But by Ander≈øon the Lord is put to ≈øue an Ou≈øter le mayne of the Land holden of him. And afterward Exception was taken to the Count, becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath not averred the life of the Tenant in tail, that is, of Bennet the Wife of Richard, to whom the Land was entailed by the ≈øecond Fine: But that Exception was di≈øallowed by the whole Court, and a difference put by Ander≈øon, Where a man pleads the grant of an Advow≈øon in gro≈øs by Tenant in tail, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the life of the Tenant in tail ought to be averred, for by his death the grant cea≈øeth. But where a man pleads the Lea≈øe of Tenant in tail of a Manor with an Advow≈øon appendant, in ≈øuch ca≈øe ≈øuch averment is not nece≈ø≈øary: So accordingly Smith & Stapletons Ca≈øe, 15 Eliz. 431. And here it was moved, if, in as much as by the fir≈øt Fine an e≈øtate for life was rendred to the Wife, and by the ≈øecond Fine, in which ≈øhe did not joyn, an e≈øtate tail was limited unto her, and now when the Husband dieth if he ≈øhall be remitted to her e≈øtate for life;Co. 1 In≈øt. 357. 2 Cro. 489. which Windham granted; for that was her lawful e≈øtate, and the ≈øecond e≈øtate tortious. But by Rhodes, Periam, and Ander≈øon the Wife is at liberty to make her election which of the two e≈øtates ≈øhe will have. And as to the Writ to the Bi≈øhop for the Queen, the Court was clear of opinion, that it ought not to be granted upon this matter: But all the que≈øtion was, if Regina incon≈øulta, the Court would or ought to proceed: And it was holden clearly by the whole Court, that the tenure alledged modo & forma, could not be a tenure in chief, for it is ≈øaid, that the Land was holden of the King, as of the Ca≈øtle of Dover, in Capite.

div.head: LXXXVI. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco. Intr. Pa≈øc. 28 Eliz. Rot. 602.
div.p:
Wa≈øt. ‚Ä¢ Cro. 40. 4 ‚Ä¢ .WA≈øt was brought by F. and his Wife agai≈øt Pepy, and counted, that the ≈øaid Pepy was ≈øei≈øed, and enfeoffed certain per≈øons to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of the Wife of the Plaintiff and her Heirs. The Defendant pleaded, that the ≈øaid Feoffment was unto the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his Heirs in Fee, &c. without that, that it was to the u≈øes in the Count; Vpon which they were at i≈ø≈øue: And it was found by verdict, that the ≈øaid Feoffment was unto the u≈øes contained in the Count: But the Iury further found, that the e≈øtate of the Defendant by the limitation of the u≈øe was priviledged with the impunity for Wa≈øt, that is to ≈øay, without impeachment of Wa≈øt. And it was moved, if upon this verdict the Plaintiff ≈øhall have Iudgment: And Ander≈øon and Rhodes Iu≈øtices, he ≈øhall, for the matter in i≈ø≈øue is found for the Plaintiff, and that is the Feoffment to the u≈øes contained in the Count; and this impunity of Wa≈øt is a forrein matter not within the charge of the Iury, and therefore the traver≈øe of it but matter of ≈øurplu≈øage. As if I plead the Feoffment of I. S. To which the other pleads, that he did not enfeoff, and the Iury find a conditional Feoffment, the Court ≈øhall not re≈øpect the finding of the condition, for it was not in i≈ø≈øue, and no advantage ≈øhall ever be had of ≈øuch a liberty if it be not pleaded. 30 H. 8. Dyer 41. In Dower the Tenant pleaded, Ne unques ≈øei≈øi que Dower; the Tenant pleaded, that before the coverture of the Demandant, one A. was ≈øei≈øed of the Lands, of which Dower is demanded in tail, who made a Feoffment to a ≈øtranger, and took the Demandant to Wife, and took back an e≈øtate in Fee, and died ≈øei≈øed, having i≈ø≈øue inheritable: Now although upon the truth of the matter ≈øhe is
not dowable de jure, yet when the parties are at i≈ø≈øue upon a point certain,Hob. 53. Owen. 91. no foreign or ≈øtrange matter not in que≈øtion betwixt the parties ≈øhall be re≈øpected in the point of the Iudgment. But if the Defendant had pleaded it in bar, he might have foreclo≈øed the Demandant of her Dower: Vide 38 H. 6. 27. 47 E. 3. 19. In a Praecipe quod reddat in the default of the Tenant one cau≈øe and ≈øhewed how the Tenant who made default was but Tenant for life of the Lands in demand, the rever≈øion in Fee to him≈øelf, and prayed to be received. The Demandant did counter-plead the receit, ≈øaying, the Defendant had fee, upon which i≈ø≈øue was joyned. And it was found, that neither the tenant, nor he which prayed to be received, had any thing in the Land; In that ca≈øe the Court did not regard the matter which was ≈øuperfluous in the verdict, for they were at i≈ø≈øue upon a point certain, that is, whether the Tenant was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, for it was confe≈ø≈øed of both ≈øides, that he had an e≈øtate for life; and with that matter the Iury was not charged, and they are not to enquire of it, and ≈øo it was found again≈øt the Demandant, for which cau≈øe the Receit was granted. 7 H 6. 20. The parties were at i≈ø≈øue upon a dying ≈øei≈øed, which is found by verdict, but the Iury further find, that the other party made continual claim; this continual claim ≈øhall not be regarded in the point of Iudgment, becau≈øe it was pleaded in avoidance of the de≈øcent. Windh. Iu≈øtice contrary, Fora≈ømuch as it appeareth unto us upon the verdict, that the Plaintiff hath not cau≈øe of Action, and therefore he ≈øhall not have Iudgment; As in Detinue,No advantage of impunity for Wa≈øt ≈øhall be taken, where the ≈øame is not pleaded though found by verdict. Judgment. Hob. 53. Owen. 91. The Plaintiff counteth of a bailment by his own hand; the Defendant pleadeth, that he doth not detain, &c. the Iury find the Detinue, but upon a bailment by another hand: In this ca≈øe, notwith≈øtanding that the Detinue be found, yet the Plaintiff ≈øhall not have Iudgment: But Rhodes, Periam, and Ander≈øon in the principal ca≈øe were of opinion, Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff, for in no ca≈øe the party ≈øhall have advantage of ≈øuch a Liberty of impunity of Wa≈øt, if he do not plead it; And the Iurors are not to meddle with any matter which is not in i≈ø≈øue: And if it be but matter of ≈øurplu≈øage it is to no purpo≈øe. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: LXXXVII. Bracebridge and Baskerviles Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
AN Action of Debt is brought again≈øt three Executors,Debt again≈øt Executors. one of them pleads in Bar a Recovery again≈øt him≈øelf in the Kings Bench: The other two plead plene admini≈øtr. Again≈øt the fir≈øt plea the Plaintiff did aver covin; and upon the ≈øecond plea they are at i≈ø≈øue: The fir≈øt i≈ø≈øue is found for the Plaintiff, and as to the other plea, it was found, that the Defendants have in their hands thirty pounds of the goods of their Te≈øtator not admini≈øtred. Note, the debt in demand was one hundred pounds, upon which the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover the goods of the Te≈øtator, and thereupon had execution. Now the Plaintiff brought a Scire facias again≈øt the ≈øaid Executors, ≈øuppo≈øing that many other goods of the Te≈øtator have come unto their hands after the Iudgment, and prayed execution thereof: upon which the Defendant did demur in Law. Vide 2 ‚Ä¢
H. 6. 40. 41. In debt again≈øt Executors of forty marks, the Defendant pleaded, that he had fully admini≈øtred, and it was ≈øound, that the Defendant, at the day of the Writ brought, had of the goods of the dead twenty marks and no more, and gave damges five marks. There the Plaintiff had Iudgment for the twenty marks of the goods of the dead, and the five marks of their own goods: And as to the other twenty marks, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould be amerced: 33 H. 6. 24. Where Executors plead that they have nothing in their hands, which is found accordingly: Afterwards
goods of the Te≈øtator came to the hands of the Executors: Now the Plaintiff upon a ≈øurmi≈øe ≈øhall have out of the ≈øame Record a Scire facias to have execution of the ≈øaid goods:Scire facias, to have Execution of A≈ø≈øets come to Executors hands, after ‚Ä¢ iens enter maynes pleaded. But ≈øee 4 H. 6. 4. contrary, for there it is ≈øaid, that upon the matter the original is determined, and ≈øo no Record, upon which a Scire facias can be grounded: And ≈øee Fitzh. abridging the Ca≈øe Scire facias, 25. by the verdict and the Iudgment the Original is abated: Vide 7 E. 4. 9. by Moile, according to 33 H. 6. and ≈øo 46 E. 3. 9. by Belknap. And the Lord Ander≈øon demanded of the Prothonotaries the manner of the entry of the Iudgments given in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, who ≈øaid, that their Entry is in this manner: (i. e.) Quod querens recuperet, that which is expre≈øly found by the verdict, but nothing of the re≈øidue, for of that no mention is made at all. And the Court ≈øeemed to be of opinion, that where, upon nothing remaining in their hands, pleaded, It is found that ≈øome part of the ≈øum in demand is in the hands of the Executors, there the Plaintiff upon a ≈øurmi≈øe of goods come to the hands of the Executors ≈øhall have a Scire facias; 3 Cro. 272. Hob, 199. 1 Cro. 318. 319 592. 8 Co. 134. contrary, where upon ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, it is found fully for the Defendants, that they have nothing in their hands.

div.head: LXXXVIII. Fordleys Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Tender pleaded. 9 Co. 79. Dy. 25. a. 1 In≈øt 207. Po≈øt. 69. 70. a. FOrdley brought debt upon an Obligation, the Condition was, that if the Defendant, viz. the Obligor deliver unto the Plaintiff the Obligee, at a ≈øuch a day and place, twenty pounds or ten Kine, at the then choice of the Obligee, &c. that then, &c. The Court was clear of opinion, that the Defendant in pleading the performance thereof ought to tender to the Plaintiff as well the twenty pounds as the ten Kine, and for default thereof Iudgment was given again≈øt the Defendant. See the Number Roll T. 29 Eliz. 1. part. 324. vide 14 E. 4 4. b.

div.head: LXXXIX. Barker and Pigots Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: EDward Barker brought Debt again≈øt Rich. Pigot Executor of the Will of E. Executrix of the Will of R. The Defendant pleaded, that he had fully admini≈øtred the goods of his Te≈øtator E. upon which they were at i≈ø≈øue,Debt. which was found for the Plaintiff. And it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that here is not any i≈ø≈øue joyned, which an≈øwers to the Action, for the Action is brought again≈øt the Defendant in the quality of the Executor of an Executor, and the verdict extends to the Defendant, but is Executor of the ≈øaid E. for it is found by it, that the Defendant hath fully admini≈øtred the goods of his Te≈øtatrix, without any enquiry of the Admini≈øtration of the goods of the fir≈øt Te≈øtator R. in which capacity the Defendant is charged. So as here the Writ charges the Defendant in the quality of an Executor of an Executor and in re≈øpect of the fir≈øt Te≈øtator, and the i≈ø≈øue and verdict doth concern the la≈øt Te≈øtator:Execution mu≈øt follow the nature of the Action. And the whole Court was clear of opinion, that although that now after verdict Fee-tail be ≈øaved, and no Iudgment ≈øhall be given upon it, yet here the Court ≈øhall give Iudgment as upon a Nihil dicit, in which ca≈øe the Execution of the Iudgment, ≈øhall not fall upon the goods of the la≈øt Te≈øtator according to the verdict, but ≈øhall follow the nature of the Action which was brought again≈øt the Defendant as Executor of an Executor.

div.head: XC. Thacker and Elmers Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: THacker recovered in an A≈ø≈øize of Novel di≈ø≈øei≈øin again≈øt Elmer certain Lands in Hackney, and had execution:Re-di≈ø≈øei≈øin, and the Judgment in it. 1 Cro. 323. Elmer entred upon Thacker and ou≈øted him, and Redi≈ø≈øei≈øed him. Thacker re-entred, and afterwards brought a Redi≈ø≈øei≈øin; And it was moved, whether Thacker again≈øt his Entry might have a Redi≈ø≈øei≈øin: And the opinion of the whole Court was, that he might well maintain the Writ, for he is not thereby to recover any Land; but the Defendant of that Redi≈ø≈øei≈øin being convicted, ≈øhall be fined and impri≈øoned, and render double damages: Vide Book of Entries 502. the Iudgment in a Redi≈ø≈øei≈øin is, Quod recuperet ≈øei≈øinam ≈øuam of the Land.

div.head: XCI. Blaunchflower and Fryes Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: BLaunchflower brought debt upon a Bond again≈øt Elinor Frye, as Executrix of one Andrew Frye her late Husband, who pleaded,Debt. that this Writ was brought 9 July, 27 Eliz. whereof ≈øhe had notice the fir≈øt of October after, within which time one Lawrence had brought an Original Writ again≈øt the ≈øaid Elinor as Admini≈øtratrix of the ≈øaid Andrew: And after the bringing of the Writ, the Bi≈øhop of Bath and Wels committed Admini≈øtration of the goods of the ≈øaid Andrew to the ≈øaid Elinor, which Elinor confe≈ø≈øed the Action, upon which Iudgment was given for the ≈øaid Lawrence, beyond which ≈øhe had not goods, upon which the now Plaintiff did demur in Law. And by Ander≈øon, the Recovery pleaded in bar ≈øhall not bind the Plaintiff, becau≈øe it appeareth unpon the plea of the Defendant, that the Admini≈øtration was committed after the Writ purcha≈øed, which matter if the Defendant had pleaded,Admini≈øtration granted, pendant the Writ. Lawrence could not have had Iudgment to recover. As where there are three Executors, and debt is brought again≈øt two of them, if they do not plead that matter in abatment of the Writ, but plead, &c. or confe≈øs the Action, ≈øo that the Plaintiff hath Iudgment to Recover, that Recovery ≈øhall not bind a ≈øtranger who hath cau≈øe of Action again≈øt them, but that he may well fal≈øify it; and yet it was ≈øaid that in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, the Defendant by the obtaining of the Letters of Admini≈øtration had made the Writ good again≈øt her, vid. 13 H. 4. Fitz. Executors, 118. Admini≈øtration committed before the Writ purcha≈øed ≈øhall abate the Writ brought again≈øt the Defendant as Executor, but ≈øuch Admini≈øtration obtained, depending the Writ ≈øhall not abate it, vid. 21 H. 6. 8. 2 R. 3. 20. Another matter was moved by Ander≈øon, becau≈øe the Defendant had pleaded a Recovery by confe≈ø≈øion had again≈øt her without Averment that it was a true Debt, in which Ca≈øe Covin is pre≈øumed. Windham and Periam were of opinion, that the matter of Covin ought to come in on the part of the Plaintiff, which Ander≈øon denyed, vid. 9 E. 4. 13, 14. 33. t ‚Ä¢ e Cardinalls Ca≈øe.

div.head: XCII. Ba≈ø≈øet and Kerns Ca≈øe. Roll. Tit. Election. Debt by Executors. 1 Cro. 819 In Communi Banco Intrat. Mich. 26 & 27 Eliz. Rot. 12.
div.p:
BA≈ø≈øet the Executor of Moris Sheppheard brought debt upon a bond again≈øt Kerne, the Ca≈øe was: That Kerne was bound to Moris in a Obligation
upon Condition, that the ≈øaid Kerne ≈øhould pay to the ≈øaid Morris his Executors,1 Roll. 446. Tit. Condition. &c. at the choice and election of the ≈øaid Morris, within a month after the death of the Lady Kerne, thirty pounds, or twenty Kine,Election. to which the Defendant pleaded that the Plaintiff within the month after the death, &c. did not make any choice or election, upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law: And the Court was clear of opinion, that it was a good Plea in Bar, for the Obligor is not bounden to make a tender of both, viz. of the mony and the Ri ‚Ä¢ e; but the Obligee him≈øelf is bounden at his peril to make election within the time limited; As if I be bounden to you, to make unto you ≈øuch further a≈ø≈øurance within ≈øuch a time by Fine or Feoffment as you ≈øhall chu≈øe, it behoveth you to make election of your a≈ø≈øurance, Fine, or Feoffment; and in the principal Ca≈øe, the election of the Plaintiff ought to precede the tender of the Defendant: vid. the Lord Li≈øles Ca≈øe, 18 E. 4. 15. 17. 20. 21. Where the Defendant was bound to the ≈øaid Lord to ≈øhew his Evidences touching ≈øuch a Hou≈øe to the ≈øaid Lord or his Council, the election was to the Defendant to whom he would ≈øhew them; and there by Brian, if I be bound to you to marry your Daughter, or to go to York on your Bu≈øine≈ø≈øes upon reque≈øt, before you require me to marry your Daughter I may do it, or go to York, which Coke granted, vid. 13 E. 4. 4. Where the condition is in the di≈øjunctive, before the day of performance the Election is to the Defendant, but if at the day he make default, the Election is to the Obligee; vid. 9 E. 4. 36, 37. And by Windham, if I be bound unto you in an Obligation of ten pounds, to pay to you ≈øuch a day ten pounds in Gold, or Silver, if you do not make your election before the day, yet the duty remains payable, for the thing to be paid is parcel of the penalty, quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum; And as to the principal Ca≈øe, the Court was clear of opinion, that upon this matter the Plaintiff ≈øhould be barred. See before this Term, Forteleyes Ca≈øe.

div.head: XCIII Searches Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Antea 68. Habeas Corpus. A Habeas Corpus i≈ø≈øued forth out of the Court of Common Pleas, to the Steward and Mar≈øhal of the Hou≈øe, &c. for one Wil. Search, which was returned in this manner, viz. quod Domina Regina per litteras ≈øuas Patentes ≈øu≈øcepit, in protectionem ≈øuam regiam, Johannem Mabbe, and his ≈øureties, and of her further grace by the ≈øaid Letters, voluit, that if any per≈øon ≈øhould arre≈øt, or cau≈øe to be arre≈øted the ≈øaid John Mabbe or any of his ≈øureties, that then the Mar≈øhal of her Hou≈øe, or his lawful Deputy might arre≈øt every ≈øuch per≈øon, and detain them in Pri≈øon until ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhould an≈øwer before the Privy Council for the contempt; And that the ≈øaid William Search cau≈øed one John Pre≈øton one of the ≈øaid ≈øureties of the ≈øaid John Mabbe to be arre≈øted, &c. And upon that return, the ≈øaid William Search was di≈øcharged; And al≈øo becau≈øe that after the ≈øaid di≈øcharge the parties cau≈øed the ≈øaid William Search to be arre≈øted again for the ≈øame cau≈øe, that is, by colour of the ≈øaid protection; An Attachment was granted again≈øt them.

Note, that the ≈øame Term, Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. Another Habeas Corpus was directed to the Steward and Mar≈øhal of the Mar≈øhal≈øey, for one Howel, Habeas Corpus. who made return, that the ≈øaid Howel was committed to his cu≈øtody, per mandatum Franci≈øci Wal≈øingham Militis Principalis Secretarij, & unius de privato concilio Dominae Reginae, and that return was by the Court holden in≈øufficient, becau≈øe the cau≈øe upon which he was committed, was not ≈øet down in the return; and therefore day was given to
amend the return, and now they returned the Writ in this manner, ≈ø≈ø. infra nominatus Johannes Howel commi≈ø≈øus fuit, &c. ex ≈øententia & mandato totius concilii privati Dominae Reginae; Ita quod corpus ejus habere non po≈ø≈øumus, &c. And that return was al≈øo holden by the Court to be in≈øufficient, for (by what≈øoever per≈øon, or by what means ≈øoever he was committed) the conclu≈øion of the return ought to be, Corpus tamen ejus paratum habeo, and if it ≈øhall ≈øeem good to the Court, that the Pri≈øoner ≈øhall have his Priviledge, and ≈øhall be di≈ømis't, he ≈øhall be di≈øcharged, but if not, then he ≈øhall be remanded. And the Court took a difference, where one is committed by one of the Privy Council, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe the cau≈øe of the committing ought to be ≈øet down in the return; But contrary where the party is committed by the whole Council, there no cau≈øe need to be alleadged.

div.head: XCV. Bret and Audars Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
BRet brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Audar, Debt upon a Bond to perform Award. Owen. 7. the Condition of which Obligation was, that the Defendant ≈øhould ≈øtand to the Award, &c. And the Arbitrator awarded, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay unto the Plaintiff ten pounds, without naming day or place; And as to that the Defendant pleaded, that he was always ready, and yet is, &c. without ≈øhewing any tender: And it was moved, That although that would have been a good Plea in debt upon an Arbitrament, as the Ca≈øe is, 7 H. 4. 97. See 21 E. 4. 40, 41, 42. Yet now by the Obligation and the Condition of it, the ≈øum is payable in another manner than it was before, ≈øee the pleading of the Ca≈øe, 21 E. 4. In Debt upon an Obligation to perform the Award; That the Award was made between the Terms of Pa≈øch. and Trinity, and he, the eighth of September after, tendred the twenty pounds, and the Plaintiff refu≈øed it. And the Lord Ander≈øon put a difference between the Ca≈øe, in 22 H. 6. 57.Tender. and the Ca≈øe at the Bar, for in our Ca≈øe the Obligation doth precede the duty which accrueth by the Award ≈øub≈øequent, but in the former Ca≈øe the duty did precede the Obligation which was made for the further a≈ø≈øurance of the duty: And here the Defendant ought to have pleaded the tender, and ≈øee 14. E. 4. 4. A. is bound unto B. that, where he hath granted to the ≈øaid B. a Rent-charge out of ≈øuch Land, now if the ≈øaid B. ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øaid Rent according to the form and effect of the ≈øaid Grant, that then, &c. there he needs not to plead any tender, for the Rent is not payable in other manner than it was before; contrary if the Condition had been for the payment of the Annuity: And of that opinion was the whole Court, that he ought to have pleaded a tender. Another matter of the Award was, that the ≈øaid Audar ≈øhould yield up, ≈øurrender & relinqui≈øh to the Plaintiff all ≈øuch Hou≈øes and Tenements which he had in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by rea≈øon of the cu≈øtody of the ≈øaid Plaintiff: As to that the Defendant pleaded, that he had yielded up, &c. All ≈øuch Hou≈øes, &c. generally without ≈øhewing which in certain; And for that cau≈øe the Court was clear of opinion, that the Plea was not good; which ≈øee 9 E. 4. 16. If I be bounden upon condition to enfeoff the Obligee of all Lands, & Tenements, which were to I.S. in pleading the performance of that Condition, I ought to ≈øhew what Lands and Tenements in certain, for they pa≈øs out of me by the Feoffment; See al≈øo 12 H. 8. 7. 13 H. 8.Non damnificatus, generally, where no Plea. 19. Another point of the Award was, That the ≈øaid Audar ≈øhould acquit and di≈øcharge, and ≈øave harmle≈øs the Plaintiff of ≈øuch an Obligation, to which the Defendant pleaded, that Querens non fuit damnificatus, and that Plea was holden in≈øufficient, for he ought to have ≈øhewed, how he had di≈øcharged him, and it is not ≈øufficient to an≈øwer only to the damnification, as if I be bounden to convey unto you the Manor
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
of B. in pleading the performance of the condition, it is not ≈øufficient to ≈øhew, that I have conveyed the ≈øaid Manor, but to ≈øhew by what manner of conveyance, viz. by Fine, or Feoffment, &c. 22 E. 4. 43. If the condition be to di≈øcharge the Plaintiff, &c. then the manner of the di≈øcharge ought to be ≈øhewed, but if it be to ≈øave harmle≈øs only, then non damnificatus generally is good enough, 40 E. 3. 20. 38 H. 6. 39. The condition of an Obligation was, that the Obligor ≈øhould keep without damage the Obligee, of ≈øuch a ≈øum of mony again≈øt B. to whom he was bounden for the payment of it, and the ≈øaid Obligor pleaded that at ≈øuch a day, &c. the ≈øaid B. at his reque≈øt delivered the Obligation to the Plaintiff in liew of an acquittance, without that, that the Plaintiff was damnified by the ≈øaid Obligation, before the delivery of it; and it was holden by the Court, that if the Defendant had pleaded, that he had kept the Plaintiff without damage, and had not ≈øhewed how, that the Plea had not been good. See 22 E. 4. 40. The Lord Li≈øles Ca≈øe. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
XCVI. Heydons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz.
div.p: RAlph Heydon pretending title to certain Land, entred into it, and made a Lea≈øe of it to try the title: Vpon which his Le≈ø≈øee brought an Ejectione firmae, in which the parties were at I≈ø≈øue; And now at the day of the Enque≈øt, the Iurors were called, and but five of them appeared, whereupon, the Defendant came and ≈øhewed to the Court, that the ≈øaid Heydon by his Friends and Servants, had laboured the Iury, not to appear, and that for the further vexation of the Defendant who had four Verdicts in affirmance of his title, that the ≈øaid Heydon to procure the Iury not to appear, had ≈øurmi≈øed to them, that he and the Defendant were in cour≈øe of an agreement, whereas in truth no ≈øuch communication of agreement had any time pa≈ø≈øed betwixt them: And all this was openly depo≈øed in Court, as well upon the oath of the Defendant him≈øelf as upon the oath of one of the Iurors, upon which the Court awarded an Attachment again≈øt the ≈øaid Heydon, to an≈øwer the contempt; And al≈øo granted to the Defendant, that he might ≈øue a Decem tales with provi≈øo, for his own expedition.

div.head: XCVII. Smith and Kirfoots Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
Debt upon Arbitrament. SMith brought Debt upon an Arbitrament again≈øt Kirfoot, and declared that the Defendant and he, impo≈øuerunt ≈øe in arbitrium, ordinationem, & judicium Johannis Popham ar. arbitratoris indifferenter electi, de jure, titulo, & inture≈ø≈øe in quibu≈ødam Me≈ø≈øuagijs, &c. Who taking upon him the burthen of the Arbitration, ordinavit, that the ≈øaid Defendant ≈øhould pay unto the Plaintiff ten pounds, in plenam ≈øatisfactionem, &c. and thereupon he brought his Action; It was moved by Walme≈øley Serjeant, that the Declaration is not ≈øufficient, for it appeareth that the Arbitrament ≈øet forth in the Declaration is utterly void; becau≈øe whereas ten pounds is awarded to the Plaintiff, nothing is awarded to the Defendant, and ≈øo the Award unequal, and ≈øo void. But the Court was clear of opinion, that notwith≈øtanding that ≈øuch an Arbitrament be void in Law, yet it may be for any thing that appeareth, that the award is good enough:1 Cro. 904. ‚Ä¢ Cro. 354. 355. For the Plaintiff is not to ≈øhew in his Declaration all the Award, but ≈øuch part only of it which doth entitle him to the
thing, &c. and if the Defendant will impeach the Award for any thing, that is to come in on his part, vide. ac. Book of Entries, 152. 123. vide. For the Arbitrament, 39 H. 6. 12. by Moile, 7 H. 6. 41.

div.head: XCVIII. Arundel again≈øt Morris. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: RIchard Arundel ≈øued an Audita Querela again≈øt Morris, and it was comprehended in the Writ; That Morris had recovered again≈øt him a certain Debt, and that he was taken by a Capias ad ≈øatisfaciendum; Audita Querela. at the ≈øuit of the ≈øaid Morris, by Hickford Sheriff of the County of Glouce≈øter; who let him go at large, &c. And they were at i≈ø≈øue, upon the voluntary e≈øcape, & it was found for the Plaintiff. It was objected in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that the Writ of Audita Querela is not good, for the words are, that the Plaintiff, captus fuit virtute brevis no≈øtri judicialis; whereas this word (judicialis) is not in the Regi≈øter; but only brevis no≈øtri de capiendo. But by the whole Court, the Writ is good, for the word (judicialis) is but a word of ≈øurplu≈øage, and ≈øhall not make void the Writ: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: XCIX. Brook again≈øt King. Mich. 29 & 30. Eliz.
div.p: IN Debt upon an Obligation by Brook again≈øt King, the Defendant pleaded that the Bond was endorced, with ≈øuch condition, viz. Debt. That it the ≈øaid Defendant King ≈øhall procure one I.S. to make rea≈øonable recompence to the Plaintiff for certain Bea≈øts which he wrongfully took from the Plaintiff, that then, &c. And he ≈øaid in facto, That the ≈øaid I. S. had ≈øtolen the ≈øaid Bea≈øts from the Plaintiff,Condition again≈øt Law. and thereof he was endicted, &c. and ≈øo the condition being again≈øt the Law, the Obligation was void, upon which the Plaintiff did demurr in Law. And it was argued by the whole Court: That where the condition of an Obligation ≈øhall be ≈øaid again≈øt the Law, and therefore the Obligation void, the ≈øame ought to be intended where the condition is expre≈øly again≈øt the Law in expre≈øs words, and in terminis terminantibus, Po≈øt. 103. and not for matter out of the condition, as it is in this ca≈øe; And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: C. Hawks again≈øt Mollineux. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: IN a Replevin by Hawks again≈øt Mollineux who avowed for Damagefe≈øant; The Plaintiff in Bar of the Avowry, pleaded that Sir Gerva≈øe Pa≈øton Knight, was ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈ø≈øuage and twenty Acres of Land; And that always tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate,Replevi ‚Ä¢ Yelv. 185. Pre≈øcription. &c. have u≈øed to have Common in the place where, &c. for all their Cattel commonable in this manner, viz. If the ≈øaid Land be ≈øowed by a≈ø≈øent of the Commoner, then no Common, until the Corn be mowed, and when the Corn is mowed, then Common until the Land ≈øhall be ≈øowed again by a≈ø≈øent of the Commoners: And this Pre≈øcription was found by Verdict, and exception was taken to this pre≈øcription becau≈øe again≈øt common right, ≈øo as a man cannot ≈øow his Land without the leave of another. But the exception was di≈øallowed by the Court; for the pre≈øcription was holden to be good by the whole Court, for by the Law of the Land, the Owner of the Land cannot plow the Land where another hath Common; but here is a benefit to each party, as well for the Owner of the Land again≈øt the Commoner, as for the Commoner again≈øt the Tenant of the Land, for each of them hath a qualified Intere≈øt in the Land.

div.head: CI. Baldwin and Cocks Ca≈øe. Intr. Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. Rot. 1410. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Replevin. Owen 52. Po≈øt. 225. 1 In≈øt. 225. 2. BAldwin was Plaintiff in a Replevin again≈øt Cocks, and upon the pleading the Ca≈øe appeared to be this, That Sir Richard Wayneman was ≈øei≈øed of the place where, &c. and lea≈øed the ≈øame to one Truepeny and one Eliz. Reade for term of 21 years, if the ≈øaid Truepeny and Eliz. or any child or children betwixt them begotten ≈øhould live ≈øo long; Eliz. within the term died without i≈ø≈øue; If now the term for 21 years be determined was the Que≈øtion. And the Lord Ander≈øon conceived, that the e≈øtate for years is not determined by the death of Elizabeth. And it was argued by Shuttleworth Serjeant, that upon the matter the term is determined: And he put the Ca≈øe of the Lord Bray, 3 Eliz. Dyer 190. Where the Lord Bray ≈øold unto four great Lords the marriage of his Son and Heir, to the intent to be married at the appointment and nomination of the ≈øaid Lords, the Lord Bray died, one of the ≈øaid Lords before any marriage,5 Co. 9 1 Brown. 31. 46, 47. 80. 101. 2 Br. 83. 148. or appointment, or nomination, died, the Son is married by the appointment, &c. of the ≈øurviving Lords; That marriage is not within the intent of the Covenant, and adjudged that upon that marrriage no u≈øe ≈øhall accrue. And al≈øo he cited this Ca≈øe adjudged in the Kings Bench. The admini≈øtration is committed to one durante minore aeta ‚Ä¢ e of two Infants, one of them becomes of full age, the power of the Admini≈øtration is determined, which Walme≈øley Serjeant granted, for it is but an authority; but here in the Ca≈øe at Bar is a matter of intere≈øt. And by Ander≈øon all the con≈øtruction of this lea≈øe and grant re≈øts upon this point, if this word (Or) either ≈øhall be taken as di≈øjunctive as it is in its nature, or as a conjunctive; and if it be taken as a di≈øjunctive, if it make the whole ≈øentence in the di≈øjunctive as if the limitation had been, if the Husband or Wife or any Child, &c. And Fenner, put this Ca≈øe out of 17 E. 3. as he cited it. Land is given to I. S. in Fee ≈øo long as A. B. hath i≈ø≈øue of his body. A. B. dieth without i≈ø≈øue, his Wife priviment en ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ent, Now the e≈øtate is determined, and upon birth of the i≈ø≈øue after ≈øhall not revive, which Rhodes and Ander≈øon denied, for in many Ca≈øes the Law ≈øhall re≈øpect the exi≈øtency of the child in the mothers belly: And ≈øee 7 Eliz. Plow. 289. where a Copulative ≈øhall be taken in the di≈øjunctive, as a covenant with B. to make a lea≈øe for years of ≈øuch Lands to the ≈øaid B. and his A≈ø≈øigns,Expo≈øition of words in deeds. 244. Po≈øt. 251. 1 Roll. 444. the ≈øame ≈øhall be con≈øtrued, or his A≈ø≈øigns. And it was clearly agreed by the other parties, that if the words had been, If Truepeny, Elizabeth, or any child or children, &c. ≈øo long, &c. upon the death of any of them the intere≈øt is determined: And by Rhodes, Periam and Windham in the principal Ca≈øe, the lea≈øe ≈øhall endure as long as any of the per≈øons named in the Provi≈øo ≈øhall live, and ≈øo ≈øeemed to be the meaning of the parties. And Ander≈øon hae≈øitavit in the words of the limitation, i. the Habendum to the ≈øaid Truepeny and Eliz. for 21 years a fe≈øto Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øt. po≈øt terminum annorum (the expiration of a former term) if the ≈øaid Truepeny and Elizabeth, or any child &c. And he conceived, that the limitation did go to the commencement of the lea≈øe only, and not to the expiration or determination, as if the lea≈øe ≈øhould not begin if they all were not alive at the commencement of the lea≈øe: And all the other Iu≈øtices were clear of the contrary opinion, for by them this limitation ≈øhall go, and ≈øhall be referred to the determination of the Lea≈øe, and not to the commencement of it.

Ander≈øon, If any cau≈øe ≈øhould be, for which the lea≈øe ≈øhould endure untill the years be encurred, notwith≈øtanding the death of the Husband or Wife, it was becau≈øe the lea≈øe was intended a common advancement to both,
for it ≈øhould be in vain to name the Wife in the lea≈øe, if the lea≈øe ≈øhould cea≈øe by the death of the Husband. And afterwards after many arguments on both ≈øides, it was adjudged, that by the death of Elizabeth, the lea≈øe was not determined, for the disjunctive before (Child) makes all the limitation in the disjunctive.

div.head: CII. Zouch and Bamfields Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
THe Ca≈øe between the Lord Zouch and Bamfield was now argued by the Iu≈øtices. And Rhodes the pui≈øne Iu≈øtice argued,1 And. 165. 3 Co. 88. that the Lord Zouch the Demandant ≈øhould be barred. Four Exceptions have been taken to the bar: Fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is not ≈øhewed in the bar that the moyety of tho≈øe ≈øixty me≈ø≈øuages, &c. of which he pleads the Fine, was parcel of the Manor at the time of the Fine levyed; for the pleading is, that the Grandfather of the Demandant was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor, unde medietas praedictorum 60. me≈ø≈øuagiorum, &c. a tempore cujus contrar. memoria, &c. was parcel, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed de manerio praedict. unde, &c. Finis ≈øe levavit; and he conceived that the pleading, notwith≈øtanding that was good enough; for he hath ≈øaid as much in effect, contrar. cujus memoria hominum non exi≈øtit, in the pre≈øent ten≈øe, which amounts to this, that men cannot remember, &c. but that this moyety was parcel of the ≈øaid Manor: As 10 H. 7 12. In an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Common, the Plaintiff makes his title, that he was ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈ø≈øuage and Carve of Land in D. to which the ≈øaid Common is appendant, and that he and all his Ance≈øtors, and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath, &c. have u≈øed to have Common, &c. Exception was taken to the title, becau≈øe the Plaintiff doth not ≈øhew in his title, that he is ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈ø≈øuage, &c. for if he hath aliened the Me≈ø≈øuage the Common pa≈ø≈øeth, ≈øo if he be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, &c. but the Exception was not allowed, for it appeareth upon the words of the title, that the Plaintiff is ≈øei≈øed: i. all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath in the pre≈øent ten≈øe, which words do ≈øhew and declare po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and ≈øei≈øin in the Plaintiff, the time of the plea pleaded; ≈øo in this ca≈øe, the ≈øub≈øtance of the words, in which the defect is a≈ø≈øigned, is ut ≈øupra; That men cannot remember, but that this moyety was parcel of the Manor, and then the words after, unde, &c. reddidit Manerium praedict. unde, &c. ≈øhall have the ≈øame con≈øtruction as before. Periam conceived, that the Bar is nought for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid, for it is not ≈øo pleaded, that we can adjudge upon it, that the ≈øaid moyety was parcel of the Manor at the time of the Fine levyed, and then the Fine cannot extend unto it. And the rea≈øon alledged by my brother Rhodes ≈øhall not help that matter, for the ≈øaid words cannot be con≈øtrued otherwi≈øe, but that no man can remember but the ≈øaid moyety was parcel, but not that it is parcel, or at the time of the Fine levyed was parcel. Vide 32 H. 6. 24. In Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant pleaded, That A. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. whereof the place, &c. is parcel, he ought to ≈øay expre≈øly, that the place where was parcel of the Manor at the time of the tre≈øpa≈øs ≈øuppo≈øed. Windham conceived, that the plea was good, and that it appeareth well upon this plea, that the ≈øaid moyety was parcel of the ≈øaid Manor at the time of the Fine levyed, for he pleads, that the Grandfather of the Demandant was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of N. Unde medietas praedictorum, &c. a tempore cujus contrar. memoria hominum non exi≈øtit, & ≈øic ≈øci≈øitus exi≈øtens, Finis ≈øe levavit; ≈øic ≈øci≈øitus; i. e. ≈øei≈øed of the Manor in ≈øuch ≈øort, as the Manor is ≈øet forth before, and that is good pleading, e≈øpecially by way of bar, which if it be good to a common intent, is well enough; and the word (unde, &c.) ≈øo often repeated after ≈øhall be idle and to no purpo≈øe if the Law ≈øhall not give ≈øuch a con≈øtruction. Ander≈øon to the ≈øame purpo≈øe. And he much
relyed upon the rea≈øon of Windham, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed. Another Exception was taken to the Bar,Averrment. becau≈øe in pleading of the Fine, it is not averred, that the Conu≈øor at the time of the Fine levyed was of full age, out of pri≈øon, &c. And as to that Rhodes took the difference between the pleading upon the Statute of 1 H. 3. where the≈øe di≈øabilities are within the purview of the ≈øaid Statute, and upon the Statute of 4 H. 7. where in the body of the Statute no mention is made of them, but afterwards in an e≈øpecial Exception by it ≈øelf; and he cited the opinion of the Iu≈øtices, e≈øpecially of the Lord Dyer in the Ca≈øe reported by Plowd. 5 Eliz. 365. betwixt Stowel and the Lord Zouch. Periam to the ≈øame intent, and upon the ≈øame rea≈øon, and further he ≈øaid that although the Statute of 32 H. 8. contains in its purview the ≈øame di≈øabilities; Yet this Fine is pleaded upon the Statute of 4 H. 7. and therefore the pleading of the ≈øame ≈øhall not be directed nor waged by the Statute of 32 H. 8. which doth not alter the pleading of a Fine which was before, nor the rea≈øon of it; for it is not properly a Statute, nor do Fines receive any ≈øtrength or virtue by it, but is but a con≈øtruction of the ≈øaid former Statute. And he put the Ca≈øe betwixt Hide and Umpton; where Umpton mean betwixt the Statutes of 32 and 34 H. 8. Declared his Will of all his Lands, which devi≈øe if it be good for two parts of the Land devi≈øed it was doubted, or that the devi≈øe ≈øhould be void for the whole; afterwards came the Stat. of 34 H. 8. and cleared the doubt, for to that intent it was made; and in the ≈øaid Statute there is a Provi≈øo, that the ≈øaid Statute ≈øhall not extend to the Will or the Devi≈øe of Tho. Umpton, or ≈øhall be prejudicial or hurtful to any per≈øon or per≈øons for any Lands &c. contained or ≈øpecified in the ≈øaid Will or Devi≈øe, but that the ≈øaid Will and Devi≈øe ≈øhall ≈øtand, remain and be in the ≈øame ca≈øe, in force and effect in the Law, as the ≈øame was before the making of this Act. Now, notwith≈øtanding that Provi≈øo, the Will of Umpton was holden good but for two parts, for ≈øo the Statute of 34. H. 8. con≈øtrued the Statute of 32 H. 8. So in our Ca≈øe, the Statute of 32 H. 8. of Fines con≈øtrues the Statute of 4 H. 7. to extend to Fines levyed by Tenant in tail, therefore the e≈øtate tail ≈øhall be adjudged in Law to be bound by the Statute of 4 H. 7. and not by 32 H. 8. which is rather a Iudgment upon the ≈øaid Statute of 4 H. 7. than any new Statute. Windham to the ≈øame intent, and he relyed upon the rea≈øon afore≈øaid. And further ≈øaid, if one will plead a Lea≈øe made by Tenant in tail upon the Statute of 32 H. 8. he need not to aver the full age of the Le≈ø≈øor, and yet that quality of full age is within the purview of the ≈øaid Statute. Fir≈øt all Lea≈øes to be made, &c. by any per≈øon being of full age, &c. and ≈øo is the common u≈øe of pleadings. And of the ≈øame opinion was the Lord Ander≈øon for the ≈øaid Exception, for the rea≈øons, and upon the difference afore≈øaid. Another Exception was taken to the Bar, becau≈øe it is not alledged, that the ≈øaid Fine was engro≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Term in which it was levyed. And as to that, it was holden by Rhodes, that in pleading of a Fine it needs not to ≈øhew any engro≈ø≈øing of it; and ≈øo are many Pre≈øidents, vide Plowd. Com. Smith and Stapletons Ca≈øe, 15 Eliz. 428. Where a Fine was pleaded, Quaedam finalis concordia facta fuit in Octav. Sancti Hillarii 35 H. 8. & po≈øtea a die Pa≈øch. in quindecem dies 36 H 8. conce≈ø≈øa & recordata, &c. Super quem finem proclam. ≈øecundum formam Statuti factae fuer. viz. prima proclam. 7. Maii. Term. Pa≈øch. 36 H. 8. without any mention of the engro≈ø≈øing of it: And ≈øee the Ca≈øe betwixt Stowel and the Lord Zouch, where the Fine is pleaded as it is pleaded in the Ca≈øe at Bar, quiquidem finis in forma praedict. levatus (and that fine was levyed Pa≈øch. 30 H. 8.) ingro≈ø≈øatus fuit, & po≈øtea in Curia praedict. ≈øecundum formam Stattui, &c. lectus, & proclamatus fuit, viz. prim. proclam. Term. Pa≈øch. 30 H. 8. And ≈øo upon the matter it is ≈øufficient to ≈øhew, that the Fine was engro≈ø≈øed the ≈øame term in which it was levyed, for the Fine is pleaded to be levyed Term. Pa≈øch. qui quidem Finis ingro≈ø≈øatus fuit, & po≈øtea proclam. viz. prim. proclam. Termino Pa≈øch. which was the ≈øame Term it was
levyed: And ≈øo, admit, that in pleading it ought to be ≈øhewed that the Fine was ingro≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Term in which it was levyed, &c. Now it appears here to us by nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, that the Fine was ingro≈ø≈øed accordingly. And al≈øo the Ingro≈ø≈øment is pleaded as the Statute is penned, for the words of the Statute of 4 H. 7. are, after the engro≈ø≈øing of every Fine, the ≈øame Fine to be openly read and proclaimed in the ≈øame Court, the ≈øame Term, and ≈øo the words of our plea here pur≈øue the words of the Statute; for the ≈øaid Statute doth not require by expre≈øs words, that the Fine be engro≈ø≈øed the ≈øame Term, but the ≈øame is to be conceived by matter of con≈øtruction and implication, and according to ≈øuch manner of ≈øpeech this plea is pleaded. And al≈øo the proclamations are endor≈øed upon the Fine, and then they appear upon the Fine, according to the words of the ≈øaid conclu≈øion. And ≈øo by Windham are many Pre≈øidents, and ≈øo in the ≈øaid Ca≈øe between Stowel and the Lord Zouch cited before, pro ut per finem illum hic de record. remanen. plane liquet. And See 1 Eliz. Plowden 224. between Willion and Barkly, a Fine pleaded without any pro ut, &c. Ander≈øon took an Exception to the Bar at the beginning of it, i. Quod medietas 60 Me≈ø≈øuagiorum, &c. parcel. medietatis 70 Me≈ø≈øuag. praedict. that that is no good pleading; for one moyety cannot be parcel of another moyety, for every moyety is entire.

Rhodes took Exception to the Replication, becau≈øe the Demandant in avoidance of the Fine, that at the time of the Fine levyed Bamfield was ≈øei≈øed, & ≈øemper po≈øtea, & hucu≈øque, &c. of the moyety in Deme≈øn, and doth not traver≈øe the ≈øei≈øin of the Conu≈øor at the time of the Fine levyed, for here two contrary pleas ≈øtand before us in equity of truth; aeque vera, aeque fal≈øa, aeque dubia, and a traver≈øe would have made an end of all, and reduced the matter to certainty: And by Periam, the Bar is not an≈øwered, for every Bar ought to be traver≈øed, confe≈ø≈øed, or avoided, See 6 H. 7. 5, and 6. where it is ≈øaid by Hu≈ø≈øey and Fairfax, where matter in fact is alledged by way of Bar it ought to be traver≈øed, if it be not for the mi≈øcheif of tryal, as in ca≈øe of Ba≈øterdy, where a thing is alledged to be done beyond the ≈øea; or to leave the matter in Law to the Court, without putting the ≈øame to the Iudgment of the Lay-people, &c. See al≈øo 5 H. 7. 12. Where it is holden, that a thing material alledged in the Bar ought to be directly traver≈øed, or confe≈ø≈øed, or avoided in fact or in Law, or conclude the other party by matter of e≈øtoppel: And that two affirmatives cannot make a good i≈ø≈øue; But the matter alledged in the Replication ≈øcil. that Bamfield was ≈øei≈øed at the time of the Fine levyed ≈øhall be holden for void, and the matter alledged in the Bar, ≈øcil. that the Coun≈øor was ≈øei≈øed, as not an≈øwered; for it ≈øhall be taken true, until it ≈øhall be avoided and de≈øtroyed by matter in Law, traver≈øe, &c. Vide Librum. So he in default of traver≈øe, the Bar is not an≈øwered but argumentative, ≈øcil. Bamfield was ≈øei≈øed, ergo, the Conu≈øor was not ≈øei≈øed: And it is a common learning that in every Replication there ought to be certainty as to that: See the Ca≈øe betwixt Fulmer≈øton and Steward 2 Ma. 103. that a Bar ought not to be an≈øwered by argument:
And as to the certainty which is requi≈øite in a Replication. See the Ca≈øe betwixt Wimbi≈øh and Talboies, Plow. Com. 4 E. 6. 42. where the Plaintiff ≈øhewed in his Replication his title as Heir, but becau≈øe he did not ≈øhew, how heir, for want of ≈øuch certainty in the Replication, the Plaintiff could never have Iudgment, although the Iu≈øtices for the matter in Law then in que≈øtion were clearly re≈øolved for the Plaintiff; and here in this Replication the incertainty is ≈øuch, that the Court doth not know to which to give credit, to the Plaintiff, or to the Def. and the bare matter of the Replication is not ≈øufficient; For in avoidance of a Fine, to ≈øay, that a ≈øtranger to the Fine, at the time of the Fine levyed, was ≈øei≈øed, was never received, but that, partes Finis nihil habuerunt, that was the ordinary plea. And we ought in this Ca≈øe fir≈øt to be in≈øured of the matter of fact; ≈øcil. Whether Zouch or Bamfield were ≈øei≈øed, and the Court doth not know to which to give credit, 39 H. 6. 49. in Debt by an Executor, the Defendant pleaded, that the Te≈øtator made the Plaintiff and one A. his Executor, wich A. is living, and the Plaintiff pleaded, that the ≈øaid A. died within ≈øuch a Ward before the Writ brought, &c. and adjudged no plea, without traver≈øe, without that, he was dead, for here are 2 affirmatives, whereon a good i≈ø≈øue cannot ri≈øe, which ≈øee 32 H. 6. 23. Ander≈øon to the ≈øame intent. Rhodes, admitting now that the Bar be naught, and the Replication faulty, as it is, then I conceive, that if the point of the Action be confe≈ø≈øed by the Bar, the Court ≈øhall give Iudgment upon the Bar, and ≈øhall not meddle with the Replication; but if it be not confe≈ø≈øed by the Bar, that then there ≈øhall be a Repleader. And I do conceive, that a Repleader may be awarded upon a Demurrer in Law: which ≈øee Plowd. 1 Ma. in the Ca≈øe betwixt Browning and Be≈øton 138. In Tre≈øpa≈øs the Plaintiff doth ≈øuppo≈øe the Tre≈øpa≈øs in two places, ≈øcil. in Berme≈øtreet and in Southwark in the County of Surrey; as to the Tre≈øpa≈øs in Southwark the Defendant doth ju≈øtifie by ≈øpecial matter of a Lea≈øe, without an≈øwering any thing to the Tre≈øpa≈øs in Berme≈øtreet. The Book which hath been vouched to the contrary out of 9 H. 6. Ander≈øon was of opinion, that as this Ca≈øe is, no Repleader ≈øhall be, and yet he held the Repleader might be upon a Demurrer as well as upon an I≈ø≈øue joyned; For a Demurrer joyned is an I≈ø≈øue to be tryed by the Iudges, &c. and ≈øuch was the opinion of Manwood chief Baron. Plowd. 171. and ≈øee the Ca≈øe betwixt Partridge and Croker; and ≈øo was opinion of the Lord Ander≈øon, who relyed much upon the Ca≈øe, where it is ≈øaid, that in pleading a plea, all matters in fact well and materially alledged by a general Demurrer are confe≈ø≈øed to be true.

Rhodes. Now we are to ≈øee, if by the Statute of 27 Eliz. cap. 5. Antea 43, 44. Periam to the contrary. In A≈ø≈øi≈øe, upon whom the Plaintiff, where it ≈øhould be upon whom the Defendant entred; And if the Averment u≈øual as above was mi≈øs-≈øet down, it was amendable, but if it were utterly left out, not, but now in both Ca≈øes it is amendable, ≈øo, defendit vim & injuriam quando, &c. if it be left out, it is amendable, for all the≈øe matters lye in the Conu≈øance of the Clark, but in our Ca≈øe, the right of the cau≈øe and matter doth not appear unto us, for if Bamfield was ≈øei≈øed at the time of the Fine levyed, then as the Demandant and his Coun≈øel pretend, the Law is with the Demandant, and if the Conu≈øor and not the Demandant, then the Law is with the Tenant, as his Coun≈øel hath argued, ≈øo as the right of the cau≈øe con≈øi≈øts and depends upon the truth of the ≈øei≈øin, which matter doth not appear unto us: And if we enter in cour≈øe of amendment,
we do not know if the Demandant would have traver≈øed, without that that the Conu≈øor was ≈øei≈øed, which ≈øhall not be a good Traver≈øe, or ab≈øque hoc, quod partes ad finem aliquid habuerunt, &c. which although it be a good Traver≈øe in Law, yet we do not know if the truth of the cau≈øe will ≈øerve to maintain ≈øuch matter, and becau≈øe without altering matter we cannot amend the Plea. Windham to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; For by the Statute of 27 Eliz. we ought to judge in this ca≈øe, as the right of the cau≈øe and matter in Law ≈øhall appear; but in this ca≈øe neither the right of the cau≈øe nor the matter in Law appeareth unto us, according to which we can judge, for we know not to which of the parties to give credit, touching the ≈øei≈øin of the Conu≈øor, or Bamfeild at the time of the Fine levyed, for as to our judicial knowledge, both Pleas are to us equally dubious; And he agreed the Ca≈øes put before touching amendment of matters upon default of the Clark, ≈øcil. de hoc ponit ≈øe ≈øuper patriam, left out, ≈øo colour in A≈ø≈øize, and Tre≈øpa≈øs wanting, ≈øo, & hoc paratus e≈øt verificare, all which matters are amendable by the Statute of 27. Eliz. But he ≈øaid, that if in Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant doth ju≈øtify by a Lea≈øe for years, without ≈øhewing the place where the Lea≈øe is made, it is not amendable, for it is matter which lyeth in the notice of the party only, and not in our judicial knowledge: And as to the Ca≈øe of 5 H. 7. 1. of the places left, he conceived it is not amendable in another Term by this Statute, for that is material, and the filling of tho≈øe ≈øpaces the parties them≈øelves ≈øhall ≈øupply and not the Court, for the Court ≈øhall never amend, where their amendment makes alteration of the ≈øub≈øtance of the pleading, or of the Verdict, as 20 H. 6. 15. In Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Plaintiff declared of a continuando u≈øque diem impetrationis brevis, viz. 18. die Martii, where the Te≈øte of the Writ was, 2 die Januarij, the Defendant pleaded to I≈ø≈øue, which was found for the Plaintiff, and that Mi≈øpri≈øion of the Te≈øte or date of the Writ could not be amended. And no amendment upon this Stat. of 27 Eliz. two things are to be con≈øidered.

Ander≈øon, to the ≈øame intent, for as it hath been ≈øaid before, the truth of the Ca≈øe doth not appear unto us according to which we can judge, and I conceive that upon any amendment upon this Statute, we cannot take out one Roll and put in another, and as our ca≈øe is we cannot amend this defect without taking out the whole Roll, and therefore in the Ca≈øe of Leonard, which was late Cu≈øtos brevium here, where in a Replevin he avowed for a Rent-≈øervice, and upon e≈øpecial Verdict the Ca≈øe was, that Sir Henry I≈øley held of the ≈øaid Leonard by Fealty, and the Rent mentioned in the Avowry, and was attainted of high Trea≈øon, and the King ≈øei≈øed and granted the Land to the Plaintiff, upon whom Leonard avowed for the Rent-≈øervice, and I and my companions were agreed, that the rent, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øei≈øure and grant of the King remained di≈øtrainable of common right, but Leonard could not have return of the Cattel, becau≈øe he had avowed for a Rent-≈øervice, & now it appeareth to us upon the Verdict, that he had right to ≈øo much rent, but not to ≈øuch a Rent, but a Rent-≈øeck di≈øtrainable of common right, ≈øo a Rent in another degree; and we al≈øo agreed, that the Avowry was not amendable, for then upon ≈øuch amendment, we ought to take out a whole Roll, which was not intended by this Statute: And he conceived al≈øo, that in debt again≈øt Executors in the Debet & detinet, ≈øuch a Writ ≈øhall not be amended by this Statute, and he conceived, that his exception to the Bar, quod ad medietatem, 60. Me≈ø≈øuag. &c. parcel. medietatis, &c. is relieved by this Statute, for the meaning appeareth: And al≈øo the exception, that it is not expre≈øly ≈øhewed that the Fine was engro≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Term in which it was levied. And Periam moved
another matter,Co. 1 In≈øt. 71. b. 72. a. if now the parties demurring in Law as to part of the Land in demand, and being at I≈ø≈øue upon the re≈øidue, if the Court ≈øhall adjudge the matter in Law, before the I≈ø≈øue be tried, or not, 32 H. 6. 5 & 6. In Tre≈øpa≈øs for taking of his Cattel, the Defendant as to parcel pleaded not guilty, and as to the remnant pleaded another Plea, upon which the parties did demur, and there they proceeded to trial before the matter in Law determined, and found for the Plaintiff, and he had Iudgment thereupon for the damages, but the co≈øts were ≈øu≈øpended until, &c. And the Defendant brought his Writ of Error. 48 E. 3. 15. In an Action of Wa≈øt, as to parcel the Defendant pleads, no Wa≈øt, and as to the re≈øt pleaded matter in Law, upon which there was a demurer joyned; It was holden, that the I≈ø≈øue ≈øhould not be tried until the matter in Law be determined: But it was ≈øaid by Fulthorpe in Tre≈øpa≈øs, if the Defendant to parcel plead the Enque≈øt, and to other parcel matter in Law, in ≈øuch ca≈øe he ≈øhould proceed to trial pre≈øently, and damages ≈øhould be taxed of the whole, as well of that upon which there was a demurrer in Law, as of that of which the I≈ø≈øue was joyned, ad quod non fuit re≈øpon≈øum. See al≈øo 11 H. 4. 228. In Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Defendant pleaded to I≈ø≈øue for part, and for the re≈øidue did demur in Law, Proce≈øs for the trial i≈ø≈øued before the matter in Law determined; And Periam conceived that the Court might proceed in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, the one way or the other: As to the matter in Law, whether the i≈ø≈øue in tail upon this Fine ≈øhould have the Averment, he conceived, that he ≈øhould not have the ≈øaid Averment, for that it ≈øhould be very perilous to the Inheritances of the ≈øubjects. And he argued much upon the dignity of Fines out of Bracton and Glanvil, whom he called Actores, non Authores Legis; & that Fines at the common Law were of great authority until the Statute of We≈øt. 2. And afterwards by the Statute of 34 E. 3. of non-claim, from whence they became to be of ≈øo little value in Law, that they were accounted no other than Feoffments upon Record, ≈øo as thereby no a≈ø≈øurance was of Inheritances but a general incertainty until the Statute of 4. H. 7. by which Statute they were re≈øtored to their ancient power and virtue: After which Statute many ≈øhifts were devi≈øed, to creep out of it: So as the Statute of 32 H. 8. was made to take away all que≈øtions and ambiguities which were conceived upon the ≈øaid Statute of 4 H. 7. And therefore we who are Iudges ought to frame our Iudgments for the maintaining of the authority of Fines, for ≈øo the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and inheritances of the Subjects ≈øhall be pre≈øerved; And that is the rea≈øon, that if a ≈øtranger levy a Fine of my Land in my name, that I have not any remedy but a Writ of Deceit again≈øt him who levyes the Fine, ≈øo if a Feme-covert levyeth a Fine of her Land as a Feme-≈øole, the ≈øame ≈øhall bind her after the coverture, if the Husband do not enter upon the Conu≈øee during the coverture and interrupt the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion gained by the Fine: And 17 E. 3. and our Books are very plentiful to this purpo≈øe that the Law doth aerge admit of ≈øuch allegations again≈øt ≈øuch Fines: A Fine was pleaded in Bar of Land in A. B. and C. he again≈øt whom it was pleaded was not received to aver again≈øt the ≈øuppo≈øal of the Fine, that there was no ≈øuch Town or Hamlet as A. 46 E. 3. 5. A woman Tenant in tail, had I≈ø≈øue a Daughter, who was inheritable to the tail, the Daughter took a Husband, & they both living the Mother, and during her ≈øei≈øin, levied a Fine of the Land entailed to a ≈øtranger, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit, come ceo, &c. who rendred the Land to the Husband and Wife in ≈øpecil tail, the Husband died having I≈ø≈øue, the Wife took another Husband, had I≈ø≈øue, and died, the Husband to entitie him≈øelf to the Land as Tenant by the curte≈øy, would in pleading have averred the ≈øei≈øin of the Mother at the time of the Fine levyed, and he could not, and yet he was a ≈øtranger to the Fine, but he was privy to the e≈øtate, and his claim was by her who levyed the Fine, 6 E. 3. 46. Fitz. Averment 40. In a Writ of Entry, ≈øur di≈ø≈øei ≈øin, the Fine of the
Ance≈øtor of the Demandant was pleaded in Bar by the name of W the Demandant in avoidance of it would have ≈øaid that the name of his Father was R. to have avoided the Fine, but to that he was not received. And 3 E. 3. 32. ≈øcil. Averment, 42. In a Formedon, the Tenant pleaded Ne dona pas, The Demandant by Replication ≈øaid, That a Fine was levied of the ≈øame Lands, between the Father of the Demandant, and one T. by which Fine the Father of the Demandant did acknowledge to T. the Lands come ceo, &c. and the ≈øaid T. gave by the ≈øaid Fine to the Father of the Demandant the Land in tail. Where it is ≈øaid by Stone, that ≈øince the gift is proved by as high a Record, a man ≈øhall not aver again≈øt ≈øuch matter in avoidance of the ≈øaid Fine, &c. and yet the party again≈øt whom it was was a ≈øtranger to the Fine: And ≈øee 38 E. 3. 7. The Lord ≈øhall not be received again≈øt a Fine levied by his Tenant to aver the dying ≈øei≈øed of his Tenant in his Homage. And as to the I≈ø≈øue in tail, he conceived, that the Averment doth not lie for him, for the I≈ø≈øue in tail is as much privy, as the Heir of a Tenant in Fee-≈øimple. And ≈øee 33 E. 3. ≈øcil. E≈øtoppel 280. In a Formedon, the Tenant voucheth, the Demandant Counter-pleaded, that the Vouchee nor any of his Ance≈øtors had any thing in the Land in demand after the ≈øei≈øin, &c. to which the Tenant ≈øaid, that to that the Demandant ≈øhould not be received, for the Father of the Demandant after the gift levied a Fine to the Ance≈øtor of the Vouchee of the ≈øaid Land in demand, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. and the ≈øame was holden a good bar to the Counter-plea.

And it was ≈øaid by the Iu≈øtices, That although the Statute of We≈øt. 2. of Donis conditionalibus, doth not avoid the Fine as to the fore-clo≈øing of the I≈ø≈øue in tail of his Formedon, yet it remaineth in force as to the re≈øtraining of the heir in tail to aver a thing again≈øt the Fine as well as again≈øt the heir in Fee-≈øimple; and in all Ca≈øes, where he again≈øt whom a Fine is pleaded claims by him who levieth the Fine, he ≈øhall not have the ≈øame Averment, but where he claims by a ≈øtranger to the Fine, there he ≈øhall have it well enough; ≈øee 33 H. 6. 18. If my Father Tenant in tail, or in Fee, grant the Land by Fine, and afterwards I make Title to the ≈øame Land by the ≈øame Ance≈øtor, and the Fine is pleaded again≈øt me, I ≈øhall not be received to ≈øay that tho≈øe who were parties to the Fine had not any thing at the time of the Fine levied, but ≈øuch a one an e≈øtranger who≈øe e≈øtate, &c. but it is a good Plea for me to ≈øay, that after the Fine ≈øuch a one was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and did enfeoff me, vid. 22 E 3. 17. before 33 E. 3. E≈øtoppel 280. And Dyer 16 Eliz. 334. The Father is Tenant for life, the Remainder in Fee to his Son and Heir, levieth a Fine to a ≈øtranger, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. with warranty, and takes back an e≈øtate by the ≈øame Fine, in that ca≈øe it was holden that the heir ≈øhould not be received to aver continuance of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and ≈øei≈øin, either ante finem, tempore finis, or po≈øt finem, in the Tenant for life, for it is a Feoffment upon Record, and makes a di≈øcontinuance of the Remainder and Rever≈øion. The only Book in our Law to maintain the Averment is 12 E. 4. 15. by Brian, who although he was a reverend Iudge in his time, yet he erred in this, that if Tenant in tail be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and levieth a Fine unto a ≈øtranger, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit, come ceo, &c. that the I≈ø≈øue in tail may well ≈øay, that partes ad finem nihil habuerunt, but Coke and Lit. were clear of a contrary opinion and ≈øee in the ≈øame year, fol. 12 by Fairfax and Littleton, that if Tenant in tail, where the Remainder is over to a ≈øtranger, levieth a Fine ≈øur conu≈øans dodroit, come ceo, &c. he in the Remainder may aver continuance of ≈øei≈øin again≈øt that Fine, for he is not party, nor heir to the party, &c. And the Stat. of 4 H. 7. goes ≈øtrongly, to extort ≈øuch Averment out of the mouth of the I≈ø≈øue in tail, for the words concerning the ≈øame point are, ≈øaving to every per≈øon or per≈øons, not party, nor privy to the ≈øaid Fine, their exception to avoid the ≈øaid Fine, by that, that tho≈øe which were parties to the ≈øaid Fine nor any of them had ought in the Land at the time of the
≈øaid Fine levied: And it is clear, that the I≈ø≈øue in tail is privy to his Ance≈øtor who≈øe heir to the tail he is, which ≈øee agreed, 19 H. 8. 6. 7. And he vouched the Ca≈øe of one Stamford late adjudged, Land was given to the elde≈øt Son in tail, the Remainder to the Father in tail, the elde≈øt Son levied a Fine, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. and died without I≈ø≈øue in the life of his Father, and afterwards the Father died; the ≈øecond Son ≈øhall inherit; but if the elde≈øt Son had ≈øurvived the Father, and afterwards died without I≈ø≈øue, the ≈øecond Son ≈øhould have been barred.

Periam to the ≈øame intent: It ≈øhould be very dangerous to the Inheritances of the Subjects to admit of ≈øuch Averments, and by ≈øuch means Fines which ≈øhould be of great force and effect ≈øhould be much weakned, and he put many Ca≈øes to the ≈øame purpo≈øe as were put before by Rhodes Iu≈øtice, and he ≈øhewed how that Fines, and the power of them were much weakned by the Statute of non-claim, whereof followed (as the preface of the Statute of 4 H. 7. ob≈øerveth) the Vniver≈øal trouble of the Kings Subjects, and therefore by the ≈øaid Statute of 4 H. 7. Fines, for the good and ≈øafety of the Subjects were re≈øtored to their former Grandure and authority, which ≈øhould be con≈øtrued by us who are Iudges, ≈øtrongly and liberally for the quiet and e≈øtabli≈øhment of pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and for the barring and extingui≈øhing of former rights, and ≈øo did the Iudges our Predece≈ø≈øors; which ≈øee in the Argument of the ≈øaid Ca≈øe between Stowel and the Lord Zouch: So ≈øee ≈øuch liberal con≈øtruction, 19 Eliz. Dyer 351. Where if Land be given to Husband and Wife in ≈øpecial tail, and the Husband alone levieth a Fine and dieth having I≈ø≈øue, the I≈ø≈øue is barred: And it hath lately been adjudged by the advice of all the Iudges of England, upon the Statute of 1 Ma. viz. All Fines levied, whereupon Proclamations ≈øhall not be dayly made by rea≈øon of Adjournment of any Term, ≈øhall be of as good force and ≈øtrength to all intents and purpo≈øes, as if ≈øuch Term had been holden and kept from the beginning to the end thereof, and not adjourned, and the Proclamations ≈øhall be made in the following Term, which rea≈øon in con≈øtruction of the ≈øaid Statute, the Iudges in the ca≈øe of the Cooks of London, 20. Eliz. have ob≈øerved, which ≈øee Plowden 538. For although Succe≈ø≈øors are not mentioned in the ≈øaid Statute of 4 H. 7. but only Heirs, yet the Iudges did con≈øtrue the ≈øaid Statute to extend to them that they ≈øhould be bounden as well as the Heirs; for it is in the like mi≈øchief, and the ≈øaid Statute was made for the publick good, and for the repo≈øe of the Inheritances of the Subjects of this Realm, and therefore the ≈øame ought to be largely extended in the meaning and ≈øen≈øe of it, and for the benefit of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of the Lands, and to the de≈øtroying of former rights which were not claimed. It hath been ≈øaid, that this Fine is but a Fine by conclu≈øion, and not in verity; and therefore not within the Statute. But without que≈øtion, Fines by conclu≈øion are within the Statute. And that is clear by the Saving, ≈øcil. to all per≈øons other than parties to the ≈øaid Fines, &c. And Periam was again≈øt the opinion in Stowells Ca≈øe by Sanders 356. A Di≈ø≈øei≈øor maks a Feoffment in fee upon condition, the Feoffee levies a Fine with Proclamation, five years pa≈øs, the condition is broken, the Di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øor re-entreth, and Periam conceived that in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øee is bounden, for by the Fine, and five years non-claim, the right of every ≈øtranger is barred, and when the Di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øor entreth for the condition broken, the Fine is not annoyed, but rather confirmed, and former rights ≈øhall not be revived. Windham to the ≈øame intent, and vouched the Books before remembred, and that the meaning of the Statute of 32 H. 8. made upon the Statute of 4 H. 7. was to bind the I≈ø≈øue in tail as ≈øtrongly as the heir of Tenant in Fee-≈øimple was bound at the common Law, and that Fines by conclu≈øion are as fully within the purview of that Statute as Fines in verity, for Fines by conclu≈øion are A≈ø≈øurances; And as to the objection again≈øt our Fine, that it
is not rite levatus becau≈øe that partes ad finem nihil habuerunt, &c. the ≈øame is no rea≈øon, wherefore this Fine ≈øhould not be rite levatus, for the≈øe words rite levatus, to the external form of a Fine are to be taken as to a Fine levied, coram Edmundo Ander≈øon & ≈øocijs ≈øuis, where all the Iu≈øtices ought to be named, and ≈øo it ≈øeemed al≈øo to Periam and Ander≈øon. Our ca≈øe had little re≈øemblance to the Ca≈øe where Tenant in tail maks a Lea≈øe according to the Statute of 32 H. 8. if he be not ≈øei≈øed at the time of the demi≈øe, it is void; for the Stat. ≈øpeaks ≈øei≈øed in tail: but ≈øo are not penned the Statutes of 4 H. 7. & 32 H. 8. as 4 H. 7. a Fine levied ≈øhall bind privies, & ≈øtrangers, &c. & 32 H. 8. Fines levied of any Lands entailed to the Conu≈øor or any of his Ance≈øtors, and it is not a Fine in re≈øpect of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion which pa≈ø≈øeth by the Fine, but in re≈øpect of the Concord and Agreement,
And Tenant in tail by the≈øe Statutes hath as great power to bind the right of the entail, although he cannot meddle with the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, as the Tenant in Fee-≈øimple at the common Law.

Ander≈øon to the ≈øame intent, All the matter re≈øts upon this point, if the I≈ø≈øue in tail be privy or not, for if he be privy, then clearly he is bounden. And as to that, the I≈ø≈øue in tail before the Statute of 32 H. 8. hath been always accounted privy. See 29 H 8. Dyer 32. Tenant in tail of the gift of the King levieth a Fine, the ≈øame ≈øhall bind his I≈ø≈øue, for they are privy. And he argued much upon the Ca≈øes cited by the other Iu≈øtices before, and e≈øpecially upon the ≈øaid Ca≈øe of Stowel and the Lord Zouch; how that the I≈ø≈øue in tail is there holden privy; and that the Statute of Fines ought to be taken and con≈øtrued to enfore the operation of Fines again≈øt former rights, and for the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and e≈øtates. And by him divers rights and per≈øons are excepted by the ≈øaid Statute, but this right in gro≈øs of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, nor the I≈ø≈øue in tail, who≈øe Ance≈øtor being out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion levieth the Fine is not excepted, therefore both of them comprehended in the Statute. And in his argument he ≈øtood much upon it, how dangerous a matter it ≈øhould be, to receive ≈øuch averments and allegations which go meerly in avoidance of Fines, for ≈øo every Fine might fall in the mouth of the Lay-Gens, which would be very inconvenient. And he concluded his Argument with this Ca≈øe. Tenant in tail doth di≈øcontinue, and di≈ø≈øei≈øeth his di≈øcontinnuee, and levieth a Fine, the di≈øcontinuee before the proclamations reentreth, the proclamations are made, Tenant in tail doth re-enter, and dieth ≈øei≈øed; again≈øt this Fine his I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall not be remitted. See as to the averment 3 H. 627. 33 H. 6. 18. 42 E. 3. 20. 8 H. 4. 8. 12 E. 4. 19. by Fairfax and Needham, and fol. 15. by Brian and Choke. And afterwards Iudgment was given, that the Demandant ≈øhould be barred.

div.head:
CIII. Guner≈øton and Hatchers Ca≈øe.
Intr. Pa≈øch. 24 Eliz. Rot. 2112. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
CHarles Duke of Suffolk was ≈øei≈øed of three parts of the Manor of D. and Poole was ≈øei≈øed of the fourth part of the ≈øaid Manor,Avowry. and afterwards the Duke granted out of the ≈øaid three parts a Rent-charge of five marks to Guner≈øton; and afterwards the ≈øaid Duke of the ≈øaid three parts did enfeoffe Hatcher in Fee, after which Poole conveyed his ≈øaid fourth part of the ≈øaid Manor to the ≈øaid Hatcher in Fee, and afterwards Hatcher being ≈øei≈øed, ut ≈øupra, reciting the ≈øaid ≈øeveral purcha≈øes, e≈øpecially the ≈øaid fourth part devi≈øed to Katherin Hatcher at Will, and Guner≈øton di≈øtreined the Cattel of Katherin Hatcher for the arrearages of the ≈øaid Rent, and in a Replevin avowed the di≈øtre≈øs: and by the opinion of the whole Court the Avowry was not maintainable, for the fourth part of the ≈øaid Manor, which was in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of
Poole, was not charged with the Rent; and although all the Manor be now in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Hatcher, yet the Mannor is not ≈øo con≈øolidated nor united by this unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but that the owner might well enough ≈øingle out eandem quartam partem, and grant it, and the grantee ≈øhall hold the ≈øame di≈øcharged, as the ≈øaid Poole held it; and the bea≈øts of the ≈øaid Katherin ≈øhall not be di≈øtreined; and ≈øo Iudgment was given again≈øt the Avowant.

div.head: CIV. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Voucher. Po≈øt. 291.IT was moved by Serjeant Walme≈øley, If a common Recovery be to pa≈øs at the Bar, and the Tenant is ready at the Bar and voucheth to warr. A. for whom one is ready at the Bar to appear for the vouchee by his warrant of Attorny; It was holden, that this appearance is meerly void, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe the vouchee ought to appear in per≈øon, becau≈øe without ≈øummons; but where ≈øummons i≈ø≈øueth, and the ≈øame is entred upon the Roll, there may the vouchee at the Return appear in per≈øon, or by Attorny, at his Election. And that was the clear opinion of all the Iu≈øtices, and al≈øo of the Prothonotaries.

div.head: CV. Keys and Steds Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: IN a Formedon by Keys again≈øt Sted, the Ca≈øe was, the Sted and his Wife were Tenants for life,Formodon. 2 Len. 9. the Remainder over to a ≈øtranger in Fee; and the Writ of Formedon brought again≈øt Sted only, who made default after default, whereupon came his Wife and prayed to be received to defend her right; which was denied her by the Court, for this Recovery doth not bind her, and it is to no purpo≈øe for her to defend her right in that Action which cannot here be impearched; Whereupon he in the Remainder came and prayed to be received, and the Court at fir≈øt doubted of the Receit, fora≈ømuch as if the Demandant ≈øhall have Iudgment to recover, he in the Remainder might fal≈øify the Recovery, becau≈øe his e≈øtate, upon which he prayeth to be received, doth not depend upon the e≈øtate impleaded, ≈øcil. a ≈øole e≈øtate, whereas his Remainder doth depend upon a joynt e≈øtate in the Husband and Wife,Fal≈øifier of Recovery. not named in the Writ; But at the la≈øt, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Exception, the Receit was granted. See 40 E. 3. 12.

div.head: CVI. Live≈øeys Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Writ of Right.IN a Writ of Right again≈øt Thomas Live≈øey of the Mannor of D. & de duabus partibus Cu≈øtodiae Forre≈øtae de C. the Tenant did demand the view and he had it, and return was made, and now the Writ of Habere facias vi≈øum, was viewed by the Court, and it was, Vi≈øum Manerii & duarum partium Cu≈øtodiae, &c. And it was holden by the Court not to be a ≈øufficient view, for the Forre≈øt it ≈øelf ought to be put in view, ≈øcil. the whole Forre≈øt,View. and not duae partes tantum, as where a Rent or Common is demanded, the Land out of which the Rent or Common is going ought to be put in view; and there a Writ of Habere facias vi≈øum de novo i≈ø≈øued forth.

div.head: CVII. Germys Ca≈øe. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: GErmy brought Debt upon a Bond again≈øt A. as Executor,Debt. 2 Len. 119. and the Ca≈øe was, That the Te≈øtator of A. by his Will did appoint certain Lands, and named which, ≈øhould be ≈øold by his Executors, and the moneys thereof ari≈øing di≈øtributed among≈øt his Daughters when they have accompli≈øhed their ages of one and twenty years; the Lands are ≈øold, if the moneys thereof being in the hands of the Executors until the full age of the Daughters ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øets to pay the debts of the Te≈øtator? And by the clear opinion of the whole Court,A≈ø≈øets. Po≈øt. 224. the ≈øame ≈øhall not be a≈ø≈øets, for that this money is limited to a ≈øpecial u≈øe.

div.head: CVIII. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: IN an Action of Debt upon an Obligation, the Defendant ≈øaith, that the Plaintiff ≈øhall not be an≈øwered, for he is out-lawed, and ≈øhewed the Outlawry in certain, by the name of I. S. of D. in the County of, &c. The Plaintiff ≈øhewed, that at the time of the ≈øute begun again≈øt I.S. upon whom the Out-lawry was pronounced, the ≈øaid I.S. now Plaintiff, was dwelling at S. ab≈øque hoc, that he was dwelling at D. Vide 21 H. 7. 13. And it was holden a good Replication, to avoid the Out-lawry without a Writ of Error, by Ander≈øon. 10 E. 4. 12. For if he were not dwelling at D. then he cannot be intended the ≈øame per≈øon: See 39 H. 6. 1.

div.head: CIX. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: IT was agreed by the whole Court, and affirmed by the Prothonotaries, That if in Account the Defendant be adjudged to account, and be taken by a Capias ad computandum, and ≈øet to mainprize, pendent the Account before the Auditors, and doth not keep his day before them, that now a Capias ad computandum de novo ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue forth again≈øt him.

div.head:
CX. Glo≈ø≈øe and Haymans Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
JOan Glo≈ø≈øe brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, vi & armis, Tre≈øpa≈øs, vi & armis, again≈øt a Servant for carrying away his Ma≈øters goods. Owen 52. Mor ‚Ä¢ 248. again≈øt John Hayman, who pleaded the general I≈ø≈øue, and the Iury found this ≈øpecial matter, That the Plaintiff was a Grocer in Ip≈øwich, and there held a Shop of Grocery, & quod illa repo≈øuit fiduciam in the Defendant, to ≈øell the Grocery Wares of the Plaintiff in the ≈øaid Shop: And further found, that the ≈øaid Defendant being in the ≈øaid Shop in form afore≈øaid, cepit & a≈øportavit, the ≈øaid Wares, and did convert them, &c. It was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, that this Action, vi & armis, upon this matter doth not lie, but rather an Action upon the Ca≈øe. But the Court was clear of opinion, that the Action doth well lie, for when the Defendant was in the Shop afore≈øaid, the Goods and Wares did remain in the cu≈øtody and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Plaintiff her ≈øelf. And the Defendant hath not any Intere≈øt, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, or other thing in them, and therefore if he entermeddle with them in any other manner, than by uttering of
them by ≈øale, according to the authority to him committed, he is a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor; for he hath not any authority to carry the Wares out of the Shop not ≈øold, but all his authority is within the Shop. And Rodes put the Ca≈øe of Littleton 25. If I deliver my Sheep to another to manure his Land, or my Oxen to plow his Land, and afterwards he kills them, I ≈øhall have an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt him: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CXI. Martin and Stedds Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz.
