div.p: RIchard Martin, Alderman of London, brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Stedd, and declared, That whereas the Queen by her Letters Patents dated, the 27. of Augu≈øt, anno 24. of her Reign, had granted to the Plaintiff the Office of Ma≈øter of the Mint, through all England, to exerci≈øe the ≈øaid Office, ≈øecundum formam quarundam Indent. betwixt the ≈øaid Queen and the ≈øaid Plaintiff conficiendam, and that in January following the ≈øaid Indenture was made, by which it was agreed betwixt the ≈øaid Queen and the Plaintiff, that the money, in po≈øterum, ≈øhould be made in ≈øuch manner, &c. according to the true Standard; and declared, that he had duly and lawfully made all the money according to the ≈øaid Standard: Yet the Defendant, machinans, &c. had ≈ølanderou≈øly ≈øpoken and given out ≈øpeeches in the≈øe words, Mr. Martin hath not made the money as good and fine as the Standard, by an half penny in the ounce, and ≈øo he hath ≈øaved four thou≈øand pounds. It was objected again≈øt this Declaration by Walme≈øley Serjeant, that here the Plantiff hath declared upon the Letters Patents, and the Office given by the Letters Patents ought to be exerci≈øed according to the Indenture, &c. And here appears upon the Declaration no Indenture, for no enrolment of ≈øuch Indenture is ≈øhewed, and if it be not enrolled, then there cannot be any Indenture betwixt the Queen. &c. and then the Qeeen cannot have an Action upon it for want of enrolment. See 21 H. 7. 21. 1 H. 7. 28. and 31. 5 E. 4. 7. and al≈øo if there be not a ≈øufficient Indenture, then the Plaintiff is not Ma≈øter of the Mint, and then al≈øo there is not any new Indenture: And then the Plaintiff ought to make the money according to the the old Standard, and then might the Defendant well ju≈øtifie the words.

Another Exception was taken, becau≈øe the Plaintiff is not at any damage, for the Queen cannot have again≈øt him but an Action of Covenant upon the ≈øaid Indenture, becau≈øe the Defendant hath not made the money accordingly, which matter is not actionable, no more than if the Farmer of the Queen had brought this Action again≈øt one, for ≈øpeaking that he had broken the condition or covenants of his Lea≈øe. And as unto the≈øe words, So that the Defendant hath ≈øaved four thou≈øand pounds, tho≈øe words are not actionable, for it may be he hath ≈øaved this four thou≈øand pounds to the Queen; and ≈øuch con≈øtruction the Iudges ought to make of ≈øuch ambiguous words in ≈øuch ca≈øes, ≈øcil. in optimam partem. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CXII. Moun≈øon and We≈øts Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Challenge. 3 Len. 22 ‚Ä¢ .IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs between Moun≈øon and We≈øt, the parties were at I≈ø≈øue, and now at the Return of the Pannel the Defendant challenged the Array, becau≈øe it was made by Bartholomew Armin,
who took to Wife the Co≈øin German of the Plaintiff, & ex ea had I≈ø≈øue living, the mother being dead: And upon this challenge the Plaintiff did demur in Law; And it ≈øeemed to the Lord Ander≈øon, that it is not a principal challenge, but only to Favour. For the matter of the challenge is not con≈øanguinity, but only affinity: And ≈øo it ≈øeemed to Periam. And Rhodes cited a ca≈øe adjudged in the Kings Bench. Markham brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Lee, who at the Ni≈øi Prius challenged the Array, becau≈øe the Sheriffs wife was ≈øi≈øter to the Plaintiffs Wife, and that was before the Lord Dyer at Nottingham, and that challenge was holden there, not to be a principal challenge, upon which Error was brought in the Kings Bench: And Error a≈ø≈øigned in that, and for that cau≈øe the Iudgment was rever≈øed: And by Windham the Writ of Venire facias is, quia nulla affinitate, &c. ≈øo as affinity is pre≈øumed in Law not indifferent. And by Ander≈øon that is to be intended of the Iurors, and not of the Sheriff, 22 E. 4. 2. The Array was challenged, becau≈øe that the Sheriff, &c. had married A. Daughter of Eliz. Si≈øter of the Mother of the Plaintiff, and that was holden a principal challenge 20 H. 7. 7. 26 E. 3. 21. And afterwards at another Term the Ca≈øe being moved, Ander≈øon, Rhodes and Windham were clear of opinion,Dy. 37. 191. 319. that it is a principal challenge; but Periam hae≈øitavit, and put a difference betwixt con≈øanguinity and affinity, for affinity is not a principal challenge, unle≈øs it be averred, that the I≈ø≈øue, &c. is inheritable to the Land. And Ander≈øon put the Ca≈øe in 14. H. 7. 2. Where one challenged, becau≈øe one of the Iurors had married the Mother of the Defendant, it was holden a principal challenge. And 15 H. 7. 9. where the challenge was for that the Brother of the Wife of the Defendant had married the Daughter of the Sheriff.

div.head:
CXIII. Sir Thomas Gre≈øhams Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
SIr Tho. Gre≈øham being ≈øei≈øed of the Manors of Wal≈øingham and Milcham in the County of Norfolk, 12 Eliz. Revocation of u≈øes. enfeoffed B. and C. to certain u≈øes, and that was with clau≈øe of Revocation upon the tender of forty ≈øhillings, and that after ≈øuch Revocation he might limit new u≈øes; and afterwards the year following, Sir Tho. Gre≈øham made the like conveyance of his Lands in the County of Suffolk to the ≈øaid per≈øons, to the like u≈øes, upon like clau≈øe of Revocation upon the tender of forty ≈øhillings, Sir Thomas tendered to the ≈øaid Feoffees one ≈øum of forty ≈øhillings, to revoke the u≈øes rai≈øed upon both the Feoffments; & afterwards rai≈øed divers u≈øes of divers of the ≈øaid Manors holden in Capite, Dyer. 372. and afterwards Sir Thomas died: And afterwards it was re≈øolved by the opinion of the Iu≈øtices, that by that tender the u≈øes were not revoked, but that the Revocation was utterly void, for two ≈øeveral ≈øums of forty ≈øhillings ought to have been tendered, for they were ≈øeveral Indentures and could not be ≈øatisfied by one ≈øum. After which by a private Act of Parliament, 23 Eliz. the ≈øaid Revocation was enacted and adjudged to be good and ≈øufficient in Law. And now the Lady Gre≈øham was called by proce≈øs into the Exchequer for a Fine due to the Queen for the ≈øaid alienation,Fine for Alienation. becau≈øe that now the ≈øaid u≈øes newly rai≈øed were good, and the ≈øaid Manor po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed according to the limitation of them, for now the Revocation is good, becau≈øe done by the ≈øaid Statute which recited the whole ≈øpecial matter, and that for want of a ≈øufficient Tender, the Revocation was void in Law; and al≈øo reciting the new u≈øes which were declared for the payment of his debts, and many honorable Legacies, & al≈øo for the ≈øecurity of tho≈øe who had purcha≈øed underneath the ≈øaid new u≈øes: For remedy whereof it was enacted, & quod praedict. Revocationes bonae & ≈øufficientes in lege habeantur, reputentur, & recogno≈øcantur. And
it was argued by Coke, that upon the matter, no Fine is due, for all tho≈øe new u≈øes took their e≈ø≈øence and effect by that Act of Parliament, to which the Queen her ≈øelf is a party, and the principal Agent, and therefore again≈øt her own Act ≈øhe ≈øhall not claim a Fine, &c. And al≈øo the alienation without licence is a wrong and tre≈øpa≈øs; and an Act of Parliament cannot do wrong, and if partition be made betwixt Parceners by Act of Parliament, no Fine is due to the Queen, which was in ure 23 Eliz. for by Parliament then a Partition was made betwixt the Co-heirs of the Lord Latimer, and I do not know that any Fine hath been demanded for it.

div.head:
CXIV. Bret and Sheppards Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt. BRet brought Debt upon a Bond again≈øt Sheppard, the Bond was endorced, upon condition, that where the Defendant was arre≈øted at the ≈øute of one A. if now the Defendant ≈øhall appear in the Kings Bench, where the proce≈øs is returnable, that then, &c. And the Defendant ≈øaid in fact, that he had appeared, ≈øecundum formam & effectum conditionis ≈øupradict. & hoc petit quod inquiratur per patriam, & praedict. Brett ≈øimiliter: It was moved, that the parties ≈øhould replead for this matter, upon which they are at I≈ø≈øue, ≈øcil. the appearance is not triable by Iury, but by the Record: And the Court was clear of opinion, that the parties ≈øhould replead for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid: And it was moved by the Lord Ander≈øon, that if A. be bound to appear in the Kings Bench at ≈øuch a day, and A. at the ≈øaid days goe to the Court, but there no proce≈øs is returned, then the party may go to one of the chief Clerks of the Court, and pray him to take a Note of his appearance: And by Nel≈øon, we have an acient form of entry of ≈øuch Appearance in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, Ad hunc diem venit I. S. & propter indemnitatem ≈øuam & Manucaptorum ≈øuorum petit quod comparentia ≈øua in Curia hic recordetur. And ≈øee for the ≈øame 38 H. 6. 17. And afterwards the Lord Ander≈øon, in≈øpecto Rotulo, ex a≈ø≈øen≈øu ≈øociorum awarded a Repleader: And ≈øo by Nel≈øon, it hath been done oftentimes here before, and put in ure: The ≈øame Law is, where at the day of appearance no Court is holden, or the Iu≈øtices do not come, &c. he who was bound to appear, ought to have an Appearance recorded in ≈øuch manner as it may be; and if the other party pleadeth Nul tiel Record, it behoveth that the Defendant have the Record ready at his peril, for this Court cannot write to the Iu≈øtices of the Kings Bench, for to certifie a Record hither.

div.head:
CXV. Baxter and Bales Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Debt not extinct by admini≈øtration. BAxter brought Debt upon a Bond as Executor of I. again≈øt Bale; who pleaded that the Plaintiff after the death of the Te≈øtator was cited to appear before the Ordinary or his Commi≈ø≈øary to prove the Will of the ≈øaid I. and at the day of his appearance he made default, upon which the Ordinary committed Letters of Admini≈øtration to the Defendant, by force of which he did admini≈øter, ≈øo the debt is extinct, &c. but the whole Court was clear of opinion, that the debt was not extinct, for now by the probate of the Will the admini≈øtration is defeated, and although the Executor made default at the day which he had by the Citation before the Ordinary, yet thereby he is not ab≈øolutely debarred, but that he may re≈øort to the proving of the Will when≈øoever he plea≈øeth; But if he had appeared and renounced the Executor≈øhip
it had been otherwi≈øe; and the debt is not extinct by the Admini≈øtration in the mean time.

div.head: CXVI. Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Franchi≈øe the parties are at I≈ø≈øue upon a matter triable out of the Franchi≈øe. And it was moved, if now the Record ≈øhould be ≈øent into the Common Pleas, and there tryed, and after trial ≈øent back into the Franchi≈øe: Which Periam and Ander≈øon utterly denied; and by Periam, there is no rea≈øon that we ≈øhould be their Mini≈øters to try I≈ø≈øues joyned before them: And it is not like,2 Len. 37. where in a Liberty or Franchi≈øe a Forrein Voucher is to warrant Lands, in ≈øuch ca≈øes we ≈øhall determine the Warranty; but that is by a ≈øpecial Statute of Gloce≈øter cap. 12. And Nel≈øon Prothonotary ≈øaid, that ≈øuch an I≈ø≈øue was tryed here of late. Quod nota.

div.head:
CXVII. The Earl of Arundel, and the Lord Dacres. Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. At Serjeants Inne.
div.p: PHilip Earl of Arundel, and the Lord William Howard his Brother marryed the Daughters and Co-heirs of the late Lord Dacres: And now came Francis Lord Dacres as heir male of the ≈øaid Family, and claimed the Inheritance, &c. And after long ≈øute betwixt both parties, they ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to the award of Gilbert Lord Talbot, and of Arthur Lord Grey of Wilton, and Windham and Periam Iu≈øtices; And before them at Serjeants Inne, the matter was well debated by the Council learned on both ≈øides; and as unto Grei≈øtock Lands, parcel of the Lands in que≈øtion, the Ca≈øe was. That Tenant in tail makes a Feoffment in fee unto the u≈øe of him≈øelf for his life, the Remainder in tail to his elde≈øt Son, with divers Remainders over, with a Provi≈øo, that if any of the Entailees do any act to interrupt the cour≈øe of any entail limited by the ≈øaid Conveyance, that then the u≈øe limited to ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhould cea≈øe, and go to him who is next inheritable; And afterwards Tenant in tail dieth, his elde≈øt Son to whom the u≈øe in tail was fir≈øt limited entreth, and doth an Act again≈øt the ≈øaid Provi≈øo, and yet held him≈øelf in and made Lea≈øes, the Le≈ø≈øees enter, the Le≈ø≈øor dieth ≈øei≈øed, his Heir being within age, and in ward to the Queen; It was holden by Shutleworth Serjeant, Yelverton, Godfrey, Owen, and Coke, who were of Council with the Heirs general of the Lord Dacres, that here is a Remitter, for by this Act again≈øt the Provi≈øo, the u≈øe,Remitter. and ≈øo the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion doth accrue to the enfant Son of him, to whom the u≈øe in tail was limited by the Tenant in tail: Then when the Tenant in tail after his ≈øaid Feoffment holds him≈øelf in, this is a di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øin; for a Tenancy by ≈øufferance cannot be after the ce≈ø≈øer of an e≈øtate of Inheritance; But admit that he be but a Tenant at ≈øufferance,H ‚Ä¢ b. 255. Dy. 54. yet when he makes Lea≈øes for years, the ≈øame is clearly a di≈ø≈øei≈øin, and then upon the whole matter a Remitter, and although the Enfant taketh by the Statute, yet the right of the tail de≈øcending to him afterwards by the death of his Father doth remit him, as if Tenant in tail maketh a Feoffment in fee to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, the Remainder in tail to his elde≈øt Son inheritable to the fir≈øt intail, notwith≈øtanding that the elde≈øt Son takes his Remainder by the Statute, and ≈øo be in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ force thereof, yet when by the death of his Father, the right of the Entail de≈øcends to him, he is remitted.

div.head:
CXVIII. Butler and Ayres Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Dower. BUtler and his Wife brought a Writ of Dower again≈øt Thomas Ayre, Son and Heir of Bartholmew Ayre, fir≈øt Husband of the ≈øaid Margaret Wife of the Plaintiff, and demanded Dower of Lands in A. and B; the Tenant pleaded, never ≈øei≈øed que Dower, and the Iury found that the ≈øaid Bartholmew was ≈øei≈øed during the Coverture, de omnibus tenementis infra ≈øcript. preterquam, the Tenements in (≈øic ut dicta Margareta dotari potuit) Exception was taken to this Verdict; becau≈øe that this preterquam, &c. doth confound the Verdict. To which it was ≈øaid by the Court, that the preterquam is idle, and ≈øurplu≈øage, for it is of another thing than that which is in demand, and the ≈øei≈øin of the fir≈øt Husband of Lands in A. and B. is confe≈ø≈øed, and the (preterquam) works nothing: Another matter was objected, becau≈øe here the Iury have a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed damages, as in ca≈øe where the Husband died ≈øei≈øed,Dy. 370. the which dying ≈øei≈øed is not found by the Verdict: In which Ca≈øe it was ≈øaid by the Court, the Demandant might pray Iudgment of the Lands, and relea≈øe damages; or the Demandant may aver that the Husband died ≈øei≈øed, and have a Writ to enquire of the damages, quod omnes Pregnotarii conce≈ø≈øerunt.

div.head:
CXIX. Michel and Hydes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Dower.DOwer by Michel and his Wife again≈øt Lawrence Hyde, who appeared upon the grand Cape; And it was becau≈øe that the ≈øaid Hyde in truth was but Le≈ø≈øee for years of the Land of which &c. in which ca≈øe he might plead non-tenure, if now he might wage his Law of non-≈øummons, ≈øo as the Writ be abated: for by the wager of Law he hath taken upon him the Tenancy, and affirmed him≈øelf to be Tenant, 33 H. 6. 2. by Pri≈øoit, to which it was ≈øaid by Rhodes, and Windham Iu≈øtices, that here the Tenant being but Le≈ø≈øee for years is not at any mi≈øchief, for if Iudgment and Execution be had again≈øt him, he notwith≈øtanding might afterwards enter upon the Demandant. Another matter was moved, That where the Writ of Dower was, de tertia parte Rectoriae de D. and upon that the grand Cape i≈ø≈øued, Cape in manum no≈øtram tertiam partem Rectoriae, and the Sheriff by colour of this Writ took the Tythes ≈øevered from the nine parts, and carried them away with him: And it was agreed by the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices, that the ≈øame is not ≈øuch a ≈øei≈øure as is intended by the ≈øaid Writ, but the Sheriff by virtue of ≈øuch Writ ought generally to ≈øeize, but leave them there where he found them. And the Court was of opinion to commit the Sheriff to Pri≈øon for ≈øuch his mi≈ødemeanor.

div.head:
CXX. Hamington and Ryders Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
RIchard Haming. Executor of I≈øabel Haming. brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Ryder, Debt. Savil Rep. 74. Owen Rep. 6. 1 Co. 52. 1 And ‚Ä¢ 162. the Ca≈øe was, that Kidwelly was ≈øei≈øed, & lea≈øed for years to John Hamington Husband of I≈øabel, and afterwards John Hamington being ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, by his will devi≈øed, that the ≈øaid I≈øabel ≈øhould have the u≈øe and occupation of the ≈øaid Land for all the years of the ≈øaid Term as ≈øhe ≈øhould live and remain ≈øole, and if ≈øhe died or married,
that then his Son ≈øhould have the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid Term not expired; John died, I≈øabel entred,Devi≈øes. to whom the ≈øaid Lawr. coveyed by Feoffment the ≈øaid Land in Fee, and in the Indenture of the ≈øaid Conveyance Lawr. covenanted that the ≈øaid Land from thence ≈øhould be clearly exouerated, de omnibus prioribus barganijs, titulis, juribus & omnibus alijs oneribus quibu≈øcunque, I≈øabel took to Husband, the Son entreth: If now the Covenant be broken was the que≈øtion. It ≈øeemed to Ander≈øon at the fir≈øt motion, that this po≈ø≈øibility which was in the Son at the time of the Feoffment, was not any of the things mentioned in the Covenant, ≈øcil. former bargain, title, right, or charge; But yet it was conceived by him that the word bargain did extend to it, for every Lea≈øe for years is a contract, and although that the Land at the time of the Feoffment was not charged, yet it was not di≈øcharged of the former contract: And by Windham, if I be bounden in a Statute-≈øtaple, and afterwards I bargain and ≈øell my Lands, and covenant (ut ≈øupra) here the Land is not charged, but if after the condition contained in the defeazance be broken, ≈øo as the Conu≈øee extends, now the Covenant is broken; And by him, the word (charge) doth extend to a po≈ø≈øibility, and this po≈ø≈øibility might be extinct by Livery as all agreed; but not tran≈ølated by grant,Ante 33. 3 Len. 43. Covenant. or extingui≈øhed by relea≈øe, as it was lately adjudged in the Ca≈øe of one Carter. At another day, it was argued by Walme≈øley, and he much relied upon the words (clearly exonerated) utterly di≈øcharged, or altogether exonerated, and without doubt it is a charge which may happen, and if it may happen, then the Land is not clare exonerated: And al≈øo former bargains do extend to it, and the Term is not extinct by the acceptance of the Feoffment afore≈øaid of Kidwelly, and although, that at the time of the Feoffment it was but a po≈ø≈øibility, and no certain intere≈øt, yet now upon the marriage of I≈øabel, it is become an actual burthen and charge upon the Land; and he cited a Ca≈øe adjudged, 8 Eliz. A man ≈øei≈øed of Lands grants a Rent-charge to begin at a day to come before which day he bargains and ≈øells the Lands, and covenants that the ≈øaid Lands are di≈øcharged of all charges, in that ca≈øe when the day when the Rent ought to begin is incurred, the Covenant is clearly broken, for the Lands were not clearly exonerated, &c. At another day the Ca≈øe was moved at the Bar. And Ander≈øon openly in Court declared, that he and all his companions were agreed, that the Land at the time of the Feoffment was not di≈øcharged of all former Rights, Titles and charges; and therefore commanded, that Iudgment ≈øhould be entred for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CXXI. Howel and Trivanians Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
HOwel brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Trivanian in the Common Pleas, and declared,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. that he delivered certain goods to the brother of the Defendant, who made the Defendant his Executor, and died, after which the Plaintiff came to the Defendant, and ≈øpake with him concerning the ≈øaid goods, upon which communication and ≈øpeech the Defendant promi≈øed the Plaintiff, that if the Plaintiff could prove, that the ≈øaid goods were delivered to the Te≈øtator,2 Roll. 594. that he would pay the value of them to the Plaintiff: And the Declaration was in con≈øideration, that the ≈øaid goods came to the hands of the Te≈øtator, and al≈øo afterwards the goods came to the Defendants hands, and upon non A≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, It was found for the Plaintiff, and Iudgment given: And afterwards Error was brought in the Kings Bench, and Error a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe that the Plaintiff had not averred in his Declaration, that he had proved the delivery of the ≈øaid goods to the ≈øaid Te≈øtator,1 Cro. 105. for the words of the promi≈øe are, ≈øi probare potui≈ø≈øet: And al≈øo it was a≈ø≈øigned
for Error, that here is not any con≈øideration upon which this promi≈øe could receive any ≈øtrength, for the Defendant hath not any profit or advantage thereby, ≈øcil. by the bailment of the ≈øaid goods to the Brother of the Defendant; And al≈øo it is a thing before executed, and not depending upon the promi≈øe, nor the promi≈øe upon it: As the Ca≈øe reported by the Lord Dyer 10 Eliz. 272. The Servant is arre≈øted in London, and two men to whom the Ma≈øter is well known, bail the ≈øaid Servant, and after the Ma≈øter promi≈øeth to them for their friend-≈øhip, to ≈øave them harmle≈øs from all co≈øts and damages, and in an Action upon the Ca≈øe brought upon that promi≈øe, the Plaintiff was barred, for here is not any con≈øideration, for they bailed the Servant of their own head without the reque≈øt of the Ma≈øter, and the matter which is alledgged for con≈øideration is executed before the A≈ø≈øump≈øit, and the promi≈øe was not before the enlargment, and the ≈øaid bailment was not at the in≈øtance,Claytons Rep. 45. 1 Cro. 756. or reque≈øt of the Ma≈øter. And the Ca≈øe of one Hud≈øon was cited, adjudged in the Kings Bench: The Defendant in con≈øideration that he was Admini≈øtrator, and natural Son of the Inte≈øtate, and that the goods of his Father have come to his hands, promi≈øeth to pay the debt to the Plaintiff. And in an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon that promi≈øe, the Defendant pleaded he made no ≈øuch promi≈øe, and it was found that no goods came to the hands of the Defendant; And it was holden, that the con≈øideration that he was Admini≈øtrator and Son to the Te≈øtator, was not of any force to maintain the Action, and afterwards in the principal Ca≈øe the Iudgment was affirmed. And it was moved by Coke that Iudgment ≈øhould not be given again≈øt the Executor of his own goods if he had not goods of the Te≈øtator, for the charge doth not extend beyond the con≈øideration, i. e. That the goods of the Te≈øtator came to the hands of the Defendant. But Wray Iu≈øtice was of opinion, that Iudgment ≈øhall be of his proper goods, as in Ca≈øe of confe≈ø≈øion. Kemp Secondary, if the Action be brought upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit of the Te≈øtator, Iudgment ≈øhall be of the goods of the Te≈øtator; but of the promi≈øe of the Executor, of his own goods; but the Original Iudgment which is now affirmed was general.

div.head:
CXXII. Savel and Woods Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
1 Cro. 71. 3 Len. 203. 265. Po≈øt, 128.THe Ca≈øe was; That a Par≈øon did Libel in the ≈øpiritual Court again≈øt a Pari≈øhoner for Tythes of ≈øuch Lands within his Pari≈øh, the Defendant came into the Kings Bench and ≈øurmi≈øed, and that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath in the Lands out of which the Tythes are demanded, have u≈øed to pay every year five ≈øhillings to the Pari≈øh Clark of the ≈øame Pari≈øh for all the Tythes out of the ≈øame place: And it was argued by Coke, that that could not be, for a Pari≈øh Clark is not a per≈øon corporate, nor hath ≈øucce≈ø≈øion: But if he had pre≈øcribed, that they had u≈øed to pay it to the Pari≈øh Clark to the u≈øe of the Par≈øon, it had been good: Al≈øo he ought to ≈øhew, that the Par≈øon ought of right to find the Pari≈øh Clark, &c. And he cited the Ca≈øe of Bu≈øhie the Par≈øon of Pancras, who libelled in the Spiritual Court for Tithes, The Defendant to have a prohibition did pre≈øcribe, that he, and all tho≈øe, &c. had time out of mind, &c. u≈øed to pay to the Vicar, &c. and at la≈øt a Con≈øultation was awarded becau≈øe it was triable in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, for both parties as well Vicar as Par≈øon are ≈øpiritual per≈øons, and the modus decimandi is not in que≈øtion, but cui ≈øolvend. And at another day, it was agreed by the Iu≈øtices, that of common right, the Par≈øon is not tied to find the Pari≈øh Clark, for then he ≈øhould be ≈øaid the Par≈øons Clark and not the Pari≈øh Clark: But if the Par≈øon be tied to find ≈øuch a Clark,Challenge. and ≈øuch a ≈øum hath been u≈øed to be paid to the Pari≈øh Clark in di≈øcharge of the Per≈øon, the ≈øame had been a good pre≈øcription, and ≈øo by way of compo≈øition; and by Clench
Tythes are to be paid to ≈øpiritual Per≈øons, but a Pari≈øh-Clark is a Lay-per≈øon: And afterwards the Court granted a Con≈øultation.

div.head:
CXXIII. Higham and Reynolds Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs the Plaintiff declared, that the Defendant 1 Maii 28 Eliz. cut down ≈øix po≈øts of the hou≈øe of the Plaintiff at D. The Defendant doth ju≈øtifie, becau≈øe that the Free-hold of the hou≈øe, 10 Aprilis 27 Eliz. was to I. S. and that he by his commandment the ≈øame day and year did the Tre≈øpa≈øs, &c. upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law, becau≈øe the Defendant did not traver≈øe, without that that he was guilty before or after. And the opinion of Wray was, that the traver≈øe taken was well enough, becau≈øe the Free-hold ≈øhall be intended to continue, &c. Vide 7. H. 7. 3. But all the other three Iu≈øtices were of a contrary opinion to Wray: But they all agreed, that where the Defendant doth ju≈øtifie, by rea≈øon of his Free-hold at the day ≈øuppo≈øed in the Declaration, there the traver≈øe (before) is good enough: And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Defendant.

div.head:
CXXIV. Knight and Footmans Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs by Knight again≈øt Footman, the Ca≈øe upon the pleading was, that one Margaret had i≈ø≈øue two Sons, Richard and Thomas, Surrender of Copy-hold Land. and ≈øurrendred to the u≈øe of Richard for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of Thomas in Fee; they both, Thomas being within age, ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of one Robert ‚Ä¢ ap John in Fee, who is admitted; Richard dieth,Co 1 In≈øt. 248. Thomas dieth, having i≈ø≈øue A. who is al≈øo admitted, and enters into the Land, and if his entry be lawful, or that he be put to his plaint in the nature of a Dum fuit infra aetatem was the Que≈øtion. And Wray was clear of opinion that it was: And if a man ≈øei≈øed of Copy-hold Land in the right of his Wife, or Tenant in tail of a Copy-hold doth ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of another in Fee, the ≈øame doth not make any di≈øcontinuance, but that the i≈ø≈øue in tail and the Wife may re≈øpectively enter;1 Cro. 372. 380. 391. 483. 717. More 596. and ≈øo was it holden in the Serjeants Ca≈øe, when Audley, who afterwards was made Chancellor of England, was made Serjeant; and afterwards it was adjudged, that the entry of the Enfant was lawful.

div.head:
CXXV. Sir Wolla≈øton Dixies Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
AN Information was in the Exchequer again≈øt Sir Wolla≈øton Dixie, upon the Statute of V≈øury, & upon not guilty pleaded,Information upon the Statute of 13. Eliz of U≈øury. The Informe ‚Ä¢ gave in evidence an u≈øurious Contract upon a bargain of Wares: The opinion of the Court was, that the Information being exhibited for the loan of money, that the Evidence was not pur≈øuing nor leading to the I≈ø≈øue. And yet the Iury again≈øt the opinion of the Court upon that evidence found the Defendant guilty. And it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that the Evidence did not maintain the Information, nor prove the I≈ø≈øue, ex parte Querentis, and it was ≈øaid, there are three things within the Statute, i. three words, i. bargain, loan, and cheivizance, and the≈øe three are ≈øeveral things,
and therefore, if the Information be conceived upon loan, and the Informer giveth in Evidence a corrupt bargain for cloth, as it is in this Ca≈øe, the ≈øame doth not maintain the Information; So if the Information be granted upon u≈øurious contract by way of mortgage, and giveth in Evidence an u≈øurious loan, ut ≈øupra. But if the Information had been conceived generally, upon an u≈øurious agreement, and giveth in Evidence a loan, the ≈øame is good enough, for every loan is an agreement.

Manwood, There cannot be any loan without bargain, nor any forbearing without bargain, for he contracts or bargains to do it, viz. to lend, or forbear: Bargain of forbearing is where the fir≈øt day of payment, is not kept and the parties have agreed for a further day for payment, &c. And it appeareth in this Ca≈øe, that it was a bargain to forbear a ≈øum of mony which ≈øhould have been paid before; And the Information here is upon a bargain by way of loan, where was a bargain for forbearing. Fuller, this word (Bargain) in the Statute cannot be intended a bargain for wares or ≈øuch things, and ≈øo di≈øtinct from the other two things, &c. If in Information upon loan, an u≈øurious contract had been given in Evidence, that would not maintain the Information: And it was moved in this Ca≈øe, if the time of the loan or forbearance of the money ≈øhall be accounted according to eight & twenty days to every month, or by the months in the Kalender, viz. January, February, &c. And it ≈øeemed to ≈øome according to the days, as in ca≈øe of the Statute of 23 Eliz. of Recu≈øants; and others conceived contrary in both Ca≈øes. And Fuller ≈øaid, That in the Ca≈øe of policy of A≈ø≈øurance made to warrant a Ship, one was bound to warrant a Ship for twelve months; & the truth was, ≈øhe did not peri≈øh within the time of the twelve months, being accounted according to eight and twenty days, but being accounted by the Kalender, as January, Feb. &c. it peri≈øhed, &c. and it was ≈øaid and holden, that he had not forfeited his Bond. Gent Baron. If I lend one a hundred pounds without any contract for Intere≈øt, and afterwards at the end of year he gives me twenty pounds for the loan thereof, the ≈øame is within the Statute, for my acceptance makes the offence‚ñ™ without any bargain or contract. And by Clarke Baron, the place where the Defendant accepted exce≈ø≈øive Intere≈øt ought to be ≈øhewed in the Information, but not the place where the contract for the loan or forbearance was made, for the ≈øame is not needful. See the Ca≈øe betwixt Stradling and Morgan, Plowd. 200. for the ≈øetting down of the place in the Declaration, where the Extortion was committed: The Information here is by way of corrupt bargain and loan. The Defendant took at Dertford ≈øuch a ≈øum, where the taking is layed, apud Dertford, but no place of the corrupt bargain or of the loan. And by Gent. If I lend to Bee≈øie for a year, and afterwards he takes further forbearance of another year beyond the rate, the ≈øame is within the Statute: but in all Ca≈øes, the place where the corrupt bargain was made ought to be certainly alledged: Manwood Baron, the Information is not good for the incertainty of the place, where the corrupt bargain was made; and although there are many Pre≈øidents on the Informes part, it is not to purpo≈øe, for they were admitted without exception, and then they pa≈ø≈øed ≈øub ≈øilentio, and ≈øo of no force. There are three things, or rather degrees of offences within the Statute. In u≈øury, within the Statute, there ought to be corrupt loan, cheivi≈øance, or ≈øhift, 1. corruption, 2. he ought to take more than eight pound for one hundred pounds, 3. it ought to be for lending or forbearing. There was a Ca≈øe in this Court in the time of this Queen, that the Defendant had taken more than ten pounds in the hundred pounds, but in the Information no corruption in the bargain was alledged; and therefore Iudgment was given again≈øt the Informer: But in the Ca≈øe at Bar corruption is ≈øet forth in facto, and therefore as to that the Information is good enough: As unto the forbearing & giving of days of payment the ≈øame is alledged in the Information,
but not according to the Statute, for the Statute is in the di≈øjunctive, but the Information is in the copulative; here in our Ca≈øe the i≈ø≈øue is Not guilty, under which general i≈ø≈øue all the points of the Statute are included and ought to be tried; as unto the corruption the ≈øame is not ≈øufficiently laid, for no place is a≈ø≈øigned where the corrupt bargain was made, ergo no vi≈øne for it to be tried, ergo, no trial can be, ergo, no i≈ø≈øue for it, ergo, this point of the Statute doth not come in i≈ø≈øue, nor can it be tried upon the general i≈ø≈øue, Not guilty. Al≈øo he held, that all the Offence ought to be within the year, for if one make a corrupt bargain for this year, and ten years after he takes exce≈ø≈øive u≈øury, the ≈øame is not within the Statute to inform upon it. And in truth there is no ≈øuch offence without corrupt bargain, ≈øo as he conceived, that the word (Lending) is a ≈øtrange word, but where the Statute is forbearing or giving day of payment, & in the Information it is giving and forbearing in the copulative, that is good enough, for the one word enforceth the other, and is not double. Al≈øo the Information hath not ≈øhewed who≈øe money it is, and therefore it is not good: And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Informer; and a Writ of Error thereupon brought in the Erchequer Chamber. And it was argued by Popham Attorney General, that Iudgment ought to have been given for the Queen and the Informer, for the ≈øhewing of the place where the corrupt bargain was made needs not to be alledged in the Information, for the offence puni≈øhable by the Statute is the receipt of exce≈ø≈øive u≈øury, and not the contract: And it was the Ca≈øe of one Bird, 20 Eliz. where the Plaintiff ≈øhewed the place of the Receipt, and not of the contract, and yet had Iudgment for the Queen, without any exception to it before Iudgment, or Error after, for the contract is but inducement to the receipt, and it ≈øhall be tried where the taking was; therefore it is not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øhew the place of the bargain: And it was adjorned.

div.head:
CXXVI. Saliard and Everats Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
THomas Saliard and Hen. Everat being Recu≈øants convicted,Recu≈øants. Owen. Rep. 37. and not having paid twenty pounds for every month, a Commi≈ø≈øion i≈ø≈øued forth to enquire of their Goods and Lands in the County of Suffolk, to levy thereon the Debt and penalty due to the Queen. And now the Commi≈ø≈øion being returned, the parties appeared, and by their Council ≈øhewed, that ≈øome of their Lands returned in the Commi≈ø≈øion are Copy-hold, and prayed as to tho≈øe, Manus Dominae Reginae amoveantur, and that upon the Statute of 29 Eliz. cap 5. concerning Recu≈øants: viz. that upon default of payment of penalties, &c. which proce≈øs i≈ø≈øued out of the Exchequer to take and ≈øeize all the goods, and two parts as well of all the Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, Lea≈øes and Farms of ≈øuch Offender, as of all other the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, liable to ≈øuch ≈øei≈øure, or to the penalties afore≈øaid, by the true meaning of this Act, leaving the third part, &c. And Popham Attorney General moved, If a Recu≈øant hath more than a third part of his Lands in Copy-hold land, if this Copy-hold as to the ≈øurplu≈øage ≈øhall be liable to the penalty. Manwood chief Baron conceived, that the Copy-hold is liable in this Ca≈øe by the Statute, although not directly by expre≈øs words, yet within the intent of it, and that by rea≈øon of the≈øe words all other the lands, &c. liable to ≈øuch ≈øei≈øure, &c. Walme≈ø. Serjeant, Copy-hold is not liable to a Statute Merchant or Staple; al≈øo if the Queen hath the Copy-hold, how ≈øhall the Lord have the ≈øervices which the Queen cannot do? Al≈øo a Copy-hold is not an Hereditament within this Statute, which extends only to Hereditaments at the common Law, and not by cu≈øtom: Al≈øo in Acts of Parliaments which are enacted
for forfeiture of Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, by tho≈øe words they ≈øhall not forfeit Copy-holds. Clark Baron, this Statute was made to re≈øtrain Recu≈øants from taking the benefit of their Livings, and Copy-holds are their Livings as well as Free-holds, and by this Statute, the Queen ≈øhall not have every e≈øtate in the Copy-hold Land, but only the taking of the profits; but the ≈øcope of the Statute was to impair the Livings of Recu≈øants, and that by driving of them for want of maintenance to repair to the Church.

Walme≈øley, If the Statute had given to the Queen to ≈øei≈øe two parts of their livings, then the Statute had extended to Copy-holds. Manwood, when a Statute is made to transfer an e≈øtate by name of Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, the Copy-hold is not within ≈øuch Statute; but if the Lords Signiory, his Cu≈øtoms and Services, are not to be impeached, or taken away by ≈øuch Statute, then it is otherwi≈øe; for ≈øuch Statute doth not make another Tenant to the Lord; And by him Copy-holder ≈øhall pay Sub≈øidies, and he ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed according to the value of his Copy-hold as well as of his Freehold, and in this Ca≈øe, the Queen is to have the profits of the Lands only, but no e≈øtate. At another day, the ca≈øe was argued for the Recu≈øants by Snag Serjeant, and he ≈øaid, that the≈øe words Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments are to be con≈øtrued, which are ≈øuch at the Common Law, not by Cu≈øtom: If I give to one all my Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments in D. my Copy-holds do not pa≈øs, and Statutes which are made to take away Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and Hereditaments out of per≈øons ought to be ≈øtrictly taken, and not by Equity: The Statute of 13 Eliz. of Bankrupts enacts, that the Commi≈ø≈øioners may ≈øell the Lands and Tenements of the Bankrupts; if the Statute had not made a further provi≈øion, the Commi≈ø≈øioners could not ≈øell Copy-hold Lands, but there are expre≈øs words in the Statute for that purpo≈øe, i.e. as well copy as fee: Al≈øo the Staute of 13 Eliz. cap. 4. of Auditors and Receivers of the Queen doth not extend to Copy-holds: And it ≈øhould be a great prejudice to the Lords of ≈øuch Copy-holds, that the Queen ≈øhould have the Land. Popham, the intention of the Law ≈øomtimes cau≈øes a liberal con≈øtruction of a Statute in the letter of it,What Statutes extend to Copy-holds. ≈øomtimes a ≈øtrict and preci≈øe expo≈øition, and here it appeareth, that the intention of the Statute was, that the Queen ≈øhould have all the goods of the offender, and two parts of the Lands, &c. Lea≈øes and Farms, and the Recu≈øant but the third part of all his Lands only; And therefore the Recu≈øant is not to have any other thing but only that which is allotted to him by the Statute, and that is the third part, which is all the maintenance which the Law allows him; and then if Copy-holds be not within this Statute, a Recu≈øant who hath great po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in Copy-holds, and hath no Free-hold ≈øhould be di≈øpuni≈øhable, and hath his full maintenance, again≈øt the meaning of the Statute: And he ≈øaid that many things are within the meaning of a Statute,
‚Ä¢ y. 5. 6. Co. 3. In≈øt. 109 Yel. 60. 12 Co. 12. which are not within the words, as Bonds, Obligations and Specialties made to Recu≈øants, ≈øhall pa≈øs to the Queen by this Statute by force of the word, goods, according to the meaning of the Statute, and all per≈øonal things are within the Statute, &c. profits of the Lands, Advow≈øons, and the like; and the very ≈øcope of the Statute was to take away from Recu≈øants all per≈øonal things what≈øoever, and two parts of real things, as Lea≈øes, Farms, Lands, Tenements, &c. with the intent that with the ≈øuperfluity of their goods and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, ≈øhe ≈øhould not maintain Ie≈øuits, and Seminary Prie≈øts, people more dangerous than the Recu≈øants: And by him, Lands in ancient deme≈øne are liable to the penalties by the Statute; although not by expre≈øs words; So if a Recu≈øant hath Lands extended by him upon a Statute acknowledged unto him, that Intere≈øt is not properly a Lea≈øe, or Farm, yet it is Land within this Statute liable, &c. And if I be Tenant by Elegit, or Statute,
&c. of Lands in D. not having other Lands in the ≈øaid Town, and I grant all my Lands in D. my Intere≈øt ut ≈øupra, ≈øhall pa≈øs; contrary, If I have other Lands there: And I grant, that if I have Copy-hold Lands in D. and none other, and I grant all my Lands in D. Copy-hold Land ≈øhall not pa≈øs by ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance; becau≈øe that Copy-hold cannot pa≈øs but by ≈øurrender; If I put out a Copy-holder out of his Lands, the ≈øame is a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin to the Lord of whom the Copy-hold is holden: And if I levy a Fine of ≈øuch Lands and five years pa≈øs, not only the Lord is bounden as to his Free-hold and Inheritance, but al≈øo the Copy-holder for his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, for the intent of the Statute of 4 H. 7. was to take away controver≈øies, & litibus finem imponere, 5 Co. 124. and contention may be as well for Copy-hold as for Land at the common Law. One hath a Lea≈øe for years to begin at a day to come, he who hath the Free-hold thereof is di≈ø≈øei≈øed, the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor levieth a Fine, five years pa≈øs, he who hath the Free-hold is bound by it, but not he who hath the Intere≈øt for years in futuro, as it hath been lately adjudged; But he ≈øaid, That if that point were to be handled again, the Law would be taken to the contrary; but it is clear that a Lea≈øe in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall be bound by ≈øuch Fine: And as unto any prejudice to the Lord it is clear, that notwith≈øtanding that the Queen hath the Copy-hold Land, yet the Lord ≈øhall have the Rent during the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen, which is the mo≈øt valuable part of the ≈øervices of the Copy-holder. The Statute of 1 E. 6. of Chantries, doth extend to Copy-hold, by the general words, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, for otherwi≈øe the Provi≈øo which excepts Copy-holds were not nece≈ø≈øary: And in our Statute, the words are Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, which are forceable words, which proves that our expo≈øition to extend it to Copy-holds is proper and agreeable to the Statute, and this in the fir≈øt branch of it; for Copy-hold is ≈øome Land, Tenement, or Hereditament; the clau≈øe in this branch of the Statute is, and al≈øo all other the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments liable to ≈øuch ≈øei≈øure, &c. the ≈øame is to be meant of ≈øuch Lands which are bound with clau≈øe of revocation, of which is ≈øpoken in the former part of this Statute. He who departs out of the Realm again≈øt the Statute of 5 R. 2. ≈øhall forfeit his goods, and thereby his debts al≈øo: The King grants omnia bona & catalla felonum, Debts of Felons ≈øhall pa≈øs; Ergo Copy-holds al≈øo,2 L ‚Ä¢ n. 56. Po≈øt. 201. 202. by the name of Lands, Tenements, &c. as well as debts by the name of goods. In our Ca≈øe, the meaning of the Statute was, that the Queen ≈øhould have two parts of the whole e≈øtate of the Recu≈øant, be it Copy-hold, Ancient deme≈øne, &c. If upon the Statute of Bankrupts, a Copy-hold e≈øtate be ≈øold to the King, the King ≈øhall pay the Rent, but ≈øhall not do any of the ≈øervices, and in ≈øo much the Lord ≈øhall be prejudiced; patiatur etiam & hic, rather than Recu≈øants ≈øhould not be puni≈øhed; and it is not a ≈øtrange thing in Law, that the Lord of a Copy-holder ≈øhould be prejudiced for the offence of his Tenant; as where a Copy-holder is outlawed, the King ≈øhall have the profits of his Copy-hold Lands, and the Lord hath not any remedy for his Rent.

div.head:
CXXVII. Stebbs and Goodlacks Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
BEtwixt Stebbs & Goodlack, the Ca≈øe was, the Par≈øon of Letcome in the County of Berks, libelled in the Spiritual Court for Tithes,Fraud ≈øhall not avoid payment of Tithes. the Defendant ≈øhewed, that the cu≈øtome of the Town of Letcome is, that the Par≈øon ≈øhall have for his Tithes the tenth Land ≈øowed with any manner of corn, and he ≈øhall begin his reckoning always at the fir≈øt Land which is next to the Church, &c. The Par≈øon ≈øhewed that the Defendant, by fraud and covin ≈øowed every tenth Land which belonged to the Par≈øon, ut ≈øupra, very ill and with ≈ømall quantity of corn, and did not dunge or manure it as he did the other nine parts, by means whereof,
whereas the other nine every of them yielded eight Cocks, the tenth yeilded but three Cocks, and for this matter the Par≈øon libelled in the Spiritual Court and confe≈ø≈øed the cu≈øtome, but for abu≈øing of the cu≈øtom prayed to have his Tythes in kind; the Defendant prayed a prohibition, and the Par≈øon afterwards a con≈øultation: And the opinion of Wray Iu≈øtice was that the cu≈øtom was again≈øt common rea≈øon, and ≈øo void, but if it be a good cu≈øtom, then the Par≈øon ≈øhall have the Action upon the ca≈øe.

div.head:
CXXVIII. Rumney and Eves Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Copy-holder.IN Ejectione firmae by Jane Rumney again≈øt Lucie Eve, it was holden, that if cu≈øtomary Land do de≈øcend to the younger Son by cu≈øtom, and he enters and lea≈øeth it to another, who takes the profits, and after is ejected:Poph. 39. 4 Co. 22. That he ≈øhall have an Ejectione firmae without any admittance of his le≈ø≈øor or pre≈øentment that he is heir. For which the Defendant ≈øhewed, that there were thirty years incurred betwixt the death of the Father, and the making of the Lea≈øe, ≈øo that here is ≈øupina negligentia, which ≈øhall di≈øable his per≈øon to make any demi≈øe, quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum. In an≈øwer of which it was ≈øaid, that the Le≈ø≈øor at the time of the death of his Ance≈øtor was but of the age of two years, and that after his full age no Court had been holden for a long time, and that at the fir≈øt Court that was holden, which was of late, he prayed to be admitted, but the Steward refu≈øed to admit him; and the ≈øame was holden a good excu≈øe of his negligence: And it was holden, that the Plaintiff ought not to ≈øhew that the Lea≈øe is warranted by the cu≈øtom,1 Cro. 469. 483. 717. 728. Ante 16. but that ≈øhall come of the other ≈øide; and ≈øo it had been lately adjudged, which Wray granted: And by him, if a Copy-holder ≈øurrender in extremis to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, &c. If he ≈øhall be well again, the ≈øurrender ≈øhall ≈øtand,4 Len. 30. 31. 8 Co. 100. for he hath re≈øerved an e≈øtate to him≈øelf. It was further holden in this Ca≈øe, that if a Copy-holder dieth, his Heir within age, he is not bound to come at any Court during his non-age to pray admittance, or to tender his Fine: Al≈øo if the death of the Ance≈øtor be not pre≈øented, nor proclamations made, he is not at any mi≈øcheif, although he be of full age.

div.head:
CXXIX. Saint-John and Petits Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IT was covenanted betwixt Saint-John and Petit, that Saint-John ≈øhould pre≈øent Petit to the Church of A. and that afterwards Petit ≈øhould lea≈øe the Par≈øonage to Saint-John, or to any other per≈øon named by him, and that the ≈øaid Petit ≈øhould not be ab≈øent by eighty days, and that he ≈øhould not re≈øign; and Petit was bound to perform the≈øe Covenants, & Petit is pre≈øented to the Benefice: Saint-John brought an Action upon the Obligation, pretending, that he could not enjoy his lea≈øe by rea≈øon of the ab≈øence of the ≈øaid Par≈øon, &c. And the Lea≈øe was made to the Curate at the nomination of Soint-John. The Par≈øon ≈øaid, that the Obligation is void by the Statute of 14 Eliz. cap. 11. See the Statute, All Lea≈øes, &c. made by any Curate ≈øhall be of no better force, than if it had been made by the beneficed Par≈øon him≈øelf. Tanfeild by 13 Eliz. 20. When a Par≈øon lea≈øeth to his Curate, who lea≈øeth over, The Statute doth not make the Lea≈øe void by any ab≈øence of the Par≈øon, but of the Curate by forty days. Quaere. For that it ≈øeemeth, that by the Statute of 14 Eliz. the Curate cannot lea≈øe, &c.

div.head:
CXXX. Gates and Halliwels Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: BEtwixt Gates and Halliwel the Ca≈øe was, one having two Sons,3 Len. 55. devi≈øed, that his elde≈øt Son with his Executors ≈øhould take the profits of his Lands until his younge≈øt Son ≈øhould come to the age of two and twenty years, and that then the ≈øaid younge≈øt Son ≈øhould have the Land to him and the Heirs of his body: It was holden clearly by the whole Court, that the elde≈øt Son ≈øhould have Fee in the interim until the younge≈øt Son came to the ≈øaid age.

div.head: CXXXI. Prow≈øe and Carys Ca≈øe. Pa≈øc. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: PRow≈øe brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Cary for words: That the Plaintiff did ≈øubborn, procure, and bring in fal≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes in ≈øuch a Court at We≈øtmin≈øter, &c. The Defendant pladed, Not guilty: And it was found, that he did procure and brought in fal≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes, but was acquitted of the ≈øuborning. It was objected,1 Cr. 296. 554. 607. That the Action doth not lie, for it may be, that the Defendant did not know that he would depo≈øe fal≈øly: Thou art a forger of fal≈øe Writings are not actionable, and ≈øo it was adjudged, for it may be under≈øtood of Letters of ≈ømall importance; but that Exception was not allowed, for it ≈øhall be taken in malam partem, and cannot be ≈øpoken of any hone≈øt man.

div.head: CXXXII. Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A. Was bounden in an Obligation to B. upon condition, that if A‚ñ™ deliver to B. twenty Quarters of Corn the nine and twentieth of February next following, datum pre≈øentium, that then, &c. and the next February had but eight and twenty days: And it was holden, that A. is not bounden to deliver the Corn, until ≈øuch a year as is Leap-year, for then February hath nine and twenty days, and at ≈øuch nine and twentieth day he is to deliver the Corn, and the Obligation was holden good.

div.head:
CXXXII. Allen and Palmers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
THe Ca≈øe was, a Copy-holder did ≈øurrender his Lands to the u≈øe of a ≈øtranger for life,Copy-holder ≈øurrenders where his heir ≈øhall be in by purcha≈øe. 2 Roll. 416. Co. 1 In≈øt. 226. and afterwards to the u≈øe of the right Heirs of the Copy-holder, who afterwards ≈øurrendred his Rever≈øion to the u≈øe of a ≈øtranger in Fee, & died, and the Tenant for life died, and the right Heir of Palmer the Copy-holder entred; And by Cook nothing remained in the Copy-holder upon the ≈øaid ≈øurrender, but the Fee is re≈øerved to his right Heirs, for if he had not made any ≈øuch ≈øecond ≈øurrender, his Heir ≈øhould be in, not by de≈øcent but by purcha≈øe. And the common difference is, where a ≈øurrender is to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to another in tail, the remainder to the right Heirs of him who ≈øurrendreth, there his Heirs ≈øhall have it by de≈øcent; contrary where the ≈øurrender hath not an e≈øtate for life or in tail limited to him, for
there his Heir ≈øhall enter as a purcha≈øor, as if ≈øuch u≈øe had been limitted to the right Heirs of a ≈øtranger. And by him, if a Copy-holder ≈øurrender to the u≈øe of his right Heirs, the Land ≈øhall remain in the Lord until the death of the Copy-holder, for then his Heir is known, &c. See Dyer 99. The Husband made a Feoffment to the u≈øe of his Wife for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of the right Heirs of the body of the Husband and Wife begotten, they have i≈ø≈øue, the Wife dieth, the i≈ø≈øue cannot enter in the life of his Father, for then he is not his Heir. See Dyer 7 Eliz. 237. The Husband is ≈øole ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and levieth a Fine of the Land to the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his Wife, and the Heirs of the Husband, and they render the Land to the Conu≈øor for the life of the Husband, the remainder to B. for life, the remainder to the right Heirs of the Husband: The Husband dieth, B. dieth: Now the Wife ≈øhall have the Land for the life of the Wife, for ≈øhe ≈øhall not lo≈øe her e≈øtate by that render; and this remainder to the right Heirs of the Husband is void, and the Land and e≈øtate in it is in him as a Rever≈øion, and not as a Remainder. And a man cannot tail a Remainder to his right Heirs while≈øt he is living, unle≈øs it begin fir≈øt in him≈øelf. See Br. 32 H. 8. Gard. 93.

div.head:
CXXXIV. Pearle and Edwards Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was, that the Defendant had lea≈øed Lands to the Plaintiff rendring Rent for certain years,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. Con≈øideration. 1 Cro. 94. and after ≈øome years of the Term expired, the Le≈ø≈øor in con≈øideration that the Le≈ø≈øee had occupied the Land, and had paid his Rent, promi≈øed the Plaintiff to ≈øave him harmle≈øs again≈øt all per≈øons, for the occupation of the Land pa≈øt, and al≈øo to come: And afterwards H. di≈øtrained the Cattle of the Plaintiff being upon the Lands, upon which he brought his Action‚ñ™ Golding, Here is not a ≈øufficient con≈øideration, for the payment of the Rent is not any con≈øideration, for the Le≈ø≈øee hath the ocupation of the Land for it, and hath the profits thereof; and al≈øo the con≈øideration is pa≈øt. Cook, The occupation, which is the con≈øideration, continues, therefore it is a good A≈ø≈øump≈øit, as 4 E. 3. A Gift in Frank-marriage after the e≈øpou≈øals, and yet the marriage is pa≈øt, but the blood continues, ≈øo here; and here the payment of the Rent is executory every year; and if the Le≈ø≈øee be ≈øaved for his occupation, he will pay his Rent the better. Godfrey, If a man marrieth my Daughter again≈øt my will, and afterwards in con≈øideration of that marriage I promi≈øe him one hundred pounds, the ≈øame is no good con≈øideration,2 Len. 111. which Clench Iu≈øtice denied. And afterwards the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover his damages.

div.head:
CXXXV. Wakefords Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Extingui≈øhment of Copy-hold by Relea≈øe.THe Earl of Bedford Lord of the Manor of B. ≈øold the Free-hold Intere≈øt of a Copy-holder of Inheritance unto another, ≈øo as it is now no part, but divided from the Manor, and afterwards the Copy-holder doth relea≈øe to the purcha≈øor. It was holden by the Court, that by this Relea≈øe the Copy-hold Intere≈øt is extingui≈øhed, and utterly gone; but if was holden, that if a Copy-holder be ou≈øted, ≈øo as the Lord of the Manor is di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and the Copy-holder relea≈øeth to the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor nihil operatur.

div.head:
CXXXVI. Docton and Prie≈øts Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking of his Clo≈øe,1 Cro. 95. it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that two were Tenants in common of a hou≈øe, and of a clo≈øe ‚Ä¢ djoyning to the hou≈øe, and they being in the hou≈øe make partition without deed of the hou≈øe and the clo≈øe, ≈øee 3 E. 4. 9. 10. Partition without deed upon the Land is good enough: Vide 3 H. 4. 1. And it ≈øeems by 3 E 4. Partition made upon the Land amounts to a Livery: Vide 2 Eliz. Dyer 179. Partition by word out the County void, 19 H. 6. 25. Betwixt Tenants in common not good without deed;2 Roll. 255. 47 E. 3. 22. being upon the Land it is good without deed: Two Ioynt-tenants make partition by word, & make partition in another County, the ≈øame is no partition, for as to that matter the common Law is not altered by the Statute, but as to compel ≈øuch per≈øons to make partition. Wray Iu≈øtice conceived, that the partition here being without deed was not good, although made upon the Lands: Vide 18 Eliz. Dyer 35. And at another day Wray ≈øaid,Dy. 179. that partition by Tenants in common without deed where≈øoever it is made is good; but in this ca≈øe it appears, that the parties who made the partition were in the hou≈øe (for they were Tenants in common of the Me≈ø≈øuage and a clo≈øe adjoyning to it) and made partition, that one ≈øhould have the hou≈øe,6 Co. 12. and the other the clo≈øe, ≈øo as they were not upon the clo≈øe when they made the partition, and then it was void for the clo≈øe, and if for the clo≈øe then al≈øo for the hou≈øe. And Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head:
CXXXVII. Cook and Songats Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the ca≈øe by Cook again≈øt Songat, the Plaintiff declared, Quod cum quaedam Lis and controver≈øie had been moved betwixt the Plaintiff Lord of the Manor, &c. and the Defendant claiming certain Lands parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, to hold it by copy; and whereas both parties ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to the Iudgment and Arbitrament of I. S. Coun≈øellor at Law, concerning the ≈øaid Land, and the title of the Defendant to it: The Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff promi≈øed to the Defendant, that if the ≈øaid I. S. ≈øhould adjudge the ≈øaid Copy to be good and ≈øufficient for the title of the Defendant, that then he would ≈øuffer the Defendant to enjoy the ≈øaid Land accordingly without mole≈øtation: The Defendant reciprocally promi≈øed the Plaintiff, that if the ≈øaid I. S. ≈øhould adjuge the ≈øaid Copy not ≈øufficient to maintain the title of the Defendant, that then he would deliver and ≈øurrender the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Land to the Plaintiff without any ≈øute: And ≈øhewed further, that I. S. had awarded the ≈øaid Copy utterly in≈øufficient, &c. yet the Defendant did continue the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land, &c. And by Godfrey, here is not any con≈øideration: But by Gawdy, the ≈øame is a good and ≈øufficient con≈øideration, becau≈øe it is to avoid variances and ≈øutes: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CXXXVIII. Pawlet and Lawrences Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øc. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: GEorge Pawlet brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt one Lawrence, Par≈øon of the Church of D. for the taking of certain Carts loaded with Corn, which he claimed as a portion of Tythes in the Right of his Wife; and ≈øuppo≈øed the Tre≈øpa≈øs to be done the ≈øeven and twentieth of Augu≈øt, 29 Eliz. & upon Not guilty it was given in evidence on the Defendants part, that the Plaintiff delivered to him a Licence to be married, bearing date the eight and twentieth of Augu≈øt, 29 Eliz. and that he married the Plaintiff and his ≈øaid Wife the ≈øame day, ≈øo as the Tre≈øpa≈øs was before his title to the Tythes: And it was holden by the whole Court, that that matter did abate his Bill: But it was holden, that if the Tre≈øpa≈øs had been a≈ø≈øigned to be committed one day after that, it had been good; but now it is apparent to the Court, that at the time of the Tre≈øpa≈øs a≈ø≈øigned by him≈øelf, the Plaintiff had not Title, and therefore the Action cannot be maintained upon that evidence, for which cau≈øe the Plaintiff was Non-≈øuit.

div.head:
CXXXIX. Sir John Braunches. Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Forfeiture.IN the Ca≈øe of Sir John Braunch, it was ≈øaid by Cook, that if a Copy-holder be dwelling in a Town long di≈øtant from the Manor, a general warning within the Manor is not ≈øufficient, but there ought to be to the per≈øon notice of the day when the Court ≈øhall be holden, &c. For his not coming in ≈øuch ca≈øe cannot be called a wilful refu≈øal:Copy-holder. So if a man be ≈øo weak and feeble that he cannot travel without danger, ≈øo if he hath a great Office, &c. the≈øe are good cau≈øes of excu≈øe: It was al≈øo holden, that if a Copy-holder makes default at the Court, and be there amerced, although that the amercement be not e≈øtreated, or levyed, yet it is a di≈øpen≈øation of the forfeiture. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, If the Copy-holder be impotent, the Lord may ≈øet a Fine upon him, and if he will not pay the Fine, then it is rea≈øon that he ≈øhall forfeit his Land. Egerton Sollicitor, Warning to the per≈øon of the Copy-holder is not nece≈ø≈øary, for then, if the Lord of a Manor hath one Copy-holder of it dwelling in Cornwal, and another in York, &c. the Lord ought to ≈øend his Bayliff to give notice of the Court to them, which ≈øhould be very inconvenient, and by him continual default at the Court doth amount to a wilful refu≈øal. And by the whole Court, general warning within the Pari≈øh is ≈øufficient,1 Cro. 353. 505. 506. for if the Tenant him≈øelf be not Re≈øient upon his Copy-hold, but el≈øewhere, his Farmer may ≈øend to him notice of the Court: And it was further given in evidence, that Sir John Braunch had by his Letter of Attorney appointed the Son of his Farmer his Attorney to do the ≈øervices for him due for his ≈øaid Copy-hold: And it was holden that ≈øuch a per≈øon ≈øo appointed, might e≈ø≈øoin Sir John, but not do the ≈øervices for him, for none can do the ≈øame but the Tenant him≈øelf.

div.head:
CXL. Wilkes and Per≈øons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: JOhn Wilkes and Margery his Wife, and Thomas Per≈øons brought Tre≈øpa≈øs, Quare clau≈øum fregit, herbam ≈øuam me≈ø≈øuit, & foenum ≈øuum a≈øportavit, Tre≈øpa≈øs. ad damnum ip≈øius Johannis, Margeriae, & Thomae; And exception was taken, that it was not the Hay of the Wife, nor ≈øhe was not damnified by it, but her Husband: Wray Iu≈øtice, the Declaration is good enough,1 Cro. 96. Record. for although it be not good for the Hay, yet clau≈øum fregit & herbam me≈ø≈øuit, makes it good: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiffs.

div.head:
CXLI. Atkin≈øon and Rol≈øes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Action upon the ca≈øe by Atkin≈øon again≈øt Rolfe, the Plaintiff declared, that the Defendant in con≈øideration of the love which he ‚Ä¢ ore unto A. his Father, did promi≈øe that if the Plaintiff would procure a di≈øcharge of a Debt of I. S. which his ≈øaid Father owed to the ≈øaid I. S. that he would ≈øave the Plaintiff harmle≈øs again≈øt the ≈øaid I. S. And declared further, that he had di≈øcharged the Father of the Defendant from the ≈øaid Debt, and is become bounden to the ≈øaid I. S. in an Obligation for the payment of the ≈øaid Debt, upon which Obligation the ≈øaid I. S. hath ≈øued the Plaintiff, and hath recovered, and had execution accordingly, and ≈øo hath not been ≈øaved harmle≈øs, &c. It was objected, that the Declaration was not good, becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath not ≈øhewed in his Declaration, that he had given notice to the Defendant of the ≈øaid Obligation, or of the ≈øuit brought again≈øt him; but that was not allowed, but the Declaration was holden to be good, notwith≈øtanding the exception. Shuttleworth. if I be bound to make to you ≈øuch an a≈ø≈øurance as I. S. ≈øhall devi≈øe, I am bound at my peril to procure notice:Notice. but if I be bound to you to make ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance as your Coun≈øel ≈øhall advi≈øe, there notice ought to be given unto me. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CXLII. Bear and Underwoods Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Replevin it was agreed by the whole Court, that the Plaintiff cannot di≈øcontinue his ≈øuit without the privity of the Court; for as Leonard, Cu≈øtos brevium, ≈øaid, the Entry is, Recordatur per curiam; Di≈øcontinuance of ≈øuit in court. And if the Plaintiff would di≈øcontinue without moving the Court, the Defendant may enter the continuance if he will. It was al≈øo holden, that where an Original is di≈øcontinued, the Defendant ≈øhall not have co≈øts; but if the Plaintiff be non-≈øuit the Defendant ≈øhall have co≈øts, by 32 H. 8. 15. But after a di≈øcontinuance in a Latitat, the Defendant ≈øhall have co≈øts by the Statute of 8 Eliz. cap. 2. And in this ca≈øe it was agreed, that the Plaintiff may be non-≈øuit after a Demurrer, and ≈øo he was.

div.head: CXLIII. Jerom again≈øt Neal and Clave. Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
GEorge Jerom, and Avice his Wife brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs of A≈ø≈øault and wounding of the Wife,A≈ø≈øault and Battery. and the Action was laid in Midd. and brought again≈øt Neal and Cleave, who pleaded that Salisb. is an antient City, & that within the ≈øame, there is this cu≈øtom, that if any make an
Affray and a≈ø≈øault any Officer of the ≈øaid City, or any other per≈øon, if he upon whom ≈øuch a≈ø≈øault is made, complain unto the Mayor of the ≈øaid City, that the Mayor for the time being may ≈øend for him who made the Affray as a Iu≈øtice of Peace, to make him to an≈øwer to it, and ≈øhewed further, that the ≈øaid Jerom made an Affray within the ≈øaid City; of which complaint being made to the Mayor, the ≈øaid Mayor ≈øent the Defendants being Con≈øtables to bring the ≈øaid Jerom to him, by virtue whereof, they went to the Hou≈øe of the Plaintiff, and ≈øignified to him the commandment of the ≈øaid Mayor, and would have brought the Plaintiff to him, and the Wife of the Plaintiff did a≈ø≈øault them, and they moliter put their hands upon the ≈øaid Wife,Impri≈øonment not good. which is the ≈øame a≈ø≈øault, battery, and wounding, &c. upon which it was demurred in Law. Coke for the Plaintiff; This cu≈øtom is not good or rea≈øonable: See Magna charta 29. Nullus liber homo capiatur, vel impri≈øonetur, &c. ni≈øi per legale judiciam parium ≈øuorum vel per legem terrae, therefore ≈øhall not be taken or impri≈øoned upon a bare ≈øugge≈øtion, and ≈øee 24 E. 3. Br. Com. 3. where a Commi≈ø≈øion i≈ø≈øued to take all which were ≈øu≈øpected notoriou≈øly for Frionies and Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, although they are not endicted, and the ≈øame was holden again≈øt the Law, and therefore it was revoked, and ≈øee the Statute of 5 E. 4. 9. 25 E. 4. 13. 28 E. 4. 13. 28 E. 3. 3. 37 E. 3. 18. & 42 E. 3. 3. 2. To be a Iu≈øtice of Peace doth not lye in Pre≈øcription. For one Iu≈øtice of Peace was before the Statute of 1 E. 3. and then the Commencement being known, pre≈øcription cannot be of it. 3. Admit, that the Mayor was Iu≈øtice of Peace, yet he cannot determin any thing out of the Se≈ø≈øions. 4. The Pre≈øcription is, that the Mayor might ≈øend for him, and doth not ≈øay within the City, and it ≈øhall be an unrea≈øonable Pre≈øcription to ≈øay, that the Mayor might ≈øend for him in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, in any place within England. 5. It is not ≈øhewed that they of Salisbury have a corporation, ≈øo as they might be enabled to pre≈øcribe. 6. The wounding is not an≈øwered, for moliter injicere manus cannot be taken for a wounding; it may well an≈øwer the battery, &c. Fleetwood Recorder of London, if the Statute of Magna Charta ≈øhould be ob≈øerved, no Felon is duly handled at Newgate, and here we have not pleaded by way of Pre≈øcription, but of u≈øage; con≈øuetudo and u≈øage are all one.1 Cro. 268. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiffs, for the Plea in Bar was holden to be naught, becau≈øe the wounding is not an≈øwered; and the Cu≈øtom is too general, and al≈øo for the 4th exception.

div.head:
CXLIV. Sir Julius Cae≈øars Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
FLeetwood came to the Bar and ≈øhewed, that Julius Cae≈øar Iudge of the Admiralty had libelled again≈øt an Officer of the Mayor of Lond. Simon Nicholas, for mea≈øuring of Coals at Wiggins Key, in the Pari≈øh of St. Dun≈øtan in the Ea≈øt, and it was upon the Thames, and prayed a prohibition, becau≈øe ≈øuch mea≈øuring of Coals had always appertained to the Mayor of London; for the Statute of 28 H. 8. 15. gave Iurisdiction to the Admiralty in Ca≈øe of robbery and murder: And that prohibition was grounded upon the Statutes of 13. & 15 R. 2. 2 H. 4. 11. And it was ≈øaid, that this mea≈øuring whereof, &c. was in the body of the County; And note, that the ≈øaid Julius Cae≈øar, being Iudge of the Admiralty had put in this Bill, ex officio judicis, upon which it was ≈øaid by Wray Iu≈øtice, that it was hard that he ≈øhould be both Plaint. and Iudge, and that his Iuri≈ødiction ≈øhould be tryed before him≈øelf, and afterwards, it was moved by Egerton Solicitor, who ≈øaid he had ≈øpoken with the Lord Admiral, who told him that the Mayor of Lond. u≈øed to take a Fine for mea≈øurage, and had made an office of it, and that he conceived, the ≈øame is extortion, and being made upon the water, he conceived he is puni≈øhable in this Court, for by the ≈øame rea≈øon the Mayor might take a Fine for the mea≈øuring of Corn, Clothes, &c. Wray and
Gawdy Iu≈øtices; If it be extortion in the Mayor, there is no remedy for it in the Court of Admiralty: But in the Kings Court. Gawdy; It ≈øhall be redre≈ø≈øed here in a Quo warranto.

div.head:
CXLV. The Town of Su≈ø≈øex.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Town of Green in Su≈ø≈øex was amereed for the e≈øcape of a Felon,Amercement. and the ≈øaid Amercement was grounded upon an inqui≈øition taken before the Coroner, by whom the e≈øcape was found; and it was moved for the Town, that here is not any ≈øuch e≈øcape found,E≈øcape. for which the Town ought to be amerced, for it is found, that he who e≈øcaped, 10 die Januarij, 30 Eliz. circa horam quartam po≈øt meridiem, with a Pitchfork mortally ≈øtruck one A. which A. of the ≈øaid ≈øtroak died at eight in the Evening of the ≈øame day, and that then the other e≈øcaped, for which e≈øcape being made in the Night, the Town by the Law ought to be amerced, for it is not Felony, until the party dieth, which ≈øee 11 H. 4. and Coles Ca≈øe, Pa≈øch. 23 Eliz. 401. And therefore the Town nor any other was chargeable with the offendor before that the party was dead. Wray; It ≈øhould be hard, that the Town ≈øhould be amerced upon this matter, for although the Town in di≈øcretion might have ≈øtayed the offender before the death of the party, yet it is not bound ≈øo to do: And the Court took time to advi≈øe of the Ca≈øe.

div.head:
CXLVI. Jerom and Knights Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
JOan Jerom brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe in the nature of Con≈øpiracy again≈øt one Knight, and declared,Con≈øpiracy, 1 Cro. 70. that the ≈øaid Knight had malitiou≈øly cau≈øed the Plaintiff to be endicted of Felony, and to be arrained upon it, and that ≈øhe was legitimo modo acquietat. &c. And the Ca≈øe was, that the Defendant came into the Court where the Se≈ø≈øions was holden, and complained of the Plaintiff for the ≈øaid Felony, for which the Iu≈øtices there comanded her to cau≈øe an Indictment to be drawn, &c. Coke upon the Books of 27 H. 6. 12. 35 H. 6. 14. 27 H. 8. 2. Fitz. 115. It appeareth, that if one come voluntarily into the Court and di≈øcover Felonies, and if it be true which he ≈øaith, or if he come in Court and draw an Indictment by the command of the Iu≈øtices, or if he be bound by order of Law, to cau≈øe the party to be Indicted, or to give in Evidence, although he do it fal≈øely, yet he ≈øhall not be puni≈øhed for the ≈øame in Con≈øpiracy, or in an Action upon the Ca≈øe; But if he come gratis with malice in him before, and malicio≈øly and fal≈øely cau≈øe the party to be Indicted, ≈øo as fal≈øity and malice are the ground of it, &c. it is otherwi≈øe. Gawdy Iu≈øtice; How ≈øhall it be tried, if he doth it with malice or not? Coke, It may be enquired of, for malice makes the difference betwixt Murder and Man≈ølaughter; and in ≈øuch ca≈øe it is to be enquired, and here he came to do the ≈øame without Proce≈øs or coher≈øion in Law. But if he will ≈øafely do ≈øuch office, his direct cour≈øe is to come to a Iu≈øtice of Peace, and to ≈øhew to him, that his Goods are ≈øtolen, and that he doth ≈øu≈øpect ≈øuch a one, and then upon examination he ≈øhall be bound to come and give in Evidence again≈øt the party, &c. and in ≈øuch ca≈øe although that his Evidence he fal≈øe, yet he is not puni≈øhable:Owen 158. At another day, it was ≈øaid by Coke in the ≈øame ca≈øe, ut ≈øupra. If a man be bound to give Evidence again≈øt any per≈øon, although he give fal≈øe Evidence, no Action lieth: Al≈øo if one come into Court gratis, and di≈øclo≈øeth a Felony, and gives Evidence, if no malice proceed again≈øt the party, it is not puni≈øhable; and here fore thought malice is alledged, and put in the Declaration, to which the Defendant hath pleaded not guilty; And now he is found guilty. See the Statute of We≈øtmin≈øter,
2. Cap. 12. Si inveniatur per inqui≈øitionem quod aliquis ≈øit abettator per malitiam, &c. Wray Iu≈øtice; It ≈øhould be hard to charge one with this Action, where he hath his goods ≈øtolen from him, and therefore cau≈øeth an Indictment to be drawn again≈øt one who he ≈øu≈øpects of it, who ≈øhall be found guilty, who ≈øhould be puni≈øhed for it; for many Malefactors notwith≈øtanding that the Evidence again≈øt them be full and pregnant, in favour of life are acquitted, whereas by Law they ought to be hanged; and it is not rea≈øon,Upon an Acquital of Grace, no Con≈øpiracy lieth. that upon ≈øuch an acquital of grace and mercy, he ≈øhould have this Action; if ≈øuch per≈øon had u≈øed any words of malice before the Se≈ø≈øions, an Action upon the ca≈øe would have lain: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, Trin. 27 Eliz. 750. Ratford, and afterwards a Writ of Error was brought, Trin. 29 Eliz. Rot. 669. In the Original Action the Writ and Declaration were that the Defendant, malitio≈øe intendens querentem in nomine, vita, fama, & bonis defraudare quandam Billam Indictamenti ≈øcribi fecit, & eam exhibuit to the grand Enque≈øt, & ibidem fal≈øe depo≈øuit omnia in ea contenta e≈ø≈øe vera, which by Coke is full matter of con≈øpiracy; for the drawing of an Indictment is not the office of a witne≈øs, but if it were by the commandment of the Court, or of one Iu≈øtice of Peace, it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe, for there he goes by cour≈øe of Iu≈øtice, 21 E. 3. 17. If one con≈øpire with another, and afterwards he procures him≈øelf to be one of the Indictors, his oath ≈øhall not excu≈øe his malice before. Gawdy, If the party had taken upon him to proceed again≈øt the party upon any good pre≈øumtions, he might have pleaded it, as to ≈øay, he found the party in the hou≈øe ≈øu≈øpiciou≈øly, &c. but becau≈øe he doth not plead any ≈øuch matter, but generally not guilty, and the Writ and Declaration ≈øtand not an≈øwered ≈øpecially, nor controlled with the Verdict, there is no rea≈øon but that the Iudgment ≈øhould be affirmed; And afterwards, the Iudgment was affirmed, and it was ≈øaid by Wray, that here the words in the Writ and Declaration are all one as the words in a Writ of con≈øpiracy, and the Defendant hath not ≈øhewed any ≈øpecial matter to enduce him to the proceedings.

div.head:
CXLVII. Ferrers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
HUmphry Ferrers brought an Action upon the ca≈øe, and declared, that he is ≈øei≈øed of an ancient me≈ø≈øuage in the Town of Tamworth, Pre≈øcription. and that he and all his Ance≈øtors, who≈øe heir he is, owners of the Me≈ø≈øuage, &c. have u≈øed time out of mind, &c. to erect Herdells, in aperta platea of Tamworth juxta Me≈ø≈øuagium praedict. every Market day, to make Penns there for Sheep, and that he, &c. have u≈øed for ≈øuch penning of Sheep, there to take divers ≈øums of mony of ≈øuch per≈øons who would Penn their Sheep there; and further declared, that the Defendant had broken and pulled down his Herdels, per quod proficuum ≈øuum inde ami≈øit; And upon this Declaration, Godfrey did demur in Law, 1. The Plaintiff hath not ≈øhewed in his Declaration, ≈øpecially where he hath u≈øed to erect his Herdels, but generally in aperta platea, without ≈øhewing in his own Land, or in the Land of another; if in the Land of another, it is no good title, for although that tho≈øe who fi≈øh in the Sea may pre≈øcribe to ≈øet Stakes on the Land adjoyning to the Sea, to hang their Nets to dry after they have done Fi≈øhing, and that is through the whole County of Kent 8 E. 4. for their pre≈øcription is for the common Wealth, but the ≈øame is not ≈øo here, but only for a private gain; al≈øo no pre≈øcription is good, but where ≈øome profit comes to him who pre≈øcribes for it, which ≈øee in the ca≈øe of the Abbot of Buckfa≈øt, 21 E. 4. 4. 21 H. 7. 20. Al≈øo the Declaration is, that the Plaintiff hath taken diver≈øas denariorum ≈øummas, and ≈øee the Prior of Dun≈øtables ca≈øe,
11 H. 6. 19. 19 R. 2. Action ≈øurle Ca≈øe 51. But the certainty of the ≈øums do not appear in this Declaration, ≈øo as the rea≈øonablene≈øs of the cu≈øtom might be known: Al≈øo it appeareth here upon the Declaration, that Tre≈øpa≈øs, vi & armis, ≈øhould lye and be brought, for the Declaration is, that the Defendant did break and pull down the Herdels which cannot be without expre≈øs force, as 42 E. 3. 24. Tre≈øpa≈øs upon the ca≈øe again≈øt a Miller, and declared that the Plaintiff u≈øed to grind at the ≈øaid Mill without Toll, and that he ≈øent his corn to the ≈øaid Mill to be ground, and there the Defendant came and took two Bu≈øhels of his ≈øaid corn; And the Writ was upon the pre≈øcription to grind ≈øine multura, and that the Defendant, praedict. querent. ≈øine multura molire impedivit, and by Award of the Court the Plaintiff took nothing by his Writ, for he hath declared that the Defendant hath taken Toll, and therefore he ought to have a general Writ of Tre≈øpa≈øs. Beaumont, to the contrary; A Market is as well for the common Wealth as a Fi≈øhing: Al≈øo he is at the co≈øts for providing of Herdels, and the erecting of them, ≈øo (as he hath declared) he hath taken divers ≈øums of mony for it; and as to any ≈øum not certain, it is well enough, for peradventure ≈øometimes he hath taken a penny, ≈øometimes two pence, as the parties could agree: And as to the exception of vi & armis, the ≈øame is not material, for the Plaintiff doth not rely upon the pulling down of the Herdels only, but upon the lo≈øs of the mony al≈øo, which he ≈øhould have had if the Defendant had not broken his Herdels: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CXLVIII. Beverly and Bawdes Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
BEverly brought a Writ of Error to rever≈øe an Out-lawry pronounced again≈øt him at the ≈øuit of one Bawdes, and ≈øhewed,Error. that he was outlawed by the name John Beverly of Humby in the County of Lincoln Gent. And that within the ≈øaid County there are two Humbyes, ≈øcil. Magna Humby, & Parva Humby, and none without addition; To which it was ≈øaid, of the other ≈øide, that the truth is that there are two ≈øuch Towns, and that Humby Magna is known as well by the name of Humby only, as taken for the name of Humby Magna: And upon that they are at I≈ø≈øue: And it was moved,Tryal by Inque≈øt of what County or place. if the Inque≈øt to try this I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall come de corpore comitatus, or from Humby Magna. And by Cooke, it ≈øhall be tryed by an Inque≈øt of Humby Magna; and he confe≈ø≈øed, that if the I≈ø≈øue had been, No ≈øuch Town; then the Inque≈øt ought to be of the body of the County, but here is another I≈ø≈øue to be tryed, 22 E. 4. 4. In Tre≈øpa≈øs done in Fulborn and Hinton in the County of C. The Defendant ≈øaid, that there is no ≈øuch Town nor Hamlet of Hinton within the ≈øame County. Iudgment of the Writ. See there by Briggs the tryal ≈øhall be, de corpore comitatus. See 14 H. 6. 8. Over-dale and Nether-dale, and none without addition, and ≈øo at I≈ø≈øue tryed by them of the body of the County, 35 H. 6. 12. And by him, where≈øoever an I≈ø≈øue may be tryed by an Inque≈øt out of a ≈øpecial Vi≈øne, there it ≈øhall never be tryed by the body of the County. As the ca≈øe before, 22 E. 4. Tre≈øpa≈øs in two Towns A. and B. The Def. as to A. pleads, there was no ≈øuch Town, and as to B. pleaded another plea. Now the whole Inque≈øt ≈øhall come out of B. for the Inque≈øt in one Town may try any thing within the ≈øame County, which ≈øee Fitz. Vi≈øne, 27. 22 E. 4. 4. And here in our ca≈øe the I≈ø≈øue is, if Humby Magna be as well known by the name of Humby only, as by the name of Humby Magna. And therefore the ≈øame may well be tryed by Inque≈øt out of the Town of Humby Magna.
