But by Wray Iu≈øtice, this I≈ø≈øue doth amount to no ≈øuch Town, for the perclo≈øe of the plea is, and no Humby without addition; and the book cited out of 22 E. 4. is not ruled, but
is only the opinion of Brian. and afterwards it was awarded, that the tryal was well. Another matter was objected, becau≈øe it is not ≈øhewed in the Writ of Error betwixt what parties the fir≈øt Writ did depend, for otherwi≈øe how can the Plaintiff in the Writ of Error have a Scire facias ad audiendum Errores, if none be named in the Writ of Error again≈øt whom it ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue. And Godfrey affirmed, that upon ≈øearch of Pre≈øidents it was both ways, ≈øo as it is at the plea≈øure of the Plaintiff to do it or not. And Kemp Secondary ≈øhewed divers Pre≈øidents to that purpo≈øe: And afterwards the Out-lawry was rever≈øed.

div.head:
CXLIX. Cibel and Hills Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Debt for a Nemine pene.
A Lea≈øe was made of a certain Hou≈øe and Land rendring Rent, and another ≈øum, Nomine poenae; and for the Nominae poenae the Le≈ø≈øor brought an Action of Debt: The Le≈ø≈øee pleaded, that the Le≈ø≈øor had entred into parcel of the Land demi≈øed,Roll. Tit. Extingui≈øhment upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue, and found for the Plaintiff: and now the Le≈ø≈øor brought Debt for the Rent re≈øerved upon the ≈øame Lea≈øe: to which the Defendant pleaded, ut ≈øupra, ≈øcil. an Entry into parcel of the Land demi≈øed: And i≈ø≈øue was joyned upon it; And one of the Iury was challenged, and withdrawn, becau≈øe he was one of the former Iury: And the I≈ø≈øue now was, whether the ≈øaid Cibel the Le≈ø≈øor, expulit & amovit & adhuc extra tenet, the ≈øaid Hills. And to prove the ≈øame, it was given in Evidence on the Defendants part, that upon the Land demi≈øed there was a Brick-kill, and and thereupon a little ≈ømall cottage, and that the Le≈ø≈øor entred, and went to the ≈øaid cottage and took ≈øome of the Bricks and untiled the ≈øaid cottage:Su≈øpen≈øion of Rent by entry upon part of the Land. But of the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, that the Le≈ø≈øor had re≈øerved to him≈øelf the Bricks and Tiles afore≈øaid, which in truth were there ready made at the time of the Lea≈øe made, and that he did not untile the Brick-kill hou≈øe, but that it fell by tempe≈øt, and ≈øo the Plaintiff did nothing but came upon the Land to carry away his own goods: And al≈øo he had u≈øed the ≈øaid Bricks and Tiles upon the reparation of the hou≈øe. And as to the Extra tenet, which is parcel of the I≈ø≈øue, the Le≈ø≈øor did not continue upon the Land,Hob. 326. Rolls ubi ≈øupra. Po≈øt. 172. but went off it, and relinqui≈øhed the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: But as to this la≈øt point, it ≈øeemed to the Court, that it is not material if the Plaintiff continued his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there or not, for if he once doth any thing which amounts to an Entry, although that he depart pre≈øently, yet the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is in him ≈øufficient to ≈øu≈øpend the Rent, and he ≈øhall be ≈øaid, extra tanere the Defendant the Le≈ø≈øee, until he hath done an Act which doth amount to a Re-entry. And afterwards to prove a Re-entry, it was given in Evidence on the Plaintiffs part, that the Defendant put in his Cattel in the Field where the Brick-kill was, and that the Cattel did e≈øtray into the place where the Defendant had ≈øuppo≈øed that the Plaintiff had entred. And by Ander≈øon Iu≈øtice, the ≈øame is not any Re-entry to revive the Rent, becau≈øe they were not put into the ≈øame place by the Le≈ø≈øee him≈øelf, but went there of their own accord. And ≈øuch al≈øo was the opinion of Iu≈øtice Periam.

div.head: CL. Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
TEnant in tail covenanted with his Son to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of his Son in tail, the Remainder to the right Heirs of the Father: The Father levyed a Fine with proclamation and died. It was moved by Fenner, if any
e≈øtate pa≈ø≈øed to the Son by the Covenant, for it is not a di≈øcontinuance, and ≈øo nothing pa≈ø≈øed but during his life, and all the e≈øtates which are to begin after his death are void. Ander≈øon, The e≈øtate pa≈ø≈øeth until, &c. and he cited the ca≈øe of one Pitts, where it was adjudged, that if Tenant in tail of an Advow≈øon in gro≈øs grant the ≈øame in Fee, and an Ance≈øtor collateral relea≈øeth with warranty and dieth: That the ≈øame is a good Bar for ever.

div.head:
CLI. Staffords Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe ca≈øe was,Attachment upon a Prohibition. More. 599. that the Par≈øon of the Church of B. did libel in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court for Ttithe-milk of eight Kine depa≈øturing within ≈øuch a Field within his Pari≈øh: The Defendant ≈øaid, that he and all tho≈øe, &c. had u≈øed time out of mind, &c. to pay every year a certain ≈øum of mony to the Par≈øon, &c. for the Tithes of the ≈øame Field; which plea the Iudges of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court would not allow, and therefore the party had now a Prohibition and an Injunction again≈øt the Iudges, Doctors, Proctors, &c. And afterwards the ≈øame Par≈øon libelled again for the ≈øame Tithes again≈øt the ≈øame Pari≈øhioner; and in both libels there was no difference, but that in the later libel it was for a le≈øs number of Kine, and now the Pari≈øhioner upon this matter prayed an Attachment upon the Prohibition, which was granted unto him by the Court, for otherwi≈øe a Prohibition ≈øhould be granted to no purpo≈øe.

div.head:
CLII. Samford and Wards Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: SAmford brought a Ravi≈øhment of Ward again≈øt Ward, Ravi≈øhment of Ward. and counted hat one A. Ance≈øtor of the Infant, who≈øe Heir he is, was ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands in Fee, and held the ≈øame of the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter in Socage, and died, his Heir within the age of 14 years; and that the cu≈øtody of the Infant did belong unto him as his prochein Amy; by force of which he ≈øei≈øed him and was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, &c. The Defendant ≈øaith, that the Land was holden of him by Knights ≈øervice, ab≈øque hoc, that it is holden of the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter as the Plaintiff hath counted. And upon the I≈ø≈øue was joyned. And it was moved by Serjant Puckering on the Plaintiffs part, that the truth of the Ca≈øe was, that all the Land de≈øcended is holden in Socage, and no part in Knights ≈øervice, but that part of it is holden of another in Socage: And prayed the opinion of the Court, if that matter ≈øhall trench to the I≈ø≈øue as the ≈øame is joyned: And the Court was of opinion, that it did not: for if all be holden in Socage, it is not material if part of it be holden of another, ≈øo as it be holden in Socage.

div.head:
CLIII. Stamp and Hutchins Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
THe Ca≈øe was, the Obligor makes his Executors and dieth;1 Cro. 120. the Executors become bounden to the Obligee for the payment of the ≈øaid Debt, and the Obligee doth deliver back the Obligation of the Te≈øtator to them; and afterwards another Creditor of the Te≈øtator ≈øues the Executors, who pleaded, that they have fully admini≈øtred, upon which they are at i≈ø≈øue, and the ≈øaid e≈øpecial
matter was found by verdict. And by Shuttleworth and Walme≈øley, The Iury have found for the Plaintiff, and that the Defendants have not fully admini≈øtred: And yet they agreed the ca≈øe of 20 H. 7. 2. The Executors paying to the Creditors of the Te≈øtator a Debt with their own goods, they may retain ≈øo much of the goods of the Te≈øtator; but that ca≈øe is not like to this, for here the Executors have not made any payment or ≈øatisfaction of the Debt, nor disbur≈øed any mony, &c. nor other things, but only have made an Obligation, to pay a ≈øum of mony at a day to come, before which day it may happen that the Obligation be cancelled or relea≈øed; but it may more fitly be compared to the ca≈øe of 27 H. 8. 6. where an Executor had compounded with a Creditor of the Te≈øtator for the payment of 20 l. for a debt of 40 l. and had an Acquitance te≈øtifying the payment of the 40 l. where it was holden, that the other 20 l. is A≈ø≈øets. And by Rhodes, this making of an Obligation by Executors,Admini≈øtration. A≈ø≈øets. (although the Obligation, in which the Te≈øtator was bounden, be delivered to the Executors and cancelled) is not any admini≈øtration nor payment of the ≈øaid debt due: So if the Executors pledge the goods for the payment of ≈øuch a debt, yet they ≈øhall be accounted A≈ø≈øets until payment be made, which Periam denied. And Periam and all the other Iu≈øtices held clearly,Retainer by admini≈øtrations. that if in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Executors make a ≈øufficient Obligation to the Creditor of the Te≈øtator, and ≈øufficiently di≈øcharge the Te≈øtator without fraud or covin, that they may retain the goods of the Te≈øtator for ≈øo much: and the goods retained ≈øhall not be ≈øaid A≈ø≈øets: And this ca≈øe is all one with the ca≈øe of 20 H. 7. for here they have di≈øcharged the Te≈øtator, and the Executors do remain charged with the ≈øame to the Creditor; and it is ≈øo fully admini≈øtred, as if the Executors had expre≈øly paid the debt. And it is not like to the ca≈øe of 27 H. 8. cited before, for there, although they have di≈øcharged the Te≈øtator, yet they have not charged them≈øelves, otherwi≈øe it is in the principal ca≈øe; and although they have appointed ulteriorem diem, for the payment of the ≈øaid debt, yet the ≈øame is not material: But the Lord Ander≈øon conceived, that if the Creditor doth deliver unto the Executors the Obligation as an Accquittance or di≈øcharge, and in con≈øideration thereof they promi≈øe to pay the debt, the ≈øame is not any admini≈øtration as to the ≈øaid debt. And by ≈øome of the Serjants, If the plea ≈øtand good to prove fully admini≈øtred, then Executors in ≈øuch ca≈øe may make an Obligation to pay the debt 40 years after, and ≈øo defraud the other Creditors, which is not rea≈øonable: If a Feoffment in Fee made upon condition to pay certain mony at ≈øuch a day, and at the day the Feoffees make an Obligation to the Feoffor for the payment of it, the ≈øame is no performance of the condition. And by Periam, If the Executor be taken in Execution for the debt of the Te≈øtator, he may retain ≈øo much of the goods of the Te≈øtator amounting to the ≈øum for which he is in Execution, and it ≈øhall be accounted A≈ø≈øets in his hands. Ander≈øon, If he to whom the Te≈øtator was endebted in 20 l. be endebted to the Executors in ≈øo much, and the Executor in ≈øatisfaction of the debt of the Te≈øtator relea≈øeth his debt, the property ≈øhall be altered pre≈øently of the whole goods in the hands of the Executors, ≈øo where the Debtor makes the Creditor his Executor. And Iudgment was given for the Executors.

div.head:
CLIV. Bears Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Formedon. A Formedon in the Di≈øcender was brought by Samuel Bear, James Bear, and John Bear of Lands in Gavel-kind; and the Warranty of their Ance≈øtor was pleaded again≈øt them in Bar, upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue.
If A≈ø≈øets by di≈øcent. And it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that Thomas, Father of the Demandants, was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Lands ≈øuppo≈øed to be de≈øcended to the Demandants, being of the nature of Gavel-kind, and devi≈øed the ≈øame to the Demandants, being his Heirs, by the cu≈øtom, and to their Heirs equally to be divided among≈øt them:Devi≈øe of Lands in Gavel-kind Owen. 65. Dy. 350. 1 Cro. 431. More 594. 558. Sty. 434. 3 Cro. 330. 443. 695. 696. And if the Demandants ≈øhall be accounted to be in of the Lands by de≈øcent, or devi≈øe, was the que≈øtion; for if by devi≈øe, then they ≈øhall not be A≈ø≈øets. Ander≈øon, Let us con≈øider the devi≈øe by it ≈øelf without the words (equally to be divided among≈øt them.) And I conceive, that they ≈øhall be in by the devi≈øe, for they are now Ioynt-tenants, and the ≈øurvivor ≈øhall have the whole, whereas if the Lands ≈øhall be holden in Law to have de≈øcended, they ≈øhould be Parceners, and ≈øo as it were Tenants in common. And although the words ≈øub≈øequent, equally among≈øt them to be divided, makes them Tenants in common, yet that doth not amend the matter; and ≈øo al≈øo was the opinion of Windham and Rhodes Iu≈øtices.

div.head:
CLV. Na≈øh and Edwards Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Ejectione firmae by Na≈øh again≈øt Edwards, 1 Cro. 100. it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that one Dover Ance≈øtor of the Plaintiff, who≈øe Heir he is, being ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands holden in Socage, devi≈øed the ≈øame by word to his three Si≈øters; And a ≈øtranger being pre≈øent recited to the Devi≈øor the ≈øaid words of his Will; and he did affirm them:3 Len. 79. And afterwards the ≈øaid ≈øtranger put the ≈øaid words in writing for his own remembrance, but did not read them to the Devi≈øor, who afterwards died. And it was moved, If this devi≈øe being reduced in writing, modo & forma, be good or not. Spurling conceived that not, for the Statute intends a Will in writing,Devi≈øes. but not ≈øuch writing as is here without privity or direction of the Devi≈øor, and it is not like to the ca≈øe of Brown and Sackvil, 6 E. 6. Dyer 72. For the Notes were written by the commandment of the Devi≈øor, but here it doth not appear that the meaning of the Devi≈øor was, that the devi≈øe ≈øhould be put in writing: And devi≈øes in Law are favoured, as the ca≈øe in the Chancery was, that Sir Richard Pexhal devi≈øed certain Lands to his Wife, and the Scrivener in≈øerted of his own head a condition, ≈øcil. (that ≈øhe ≈øhould be cha≈øt) which was di≈øallowed by the Devi≈øor him≈øelf, for which after his death, the condition, although it was put in writing, was void. And by the whole Court the devi≈øe is void. And by Wray, 2 Len. 35. if he appoint A. to write his Will, and it is written by B. it is void; but if after he had written the Will if he had read it to the Devi≈øor, and he had confirmed it, it had been a good Will, which Gawdy granted: And afterwards Iudgment was given, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould recover.

div.head:
Stone and Withypolls Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. Rot. 771. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
STone brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Dorothy Withypol the Executrix of W. Withypol her Husband,1 Cro. 126. Owen. 94. 9 Co. 94. & declared that where her≈øaid Husband for certain yards of Velvet of the value of fourteen pounds, & pro diver≈øis alijs mercimonijs, was endebted to the Plaintiff in the ≈øum of ninety two pounds, and made the Defendant his Executrix & died, that after his death he came to the Defendant, and demanded of her the ≈øaid debt, who gave to him ≈øuch an≈øwer, Forbear me until Michaelmas, and then I will pay it you, or put you in ≈øufficient ≈øecurity for the
true payment thereof: And declared further, that at Michaelmas afore≈øaid, the Defendant did not pay, nor hath found any ≈øecurity, and ≈øhewed a reque≈øt, to which the Defendant ≈øaid that the ≈øaid Te≈øtator at the time of the ≈øaid Contracts for the Velvets and other Wares, was within age:A≈ø≈øump≈øit. And upon that Bar the Plaintiff did demur in Law. Egerton Solicitor, for the Plaintiff. As I conceive the≈øe Contracts made by the Plaintiff are not meerly void, ≈øo that if an Action of Debt, or upon the Ca≈øe, had been brought again≈øt the Te≈øtator him≈øelf, he could not have pleaded upon the matter Nihil debet, or Non A≈ø≈øump≈øit, or Non e≈øt factum, but he ought to avoid the matter by ≈øpecial pleading, and therefore here it is a good con≈øideration; and I conceive that if the Te≈øtator at his full age had a≈ø≈øumed to pay the debt, that that promi≈øe would have bound him, 9 Eliz. it was the Ca≈øe of the Lord Grey, his Father was endebted to diver≈øe Merchants upon ≈øimple Contracts, and died ≈øei≈øed of diver≈øe Lands which de≈øcended to his Son and Heir in Fee, the Creditors demanded their debts of the Heir, who an≈øwered unto them, if my Father were endebted unto you, I will pay it, and upon that promi≈øe an Action was adjudged maintainable, although the Heir by the Law was not chargeable; and al≈øo here the Defendant is to have ea≈øe, and ≈øhall avoid trouble of Suits, for perhaps if ≈øhe had not made ≈øuch promi≈øe, the Plaintiff would have ≈øued her pre≈øently, which ≈øhould be a great trouble unto her, and therefore it is a good con≈øideration. Cooke contrary, No con≈øideration can be good, if not, that it touch either the charge of the Plaintiff, or the benefit of the Defendant, and none of them is in our ca≈øe, for the Plaintiff is not at any charge, for which the Defendant can have any benefit, for it is but the forbearance of the payment of the debt, which ≈øhe was not compellable to pay, and as to the ≈øuit of the Chancery, the ≈øame cannot make any good con≈øideration, for there is not any matter in the Ca≈øe which gives cau≈øe of ≈øuit in Chancery, for they will not order a matter there which is directly again≈øt a Rule and Maxim of the common Law. As if a Feme Covert be bound, &c. and the Obligee bring her into the Chancery, and if a man threaten me, that if I will not pay to him ten pounds, he will ≈øue me in Chancery, upon which I promi≈øe to pay it him, no Action will lye: And an Infant is not chargeable upon any contract, but for his meat, drink, and nece≈ø≈øary Apparel, 19 Z. 4. 2. And in Debt upon ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øary Contract, the Plaintiff ought to declare ≈øpecially, ≈øo as the whole certainty may appear upon which the Court may judge, if the expen≈øe were nece≈ø≈øary and convenient or not, and upon the rea≈øonablene≈øs of the price, for otherwi≈øe, if the nece≈ø≈øity of the thing, and rea≈øonablene≈øs of the price doth not appear, the Chancellor him≈øelf would not give any remedy, or recompence to the party. Wray Ju≈øtice conceived, that the Action would not lye, for the contract was void, and the Infant in an Action again≈øt him upon it may plead Nihil debet: And if an Infant ≈øell goods for money and doth not deliver them, but the Vendee takes them, he is a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor; but if the Infant had been bounden in an Obligation with a ≈øurety, and afterwards at his full age he in con≈øideration thereof promi≈øeth to keep his ≈øurety harmle≈øs, upon that promi≈øe an Action lyeth, for the Infant cannot plead non e≈øt factum, which ≈øee Mich. 28, & 29 Eliz. in the Ca≈øe of one Edmunds: And afterwards it was adjudged again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLVII. Charnock and Wor≈øleys Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. Rot 833. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Owen. 21. 1 Cr. 129. CHarnock and his Wife brought a Writ of Error again≈øt Wor≈øley; the Ca≈øe was that the Husband and Wife, the Wife being within age levyed a Fine, and the Wife upon in≈øpection was adjudged within
age, & it was moved, if the Fine ≈øhould be utterly rever≈øed, or as to the Wife only, & ≈øhould ≈øtand again≈øt the Husband; & by Godfrey the Book of 50 E. 3. 6. was vouched where it is ≈øaid by Candi≈øh, that where ≈øuch a Fine is rever≈øed, the Plaintiff ≈øhall not have execution till after the death of the Husband; and by Coke and Atkin≈øon, a Fine acknowledged by the Husband and Wife, is not like to a Feoffment made by them, for in ca≈øe of Feoffment ≈øomething pa≈ø≈øeth from the Husband, but in ca≈øe of a Fine all pa≈ø≈øeth out of the Wife, and the Conu≈øee is in by her only: And Atkin≈øon ≈øhewed a Precedent in 2 H. 4. where the Fine was rever≈øed for the whole, and al≈øo another Precedent, P. b. H. 8. Rot. 26. A Fine levyed betwixt Richard Elie Plaintiff, and N. Ford. and Jane his Wife Deforceants, the Wife being within age, and Iudgment was given quod finis praedict. adnulletur, & pro nullo penitus habeatur, and that the Husband and Wife ≈øhould be re≈øtored, and thereupon a Writ i≈ø≈øued to the Cu≈øtos Brevium, to bring into Court the Foot of the Fine, and it was pre≈øently cancelled in Court. Wray, this is a ≈øtrong Precedent, and we will not var≈øe from it, if other Precedents are not contrary. Gawdy (who was the ≈øame day made Iu≈øtice) the Fine cannot be rever≈øed as to one, and ≈øtand as to the other, and re≈øembled it to the Ca≈øe of Littleton 150. where Land is given to Husband and Wife in tail before coverture, and the Husband aliens, and takes back an e≈øtate to him and his Wife for their lives, they both are remitted, for the Wife cannot be remitted if the Husband be not remitted: And a Precedent was cited to the contrary, 7 Eliz. where the Ca≈øe was that the Husband and Wife levyed a Fine, the Husband died, the Wife being within age the Wife took another Husband, and they brought a Writ of Error, and the Wife by in≈øpection adjudged within age,Fine rever≈øed as to one, to ≈øtand good again≈øt another. and the Fine was rever≈øed as to the Wife and her Heirs. And it was argued by Golding, that here the Writ of Error ought to abate, for the Writ is too general, whereas it ought to be ≈øpecial, Ex querela A.B. nobis humillime ≈øupplicantis accepimus, &c. See the Book of Entries 278. Al≈øo the purclo≈øe of the Writ is, ad damnum imp≈øorum, the Husband and the Wife, whereas the Wife only hath lo≈øs by it; and as to the Fine it ≈øelf, he conceived that it ≈øhould be rever≈øed but as to the Wife; as if a man of full age, and a man within age, levy a Fine, in a Writ of Error brought, the Fine ≈øhall be rever≈øed, as to the Infant only, and ≈øhall ≈øtand again≈øt the other; and he cited the Ca≈øe of the Lord Mountjoy, 14. Eliz. Where a man ≈øei≈øed in the right of his Wife acknowledged a Statute, and afterwards he and his Wife levyed a Fine, and he ≈øaid that during the life of the Husband, the Conu≈øee of the Fine ≈øhould hold the Land charged with the Statute: Al≈øo in the Precedent of 2 H. 4. the Iudgment is, that propter hunc & alios errores, the Fine ≈øhould be rever≈øed, and I conceive that another Error was in the ≈øaid Writ, for which the Fine might be rever≈øed in all viz. the Fine was levyed of two parts of the Manor of D. without ≈øaying in tres partes dividend. And ≈øee that where two parts are demanded in a Writ,3 Co. 58, 59. Modern Rep. 182. the Writ ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øo, Brief 244 Coke contrary, and as to the la≈øt matter I confe≈øs the Law is ≈øo in a Writ, but not in a Fine, for the ≈øame is but a Conveyance, for it I be ≈øei≈øed of a Manor, and I grant to you two parts of the ≈øaid Manor, it is clear, it ≈øhall be intended in three parts to be divided. And as to the principal matter, I conceive, when the Fine is levyed by the Husband and Wife, it ≈øhall be intended that the Land whereof, &c. is the Inheritance of the Wife, if the contrary be not ≈øhewed, and therefore if the party will have an e≈øpecial Rever≈øal, he ought to ≈øhew the ≈øpecial matter, as in Engli≈øhes Ca≈øe: A Fine was levyed by Tenant for life, and he in the rever≈øion being within age, bringeth a Writ of Error, now the Fine ≈øhall be rever≈øed as to him in the Rever≈øion, but not as to the Tenant for life, but here it ≈øhall be intended the Inheritance of the Wife, and that the Husband hath nothing but in the right of his Wife, and therefore ≈øhe ≈øhall be re≈øtored
to the whole, for nothing pa≈ø≈øeth from the Husband, but he is named with his Wife only for conformity, 11 H. 7. 19. A. takes to Wife an Inheretrir, who is attainted of Felony, the King ≈øhall not have the Land pre≈øently, by which it appeareth that all is in the Wife, and ≈øhe ≈øhall be re≈øtored to the whole, and the Iudgment ≈øhall be according to the Pre≈øidents cited before: And as to the Pre≈øident cited 7 Eliz. the ≈øame is not to the purpo≈øe, for the ≈øecond Husband was a ≈øtranger to the Fine, for it would be ab≈øurd to rever≈øe the Fine as again≈øt him. Egerton Solicitor General; Pre≈øidents are not ≈øo holy, quod violari non debeant, as to be rules to other Iudges, in perpetuum; and I conceive that the Fine ≈øhall be rever≈øed as to the Wife only, for the Fine is but a Conveyance, and the Husband may lawfully convey the Land of his Wife for his life; and if the Husband alone had levyed the Fine, the ≈øame had bounden the Wife during his life: If a woman Le≈ø≈øee for life taketh to Husband him in the Rever≈øion, and they joyn in a Fine, the Fine ≈øhall ≈øtand as to the Inheritance of the Husband, but ≈øhall be rever≈øed as to the Intere≈øt of the Wife. Coke, it ≈øhall be intended here, all the Intere≈øt and e≈øtate in the Land to be in the Wife, as 20 H. 7. 1. Where the Husband and Wife are vouched, it ≈øhall be intended by rea≈øon of the Warranty of the Wife only, and ≈øo the Counter-plea ≈øhall be of the ≈øei≈øin of the Wife and her Ance≈øtors. Wray, when the Husband and Wife joyn in the Fine, it ≈øhall be pre≈øumed the Inheritance of the Wife, and if it be otherwi≈øe, it ought to be ≈øpecially ≈øhewed; and as to that which hath been ≈øaid, that if the Husband alone had levyed a Fine, it ≈øhould have bounden the Wife during the life of the Husband, the ≈øame is true, but ≈øuch Fine is but a di≈øcontinuance, but the right continueth in the Wife; but when the Husband and Wife joyn in the Fine, all pa≈ø≈øeth out of her, and if the Fine in ≈øuch ca≈øe for the Inheritance ≈øhall be rever≈øed in all, to whom belongs the Free-hold, & to whom ≈øhall he be attendant? Gawdy, 12 H. 7. 1. In a Praecipe quod reddat again≈øt three, they vouch ≈øeverally, the Voucher was not received, and yet they might have ≈øeveral Cau≈øes of Voucher, but the Law pre≈øumes they are Ioynt-tenants, and have a joynt cau≈øe of Voucher, if the contrary be not ≈øhewed: And afterwards Iudgment was given, quod finis predict. rever≈øetur; and Wray ≈øaid he had conferred with many of the other Iu≈øtices, who were of the ≈øame opinion. Gawdy, the Fine ≈øhall be rever≈øed in all, for this is an Error in Law of the Court, F. B. 21. D. For by this Fine the Husband giveth nothing divided from the e≈øtate of the Wife, but all pa≈ø≈øeth from the Wife, and therefore all ≈øhall be rever≈øed, and if the Fine ≈øhould be rever≈øed as to the Wife only, then the Fine levyed now by the Husband alone is a di≈øcontinuance, by which the Wife by the common Law ≈øhall be put to her Cui in vita, and that is not rea≈øon. Al≈øo we cannot by this Rever≈øal, make the Conu≈øee to have a particular e≈øtate during the life of the Wife: And therefore the Fine is to be rever≈øed for the whole, and as void for the whole to the Conu≈øee.

div.head:
CLVIII. Cage and Paxlins Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
1 Cro. 125. 3 Len. 16. DAniel Cage brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Thomas Paxlin for Tre≈øpa≈øs done in a Clo≈øe of Wood, called the Frith-Clo≈øe, and in the Park, and for taking of certain Loads of Wood: the Defendant pleaded, that the Earl of Oxford was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of W. of which the place where, &c. is parcel, and lea≈øed the ≈øame to J. S. for years, excepting all Woods, great Trees, Timber-trees, and Vnderwoods,
&c. And covenanted with the Le≈ø≈øee and his A≈ø≈øigns, that he might take Hedg-boot, and Fire-boot ≈øuper dicta premi≈ø≈øa, and ≈øhewed further, that the ≈øaid I. S. a≈ø≈øigned his Intere≈øt unto the Defendant, and that he came to the ≈øaid Clo≈øe called the Frifth-Clo≈øe, Lea≈øe of Lands excepting the wood and cut the Wood there for Fire-boot, as it was lawful for him to do, &c. And note, that after the Lea≈øe afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid Earl had a≈ø≈øured the Inheritance thereof to Cage the Plaintiff. And it was argued by Godfrey, that the Le≈ø≈øee cannot take Fire-boot in the ≈øaid Clo≈øe, for the wood, &c. is excepted, and was never demi≈øed, and by the exception of the wood, the ≈øoil thereof is excepted: See 46 E. 3. 22. A. lea≈øed for life certain Lands re≈øerving the great wood, by that the ≈øoil al≈øo is re≈øerved, vi. 33 H. 8. Br. Re≈øervation, 39, 28 H. 8. 13.3 Len. 16. And by the words of the Covenant, the intent of the Le≈ø≈øor appeareth, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall have his Fire-boot out of the re≈øidue of the Lands demi≈øed, for praemi≈ø≈øa here is equivalent with praedimi≈ø≈øa: And he cited the Ca≈øe moved by Mountaine cheif Iu≈øtice, 4 E. 6. in Plowden, in the Ca≈øe betwixt Dive and Manningham, 66. A. lea≈øeth unto B. a Manor for years, excepting a Clo≈øe, parcel of it, rendring a Rent, and the Le≈ø≈øee is bounden to perform all Grants, Covenants, and Agreements, contenta & expre≈ø≈øa aut recitata in the Indenture; if the Le≈ø≈øee di≈øturb the Le≈ø≈øor, upon his occupation of the Clo≈øe excepted, he hath forfeited his Obligation, &c. But our Ca≈øe is not like to that:Po≈øt. 122. And if I let the Manor of D. for years, except Green-meadow, and afterwards I covenant that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall enjoy the Premi≈ø≈øes, the ≈øame doth not extend to Green-meadow. Snagg Serjeant to the contrary, and by him praemi≈ø≈øa, are not re≈øtrained to praedimi≈ø≈øa, but to all the Premi≈ø≈øes put in the former part of the Indenture of Demi≈øe, therefore the Le≈ø≈øe ≈øhall have Fire-boot in the one, and the other;2 Roll. 455. 2 Cro. 524. Po≈øt. 122. and he put a difference betwixt all Woods excepted, and all woods growing excepted, for in the one ca≈øe the ≈øoil pa≈ø≈øeth, in the other not; And as to the Ca≈øe cited before in Plowden. 66. that is true, for exception is an Agreement: And he ≈øaid that by that exception the ≈øoil it ≈øelf is excepted, and the≈øe woods which are named by name of woods; contrary where a Clo≈øe containeth part in woods, and part in Pa≈øture; And by the exception of Timber-trees, and Vnder woods, all the other woods are excepted but not the ≈øoil: As if a man grant all his Lands in D. Land, Meadow, Pa≈øture, and woods thereby pa≈ø≈øeth; by exception of this Clo≈øe of wood, the ≈øoil al≈øo is excepted, and he conceived, that although all the woods be excepted, yet by the Covenant an Intere≈øt pa≈ø≈øeth to the Le≈ø≈øee,Select Ca≈øe 155 Hob. 173. Dy. 19, 198, 314. 21 H. 7, 31. More 23. 1 Roll. 939. ≈øo as he may take Fire-boot without being put to his Action of Covenant: As 21 H. 7. 30. A. lea≈øeth unto B. for life, and Covenants in the Indenture of lea≈øe, that he ≈øhall be di≈øpuni≈øhed of Wa≈øt, although the ≈øame be penned by way of Covenant, yet it is a good matter of Bar, being all by one Deed: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, as to that Clo≈øe of wood called Frith-Clo≈øe; but as to the Park, for the Defendant, for that Frifth-Clo≈øe was all excepted, ≈øcil. the wood and the ≈øoil: And the≈øe words, ≈øupra praemi≈ø≈øa, ≈øhall be intended ≈øuch things which were demi≈øed, and no other, and by this Covenant,Dy. 199. Hob. 173. 2 Cro. 172. Bridg. 117. the Le≈ø≈øee hath power to take the wood upon the other Lands, although that the wood be excepted, for the ≈øoile was demi≈øed, and he ≈øhall not be puni≈øhed in Tre≈øpa≈øs, and put to his remedy, by Action of Covenant again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øor: And by Wray, there is not any colour again≈øt the Plaintiff for the Frith-Clo≈øe, if not that the Defendant had averred, that there is not any wood upon the other Lands not excepted but demi≈øed; And this word, Praemi≈ø≈øa, doth not extend by con≈øtruction to this mentioned before, being excepted, but only to the things demi≈øed.

div.head:
CLIX. Rivett and Rivetts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: EDmund Rivett brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Geoge Rivett, and declared, that where it was pretended by the Defendant, that one R. made his Will, and by the ≈øame devi≈øed certain Legacies to the Defendant, and the Plaintiff upon that had ≈øued in the Prerogative Court of Canterbury for to di≈øprove the ≈øaid Will: And if he pro≈øecutus fui≈ø≈øet, he might have di≈øproved the ≈øaid Will, and ≈øo defeated the Defendant of his pretended Legacies:A≈ø≈øump≈øit. Owen 133, 134. The Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff, ultra non procederet, did promi≈øe to give to the Plaintiff one hundred pounds; and averred, that he had ≈øurcea≈øed his ≈øaid ≈øuit; And further declared, that licet the Defendant, ad hoc requi≈øitusfuerit tali die & anno, &c. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that here is not any con≈øideration, for the Defendant hath not any means to compel the Plaintiff for to ≈øurcea≈øe his ≈øuit, for there is not any cro≈øs promi≈øe ≈øet forth in the Declaration; And although that he doth ≈øurcea≈øe his ≈øuit, yet he may begin the ≈øame again, and therefore the Plaintiff ought to have ≈øhewed in his Declaration a Relea≈øe or other di≈øcharge of it, as the ca≈øe was 3 Eliz. reported by Bendloe. A. was bound unto B. in twenty pounds, and afterwards A. promi≈øed B. that in con≈øideration the ≈øaid A. ≈øhould not be damnified by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Bond, to give the ≈øaid B. ten pounds, and upon that promi≈øe B. brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe, and ≈øhewed, that the Defendant was not damnified by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Bond. But it was adjudged, that the Action was not maintainable upon that matter, becau≈øe that the Plaintiff did not ≈øhew in his Declaration, that he had relea≈øed or otherwi≈øe di≈øcharged the Defendant of the ≈øaid Bond, and ≈øo no con≈øideration in the ca≈øe.

Reque≈øt.Another Exception was, becau≈øe the reque≈øt is not layed certainly, but generally, licet requi≈øitus, and doth not ≈øay by whom he was required, or what thing to do: And afterwards a Precedent was ≈øhewed, Trinit. 28 Eliz. rot. 523. betwixt Smith and Smith. An A≈ø≈øump≈øit, in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff ≈øhould not implead the Defendant upon Bond; And the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover. And as to the reque≈øt it ws ≈øaid by Kempe, that there are many Precedents, that a Reque≈øt generally layed is ≈øufficient: And afterwards in the principal Ca≈øe Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CXL. Wheeler and Twogoods Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
WHeeler brought an Ejectione firmae again≈øt Twogood, and it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that the Earl of Oxford was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Hornely, in which were divers Copy-holds: And that the ≈øaid Earl lea≈øed the ≈øaid Manor to one Heywood for one and twenty years, to begin two years after. Except all ca≈øualties and profits of Courts, which ≈øeverally did not pa≈øs the value of ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence. And afterwards the Earl bargained and ≈øold the Rever≈øion to Anthony Cage: And afterwards a compo≈øition was made betwixt Anthony Cage and the Le≈ø≈øee, by which the Le≈ø≈øee did grant and covenant to and with the ≈øaid A. Cage, that he would permit the ≈øaid Anthony Cage peaceably to hold the Courts and to take the profits to his own u≈øe, Provi≈øo, that the ≈øaid Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have the Rents of the Copy-holders & Free-holders: And afterwards the Le≈ø≈øee granted over his Intere≈øt in the
≈øaid Term. It was moved by Tow≈øe, that by this Exception the Court Baron is not excepted nor ≈øevered from the Manor, nor de≈øtroyed,Covenant amounts to a grant. for it is incident to the Manor, and this Covenant betwixt the Le≈ø≈øee and Anthony Cage amounts to a grant of the Court to Anthony Cage. See 44 E. 3. Fitz. Mannors de faits 144 & 29 E. 3. Burr. 280. and ≈øee 37 H. 8. & 1 E. 6. Br. Lea≈øes 60. That where I.S. Covenants, & conce≈ø≈øit to I. N. that he ≈øhall have twenty acres of Land in B. for one and twenty years, it is a good Lea≈øe, for this word conce≈ø≈øit is as ≈øtrong as dimi≈øit. And it was moved, that here the Earl lea≈øed for years to begin two years after, and the Le≈ø≈øee being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, doth continue it after the two years, and afterwards before any entry the Le≈ø≈øee a≈ø≈øignes over his Intere≈øt, that the ≈øame is not a good grant, but only a Right: But by the whole Court the grant was holden good, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Exception: And it was holden al≈øo, that the Covenant (ut ≈øupra) was void; for although that Anthony Cage hath authority to hold the Courts, yet it ought to be in the name of the Le≈ø≈øee.

div.head:
CLXI. Stretton and Taylors Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: STretton did inform again≈øt Taylor upon the Statute of V≈øury:Information upon the Statute of U≈øury. Retraxit by the Queens Attorney ≈øhall not bind the Informer. 1 Cro. 138. & 583. Qui ≈øequitur tam pro Domina Regina, quam pro ≈øeip≈øo: And the Queens Attorney entred upon it, &c. non vult pro≈øequi, and that was pleaded in Bar again≈øt the Informer for the whole: And by Wray, the ≈øame is not any Barr to the Informer. But Popham the Attorney general ≈øaid, that by the favour of the Court he would maintain the authority of his place, which his Predece≈ø≈øors had enjoyed, for he ≈øaid, it cannot be found by any Record in this Court, Common Pleas, or the Exchequer, that the Informer had proceeded where the Attorney General had made ≈øuch an Entry, for we have not u≈øed to do it without great con≈øideration; for if the Informer hath cea≈øed to pro≈øecute the Suit two or three Terms, then we u≈øed to enter a Non vult pro≈øequi. For it is not rea≈øon that the Subject ≈øhould be mole≈øted or attendant ≈øo long without ju≈øt cau≈øe, and it is not again≈øt Law, that in per≈øonal Suits the act of one ≈øhould prejudice the other: And the Queen is the principal party in this Suit, for the Replication ≈øhall be made in the name of the Queen only, and not of the Informer. And afterwards by Award of the Court it was ruled, that that Entry by the Attorney is not any Barr, quoad the Informer, ≈øo if the Queen be Non≈øuit, ≈øo the Non≈øuit of the Informer is no Barr again≈øt the Queen: And Wray ≈øaid, that ≈øuch was the opinions of Ander≈øon and Gawdy Iu≈øtices, &c.

div.head:
CLXII. The Queen again≈øt Lewis, Green, and others.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Intrat. Hill. 30 Eliz. Rot. 10.
div.p:
AN Information for the Queen again≈øt Lewis, Green, and others:Grants of the King. 2 Roll. 51. 1 Co. 46. The Ca≈øe was, King E. 6. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Stepneth, and twenty acres of Lands in Stepneth, called Stepneth Mar≈øh, and of another Mar≈øh al≈øo called Stepneth Mar≈øh, and granted unto the Lord Wentworth and his Heirs the Manor of Stepneth, in the County of Midd. Nec non mari≈øcam in Stepneth, appel. Stepneth Mar≈øh in com. praedict. nec non omnia terr. & ten. eidem Manerio five premi≈ø≈øis pertinent. And if twenty Acres, called Stepneth Mar≈øh, not parcel of the ≈øaid Manor pa≈øs, or not, was the Que≈øtion: Cook,
that they ≈øhall pa≈øs: Here this grant doth con≈øi≈øt of three parts; 1. The grant of the Manor; 2. Nec non mari≈øcum in Stepneth; 3. Nec non omnia terras & tenementa dicto Manerio ≈øive praemi≈ø≈øis pertinen. And by the ≈øecond clau≈øe the≈øe twenty acres ≈øhall pa≈øs, be the ≈øame parcel or not; and the latter words cannot refer to that, for it is certainly expre≈ø≈øed before. And the ca≈øe lately agreed in the Court of Wards betwixt Bronker and Robotham was cited, which was, That the King being ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Sandridge and Newnam, parcel of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Mona≈øtery of Saint Albans, and part of the Manor of Newnam extended into the Pari≈øh of Sandridge, and the King granted the Manor of Sandridge, nec non omnia terras & tenementa ≈øua in Sandridge, dicto nuper Mona≈øterio pertinen. nec non omnia terras & tenementa ≈øua dicto Manerio de Sandridge pertinen. By which grant, although that the latter clau≈øe doth re≈øtrain it to the Manor of Sandridge, yet the general words of the ≈øecond clau≈øe ≈øhall extend to make pa≈øs all the whole Manor of Newnam, which extended into the Pari≈øh of Sandridge, & a Decree was in the ≈øaid Court accordingly.

Hob. 175. 303. Dy. 207. 6 Co. 39.At another day the ca≈øe was argued, and the ca≈øe put to be thus. King E. 6. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Hackney and Stepneth in the County of Midd. within which was a great Mar≈øh, called Stepneth Mar≈øh, parcel of the Manor of Stepneth, which the King had by exchange of the Bi≈øhop of London, and there were al≈øo twenty acres of Lands which were lying in Stepneth Mar≈øh, and were known by the name of Stepney Mar≈øh, late parcel of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Priory of Grace, and granted unto the Lord Wentworth and his Heirs, Dominia ≈øive Maneria ≈øua de Hackney & Stepney, nec non mari≈øcos ≈øuos de Stepney in Stepney praedict. nec non omnia Maneria terras & tenem. & mari≈øcos dictis Maneriis aut caeteris praemi≈ø≈øis pertinen. If the≈øe twenty acres pa≈øs in the general words in the fir≈øt Nec non, or if the words in the ≈øecond Nec non (dictis Maneriis pertinen.) doth re≈øtrain the generality of the fir≈øt words, was the que≈øtion: And by Phillips the twenty acres do not pa≈øs, for the grant of the King ≈øhall be always taken to a common intent: And becau≈øe here the King hath the≈øe Mar≈øhes by ≈øeveral titles, that Mar≈øh only ≈øhall pa≈øs, which by general entendment ≈øhall be intended to pa≈øs, ≈øcil. the great Mar≈øh, which was in truth parcel of the Manor of Stepney, and not the twenty acres which the King hath by a ≈øpecial title, although, that ex vi termini, the grant may extend unto it: Al≈øo the grant of the King ≈øhall be taken, ≈øecundum intentionem Regis, Grants of the King taken according to his intent. and not in deceptionem; and here it appearth, that the intent of the King was not, that the≈øe twenty acres ≈øhould pa≈øs, i. the King grants Maneria ≈øua & terras, and all Lands, &c. ii≈ødem pertinen. but it is not part of any thing pertinen. to tho≈øe twenty acres, therefore his intent was not to pa≈øs them. Secondly, the grant is to have them as fully as the Bi≈øhop of London had them, without mentioning of the Prior. Thirdly, as fully as the Bi≈øhop had granted them to us, but the Bi≈øhop had not granted the≈øe twenty acres to the King. Fourthly, in the Letters Patents the King recites the value of the Manor of Hackney and Stepney, but no value of the twenty acres, (Quaere, what difference there is betwitxt Stepney Mar≈øh and the Mar≈øh of Stepny.) As to the fir≈øt, the grant is ii≈ødem & ita praemi≈ø≈øis pertinen. which word praemi≈ø≈øis includes the premi≈ø≈øes or otherwi≈øe ≈øhould be void: Secondly, the words, as the Bi≈øhop had, and as amply as we have from the Bi≈øhop, are ≈øuplu≈øage, & nihil operatur by them. And if the King had not the ≈øame of the Bi≈øhop it is not material, but they ≈øhall pa≈øs notwith≈øtanding, becau≈øe by a ≈øpecial name: As if the King grants to me Manerium de Dale, quod √† nobis nuper concelat. fuit, and in truth it ws not concealed, yet it ≈øhall pa≈øs by his ≈øpecial name: But if the grant had been, Provi≈øo, that if the ≈øaid Manor were concealed, &c. the ≈øame had been good, for it is good by way of Provi≈øo, but not by reference. As to the valuation the ≈øame is not material, for who can re≈øtrain the bounty of the King. 29 E. 3. 7. and 8. The King granted omnes Advocationes
pertinend. to ≈øuch a Priory, quas nuper conce≈ø≈øimus patri of the Patentee, although the King had not ever made ≈øuch a grant, yet it is a good grant to the Sons, cau≈øa qua ≈øupra. Gawdy Iu≈øtice conceived, that the twenty acres did pa≈øs, and he confe≈ø≈øed the ca≈øe betwixt Bronkor and Robotham to be good Law, for there the intention is fully, that all appertaining to the Mona≈øtery, whether it were parcel of the Mannor of Newnam or of Sandridge, pa≈ø≈øeth, 6 E. 6. 8. Dyer. A man lea≈øeth all his Meadows in A. containing ten acres, whereas in truth they are twenty acres, all pa≈ø≈øeth, &c. And if the King grant the Manor of D. to A; and further ≈øaith, Damus & concedimus, ≈øo freely as I. S. had it, and I. S. never had it, yet the grant is good: And as to the mi≈ørecital of the value, the ≈øame is helped by the Statute. Clench Iu≈øtice to the ≈øame intent; and the Iury hath found, that the twenty acres are parcel of Stepney Mar≈øh. Wray to the ≈øame intent, Again≈øt expre≈øs words no favour ≈øhall be given to the King. And note, that the Mar≈øhes pertaining to the Manor are in the third clau≈øe, ergo, the Mar≈øh in the ≈øecond clau≈øe ≈øhall be intended a Mar≈øh in gro≈øs, or otherwi≈øe it ≈øhould be idle. And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Queen.

div.head:
CLXIII. Piers and Lever≈øuchs Ca≈øe In Ejectione firmae.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IT was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that one Robert Lever≈øuch Grand-father of the Defendant, was Tenant in tail of certain Lands, whereof, &c. and made a Lea≈øe for years to one Pur. who a≈ø≈øigned it over to P. father of the Plaintiff. Robert Lever≈øuch died: W. his Son and Heir entred upon P. who re-entred. W. demi≈øed without other words the Land to the ≈øaid P. for life, the remainder to Joan his Wife for life, the remainder to the Son of P. for life with warranty, and made a Letter of Attorney therein to enter and deliver ≈øei≈øin accordingly. P. died before that the Livery was executed, and afterwards the Attorney made livery to Joan. W. died; Ed. his Son and Heir entred upon the Wife, ≈øhe re-entred, and lea≈øed to the Plaintiff, who upon an ou≈øter brought the Action. Heale. When P. entred upon W. Lever≈øuch the i≈ø≈øue in tail, he was a di≈ø≈øei≈øor, and by his death the Land de≈øcending to his Heir, the entry of W. Lever≈øuch, the i≈ø≈øue in tail, was taken away.3 Cro. 222. Cook contrary. P. by his entry was not a di≈ø≈øei≈øor, but at the Election of W. for when P. accepted ≈øuch a deed from W. it appeareth that his intent was not to enter as a di≈ø≈øei≈øor; and it is not found that the ≈øaid P. had any Son and Heir at the time of his death, and if not, then no de≈øcent; and there is not any di≈ø≈øei≈øin found that P. expulit Lever≈øuch out of the Land. And Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff. And Cook cited a Ca≈øe which was adjudged in the Common Pleas, and it was the Ca≈øe of Shipwith; Grand-father, Tenant in tail, Father and Son; The Grand-father died, the Father entred and paid the Rent to the Le≈ø≈øor, and died in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and adjudged, that it was not any de≈øcent, for the paying of the Rent doth explain by what title he entred, and ≈øo he ≈øhall not be a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor but at the Election of another.

div.head:
CLXIV. Severn and Clerks Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: ‚Ä¢ ts.THe Ca≈øe was, that A. by his Deed Poll recited, That (whereas he was) po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of certain Lands for years of a certain Term; By good and lawful conveyance he a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øame to I. S. with divers Covenants, Articles and Agreements in the ≈øaid deed contained, which are or ought to be performed on his part. It was moved, if this recital (whereas he was) be an Article or Agreement within the meaning of the condition of the ≈øaid Obligation, which was given to perform, &c. Gawdy conceived, that it is an agreement: For in ≈øuch ca≈øe I agree, that I am po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of it, for every thing contained in the deed is an Agreement, and not only that which I am bound to perform: As if I recite by my deed, that I am po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of ≈øuch an intere≈øt in certain Land, and a≈ø≈øign it over by the ≈øame deed, and thereby covenant to perform all Agreements in the deed, if I be not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of ≈øuch Intere≈øt, the covenant is broken. And it was moved, if that recital be within the≈øe words of the condition (which are or ought to be performed on my part.) And ≈øome were of opinion, that it is not within tho≈øe words; for that extends only in futurum, but this recital is of a thing pa≈øt, or at the lea≈øt pre≈øent.

Recital. 2 Cro. 281. Yyl. 206. Clench. Recital of it ≈øelf is nothing, but being joyned and con≈øidered with the re≈øt of the deed it is material, as here, for again≈øt this recital he cannot ≈øay that he hath not any thing in the Term. And at the length, it was clearly re≈øolved, that if the party had not that Intere≈øt by a good and lawful conveyance the Obligation was forfeited.

div.head:
CLXV. Page and Jourdens Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Trepa≈øs betwixt Page and Jourden the ca≈øe was: A Woman Tenant in tail took a Husband, who made a Feoffment in Fee and died. The Wife without any Entry made a Lea≈øe for years: It was moved, that the making of this Lea≈øe is an Entry in Law. As if A. make a Lea≈øe for years of the Land of B. who enters by force of that Lea≈øe,A general entry amounts to a di≈ø≈øei≈øin. now the Le≈ø≈øor without any Entry is a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor. And it was re≈øolved, that by that Lea≈ø ‚Ä¢ , the Free-hold is not reduced without an Entry.

div.head:
CLXVI. Havithlome and Harvies Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Action upon the Statute of 5 Eliz. cap. 9. 1 Cro. 130. 3 Cro. Goodwin. ver≈ø. We≈øt. HAvithlome brought an Action upon the Statute of 5 Eliz. cap. 9. again≈øt Harvy and his Wife for the penalty of ten pounds given by the ≈øaid Statute again≈øt him who was ≈øerved with proce≈øs, ad te≈øtificandum, &c. and doth not appear, not having any impediment, &c. and ≈øhewed that proce≈øs was ≈øerved upon the Defendants Wife, and ≈øufficient charges, having regard to her degree and the di≈øtance of the place, &c. tendred to her, and yet ≈øhe did not appear. And it was found for the Plaintiff. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that the Declaration is not good, becau≈øe the Plaintiff in ≈øetting forth that he was damaged for the not appearance of the Wife according to the proce≈øs, hath not ≈øhewed how damnified: Al≈øo it was moved, that a Feme
Covert is not within the ≈øaid Statute, for no mention is made of a Feme Covert, and therefore upon the Statute of We≈øt. 2. cap. 25. If a Feme Covert fail of her Record, ≈øhe ≈øhall not be holden di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øere≈øs, nor impri≈øoned. Al≈øo here the Declaration is, that the Plaintiff tendered the charges to the Wife where he ought to have tendered the ≈øame to the Husband.

To the≈øe three Exceptions it was an≈øwered. 1. That although the party be not at all damnified, yet the penalty is forfeited. 2. Feme Coverts are within the ≈øaid Statute, otherwi≈øe it ≈øhould be a great mi≈øcheif, for it might be that ≈øhe might be the only witne≈øs: And Feme Coverts, if they had not been expre≈øly excepted, had been within the Statute of 4 H. 7. of Fines. 3. The wife ought to appear, therefore the tender ought to be to her: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLXVII. Dellaby and Ha≈ø≈øels Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe,1 Cro. 132. the Plaintiff declared that the Defendant in con≈øideration that he had retained the Plaintiff to go from London to Paris to Merchandize diver≈øe goods to the profit of the Defendant, promi≈øed to give to him ≈øo much as ≈øhould content him, and al≈øo to give him all and every ≈øum of money which he ≈øhould expend there in his Affairs; and further declared, that he was contented to have twenty-pounds for his labour, which the Defendant refu≈øed to pay: And exception was taken to the Declaration, becau≈øe there is not ≈øet down any place or time of the notification of his contentment, for the ≈øame is traver≈øable. Gawdy, The I≈ø≈øue here is, non A≈ø≈øump≈øit; A≈ø≈øump≈øit. and therefore that matter is out of the Book. Cook, If one a≈ø≈øume to pay twenty pounds to another upon reque≈øt, although the Defendant plead, non A≈ø≈øump≈øit, yet if the place and time of reque≈øt be not ≈øhewed, Iudgment many times hath been ≈øtayed, for no Action without a Reque≈øt; ≈øo here without notification of his contentment, no Action, therefore he ought to ≈øhew it. Gawdy, The ground of this Action is the A≈ø≈øump≈øit, but that cannot be certain without Declaration, and thereof notice ought to be given to make certainty of the duty, but not to enforce the promi≈øe; but in our ca≈øe, without a Reque≈øt A≈ø≈øump≈øit will not lye; But here it being but conveyance, the certainty of the time and place is not nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øhewed, but the general form ≈øhall ≈øerve, for it is but inducement: As if a man will plead a devi≈øe of goods to him, and a≈ø≈øent of the Executors to take them, he need not to ≈øhew the time and place of the a≈ø≈øent. Gawdy, at another day, ≈øaid that Iudgment ought to be given for the Plaintiff; the A≈ø≈øump≈øit is the ground and cau≈øe of the Action, and the ≈øhewing of the contentment is only to reduce the Action to certainty: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLXVIII. Musket and Coles Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
WIlliam Musket brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Cole, 1 Cro. 13. and declared that in con≈øideration, that the Plaintiff had payed unto the Defendant forty ≈øhillings, for the Debt of Symon his Son, the Defendant promi≈øed to deliver to him, omnes tales billas & Obligationes, in which his Son was bounden to him; which thing he would not do, and it was found by Verdict for the Plaintiff: And it was moved for ≈øtay of Iudgment, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had not averred in his Declaration,
that the ≈øaid Defendant had Bills or Obligations, in which Simon his Son was bounden to the Defendant,Averment. for if there were none, then no damage. And ≈øee Onlies Ca≈øe, 19 Eliz. Dyer 356. D. in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff had expended divers ≈øums of money circa the bu≈øine≈ø≈øes of the Defendant, promi≈øed, &c. Exception was taken to that Declaration by Manwood and Moun≈øon Iu≈øtices, becau≈øe it was not ≈øhewed, in what bu≈øine≈ø≈øes certain, and betwixt what per≈øons. Gawdy, The Plaintiff here is not to recover the Bills or Obligations, but damages only, and therefore needeth not to alledge any Bills in certain. And 47 E. 3. 3. A. covenants with B. to a≈ø≈øure unto B. and his Heirs, omnia terras & tenementa quas habet in ≈øuch Counties, and for not a≈ø≈øurance, an Action of Covenant was brought, and the Plaintiff declared, that the Defendant had broken the ≈øaid Covenant, and that he had required the Defendant to make a Feoffment unto him of all his Lands and Tenements in the ≈øaid Counties; and the plea was not allowed, for the Land is not in demand, but only damages to be recovered. See al≈øo 46 E. 3. 4. and 20 E. 3. And in the principal ca≈øe, the Plaintiff had time enough for the ≈øhewing to the Iury what Bills or Obligations for the in≈øtructing of the Iury of the damages.

div.head:
CLXIX. Engli≈øh, and Pellitary and Smiths Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A≈ø≈øault and Battery. 1 Cro. 139, 140.IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs of A≈ø≈øault and Battery and wounding: The Defendants ≈øay, that they were Le≈ø≈øees of certain Lands, and the Plaintiff came to the ≈øaid Lands, and took certain Po≈øts which were upon the Lands, and they gently took them from him. S. pleaded, that he found the Plaintiff and P. contending for the ≈øaid Po≈øts, and he to part them mollite, put his hands upon the Plaintiff; which is the ≈øame, &c. The Plaintiff replyed, De injuriis ≈øuis propriis ab≈øque tali cau≈øa per ip≈øos P. & S. allegat. upon which i≈ø≈øue was joyned, which was found for the Plaintiff. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that here was not any i≈ø≈øue, for the Plaintiff ought ≈øeverally to reply to both pleas afore≈øaid, for here are ≈øeveral Cau≈øes of Iu≈øtification, and his Replication, ab≈øque tali cau≈øa, Nomen Collectivum. Po≈øt. 139. Dy. 182. doth not an≈øwer to both. Cook, This word (Cau≈øa) is, nomen Collectivum, which may be referred to every Cau≈øe by the Defendants alledged, reddendo ≈øingula ≈øingulis, and their Iu≈øtifications are but one matter, and the Defendants might have all joyned in one plea. Wray, Both pleas depend upon one matter, but are ≈øeveral cau≈øes; for two ju≈øtifie by rea≈øon of their Intere≈øt, and the third for the pre≈øervation of the Peace. And by him and the whole Court, although it be not a good form of pleading, yet by rea≈øonable con≈øtruction this word (Cau≈øe) ≈øhall be referred to every cau≈øe, and ≈øo the pleading ≈øhall be maintained: And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLXX. Cater and Boothes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30. Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Intrat. Hill. 30 Rot. 58. or 581.
div.p:
IF a Writ of Covenant the Plaintiff declared, that the Defendant by his deed, bearing date the fir≈øt of October, 28 Eliz. did covenant, that he would do every act and acts at his be≈øt endeavour to prove the Will of I. S. or otherwi≈øe,Covenant. that he would procure Letters of Admini≈øtration, by which he might convey ≈øuch a Term lawfully to the Plaintiff, which he had not done, licet ≈øaepius requi≈øitus, &c. The Defendant pleaded that he came to Doctor Drury into the Court of the Arches, and there
offered to prove the Will of the ≈øaid I. S. but becau≈øe the Wife of the ≈øaid I.S. would not ≈øwear, that it was the Will of her Husband, they could not be received to prove it; Vpon which it was demurred in Law. It was moved by Williams, that the Action doth not lie, for there is no time limited by the Covenant when the thing ≈øhould be done by the Defendant, for which he hath time during his life, for as much as it is a collateral thing. See 15 E. 4. 31. if there be not a Reque≈øt before; but admit that the Covenant had been to perform upon reque≈øt,Reque≈øt. then the Plaintiff in his Declaration ought to have ≈øhewed an expre≈øs reque≈øt with the place and time of it, for that is traver≈øable. See 33 H. 6. 47, 48. 9 E. 4. 22. Gawdy, If the Covenant had been eypre≈øly to do it upon reque≈øt, there the reque≈øt ought to be ≈øhewed ≈øpecially: But when a thing upon the expo≈øition of the Law only is to be done upon Reque≈øt, ≈øuch Reque≈øt alledged generally is good enough. And by Wray, the Covenantor hath not time during his life to perform this Covenant, but he ought to do it upon reque≈øt within convenient time; but in ≈øome ca≈øe a man ≈øhall have time during his life, as where no benefit ≈øhall be to any of the parties, as if the condition were to go to Rome: And as to the Reque≈øt, he conceived, that it ought to be ≈øhewed ≈øpecially and certainly; for it is for the benefit of the Covenantee, for without reque≈øt, the Action doth not lie, which Clench granted. And it was holden by the whole Court, that the bar ≈øhall not help the in≈øufficient Declaration: No more, if the Defendant plead, Non A≈ø≈øump≈øit, yet the defect in the Declaration of a Reque≈øt not duly ≈øhewed, remaineth. Gawdy, The bringing of the Action is a Reque≈øt. Clench, A Writ of Debt is a Praecipe, for which there, licet ≈øaepius requi≈øitus, is ≈øufficient; but a Writ of Covenant is not ≈øo.

div.head:
CLXXI. Piers and Hoes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, it was found by ≈øpecial verdict,Tre≈øpa≈øs. 1 Cro. 131. 1 Roll. 854. that A. ≈øei≈øed of Land in the right of his Wife, being her Ioynture by a former Husband, he and his Wife made a Feoffment to a ≈øtranger and his Heirs, Habend. to the u≈øe of the ≈øtranger and his Heirs during the life of the Wife only. Shutleworth, The ≈øame is a forfeiture, for if the ≈øame Feoffment had been without any u≈øe expre≈ø≈øed,Forfeiture. then it ≈øhould be to the u≈øe of the Feoffor and his Heirs, and by con≈øequence a forfeiture; and as the ca≈øe is here, it is al≈øo a forfeiture, for during the life of the Wife the u≈øe is expre≈øly to the u≈øe of the Feoffee and his Heirs, and the remainder of the Fee-≈øimple is to the u≈øe of the Feoffor, ≈øcil. the Husband and his Heirs. Popham, I conceive that here is a forfeiture,Owen 64. 2 Cr. 200, 201. 3 Cr. 167. Hob. 373. for here are ≈øeveral limitations, limitation of the e≈øtate unto one, and of the u≈øe unto another: And the words (for the life of the Wife) do not refer to the e≈øtate, but to the u≈øe, with proximum antecedens; And he re≈øembled the ≈øame to the ca≈øe of Leonard Sturton, in which he was of Councel. A man granted Lands, Habend. unto the Grantee, to the u≈øe of the Grantee, and the Heirs of his body; the ≈øame is no e≈øtate tail in the Grantee, but only an e≈øtate for life, for the Limitation of the u≈øe cannot extend the e≈øtate. Cook contrary. The ca≈øe is, that A. Wife of one Piers, being Tenant for life of the Ioynture of the ≈øaid Piers, took to Husband Hoe, they both by Deed grant totum ≈øuum Me≈ø≈øuagium to one Clarke, Habendum to him and his Heirs for the life of the Wife only, I conceive, that here is not any forfeiture, for it is but one intire ≈øentence: And if there be a double con≈øtruction of a deed, that which is mo≈øt rea≈øonable ≈øhall be taken, ≈øo as wrong be not done,Con≈øtruction of Deeds. and therefore the≈øe words (for the life of the Wife) ≈øhall refer unto both, ≈øcil. the e≈øtate and the u≈øe, and their intent was not to commit a forfeiture, as appeareth by the words of the Deed,
for they grant ≈øolum me≈ø≈øuagium, and that was not but for the life of the wife ad ≈øolum u≈øum of the Feoffee and his Heirs, during the life of the Wife, and violence ≈øhould be offered to this word (≈øolum) if the Feoffee or his Heirs, ≈øhould have ultra the life of the Wife; and the word (tantum) cannot otherwi≈øe be expounded, but that the e≈øtate for life only ≈øhall pa≈øs from them: And he cited the Ca≈øe of 34 E. 3. Avowry 258. A. gives Lands unto B. in tail, and for default of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, to the u≈øe of C. in tail, rendring Rent, the ≈øame render ≈øhall go to both the e≈øtates: So a Lea≈øe for life to A. the remainder to B. to the u≈øe of C. the ≈øame u≈øe goeth out of both the e≈øtates, and not only out of the Remainder; ≈øo here upon the ≈øame rea≈øon,Regula. the≈øe words, for the life of the wife, ≈øhall refer to the fir≈øt e≈øtate, as well as to the u≈øe; And in ≈øuch Ca≈øes the rule of Bracton ought to be ob≈øerved, viz. Benignae faciendae ≈øunt interpretationes verborum, ut res magis valeat, quam pereat. As the Ca≈øe in 6 H. 7. 7. in a Ce≈ø≈øavit, the Plaintiff counted, that the Tenant held by Homage, Fealty, Sute at Court, and certain Rent, and in the doing of the ≈øervices afore≈øaid, the Defendant had ce≈ø≈øed, and in not doing of Homage and Fealty, a man cannot ce≈ø≈øe by two years; But it was holden that the ≈øaid Ce≈ø≈øavit ≈øhould be referred to ≈øuch ≈øervices only, in which one might cea≈øe, and that is Sute of Court, and Rent; And if pleadings ≈øhall have ≈øuch favourable con≈øtruction, a multo fortiori, ≈øhall a Deed, 4 E. 3. Wa≈øt. 11. A man lea≈øed for life, and by the ≈øame deed granted power unto the Le≈ø≈øee, to take and make his profit of the ≈øaid Lands, in the be≈øt manner ≈øhould ≈øeem good to him without contradiction of the Le≈ø≈øor or his Heirs; yet by tho≈øe words it is not lawful for him to do wa≈øt, for there it is ≈øaid, that in con≈øtruction of Deeds, we ought to judge according to that intent, which is according to Law and Rea≈øon, and not to that which is again≈øt rea≈øon: See 17 E. 3. 7. accordingly, ≈øo in the principal Ca≈øe, the words in the Deed of Feoffment ≈øhall be ≈øo expounded, that the e≈øtate be ≈øaved and not de≈øtroyed.

Popham contrary, The Ca≈øes put by Coke are not like to the Ca≈øe in que≈øtion; For where the Rent is out of both e≈øtates the ≈øame is but rea≈øon, for the Rent is in re≈øpect of the Land, and becau≈øe he departs with both e≈øtates, it is rea≈øon the Rent i≈ø≈øue out of both; and the like rea≈øon is of the Ca≈øe of an u≈øe, for if a man makes a Lea≈øe for life to A. the Remainder over to B. the ≈øame ≈øhall be to their u≈øe re≈øpectively, and if he do expre≈øs the u≈øe, the ≈øame ≈øhall be accordingly, and ≈øhall bind both e≈øtates, but there Clark hath two e≈øtates, one by the common Law, and the other by the Statute;3 Cro. 167. But the words ≈øub≈øequent (for the life of the wife only) cannot refer to both e≈øtates: A. gives Lands to one & his Heirs for forty years, the ≈øame is but a plain Term for years: But if a Feoffment in Fee be made to one & his Heirs to the u≈øe of another for forty years, there the Fee pa≈ø≈øeth to the Feoffee, and the Term to Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe. Gawdy conceived, that it is not any forfeiture, for the≈øe words (during the life of the wife only) were put in the Deed to expre≈øs the intent of the parties, and therefore the ≈øame ≈øhall not be void; and he conceived that they were put in, to exclude the forfeiture, and therefore they ≈øhall ≈øerve for that purpo≈øe. And afterwards it was re≈øolved by all the Iu≈øtices except Gawdy, that it was a forfeiture, for by the Feoffment the Fee-≈øimple pa≈ø≈øeth, and that to the u≈øe of the Feoffor; & the e≈øtate, and the u≈øe are ≈øeveral things, and the limitation for the life of the Wife cannot extend to both: And as to the Book of 24 H. 8. Br. Forfeiture 87.3 Cro. 167, 168. Tenant for life aliens in Fee to B. Habendum ≈øibi & haeredibus ≈øuis, for Term of the life of the Tenant for life, the ≈øame is not a forfeiture, for the whole is but the limitation of the e≈øtate: And afterwards it was adjudged that it was a forfeiture, Gawdy continuing in his former opinion: And VVray ≈øaid that he had conferred with the other Iudges of their Hou≈øe, and they all held clearly, that it is a forfeiture.

div.head:
CLXXII. Toft and Tompkins Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Rot. 528.
div.p: UPon a ≈øpecial Verdict the ca≈øe was, that the Grand-father, Tenant for life, the Remainder to the Father in tail,Di≈øcontinuance. 1 Cro. 135. that the Grand-father made a Feoffment in fee to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, the Remainder to the Father in Fee; And afterwards they both came upon the Land, and made a Feoffment to Tompkins the Defendant. Coke, There is not any di≈øcontinuance upon this matter, for the Father might well wave the advantage of the forfeiture committed by the Grand-father; then when the Father joyns with the Grand-father in a Feoffment, the ≈øame declares that he came upon the Land, without intent to enter for a forfeiture: It was one Waynmans Ca≈øe, adjudged in the common Pleas, where the Di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øee cometh upon the Land to deliver a Relea≈øe to the Di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øor, that the ≈øame is no Entry to reve≈øt the Land in the Di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øee: Then here it is the Livery of the Tenant for life, and the grant of him in the Remainder, and he in the Remainder here was never ≈øei≈øed by force of the tail, and ≈øo no di≈øcontinuance. Godfrey, Here is a Remitter by the Entry, and afterwards a di≈øcontinuance, for by the Entry of both, the Law ≈øhall adjudge the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in him who hath right, &c. Gawdy, This is a di≈øcontinuance, for when the Father entreth, ut ≈øupra, he ≈øhall be adjudged in by the forfeiture, and then he hath gained a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øo a di≈øcontinuance, for both cannot have the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Clench, The intent of him in the Remainder when he entred was to joyn with the Grand-father, and when his intent appeareth, that the e≈øtate of the Grand-father, and his own al≈øo ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe, that doth declare that he would not enter for the forfeiture: Shute agreed with Gawdy.

div.head: CLXXIII. Broake and Doughties Ca≈øe. Hill. 31 Eliz. Rot. 798. Trin. 30. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
AN Action upon the Ca≈øe for words,Action upon the Ca≈øe for words. 1 Cro. 135. viz. Thou wa≈øt for≈øworn in the Court of Reque≈øts, and I will make thee ≈øtand upon a Stage for it: It was found for the Plaintiff. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that the Action will not lye for the≈øe words, for he doth not ≈øay, that he was there for≈øworn as Defendant, or witne≈øs: And Trin. 28 Eliz. betwixt Hern and Hex, thou wa≈øt for≈øworn in the Court of Whitchurch; And Iudgment given again≈øt the Plaintiff, for the words are not Actionable, and as to the re≈øidue of the words, I will make thee ≈øtand upon the Stage for it, they are not Actionable, as it was adjudged between Rylie and Trowgood, If thou had≈øt Iu≈øtice thou had≈øt ≈øtood on the Pillory; and Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff. Daniel contrary, thou wa≈øt for≈øworn before my Lord chief Iu≈øtice in an Evidence, the≈øe words are Actionable, for that is perjury upon the matter, and between Fo≈øter and Thorne, T. 23 Eliz. Rot. 882. Thou wa≈øt fal≈øly for≈øworn in the Star-Chamber, the Plaintiff had Iudgment, for it ≈øhall be intended that the Plaintiff was Defendant or a Deponent there: And yet the words in the Declaration are not in the Court of Star-Chamber. Wray, Thou art worthy to ≈øtand upon the Pillory, are not Actionable, for it is but an implication; but in the words in the Ca≈øe at the Bar there is a vehement intendment, that his Oath was in the quality of a Defendant, or Deponent; which Gawdy granted. In the Ca≈øe 28 Eliz. Thou wa≈øt for≈øworn in Whit-Church
Court, there the words are not actionable; for that Court is not known to you as Iudges. And it may be it is but a great Hou≈øe or Man≈øion hou≈øe called Whit-church Court: But here in the principal ca≈øe it cannot be meant but a Court of Iu≈øtice, and before the Iudges there juridice, and the ≈øub≈øequent words ≈øound ≈øo much, I will make thee ≈øtand upon a Stage for it. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLXXIV. Gatefould and Penns Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Pre≈øcription for tythes. 1 Cro. 136. 3 Len. 203, 265. Antea. 94. GAtefould Par≈øon of North-linne libelled again≈øt Penne in the ≈øpiritual Court for tythes in Kind of certain pa≈øtures: The Defendant to have prohibition doth ≈øurmi≈øe, that he is Inhabitant of South-linne, and that time out of mind, &c. every Inhabitant of South-linne, having pa≈øtures in North-linne hath paid tythes in Kind for them unto the Vicars of South-linne, where he is not re≈øident, and the Vicar hath al≈øo time out of mind payed to the Par≈øon of North-linne for the time being two pence for every acre. Lewis, This ≈øurmi≈øe is not ≈øufficient to have a prohibition, for upon that matter Modus Decimandi ≈øhall never come in que≈øtion, but only the right of tythes, if they belong to the Par≈øon of North-linne, or to the Vicar of South-linne, and he might have pleaded this matter in the ≈øpiritual Court, becau≈øe it toucheth the right of tythes, as it was certified in the Ca≈øe of Ba≈øhly by the Doctors of the Civil Law. Gawdy, This pre≈øcription doth ≈øtand with rea≈øon, for ≈øuch benefit hath the Par≈øon of North-linne, if any Inhabitant there hath any Pa≈øtures in South-linne. And afterwards the whole Court was again≈øt the prohibition, for Modus Decimandi ≈øhall never come in debate upon this matter, but who ≈øhall have the tythes, the Vicar of South-linne, or the Par≈øon of North-linne? and al≈øo the pre≈øcription is not rea≈øonable.

div.head: CLXXV. Gomer≈øal and Bi≈øhops Ca≈øe. Hill. 31 Eliz. Rot. 175. Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 136. BI≈øhop libelled in the Spiritual Court for tythe Hay; the Plaintiff Gomer≈øal made a ≈øurmi≈øe, that there was an agreement betwixt the ≈øaid parties, and for the yearly ≈øum of ≈øeven ≈øhillings to be paid by Gomer≈øal unto Bi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop faithfully promi≈øed to Gomer≈øal, that Gomer≈øal ≈øhould have the tythes of the ≈øaid Land during his life. And upon an Attachment upon a Prohibition Gomer≈øal declared, that for the ≈øaid annual ≈øum Bi≈øhop lea≈øed to the Plaintiff the ≈øaid tythes for his life: And upon the Declaration Bi≈øhop did demur in Law for the variance between the Surmi≈øe and the Declaration; for in the Surmi≈øe a promi≈øe is ≈øuppo≈øed, for which Gomer≈øal might have an Action upon the Ca≈øe, and in the Declaration a Lea≈øe. But note, that the Surmi≈øe was not entred in the Roll, but was recorded by it ≈øelf, and the Declaration only enrolled. Godfrey, It was re≈øolved in the Ca≈øe betwixt Pendleton and Hunt, Prohibition for tythes. that an Agreement betwixt the Par≈øon and any of his Pari≈øhioners is a good cau≈øe to grant a Prohibition, if he libel in the Spiritual Court again≈øt ≈øuch Agreement, becau≈øe the Spiritual Court cannot try it, and they will not allow ≈øuch Plea. Curia, The Surmi≈øe is as a Writ, for which if variance be betwixt the ≈øame and the Declaration all his naught.

div.head: CLXXVI. Colebourn and Mix≈øtones Ca≈øe. Intrat. Hill. 31. Eliz. Rot. 146. Trin. 30. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
COlebourn was ≈øued in the Spiritual Court, for that being Executor to one Alice Leigh, he had not brought in a true Inventory of all the goods of the ≈øaid Alice, but had omitted and left out a lea≈øe of two hou≈øes, and this ≈øuit was at the pur≈øuit of two Daughters of the Te≈øtator. Colebourn ≈øueth for a Prohibition; and ≈øurmi≈øes and declares, how this Lea≈øe is extinct, and the matter was this, H. Leigh was ≈øei≈øed of a hou≈øe called the Marigold, and two other hou≈øes in London, and lea≈øed the ≈øaid two hou≈øes to one Alice Cheap for 21 years, if ≈øhe ≈øhould live ≈øo long, and afterwards made a Lea≈øe in Rever≈øion of the ≈øaid two hou≈øes to the ≈øaid Alice Leigh for 21 years, and afterwards he devi≈øed the≈øe two hou≈øes,Devi≈øes. and al≈øo the hou≈øe called the Marigold to the ≈øaid Alice Leigh for her life for to bring up his children, and died, after who≈øe death the ≈øaid Alice Leigh entred into the ≈øaid hou≈øe called the Marigold, and took the rents and profits of the ≈øaid two hou≈øes for the ≈øpace of 7 years, virtute te≈øtament. praedict. upon which Declaration the Defendants do demurr in Law. Coke, the Declaration is not good, and for the matter of it, it is clear, that by this devi≈øe unto Alice, her Term in futuro is not extinct without her agreement to it: And al≈øo in this Ca≈øe the Devi≈øe is not for the benefit of the ≈øaid Alice Leigh, but of her children, and ≈øhe hath liberty to accept or refu≈øe the ≈øaid e≈øtate by devi≈øe, and to make her election:Extingui≈øhment. And the Plaintiff hath declared, that ≈øhe hath accepted the Rent re≈øerved upon the Lea≈øe of the ≈øaid two hou≈øes for 7 years: And therein the Declaration naught in divers re≈øpects. 1. He hath declared, that the ≈øaid Alice Leigh hath accepted the Rents of the ≈øaid two hou≈øes, by rea≈øon of the rever≈øion, & virtue te≈øtament. praedict. by 7 years, which is double and treble; for acceptance of a Rent at one day, ≈øcil. one rent day is a ≈øufficient election: As if the I≈ø≈øue in tail, after the death of his Ance≈øtor, who hath made a Lea≈øe not warranted by the Statute, once accepts the Rent, the Lea≈øe is affirmed; but if in plea pleading, the acceptance of the ≈øaid Rent for 3 years be pleaded, the ≈øame clearly is not good; for no good I≈ø≈øue can be taken thereupon. 2. This acceptance is not pleaded (as the Law wills) and in the phra≈øe of the Law, viz. to which devi≈øe ≈øhe agreed, but pleads the acceptance of the Rent, which is matter of evidence, the which is not good pleading. As 5 H. 7. 1. One ≈øweareth another to enter into his Land, and the ≈øame to occupy for a certain time,E≈øtate executed. the ≈øame is a Lea≈øe in Law; and if in pleading the party is to make his title to the ≈øame Land, he ought to plead it as an expres Lea≈øe, and not as a Licence; and if the Lea≈øe be traver≈øed, he may give the Licence in evidence. Tanfield, pre≈øently by the devi≈øe, the e≈øtate for life is in the Devi≈øee and the Term extinct by it, and that is ≈øufficient for the Plaintiff: And if there was any di≈øagreement the ≈øame is to be ≈øhewed on the other ≈øide. But if Alice had not notice of the Devi≈øe, but dieth before notice, the ≈øame amounteth unto a di≈øagreement. And as to the pleading of the Agreement, I conceive its well enough pleaded, for if the Lea≈øe had not been ≈øhe might have entred, and then if ≈øuch Entry had been pleaded it had been good enough; and then becau≈øe ≈øhe could not enter by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, ≈øhe hath taken the rents and profits which is an actual agreement, and as ≈øtrong as an Entry. Al≈øo we have ≈øhewed that ≈øhe had entred into the hou≈øe called the Marigold, A≈ø≈øent not to be apportioned. of which the Devi≈øor died ≈øei≈øed in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and that is a ≈øufficient agreement for the whole, for it is an entire Legacy. As 18 E. 3. Variance 63. If the Rever≈øion of three acres be granted, and the Tenant for life attorneth for one
acre, it is a good attornment for the whole, for he cannot apportion his a≈ø≈øent: and 2 E. 4. 13. If the Executor deliver unto the Devi≈øee goods to him devi≈øed to redeliver them to him again at ≈øuch a day, the ≈øame is a good a≈ø≈øent, and execution of the Devi≈øe, and the words of the re-delivery are void. Gawdy, The devi≈øe doth not ve≈øt the e≈øtate in the Wife until agreement, where a man takes in a ≈øecond degree, as in a Remainder the ≈øame ve≈øts pre≈øently before agreement, but where he taketh immediatly it is otherwi≈øe, and he held the agreement was well enough pleaded. Wray, Pre≈øently upon the death of the Te≈øtator, the Free-hold re≈øted in the Devi≈øee, and it was not an Agreement, ut ≈øupra, by taking of the Rents, yet the entry into the Marigold was a con≈øent, and an Execution of the whole Legacy; and as to the re≈øt he agreed with Gawdy. Clench, The Free-hold re≈øted pre≈øently in Alice Leigh before agreement, al≈øo the entry into the Marigold is an execution of the whole Legacy to the Devi≈øee, for her entry ≈øhall be adjudged mo≈øt beneficial for her; and that is, for all the three hou≈øes.

div.head:
CLXXVII. Stran≈øham and Medcalfes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 178. STran≈øham libelled in the Court of the Bi≈øhop of Norwich again≈øt Medcalfe, for a portion of Tithes, as Farmor of the Rectory of Dunham: the Par≈øon of Stonham came in and ≈øaid, that the Land, whereof the Tithes are demanded, is in his Pari≈øh of Stonham, and not in the Pari≈øh of Dunham; and afterwards ≈øentence pa≈ø≈øed again≈øt Stran≈øham; who brought an Appeal, and notwith≈øtanding that, by the Statute of 32 H. 8. cap. 7. the ≈øpiritual Iudges may proceed to make proce≈øs again≈øt the Appellant for co≈øts, for the principal matter, ≈øcil. parcel, or within ≈øuch a Pari≈øh or not, is tryable at the Common Law. Cook now prayed a Con≈øultation; and he confe≈ø≈øed (ut ≈øupra) that the matter was tryable at the Common Law; but yet the co≈øts were not given for the matter, but for the unju≈øt vexation,No Prohibition for co≈øts in the ≈øpiritual Court. and it was his ≈øuit and own act to pro≈øecute the ≈øame in the Spiritual Court. Note, that Stran≈øham had a Prohibition to ≈øtay the proceedings for the co≈øts, for in ≈øome ca≈øes the Plaintiff him≈øelf, who libelleth, may have a Prohibition, and that was the ca≈øe betwixt Wignal and Brook. And afterwards a Con≈øultation was granted by the Court; for Stran≈øham had begun the ≈øuit in the Spiritual Court in the principal matter, and therefore he cannot have a Prohibition for the co≈øts. But afterwards Iudgment was ≈øtayed, for the ≈øaid Statute ≈øpeaks ≈øpecially in ca≈øe of Tithes, where the Court hath Iuri≈ødiction, and here it hath not of the matter: But it was ≈øaid, that if a Con≈øultation be once granted,1 Cro 277. the party ≈øhall never have another Prohibition in the ≈øame cau≈øe, as it was holden in the ca≈øe betwixt Hoskins and Jones.

div.head:
CLXXVIII. Chamberlain and Thorps Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31 Eliz. Rot. 186. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Recognizances in London, by cu≈øtom. 1 Cro. 186.IN Debt upon a Recognizance acknowledged in London, the Plaintiff declared, that London is antiqua Civitas, and that they have u≈øed time out of mind, &c. That the Mayor take Recognizances of any per≈øon being of full age, and not a Feme Covert, every day in the year, except Sundays, Holy-days, Coun≈øel days, and days of Quarter Se≈ø≈øions and Gaol-delivery; And declared further, now that the Defendant ≈øuch a day did acknowledge a Recognizance to him, &c. Tanfield, the Declaration is not good, but the cu≈øtom, as it is laid is unrea≈øonable,
for thereby the Mayor may take Recognizances of Idiots, men of Non ≈øanae Memoriae, &c. nor is it re≈øtrained to any per≈øons, or to any matters, but is too general, and therefore cannot be a good cu≈øtom. Gawdy, The Declaration is good notwith≈øtanding the Exception for want of averment, for that ought to come in on the other ≈øide. And as to the cu≈øtom I conceive it is not good, for it is hard, That they ≈øhould take Recognizances of all Per≈øons, and for all Cau≈øes which ri≈øe out of the City, and through the whole Realm, as well as within the City: al≈øo none ≈øhall take a Recognizance, but a Iudge of Record, and a Recognizance cannot be taken by pre≈øcription.
