As to the fir≈øt Exception, Wray agreed with Gawdy; and as to the Cu≈øtom, he held the ≈øame to be good. For it hath been always allowed, and their cu≈øtoms are confirmed by Act of Parliament which makes them good. But if the cu≈øtom be not confirmed by Parliament it is not good; al≈øo it is not an unrea≈øonable Cu≈øtom, for it is for the benefit of the Subjects to have ≈øecurity for their Debts. Coke, The Recognizance makes the Debt local, and therefore 13 Rich. 2. bar. 649. Debt was brought in London upon a Recognizance acknowledged in the Chancery at We≈øtmin≈øter, and the Writ was abated; for the Recognizance makes it local there; and by him the cu≈øtom ≈øtands with rea≈øon: The Mayor is ≈øuch a per≈øon who may take a Recognizance, for he is a Iudge of Record. See 1 H. 7. 20. and Br. Recognizance 8. and the Recogni≈øee cannot have an Action of Debt upon this Recognizance el≈øewhere than in London. For it is not a Debt out of the Iurisdiction of the Court, for the Recognizance hath made it local. Wray, If the Recogni≈øor be within age, the ≈øame ≈øhall come in of the other ≈øide, and the Plaintiff needs not ≈øhew the ≈øame in his Declaration. Cooke, It was agreed betwixt Mabbe and Frend, That ≈øuch a Recognizance was good. Tanfield, The ≈øaid Recognizance was taken for Orphans goods which is a thing within their Iurisdiction. Clench, They of London cannot take Recognizance of more than they can hold plea of it. Wray, They have u≈øed of long time to take Recognizances, and their cu≈øtoms are confirmed by Parliament, and a more ≈øtrange cu≈øtom than this hath been allowed of here before, ≈øcil. That a feme Covert ≈øhall ≈øue an Action alone without her Husband, for ≈øhe is a ≈øole Merchant; Al≈øo they do certifie Recognizances ore tenus. Gawdy, A feme Covert may have an Action within the City, but not here.

div.head: CLXXIX. Pierce again≈øt Howe. Hill. 32 Eliz. Rot. 434. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
AN Action upon the Ca≈øe for the≈øe words,Action upon the ca≈øe for words. 1 Cro. 185. Pierce hath taken a fal≈øe Oath in the Con≈øi≈øtory Court of the Bi≈øhop of Exeter, and upon the Declaration, the Defendant did demur in Law. And by Prideaux the≈øe words are Actionable, although the perjury be ≈øuppo≈øed to be committed in the ≈øpiritual Court; For he ≈øhall be excommunicated if he will not appear, and he ≈øhall do pennance in a White ≈øheet, which is as great a di≈øgrace as to be ≈øet upon the Pillory. And it was ruled in an action upon the ca≈øe betwixt Dorrington and Dorrington, upon the≈øe words, Thou art a Ba≈øtard, that an action lyeth, and yet Ba≈øtardy is a ≈øpiritual matter, and there determinable; So for the≈øe words, Thou art a Pirate, an action lyeth, and yet Piracy is not puni≈øhable by the common Law, but in the Court of Admiralty. And the≈øe words, He hath taken a fal≈øe oath, do amount to the≈øe words, He is for≈øworn. Wray conceived, that the words are not actionable, for there is a provi≈øo in the Statute of Eliz. cap. 9. That the ≈øaid Act ≈øhall not extend to any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, but that every ≈øuch offendor ≈øhall be and may be puni≈øhed by ≈øuch u≈øual and ordinary Laws as heretofore have been, and is yet u≈øed, and
frequent in the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court. Gawdy upon the≈øe words, an action doth not lye, for they are not pregnant of any perjury in the Pl. for he may be meer pa≈ø≈øive in it: for if one of the Ma≈øters of the Chancery mini≈øter an Oath unto any per≈øon, or any Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c. and the Plaintiff ≈øweareth fal≈øly, a man may ≈øay, That the Ma≈øter of the Chancery, or the Commi≈ø≈øioner hath taken a fal≈øe oath, and yet he is not guilty of fal≈øity. And afterwards Wray, mutata opinione, That the Provi≈øo in the ≈øaid Statute, is to this intent, That notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Statute, ≈øuch an offence may be enquirable and examined in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court in ≈øuch manner as it was before, but the ≈øame doth not take away or re≈øtrain the authority of the Common Law, but that ≈øuch an offence may be here examined. And it hath been lately adjudged in the Star-Chamber, That ≈øuch perjury was examinable there, for it is not re≈øtrained: and as to the latter exception, upon the≈øe words (he hath taken a fal≈øe oath) it ≈øhall be intended actively, and not pa≈ø≈øively, and if ≈øo, the Defendant ought to have ≈øo pleaded it, and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLXXX. Palmer and Smalbrooks Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 178. Owen 97. 3 Len. 227.IN an action upon the Ca≈øe by Palmer again≈øt Smalbrook, The Plaintiff declared, That the Defendant had recovered a certain Debt again≈øt A. and thereupon purcha≈øed a Writ of Capias again≈øt A. to take his body, and delivered the ≈øaid Capias to the Plaintiff being then Sheriff, and prayed a Warrant for the ≈øerving of the ≈øaid Capias; and that he would name in it, one B. for ≈øpecial Bailiff, and promi≈øed the Plaintiff that if B. arre≈øted A. by force of the ≈øaid Capias, and ≈øuffered him to e≈øcape, That he would not ≈øue the Plaintiff for the e≈øcape: and ≈øhewed further, That he made a Warrant according to the ≈øaid Capias, and therein named and appointed the ≈øaid B. his ≈øpecial Bailiff, who arre≈øted A. accordingly and afterwards ≈øuffered him to e≈øcape, and the Defendant notwith≈øtanding his promi≈øe afore≈øaid, ≈øued the Plaintiff, for the ≈øaid e≈øcape. And it was found for the Plaintiff; It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That the promi≈øe is again≈øt the Law, to prevent the puni≈øhment inflicted by the Statute of 23 H. 6. upon the Sheriff, and it is meerly within the Statute, and ≈øo the promi≈øe void. Cooke, The ≈øame is not any Bond or promi≈øe taken of the Pri≈øoner, nor of any for him, and therefore it is not within the Statute, as it was in Danvers Ca≈øe. Wray, A promi≈øe is within the Statute as well as a Bond; but the Statute doth not extend but where the Bond or promi≈øe is made by the Pri≈øoner, or by any for him; And after Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CLXXXI. Moun≈øon and We≈øts Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN Tre≈øpa≈øs by Moun≈øon again≈øt We≈øt, the Iury was charged and evidence given, and the Iurours being retired into a hou≈øe for to con≈øider of their evidence,Owen 38. Plowd. 520. Co. 1 In≈øt. 227. Dyer 37. they remained there a long time without concluding any thing; and the officers of the Court who attended them ≈øeeing their delay, ≈øearched the Iurours if they had any thing about them to eat; upon which ≈øearch it was found, that ≈øome of them had figs, and others pippins; for which the next day the matter was moved to the Court, and the Iurours were examined upon it upon Oath. And two of them did confe≈øs that they had eaten figs before
they had agreed of their verdict: and three other of them confe≈ø≈øed, That they had Pippins, but did not eat of them,Where Jurors ≈øhall be fined for eating before verdict; but it ≈øhall not make void the verdict. and that they did it without the knowledge or Will of any of the Parties. And afterwards the Court ≈øet a fine of five pound upon each of them which had eaten, and upon the others who had not eaten forty ≈øhillings. And they would advi≈øe, if the verdict was good or not, for the Iury found for the Plaintiff. And afterwards at another day, the matter was moved, and Ander≈øon was of opinion, That notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Mi≈ødemeanor of the Iury, the verdict was good enough, for the≈øe victuals were not given to them by any of the Parties to the action, nor by their means, or procurement. Rhodes thought the contrary, becau≈øe ≈øome of the Iurors had eaten, and ≈øome not, contrary if all of them had eaten. See 14 H. 7. 1. A Iury was charged and before their verdict, they did eat and drink, and it was holden that upon that Mi≈ødemeanor, their verdict was void, for which cau≈øe a venire facias de novo was awarded. And it was prayed by the Coun≈øel of the Defendant We≈øt, That the ≈øaid Mi≈ødemeanor ≈øo found by examination might be entred of Record, which the Court granted. And afterwards at another day, the matter was moved again. And upon great advice and deliberation, and conference with the other Iudges, The verdict was holden to be good notwith≈øtanding the Mi≈ødemeanor afore≈øaid. See 24 E. 3 24. 15 H. 7. 1. 2 H. 7. 3. 29 H. 8. 37. and 35 H. 8. 55. where it was holden, where the eating and drinking of the Iury at their own co≈øts is but fineable, but if it be at the co≈øts of the parties, the verdict is void. And ≈øee Book of Entries 251. The Iurors after they went from the Bar ad ≈øeip≈øos of their verdict to be advi≈øed, comederunt qua≈ødam ≈øpecies, ≈øci. rai≈øins, dates, &c. at their own co≈øts, as well before, as after they agreed of their verdict; And the Iurors were committed to pri≈øon; but their verdict was good, although the verdict was given again≈øt the King.

div.head:
CLXXXII. Hunt and Gilborns Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Dower brought by Hunt and his Wife again≈øt Gilborn, The Defendant pleaded, That the Land of which Dower is demanded,Dower of Gavelkind by Cu≈øtom. Ante. 62, 63. 1 Cro. 825. is of the nature of Gavelkind, and that the cu≈øtom is, That in Dower of Land of ≈øuch nature The Wife ought to be endowed of the moity of ≈øuch Land, Tenendum quam diu non maritata reman≈øerit, & non aliter; upon which plea in Bar, the Demandants did demur in Law; and the Lord Ander≈øon was of opinion, That the Cu≈øtom is ≈øtrongly pleaded again≈øt the Dower in the affirmative with a Negative & non aliter; and that is confe≈ø≈øed by the Demurrer, That Dower out of ≈øuch Land ought to be ≈øo allowed, and ≈øo demanded, and in no other manner. And by Periam, If tho≈øe words (& non aliter) had not been in the Plea, yet the Demandants ≈øhould not have Iudgment: For Dower by moiety, & non maritatis, is as proper in ca≈øe of Gavelkind, as Dower of the third part of Land at the Common Law, and as the de≈øcent in ≈øuch ca≈øe of Lands to all the Sons. And afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Demandants.

div.head: CLXXXIII. The Ca≈øe of the Provo≈øt and Scholars of Queens Colledge in Oxford. Hill. 30. Eliz.
div.p: THe Provo≈øt, Fellows, and Scholars of Queens Colledge in Oxford, are Guardians of the Ho≈øpital, or Mea≈øon de Dieu in Southampton. And they make a Lea≈øe of the Land parcel of the ≈øaid Ho≈øpital to one Hazel for Term of years by the name Praepo≈øitus Socii & Scholares Collegii reginalis in Oxonia, Gardianus Ho≈øpitalis, &c. And in an Ejectione firmae upon that lea≈øe It was found for the Plaintiffs; and it was objected in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That the word Gardianus, ought to be Gardiani, for the Colledge doth con≈øi≈øt of many per≈øons, and every per≈øon is capable, and it is not like unto Abbot and Covent: But the whole Court was of opinion, that the Exception was not good, but that as well the Lea≈øe as al≈øo the Declaration was good, for the Colledge is one body, and as one per≈øon: And ≈øo it is good enough Gardianus.

div.head:
CLXXXIV. Wooden and Hazels Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Ejectione betwixt Wooden and Hazel they were at i≈ø≈øue upon, Not Guilty: and a Venire facias awarded returnable, Tres Trinit. And the E≈ø≈øoin adjudged and adjorned by the Plaintiff until Michaelmas Term;Ni≈øi Prips. And at next A≈ø≈øi≈øes, the Plaintiff not with≈øtanding that E≈ø≈øoin, and the adjorning of it procured a Ni≈øi Prius, by which it was found for the Plaintiff: And now it was moved in Court for the ≈øtay of Iudgment, becau≈øe no Ni≈øi Prius ought to i≈ø≈øue in the Ca≈øe.E≈ø≈øoin. For the E≈ø≈øoin was adjudged and adjorned until Michaelmas Term by the Plaintiff him≈øelf. And Leonard cu≈øtos Brevium ≈øaid, That the words of the Statute of We≈øtmin≈øter 2 cap. 27. Po≈øtquam aliquis po≈øuerit ≈øe in aliquem inqui≈øitionem ad proximum diem allocet. ei e≈ø≈øon. Imports, That the E≈ø≈øoin ≈øhall not be taken at the return of the Proce≈øs again≈øt the Iury, although the Iury be ready at the Bar. Ander≈øon was of opinion, That the awarding of the Ni≈øi Prius ut ≈øupra, is but a mi≈øawarding of the Proce≈øs, and then relieved by the Statute. And afterwards the ca≈øe being moved at another day,1 Cro. 367. the Court was clear of opinion, That no Ni≈øi Prius ought to i≈ø≈øue forth in this ca≈øe, becau≈øe that the Plaintiff him≈øelf, by the adjorning of the E≈ø≈øoin, ca≈øt by the Defendant until Michaelmas Term, had barred him≈øelf of all Proceedings in the mean time: But afterwards it was ≈øurmi≈øed to the Court on the Plaintiffs part, that he the Defendant was not e≈ø≈øoined, for the name of the Defendant is Edward Hazel, and it appeared upon the tryal that Edward Ru≈ø≈øel was e≈ø≈øoined,Amendment. but no Edward Hazel, and then if no E≈ø≈øoin, no adjornment, and then the Plaintiff is at large, &c. and may proceed, &c. But the Remembrance of the Clark was Edward Hazel, as it ought to be, and yet it was holden of no effect, being in another Term: And afterwards the Coun≈øel of the Defendant prayed, that the Roll in hac parte, be amended according to the Remembrance of the Clark: But the Court utterly denied that, for no Statute gives amendment, but in the affirmance of Iudgments, and Verdicts, and not in defeazance of Iudgments or Verdicts: and afterwards it was re≈øolved by the whole Court, That Iudgment be entred for the Plaintiff.

div.head: CLXXXV. Sir Henry Goodiers Ca≈øe. Hill. 32 Eliz. Intratur M. 29 & 30. Eliz. Rot. 2116.
div.p: IN an Ejectione firmae the Ca≈øe was, Sir Ralph Rowlet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of certain Lands for years made his Will, and ordained Sir Nicholas Bacon, Renouncing of an Executor≈øhip. Owen. 44. Office of Executors. 54. 1 Cro. 92. 9 Co. 37. Keeper of the great Seal of England, Sir Robert Catline, Lord Chief Iu≈øtice of England, Iu≈øtice Southcote, and Gerrard Attorney General his Executors, and died. And afterwards the ≈øaid per≈øons named Executors, ≈øent their Letters to the Chief Officer of the Prerogative Court as followeth. Whereas our Loving friend Sir Ralph Rowlet Knight, lately decea≈øed, made and ordained us Executors of his la≈øt Will, and whereas our bu≈øine≈øs is ≈øo great, that we cannot attend the execution of the ≈øaid Will, Therefore we have thought good to move the bearer hereof Mr. Henry Goodier one of the Co-heirs of the ≈øaid Sir Ralph to take upon him the execution of the ≈øaid Will. And therefore we pray you to grant Letters of Admini≈øtration in as ample manner as the ju≈øtice of the cau≈øe doth require; and afterwards an Entry was made in this manner in the ≈øame Court, Executores Te≈øtamenti praedict. executionem inde ≈øuper ≈øe a≈ø≈øumere di≈øtulerant & adhuc di≈øtarent: And upon that the ≈øaid Goodier obtained Letters of Admini≈øtration, and granted a Lea≈øe to A. for years, of which the ≈øaid Sir Ralph Rowlet died po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. And afterwards Sir Robert Catline claiming as Executor, granted the ≈øame Term to another, &c. and all the matter of difficulty was, If this Letter written by the Executors be a ≈øufficient Renunciation of the Executor≈øhip in Law, ≈øo as the Executors cannot afterwards claim or u≈øe the ≈øaid authority, &c. 2. If the Entry of the ≈øaid Renuntiation be ≈øufficient and effectual. And it was argued by Ford, one of the Doctors of the Civil Law, That as well the Renunciation as the Entry of it is good and ≈øufficient in Law, ≈øo that none of the Executors could not after entermeddle. And he ≈øaid, That in their Law, there is not any certain form of Renuntiation, but if the meaning and intention of the Renouncer appeareth, it is ≈øufficient without any formal Terms of Renunciation: And he put many rules and Maximes in their Law to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, Ego dico me nolle e≈ø≈øe haeredem, are ≈øufficient words to ≈øuch intent. Non vult haeres e≈ø≈øe quin ad aliam transferre debet haereditatem. Qui ≈øemel repudiavit haereditatem non pote≈øt eam repetere. Quod ≈øemel placuit, po≈øt di≈øplicere non pote≈øt. Variatio non permittitur in contractibus. So that after the Executors have ≈øignified to the Officer of their Court their plea≈øure to renounce the Execution of the Will, they cannot afterwards entermeddle, nam intere≈øt reipublicae ut dominia rerum ≈øint in certo. And as to the Entry of the ≈øaid Renunciation inter acta Curiae, di≈øtulerint et adhuc di≈øtarent, that was the error of the Clark. And it is Rule in our Law, veritas rerum ge≈øtarum non vitiatur Errore factorum. And the Lord Ander≈øon demanded of the ≈øaid Doctor, how far tho≈øe words haeres, et haereditas did extend in their Law, who an≈øwered, That haereditas comprehends all Chattels, as well real as per≈øonal, Inheritance as well as Chattels, for by their Law, Haereditas nihilaliud e≈øt quam ≈øucce≈ø≈øio in univer≈øum jus quod defunctus habuit tempore mortis ≈øuae. And afterwards the Court gave day to the other party to hear an Argument of their ≈øide, but the ca≈øe was ≈øo clear, That no Profe≈ø≈øor of the Civil Law would be retained to argue to the contrary. And afterwards Iudgment was given, That the ≈øaid Renunciation, and the entry of it was ≈øufficient.

div.head:
CLXXXVI. Littleton and Pernes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt. LIttleton brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Humphry Pernes, who pleaded, that the ≈øaid Obligation was endorced with this condition, for the performance of certain Articles and Covenants contained in certain Indentures, by which Indentures the Plaintiff fir≈øt covenanted, that Edward brother of Humphry ≈øhould enjoy ≈øuch Land until the Fea≈øt of Michaelmas next following, rendring ≈øuch Rent at the end of the ≈øaid Term: and the ≈øaid Humphry covenanted, that the ≈øaid Edward at the Fea≈øt afore≈øaid ≈øhould ≈øurrender quietly and peaceably the ≈øaid Lands to the Plaintiff, and that the ≈øaid Plaintiff to ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Lands as by the Cu≈øtom of the Country, tunc jacebant fri≈øca, ≈øhould have in the mean time free ingre≈øs, egre≈øs, &c. at his will and plea≈øure, with his ≈øervants, ploughs, &c. And as to that Covenant, the Defendant pleaded, Quod permi≈øit querentem habere intrationem & exitum, &c. in tales terras, quales tunc jacebant ≈øecundum con≈øuetudinem patriae, &c. And Exception was taken to this plea, becau≈øe he hath not ≈øhewed in certain, which Lands they were which then then did lie Frecy, according to the cu≈øtom of the Country; which Ander≈øon allowed of, but Walm≈øly ≈øtrongly in≈øi≈øted to the contrary: And he confe≈ø≈øed, that where an Act is to be done, according to a Covenant, he who pleads the performance of it ought to plead it ≈øpecially; but as our ca≈øe is, here is no Act to be done, but a permittance as above≈øaid, and it is in the Negative, not a di≈øturbance, in which ca≈øe permi≈øit is a good plea; and then it ≈øhall come on the other ≈øide on the Plaintiffs part, to ≈øhew in what Lands the Defendant non permi≈øit: Which difference ≈øee agreed, 17 E. 4. 26. by the whole Court. And ≈øuch was the opinion of the whole Court in the principal ca≈øe.

1 Co. 127.Another Exception was taken to it, that the Defendant had covenanted, that his brother Edward ≈øhould pay to the Plaintiff the ≈øaid Rent; To which the Defendant pleaded, that his ≈øaid brother had payed to the Platntiff before the ≈øaid Fea≈øt of Michaelmas, in full ≈øatisfaction of the ≈øaid Rent, three ≈øhillings, and that was holden a good plea; and upon the matter the Covenant well performed, for there is not any Rent in this Ca≈øe, for here is not any Lea≈øe, and therefore not any Rent. For if A. covenant with B. that C. ≈øhall have his Land for ≈øo many years rendring ≈øuch a Rent,1 Roll. 847. 1 Cro. 173. Owen 97. here is not any Lea≈øe, and therefore neither Rent. But if A. had covenanted with C. him≈øelf, it had been otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe it is betwixt the ≈øame parties. And if the Le≈ø≈øee covenant to pay his Rent to the Le≈ø≈øor, and he payeth it before the day, the ≈øame is not any performance of the Covenant, cau≈øa patet, contrary of a ≈øum in gro≈øs: Another Covenant was, that the ≈øaid Humphry ≈øolveret ex parte dicti Edwardi 20 l. to which the Defendant pleaded, that he had paid ex parte dicti Humfridi 20 l. and that defect was holden incureable, and therefore the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover.

div.head:
CLXXXVII. Ge≈ølin and Warburtons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
1 Cro. 128.IN an Ejectione firmae by Joan Ge≈ølin again≈øt Hen. Warburton and Seba≈øtian Cri≈øpe of Lands in Dickilborough in the County of Norf. Mich. 30. & 31 Eliz. rot. 333. upon the general I≈ø≈øue, the Iury found a ≈øpecial verdict, that before the Tre≈øpa≈øs ≈øuppo≈øed one Martin Frenze was ≈øei≈øed of the
Lands, of which the Action was brought in tail to him and his Heirs males of his body, ≈øo ≈øei≈øed ≈øuffered a common Recovery to his own u≈øe,Devi≈øes. and afterwards devi≈øed the ≈øame in this manner: I give my ≈øaid Land to Margaret my Wife, until ≈øuch time as Prudence my Daughter ≈øhall accompli≈øh the age of nineteen years, the Rever≈øion to the ≈øaid Prudence my Daughter, and to the Heirs of her body Lawfully begotten, upon condition that ≈øhe the ≈øaid Prudence ≈øhall pay unto my ≈øaid Wife yearly during her life, in recompence of her Dower of and in all my Lands 12 pounds, and if default of payment be made, then I will that my ≈øaid Wife ≈øhall enter and have all my Lands during her life, &c. the Remainder ut ≈øupra, the Remainder to John Frenze in tail, &c. Martin Frenze died, Margaret entred, the ≈øaid Prudence being within the age of fourteen years; Margaret took to Husband one of the Defendants, John Frenze being Heir male to the former tail brought a Writ of Error upon the ≈øaid Recovery and a≈ø≈øigned Error, becau≈øe the Writ of Entry upon which the Recovery was had, was Praecipe quod reddat unum Me≈ø≈øuag. and twenty acras prati in Dickelborough, Linford Hamblets, without naming any Town: And thereupon the Iudgment was rever≈øed. And it was further found, that in the ≈øaid Writ of Error, and the proce≈øs upon it,Hutt. 106. 2 Cro. 574. 3 Cro. 196. no Writ of Scire facias i≈ø≈øued to warn dictam Prudentiam ten. exi≈øtentem liberi ten. praemi≈ø≈øorum, ad o≈øtendendam quid haberet, vel dicere ≈øciret quare Judicium praedict. non rever≈øaretur: The Iury further found, that the ≈øaid Margaret, depending the ≈øaid Writ of Error was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed virtute Te≈øtamenti & ultimae voluntatis dict. Martini, rever≈øione inde expectant. dictae Prudentiae pro ut lex po≈øtulat: And they further found,Error. that ≈øix pound of the ≈øaid tewlve pounds were unpaid to the ≈øaid Margaret at the Fea≈øt, &c. and they found, that the ≈øaid John Frenze, praetextu Judicii ≈øic rever≈øat. entred into the premi≈ø≈øes as Heir male, ut ≈øupra. And ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, a Fine was levyed betwixt John Frenze Plaintiff, and one Edward Tindal, Owen 157. Dyer 321. 1 Cro. 471. 739. and the ≈øaid Prudence his Wife Deforceants, and that was to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid John Frenze: And that afterwards Humphry Warburton and the ≈øaid Margaret his Wife, brought a Writ of Dower again≈øt the ≈øaid John Frenze, Edw. Tindal, and Prudence his Wife, of the ≈øaid Lands: The ≈øaid Edward and Prudence made default, and the Demandants counted again≈øt the ≈øaid Frenze, and demanded again≈øt him the moity of the third part of the ≈øaid Lands: To which the ≈øaid Frenze pleaded, that the default of the ≈øaid Edward and Prudence idem John Frenze nomine non debet, quia he ≈øaid, that he the ≈øaid John was ≈øole ≈øei≈øed of the Lands afore≈øaid at the time of the Writ brought, &c. and pleaded in Bar, and it was found again≈øt the ≈øaid John, and Iudgment given for the Demandants of the third part of the whole Land, and ≈øei≈øin accordingly: And that afterwards, 17 Eliz. the ≈øaid Frenze levyed the Fine to the ≈øaid Tindal, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Tindal and his Heirs: And they found, that after the ≈øaid Fea≈øt the ≈øaid Henry Warburton and Margaret his Wife came to the Me≈ø≈øuage afore≈øaid half an hour before Sun-≈øet of the ≈øaid day, and there did demand the Debt of the ≈øaid twelve pounds,Dower. to the ≈øaid Margaret, by the ≈øaid Martin Frenze devi≈øed to be paid unto them, and there remained till after Sun-≈øet of the ≈øaid day, demanding the Rent afore≈øaid, and that neither the ≈øaid Tindal nor any other was there ready to pay the ≈øame.

And fir≈øt it was moved, if the ≈øaid yearly ≈øum of twelve pounds appointed to be paid to the ≈øaid Margaret were a Rent, or but a ≈øum in gro≈øs: And the opinion of the Court was, that it was a Rent, and ≈øo it might be fitly collected out of the whole Will, where it is ≈øaid, that Prudence his Daughter ≈øhould have the Land, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould pay yearly to Margaret twelve pounds in recompence of her Dower, &c. But if it be not a Rent, but a ≈øum in gro≈øs, it is not much material to the end of the ca≈øe: For put ca≈øe it be a Rent, the ≈øame not being pleaded in Bar, the Dower is well recovered, and then when default
of payment is made, if the Wife of the Devi≈øor ≈øhall have the whole, was the Que≈øtion: And the Court was clear of opinion, that by the ≈øuit and Iudgment in the Writ of Dower, the Wife of the Devi≈øor had lo≈øt all the benefit which was to come to her by the devi≈øe: For the ≈øaid Rent was devi≈øed to her in recompence of her Dower, ≈øo as it was not the meaning of the Devi≈øor that his Wife ≈øhould have both; And therefore by the Recovery in Dower ≈øhe had di≈ømi≈ø≈øed her ≈øelf of the Rent, and by con≈øequence of the benefit of the penalty for not payment of it.

div.head:
CLXXXVIII. Stephens Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Fines levyed to rai≈øe an u≈øe.IN an Ejectione firmae the ca≈øe was, that the Father covenanted with one A. that in con≈øideration of a Marriage to be had betwixt the Son of the Covenantor and the Daughter of A. that he before ≈øuch a day would levy a Fine, which Fine ≈øhould be to the u≈øes of the Son and Daughter in tail for the Ioynture of the Daughter. The Fine is levyed accordingly to the u≈øes afore≈øaid: The Father dieth, but in the Fine no mention is made of any marriage had: And upon that matter the Court was clear of opinion, that notwith≈øtanding that the marriage was not accompli≈øhed, yet the e≈øtate tail was well enough executed in the Son and Daughter, for the Fine without any con≈øideration doth carry the u≈øes, but without a Fine ≈øuch a con≈øideration would not rai≈øe ≈øuch an u≈øe without accompli≈øhment of the marriage, for the con≈øideration executed ought to produce the u≈øe. But in this ca≈øe the u≈øes are perfected by the Fine, and A. upon the matter might have had covenant again≈øt the Father to have the Fine before the marriage.

div.head:
CLXXXIX. Billford and Foxes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
BIllford brought an Action of Debt again≈øt Fox and his Wife, Executrix of one A. her former Husband,Debt. proce≈øs continued again≈øt them till the Exigent, upon which the Husband appeared, and put in a ≈øuper≈øedeas for him≈øelf only,1 Cro. 118. without making mention of his Wife, and the ca≈øe being moved to the Iu≈øtices, they demanded of the Prothonotaries what was to be done, for the ≈øame is practi≈øe and a dangerous ca≈øe for example. And it was an≈øwered by the Prothonotaries, that the Court cannot remedy it, for now by the Supe≈øedeas the Husband is ≈øine die, for he ≈øhall not be driven to an≈øwer without his Wife, as this ca≈øe is, and he is impleaded, as in the right of his Wife, and therefore the Wife ≈øhall be waived, Super≈øedeas by the Husband is not good for the Wife. and the Husband di≈øcharged. See the Book of Entries 187. Debt again≈øt the Husband and Wife, and proce≈øs continued until the Exigent, the Husband rendred him≈øelf, and the Wife was waive, and Iudgment given, quia videbatur Ju≈øticiariis hic that the Husband ab≈øque praefata uxore ≈øua re≈øpondere non potuit, & ratoni di≈ø≈øonum ≈øit, ip≈øum in Curia hic, cum in eadem loquela re≈øpondere non potuit, ulterius detineri, ideo eat inde ≈øine die. And ≈øo ≈øee 43 E. 3. 18. Detinue again≈øt the Husband and Wife, the Wife is waive, and the Husband rendred him≈øelf at the Exigent. And the point of the Action was upon a bailment to the Wife, dum ≈øola ≈øuit, and the Husband was ≈øine die, for he could not an≈øwer in ≈øuch ca≈øe without the Wife. But at the la≈øt the Iu≈øtices advi≈øed thereof, and gave order that the Super≈øedeas ≈øhould by ≈øtayed without recording the appearance of the Husband. And by Anthrobus one of the Attorneys of the Court, that was the ca≈øe of the Lady Malory and her Husband, who
were ≈øued in an Action of Debt, and proce≈øs continued again≈øt them till the Exigent, upon which the Husband appeared and put in a Super≈øedeas for him≈øelf, without ≈øpeaking of his Wife; and his Super≈øedeas was not allowed, but proce≈øs continued until Out-lawry.

div.head:
CXC. The Queen again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and others.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Queen brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter, and the Incumbent: And counted,Quare Impedit. that A≈øhburnham was ≈øei≈øed of the Advow≈øon, and that he was out-lawed in an Action per≈øonal at the ≈øuit of ≈øuch a one, and ≈øhewed the whole Out-lawry certain. And Exception was taken to the Count, becau≈øe in the ≈øetting down of the Out-lawry, the proce≈øs is alledged to be returned by the Sheriff, but the name of the Sheriff is not there expre≈ø≈øed. As to that, it was agreed by the Court that the truth is, that it is provided by the Statute of 12 E 2. cap. 5. That the Sheriffs in their returns put their names to the ≈øaid Returns; but it is not requi≈øite ≈øo to plead it, for the omitting thereof doth not make the Return void, but the Sheriff ≈øhall be amerced.

Another matter was objected, for that whereas the Patron had pleaded one plea, and the Incumbent the ≈øame plea by him≈øelf in Bar. The Queen demurred in Law in this manner, quoad ≈øeperalia placita per dictos, 1 Cro. 140. Dyer 181, 182. Ante 124. &c. ≈øeperaliter placitat. &c. Dicta Domina Regina nece≈ø≈øe non habet, nec per legem terrae tenetur re≈øpondere: And the Court was clear of opinion, that the Demurrer ought to have been ≈øeveral, upon the plea of the Patron by it ≈øelf, and upon the plea of the Incumbent by it ≈øelf.

div.head:
CXCI. Mallet and Ferrers Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs of Battery; the parties were at I≈ø≈øue upon not guilty,Damages increa≈øed of a Maim by the Court. and at the Ni≈øi prius it appeared, that the Thumb of the right hand of the Plaintiff was clear cut off, and ≈øo maimed; And it was found for the Plaintiff, and damages taxed to forty pounds, and now the party came in per≈øon into Court, and prayed, in re≈øpect of the heinousne≈øs of the Maim, that the Court would encrea≈øe the damages;Dyer 105. 1 Cro. 223. 544. Sty. 310, 311. which damages, upon great con≈øideration had, were made one hundred pounds, and Iudgment given accordingly. See that the cutting off any of the Fingers is a Maim, 28 E. 3. 54. by Stone; and as for the damages further a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Court, than the damages taxed by the Iury, See Book of Entries, 46. 8 H. 4. 135. 39 E. 3. 20.

div.head:
CXCII. Atkins and Hales Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
RIchard Atkins of Lincolns-Inn brought a Writ of Forger of fal≈øe Faits again≈øt Hale of Glouce≈øter, and counted upon the Forger of an Indenture,Forger of fal≈øe faits. in quo continetur quod quidam Abbas Mona≈øterii de Glouce≈øter Demi≈øit Situm Manerii de R. & terras dominicales, &c. The Defendant pleaded, Not guilty. And it was given in evidence on the Plaintiffs part, a Lea≈øe ≈øuppo≈øed to be made and forged; containing that the ≈øaid Abbot lea≈øed the ≈øaid
Site and all the deme≈øne Lands of the ≈øaid Manor, exceptis duobus ≈øeperalibus clau≈øuris inde, &c. vocat. &c. And it was moved, if this Evidence doth not maintain the I≈ø≈øue. And it was holden by the whole Court, that the Evidence was good enough, for it is not nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øtrue terras Dominicales, omnes terras Dominicales, for the Lands not excepted are terrae Dominicales, and ≈øo the Count is ≈øatisfied by that Evidence, &c.

div.head:
CXCIII. Chamberlain and Stauntons Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: CHamberlain brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Staunton, and upon non e≈øt factum, Deeds, and ≈øealing of them. Owen 95. the Iury found this ≈øpecial matter, that the Defendant ≈øub≈øcribed and ≈øealed the ≈øaid Obligation, and ca≈øt it upon a certain Table, and the Plaintiff took it without any other delivery, or any other thing amounting to a delivery. And the Court was clear of opinion, that upon that matter the Iury had found again≈øt the Plaintiff, and it is not like the ca≈øe which was here lately adjudged, that the Obligor ≈øub≈øcribed and ≈øealed the Obligation, and ca≈øt it upon a Table, ≈øaying the≈øe words, this will ≈øerve, the ≈øame was held to be a good delivery, for here is a circum≈øtance, the ≈øpeaking of the≈øe words, by which the Will of the Obligor appeareth, that it ≈øhall be his deed.

div.head:
CXCIV. Oldfield and Wilmers Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Arbitrament. Po≈øtea. 304.IN Debt upon an Obligation, the Defendant pleaded, that the Obligation was endorced with condition, that the Defendant ≈øhould ≈øtand to the Award of I.S. &c. who awarded, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay to the Plaintiff at ≈øuch a day 100 l. or ≈øhould find two ≈øufficient Sureties to be bound with him to the Plaintiff to pay the ≈øaid 100 l. to the Plaintiff, by twenty pound a year, until the whole ≈øum be paid: And pleads further, that he had performed the ≈øaid Award. The Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaith, that the Defendant hath not paid unto him the ≈øaid one hundred pounds, and ≈øo in that a≈ø≈øigned the breach of the Award, and upon the Replication the Defendant doth demur in Law, becau≈øe by the pretence of the Award, the Defendant had election either to pay the one hundred pounds at the day, or to find two Sureties for the payment of it by twenty pounds per annum, &c. for ≈øo is the Award in the di≈øjunctive. But the Court was clear of opinion, that the Replication was good, for although that the Award be ≈øet down and conceived in words di≈øjunctive, yet in Law and in ≈øub≈øtance it is ≈øingle, for as to the finding of Suretis the Award is void, and ≈øo nothing is awarded but the payment of the one hundred pounds at the day,1 Cro. 4. to which the Plaintiff in his Replication hath fully an≈øwered: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CXCV. The Lord Dudley and Lacyes Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.

CXCVI. Askew and the Earl of Lincolns Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: ASkew was bound to the Earl of Lincoln in a Statute Staple,Audita querela. the Earl ≈øued execution, by which Askew was put in pri≈øon; and now the friends of Askew offered the mony in Court, and ca≈øt an Audita Querela for Askew, and prayed he might be bailed, and the mony remain in Court till the Audita Querela determined. But the Earl pre≈øently demanded the mony to be delivered to him, but the Court denied it, and commanded the Prothonotaries to keep the mony, until the Audita Querela were determined: And let Askew to bail for the co≈øts of ≈øuit.

div.head:
CXCVII. Ward and Blunts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: WArd brought an Action of Trover and Conver≈øion again≈øt Blunt of forty loads of Corn:Trover and Conver≈øion. as unto twenty loads the Defendant pleaded not guilty, and as to the re≈øidue a ≈øpecial plea, upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law, and it was adjudged for the Plaintiff, upon which i≈ø≈øued a Writ of Enquiry of Damages, which is returned: It was moved, that the Writ of Enquiry of Damages ought not to have i≈ø≈øued forth, for the I≈ø≈øue doth yet depend untryed, and the Book of 34 H. 6. 1. was vouched, and there the ca≈øe was, that in Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt many, one of them made default after a plea pleaded; Now a Writ of Enquiry of Damages ≈øhall be awarded, but ≈øhall not i≈ø≈øue forth until the plea of the others be tryed; and if the I≈ø≈øue be tryed for the Plaintiff, then the Enque≈øt who tryed the I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall a≈ø≈øe≈øs damages for the whole, and if for the Defendant again≈øt the Plaintiff, then the Writ which was awarded to i≈ø≈øue forth. See 44 E. 3. 7. Cook, It is in the di≈øcretion of the Court, to award ≈øuch Writ or not, which Wray granted, but it is u≈øual here to grant the Writ pre≈øently. Gawdy, The ca≈øe in 39 H. 6. is not like this ca≈øe, for in this ca≈øe the Tre≈øpa≈øs is divided, and as it were apportioned in twenty loads, and twenty loads, but in the other ca≈øe not.

div.head: CXCVIII. Smith and Bu≈øtards Ca≈øe. Trin. 31 Eliz. Rot. 666.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, that one S. was ≈øei≈øed of Lands, and lea≈øed the ≈øame to F. for 31 years,10 Co. 129. yeilding and paying
twenty pounds per annum at the Font-≈øtone in the Temple Church (the Land it ≈øelf lying in E≈ø≈øex) upon the Fea≈øts of the Annunciation of our Lady and St Michael, or within twelve days after either of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts, by even portions, upon condition, that if the ≈øaid Rent or any part thereof be unpaid by the ≈øaid ≈øpace of twelve days, Proxime po≈øt aliquod fe≈øtorum vel dierum ≈øolutionis inde, that then it ≈øhould be lawful for the Le≈ø≈øor to re-enter. T. a≈ø≈øigned his intere≈øt to Bu≈øtard the Defendant, at Michaelmas the Rent is behind, and the twelfth day after the Le≈ø≈øor demanded the Rent at the Temple Church, and for not payment thereof re-entred.Dyer 142. Tow≈øe, The re-entry of the Le≈ø≈øor was not lawful, for by the ≈øaid Re≈øervation the Rent was not due until the twelfth day after Michaelmas, for before that he cannot have an Action of Debt, or di≈øtrein for it;Conditions expounded liberally for the party who is to perform it. and the≈øe words (dierum ≈øolutionis) are greatly material, for conditions are odious in Law, and if the words thereof be doubtful, they ≈øhall be con≈øtrued for the avail of him who is bound by it. As in the ca≈øe of 28 H. 8. 17. If I be bound to you upon condition, to pay to you before the Fea≈øt of St. Thomas twenty pounds, if there be in one year two Fea≈øts of St. Thomas, the latter Fea≈øt ≈øhall be my day of payment. Wray, This Rent is not due until the la≈øt day of the twelve days, for neither debt or di≈øtre≈øs lieth for it, then the day of payment mentioned in the condition ought to be the la≈øt day of the la≈øt twelve days, and dict. ≈øpatium ≈øhall be con≈øtrued the ≈øame number of days, and not the ≈øame days.4 Len. 91. And at la≈øt it was re≈øolved and adjudged, that the entry of the Le≈ø≈øor was not congeable, but he ought to expect the latter day of the twelve days.

div.head:
CXCIX. Sir George Farmer and Brooks Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared, that time out of mind,Pre≈øcription. Owen 67. 1 Cro. 203. 8 Co. 125. &c. there had been a Manor called Toce≈øter, and al≈øo there had been there a Town called Toce≈øter, and that all the Me≈ø≈øuages, Lands and Tenements within the ≈øaid Town had been holden of the ≈øaid Manor, and that he is Lord of the ≈øaid Manor, and that he, and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath in the ≈øaid Manor, have u≈øed to have a Bake-hou≈øe, and a Baker, to bake white bread and hou≈øe bread for all the Inhabitants and Pa≈ø≈øengers there, which bread hath been of a rea≈øonable A≈ø≈øize and price, and ≈øufficient for all the Inhabitants and Pa≈ø≈øengers there (but doth not ≈øay whol≈øom) and that time out of mind, &c. no per≈øon had or u≈øed any Bake-hou≈øe there, but by the appointment of the ≈øaid Lord of the Manor for the time being: But that now the Defendant had erected a Bake-hou≈øe unto the Nu≈øance of the Plaintiff: The Defendane ≈øhewed, that at the time he had ≈øet up his Bake-hou≈øe, there were three Bakers there; and ≈øhewed, how that he was Apprentice to the Trade, and that at the time, he ≈øet up the ≈øaid Bake-hou≈øe for the benefit of all per≈øons, as it was lawful for him to do. Morgan, The matter only is, if this pre≈øcription made by the Plaintiff be good or not: It is to be con≈øidered, if all pre≈øcriptions at the Common Law are one, and if all pre≈øcriptions be guided by one rule and line: And I conceive, that pre≈øcription at the Common Law is but one: And there are two points in pre≈øcriptions, V≈øage and Rea≈øonablene≈øs, but they are not guided by one line, for ≈øome pre≈øcriptions are again≈øt ≈øtrangers, and then there ought to be con≈øideration and recompence: Some pre≈øcriptions again≈øt privies, as between Lord and Tenant, for there the Tenure is ≈øufficient, & volenti non fit injuria. For the fir≈øt, ≈øee 5 H. 7. 9. where in Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant doth ju≈øtifie, that the place where, is his Free-hold, and that he had a Foldage, and that he, and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate he hath, &c. have u≈øed, that if any man depa≈øture
his Sheep with the Sheep of the Defendant for the day time, that it was lawful at night to take all the Sheep and put them in his fold all the night, and in the morning to put them out, and the ≈øame was holden a good pre≈øcription, for which the Plaintiff traver≈øed the pre≈øcription: And for the other ≈øee 11 H 7. 13, 14. 21 H 7. 40. betwixt Lord and Tenant, that every Tenant for every pound-breach ≈øhould forfeit three pounds; and ≈øee the Prior of Dun≈øtables ca≈øe, 11 H. 6. 19. Br. pre≈øcription 98. The Prior declared, that he and his Predece≈ø≈øors time out of mind, &c. had had a Market in D. every week one day, and that Butchers and others, who ≈øold victuals, ≈øhould ≈øell the ≈øame in the high ≈øtreet upon ≈øtalls of the Prior to them a≈ø≈øigned, and that the Prior ≈øhould have one penny for every ≈øtall every day; and ≈øhewed, that the Defendant had ≈øold in his hou≈øe, whereby the Prior had lo≈øt the advantage and profit of his ≈øtalls there. And the ≈øame was holden a good pre≈øcription. And on the other ≈øide, the Defendant did pre≈øcribe, that he and all hou≈øe-holders of D. had u≈øed to ≈øell in their hou≈øes: The ≈øame was holden a naughty pre≈øcription. See 43 E. 3. 5. and ≈øee al≈øo Suit ad moliendum, upon pre≈øcription without tenure, for peradventure he had not any Mill there before, and now it is an ea≈øe to the neighbours: Vide Regi≈øter 105. where the Writ is, Cum querens habeat ratione Dominii ≈øui apud R. talem libertatem quod nullus in eadem villa uti debeat ≈øeu con≈øuever. Officio, ≈øine My≈øterio tinctoris ≈øine licentia ip≈øius querentis, the ≈øame is good by way of pre≈øcription, but is void by way of grant: And there the Defendant is forbid to u≈øe the trade of his Dye-hou≈øe whithin his Manor without his licence, which appeareth upon the Writ which is in the Regi≈øter (which Regi≈øter was made by the Iudgment and advi≈øe of the grave Iudges of the Law) and there is remedy given for the like ca≈øe, as in the ca≈øe at the Bar. And ≈øee F. B. 122. b. Sectam ad furnam, and although ≈øuch a manner of pre≈øcription ≈øhould bind a ≈øtranger, yet here our ca≈øe is ≈øtronger, for the Defendant is our Tenant. And Hill. 15 Eliz. Rot. 166. an expre≈øs Iudgment was given in ≈øuch ca≈øe for the Plaintiff. Buckley contrary, although here be a lo≈øs to the Plaintiff, yet there is not a wrong, as the ca≈øe in 12 H. 8. 3. If I have an acre of Land adjoyning to your acre, and my acre is drowned, I may make a ≈øluce to carry away the water, and although that by ≈øo doing your acre is drowned, yet I ≈øhall not be puni≈øhed for it, becau≈øe it is lawful for me to make a trench in my own Land, and then if it be any Nu≈øance to you, you may make a trench in your ground, and ≈øo carry away the water until it come to a River or ditch. See the ca≈øe 11 H. 4. of Schoolma≈øters 200. for it is damnum ab≈øque injuria. And it is again≈øt the liberty of the Common-wealth,1 Cro. 112, 113. that liberty of Contracts be not free but re≈øtrained with Priviledges to one only: Vide 22 H. 6. 14. If one erect a Mill neer to my Mill, no Action lieth again≈øt him, for it is for the u≈øe of the Kings Subjects, and God forbid, that Bread and the baking of it ≈øhould be re≈øtrained to any ≈øpecial per≈øon, e≈øpecially in a Market Town. And as to the ca≈øe of the Prior of Dun≈øtable, that is not to the purpo≈øe, for there he pre≈øcribed to have a Market and the correction of it; and the fault there is not in the u≈øurping of a Market in Nu≈øance of the Plaintiff, but becau≈øe the Defendant ≈øold meat there ≈øecretly, ≈øo as the Plaintiff could not have the correction of it. See 22 H. 6. 14. And it is not rea≈øonable, that ≈øuch profits be re≈øtrained and drawn from the publick good to the private commodity of any per≈øon. And he cited a ca≈øe which was ruled in the Exchequer 9 Eliz. upon an Information exhibited there by the Burge≈ø≈øes of Southampton, that the King had granted to the Burge≈ø≈øes of Southam. that all the ≈øweet Wines brought within the Realm ≈øhould be unladen at Southam. only:Grant of the King void. And it was agreed by Wray, that ≈øuch a grant was not good to deprive the Common-wealth of ≈øuch a benefit, and to appropriate it to one, which might be profitable to many: And it was further ≈øaid by the Lord Wray,
that if the King will grant by his Letters Patents, that A.B. ≈øhall be of Coun≈øel only with the Defendant in the Chancery, and C.B. with the Plaintiffs in the Exchequer Chamber, the ≈øame is no good grant, &c.

div.head: CC. Park again≈øt Mo≈øs and How. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Intrat. Hill. 31 Rot. 31.
div.p: Trover and Conver≈øion. 1 Cro. 181. More 352. 1 Roll. 893.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon Trover and Conver≈øion. The Defendant pleaded, that one A. recovered in Debt again≈øt I. P. Executor of E. P. one hundred pounds and twenty pounds in Damages: The Debt of the goods of the Te≈øtator, and the Damages of the goods of the Te≈øtator, ≈øi quae fuerint, and if not, of the goods of the Executor. Vpon which A. procured a Fieri facias directed to the Sheriff of N. who made his Warrant to the Defendants to execute the ≈øaid Writ. And before Execution I. P. died inte≈øtate, and admini≈øtration was committed to the Plaintiff, and the Defendants afterwards did execution of the proper goods of I. P. and ≈øold them, and deliver'd the mony to the Sheriff, which is the ≈øame Trover and Conver≈øion, and averred that E. P. had no other goods. The Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaid, that the Sheriff upon return of the ≈øaid Writ of Execution, returned as to the principal Debt, That the goods of the Te≈øtator were wa≈øted, and as to the Damages that he could not execute the Writ, quia tarde.

Tanfield, I conceive that the fal≈øe return of the Sheriff ≈øhall not make the Defendant puni≈øhable, for they did execution ≈øecundum exigentiam brevis, and delivered the monies coming thereby to the Sheriff; and if they ≈øhould not be excu≈øed it ≈øhould be a great inconvenience, for it is nece≈ø≈øary that the Sheriff have inferiour Officers under him. As 37 H. 6. an Executor named in the Will, named one to take the goods of the Te≈øtator in ≈øuch a place, who did accordingly, and afterwards the Executor doth refu≈øe; yet the ≈øervant ≈øhall not be puni≈øhed for that medling, 13 H. 7. 2. 21 H. 7. 23. Where it is ≈øaid by Read chief Iu≈øtice, that if the Baily delivereth the body of one who he hath taken in Execution to the Sheriff, he ≈øhall be excu≈øed, although that the Sheriff doth not return the Capias; And we have pleaded in this ca≈øe, that we have delivered the mony to the Sheriff, and that is confe≈ø≈øed by the demurrer. Altham, I conceive that this Execution after the death of the party is not good. For an Admini≈øtrator is another per≈øon, wherefore new proce≈øs ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue again≈øt him, as in all ca≈øes where the per≈øon is changed: 18 E. 3. If one ≈øueth a Certificate out of a Statute, and before execution had he dieth, his Executors ≈øhall not have execution upon that Certificate, but fir≈øt they ought to have a Scire facias: And 28 H. 8. Dyer 29. Tran≈øcript of a Fine is removed by the Ance≈øtor out of the Trea≈øury into the Chancery, and comes in by Mittimus to have execution, and the Ance≈øtor dieth before Execution; Now the Heir cannot proceed without a new Mittimus, for he is another per≈øon. See 36 H. 8. Br. Statute Merchant 43. and in our ca≈øe here, at the time of the Execution the≈øe are not the goods of the Executor, for he is not in e≈ø≈øe, and it ought to appear who≈øe goods they are which are taken in Execution: If Lands be recovered again≈øt the Father who dieth, and the Heir be ou≈øted by Execution, without a Scire facias again≈øt the Heir, he ≈øhall have an A≈ø≈øi≈øe. And 6 E. 6. Dyer 76. is our ca≈øe. A. is condemned in Debt, and a Fieri facias is awarded, and before execution A. dieth inte≈øtate: The Sheriff levyed the Debt upon the goods of the Inte≈øtate in the hands of the Admini≈øtrators; upon which the Admini≈øtrators brought Error and rever≈øed the Execution. Tanfield, The Execution is erronious, but is not void, but ≈øhall ≈øtand until it be rever≈øed by Error. And it was holden by the whole Court, that the fal≈øe return of the Sheriff ≈øhould not prejudice the Defendants: At another day it was moved again, and it was holden, that the averment, that the goods put in
Execution were the goods of the Te≈øtator the day of the Writ of Execution ≈øued, was a good averment without ≈øaying,Execution again≈øt an Admini≈øtrator, after the death of the Inte≈øtate of the Inte≈øtates goods; good. Execution ≈øhall relate to the date of the Writ. 3 Cro. 106, 330 1 Roll. 893. The day of Execution done, for the award of the Writ of Execution ≈øhall bind all his goods again≈øt whom the Iudgment was given which he had at the day of the Writ of Execution awarded. And it was al≈øo holden, That notwith≈øtanding the death of the party again≈øt whom, &c. The Sheriff might do execution of the goods of the dead in the hands of his Executors, according to the opinion of Bryan. 16 H. 7. 6. and afterwards in the principal Ca≈øe Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCI. Carie and Denis Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was; Vpon a Latitat, the Sheriff returned,Retorn of the Sheriff. That by vertue of the ≈øaid proce≈øs he had arre≈øted the Body of the Defendant, and that ≈øuch a day after, and before the Return of the Latitat, a Habeas Corpus came to him to bring the body immediately into the Chancery, which was done accordingly, and there the Pri≈øoner was di≈øcharged by the Order of the ≈øaid Court: And the ≈øame was holden a good Return, for the Sheriff is bound to obey the Kings Writs, and to execute them, and he cannot compel the party to put in Sureties to appear here: And the truth was, That the party was brought before the Ma≈øter of the Rolls, and he did di≈øcharge him. And per Curiam, the ≈øame is no offence in the Court; but it was an ill act of the Ma≈øter of the Rolls: For we oftentimes have per≈øons here upon Habeas Corpus who are al≈øo arre≈øted by Proce≈øs out of the Exchequer, or of the Common Pleas, but we will not di≈øcharge them before they have found Sureties for their appearance, &c. and ≈øo the ≈øaid Courts u≈øe to do reciprocally: and we cannot puni≈øh the Sheriff, for the Hebas Corpus was fir≈øt returnable before the Latitat, but the party may have an action again≈øt the Sheriff, but we will ≈øpeak with the Ma≈øter of the Rolls, &c. and afterwards Baill was put in. But afterwards another Exception was taken to the Return: ≈øcil. a cu≈øtodia no≈øtra exoneratus fuit, which might be intended as to the Cau≈øe in the Chancery only, and not for the Cau≈øe here, for he hath not alledged, that he hath not alledged, That he was committed to any other in cu≈øtody, and for that cau≈øe day was given to the Sheriff to amend his Return.

div.head:
CCII. Upton and Wells Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Ejectione firmae by Upton again≈øt Wells, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, and upon the habere facias po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem, The Sheriff retuned that in the Execution of the ≈øaid Writ he took the Plaintiff with him, and came to the hou≈øe recovered, and removed thereout a woman, and two children, which were all the per≈øons which upon diligent ≈øearch, he could find in the ≈øaid hou≈øe, and delivered to the Plaintiff peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to his thinking, and afterwards departed, and immediately after three other per≈øons which were ≈øecretly lodged in the ≈øaid hou≈øe expul≈øed the Plaintiff again:2 Len. 12, 13. Latch. 165. upon notice of which he returned again to the ≈øaid hou≈øe to put the Plaintiff in full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but the other did re≈øi≈øt him, ≈øo as without peril of his life, and of them that were with him in company he could not do it. And upon this Return the Court awarded a new Writ of execution, for that the ≈øame was no Execution of the fir≈øt Writ, and al≈øo awarded an Attachment again≈øt the parties.

div.head:
CCIII. Mar≈øh and A≈øtreys Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 175. MAr≈øh brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt A≈øtrey, and declared, That he had procured a Writ of Entry ≈øur di≈ø≈øei≈øin again≈øt one A. and thereupon had a ≈øummons for Lands in London, and delivered the ≈øaid Summons to A≈øtrey being Vnder-Sheriff of the ≈øame County; virtute cujus, the ≈øaid A≈øtrey ≈øummoned the ≈øaid A. upon the Land, but notwith≈øtanding that did not return the ≈øaid Summons. A≈øtrey pleaded Not guilty; And it was tryed in London, where the action was brought for the Plaintiff; and it was moved by Cook in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That here is a mi≈ø-trial, for this i≈ø≈øue ought to be tryed in the County where the Land is, becau≈øe that the cau≈øe is local; but the Exception was not allowed, for the action is well layed in London, and ≈øo the trial there al≈øo is good.Trial. Another Exception was moved becau≈øe the action ought to be again≈øt the Sheriff him≈øelf, and not again≈øt the Vnder-Sheriff, for the Sheriff is the Officer to the Court, and all Returns are in his Name; and I grant that an action for any fal≈øity or deceit lyeth again≈øt the Vnder-Sheriff, as for embe≈ø≈øeling, ra≈øing of Writs, &c. but upon Non fea≈øans, as the Ca≈øe is here, the not Retorn of the Summons, it ought to be brought again≈øt the Sheriff him≈øelf. See 41 E. 3. 12. And if the Vnder-Sheriff take one in Execution, and ≈øuffereth him to e≈øcape, debt lyeth again≈øt the Sheriff him≈øelf. Another Exception was taken becau≈øe the Declaration is that the ≈øaid A≈øtrey Intendens & machinans ip≈øum querent. in actione ≈øua praedict. pro≈øequend. impedire, &c. did not retorn the ≈øaid Summons, but doth not ≈øay, tunc exi≈øt. Vnder-Sheriff. Snag, contrary, If a Baily Errant of the Sheriff, take one in Execution, and he ≈øuffer him to e≈øcape, an action lieth again≈øt the Baily him≈øelf. And that was agreed in the Ca≈øe of a Baily of Middle≈øex, and Sir Richard Dyer Sheriff of Huntington, and his Vnder-Sheriff, who ≈øuffered a Pri≈øoner to e≈øcape, & the action was brought again≈øt the Vnder-Sheriff; for it may be the Sheriff him≈øelf had not notice of the matter, becau≈øe the Writ was delivered to the Vnder-Sheriff, and he took a Fee for it, and therefore it is rea≈øon that he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed. As if a Clerk in an Office mi≈ø-enter any thing, he him≈øelf ≈øhall be puni≈øhed, and not the Ma≈øter of the Office, becau≈øe he takes a fee for it. But if the Retorn made by the Baily be in≈øufficient, Then the Sheriff him≈øelf ≈øhall be amerced; but in the principal ca≈øe it is clear, That the action lieth again≈øt the Vnder-Sheriff if the party will, and ≈øuch was the opinion of Gawdy and Clench: As to the other matter, becau≈øe it is not alledged in the Declaration, That the Defendant was Vnder-Sheriff at the time, the Declaration is good enough notwith≈øtanding that, for ≈øo are all the Pre≈øidents, and if the Defendant were not Vnder-Sheriff the ≈øame ≈øhall come in of the other ≈øide. See 21 E. 4. 23. And afterwards in the principal Ca≈øe, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCIV. Hedd and Chaloners Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
1 Cro. 176. 2 Roll. 42. 176.IN an Ejectione firmae by Hedd again≈øt Chaloner upon a Demi≈øe for years of Jane Berd, It was found by e≈øpecial Verdict, That William Berd was ≈øei≈øed in fee, & made a Feoffment to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, & afterward to the u≈øe of his two Daughters Joan & Alice in fee, and died, and Joan entred
into the Land, and by Indenture by the name of Jane Berd, lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Plaintiff for three years. And it was further found; That Joan intended in the Feoffment, and Jane who lea≈øed, are one and the ≈øame per≈øon. Wray, It hath been agreed here upon good advice and Conference with Grammarians, that Joan and Jane are but one Name. And Women becau≈øe (Joan) ≈øeems to them a homely name, would not be called Joan but Jane: But admit that they were ≈øeveral Names, Then he and Gawdy were of opinion, it ≈øhould not be good: But afterwards, it was ≈øaid by Gawdy, That this action is not grounded meerly upon the Indenture, but upon the Demi≈øe, and that is the ≈øub≈øtance, and the Indenture is but to enforce it, ≈øci. the lea≈øe, 44 E. 3. 42. Another matter was moved here, the remainder was limited to Joan and Alice in fee, by which they are Ioint Tenants, and then when one of them enters, the ≈øame ve≈øts the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in them both; Then by the demi≈øe of Joan a moyety pa≈ø≈øeth only to the Plaintiff. Wray, Here the Term is incurred, and the Plaintiff is to recover damages only, and no title at all is found for the Defendant, and ≈øo there is no cau≈øe but that Iudgment ≈øhould be given for the Plaintiff; and thereupon Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCV. Read and Na≈øhes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs by Read and his Wife again≈øt Na≈øh, for entring into a hou≈øe called the Dayry-hou≈øe; upon Not guilty pleaded, The Iury found this ≈øpecial matter, Sir Richard Gre≈øham Knight, was ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Mannours of I. and S. and of diver≈øe other Lands mentioned in his Will, and 3 Edw. 6. devi≈øed the ≈øame to Sir Thomas Gre≈øham his Son for life, the Remainder to the fir≈øt ≈øon of the ≈øaid Sir Thomas Gre≈øham in tail, the Remainder to the ≈øecond ≈øon, &c. the Remainder to the third ≈øon, &c. The Remainder to Sir John Gre≈øham his brother; Provi≈øo, That if his Son go about or made any Alienations or di≈øcontinuance, &c. whereby the premi≈ø≈øes cannot remain, de≈øcend and come, in the form as was appointed by the ≈øaid Will, otherwi≈øe than for Ioyntures for any of their Wives for her life only or lea≈øes for 21. years, whereupon the old and accu≈øtomed Rent ≈øhall be re≈øerved, That then ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhall forfeit his e≈øtate. Sir John Gre≈øham dyed; Sir Thomas Gre≈øham his ≈øon built a new Hou≈øe upon the Land, and, 4 Mariae, lea≈øed to Bellingford for one and twenty years, rendring the antient Rent. And afterwards 2 Eliz. he levyed a fine of the ≈øaid Manours and of all his Lands: and 5 Eliz. he made a Iointure to his Wife in this manner, ≈øci. He covenanted with certain per≈øons to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of him≈øelf, and his Wife for their lives, and afterwards to the u≈øe of his Right Heirs, and afterwards, 18 Eliz. he lea≈øed unto Read and his wife for one and twenty years to begin pre≈øently (which was a year before the expiration of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe made unto Bellingford;) which Lea≈øe being expired, Read entred. It was argued by Cook, That here, upon the words contained in the Provi≈øo, Sir Thomas had power and authority, not being but Tenant for life, to make a Lea≈øe for years, or Iointure, and that upon implication of the Will, which ought to be taken & con≈øtrued according to the intent of the parties; for his meaning was to give a power, as well as an e≈øtate, otherwi≈øe the word (otherwi≈øe) ≈øhould be void; and it is to be ob≈øerved, That the parties intere≈ø≈øed in the ≈øaid conveyance were Knights, and it is not very likely, That the ≈øaid Sir Richard Gre≈øham did intend, that they ≈øhould keep the Lands in their own manurance as Husbandmen, but ≈øet the ≈øame to Farm for Rent. And it is great Rea≈øon, although he wille ‚Ä¢
that the order of his Inheritance ≈øhould be pre≈øerved, yet to make a Provi≈øion for Iointure; and it is great rea≈øon and cau≈øe to his family to enable and make them capable of great Matches, which ≈øhould be a ≈øtrengthning to his po≈øterity, which could not be without great Iointures, wherefore I conceive it rea≈øonable to con≈øtrue it ≈øo, That here they have power to make Iointures for their Wives. It hath been ≈øaid, That no grant can be taken by implication, as 12 E. 3. Tit. Avow. 77. Land was given to I. and A. his wife, and to the heirs of the body of I. begotten: and if I. & A. dy without heir of their bodies, betwixt them begotten, that then it remain to the right heirs of I. and it was holden that the ≈øecond clau≈øe did not give an e≈øtate tail to the wife, by implication being in a grant, but otherwi≈øe it is in Ca≈øe of a devi≈øe, as 13 H. 7. 17. (and there is no difference) as ≈øome conceive (when the devi≈øe is to the heir, and when to a ≈øtranger) but the≈øe ca≈øes concern matter of Intere≈øt, but our ca≈øe concerns an Authority: And admit that Sir Thomas hath power and authority to make this lea≈øe, Then we are to con≈øider if the Iointure be good, for if it be, Then being made before the Lea≈øe,U≈øe cannot ri≈øe out of a power. it ≈øhall take effect before, and the woman Iointre≈øs is found to be alive. But I conceive, That this Iointure is void, and then the Lea≈øe ≈øhall ≈øtand, for an u≈øe cannot ri≈øe out of a power, but may ri≈øe out of an e≈øtate of the Te≈øtator, and out of his Will, 19 H. 6. A man devi≈øeth, That his Executors ≈øhall ≈øell his rever≈øion, and they ≈øell by Word, it is a good Sale, for now the Rever≈øion pa≈ø≈øeth by the Will. But an u≈øe cannot be rai≈øed out of an u≈øe, and a man cannot bargain, and ≈øell Land to another u≈øe than of the Bargainee. And it is like unto the ca≈øe of 10 E. 4, 5. The di≈ø≈øei≈øee doth relea≈øe unto the di≈ø≈øei≈øor rendring Rent, the render is void, for a rent cannot i≈ø≈øue out of a right, ≈øo an u≈øe cannot be out of a Relea≈øe by the di≈ø≈øei≈øee, for ≈øuch relea≈øe to ≈øuch purpo≈øe ≈øhall not enure as an Entry and Feoffment: Al≈øo here after that conveyance Sir Thomas hath built and erected a New hou≈øe, and no new Rent is re≈øerved upon it, and therefore here it is not the ancient Rent, for part of the ≈øum is going out of the new hou≈øe. But as to that, It was ≈øaid by the Iu≈øtices, do not ≈øpeak to that, for it appears that the Rent is well enough re≈øerved. Another matter was moved for that, That a year before the Expiration of the Lea≈øe made to Billington, this Lea≈øe was made to Re ‚Ä¢ d for 21 years to begin pre≈øently from the date of it; although by the ≈øame authority he cannot make Lea≈øes in Rever≈øion, for then he might charge the Inheritance in infinitum. But yet ≈øuch a Lea≈øe as here is he might make well enough, for this Lea≈øe is to begin pre≈øently, and ≈øo no charge to him in the Rever≈øion, as in the Ca≈øe betwixt Fox and Colliers, upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. A Bi≈øhop makes a Lea≈øe for three years before the Expiration of a former Lea≈øe, to begin pre≈øently, It was holden a good Lea≈øe to bind the Succe≈ø≈øor, for the Inheritance of the Bi≈øhop is not charged above one and twenty years in toto. But if a Bi≈øhop make a Lea≈øe for years, and afterwards makes a Lea≈øe for three lives, the ≈øame is not good, 8 Eliz. Dy. 246. Tenant in tail lea≈øeth to begin at Michaelmas next en≈øuing, for twenty years, it is a good Lea≈øe by the Statute of 32 H. 8. ≈øo is a lea≈øe for 10 years, and after for eleven years, and yet the Statutes are in the Negative, but this power in our Ca≈øe is in the Affirmative; and the Inheritance is not charged in the whole with more than one and twenty years.

div.head:
CCVI. Kinner≈øly and Smarts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
„Äà‚óä„Äâ upon a u≈øurious Contract. 1 Cro 155.IN Debt upon a Bond, The Plaintiff declared, That the Bond was made in London; The Defendant pleaded, That an u≈øurious Contract
was made betwixt the parties at D. in Stafford-≈øhire, & that the Obligation was made for the ≈øame contract. The Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaith, that the Bond was made bona fide, & non pro u≈øura, and that I≈ø≈øue was tryed in the County of Stafford, and was found for the Plaintiff: And it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that that I≈ø≈øue ought to be tryed in London, where the contract was made. Gawdy conceived, that the tryal is well, As 8 E. 3. 8. In debt upon an Obligation in London, the Defendant pleaded, that the Obligation was made by dure≈ø≈øe at York, the ≈øame I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall be tryed at York. At another day the ca≈øe was put more certain, ≈øcil. that the contract was made at W. in Stafford-≈øhire, by which it was agreed, that for a Hor≈øe and two Tun of Iron, the Plaintiff ≈øhould have for them and the forbearing of the mony for ≈øuch a ≈ømall time fifty pounds; whereas in truth they were but of the value of forty pounds,Tryal. and that the ≈øaid Bond was made for the payment of the ≈øaid fifty pounds. Cook, The I≈ø≈øue is well tryed, for the ground of the matter is the u≈øurious contract, and tho≈øe of Stafford-≈øhire may better know it than they of London. And according to this Tryal it hath been before adjudged. H. 28. Eliz. rot. 209. Betwixt Sybthorpe and Turner. And P. 31. Eliz. rot. 303. betwixt Payne and Wilken≈øon, where the I≈ø≈øue was, ab≈øque hoc, that it was a corrupt agreement, but the pleading was, ut ≈øupra. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCVII. The Queen and Buckberds Ca≈øe.
Trin. 36 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
THe Queen recovered again≈øt Buckberd in a Quare Impedit; Quare Impedit. 1 Cro. 162. and thereupon a Writ of Error was brought, and it was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that the Queen, po≈øt tempus ≈øeme≈øtre, had Iudgment to recover damages for the value of the Church for half a year. Cook, The ≈øame is no Error, as it was adjudged, 7 Eliz. 236. See al≈øo 34 H. 6. 51. And the≈øe damages are not as damages, but as a penalty inflicted upon the di≈øturbance. See Book of Entries, 483. The King in a Quare Impedit counted to his damage of forty pounds, and 484. 1000 li. and although, tempus ≈øeme≈øtre tran≈øierit, yet the King ≈øhall recover damages, but the value of the Church for half a year, for the King at all times may pre≈øent in his own right; for nullum tempus occurrit Regi. Damages in a Quare Impedit where by King, & e contra. At another day it was moved by Fenner Serjeant, and he conceived, that here the Queen is not to recover damages, for ≈øhe doth not pre≈øent in her own right, for the Incumbent had two Benefices without Qualifications, & therefore the fir≈øt was void, and the Lap≈øe encurred, and therefore the Queen did pre≈øent in the right of the Crown, and ≈øo is not verus Patronus. 14 E. 3. Quare Impedit 54. The King ≈øhall not recover damages, although he count of damages, 3 H. 6. Damages 17. And as to the ca≈øe of 7 Eliz. it doth not appear there, that the King did pre≈øent by rea≈øon of his Prerogative, & he ≈øhewed divers Pre≈øidents, that the King ≈øhall not recover damages in ≈øuch ca≈øe. P. 7. H. 5. rot. 402. 2 H. 6. rot. 316. For the Statute was intended to give damages to the very Patron, and not otherwi≈øe. Cook, Where the King pre≈øents by Lap≈øe he is verus Patronus hac vice, as Grantee of the next Avoidance: Vide T.E. 1. Quare Impedit 181. The King recovered damages in the ca≈øe of a Prior. Godfrey ≈øaid, he had ≈øearched the Roll of 7 Eliz. and there is more reported in the Book than is in the Roll, for Iudgment is given for the Pre≈øentee, but as for the damages, the Court would advi≈øe of it. Gawdy, It is clear, that the Queen ≈øhall not recover double damages,Where only ≈øingle damages. for ≈øhe cannot lo≈øe her pre≈øentment, quia nullum tempus occurrit, and becau≈øe eo quod tempus ≈øeme≈øtre tran≈øierit, but ≈øhe ≈øhall have ≈øingle damages, for they are
given for the wrong and di≈øturbance, and not for the pre≈øentment; and therefore the damages are well awarded. Wray, If the King be not within one part of the Statute (as it is agreed as to the double damages) it is hard that he be within the other branch.

Popham Attorney general, The Queen ought to recover damages, but only ≈øingle damages, but not double damages; and the words of the Statute are general, therefore the Queen ≈øhall have the benefit of it, and of all Statutes made for the benefit of the Subjects, the King ≈øhall take advantage: The Statute of Glouce≈øter gives damages in a Writ of Co≈øinage, Ai ‚Ä¢
and Be≈øail, and the King brings an Action upon the ≈øei≈øin of his Ance≈øtors, he ≈øhall recover damages, and in con≈øtruction of Statutes, the opinions of them which were next to the making of them is to be much re≈øpected: Vide 19 E. 2. Rot. 90, 19 E. 1. Rot. 255, 231, 136. And always the King counts to his damage, &c. and that ≈øhould be in vain, if he ≈øhould not recover damages: And as to the Pre≈øidents ≈øhewed to the contrary, that was the default of tho≈øe Clerks which the King had pre≈øented; and when in a Quare Impedit the King had prevailed, they contented them≈øelves with the Incumbency without regard of the damages: But if damages be not to be given, yet the Iudgment to recover the pre≈øentment is not erronious. And the Iudgment only as to the giving of damages ≈øhall be rever≈øed, and the Defendant in the Quare Impedit here ≈øhall not a≈ø≈øign the ≈øame for Error, becau≈øe no damages are given,5 Co. 58. for it is for his advantage. And always where it is found for the Queen in a Quare Impedit, they enquire of the value of the Church,A man ≈øhall not a≈ø≈øign for error, that which is for his advantage. which ≈øhould be a trivolous thing, if the Queen ≈øhould not recover damages. Gawdy, Of things tran≈øitorie the Queen may be di≈øturbed, and if ≈øhe be, wherefore ≈øhall ≈øhe not recover damages? but the doubt is, if the intent of the Statute be, if the party ≈øhall have ≈øingle damages in any ca≈øe: And here in this ca≈øe the Iudgment is one and entire, and if it be rever≈øed in part it ≈øhall be rever≈øed in the whole; as in Dower, the Tenant pleads, that he is always ready, &c. the Demandant ≈øhall have Iudgment to recover her Dower, and a Writ ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue forth to enquire of the damages. And ≈øee al≈øo 17 E. 3. In an A≈ø≈øize of Darrein pre≈øentment, the Plaintiff had Iudgment to have a Writ to the Bi≈øhop: And the A≈ø≈øize was taken after for the damages: And in the mean time the Defendant brought a Writ of Error, and it was holden maintainable, for they are ≈øeveral Iudgments; but it is not ≈øo here, for the Entry is, Quod querens habeat bre. Epi≈øcopo, & quia ne≈øcitur quae damna, &c. for it is one Iudgment.

Wray, It is but one Statute, and therefore it ≈øhall be con≈øtrued with one con≈øtruction, and it ≈øhould be a ≈øtrange con≈øtruction, that the King ≈øhould be within one part of the Statute, and out of the other. And 34 H. 6. 3. The Kings Attorney could not have damages, which is a great proof and authority, that the Iudgment for damages in ≈øuch ca≈øe is Error: The experience and u≈øage of Law is ≈øufficient to interpret the ≈øame to us, and from the time of E. 3. until now, no damages have been given in ≈øuch ca≈øe. Thrice this matter hath been in que≈øtion, 1. 3 H. 9. and the Iu≈øtices there would not give damages, 34 H. 6. there the Councel learned of the King, could not have damages for the King. And 7 Eliz. there was no damages: And whereas it hath been ≈øaid, that a man ≈øhall not have a Writ of Error, where Iudgment is given for his benefit, that if Iudgment be entred that the Defendant be in Mi≈øericordia, where it ought to be, Capiatur, yet the Defendant ≈øhall have a Writ of Error. And he conceived al≈øo, that here is but one Iudgment: Clench, The fir≈øt Pre≈øident after the making of that Statute was, that damages were given for the King in ≈øuch ca≈øe; but afterwards the practice was always otherwi≈øe, & that the ≈øaid Statute could not be con≈øtrued, to give in ≈øuch ca≈øe damages, & the rea≈øon was becau≈øe the Iu≈øtices took the Law to be otherwi≈øe: And the King
is not within the Statute of 32 H. 8. of buying of Tythes, nor any Subjects who buy any title of him: And here in our ca≈øe, the Queen is not verus Patronus but hath this pre≈øentment, by Prerogative: And if title do accrue to the Bi≈øhop to pre≈øent for Lap≈øe, yet the Patron is verus Patronus.

At another day the ca≈øe was moved, and it was ≈øaid by VVray, that he had conferred with Ander≈øon, Manwood, and Periam, who held, that the Queen could not have damages in this ca≈øe, but Periam ≈øomewhat doubted of it. Gawdy, In 22 E. 4. 46. In Dower the Demandant recovered her Dower, and damages by verdict, and afterwards for the damages the Iudgment was rever≈øed, and ≈øtood for the Lands. Clench, It ≈øhall be rever≈øed for all, for there is but one Iudgment. And afterwards Iudgment was given, and that the Queen ≈øhould have a Writ to the Bi≈øhop and damages. Popham, The Court ought not to proceed to the examination of the Errors, without a Petition to the Queen, and that was the ca≈øe of one Mordant, where an Infant levyed a Fine to the Queen, and thereupon brought a Writ of Error, and afterwards by the Re≈øolution of all the Iudges, the proceedings thereupon were ≈øtayed. See 10 H. 4. 148. a good ca≈øe.

div.head:
CCVIII. Chapman and Hur≈øts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: BEtwixt Chapman and Hur≈øt, Tythes. the Defendant did libel in the ≈øpiritual Court, for Tythes again≈øt the Plaintiff, who came and ≈øurmi≈øed, that whereas he held certain Lands by the Lea≈øe of Sir Ralph Sadler for term of years within ≈øuch a Pari≈øh, that the now Defendant being Farmor of the Rectory there: The Defendant, in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff promi≈øed and agreed to pay to the Defendant ten pounds per annum, during the Term, for his Tythes, he promi≈øed, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould hold his ≈øaid Land without Tythes, and without any ≈øute for the ≈øame, and thereupon prayed a Prohibition: And by Gawdy; the ≈øame is a good di≈øcharge of the Tythes for the time, and a good Compo≈øition to have a Prohibition upon; and it is not like unto a Covenant. See 8 E. 4. 14. by Danby.

div.head:
CCIX. Kirdler and Lever≈øages Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Avowry the ca≈øe was,Avowry. 1 Cro. 241. that A. ≈øei≈øed of Lands lea≈øed the ≈øame at Will, rendring rent ten pounds per annum, and afterwards granted eundem redditum, by another deed to a ≈øtranger for life, and afterwards the lea≈øe at will is determined. Periam was of opinion, that the Rent did continue; and although that the words be, eundem redditum, yet it is not to be intended, eundem numero, ≈øed eundem ≈øpecie, ≈øo as he ≈øhall have ≈øuch a Rent, ≈øcil. ten pounds per annum: As where the King grants to ≈øuch a Town, ea≈ødem libertates quas Civitas Che≈øter habet, it ≈øhall be intended ≈øuch Liberties, and not the ≈øame Liberties, ≈øo in the principal ca≈øe: Al≈øo he held, that a Rent at will cannot be granted for life, and therefore it ≈øhall not be meant the ≈øame Rent: But it was afterwards adjudged, that the Rent was well granted for the life of the Grantee.

div.head:
CCX. Heayes and Alleyns Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Cui in vita. 1 Cro. 234. Poph. 13. HEayes brought a ≈øur cui in vita again≈øt Alleyn. And the ca≈øe was this, The Di≈øcontinuee of a Me≈ø≈øuage, had other Lands of good and indefe≈øible title adjoining to it, and demoli≈øht and abated the ≈øaid hou≈øe, and built another which was larger, ≈øo as part of it extended upon his own Land, to which he had good title. And afterwards the heir brought a ≈øur cui in vita, and demanded the hou≈øe by the Name of a Me≈ø≈øuage, whereas part of the hou≈øe did extend into the Land to which he had no right. And by Periam, The Writ ought to be of a Me≈ø≈øuage with an Exception of ≈øo much of the hou≈øe which was erected upon the ≈øoil of the Tenant,Demand, and the manner of it, in a writ. as demand of a Me≈ø≈øuage except a Chamber: And it was argued by Yelverton, That the Writ ought to abate, for if the Demandant ≈øhall have Iudgment according to his Writ, then it ≈øhall be entred quod petens recuperet Me≈ø≈øuagium, which ≈øhould be Erronious, for it appeareth by the verdict it ≈øelf, that the demandant hath not title to part of it; and therefore he ought to have demanded it ≈øpecially 5 H. 7. 9. parcel of Land, containing 10 Feet. 16 E. 3. Br. Mortdanc. of a piece of Land containing ≈øo much in breadth, and ≈øo much in length. And the moyetie of two parts of a Me≈ø≈øuage, and 33 E. 3. br. Entrie 8. a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor of a Mar≈øh ground made Meadow of it; Now in a Writ of Entry it ≈øhall be demanded for Meadow. Drue Serjeant contrary, and he confe≈ø≈øed the Ca≈øes put before, and that every thing ≈øhall be demanded by Writ in ≈øuch ≈øort, as it is at the time of the action brought: as a Writ of Dower is brought of two Mills, whereas during the Coverture they were but 2 Tofts; but at the day of the Writ brought, Mills; and therefore ≈øhall be demanded by the name of Mills, 14 H. 4. 33. Dower 21. 13 H. 4. 33. 175. 1 H. 5. 11. Walme≈øly, part of a M≈ø≈øeuage may be demanded by the Name of a Me≈ø≈øuage: and if a Hou≈øe de≈øcend to two Coparceners, if they make partition that one of them ≈øhall have the upper Chamber, and the other the lower, here if they be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, they ≈øhall have ≈øeveral A≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øes, and each of them ≈øhall make his plaint of a Me≈ø≈øuage; and by him a Chamber may be demanded by the name of a hou≈øe. And afterwards the Writ was awarded good, but a ≈øpecial Iudgment was given, ita quod querens recuperet Me≈ø≈øuagium praedict. viz. ≈øo many feet in length, and ≈øo many in breadth, according to that which was found by the Verdict.

div.head:
CCXI. Degory and Roes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Debt. DEgory brought Debt upon an Obligation again≈øt Roe, as heir to his Ance≈øtor, The defendant pleaded, That his Ance≈øtor by his deed did covenant with Sir W. Winter, and A. Mar≈øh, to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of the Defendant and his heirs, and ≈øo he had nothing by de≈øcent. The Plaintiff replicando ≈øaid, non convenit; and it was found by ≈øpecial verdict That ≈øuch a deed of Covenant was made by the Ance≈øtor of the Defendant, but the fir≈øt u≈øe was limited to the Covenantor and his wife, for their Lives, &c. And that he delivered the ≈øame to I. S. as his deed, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Sir W. VVinter, and the ≈øaid Mar≈øh, if the ≈øaid Sir W. VVinter would agree to the ≈øame, and take the charge of it upon him, and if he will not agree, That then it ≈øhould not be his deed, and
further found, That Sir W. Winter died before any agreement; and it was moved by Periam, If the ≈øame be pre≈øently the Deed of the Ance≈øtor, or if it do not take effect till the condition be performed, ≈øci. until Sir W. Winter hath agreed to it. See 14. H. 8. 17, 18, 19, 20, 23. And by Walme≈øly, Deeds, when to take effect.
