The ≈øame is not the Deed of the Ance≈øtor until Sir William hath agreed; But by Ander≈øon and Periam, although Sir William Winter doth not agree to it, yet it is the deed of Roe; for although a deed be upon condition, ut ≈øupra, yet becau≈øe he delivered it as his deed, and the Condition is ≈øub≈øequent to it, It ≈øhall be taken for his deed, and the condition after ≈øhall be void, becau≈øe repugnant: For although that in E≈øtates limited to men, the e≈øtate may be precedent, and the condition ≈øub≈øequent, & the not performance of the condition may de≈øtroy the e≈øtate, for the e≈øtate is always ≈øubject to the condition, yet it is not ≈øo in Deeds, for being once the deed of the party, it can never cea≈øe to be his deed, after it is once delivered as his deed, Owen, Although the ≈øame be the deed of the party, yet it is not well pleaded; & he conceived the i≈ø≈øue is found again≈øt him, for the Covenant is pleaded, to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed unto the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, the Remainder over: To which the Plaintiff Replicando ≈øaith, non convenit, ≈øo as the I≈ø≈øue is, if any ≈øuch Deed of Covenant was, and the Iury find, That the Covenant was to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of him≈øelf, and his wife, &c. ≈øo as it is not ≈øuch a Deed as the Defendant hath pleaded, for other e≈øtates are limitted by it, and therefore it ≈øhall not be intended the ≈øame Deed. Periam, The ≈øame is not material, for the ≈øub≈øtance of the Plea is, Nothing by de≈øcent, &c. and it was adjourned.

div.head:
CCXII. The Scholars of All-≈øouls in Oxford, and Tamworths Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Writ of Night by the Colledge of All-≈øouls in Oxford again≈øt Tamworth: Writ of Right 1 Cro. 232. the Writ was, Quod clamat tenere de nobis in liberam puram et perpetuam Elemo≈øinam. And exeception was taken to it, becau≈øe it ought to be in liberam Eleemo≈øinam, ≈øans pura & perpetua, al≈øo it ought to be Eleemo≈øina, with a Double e, and not Elemo≈øina, with a ≈øingle e, but the exception was not allowed. For as to the fir≈øt Exception, it is but ≈øurplu≈øage, and as to the other, It is the common cour≈øe. Another exception was taken to the Writ, becau≈øe the words are quod clamat e≈ø≈øe jus & haereditatem ≈øuam, without ≈øaying in jure Collegii. Ander≈øon, The Writ is good enough. If a Par≈øon plead that he is ≈øei≈øed, he ≈øhall ≈øay in jure Eccle≈øiae, for he hath two capacities, and without ≈øuch words here ≈øhall be intended ≈øei≈øed in his own Right: But if an Abbot plead that he was ≈øei≈øed, there needs not ≈øuch words, for he hath no other capacity; ≈øo of Dean and Chapter, Mayor and Comminalty: And afterwards, the Writ was awarded good, and that the Tenant ≈øhould an≈øwer over, &c. See Book Entries 236, 237. It was al≈øo moved, If the Colledge ≈øhall count of its ≈øei≈øin within 30 years, becau≈øe that the Corporation never dies, and then if he count of its own po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the ≈øame is without limitation. And it was holden, that if the Guardian of the Colledge which now is, was ever ≈øei≈øed, he ought to count upon a ≈øei≈øin within thirty years; But upon the ≈øei≈øin of his Predece≈ø≈øor he ought to count of a ≈øei≈øin within 60 years as another common per≈øon; for the change of the Te≈øte of ≈øuch a ≈øei≈øin, is as the dying ≈øei≈øed, and de≈øcent of a common per≈øon.

div.head: CCXIII. The Lord Buckhur≈øt and the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øters Ca≈øe. Trin. 31 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Quare Impedit.THe Lord Buckhur≈øt brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Winc. and counted, that he was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. to which the Advow≈øon was appendant, and that the ≈øaid Church became void, and that he pre≈øented Maurice Sackvil his Clark. The Defendant pleaded, that he was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Advow≈øon, as in gro≈øs, and pre≈øented one Maurice Sackvil, ab≈øque hoc, that the Advow≈øon was appendant. It was moved, that the Defendant ought to traver≈øe the Pre≈øentment, and not the Appendancy, e≈øpecially as the cau≈øe is here, where they both pre≈øent one and the ≈øame per≈øon: To which it was ≈øaid, that that doth not appear, for the Defendant hath pleaded, that he pre≈øented Maurice Sackvil, but doth not ≈øay, praedict, Maurice Sackvil, ≈øo as it may be he is not the ≈øame per≈øon, but another. See 10 H. 7. 27. The Traver≈øe is well taken; contrary where the Plaintiff declares of an Advow≈øon in gro≈øs, and that he to the ≈øame pre≈øented, and the Defendant pleadeth, that he is ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch a Manor to which the Advow≈øon is appendant, &c. without that, that the Advow≈øon is in gro≈øs, there he ≈øhall traver≈øe the pre≈øentment, for the pre≈øentment ≈øhall make it in gro≈øs. See 13 H. 8. 12.

div.head:
CCXIV. Jennings and Winches Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: A≈ø≈øump≈øit.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe by Jennings again≈øt Winch. The Plaintiff declared upon an A≈ø≈øump≈øit by the Defendant, 1 Maii. 32. Eliz. and counted upon a Mutuatus for twenty ≈øhillings, and an Indebitatus for four pounds. The Defendant pleaded, that he being endebted to the Plaintiff in five pounds, and W. S. in another five pounds, they became bounden to the Plaintiff in twenty pounds for the payment of ten pounds in ≈øatisfaction of the ≈øaid ≈øum of five pounds, and five pounds, and that the Obligation was ≈øealed before the day of the A≈ø≈øump≈øit ≈øuppo≈øed, and added, that the ≈øame is the ≈øame debt, and that the Obligation was made for the ≈øame debt. And by the opinion of the whole Court, the ≈øame cannot be a good plea, for an Obligation cannot deraign a Contract or an A≈ø≈øump≈øit afterwards made. And the truth of the matter was, that the Obligation was made after the A≈ø≈øump≈øit, although that the Plaintiff declared of an A≈ø≈øump≈øit made after. And in that ca≈øe it was holden, that the Defendant might plead the ≈øpecial matter; that the Obligation was made after the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øump≈øit, ab≈øque hoc, that he A≈ø≈øump≈øit, &c.

div.head:
CCXV. Hawkins and Law≈øe Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Debt. HAwkins brought an Action of Debt again≈øt Law≈øe, Executor of one A. for Rent re≈øerved upon a Lea≈øe for years made to the Te≈øtator.3 Cro. 62, 63. The Defendant pleaded, fully admini≈øtred, and upon the Evidence it appeared, that the ≈øaid A. made the Defendant his Executor, and
that he did meddle with the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of divers goods of the Te≈øtaor, and ≈øo admini≈øtred, and afterwards ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ u≈øed in Court; and that the Admini≈øtration was afterwards committed to one B. and that the Inventory of the goods of the Te≈øtator came to one thou≈øand pounds: And it was given in Evidence for the Defendant, that he him≈øelf had paid certain debts, and that divers per≈øons have recovered again≈øt the Admini≈øtrator divers ≈øums of money amounting to one thou≈øand pounds, & ultra; And it was moved, if that evidence did maintain the I≈ø≈øue for the Defendant, becau≈øe that the Defendant had pleaded, plene admin≈øtravit, which implies an Admini≈øtration by him≈øelf. And now upon the Evidence it appeareth, that the greate≈øt part of the goods of the Te≈øtator were admini≈øtred by the Admini≈øtrator.

Periam, If that Admini≈øtrator (who in truth is but a ≈øtranger) pay any debts with the goods of the Te≈øtator without commandment of the Executor, the ≈øame is not an Admini≈øtration,Admini≈øtration. and the Executor cannot give ≈øuch matter in Evidence, to prove his plea of fully admini≈øtred. Drew Serjeant, If an Executor of his own wrong,3 Cro. 62, 63. meddle with the goods of the Te≈øtator, and afterwards the Admini≈øtrator meddle with the re≈øidue and admini≈øter them; In Debt again≈øt the Executor, who pleads fully admini≈øtred, if he can prove that he him≈øelf hath admini≈øtred part, and the Admini≈øtrator the Re≈øidue, the ≈øame is good Evidence to maintain his I≈ø≈øue. Periam, It may be ≈øo there, but here in our ca≈øe, the Defendant is the very Executor, and he hath admini≈øtred, in which ca≈øe afterwards he cannot refu≈øe; and ≈øo the Admini≈øtration is not well committed, and is granted without cau≈øe; and he to whom the Admini≈øtration is committed is a meer ≈øtranger, and what he did was without warrant; and therefore it is no Admini≈øtration to prove the I≈ø≈øue: And then the whole matter by direction of the Court was found by ≈øpecial verdict. And by Periam, in this ca≈øe an Action may be brought, either again≈øt the Executor of his own wrong, or the Admini≈øtrator, but not again≈øt both of them joyntly. See 21 H. 6. 8. by Yelverton and Portington. Periam, If the Te≈øtator mortgages a Lea≈øe for years and dyes, and the Executors redeem it with their own monyes, the ≈øaid Lea≈øe ≈øhall be A≈ø≈øets in their hands, for ≈øo much as the ≈øame is worth, above the ≈øum which they have paid for the redemption of it.

div.head:
CCXVI. Ivory and Fryes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IT was ruled by the whole Court in this ca≈øe: That if A. make B. his Executor, and B. makes C. his Executor and dieth, and a Debt is due to A. the fir≈øt Te≈øtator. If C. bring an Action of Debt for the ≈øaid Debt, as Executor to B. the Writ ≈øhall abate: It was moved, if an Infant within the age of one and twenty years be made Executor, and admini≈øtration is committed, durante minore aetate, in who≈øe name the Action ≈øhall be brought, in the name of the Infant, or the Admini≈øtrator. Periam, If the Will be proved before the Admini≈øtration be committed, the Action ≈øhall be brought in the name of the Infant Executor.

div.head:
CCXVII. Read and John≈øons Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe betwixt Read and John≈øon, A≈ø≈øump≈øit. the Plaintiff declared that where the Defendant was endebted to him,1 Cro. 242. he a≈ø≈øumed
to pay it: And upon Non A≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, this ≈øpecial matter was found, that the Plaintiff ‚Ä¢ a≈øed unto the Defendant certain Lands for years, rendring rent eight pounds per annum, and that the ≈øaid Rent was behind for three years, and that the Defendant was not otherwi≈øe endebted to the Plaintiff, nor made any other promi≈øe but the contract upon the Re≈øervation of the Rent: And by the clear opinion of the whole Court, the Action doth not lye, becau≈øe he hath a proper Action, ≈øcil. an Action of Debt, in which no wager of Law lyeth.

div.head:
CCXVIII. Wright and the Bi≈øhop of Norwiches Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas
div.p: Quare Impedit. Dy. 348. 360.IN a Quare Impedit betwixt Wright and the Bi≈øhop of Norwich, it was moved, if the King hath title to pre≈øent for Lap≈øe, and pre≈øents; and his Clerk is admitted and in≈øtituted, but not inducted, and dyeth before Induction; If now the King ≈øhall pre≈øent for the ≈øaid Lap≈øe, becau≈øe the Church was not full again≈øt the King. And the Iu≈øtices were all clear of opinion, that the King might repeal ≈øuch pre≈øentment before induction: And as to the principal matter, the Court ≈øeemed to incline, that the King might pre≈øent again.

div.head:
CCXIX. Whiskon and Cleytons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Intrat. Trin. 30 Eliz. Rot. 1160.
div.p: Devi≈øes.IN an Ejectione firmae, upon a ≈øpecial verdict found, the ca≈øe was this, That C. was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and devi≈øed the ≈øame to Solomon Whiskon his God-≈øon after the death of his Wife; and if he fail, then he willed all his part to the di≈øcretion of his Father, and died; Solomon ≈øurvived,Po≈øt. 283. the Father being dead before without any di≈øpo≈øition of the Land. Gawdy was of opinion, that upon tho≈øe words, that the Father had a Fee-≈øimple, as, I will that my Lands ≈øhall be at the di≈øpo≈øition of I. S. by the≈øe words, I. S. hath a Fee-≈øimple, quod Periam conce≈ø≈øit; and they amount to as much as, I will my Land to I. S. to give and ≈øell at his plea≈øure: And by Windham and Periam, there is no difference where the Devi≈øe is, that I. S. ≈øhall do with the Land at his di≈øcretion, and the devi≈øe thereof to I. S. to do with it at his di≈øcretion.

div.head: CCXX. Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: A lea≈øed to B. for years, and before the expiration of the ≈øaid Term lea≈øed the ≈øame by Indenture to a ≈øtranger to begin pre≈øently, and the fir≈øt Le≈ø≈øee committed Wa≈øt. A. brought an Action of Wa≈øt again≈øt the ≈øecond Le≈ø≈øee, and declared upon a Lea≈øe made for years without ≈øpeaking of the Indenture. And Gawdy Serjeant demanded the opinion of the Court, if the Defendant might ≈øafely plead no Wa≈øt? And they conceived, that it ≈øhould be dangerous ≈øo to do. Then it was demanded, if the Defendant plead, that the Plaintiff had nothing tempore dimi≈ø≈øionis, whereof he had counted, if the Plaintiff might e≈øtop the Defendant by the Indenture, although he had not counted upon it, and if ≈øuch Replication be not a departure. And it ≈øeemed to Periam, and Leonard, Cu≈øtos brevium, that it was not, for it is not contrary to the Declaration, but rather doth enforce the Declaration.

div.head: CCXXI. Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: WAlme≈øley Serjeant demanded the opinion of the Court upon this matter. Land is given to Husband and Wife in ≈øpecial tail (during the Coverture) they have i≈ø≈øue, the Husband is attainted of Trea≈øon and dieth, the Wife continues in as Tenant in tail, the i≈ø≈øue is re≈øtored by Parliament, and made inheritable to his Father, ≈øaving unto the King all advantages which were devolded unto him by the Attainder of his Father, the Wife dieth. And he conceived, that the i≈ø≈øue was inheritable, for the Attainder which di≈øturbed the inheritance is removed, and the blood is re≈øtored, and nothing can accrue to the King, for the Father had not any e≈øtate forfeitable, but all the e≈øtate did ≈øurvive to the Wife, not impeachable by the ≈øaid Attainder. And when the Wife dieth, then is the I≈ø≈øue capable to enherit the e≈øtate tail. Windham and Rhodes, prima facie, thought the contrary, yet they agreed, that if the Wife had ≈øuffered a common Recovery, the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ me had bound the King.

div.head: CCXXII. Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. that he had delivered to the Defendant, diver≈øa bona ad valentiam 10 li. the Defendant in con≈øideration thereof did promi≈øe to pay to the Plaintiff the Debt owing, pro bonis praedictis, and did not ≈øhew, that the Defendant bought the ≈øaid goods of the Plaintiff, and ≈øo it doth not appear that there was any Debt; and then a promi≈øe to pay it, is meerly void, which was agreed by the whole Court.

div.head:
CCXXIII. Seaman and Brownings Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: GEorge Seaman brought Debt upon a Bond again≈øt W. Browning and others, Executors of one Mar≈øhal; the condition was,Debt. that where the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal had ≈øold certain Lands to the Plaintiff, if the ≈øaid Plaintiff peaceably and quietly enjoy the ≈øaid Lands again≈øt the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal, &c. and a≈ø≈øigned the breach in this, that the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal had entred upon him, and cut down five Elms there, upon which the parties were at i≈ø≈øue; And it was found, that A. ≈øervant of the ≈øaid Mar≈øhal, by commandment of his ≈øaid Ma≈øter, had entred and cut, &c. in the pre≈øence of his ≈øaid Ma≈øter, and by his commandment, for he is a principal Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor: And it was ≈øo holden by the Court.

div.head: CCXXIV. Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IF the Kings Tenant by Knights ≈øervice dieth, his Heir within age,8 Co. 172. and upon Office found the King ≈øei≈øeth the Body and Land, yet the Heir during the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King may ≈øell the Lands by Deed enrolled, or make a Lea≈øe of ≈øuch Land, and the ≈øame ≈øhall bind the Heir notwith≈øtanding the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King; but if he maketh a Feoffment in Fee, it is utterly void, for the ≈øame is an intru≈øion upon the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King; but where the King by Office found is entituled to the Inheritance, as that his Tenant dieth without Heir, whereas it is fal≈øe, for which the King ≈øei≈øeth, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Tenant of the King, before his Ou≈øter le mayne, cannot make a Lea≈øe for
years, or ≈øell the Land by Deed enrolled: The Ca≈øe depended in London before the Iudges of the Sheriffs Court. The King, by colour of a fal≈øe Office, which doth fal≈øly entitle him to the Inheritance, is ≈øei≈øed of certain Land; he who hath right, lea≈øed the ≈øame for years by Deed indented; and then an Ou≈øter le mayne was ≈øued, and he enfeoffed a ≈øtranger; And it was holden, that the Lea≈øe ≈øhould not bind the Feoffee, although it was by Deed indented, for the Feoffee is a ≈øtranger to the Indenture, and therefore ≈øhall not be e≈øtopped by it. 18 H. 6. 22. A ≈øtranger ≈øhall not take advantage of an E≈øtoppel, and therefore ≈øhall not be bound by it: As if one take a Lea≈øe for years by Indenture of his own Lands, the ≈øame ≈øhall bind him, but if he dieth without Heir, it ≈øhall not bind the Lord in point of E≈øcheat.

div.head:
CCXXV. Gibbs Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Trover and Conver≈øion. 1 Cro. 861. Owen. 27. GIbbs brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon Trover and Conver≈øion of a Gelding; and the Ca≈øe was, that one P. had ≈øtolen the ≈øaid Hor≈øe, and ≈øold the ≈øame unto the Defendant in open Market, by the name of Li≈øter, and the ≈øaid fal≈øe name was entred in the Toll-book. And it was holden clear by the Court, that by that ≈øale the property was not altered.

div.head: CCXXVI. Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Owen. 45. Hutton. 105. 1 Cro. 734. Po≈øt. 322.TEnant in Socage lea≈øed his Lands for four years, and died, his Heir within the age of eight years, the Mother being Guardian in Socage, lea≈øed the Land by Indenture to the ≈øame Le≈ø≈øee for fourteen years; It was holden by the Court, that in this Ca≈øe the fir≈øt lea≈øe is ≈øurrendred, but otherwi≈øe upon a Lea≈øe made by Guardian by Nurture.

div.head:
CCXXVII. Kimpton and Dawbenets Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Defendant did ju≈øtifie by a grant of the Land, where, &c. by Copy: The Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaith, that the Land is cu≈øtomary Land (ut ≈øupra) and claimed the ≈øame by a former Copy: The Defendant by Rejoynder ≈øaith, that well and true it is, that the Lord may grant Copies in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at his plea≈øure, and al≈øo e≈øtates by Copy in Rever≈øion, with the a≈ø≈øent of the Copy-holder in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but all e≈øtates granted by Copy in Rever≈øion without ≈øuch a≈ø≈øent, have been void. It was argued, that this cu≈øtom is not good, for it is not rea≈øon, that the Lord in di≈øpo≈øing of the cu≈øtomary po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of his Manor ≈øhould depend upon the will of his Tenant at will; and the ≈øame is not like to the ca≈øe of Attornment, for there the Attendancy is to be re≈øpited, which is not to be done here, for the Copy-holder in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall continue attendant to his Lord, notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch a grant in Rever≈øion: And ≈øee for the unrea≈øonablene≈øs of the cu≈øtom, 19 Eliz. 357. in Dyer, Sallfords Ca≈øe: It was moved on the other ≈øide, that the Cu≈øtom was good enough; and 3 H. 6. 45. was vouched, That every Freehold of a Manour upon alienation might ≈øurrender his Land, &c. It was adjourned.

div.head: CCXXVIII. Marriot and Pa≈øcalls Ca≈øe in a Writ of Error. Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Exchequer-chamber.
div.p:
RObert Marriot one of the Attorneys of the Court of Exchequer,Mi≈øno≈ømer of a Corporation. 10 Co. 123. brought an Ejectione firmae again≈øt Mary, Pa≈øcal, and upon Not guilty pleaded, the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict, containing this matter; viz. That King H. 7. the fourth year of his Reign erected and founded an Ho≈øpital, by the name of the Ma≈øter and Chaplains of the Ho≈øpital of King Henry the eighth, de le Savoy: And afterwards in the time of Queen Mary, the ≈øaid Ma≈øter and Chaplains being ≈øei≈øed, &c. lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Defendant by the name of W. Holgil Ma≈øter of the Ho≈øpital, Henrici nuper Regis Angliae ≈øeptimi vocat. le Savoy & Capellani Ho≈ø≈øpitalis praedict. And afterwards by the former name (which was in truth their very name) lea≈øed the ≈øame to Thomas Fan≈øhaw, who lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Plaintiff: And if the Lea≈øe afore≈øaid made unto the Defendant in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rm and by the name afore≈øaid, be a good Lea≈øe, was all the que≈øtion. And this matter was argued, and many times debated in the Exchequer, as well at the Bench as at the Bar. And it was agreed by Clerk and Gent, Barons there, That the ≈øaid Lea≈øe made to the Defendant was utterly void by rea≈øon of the Mi≈øno≈ømer. Manwood argued ≈øtrongly to the contrary; and Iudment was given for the Plaintiff, according to the opinions of the ≈øaid two Barons: Vpon which the Defendant brought a Writ of Error in the Exchequer-chamber before the Lord Chancellor, Trea≈øurer, &c. And now this Term it was argued by Godfrey on the part of the Defendant: Three variances have been ≈øuppo≈øed in this Lea≈øe from the Original Foundation of the Ho≈øpital in the name of it. 1. The name of the Foundation is the Ma≈øter of the Ho≈øpital, &c. Et Capellani dict. Ho≈øpitii; So that in the Lea≈øe re≈øts part of the name (Capellani) as not immediately annexed to Ma≈øter, as it is in the name of the Foundation. But as to that point, the Iu≈øtices A≈ø≈øi≈øtants delivered Godfrey from the arguing of it, as of a variance not material: Another variance hath been objected, becau≈øe that in the Foundation the words are Ho≈øpitalis Regis H. 7. and in the Lea≈øe the words are, Ho≈øpitalis Henrici ≈øeptimi nuper Regis Angliae, ≈øo as this word (Nuper) is Surplu≈øage, and ex abundant. But of that matter he was al≈øo di≈øcharged, becau≈øe it is no variance in ≈øub≈øtance: But all the difficulty re≈øted in this, that in the Foundation the words are (de le Savoy) and in the Lea≈øe (vocat. le Savoy) And he put the Ca≈øe 4 Mar. Dyer 150. The Colledge of Eaton was incorporated by the name of Praepo≈øiti & Collegii regalis S. Mariae de Eaton juxta Wind≈øor, and a Lea≈øe is made by the name Praepo≈øiti & Sociorum Collegii regalis de Eaton, and that was holden a void Lea≈øe: And I confe≈øs that in the names of Corporations, we ought to re≈øort to the Foundation of the Corporations, for the name of a Corporation is as a name of Bapti≈øm, & ought to be as preci≈øely ob≈øerved, but that ought to be intended in matter of ≈øub≈øtance, & not otherwi≈øe, vide 10 Eliz. Dyer 278. The Dean & Chapter of Carlile was incorporated by the name of Decanus & Capitul. Eccle≈øiae Cathedralis Sanct. & individuae Tri. Carl. and they make a Lea≈øe by the name, Decanus Eccle≈øiae Cathedralis S. Trin. in Cant. et totum Capit. de Eccle≈øia praedict. And the ≈øame was holden a good Lea≈øe, notwith≈øtanding that variance, which is not in ≈øub≈øtance of the name. And the Dean and Chapter of Peterborow was incorporated by the name of Decanus et Capitul. Eccle≈øiae Petriburgen≈øis, and they made a Lea≈øe by the name Decanus et Capitulum Eccle≈øiae de Peterborow, and holden good enough, becau≈øe the variance was not in any matter of ≈øub≈øtance: And he cited the Ca≈øe betwixt Croft and Howel, 20 Eliz. Plow. Com. 537. The Cooks of London were incorporated by the name of Ma≈øters, and Governors,
and Commonalty of the Mi≈øtery of Cooks, and they by the Name of Ma≈øter and Wardens of the ≈øaid Craft and Mi≈øtery of Cooks made a Conveyance, and it was holden that the variance a≈ø≈øigned in the abundance of this word (Craft) in the Conveyance, which was not in this Corporation, was not any material variance, but only matter of ≈øurplu≈øage, for (Craft) and (My≈øtery) are all one, and of one ≈øen≈øe, &c. And ≈øo in the principal Ca≈øe, The Ho≈øpital de le Savoy, and the Ho≈øpital vocat. le Savoy, ≈øound the ≈øame, and in effect do not differ. And as it was ≈øaid by the Lord Chief Baron in his Argument in the Court of Exchequer, in this ca≈øe, four things are only to be re≈øpected in the Name of a Corporation:Po≈øt. 162, 164. Fir≈øt the Name of the living per≈øons who are the Corporation, as in our Ca≈øe the Ma≈øter and Chaplains: Secondly, the hou≈øe in which they are re≈øident, and make their aboad: Thirdly, The Name of the Founder: Fourthly, the place upon which the place of their aboad is built and erected. And if the≈øe four matters are ≈øufficiently ≈øet down, although not formally, it is good enough. It hath been objected, That the Ho≈øpital de le Savoy, and the Ho≈øpital vocat. le Savoy, do much differ, for de le Savoy, implieth the demon≈øtration of the Place, but vocat. le Savoy, trencheth only to the Name, As if the Dean & Chap. de Pauls in London, make a Lea≈øe by the Name of Dean and Chap. of St. Paul vocat. London, ≈øo if the Ma≈øter and Fellows of Trinity Colledge; in Cambridge make a Lea≈øe by the Name of Ma≈øter & Fellows of Trinity Coll. vocat. Cambridge, ≈øuch Lea≈øes are utterly void. I do well agree tho≈øe Ca≈øes, for the Dean and Chapter is not all London, but part of London, and therefore cannot be called or ≈øaid London; and ≈øo Trinity Colledge is but part of Cambridge, and therefore cannot be called Cambridge; but here in our ca≈øe, The Ho≈øpital is not parcel of the Savoy, but the whole Savoy is the Ho≈øpital, and there is not any part of the Savoy, which is not the Ho≈øpital; But if Trinity Colledge in Cambridge make a Lea≈øe by the Name of Ma≈øter and Fellows Collegii vocat. Trinity Colledge in Cambridge, it is a good Lea≈øe: And he put a difference, where the word in the Name of the Corporation, which precedes (de) is all one and of the ≈øame Nature with the word which follows (de) and where on the contrary, as in our ca≈øe, The word which precedes (de) is Ho≈øpital, and the words which follow (de) are le Savoy, are all one and the ≈øame thing, ≈øo as the Ho≈øpital and Savoy are all one and the ≈øame, and therefore may be well called Le Savoy, and al≈øo (de) and (vocat.) in con≈øtruction are the ≈øame, & ≈øo our Lea≈øe is good enough: And it is found by verdict, That this Ho≈øpital was erected upon the Manor of Savoy, and thereupon it is now commonly called Le Savoy, without any addition of Ho≈øpital, for as it was called Savoy before it was erected into an Ho≈øpital, ≈øo it is al≈øo called after the Erection; and true it is that the mi≈ønaming of a Corporation in any ≈ømall thing ≈øhall abate a Writ, for there is only delay, yet it is not of force in a Conveyance, unle≈øs the mi≈ønaming be in a point material. Coke to the contrary, The variance from the true Name of a Corporation which ≈øhall prejudice a Conveyance ought to be in matter of ≈øub≈øtance, for variance in matter of form and circum≈øtance will not hurt it, ≈øed parum differunt quae re concordant. And fir≈øt it is to be confe≈ø≈øed, That the Name of a Corporation is as the Name of Bapti≈øm, which admits of no variance, and therefore it is ≈øaid 38 E. 3. 15. by Knivet, when a Man founds a Chantry or a hou≈øe, &c. it ought to bear ≈øuch a Name as his Founder hath given to it, for that is its proper name. And ≈øo it hath been Reported by Bendloes, Serjeant, 4 and 5 Phi. and Mar. That it was holden for a po≈øitive Law, by all the Iudges of England, That the mi≈øtaking of the Name of a Corporation in any matter of Sub≈øtance, makes the Conveyance utterly void, for a name is given to a Corporation upon the Foundation, and that by the ≈øame Name they ≈øhall implead and be impleaded, but that ut idem nomen, et ≈øub eodem nomine ≈øint habiles ad perquirend. & concedend. to be impleaded, and to implead, but that is to be meant idem re, for
it is not nece≈ø≈øary, that it be idem litera, for, qui haeret in litera haeret in Cortice, but if it be idem re with the Foundation it is well enough. And therefore it hath been adjudged, That where the Colledge is incorporated by the Name of Ma≈øters and Fellows Collegii St. & individ. Trin. in Cantabrig. and they make a Lea≈øe by the Name of Collegii Trin. this is good enough, for the word Trinity, implies, and imports St. & individ. And therefore ≈øuch variance was holden not material. But here in our ca≈øe is a variance in Sub≈øtance, betwixt the Name given to the Ho≈øpital upon the foundation, and the name u≈øurped in the Lea≈øe. And the ≈øame will clearly appear upon my Argument, viz. If the Name given to this Ho≈øpital upon the foundation of it, and the Name u≈øurped in the Lea≈øe be not unum in ≈øen≈øu (not in your private under≈øtanding as private per≈øons, but in your judicial knowledge upon the Record quod coram vobis re≈øidet, as Iudges of Record) then this lea≈øe is void; For although you as private per≈øons, otherwi≈øe than by Record, know, That the Ho≈øpital of Savoy, and the Ho≈øpital vocat. le Savoy, are all one Ho≈øpital; you ought not upon that your private knowledge to give Iudgment, unle≈øs al≈øo your judicial knowledge agree with it; that is, the knowledge which is out of the Records which you have before you: But if the Name given upon the Foundation, and the u≈øurped Name be not idem ≈øen≈øu in your Iudicial knowledge; and you cannot otherwi≈øe conceive the Identity of the≈øe two Ho≈øpitals, nor make any Con≈øtruction to imagine it but by the Record, for the Record is your eye of Iu≈øtice, and you have no other eye to look unto the cau≈øe depending before you, but the Record; and to this purpo≈øe he cited the ca≈øe of 7 H. 4. 108. Where a man killed another in the pre≈øence of a Iudge traveling on the way where the murther was, And at the next A≈ø≈øi≈øes in the ≈øaid County before the ≈øame Iudge, another man is indicted of the ≈øame murder, and arraigned, and convicted by verdict; In that ca≈øe, The Iudge he ought not to carry him≈øelf according to his private knowledge, which he hath of the ≈øaid fact, ≈øci. to acquit the Pri≈øoner, but all that he can do is to re≈øpite Iudgment again≈øt the party, becau≈øe of the Iudges knowing to the contrary, and to make further Relation thereof to the King for his Pardon of grace for the Party. So in our Ca≈øe, It may be that you in your private knowledge know, That the Ho≈øpital de le Savoy, and the Ho≈øpital vocat. le Savoy, is all one, but that doth not appear unto you upon the Record which is before you, but it may be for any thing that appears in the Record, that they are diver≈øe and ≈øeveral Ho≈øpitals; Therefore the Lea≈øe is void. To prove my Minor, I do ≈øay that this word (de) as here, de Savoy, de≈øignes a place, ≈øo as by this Word (de) the place is become parcel of the Name, but this word vocat. locum non denotat, but only the very name, and ≈øo here is a material difference and variance, for here by pretence of the Name in this Lea≈øe, there is not any place of the Corporation in the Name, but the Corporation is tran≈øitory, which cannot be, for a Corporation e≈øpecial con≈øi≈øting of many per≈øons, as Corpus aggregatum ought to have a certain place of their abiding, or otherwi≈øe it cannot be di≈øcerned by the Law, and it is but a Mathematical thing, and nothing el≈øe but a fiction, and they cannot be otherwi≈øe con≈øidered in Law, but as they are circum≈øcripti within the bounds of their hou≈øe, and they cannot appear but by Attorney: and if a Prebend con≈øi≈øt upon a Manor, & afterwards the Manor by Writ be demanded again≈øt the Prebend, and he lo≈øe it, here he hath lo≈øt his Name, becau≈øe he hath lo≈øt that which giveth to him his Name, by Contrary by Blake, for his e≈øtate and place in the Chapter, doth remain unto him: And ≈øecondly, for another Cau≈øe here is a material variance, for this word (de) ≈øuppo≈øeth a place before the Foundation, as the place upon which the Ho≈øpital was erected was called Le Savoy before the Erection of it; but the≈øe words (vocat. le Savoy) ≈øuppo≈øeth the ≈øame Name Savoy was impo≈øed upon the Foundation. Thirdly, the≈øe words (de le Savoy) do import the
Ho≈øpital to be part of the place, which before the Foundation, was called Savoy, but vocat. trencheth only to all the place called Savoy: Fourthly; (de le Savoy) is matter of certainty and verity; (vocat.) but matter of Reputation. And ≈øo for the≈øe four rea≈øons, great difference in ≈øub≈øtance appeareth betwixt the very name of the Ho≈øpital, and the Name u≈øurped in the Lea≈øe. And he cited the Ca≈øe 29 Eliz. in the Kings Bench betwixt Hall and Wingat. King E. 4. did incorporate the Dean and Cannons of Wind≈øor, by the Name of Dean and Cannons of the King and Queens Free Chappel of Saint George the Martyr within his Ca≈øtle of Wind≈øor; and made a Lea≈øe by another Name, viz. by the Name of Dean and Cannons of the King and Queens Free Chappel there, and the ≈øame Lea≈øe was made in the time of Queen Mary, and it was holden that the ≈øame was a variance in Sub≈øtance. And he cited another Ca≈øe 30 Eliz. in the Kings Bench betwixt Fi≈øher and Boys. A Colledge in Oxford was by Act of Parliament incorporated by the Name of Warden and Scholars, Domus ≈øive Collegii Scholarium de Merton in univer≈øitate Oxoniae, and they make a Lea≈øe by the Name Cu≈øtos Domus ≈øive Collegii de Merton in Oxonia, and Scholares eju≈ødum Domus, and the variance in that point, becau≈øe in the very name of the Foundation, Domus five Collegii Scholarium de Merton, and in the u≈øurped Name in the Lea≈øe Domus ≈øive Collegii de Merton, was holden material, and the true name was de Merton in univer≈øitate Oxoniae, but in the Lea≈øe, in Oxonia only, leaving out the word Vniver≈øity, and the ≈øame was holden a variance in ≈øub≈øtance: For Oxford doth contain in it ≈øelf the Vniver≈øity, which is a thing of it ≈øelf, and al≈øo the City is a thing by it ≈øelf: and it may be that there is a Colledge in the City called Merton Colledge, and al≈øo a Colledge which is called by ≈øuch Name in the Vniver≈øity: and ≈øo in our Ca≈øe, it may be that there is an Ho≈øpital which is called the Savoy, and al≈øo another which is Le Savoy, and then the Court ≈øhall be enveigled, &c. And in the end of the Argument, the Lord Trea≈øurer, which was the Lord Burleigh, put this Ca≈øe, which was adjudged in his time. The Guild of Bo≈øton in Lincoln≈øhire, was incorporated by the Name of the Guild of St. Nicholas, and our Lady the Virgin Mary, &c. and they made a Lea≈øe for years by the Name of the Guild of our Lady the Virgin, and St. Nicholas, Religione quadam motus ut nomen Virginis Mariae, in charta dimi≈ø≈øionis, proponeretur nomini Sancti Nicholai; and it was adjudged a void Lea≈øe for the variance afore≈øaid. And afterwards at another day, the matter was argued by Atkin≈øon, on the part of the Defendant. Starkey 21 E. 4. 56. ≈øaith, That the Name of the Corporation, by which it is incorporated, is as properly the Name of a Corporation, as the Name of Bapti≈øm is the Name of a ≈øingle and individual per≈øon, and yet there is a great difference in the mi≈øpri≈øion of them, for the Name of Bapti≈øm doth con≈øi≈øt of one word, and therefore it cannot admit of any variance, but the name of a Corporation doth con≈øi≈øt of many words: in which ca≈øe variance in words which are ≈øupplyed by other words, and not in matter of ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øhall not hurt; and that hearing is notably di≈øcu≈ø≈øed in the ca≈øe of the Cooks of London, cited before by Godfrey. Four things are to be con≈øidered in the Name of a Corporation, which are of the E≈ø≈øence and Sub≈øtance of it: Fir≈øt, the per≈øons incorporated, of which the Corporation doth con≈øi≈øt, as here the Ma≈øter and Chaplains de Savoy. Secondly, The quality of the Corporation, as Dean and Chapter, Mayor and Commonalty: Thirdly, the Patron or Founder, as, Merton Colledge; Fourthly, The Place whereupon the Corporation is founded. As to this la≈øt point, ≈øee 31 E. 3. 28. and fo. 15 by Knivet; and ≈øee 6 Eliz. Dyer. King H. 8. erected the Dean and Prebend of Che≈øter, by the≈øe words, ≈øcil. Decanus et Capit. Cathedralis Eccle≈øiae Chri≈øti, et Sanctae Mariae Virginis Ce≈øtriae. And afterwards by Letters Patents, gave to the ≈øaid Dean and Chapter, certain Manors, Decano et Capitulo Eccle≈øiae Cathedralis Chri≈øti et Sanctae Mariae Virginis, by us before erected, and
that grant was holden void, becau≈øe that the place where, &c. is not expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øaid Letters Patents, for Ce≈øtria is the local place of the Incorporation. And as to the Objection made upon the word (de) that this word (de) goeth only to part, and (vocat.) goes to the whole, and ≈øo here is a great difference; the ≈øame is not any rea≈øon, for this word (de) extends as well to the whole as to part. As a Rent granted percipiend. de Manerio de D. the ≈øame ≈øhall go to the whole Mannor, 5 E. 4, 5. ad re≈øpondendum I. Abbati Mona≈øterii Sanctae Mariae Ebor. where the Obligation was, Abbati Mona≈øterii Sanctae Mariae Virginis extra Muros Ebor. and yet the Writ was well enough, notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch variance, a fortiori, in the ca≈øe of a conveyance and Intere≈øt. And I conceive that it appeareth in the Record, That the Lea≈øe given in evidence of the part of the Defendant, is a Lea≈øe made by the Ma≈øter and Chaplains of the Ho≈øpital of the Savoy, for it is found by verdict, That King Henry the eighth, upon the Site of the Manour of Savoy, betwixt the hou≈øe of the Bi≈øhop of Worce≈øter, and the hou≈øe of the Bi≈øhop of Carli≈øle, and that it was incorporated by the Name, &c. and that afterwards Q. Mary by her Letters Patents, reciting the foundation of the ≈øaid Ho≈øpital called the Savoy, and lamenting the Ruin of it, being ≈øurrendred in the time of E. 6. did re≈øtore it, by which it appeareth, That the Ho≈øpital of the Savoy, and Ho≈øpital called the Savoy is one and the ≈øame in re≈øpect of the Bounds, Foundation, and Situation. And in the whole cour≈øe of our Books, no ca≈øe can be found, That any Corporations have avoided their own acts, by ≈øuch cau≈øe of Mi≈øno≈ømer, nor of ≈øuch matter, is any que≈øtion moved in our Books. And as to that which hath been objected, That although the Iudges in their private knowledge well know, That the Hou≈øe de le Savoy, and the Hou≈øe vocat. the Savoy, be all one, yet they ought not to judge according to ≈øuch their private knowledge, but according to their judicial knowledge, which they have out of the Record. I conceive, That the Iudges of nece≈ø≈øity ought to u≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øes their private knowledge; as where Mi≈øno≈ømer of a Colledge was objected, viz. Trinity Colledge in Cambridge, where it was incorporated by the Name of Ma≈øters, Fellows, and Scholars Collegii Sanctae & individuae Trin. and they made a Lea≈øe by the Name of Ma≈øter, Fellows, and Scholars of the Colledge of Trinity, the ≈øame was holden a good Lea≈øe, for the Iudges knew well enough, That this word Trinity doth imply in it ≈øelf Sancta & individua, but by what knowledge? not by their judicial knowledge, but by their private knowledge; So in our ca≈øe. Egerton the Queens Sollicitor to the contrary: It is a clear and plain Rule in our Law, That the name of a Corporation is as a name of Bapti≈øm to a natural man, and if there be any difference, I conceive, that the Law requires more ≈øtrict certainty in the name of a Corporation than in the Name of any particular per≈øon, For a name is more nece≈ø≈øary to a Corporation than to another, for when an infant is born, he is pre≈øently a perfect creature, before any name given him, and the giving of the Name is not a matter of nece≈ø≈øity, but of policy for di≈øtinction, &c. but in the ca≈øe of a Corporation, The Name is the ≈øub≈øtance and e≈ø≈øence of it, and it is not a Body before a Name be impo≈øed upon it, and therefore in the Charters of Corporations there is always ≈øuch a clau≈øe, per tale nomen implacitare, & implacitari, acquirere, &c. po≈ø≈øint, and without their Name, they are but a Trunk: but contrary in the ca≈øe of particular per≈øons; Land is given primogenito filio J. S. It is a good gift, although there be no Name of Bapti≈øm: Lands given omnibus filiis J. S. is a good name of purcha≈øe, and if a man be bound in an obligation by a wrong or fal≈øe Name, and in an action brought upon the ≈øame, if it appeareth upon evidence, that he was the ≈øame per≈øon which ≈øealed and delivered it, the ≈øame is ≈øufficient, and the Bond ≈øhall bind him. But contrary in the ca≈øe of a Corporation, and we cannot give any thing to a Corporation by circum≈øtances, inducing or implying
their true name. As Land given to the fir≈øt Ho≈øpital which the Queen ≈øhall found,Ante. 161, 162. although that it ≈øufficiently appear, That ≈øuch a one was the Ho≈øpital which the Queen fir≈øt founded, yet the gift is void: And he denied, That the four things remembred before are nece≈ø≈øarily required in the Name of a Corporation: for if the Queen will found a Corporation, as an Ho≈øpital by the Name of Utopia, the ≈øame is well enough without any re≈øpect of per≈øons, place, Founder, &c. ≈øet forth in the Charter. And al≈øo other things be≈øides the ≈øaid four things are ≈øometimes nece≈ø≈øary in a Corporation; As if the Queen will found an Ho≈øpital by the Name, Quod fundavimus ad roga. Chri≈øt. Hatton Cancel. Angliae. all the ≈øame ought to be expre≈ø≈øed in every grant made by, or to the ≈øaid Ho≈øpital; So Quod fundavimus ad relevandum pauperes; and ≈øometimes the number of the per≈øons incorporated, if it be in the Charter, it ought to be u≈øed in all acts made by or to them; As Ma≈øter and ≈øir Chaplains; ≈øo as the ≈øaid four things recited before, are not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary in the Name of a Corporation, but ≈øo far forth as they are parcel of the Name given to them in the Charter of the Corporation: And in our ca≈øe, 1. The place de le Savoy, is part of their name, ≈øet down in the Charter of their Corporation, and therefore the ≈øame ought to be preci≈øely followed. And he relyed much upon the argument of Cook in noting material variances betwixt de le Savoy, and vocat. le Savoy, as (de) ≈øignifies part (vocat.) the whole; (de) ≈øignifies the place de facto, vocat. implyes reputation only. There is a place near unto Whitehal called Scotland, becau≈øe that the Kings of Scotland, when they came to our Parliament u≈øed there to re≈øide, as the Lord Trea≈øurer affirmed. There is al≈øo a place in England called Normandy, and another called Callais, and al≈øo a place here in We≈øtmin≈øter called Jeru≈øalem, but the≈øe, Scotland, &c. but by Reputation, ≈øo as what difference is betwixt the very Scotland and Scotland here, &c. ≈øuch and ≈øo much difference is there betwixt the Ho≈øpital de le Savoy, and the Ho≈øpital vocat. the Savoy. And as to that which hath been objected by Atkin≈øon, That that word (de) ≈øignifies as well the whole as part, as a Rent granted percipiend. de Manerio de D. I confe≈øs that this word (de) hath many ≈øignifications, ≈øo that we ought not only to con≈øider what (de) ≈øignifyes of it ≈øelf, but rather to ob≈øerve what goes before, what follows; for, as ≈øaith Hillary, intelligentia verborum ex cau≈øa dicendi ≈øumenda e≈øt. And this word (de) is a material word in the Name of a man, therefore al≈øo in the name of a Corporation, 26 H. 6. 31. A≈ø≈øi≈øe by I. de S. and it was found for him, and afterwards the Tenant in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe brought attaint, and in the reher≈øal of the A≈ø≈øi≈øe in the writ of attaint he was named I.S. leaving out (de) and for that cau≈øe the Writ did abate, 28 E. 3. 92. Debt brought by the Executor of John Holbech, where the Te≈øtament was John de Holbech, and for want of this word (de) in the Writ, it was abated by Award. And in a Praecipe quod reddat again≈øt Mich. de Triage, he ca≈øt a Protection for Michael Triage, leaving out (de) and for ≈øuch variance the Protection was di≈øallowed, and a Petit cape awarded. And although the Iudges in their private knowledge know well enough, That the Ho≈øpital de le Savoy, and the Ho≈øpital vocat. the Savoy, be all one, yet in point of Iudgment they ought not otherwi≈øe receive information, but out of the Record, and therefore, if ≈øufficient matter be not within the Record to inform the Iudges of the Identity of the ≈øaid two Ho≈øpitals, their private knowledge ≈øhall not avail. And he cited the cau≈øe of the Lord Conniers, where the Parties being at i≈ø≈øue, and the Iury charged for the trial of it; It was found by ≈øpecial verdict, That a fine was levyed of the Lands in Que≈øtion, &c. but nothing found of the Proclamations, whereas in truth, the Proclamations were as well given in evidence as the fine, But found, Quod finis levatus fuit prout per recordum finis ip≈øius, in evidenciis o≈øten≈øum, plenius apparet, Now in that ca≈øe, although that the Iu≈øtices, knew well enough, That the Proclamations were expre≈ø≈øly given in evidence, yet becau≈øe
it did not appear unto them as Iudges out of the Record, They would not give Iudgment, according to the truth of matter, but according to the Record, for they cannot take notice if the Proclamations be in the Chirographers Office or not: But after it appeared unto them, That that defect was but a ≈ølip of the Clerk, they commanded the Record to be brought before them, and the Proclamation to be in≈øerted in the verdict; and then gave Iudgment according to the verdict reformed as afore≈øaid. And as to the Ca≈øe of Martin Colledge cited before, he ≈øaid he was of Councel in it, and he knew, That the Iudgment there was not given for the cau≈øe alledged by Cook, but becau≈øe that this word, Scholars, was left out in the Lea≈øe. And he held, that if in the principal Ca≈øe, the Lea≈øe had been, That the Ma≈øter and Chaplains of the hou≈øe called the Ho≈øpital of the Savoy, &c. it had been well enough, for there is, de le Savoy. See a good ca≈øe 36 H. 6. fitz. Brief. 485. by Danby a Corporation cannot be Tenants of Lands, but according to their Corporation, and their foundation, and their very Name, nor they cannot be impleaded, nor take Lands by a wrong Name, nor purcha≈øe, nor di≈øpo≈øe of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, but by their true Name. And afterwards the matter was compounded by the mediation of Friends: and Fan≈øhaw had the Lea≈øe for a certain ≈øum of mony. See now Cook 10 Report, The Ca≈øe of the Mayor and Burge≈ø≈øes of Lyn Regis: See al≈øo Cook 11. Report. 18. Doctor Arays Ca≈øe, to this purpo≈øe.

div.head:
CCXXIX. Hu≈øon and Webbs Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: RObert Hu≈øon brought an action of Debt again≈øt Anne Webb, Debt lieth not again≈øt Executor of an Admini≈øtrator. 1 Cro. 121. Yel. 20. 9 Co. 87. Admini≈øtratrix of Joan Webb, and declared of a Contract without ≈øpecialty, The Defendant pleaded, That ≈øhe had fully admini≈øtred, and it was found again≈øt her. And now it was moved for the Defendant, That upon the matter an action of Debt doth not lye again≈øt the Executor or Admini≈øtratrix; which was granted by the Court. But the doubt was, If now, fora≈ømuch as the Defendant by pleading the plea above, hath admitted the action, ≈øhe ≈øhall now take advantage of the Law in that point. For the rea≈øon why this action doth not lye again≈øt an Executor or Admini≈øtrator is, becau≈øe the Te≈øtator him≈øelf might have waged his Law, if he had been impleaded upon it; and by intendment of Law the Executor or Admini≈øtrator cannot have notice of ≈øuch a Debt, or of the di≈øcharge of it; But now by an≈øwering to the Declaration as above, the Defendant hath taken notice of the Debt, and in manner confe≈ø≈øed it. And by Rhodes and Ander≈øon, Iudgment ≈øhall be given again≈øt the the Plaintiff, becau≈øe it is apparent to the Court, that the action doth not lye. And by Ander≈øon, If Iudgment be entred again≈øt the Admini≈øtratrix, in ≈øuch an action upon Nihil dicit, the Court, ex officio ≈øhall give judgment again≈øt the Plaintiff. Periam and Windham doubted at the fir≈øt that the Defendant by her plea had admitted the whole matter upon the ≈øpecially admini≈øtred, pleaded, and had taken notice of the Debt, 41 E. 3. 13. 46 E. 3. 10, 11. 13 E. 4. 25. 13 H. 8. Fitz. Execut. 21. And afterwards Ander≈øon, ex a≈ø≈øen≈øu of the other Iudges, cau≈øed to be entred, Querens capiat nihil per breve.

div.head:
CCXXX. Hambleden and Hambledens Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Intrat. Mich. 29. & 30 Eliz
div.p: Devi≈øes. 1 Cro. 163. 1 And. 381.THe ca≈øe was, William Hambleden the Father of the Plaintiff, and the. Defendant, was ≈øei≈øed of the Lands, &c. And by his Will devi≈øed to his Elde≈øt Son, Black Acre; to his ≈øecond Son, White Acre; and to his third Green Acre, in tail. And by his ≈øaid Will further willed, That in Ca≈øe any of my ≈øaid Sons do dye without i≈ø≈øue, that then the Survivor be each others heir, The Elde≈øt ≈øon dieth without i≈ø≈øue, &c It was moved by Gawdy Serjeant, That the ≈øecond Son ≈øhall have Black Acre in tail, and he cited the Ca≈øe 30 E. 3. 28. propinquioribus haeredibus de ≈øanguine puerorum, for the con≈øtruction of ≈øuch devi≈øes. Walme≈øley argued, That both the ≈øurviving Brothers ≈øhould have the ≈øaid Black Acre, for the words of the devi≈øe are quilibet ≈øupervivens, which amounts to uterque; and the Court was in great doubt of this point. And they conceived, That the e≈øtate limited in Remainder to the Survivor, &c. is a fee-≈øimple by rea≈øon of the words, Each others heir; And al≈øo they conceived, That both the Survivors ≈øhould not have the Land, for the ≈øame is contrary to the expre≈øs words of the devi≈øe, The Survivor ≈øhall be each others heir, in the ≈øingular number; ≈øee 7 E. 6. Br. Devi≈øe 38. A man ≈øei≈øed of Land hath i≈ø≈øue three Sons, and devi≈øeth part of his Lands to his ≈øecond Son in tail, Heb. 75. and the re≈øidue to his third ≈øon in tail: and willeth, That none of them ≈øhall ≈øell the Land, but that each ≈øhall be heir to the other, The ≈øecond ≈øon dieth without i≈ø≈øue, the ≈øame Land ≈øhall not revert to the elde≈øt Son, but ≈øhall remain to the third ≈øon,1 Len. 261. notwith≈øtanding the words each ≈øhall be heir to the other.

div.head:
CCXXXI. Slywright and Pages Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Maintenance. More. 266. 1 And. 201. Gold≈ø. 101, 102.AN Information was in the Common Pleas, by John Slywright again≈øt Page, upon the Statute of 32 H. 8. of Maintenance; and declared that the Defendant took a Lea≈øe of one Joan Wade, of certain Lands, whereas the ≈øaid Joan was not ≈øei≈øed nor po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof according to the Statute; and upon Not guilty, the Iury found this ≈øpecial matter, That Edmund Wade was ≈øei≈øed, and made a Feoffment in fee thereof unto the u≈øe of him≈øelf, and of the ≈øaid Joan, who he then intended to marry, and the heirs of the ≈øaid Edmund. The marriage took effect, Edmund enfeoffed a Stranger, who entred, Edmund died, Joan not having had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Land after the death of Ed. her husband nor bing now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, by Indenture demi≈øed the ≈øaid Land to the Defendant for years, without any Entry or delivery of the Indenture upon the Land, The ≈øaid Defendant knowing the ≈øaid Joan never had been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Land, and al≈øo the Defendant being Brother of the half blood to the ≈øaid Joan. The fir≈øt Que≈øtion was, If the Lea≈øe being made by one out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and not ≈øealed or delivered upon the Land, and ≈øo not good in Law as to pa≈øs any intere≈øt, be within the Statute afore≈øaid. And the whole Court was clear of opinion that it was: for by colour of this pretended Lea≈øe, ≈øuch might be undertaken & advanced to the trouble & di≈øquiet of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, for among≈øt the vulgar people, it is a Lea≈øe, & it is a Lea≈øe by Reputation: Another matter was moved, becau≈øe that the entry of the wife is now made lawful by 32 H. 8. and then ≈øhe might well di≈øpo≈øe of the Land.

But as to that, It was ≈øaid by the whole Court, That the meaning of the Statute was to repre≈øs the practi≈øes of many, That when they thought they had title or right unto any Land, they for the furtherance of their pretended Right conveyed their intere≈øt in ≈øome part thereof to great per≈øons, and with their countenance did oppre≈øs the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors: And although here the Lea≈øe was made by the ≈øaid Joan to her Brother of the half blood, yet by the clear opinion of the Court the Lea≈øe is within the danger of the Statute, and yet in ≈øome Ca≈øe the Son may maintain his Father, & the Kin≈øman his Kin≈øman. And note in this ca≈øe it was holden by the Iu≈øtices, That of nece≈ø≈øity it ought to be found by verdict, That the Defendant knowing that the Le≈ø≈øor never had been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: CCXXXII. Brokesby again≈øt Wickham and the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln. Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Quare Impedit, the Plaintiff counted,Quare Impedit. 3 Len. 256. 1 Cro. 173. Owen 85, 86. Popham. 189. That Robert Brokesby was ≈øei≈øe of the Advow≈øon, and granted the next Avoidance to the Plaintiff, and Humphrey Brokesby, and that afterwards the Church became void, and after during the avoidance, Humphrey relea≈øed to the Plaintiff, and ≈øo it belongs to him to pre≈øent. And upon this count the Defendant did demar in Law. For it appeareth upon the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing, that Humphrey ought to have joined with the Plaintiff in the action, for the Relea≈øe being made after the Church became void, is not of any effect, but utterly void. So is the grant of the pre≈øentment to the Church where the Church is void, for it is a thing in action. See the Lord Dyer, 28 H. 6. 26. 3 Ma. Dyer 129. 11 Eliz. Dyer 283, Walm≈øley Serjeant put this Ca≈øe, Two Ioint-tenants of a Rent, the one may relea≈øe to the other, but if the Rent be behind, now the one cannot Relea≈øe his Intere≈øt in the Arrearages to the other. And afterwards in the Principal ca≈øe Iudgment was given that the Relea≈øe was void.

div.head:
CCXXXIII. Sammes and Paynes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Intr. Trin. 29 Eliz. Rot. 721.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae the ca≈øe was, That the Mother being ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands, had i≈ø≈øue two Daughters,Tenant by the curte≈øie. 1 And. 184. Goldsb. 81. 82. 8 Co. 34. and by Indenture covenanted with diver≈øe per≈øons to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of Eliz. her elde≈øt Daughter in tail, upon condition that the ≈øaid Eliz. ≈øhould pay to her other Daughter within a year after the death of the Mother, or within a year after the ≈øaid other Daughter ≈øhould come to the age of eighteen years, 300 l. And if the ≈øaid E. ≈øhould fall in the payment of the ≈øum afore≈øaid, or ≈øhould dye without i≈ø≈øue before ≈øuch payment, then to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid ≈øecond Daughter in tail, The Mother dieth, E. taketh Husband, hath i≈ø≈øue, & afterwards dieth without i≈ø≈øue before the day of payment. And if the Husband ≈øhall be tenant by the curte≈øie or not, was the Que≈øtion, And by the Court cleerly, he ≈øhall be, For as to the condition of payment of the ≈øaid Sum, the ≈øame is not determined; for ≈øhe died without i≈ø≈øue before the day of payment, ≈øcil. before the ≈øecond Daughter came of the age of eighteen years; & as to that there is no condition broken; & as to the point of dying without i≈ø≈øue, The ≈øame is not a condition
but rather a Limitation of the E≈øtate, and the ≈øame is no more than what the Law ≈øaith, and the e≈øtate tail in Elizabeth is ≈øpent and determined by the dying without i≈ø≈øue; and doth not cea≈øe, or is cut off by any Limitation; and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Tenant by the curte≈øie. And by Ander≈øon, If a Feoffment be made to the u≈øe of I. S. and his heirs, until I. D. hath done ≈øuch a thing, and then unto the u≈øe of I. D. and his heirs, the thing is done, and I. S. dieth, his wife ≈øhall be endowed.

div.head:
CCXXXIV. Bowry and Popes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: 1 Roll. 676. Plow. Queries ver≈ø. finem. BOwry brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Pope, and declared, that in the time of E. 6. the Dean and Chapter of We≈øtmin≈øter, lea≈øed two hou≈øes in Saint Martins in London to Ma≈øon for ≈øixty years, The which Ma≈øon, lea≈øed one of the ≈øaid Hou≈øes to one A. and covenanted by the Indenture of Lea≈øe with the ≈øaid A. that it ≈øhould be lawful for the ≈øaid A. his Executors, and a≈ø≈øigns to make a window in the ≈øhop of the hou≈øe ≈øo to him a≈ø≈øigned, and afterwards in the time of Queen Mary, a window was made accordingly, where no window was there before. And afterwards A. a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øaid hou≈øe to the Plaintiff. And now Pope having a hou≈øe adjoining, had erected a new building ≈øuper ≈øolum ip≈øius Pope ex oppo≈øito the ≈øaid new Window,Nu≈øance. ≈øo as the New Window is thereby ≈øtopped. The Defendant pleaded, Not guilty, and it was found for the Plaintiff; and it was moved for the Defendant in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that here upon the Declaration appeareth no cau≈øe of action, for the window, in the ≈øtopping of which the wrong is a≈ø≈øigned, appears upon the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing to be of late erected, ≈øcil. in the time of Queen Mary, The ≈øtopping of which by any act upon my own Land, was holden lawful and ju≈øtifiable by the whole Court. But if it were an antient window time out of memory, &c. there the light or benefit of it ought not to be impaired by any Act what≈øoever; and ≈øuch was the opinion of the whole Court. But if the ca≈øe had been, That the hou≈øe & ≈øoil upon which Pope had erected the ≈øaid building, had been under the e≈øtate of Ma≈øon, who covenanted as above≈øaid, Then Pope could not have ju≈øtified the nu≈øance, which was granted by the whole Court.

div.head:
CCXXXV. Lee and Maddoxes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Intrat. Mich. 29, & 30 Eliz. Rot. 1737.
div.p:
Covenant. WIlliam Lee brought a Writ of Covenant again≈øt Richard Maddox, & I≈øabel his Wife, and declared, That one Errington the fir≈øt husband of the ≈øaid I≈øabel was endebted to the Plaintiff in 20 l. and that one Georgy A≈øhley was al≈øo endebted to the ≈øaid Errington, in the like ≈øum of 20 l. And al≈øo that the ≈øaid Errington made and con≈øtituted the ≈øaid I≈øabel his Executrix, and died, and afterwards the ≈øaid I≈øabel by Indenture dum ip≈øa ≈øola fuit, reciting that whereas her ≈øaid late husband was endebted to the Plaintiff in the ≈øum afore≈øaid, and whereas the ≈øaid George A≈øhley was al≈øo endebted unto her ≈øaid late Husband in the like ≈øum, Now for the better ≈øatisfaction of the Plaintiff for his ≈øaid Debt, ≈øhe appointed and con≈øtituted the Plaintiff, atturnatum ≈øuum irrevocabilem ad petendum, levandum, recuperand. & recipiend. ad u≈øum ≈øuum proprium in nomine dict. I≈øabellae de dicto Georgio, the ≈øaid twenty pounds; And the ≈øaid I≈øabel covenanted, quod ip≈øa ad requi≈ø. dict. quer. de tempore in tempus, adjuvaret, & manu teneret quamlibet & omnes ≈øectam &
≈øectas quam vel quas dictus querens commen≈øaret & pro≈øequeretur in nomine dictae I≈øabellae, again≈øt the ≈øaid George, to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff Non exi≈øtendo Non-≈øuit voluntarie, or making any Di≈øcontinuance, Relea≈øe, Revocations, Anglice, Countermand, without the a≈ø≈øent of the Plaintiff: And declared further, that the Plaintiff had brought a Suit again≈øt the ≈øaid George for the ≈øaid Debt, and ≈øhewed all in certain. And that the ≈øaid I≈øabel, depending the ≈øaid Suit,Countermand. had taken to Husband the Defendant without the a≈ø≈øent of the Plaintiff: And if by this Marriage the ≈øaid Suit be countermanded was the Que≈øtion. And fir≈øt it ≈øeemed to the Court that the Declaration was in≈øufficient,Reque≈øt. becau≈øe there is not any reque≈øt ≈øurmi≈øed in the Declaration, for the words of the Covenant are, Quod ip≈øa ad requi≈øitionem, &c. So as it ≈øeemed to the Iu≈øtices, that the Plaintiff ought to have notified to I≈øabel that he had commenced ≈øuch Suit, otherwi≈øe the Action will not lye. And al≈øo the Court was of opinion, that here is not any Countermand, for by the taking of the Husband the Writ is not abated, but only abateable; and therefore the Plaintiff ought to have ≈øhewed,1 Roll. 781. that by the taking of the Husband, the Writ by Iudgment was abated, otherwi≈øe it is not any Countermand, and their no cau≈øe of Action.

div.head:
CCXXXVI. Salway and Lu≈øons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
MAtthew Salway brought a Writ of Right again≈øt Lu≈øon, Writ of Right. 2 Len. 36. and the Writ was, Me≈ø≈øuag. & 200. acr. jampnor. & bruerae. And exception was taken to the Writ, becau≈øe jampnor. & bruerae, are counted together, where they ought to be di≈øtingui≈øhed ≈øeverally, As ≈øo many acr. jampnor. and ≈øo many acr. bruer. although it were objected on the part of the demandant in the maintenance of the Writ, that in the Regi≈øter the Writ of Right is reditu unius librae of Cloves and Mace together,Abatement of a Writ. without di≈øtinction or ≈øeverance. And it was ≈øaid, that in a Writ of Right we ought to follow the Regi≈øter, and therefore a Writ of Right was abated, becau≈øe this word (Pomarium) was put in the Writ, for in the Regi≈øter there is no ≈øuch Writ, becau≈øe the word Gardinum comprehends it: But in other Writs as Writs of Entry, &c. it is otherwi≈øe. See the Ca≈øe of the Lord Zouch, 11 Eliz. 353, In a Writ of Entre ≈øur di≈ø≈øei≈øin mille acr. jampnor. & bruer. But this exception was not allowed, for it may be that jampnor. & bruer. are ≈øo promi≈øcuous that they cannot be di≈øtingui≈øhed: Vide 16 H. 7. 8. 9. The re≈øpect the Iu≈øtices had to the Regi≈øter, was ≈øuch, as they changed their opinions and conformed the ≈øame to the Regi≈øter. Another exception was taken to the Writ, becau≈øe thereby the Demandant doth demand Duas partes Cu≈øtodiae del Hay in the Forre≈øt of C. And the Court was of opinion that the Writ ought to be Officium Cu≈øtodiae duarum partium de Hay, &c. and not Duas partes Cu≈øtodiae, As Advocationem duarum partium Eccle≈øiae, And not Duas partes Eccle≈øiae. Another Exception, becau≈øe the Writ was, duas partes, &c. in tribus dividend. where it ≈øhould be Divi≈ø. for Dividend. is not in any Writ, but only in a Writ of Partition; And by Windham the parts of this Office are divided in Right, which the Court granted. Another Exception was taken, becau≈øe that in the Writ it is not ≈øet down in what Town the Forre≈øt of C. is, ≈øo as the Court doth not know from whence the Vi≈øne ≈øhould come: For no Venire ≈øhall be de vicineto Fore≈øtae, as de vicineto Hundredi, 1 Cro. 200. & Manerii; And the ≈øame was holden to be a material Exception. Another Exception was taken,Vi≈øne. becau≈øe a Writ of Right doth not lye of an Office: for at the Common Law an A≈ø≈øi≈øe did not lye of it, but now
it doth by the Statute of We≈øt. 2. Cap. 25. for it was not Liberum ten. but the party grieved was put to his Quod permittat: And of this opinion was the whole Court.

div.head:
CCXXXVII. Smith and Lanes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Queen was ≈øei≈øed of a Manor whereof Bl. acr. was holden by Copy in Fee; the Queen lea≈øed Bl. acr. to B. for one and twenty years, who a≈ø≈øigned the ≈øame to the Copyholder, who accepted of it. The Queen granted Bl. acr. to C. in Fee,Copyholder determined by acceptance of a Lea≈øe. 2 Co. 16, 17. the term expired, C. entred, and his entry was holden to be congeable, for by acceptance of the ≈øam Term, the Cu≈øtomary E≈øtate was determined, as if the Copyholder had accepted it immediatly from the Queen: It was al≈øo holden by the Court, that a Lea≈øe for years under the Seal of the Exchequer may be pleaded, and that without making mention of the Commi≈ø≈øion, by which the Court of Exchequer is authorized to make ≈øuch Lea≈øes: And ≈øo are all the Pre≈øidents as well in this Court as in the Court of Exchequer. And whereas the Court was upon the point of giving their Iudgment, It was objected by Shuttleworth Serjeant, That here is pleaded a Bargain and Sale of Land, without, ≈øaying pro quadam pecuniae ≈øumma: And he ≈øtood much upon the Exception, and the Court al≈øo doubted of it, and demanded of the Prothonotaries what is their form of pleading:Bargain and Sale, and con≈øideration of it. And by Nel≈øon cheif Prothonotary; the≈øe words Pro quadam pecuniae ≈øumma, ought to be in the pleading. Scot Prothonotary contrary. Ander≈øon conceived it was either way good, but Pro quadam pecuniae ≈øumma is the be≈øt: And ≈øo Leonard Cu≈øtos Brevium conceived. And the opinion of the Iu≈øtices was, that a Bargain and Sale for dives Cau≈øes and Con≈øiderations is not good without a ≈øum of money.1 Co. Mildmays Ca≈øe. And by Windham, Bargain and Sale Pro quadam pecuniae ≈øumma, although no money be paid, is good enough, for the payment or not payment is not traver≈øable: And by Periam, If Pro quadam pecuniae ≈øumma, be not in the Indenture of Bargain and Sale, yet the payment thereof is averrable. And for this Exception the Iudgment was ≈øtayed.

div.head:
CCXXXVIII. Bedel and Moores Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. In the Exchequer Chamber.
div.p: Action upon the Ca≈øe for not performing an Award. BEdel brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Moore in the Kings-Bench, and declared, That the Defendant did a≈ø≈øume to perform the Award of J.S. and a≈ø≈øumed al≈øo, that he would not ≈øue Execution upon a Iudgment which he had obtained again≈øt the Plaintiff in an Action of Account, &c. And ≈øhewed further, that the Award was made, &c. (which Award in Law was utterly void) and that the Defendant had not performed the ≈øaid Award, and al≈øo that he had ≈øued Execution again≈øt the Plaintiff.10 Co. 131. 5 Co. 108. The Defendant pleaded Non-a≈ø≈øump≈øit, and it was found for the Plaintiff, and Iudgment given accordingly. Vpon which Moore brought a Writ of Error in the Exchequer-chamber, upon the Statute of 27 Eliz. And a≈ø≈øigned Error,Error. becau≈øe the Plaintiff had declared upon two Breaches, whereas for one of them there was not any cau≈øe of Action, for the Award is void in Law, & then no breach could be a≈ø≈øigned in that; and then when the Iury hath a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Damages intirement for both breaches, whereas for one there was not any cau≈øe of Action by the Law, the Verdict was void, & then the Iudgment given upon it rever≈øable; for it is not rea≈øon that the Plaintiff have Damages for ≈øuch matter for which the Law doth not give an Action.

And if the Iury had a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed damages ≈øeverally, viz. For the not performance of the Award ≈øo much,Damages. and for the ≈øuing forth Execution ≈øo much, then the Iudgment had been good, and the damages a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for the not performance, &c. void. Manwood Chief Baron: The verdict is well enough, for here the whole A≈ø≈øump≈øit is put in i≈ø≈øue, and there is but one i≈ø≈øue upon the whole A≈ø≈øump≈øit, but if ≈øeveral i≈ø≈øues had been joined upon the≈øe ≈øeveral points of the A≈ø≈øump≈øit, and both had been found for the Plaintiff, and damages a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed entirely for both breaches, then was the Iudgment rever≈øable, for being ≈øeveral i≈ø≈øues the Iury might have a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the damages ≈øeverally, ≈øcil. for each i≈ø≈øue ≈øeveral damages, but here is but one i≈ø≈øue, and it was the folly of the Defendant that he would not demur in Law upon the Declaration for one part, ≈øcil. the not performance of the Award, and traver≈øe the other part, ≈øcil. The ≈øuing of the Execution, or the A≈ø≈øump≈øit of it. And in our ca≈øe, it may be that the Iury did a≈ø≈øe≈øs the damages for the ≈øuing of the Execution without any regard had to the performance of the Award: And note that the verdict for a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing of the Damages was in the≈øe Terms, ≈øcil. Et a≈ø≈øidunt damna occa≈øione non performationis A≈ø≈øump≈øionis praedict. &c. And Cook who was of Councel in this Ca≈øe, put this Ca≈øe. The late Earl of Lincoln, Admiral of England, brought his Action of Scandalis Magnatum, and declared, That the Defendant exhibited in the Star-chamber again≈øt him a Bill of Complaint, containing diver≈øe great and infamous ≈ølanders: viz. That the ≈øaid Earl was a great and outragious oppre≈ø≈øour; and u≈øed outragious oppre≈ø≈øion, and violence again≈øt the Defendant, and all the Country al≈øo. The Defendant pleaded, Not guilty, and found for the Plaintiff, and a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed damages, and it was moved in ≈øtay of Iudgment, fir≈øt, That the Plaintiff had declared upon matter of ≈ølander for part, for which an Action lyeth, and for part not. For the oppre≈ø≈øion ≈øuppo≈øed to be made to him≈øelf, no Action lieth, becau≈øe every ≈øubject may complain for wrong done unto him, and although he cannot prove the wrong, an Action will not lye. But as for the oppre≈ø≈øion done to others by the ≈øuppo≈øal of the Bill an Action lieth, for what is that to him, he hath not to do with it, for he is not pars gravata. But becau≈øe the Iury a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Damages entirement, the Iudgment was arre≈øted, for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid. And afterwards in the principal ca≈øe, the la≈øt day of this term, Iudgment was ≈øtaied.

div.head:
CCXXXIX. Palmer and Thorps Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: BEtwixt Palmer and Thorpe, the Ca≈øe was this,1 Cro. 152 A man demi≈øed his Manour of M. for thirty two years, and the day after let the ≈øame Manour for forty years, to begin from Michaelmas, after the date of the fir≈øt Lea≈øe, and the Tenant attorned. And by Cook the ≈øame is a good grant, although to begin at a day to come, for it is but a Chattel; and ≈øo was the opinion of Wray Chief Iu≈øtice, for a Lea≈øe for years may expect its commencement, as a man ≈øei≈øed of a Rent in Fee grants the ≈øame for twenty years from Mich. following, and good, for no e≈øtate pa≈ø≈øeth pre≈øently, but only an Intere≈øt. See 28 H. 8. 26. Dyer.

div.head:
CCXL. Sir Anthony Shirley and Albanyes Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Rot. 668.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit by Sir Anthony Shirley again≈øt Albany. A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 150. The Plaintiff declared, That he was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Whittington for the term of his life, the Rever≈øion to the Earl of Arrundel in Fee, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, ≈øurrendered all his E≈øtate to the ≈øaid Earl, who afterwards by his Deed granted a Rent-charge of 40 l. per annum out of the ≈øaid Mannor to him, and afterwards conveyed the Manor to the Defendant in Fee. And afterwards, 27 Maii 22. Eliz. upon a Communication betwixt the Plaintiff and the Defendant concerning the ≈øaid Rent; the Defendant did promi≈øe to the Plaintiff, that if the Plaintiff would ≈øhew unto the Defendant any Deed, by which it might appear that he ought to pay to the Plaintiff ≈øuch a Rent, he would pay that which is due, and that which ≈øhould be due from time to time. And further declared, that 27 April 27 Eliz. he ≈øhewed unto the Defendant a Deed, by which it appeared that ≈øuch a Rent was granted, and due; And for eighty pounds due for the two la≈øt years, he brought the Action. The Defendant pleaded, that after the ≈øaid promi≈øe, and before the ≈øhewing of the ≈øaid Deed, ≈øcil. 14 Jan. 22 Eliz. the Plaintiff entred into the ≈øaid Land, and lea≈øed the ≈øame for three years. The Plaintiff Replicando ≈øaid, that 1 Decem. 27 Eliz. the Defendant did re-enter, upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue, and it was found for the Plaintiff. It was moved by Glanvil Serjeant, that by the entry the Promi≈øe was ≈øu≈øpended, and being a per≈øonal thing once ≈øu≈øpended, it is always extinct. Wray, The Action is brought for the Arrerages due the two la≈øt years, and ≈øo at the time of his re-entry the Plaintiff had not cau≈øe of Action, and therefore it could not be ≈øu≈øpended.Su≈øpen≈øion of Rent. Ante. 110. Gawdy, When the Plaintiff ≈øheweth the Deed, the Defendant is chargable to arrerages due before and after the promi≈øe; wherefore if the entry maketh a ≈øu≈øpending of the Rent, the ≈øu≈øpen≈øion doth continue: but I conceive here is not any ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, for this promi≈øe is a meer collateral thing, and ≈øo not di≈øcharged by the entry into the Land, for it is not i≈ø≈øuing out of the Land. But if the Plaintiff before the Deed ≈øhewed had relea≈øed all Actions, the ≈øame had been a good Bar; and I conceive that the Deed was not ≈øhewed in time, for it ought to be ≈øhewn before any arrerages due after the promi≈øe, but here it is ≈øhewn five years after: But that was not denied by all ther other Iu≈øtices. Another exception was taken, that where the promi≈øe was, that if the Plaintiff ≈øhewed any Deed by which it might appear, that the Defendant ≈øhould be charged with the ≈øaid Rent, and the Declaration is, by which it might appear, that the Plaintiff ought to have the Rent, &c. ≈øo as the Declaration doth not agree in the whole. See 1 Ma. 143. in Browning and Be≈øtons Ca≈øe, the Condition of the Lea≈øe was, if the Rent ≈øhould be arrear, not paid by two Months after the Fea≈øt, &c. and the Rejoynder was by the ≈øpace of two months, &c. And the pleading holden in≈øufficient, for per duos men≈øes doth not affirm directly po≈øt duos men≈øes, but by Implication and Argument: And here it was holden, that the Condition was a good con≈øideration. Another exception was taken, becau≈øe the promi≈øe is layed, All the Rent ad tunc debitum aut deinceps debend. It was holden, that this word (ad tunc) doth refer to the time of the ≈øhewing of the Deed, and not to the promi≈øe. And as to the la≈øt exception but one, it was re≈øolved, that the Declaration, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øame, was good enough (≈øcil.) o≈øtendit factum per quod apparet quod redditus praedict. ≈øolvi deberet in forma praedict. Another exception was taken, becau≈øe here no breach of the promi≈øe is
alledged, for it is pleaded, thath eight pounds de annuali redditu arrer. fuer. but it is not ≈øaid, de redditu praedict. 8 l. ergo it may be another Rent, and then the promi≈øe, as to this Rent, is not broken. Wray, Although the word (praedict.) be wanting, yet the Declaration is well enough, and it ≈øhall be intended the Rent mentioned before. See 21 H. 7. 30. b. Where (Villa We≈øt.) ≈øhall be intended Villa praedict. 19 E. 4. 1. In a Quare Impedit the Plaintiff doth entitle him≈øelf by grant of the next Avoydance cum acciderit, and doth not ≈øhew in his Count that the ≈øame was the next Avoydance, and yet the Count was holden to be good, for ≈øo it ≈øhall be intended; ≈øo here: And he ≈øaid, It is not nece≈ø≈øary that a Declaration be exactly certain in every point, but if one part of it expound the other, it is well enough: And although the Identity of the Rent doth not appear by the word praedict. yet it appeareth by other circum≈øtances, as by the days of payment, &c. and no other Rent can be intended. And now, this Exception is after Verdict, and therefore favourably to be taken: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCXLI. Mu≈øted and Hoppers Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared,A≈ø≈øum≈øit. p 1 Cro. 149. That where he and one Atkin≈øal, were joyntly and ≈øeverally bounden by Obligation in fifty pounds, to a ≈øtranger, for the only Debt of the ≈øaid Atkin≈øal, which Atkin≈øal died, and the Defendant married afterwards his Wife, and ≈øo the Goods of Atkin≈øal came to his hands; yet the Plaintiff, the fir≈øt day of May after, which was the day of payment of the money, paid five and twenty pounds for avoiding the Forfeiture of the penalty. The Defendant as well in con≈øideration of the Premi≈ø≈øes, as in con≈øideration that he might peaceably enjoy the Goods of the Te≈øtator promi≈øed to pay the ≈øaid ≈øum, cum inde requi≈øitus fuer. And upon Non A≈ø≈øump≈øit, the Iury found the payment of the ≈øaid ≈øum, and all the precedent matter: And that the Defendant in con≈øideration praemi≈ø≈øiorum, promi≈øed to pay the ≈øaid ≈øum if he might peaceably enjoy the Goods of the ≈øaid Te≈øtator. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that although here the Iury have found ≈øufficient cau≈øe of Action, yet if the Declaration be not accordingly, the Plaintiff ≈øhall not have Iudgment.Verdict. And here the Plaintiff hath declared upon two Con≈øiderations, and the Iury hath found but one, ≈øcil. if he peaceably enjoy the Goods of the Te≈øtator. Al≈øo the Plaintiff declared of a ≈øimple promi≈øe, and the Iury have found a Conditional, Si gaudere pote≈øt, &c. And ≈øo the promi≈øe ≈øet forth in the Declaration, is not found in the Verdict.

Gawdy was of opinion, That the fir≈øt con≈øideration is good,Con≈øideration. for the Plaintiff entred into Bond at the reque≈øt of the Defendant, and then the promi≈øe following is good: But the ≈øecond con≈øideration is void, ≈øcil. That the Defendant ≈øhall enjoy the goods of the Te≈øtator, &c. as if it had been that he ≈øhould enjoy his own goods. And all the Iu≈øtices were clear of opinion. That the Promi≈øe found by the Iury is not the promi≈øe alledged in the Declaration, and ≈øo the i≈ø≈øue is not found for the Plaintiff, and ≈øo the judgment was ≈øtayed.

div.head:
CCXLII. Creckmere and Patter≈øons Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Rot. 568.
div.p: Devi≈øe conditional. 1 Cro. 146. 1 Roll. 410. 1 In≈øt. 236. b.UPon a ≈øpecial Verdict, the Ca≈øe was this, Robert Dookin was ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands in Fee, and having i≈ø≈øue two Daughters, devi≈øed the ≈øame to Alice his Elde≈øt Daughter, that ≈øhe ≈øhould pay forty pound to Ann her Si≈øter at ≈øuch a Day; the money is not paid, whereupon Ann entreth into the moiety of the Land: And it was holden by the whole Court, that the ≈øame is a good Condition, and that the Entry of Ann was lawful. It hath been adjudged, That where a man devi≈øed his Land to his wife, Provi≈øo, My will is, That ≈øhe ≈øhall keep my hou≈øe in good Reparations, that the ≈øame is a good Condition. Wray, A man devi≈øeth his Lands to B. paying 40 l. to C. it is a good condition; for C. hath no other remedy, and a Will ought to be expounded according to the intent of the Devi≈øor.

div.head:
CCXLIII. Dove and Williots and others Ca≈øe..
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 160.IN an Ejectione firmae, upon a ≈øpecial Verdict, the ca≈øe was, That W. was ≈øei≈øed of the Land, where, &c. and held the ≈øame by Copy, &c. and ≈øurrendred the ≈øame unto the u≈øe of E. for life, the Remainder to Robert and A. in Fee, Robert made a Lea≈øe to the Defendant; E. Robert, & A. ≈øurrendred the ≈øaid Land, ≈øcil. a third part to the u≈øe of Robert for the life of E. the Remainder to the Right heirs of Robert, and of another third part to the u≈øe of Robert for life, the Remainder to E. the Remainder to Richard, &c. and of another third part to the u≈øe of A. and his Heirs. After which Partition was made betwixt them, and the Land where, &c. was allotted to Richard, who afterwards ≈øurrendred to the u≈øe of the Plaintiff. It was holden, That Iudgment upon this verdict ought not to be given for the Plaintiff, For the Le≈ø≈øee of Robert had the fir≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and that Lea≈øe is to begin after the death of E. who was Tenant for life, and when E. and he in the Rever≈øion joyn in a ≈øurrender, thereby the e≈øtate for life in that third part is extinct in Robert, who hath the Inheritance, and then his Lea≈øe took effect for a third Part. So that the Parties here are Tenants in Common,1 In≈øt. 200. betwixt whom Tre≈øpa≈øs doth not lye.

div.head:
CCXLIV. Bulleyn and Graunts Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Copyhold.UPon Evidence to a Iury, the Ca≈øe was, That Henry Bulleyn the Father, was ≈øei≈øed of the Land being Copyhold, and had I≈ø≈øue three Sons, Gregory, Henry, andy Thomas, and afterwards ≈øurrendred to the u≈øe of the la≈øt Will,Devi≈øe. 1 Cro. 148. and thereby devi≈øed the ≈øaid Land to Joan his Wife for life, the remainder to the ≈øaid Henry, and the Heirs of his body begotten: Joan died, after admittance, Henry died without I≈ø≈øue, and afterwards the Lord granted it to Thomas and his Heirs, who ≈øurrendred to the u≈øe of the Defendant then his Wife for life, and afterwards died without I≈ø≈øue: Gregory elde≈øt Son of Henry Bulleyn entred, &c.
