Coke, When the Father ≈øurrendreth to the u≈øe of his la≈øt Will, thereby all pa≈ø≈øeth out of him, ≈øo as nothing accrueth
to the Heir, nor can he have and demand any thing before admittance. Wray, The entry of Gregory is lawful, and admittance for him is not nece≈ø≈øary, for if a Copyholder ≈øurrendereth to the u≈øe of one for life who is admitted, and dieth, he in the Rever≈øion may enter without a new Admittance. It was moved by Coke, if this E≈øtate limited to Henry be an E≈øtate tail, or a Fee conditional, For if it be a Fee-≈øimple conditional, then there cannot be another E≈øtate over: but yet in ca≈øe of a Devi≈øe an E≈øtate may depend upon a Fee-≈øimple precedent, but not as a Will, but as an Executory Devi≈øe. Wray, It is not a conditional E≈øtate in Fee, but an E≈øtate tail. Coke, They who would prove the Cu≈øtom to entail Copyhold Land within a Manor, it is not ≈øufficient to ≈øhew Copies of Grants to per≈øons and the Heirs of their bodies,Copyhold E≈øtate. but they ought to ≈øhew that ≈øurrenders made by ≈øuch per≈øons have been enjoyed by rea≈øon of ≈øuch matter. VVray, That is not ≈øo, for Cu≈øtomary Lands may be granted in tail, and yet no ≈øurrenders have been made within time of memory.

div.head:
CCXLV. Matthew and Ha≈ø≈øals Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Ejectione firmae, betwixt Matthew and Ha≈ø≈øal, the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover, and the Defendant brought a Writ of Error,Error. 1 Cro. 144. and a≈ø≈øigned Error in this, that the Iudgment was entred, Quod querens recuperet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem, &c. where it ≈øhould be (Terminum) vent. in ten. praedict. See 9 Eliz. Dyer 258. Coke contrary, That the Iudgment is good enough, for the Writ of Execution upon it is Habere facias po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem, and in a real Action the Writ is, Quod perens recuperet ≈øe≈øinam, and not terram. And afterwards Iudgment was affirmed.

div.head:
CCXLVI. Tempe≈øt and Mallets Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs by Tempe≈øt again≈øt Mallet, Iudgment was given, and Eror brought, and a≈ø≈øigned for Error;1 Cro. 153, 145. that whereas the Action was brought again≈øt four, one of them died, Me≈øne betwixt the Award of the Ni≈øi prius, and the Inque≈øt taken: And it was ≈øaid on the part of the Defendant in the Writ of Error which was entred upon the Record, that the Plaintiff ≈øhewed unto the Court the death of one of the Defendants, and prayed Iudgment again≈øt the others. See 4 H. 7. 2 Eliz. 175. And there is a difference, where in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs there is but one Defendant, and where many. Another Error was a≈ø≈øigned, the Defendant Obtulit ≈øe per Higgins Attornat. ≈øuum, without ≈øhewing his Chri≈øtian Name, as John, or VVilliam; for Higgins only without the Chri≈øtian Name, is not any Name, for it is but an addition to ≈øhew, which John, or VVilliam. Coke. The ≈øame is helped by the Statute of 32 H. 8. cap. 30. Where it is enacted, that after Verdict, Iudgment ≈øhall be given notwith≈øtanding the lack of Warrant of Attorney of the party again≈øt whom the I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall be tried, or any default or negligence of any the parties, their Coun≈øellors or Attorneys; and of nece≈ø≈øity this default here in the Chri≈øtian Name ought to be the fault of one of them. See al≈øo 18 Eliz. Cap. 14. for want of any Warrant of Attorney, &c. Glanvil, The Statute provides for default of Warrant of Attorney, &c. Then (Coke) To what end was the Statute of 18 Eliz. made? for the Statute of 32 H. 8. provides for defects of Warrants of Attorney. Glanvil, The fir≈øt Statutes for Warrants of Attorneys of ≈øuch per≈øons again≈øt
whom the I≈ø≈øue was tryed, but the later Stat. is general. Another Error was a≈ø≈øigned, Quod defendens Capiatur, where the Offence, & ≈øo the Fine is pardoned by Parliament, and therefore the entry of the Iudgment ought to be, Et de fine nihil, quia perdonatur. Coke, The Iudgment is well enough, for in every general Pardon ≈øome per≈øons are excepted; & it doth not appear if the Defendant here were one of them, and then the Fine is not pardoned,1 Cro. 768. 778. 3 Cro. 22. for the Court cannot take notice of that, as it was holden in Serjeant Harris Ca≈øe: but if the Defendant be charged with the Fine, then he ought to plead the pardon, and to ≈øhew that he was not any of the per≈øons excepted. And afterwards at another day the Defendant did alledge, that there was a Warrant of Attorney in the Common Pleas. And al≈øo it appeareth upon Record, that the Defendant did appear upon the Super≈øedeas by Attorney, who had his full Name, and therefore prayed a Certiorari de novo, to certifie the ≈øame matter, vide 9 E. 4. 32. VVray, A Ca≈øe here greatly debated betwixt the Lord Norris and Braybrook, In nullo e≈øt erratum. and upon Advice ≈øuch a Writ of Certiorari was granted after the Plaintiff had pleaded In nullo e≈øt erratum; for this Plea, in nullo e≈øt erratum, goes but to that which is contained within the body of the Record, and not unto collateral matter, ≈øcil. Warrant of Attorneys: And afterwards the Writ of Error was allowed, and upon the day of return thereof, it appeared upon the Record of Super≈øedeas, that the Defendant did appear by ≈øuch a one his Attorney: But it was ≈øaid by the Court, that there ought to be two appearances, the one upon the Super≈øedeas, and the other when the Plaintiff declares. See as to the name of the Attorney, Tirrells Ca≈øe, 1 Mar. Dyer 93.

div.head:
CCXLVII. Palmer and Knowllis Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 160. PAlmer recovered Debt again≈øt Knowllis, and ≈øued Execution by Elegit, upon which the Sheriff returned, that he had made Execution of the lands of the Defendant by the Oath of twelve men, but he could not deliver it to the party,Execution. for it is extended to another upon a Statute, upon which the Plaintiff ≈øued a Capias ad ≈øatisfaciendum. And now came the Defendant by his Coun≈øel, and moved that after Elegit returned, the Plaintiff could not re≈øort to the Execution by Capias, and therefore prayed a Super≈øedeas, Caplas after Elegit. becau≈øe the Capias erronice emanavit. But the whole Court was clear to the contrary; for upon Nihil returned upon Elegit, the Plaintiff ≈øhall have a Capias, 17 E. 4. 5. See 21 H. 7. 19. A man ≈øhall have a Capias after a Fieri facias, or Elegit, 34 H. 6. 20. and here the ≈øpecial return doth amount to as much, as if the Sheriff had returned Nihil: Al≈øo the Statute of We≈øt. 2. which giveth the Elegit, is not in the Negative, and therefore it ≈øhall not take away the Execution which was at the Common Law. And here is no Execution returned, for after the former extent ended, he ought to have a new Elegit; which Wray granted: And afterwards the ≈øaid Knowllis was taken by force of the Capias ad ≈øatisfaciend. and came into Court in the Cu≈øtody of the Sheriff, and the Ca≈øe was opened, and in the whole appeared to be worthy of favour; but by the Law he could not be helped, and although he in≈øtantly prayed a Super≈øedeas, yet the ≈øame was denied unto him.

div.head:
CCXLVIII. The Church-wardens of Fether≈øtones Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: AN Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs was brought by the Church-wardens of Fether≈øtone in the County of Norfolk, and declared,Church-wardens. 1 Cro. 145. 179. That the Defendant took out of the ≈øaid Church a Bell, and declared, that the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done 20 Eliz. And it was found for the Plaintiffs. And now it was moved by Godfrey in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That it is apparent upon the Declaration, That the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done in the time of their Predece≈ø≈øors, of which the Succe≈ø≈øor cannot have action; and actio per≈øonalis moritur cum per≈øona. See 19 H. 6. 66. But the old Church-wardens ≈øhall have the action. Cook contrary, and that the pre≈øent Church-wardens ≈øhall have the action, and that in re≈øpect of their office, which the Court granted. And by Gawdy, Church-wardens are a Corporation by the Common Law. See 12 H. 7. 28. by Frowick, That the New Church-wardens ≈øhall not have an action upon ≈øuch a Tre≈øpa≈øs done to their Predece≈ø≈øors, contrary by Yaxley. See by Newton and Pa≈øton, That the Executors of the Guardian in who≈øe time the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done, ≈øhall have Tre≈øpa≈øs.

div.head:
CCXLIX. Hauxwood and Husbands Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared for di≈øturbing of him to u≈øe his common, &c. and ≈øhewed, that A. was ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands, to which this Common was appendant,Pre≈øcription. 1 Cro. 153. for the term of his Life, the Remainder to B. in tail, and that the ≈øaid A. and B. did demi≈øe unto him the ≈øaid Lands for years, &c. Pepper, The Declaration is not good, for it is not ≈øhewed how the≈øe particular e≈øtates did commence. See 20 E. 4. 10. By Piggot, Le≈ø≈øee for life and he in the Remainder, cannot pre≈øcribe together; and he in the Remainder cannot have common. Al≈øo he declares, That Tenant for life, and he in Remainder demi≈øed to him, whereas in truth it is the demi≈øe of Tenant for life, and the Confirmation of him in the Remainder; al≈øo he doth not aver the life of Tenant for life. Popham, He needs not to ≈øhew the commencement of the particular e≈øtates, for we are a ≈øtranger to them, the Pre≈øcription in them both is well enough, for all is but one e≈øtate, and the Lea≈øe of both. See 27 H. 8. 13. The Le≈ø≈øee for life, and he in the Rever≈øion made a Lea≈øe for life, and joyned in an action of wa≈øt, and there needs no averment of the life of the Tenant for life, for he in the Rever≈øion hath joyned; which Gawdy granted as to all. And ≈øaid the particular e≈øtates are but as conveyance unto the action. Wray conceived the fir≈øt Exception to be material, &c.

div.head: CCL. Sweeper and Randals Ca≈øe, Rot. 770. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking of his Clo≈øe, and carrying away his goods, by Sweeper again≈øt Randal, upon Not guilty pleaded,i Cro. 156. The Iury found, That one John Gilbert was ≈øei≈øed of the Land, where, &c. and lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Plaintiff at Will, who ≈øowed the Land, and afterwards the Plaintiff agreed with the ≈øaid Gilbert, to ≈øurrender to him the ≈øaid Land, and his intere≈øt in the ≈øame; and the ≈øaid Gilbert entred, and lea≈øed to the Defendant, who took the Corn. It was
moved, if the≈øe words, I agree to ≈øurrender my Lands, be a pre≈øent and expre≈øs ≈øurrender. Gawdy, It is not any ≈øurrender, for Tenant at will cannot ≈øurrender, but it is but a relinqui≈øhing of the e≈øtate, if it be any thing;Surrender. but in truth it is not any thing in pre≈øent, but an act to be done in future. Wray, I agree. A. demi≈øeth the Manor of D. at will, it is no Lea≈øe, no more ≈øhall it be here any Surrender, or any relinqui≈øhing of the e≈øtate. Clench conceived, That the intent of the Party was, to leave his e≈øtate at the time of the ≈øpeaking, otherwi≈øe tho≈øe words were void, for he might leave it at any time without tho≈øe words. Gawdy, If ≈øuch was his intent, the Iury ought to find it expre≈øsly; and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCLI. Ward and Blunts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Trover and Conver≈øion. 1 Cro. 146.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe of Trover of certain Loads of Corn at Henden in Middle≈øex, and the conver≈øion of them; The Defendant pleaded, That before the conver≈øion, he was ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands called Harminglow in the County of Stafford, and that the Corn whereof, &c. was there growing, and that he did ≈øever it, by force of which he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and the ≈øame ca≈øually lo≈øt; and that the ≈øame came to the hands of the Plaintiff, and the Plaintiff ca≈øually lo≈øt the ≈øame, and the ≈øame came to the hands of the Defendant at Henden, afore≈øaid, and he did convert the ≈øame to his own u≈øe, as it was lawful for him to do: upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. Atkin≈øon, The Plea is good, for the conver≈øion is the point of the action, and the effect of it. For if a man take the ≈øame, and do not convert, he is not guilty. And here the Defendant doth ju≈øtifie the conver≈øion, wherefore he cannot plead, Not guilty. The general i≈ø≈øue is to be taken where a man hath not any colour, but here the Defendant hath colour, becau≈øe the Corn whereof, &c. was growing upon his Land, which might enveigle the Lay people, and therefore it is ≈øafe≈øt to plead the ≈øpecial matter. But admit, that it doth amount but to the general i≈ø≈øue; yet there is not any cau≈øe of Demurrer, but the Plaintiff ought to ≈øhew the ≈øame to the Court, and pray that the general i≈ø≈øue be entred; and the Court ex officio ought to do it. Egerton, the Queens Solicitor, contrary. The Plea in Bar is not good; The Plaintiff declares of a Trover of his goods, ut de bonis ≈øuis propriis, and the Defendant pleads, That he took his own goods, which is not any an≈øwer to the Plaintiff. See 22 E. 3. 18. In Tre≈øpa≈øs of taking and carrying away his Trees, The Defendant pleads, That they were our Trees, growing in our own ≈øoil, and we cut them and carryed them away, and the plea was challenged, wherefore the Defendant pleaded over, without that that he took the Trees of the Plaintiff. So 26 A≈ø≈ø. 22. and 30 E. 3. 22. Another matter was, The Plea in Bar is, That before the time of the Conver≈øion, the Defendant was ≈øei≈øed of the Land, and ≈øowed it; and that after the Corn was ≈øevered, (but he doth not ≈øay that he was ≈øei≈øed at the time of the ≈øeverance) and then it might be that he had ≈øevered the Corn of the Plaintiff, &c. and that was holden by the Court to be a material exception, wherefore Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff: But as to the fir≈øt Exception, the ≈øame was di≈øallowed, For the Court ex Officio, in ≈øuch ca≈øe ought to cau≈øe the general i≈ø≈øue to be entred, but the Plaintiff ought not to demur upon it.

div.head: CCLIV. Cheiny and Langleys Ca≈øe, Hill. 31. Eliz. Rott. 638. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe ca≈øe was, That Tenant for life of certain Lands lea≈øed the ≈øame for years by Indenture, with the≈øe words; I give, grant,1 Cro. 157. Lea≈øes. bargain, and ≈øell my intere≈øt in ≈øuch Lands for twenty years, To have and to hold, in ≈øuch manner, and form as I my ≈øelf did hold the ≈øame, and no otherwi≈øe: Tenant for life died within the Term, and he in the Rever≈øion entred, and the Le≈ø≈øee brought an action of Covenant. Godfrey, The action doth not ly, for here is not any warranty, for the Plaintiff is not Le≈ø≈øee, but A≈ø≈øignee, to whom this Warranty in Law cannot extend; but admit that the Warranty doth extend to the Plaintiff, yet it is now determined with the e≈øtate of the Tenant for life, and ≈øo the Covenant ended with the e≈øtate. See 32 H. 6. 32. by Littleton 9. Eliz. Dyer 257.Covenant. And if Tenant in tail make a Lea≈øe for years (ut ≈øupra) and afterwards dieth without i≈ø≈øue, the Covenant is gone; and after Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head: CCLV. Fi≈øh, Brown and Sadlers Ca≈øe, Intrat. Mich. 29 Eliz. Rot. 606. Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
AN action upon the Ca≈øe was brought by Fi≈øh and Brown again≈øt Sadler, Hill. 29 Eliz. rot. 606. and they declared,Action upon the Ca≈øe. That they were proprietaries of certain goods, which were in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one A. again≈øt which A. Sadler one of the Defendants had commenced a feigned and covenous ≈øuit in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court in the Name of one Colli≈øon, to the intent to get the ≈øaid goods into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, of which the Plaintiffs having notice, and to the intent that the ≈øaid Plaintiffs ≈øhould ≈øuffer the Defendant to recover and obtain the ≈øaid goods by the ≈øaid ≈øuit, the Defendant did promi≈øe to the Plaintiffs to render to them a true accompt of the ≈øaid goods; and ≈øhewed further, That by the ≈øaid ≈øuit the Defend. did obtain the ≈øaid goods by ≈øufferance of the Plaintiff. Tanfeild, It is a good con≈øideration, the Plaintiffs were not parties or Privies at the beginning of the ≈øuit, & it is not like Onlies Ca≈øe in 19 Eliz. Dyer 355. Where in an action upon the Ca≈øe Onlie declared,A≈ø≈øump≈øit and con≈øideration. That the Defendant Counte≈øs, &c. being a Widow, had divers ≈øuits and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, and that the Plaintiff at her reque≈øt had be≈øtowed great labour and travail, and had expended circa the affairs of the ≈øaid Counte≈øs 1500 l. Whereupon ≈øhe promi≈øed to the Plaintiff to pay all the ≈øaid expences, and ≈øuch a ≈øum above, for that matter which is the ground of the action, is maintenance, and malum prohibitum, but ≈øuch matter is not here; for it is lawful for a man to u≈øe means to get his goods. Gawdy; All covins are abhorred in Law, and here the Plaintiffs are privies to the wrong, and therefore, it cannot be any con≈øideration. Wray, Although that the ≈øuit at the beginning was wrongful and covenous, yet when the Plaintiffs who were owners of the ≈øaid goods do a≈ø≈øent to ≈øuch proceedings, now the ≈øuit is become ju≈øt and lawful ab initio, Corin. and ≈øo no wrong in the con≈øideration, but all the wrong is purged by the agreement. If any covin be, the ≈øame is between Sadler and him who is ≈øued, to whom the Plaintiffs are not privies. Clench, If this privity betwixt the Plaintiffs and Sadler had been before the ≈øaid ≈øuit; then the con≈øideration is without any fraud. Cooper Serjeant conceived here is not any good con≈øideration, upon which the Promi≈øe of the Defendant may be
grounded, for the Defendant hath not any benefit by it, and he cited the ca≈øe between Smith and Smith 25 Eliz. Egerton, Here the con≈øideration is good enough, for the Plaintiffs forbear their own ≈øuit, which was a hinderance unto them. Clench was of opinion, that the Plaintiff ≈øhould not have Iudgment, for that ≈øuit was begun by Sadler in the Name of Colli≈øon without his privity, and therefor it was unlawful, and the ≈øame was for the goods of another man, which is unlawful al≈øo, and then when the unlawful act is begun, the illegal agreement afterwards that they ≈øhall proceed is unlawful al≈øo, and therefore there cannot be any con≈øideration: and as to the covin, it is not material, for without that the matter is illegal enough. Al≈øo the Declaration is not good in this, becau≈øe it is not ≈øhewed in what Court the ≈øuit did depend, ≈øo as it might appear unto us, that they had power to hold plea of it. Gawdy agreed with Clench in the fir≈øt point, and al≈øo in the la≈øt; and by him, in the a≈ø≈øump≈øit, the Plaintiff declares, that a ≈øuit was depending betwixt the Defendant and another, and where the Plaintiffs if they were produced might have given ≈øtrong witne≈øs again≈øt the Defendant, the ≈øaid Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiffs would not give Te≈øtimony again≈øt him, promi≈øed to give to the Plaintiff 20 l. the ≈øame con≈øideration will not maintain this action; becau≈øe it is unlawful for any man to ≈øuppre≈øs te≈øtimony in any cau≈øe.1 Cro. 337. Wray, Here is a con≈øideration good enough, For where Sadler ≈øhould lo≈øe co≈øts upon the fir≈øt ≈øuit, now upon this promi≈øe upon his account he ≈øhall be allowed the ≈øame, the which is a benefit unto him: and as to the ≈øhewing in what Court the ≈øuit doth depend, that needs not by way of Declaration, but the ≈øame ≈øhall be ≈øhewed by way of Evidence, and it is not traver≈øable, and it is but inducement to the action. And as to the covin, that is not here, for covin is always to the prejudice of a third per≈øon, but ≈øo it is not here: But in truth this ≈øuit was unlawful, for Sadler ≈øo to ≈øue in the Name of another, and therefore it cannot be a good con≈øideration. And for that cau≈øe, it was awarded, Quod querens nihil capiat per billam.

div.head:
CCLIV. How and Conneys Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Tre≈øpa≈øs. 1 Cro. 159.IN an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs by How again≈øt Conney, the ca≈øe was, That one Smith was ≈øei≈øed of two hou≈øes, and lea≈øed one of them to his Brother for life, and afterwards by his Will devi≈øed, viz. I give to my Executors, All my Lands and Tenements free and copy, to hold to them, and they to take the profits of them for ten years, and afterwards to ≈øell the ≈øaid Lands and Tenements; and afterwards died, his Brother died before the quarter of a year after: and it was found, That the Executors entred into the hou≈øe undemi≈øed, and took the profits, but not into the other, and that at the end of the ≈øaid ten years, they ≈øold the whole. Godfrey, The hou≈øe only which was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øhall pa≈øs by the Will. (To hold unto them) doth imply matter of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øo as nothing pa≈ø≈øeth but that whereof they may take the profits, the which cannot be of a bare Rever≈øion; al≈øo by this devi≈øe, the Executors have not intere≈øt in the thing devi≈øed but for ten years,Plow. 66. Shop. 437. whereas the Brother of the Te≈øtator had an e≈øtate for life, which by po≈ø≈øibility might continue above twenty years, and to prove that, the meaning of the devi≈øor to be collected upon the words of the Will ought to direct the con≈øtruction of the Will, he cited Chicks ca≈øe, 19 Eliz. 357 and 23 Eliz. 371. Dyer. At another day it was argued by Cook, That both the Hou≈øes pa≈øs, and the words (take the profit) do not re≈øtrain the general words before, (viz. All my Lands and Tenements) but rather expounds them, ≈øci. ≈øuch profits that they might
take of a Rever≈øion, cum acciderit, for it may be that the Brother ≈øhall die within ten years. And he cited the ca≈øe 34 H. 6. 6. A man ≈øei≈øed of diver≈øe Rever≈øion upon e≈øtates for life, devi≈øes them by the name of omnium terrarum & tenementorum, which were in his own hands, and by tho≈øe parols the Rever≈øion did pa≈øs; and yet the Rever≈øion (to ≈øpeak properly) was not in his hands: and if the Brother had died in the life of the devi≈øor, they had clearly pa≈ø≈øed, and then his death or life ≈øhall not alter the ca≈øe. And he re≈øembled the ca≈øe to the ca≈øe in 39 E. 3. 21. The King grants to the Abbot of Redding, That in time of vacation the Prior and Monks ≈øhall have the di≈øpo≈øition of all the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Abbey ad ≈øu≈øtentationem Prioris & Monachorum, 3 Cro. 290. and if in the time of vacation they ≈øhall have the Advow≈øons, was the que≈øtion, for it was ≈øaid, That advow≈øons could not be to their ≈øu≈øtentation: But yet by the better opinion the grant of the King did extend to Advow≈øons, for it ≈øhall be intended ≈øuch ≈øu≈øtentation as Advow≈øons might give. Godfrey, Our Ca≈øe is not like to the ca≈øe of 34. H. 6. for there the Devi≈øor had not any thing in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and therefore if the Rever≈øion did not pa≈øs, the devi≈øe ≈øhould be utterly void. Gawdy conceived that the hou≈øe in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion only pa≈ø≈øed, for the devi≈øe extends to ≈øuch things only, whereof the Profits might be taken, but here is not any profit of a Rever≈øion. Clench, and Wray contrary, The intent of the devi≈øe was to perform the Will of his Father, and al≈øo of his own Will; and in ca≈øe the hou≈øe in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was not ≈øufficient to perform both the Wills, all ≈øhall pa≈øs, and therefore the devi≈øe by favorable con≈øtruction is to be taken largely, ≈øo as the Wills might be throughly performed; and al≈øo the devi≈øe is general, and further all his Lands and Tenements, which are not re≈øtrained by the Sub≈øequent words (to take the profits;) for to have and to hold, and to have and to take the profits is all one.

div.head:
CCLV. Slugge and the Bi≈øhop of Landaffs Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
SLugge libelled again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Landaff in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, becau≈øe where he was pre≈øented by the Dean and Chapter of Glouce≈øter to the Church of Penner, the Bi≈øhop did refu≈øe to admit him, and now the Bi≈øhop ≈øued a Prohibition, and ≈øhewed,Prohibition. Quod non habetur talis Rectoria cum cura animarum in eadem dioce≈øi, ≈øed perpetua vicaria. And by Popham a Prohibition doth not lye, but the matter ought to be determined in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, and when he who is pre≈øented to the ≈øame Church, whether it be a Church or not, ≈øhall be tried in an action of tre≈øpa≈øs; and the like matter was ruled, Mich. 14. Eliz. betwixt We≈øton and Grendon, who was pre≈øented by the Queen, and it was holden, that becau≈øe in≈øtitution and admi≈ø≈øion do belong to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, and not to the Kings Court, that no Prohibition ≈øhould lye, and therefore he prayed a Con≈øultation. And note, That the Defendant in the Prohibition did not demur formally upon the ≈øugge≈øtion; for the Iudges u≈øe, if the ≈øugge≈øtion be not ≈øufficient to maintain the Prohibition, to grant a Con≈øultation without any formal demurrer upon the Sugge≈øtion, if the in≈øufficiency of the Sugge≈øtion be manife≈øt;Trial. which was granted by the whole Court. Cook, That a Con≈øultation ought not to be granted, for whether there be ≈øuch a Rectory or not ≈øhall be tried here. So 2 H. 4. 30. Prior or not Prior, 49 E. 3. 17, 18. Wife, or not Wife, but never accoupled in loyal matrimony by the Bi≈øhop,Ante. 53. 54. 44 E. 3. So within or without the Pari≈øh, 50 E. 3. 20. So, 45 E. 3. Quare Impedit, 138. In a Quare Impedit, no ≈øuch Church within the County. Afterwards, at another day, Popham put the ca≈øe, Slugge was pre≈øented to the vicaridge of Penner, the Bi≈øhop refu≈øed to admit him, and admitted one Morgan Bletthen unto the Par≈øonage
of Penner, at the pre≈øentment of the Lord St. John; Slugge ≈øued the Bi≈øhop for contumacy, per duplicem querelem, The Bi≈øhop ≈øaid, Non habetur talis vicaria, upon which matter he ≈øued a Prohibition, and he conceived, That the Prohibition did not ly, for a Vicar is but he that gerit vicem Per≈øonae, to ≈øupply his place in his ab≈øence, ≈øo as the ≈øame is a ≈øpiritual matter which ought not to be tried here: Al≈øo the libel is, to have Admi≈ø≈øion and In≈øtitution, and the other matter ari≈øeth by their Plea, ≈øci. Quod Rectoria de Penner e≈øt Eccle≈øia cum cura animarum, ab≈øque hoc quod habetur talis Vicaria, and ≈øo it is but an incident to the principal matter, wherefore it ≈øhall be tried there, and he prayed a Con≈øultation. Cook, We have ≈øhewed, That in the time of E. 3. one L. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manour of Penner, to which the Church of Penner is appendant; and we alledge pre≈øentments from the time, and we convey it to the Lord St. John, which now is, and they would now defeat us by this ≈øurmi≈øe, That there is no ≈øuch Church with cure of Souls, which is triable here. Popham the libel doth contain nothing but contumacy in the Bi≈øhop, in that he hath not admitted Slugge, and the other matter comes in the Replication, and afterwards by a≈ø≈øent of the parties a Con≈øultation was granted, quoad in≈øtitutionem of Slugge only, but that they ≈øhould not proceed further.

div.head:
CCLVI. Fennick and Mitfords Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31 Eliz. Rot. 154. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Mo ‚Ä¢ e 284. 2 Co. 91.THe Ca≈øe was, A man ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Fee, levieth a Fine to the u≈øe of his wife for life, the remainder to the u≈øe of his elde≈øt ≈øon, & the heirs males of his body, the Remainder to the u≈øe of the right heirs of the Conu≈øor, The Conu≈øor makes a Lea≈øe for a thou≈øand years to B. the elde≈øt ≈øon dieth without i≈ø≈øue male, having i≈ø≈øue a daughter, the Conu≈øor dieth, the wife afterwards dieth, the elde≈øt ≈øon enters and lea≈øeth the Lands to the Plaintiff. Atkin≈øon, That upon this conveyance a Rever≈øion was left in the Conu≈øor, although by the fine all is conveyed out of the Conu≈øor; and ≈øo (as it hath been objected) the u≈øe limited to the right heirs of the Conu≈øor, is a new thing: For it is to be ob≈øerved, When a man is ≈øei≈øed of Lands, he hath two things, the Land, or the E≈øtate, and ≈øecondly the u≈øe which is the profits; and if he make a Feoffment without con≈øideration, by that the e≈øtate and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pa≈ø≈øeth, but not the u≈øe, wherefore the u≈øe de≈øcends after to the Son and Heir. And in our ca≈øe if the Wife and Son had died without i≈ø≈øue in the life of the Father, all ≈øhould be in the Father and his Heirs. And if a man make a Feoffment in Fee, unto the u≈øe of his la≈øt Will, it ≈øhall be unto the u≈øe of the Feoffor and his Heirs, and in our ca≈øe, this limitation to the Right Heirs of the Conu≈øor is, as if no mention had been made of it, and then it ≈øhould be to the Father, and his Heirs. And afterwards it was adjudged, That it was a Rever≈øion, and no Remainder,Co. In≈øt. 22. b. Po≈øt. 88. and by Gawdy, This Limitation, To his Right Heirs, is meerly void. Wray, As if he had made a Feoffment to the u≈øe of one for life, without further Limitation.

div.head:
CCLVII. Holland and Franklins Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. Rot. 723. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN a Replevin,Replevin. Owen 138, 1 ‚Ä¢ 9. 2 Len. 121. 3 Len. 175. the Defendant made Conu≈øans as Bailiff to Thomas Lord Howard, and ≈øhewed, How that the Priore≈øs of Holliwel was ≈øei≈øed o ‚Ä¢ the Manor of Prior in her deme≈ø ‚Ä¢ e as of Fee, &c. and 4 Nov. 19 H. 8. by Deed enrolled ≈øold unto the Lord Audley, the ≈øaid Manor, who died having i≈ø≈øue a Daughter, who took to Husband Thomas late Duke of Norfolk, who had i≈ø≈øue the ≈øaid Lord Howard, and that after their death the ≈øaid Manor de≈øcended, &c. The Plaintiff in bar of the Conu≈øans ≈øhewed, That the ≈øaid Deed was primo deliberatum, 4 Nov. 30 H. 8. And that mean betwixt the date and the delivery, ≈øcil. 12 October, The ≈øaid Priore≈øs lea≈øed the ≈øaid Manor to one A. for ninety nine years, and conveyed the Term to the Plaintiff, ab≈øque hoc, that the Priore≈øs bargained and ≈øold the ≈øaid Manor to the Lord Audley, ante dimi≈ø≈øionem praedict. dicto A. fact. upon which there was a Demurrer. Cook, Averment. This Averment of another delivery than the Deed doth purport again≈øt the Deed enrolled, ≈øhall not be received, no more than a man may aver, That a Recognizance was acknowledged at another day, &c. for every Record imports a truth in it, and expre≈øs averment ≈øhall not be received again≈øt it, but a man may confe≈øs and avoid; See 7 H. 7. 4. It cannot be a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that in a Redi≈ø≈øei≈øin, the Sheriff non acce≈ø≈øit ad tenementa, as he hath retorned, for that is again≈øt his Retorn which is Recorded, and the date of the Record is the principal part of it, which ≈øee 37 H. 6. 21. by all the Iu≈øtices, That matter of Record hath always relation to the date, and not to the Delivery, contrary of a Deed which is not of Record, for the ≈øame ≈øhall have relation always to the delivery; and ≈øee 39 H. 6. 32. by all the Iu≈øtices,Relation of Records and Deeds. averment again≈øt a Deed enrolled that it was not delivered ≈øhall not be received; ≈øo in the Ca≈øe betwixt Ludford and Gretton, 19 Eliz. Plowd. 149. It is holden by all the Iu≈øtices, That the Kings Charter hath relation to the time of the date, becau≈øe that matters of Record carry in them by pre≈øumtion of Law for the Highne≈øs of them, truth, and therefore one cannot ≈øay, That ≈øuch a Charter was made or delivered at another day, than at that at which it bears date; So of a Recognizance, Statute, &c. but again≈øt Letters Patents a man may ≈øay, Non conce≈ø≈øit, for perhaps nothing pa≈ø≈øeth thereby,Averment. and then it is not contrary to the Record. Atkin≈øon contrary, I confe≈øs that the party him≈øelf (who≈øe Deed it was) cannot take a direct averment again≈øt a Deed enrolled, but he may confe≈øs and avoid it, ≈øo as he leave it a Record, as if a Fine were levyed by another in my name of my Land, I am bound by it; but if the Fine were levyed by another in my name I am not bound, for I may confe≈øs and avoid it, and yet leave the Record good; but here the Plaintiff is a ≈øtranger to his Deed enrolled: And ≈øome Records ≈øhall bind all per≈øons, as Certificates of Ba≈øtardy, &c. for all may give evidence in ≈øuch ca≈øe, 2 H. 5. E≈øtoppel 91. A. makes a Feoffment in Fee,Co. 3 In≈øt. 230, 231. and afterwards before the Coroner confe≈ø≈øeth a Felony ≈øuppo≈øed to done before the Feoffment, the Feoffee ≈øhall have an averment again≈øt it. Egerton the Queens Solicitor, contrary, Matter of Record cannot be gain≈øaid in the point, or in matter of implication, and therefore again≈øt that he cannot ≈øay, Non e≈øt factum, 16 E. 3. Abb. 13. A Deed enrolled in pais, cannot be denyed, 24 E. 3. 64. A Deed enrolled is not a Record, but a thing recorded, which cannot be denyed. And here this plea is a violent averment again≈øt the Deed, for it amounts to as much as if he had ≈øaid, Not his Deed at the time of the enrollment: but I confe≈øs that ≈øuch a Deed may be avoided by a thing which ≈øtands with the Deed by matter out of the Deed. It hath been objected, That this acknowledging of the Deed ought to be made by Actorn ‚Ä¢ y,
and therefore made in per≈øon it is not any acknowledgment, and ≈øo again≈øt ≈øuch acknowledgment, Non e≈øt factum may be pleaded, and a Fine or confe≈ø≈øion in a Writ of annuity upon pre≈øcription, or in a≈ø≈øi≈øe ≈øhall bind the hou≈øe, See 16 E. 3. Abb. 13. That a fine, Recognizance, and Covenant of Record ≈øhall bind the Hou≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øe. And the acknowledgment of the Priore≈øs alone will ≈øerve in this Ca≈øe, for the Nuns are as dead per≈øons: And po≈øito, that a Ma≈øter of the Chancery comes into the Chapter-hou≈øe, and receives ≈øuch an acknowledgment, I conceive that it is good enough. It hath been objected, That here the Plaintiff is not e≈øtopped to take the averment, becau≈øe we have not pleaded our matter by way of E≈øtoppel; certainly the ≈øame needs not here, for the Record it ≈øelf carries the E≈øtoppel with it, and the truth appeareth by the Record, and the Court ought to take hold of it. Godfrey contrary, A Deed enrolled may be avoided by matter, which is not contrary to the Record, as 19 R. 2. E≈øtoppel 281. in ≈øur cui in vita, a Relea≈øe of the Mother of the Demandant with warranty was pleaded in Bar, and that enrolled, To which the Demandant ≈øaid, That at the time of the Relea≈øe ≈øuppo≈øed to be made, our mother had a husband one F. and ≈øo the Deed was void, and ≈øo avoided the Deed by matter dehors, ≈øcil. Coverture; ≈øo of enfancy, but not by a general averment: A man no lettered ≈øhall avoid a Deed enrolled by ≈øuch ≈øpecial matter; ≈øo an obligation made again≈øt the Statute of 23 H. 6. and the≈øe ≈øpecial matters ≈øhall utterly avoid the Deeds again≈øt whom they are pleaded; but in our ca≈øe we do confe≈øs the Deed to be good to ≈øome intent,1 Len. 84. ≈øcil. after our Lea≈øe expired, for which our ca≈øe is the better ca≈øe. And at another day it was objected, That the Deed could not be acknowledged without a Letter of Attorney, being a Corporation, which con≈øi≈øted upon divers per≈øons, as Priore≈øs and Covent, and they are alwaies to be intended to be in their Chapter-hou≈øe, and cannot come into Court to acknowledge a Deed: To which it was an≈øwered by Cook, That this acknowledgment being generally pleaded, it ≈øhall be intended, that it was done by a Lawful means, and there is no doubt, but that ≈øuch a Corporation may levy a Fine, and make a Letter of Attorney to acknowledge it, and ≈øee, 2 Ma. Fulmer≈øtones ca≈øe 105. It was further objcted,2 In≈øt. 674. That this Deed was enrolled the ≈øame day that it beareth date, for the pleading is per factum ≈øuum gerens Datum, 2 Novemb. 29 Hen. 8. et ii≈ødem die & anno irrotulat. And by the Statute ≈øuch a Deed ought to be enrolled within ≈øix Months next after the date, ≈øo as the day of the date is excluded, and ≈øo it is not enrolled within ≈øix Months: As to that it was an≈øwered by Cook, That the time of computation doth begin pre≈øently after the delivery of the Deed, as in the common Ca≈øes of Lea≈øes, If a man makes a Lea≈øe for years to begin from the day of the date, the ≈øame is exclu≈øive; but if it be To have and to hold from the date of the Deed, it ≈øhall begin pre≈øently. And an Ejectment ≈øuppo≈øed the ≈øame day is good, and then here, this Enrolment is within the ≈øix Months;Dyer 220. b. 1 Cro. 717. and yet ≈øee 5 Eliz. 128. Dyer, Pophams ca≈øe. It was al≈øo objected, That it is alledged in the conu≈øans, That the Manor was ≈øold to the Lord Audley, and that the Deed of Bargain and Sale was acknowledged and enrolled in the Chancery, the ≈øaid Lord being then Lord Chancelor, and he cannot take an acknowledgment of a Deed, or enrolment of it to him≈øelf, for he is the Sole Iudge in the ≈øaid Court, ≈øo as the Deed is acknowledged before him≈øelf, and enrolled before him≈øelf, and that is good enough, for here we are not upon the common Law, but upon the Statute, and here the words of the Statute are performed. And the enrolment of the Deed is not the ≈øub≈øtance of the Deed, but the Deed it ≈øelf. Al≈øo the acknowledgment of the Deed, after it is enrolled is not material, for he is e≈øtopped to ≈øay that it is not acknowledged. And as to the matter it ≈øelf, a man ≈øhall not have averment again≈øt
the purport of a Record, but again≈øt the operation of a Record, as not put in view, not compri≈øed, partes ad finem nihil haberunt, &c. And again≈øt Letters Pattens of the King, Non conce≈ø≈øit, is a good plea, which ≈øee 18 Eliz. for by ≈øuch plea it is agreed, that it is a Record, but that nihil operatur.

div.head:
CCLVIII. Osborn and Kirtons Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench. Rot. 258.
div.p: IN Debt upon an Obligation, The Defendant ca≈øt a Protection,Debt. upon which the Plaintiff did demur. Tanfield, The Protection is not good, for the Defendant is let to Bail, and ≈øo is intended always in pri≈øon, for ≈øo the Record makes mention, and then the Protection quia moratur in portubus Zeland is again≈øt the Record,Protection. and the Court ought to give credit to Records e≈øpecially. Secondly, The words of the Protection are, That Kirton is imployed in Ob≈øequio no≈øtro, which is no cau≈øe of protection, for the u≈øual form (and ≈øo is the Law) that ≈øuch a per≈øon be imployed in negotio Regni, for the defence of England, &c. For if the King will give aid unto another Princes Subjects employed in ≈øuch ≈øervice, he ≈øhall not have Protection. And afterwards variance was objected betwixt the Bill and Declaration, and the Protection: for the Bill is again≈øt John Kirton of A. Gentleman, & the Protection is John Kirton only: But the ≈øame was holden no ≈øuch variance being only in the Addition, for before the Statute 1 H 5. additions were not nece≈ø≈øary in any actions.

div.head:
CCLIX. Boyton and Andrews Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 Eliz. Rot. 156. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Debt upon an Obligation, the Condition was,Debt. 1 Cro. 135. to make ≈øufficient a≈ø≈øurance of certain Lands to the Obligee before the tenth day of March 17 Eliz. And if it fortune the ≈øaid Obligee be unwilling to receive, or mi≈ølike ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance, but ≈øhall make Reque≈øt to have one hundred pounds for ≈øatisfaction thereof, Then if upon ≈øuch Reque≈øt, the Obligor pay one hundred pounds within five months, That then the Obligation ≈øhall be void. And at the day, the Obligee doth refu≈øe the a≈ø≈øurance, and afterwards 27 Eliz. reque≈øt is made to have the hundred pounds, It was the clear opinion of the whole Court, That the ≈øaid Reque≈øt was well enough for the time, and he might make it at any time during his life, & he is not re≈øtrained to make it before the day in which the A≈ø≈øurance is to be made, and afterwards judgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCLX. Knight and Savages Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29, & 30 Eliz. Rot. 546. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A Writ of Error was brought upon a Iudgment given in Leice≈øter in Debt: Tanfield a≈ø≈øigned Error,Error. 2 Cro. 206. 2 Cro. 109. 654. Sty. 91. Yel. 164. 165. Po≈øt. 302. becau≈øe in that Suit there was not any plaint, and in all inferior Courts, the plaint is as the original at the common Law, and without that no proce≈øs can i≈ø≈øue forth. And here upon the Record nothing is entred but that the Defendant ≈øummonitus fuit, &c. and therefore the fir≈øt entry ought to be A. B. queritur adver≈øus, C, &c.

Clench, A Plaint ought to be entred before proce≈øs i≈ø≈øueth, & the ≈øummons which is entred here, is not any plaint, and for that cau≈øe the Iudgment was rever≈øed: It was ≈øaid, That after the Defendant appeared, a Plaint was entred, but it was ≈øaid by the Court, That that ≈øhall not mend the matter, for there ought to be a plaint out of which the proce≈øs ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue, as in the Courts above out of the original Writs.

div.head:
CCLXI. Kirby and Eccles Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 137.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared, Quod cum quaedam communicatio fui≈ø≈øet betwixt the Plaintiff, and one Cowper, That Cowper ≈øhould ma≈øt certain Hogs for the Plaintiff, the Defendant did promi≈øe, That in con≈øideration, that the Plaintiff promi≈øed give unto the Defendant three ≈øhillings and four pence, for the fatting of every Hog, That the ≈øaid Hogs ≈øhould be redelivered to him well fatted; to which promi≈øe and warranty, the Plaintiff giving faith, delivered to the ≈øaid Cowper one hundred and fifty Hogs to be ma≈øted; and that one hundred of them were delivered back, but the re≈øidue were not: It was moved, That here is not any con≈øideration for which the Defendant ≈øhould be charged with any promi≈øe: but it was argued, on the other ≈øide, That the Promi≈øe was the cau≈øe of the Contract, and being made at the time of the Communication and contract, ≈øhould charge the Defendant; but if the promi≈øe were at another time, it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe. There was a Ca≈øe lately betwixt Smith and Edmunds, Two Merchants, being reciprocally endebted the one to the other, agreed betwixt them≈øelves to deliver all their Bills and Bonds into the hands of one Smith, who promi≈øed that he would not deliver them to the parties until all accounts were ended betwixt them; and yet he did deliver them, and for that an Action brought again≈øt him was adjudged maintainable: yet there was not any con≈øideration, nor was it material, for the action is grounded upon the Deceit, and ≈øo is it here, upon the Warranty: And of that opinion were Clench and Wray, Iu≈øtices; but Gawdy was of a contrary opinion.

div.head:
CCLXII. Wood≈øhaw and Fulmer≈øtones Ca≈øe.
Hill. 30. Eliz. Rot. 699 In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
WOod≈øhaw, Executor of Heywood, brought Debt upon a Bond again≈øt Richard Fulmer≈øtone, and the Writ was dated October Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz. and the Condition of the Bond was, That if Fulmer≈øtone died before his Age of one and twenty years, and before that he had made a Ioynture to A. his Wife, Daughter of the Te≈øtator Heywood, Then if the ≈øaid Defendant cau≈øed one hundred pounds to be payed to the ≈øaid Heywood, within three months after the death of the ≈øaid William, that then the Bond ≈øhould be void; and the ≈øaid William Fulmer≈øtone died 30 September 30 Eliz. which matter he is ready, &c. The Plaintiff doth traver≈øe, ab≈øque hoc, that the ≈øaid Heywood died inte≈øtate. Tanfield, It appeareth of Record that the Plaintiff hath not cau≈øe of action, for this one hundred pounds, was to be paid within three Months after the death of William Fulmer≈øtone, 1 Cro. 271, 325, 565. as the Defendant hath alledged, which is al≈øo confe≈ø≈øed by the Plaintiff, and this Action is entred Mich. October 30 Eliz. ≈øcil. within a month after the death of William Fulmer≈øtone, and ≈øo before the Plaintiff hath cau≈øe of action, and therefore he ≈øhall be barred. Gawdy, Where it appeareth to the Court, that the
Plaintiff hath not cau≈øe of Action, he ≈øhall never have Iudgment, as in the Ca≈øe betwixt Tilly and Wordy, 7 E. 4. But here it doth appear that the Plaintiff hath cau≈øe of Action, for where a man is bound in an obligation, the ≈øame is a duty pre≈øently,Obligation. and the condition is but in defeazance of it, which the Defendant may plead in his di≈øcharge.

div.head:
CCLXIII. Windham and Sir Edward Cleers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
ROger Windham brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Sir Ed. C. declared that the ≈øaid Ed. being a Iu≈øtice of Peace in the County of N. and where the Plaintiff was a loyal ≈øubject,Action upon the Ca≈øe of ≈øclander. 1 Cro. 130. and of good fame all his life time, nor ever touched, or reproched with any offence of Ro ‚Ä¢
ery, &c. the Defendant, malitio≈øe & invide machinams ip≈øum Rogerum, de bonis, nomine, fama et vita deprivare, directed his warrant to divers Baylifs and Con≈øtables of the ≈øaid County to arre≈øt the ≈øaid Plaintiff: And it was alledged in the ≈øaid Warrant, That the Plaintiff was accu≈øed before him of the ≈øtealing of the hor≈øe of A. B. by rea≈øon of which the Plaintiff was arre≈øted, and ≈øo detained until he had entred into a Bond for his appearance, &c. whereas in truth, he was never accu≈øed thereof, nor ever ≈øtole ≈øuch hor≈øe; and whereas the Defendant him≈øelf knew that the Plaintiff was guiltle≈øs; by rea≈øon of which, he was greatly di≈øcredited, &c. And it was found for the Plaintiff; And it was moved, that upon this matter an Action doth not lye, for a Iu≈øtice of Peace if he ≈øu≈øpect any per≈øon of Felony, or other ≈øuch Offence may direct his Warrant to arre≈øt him. 14. H. 8. 16 Gaudy and Clench, If a man be accu≈øed to a Iu≈øtice of Peace for Felony, for which he directs his Warrant to arre≈øt him, although the accu≈øation be fal≈øe the Iu≈øtice of Peace is excu≈øed, but if the party in truth was not accu≈øed before the Iu≈øtice, it is otherwi≈øe: It was a Ca≈øe lately betwixt the Lord Lumley and Foord, where Foord in a letter written by him, had written, It is reported, That my Lord Lumley ≈øeeketh my life: If it was not Reported, an Action upon the Ca≈øe lieth, but if reported, no Action lieth: So here, if he was accu≈øed no Action lieth, but if not, an Action lieth: And afterwards in the principal Ca≈øe, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCLXIV. I≈øleys Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
ISley and others were Plaintiffs in an Ejectione firmae, and upon the general I≈ø≈øue it was found for the Plaintiffs, and 4 days after the verdict given, was moved in ≈øtay of judgment a ≈øpecial ma ‚Ä¢ ter in Law, whereof the Iu≈øtices were not re≈øolved for the law, but took advi≈øement and gave day over; and in the mean time one of the Plaintiffs died, which matter the Defendant ≈øhewed to the Court in further ≈øtay of the Iudgment: But by Coke, the ≈øame is not any cau≈øe, for the Po≈øtea came in Quindena Pa≈øch. which was 16 Aprilis, at which day the Court ought to have given Iudgment pre≈øently, but took time to be advi≈øed, and the 19 of April, one of the Plaintiffs died; And the favour of the Court ought not to prejudice us; for the Iudgment here ≈øhall have Relation to the 16 of April, at which time he was alive; and it was ≈øo of late adjudged in the Ca≈øe of Derick James, who died the day after the verdict, and yet Iudgment was not ≈øtayed, for the Court after verdict cannot examine ≈øurmi≈øes, and they have not a day in Court to plead, and in our ca≈øe, It was but a day of Grace, and no entry is
made of it; Although no plea can be now pleaded after verdict, yet as amicus curiae, one may inform us of ≈øuch matter: And ≈øometimes in ≈øuch ca≈øe, Iudgment hath been ≈øtayed, as 9 Eliz. and ≈øometimes notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch Exception, as 2 Eliz. So as I conceive the matter is much in the di≈øcretion of the Iu≈øtices. And becau≈øe the ≈øame was a hard verdict, and much again≈øt the Evidence, It is good di≈øcretion upon this matter to ≈øtay Iudgment, and ≈øuch was the opinion of the Court.

div.head:
CCLXV. Steed and Courtneys Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Error. 1 Cro. 116. Owen 93. More. 691. Pre≈øcription to levy a fine, not good.ERror was brought upon a Fine levied upon a Plaint in a writ of Covenant in the City of Exceter. And two Errors were a≈ø≈øigned: Fir≈øt, The Plaint was, quod teneat convent. de duobus tenementis. Whereas in truth, the word Tenement doth not comprehend any certainty, for in the Word (Tenement) is under≈øtood, Me≈ø≈øuage, Land, Meadow, Pa≈øture, &c. and what≈øoever ≈øyeth in tenure: And 11 H. 6. 18. by grant of Lands and Tenements, Rent or Common ≈øhall pa≈øs. And an Ejectione firmae both not lye of a Tenement, nor a forcible entry ≈øuppo≈øed in a Tenement, 11 H. 7. 25. & 38 H. 6. 1. Another error was, becau≈øe the Fine was levyed in the Court of the City of Exceter: Which ≈øee 44 E. 3. 37, 38. Tho≈øe of Exceter can pre≈øcribe to have the Conu≈øans; but the ≈øame ought to be by ≈øpecial Charter of the King by expre≈øs words. Egerton the Queens Solicitor, who ≈øate under the Iu≈øtices, and was not of Coun≈øel in the ca≈øe ≈øaid,2 In≈øt. 515. 1 Roll. 489. That he was of Coun≈øel in a ca≈øe betwixt Bunbery and Bird, where ≈øuch a Fine levyed in Che≈øter by pre≈øcription was in que≈øtion, was by a Writ of Error rever≈øed: And afterwards in the principal ca≈øe the Fine was rever≈øed for the fir≈øt Error.

div.head: CCLXVI. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: 1 Cro. 96. 97.THe Ca≈øe was this, Grandfather, Father and Son: The Grandfather ≈øei≈øed of a hou≈øe called the Swan in Ip≈øwich, devi≈øed the ≈øame to his elde≈øt Son for life, the Remainder to A. Son of his elde≈øt Son, and the heirs males of his body,Devi≈øes. the Remainder to the right heirs of the Devi≈øor, and to the heirs males of his body, and died. The Father and Son died without i≈ø≈øue male, the Son having i≈ø≈øue a Daughter, who entred and a≈ø≈øured the Land unto one Hawes, and covenanted, That ≈øhe was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage of a certain and ≈øure e≈øtate in Fee-≈øimple. Godfrey, That the Daughter ≈øhall take the la≈øt Remainder, as right heir at the time that it ought to be executed, & to the heirs males of her body, as if it had been devi≈øed to her by her proper Name, ≈øo ≈øhe hath but an e≈øtate tail, and ≈øo the covenant is broken. Cook contrary: At the time that the devi≈øe took effect by the death of the Devi≈øor, the Father was his Right heir, ≈øo as the Remainder ve≈øted in him immediately,Antea 182. and ≈øhall not expect in abeyance until the Father and Son dye without heir male of the Son, for the Father is a per≈øon able to take, ≈øo that upon the death of the Devi≈øor, the Father is Tenant for life, the Remainder to the Son, and the heirs males of his body, the Remainder to the Father in tail ut ≈øupra, the Rever≈øion to the Father in fee, and the Daughter hath the ≈øame Rever≈øion by di≈øcent after the Entayls ≈øpent; all which Wray Iu≈øtice granted.

div.head:
CCLXVII Galliard and Archers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas, Intrat. Trin. 31 Eliz. Rot. 1529.
div.p: GAlliard brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Archer; Trover and Conver≈øion. The Plaintiff declared, That he him≈øelf was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of certain goods, which by trover came to the hands of the Defendant, who hath converted them to his own u≈øe: The Defendant pleaded,Po≈øtea. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . That before the Trover ≈øuppo≈øed, one A. was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid goods as of his proper goods, and ≈øold them to the Defendant, and that he had not any notice that the ≈øaid goods were the goods of the Plaintiff, upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. And by Ander≈øon the plea is not good, for the Plaintiff may chu≈øe to have his Action again≈øt the fir≈øt finder, or again≈øt any other, which gets the goods after by Sale, Gift, or Trover; And by ≈øome,Po≈øtea. 253. The Defendant having the goods by Sale, might traver≈øe the finding: See Contr. 27 H. 6. 13. a. And ≈øee by ≈øome, In detinue, where the Plaintiff declares of a Bailment, The Defendant may ≈øay, That he found them, and traver≈øe the Bailment, 39 H. 6. 37. by Moile; and by Windham Iu≈øtice, The Defendant may traver≈øe the property of the goods in the Plaintiff, 12 E. 4. 11.

div.head:
CCLXVIII. Edwards and Tedbuties Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: EDwards of London was endebted unto one A. of the ≈øame City,Bailment of goods to a Carrier. and Edwards delivered goods to one Tedbury Carrier of Exceter, who went to him to carry for him certain Wares to be carried to Exceter, to certain Trade≈ømen there, the ≈øaid goods to be delivered to them, &c. And ≈øo the ≈øaid goods, Wares, and Merchandizes, being in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Defendant Tedbury to be carried to Exceter, the ≈øaid A. cau≈øed them to be attached in the hands of the ≈øaid Carrier, for the Debt of the ≈øaid Edwards, The ≈øaid Carrier being then priviledged in the Common Pleas, by rea≈øon of an Action there depending. And by the clear opinion of the whole Court, the ≈øaid Attachment ought to be di≈ø≈øolved:Attachment of goods. For the Carrier for the rea≈øon afore≈øaid is priviledged in his par≈øon, and his goods, and not only in his own goods, whereof the property belongs to him, but al≈øo in ≈øuch goods in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion for which he is an≈øwerable to others, &c. And ≈øo it was adjudged.

div.head:
CCLXIX. Cock≈øhal, and the Mayor, &c. of Boaltons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: HEnry Cock≈øhal brought an Action upon the ca≈øe again≈øt the Mayor,Con ‚Ä¢ pi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Town-Clark, and Goal or of Boalton, in the County of L. and declared, That where he him≈øelf had affirmed a Plaint of Debt in the Court of the ≈øaid Town, before the ≈øaid Mayor, &c. again≈øt I.S. and thereupon had cau≈øed the ≈øaid I.S. to be arre≈øted, The ≈øaid Defendants did con≈øpire together to delay the Plaintiff of his ≈øaid ≈øuit, in peril of his Debt, had let the ≈øaid I. S. go at large without taking Bail. Periam Iu≈øtice conceived, That upon that matter, the Action doth not lye, for the not taking of Bail is a judicial act, for which he ≈øhall not be impeached: But all the other Iu≈øtices were ≈øtrongly of opinion again≈øt him, for the not taking of Bail is not the cau≈øe of the Action, but the Con≈øpiracy.

div.head:
CCLXX. Erbery and Lattons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: 1 And. 234.IN a Replevin, The Defendant doth avow becau≈øe he is ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch a Manor within which there is a Cu≈øtom, That the greater part of the Tenants at any Court within the ≈øaid Manor holden appearing may make By-laws, for the mo≈øt profit and be≈øt government of the Tenants of the ≈øaid Manor, &c. and that ≈øuch By-laws ≈øhould bind all Tenants, &c. and ≈øhewed further, That at ≈øuch a Court holden within the ≈øaid Manor the Homage there, being the greater part of Tenants of the Mannor afore≈øaid, at the Court afore≈øaid appearing, made this By-law, ≈øcilicet, That no Tenant of the ≈øaid Manor ≈øhould put into ≈øuch a Common any Steer being a year old or more, upon pain of ≈øix pence for every ≈øuch Offence, and that it ≈øhould be lawful to di≈øtreyn for the ≈øame: And the Court was Clear of opinion, That the By-law was utterly void, For it is again≈øt Common Right, where a man hath Common for all his Cattel Commonable, to re≈øtrain him to one kind of Cattel, &c. But if the By-law had bin, That none ≈øhould put in his Cattel before ≈øuch a day, the ≈øame had bin good, for ≈øuch By-law doth not take away, but order the Inheritance; For the nature of a By-law is to put Order betwixt the Tenants concerning their affayrs within the Manor which by law they are not compellable to do: And by Periam, The Avowant ought to have averred, That this By-law was for the Common profit of the Tenants: See the Lord Cromwells Ca≈øe. 15 Eliz. Dyer 322. and afterwards in the Principal Ca≈øe, Iudgment was given again≈øt the Avowant.

div.head:
CCLXXI. Wicks and Dennis Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Replevin. WIcks brought a Replevin of Dennis, who avowed, That one Dennis his Father was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor, &c. and granted out of it to the avowant a Rent of twenty pounds per annum, and further granted, That if the ≈øaid Rent be arrear unpaid ≈øix days after the fea≈øts, &c. wherein it ought to be paid, ≈øi licite petatur, That then it ≈øhould be lawful to di≈øtrein; The grantor afterward by Indenture Covenanted with the Lord Trea≈øurer and others, to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øame Manor, unto the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his heirs, until he or his heirs have made default in they payment of one hundred pounds per annum, until three thou≈øand pounds be paid, and after default of payment, to the u≈øe of the Queen and her heirs, until the ≈øum of three thou≈øand pounds ≈øhould be paid and levied; The grantor afterwards levied a fine to the ≈øaid Lord Trea≈øurer and others to the u≈øes afore≈øaid, the Rent is arrear; default of the payment of the hundred pounds in made, Office is found, The Queen ≈øei≈øed the land, the Avowant during the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Q. demanded the Rent, & the arrearages thereof, The Queen granted over the Manor to W. & B. & D. the grantee did di≈øtrain for the rent, & arrearages demanded, ut ≈øupra. It was moved by H. Serjeant That this demand of ≈øeveral ≈øums payable at ≈øeveral days before, is not good; for every ≈øum ought to be ≈øeverally demanded when it was fir≈øt due, ≈øcil. ≈øi licite petatur, ≈øcil. within the ≈øix days; for otherwi≈øe without ≈øuch demand, di≈øtre≈øs is not lawful, and he re≈øembled it to the ca≈øe of Sir Thomas Gre≈øham 23. Elizabeth Dyer, 372 of ≈øeveral Tenders. Periam
conceived that the demand ought to be ≈øeveral. Ander≈øon, That the demand is good enough. And as to the demand made during the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen, It was holden by the whole Court to be good enough; for although the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen be priviledged, as to the di≈øtre≈øs, yet the demand is good,Demand of Rent charge during the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King; good. without any wrong to her prerogative; for the Rent in right is due, and the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen is in right charged with it, and the Rent, is only recoverable by Petition, as it was by way of di≈øtre≈øs; and if the partie ≈øueth to the Queen by Petition for the ≈øaid Rent, he ought to ≈øhew in his Petition, that he hath demanded the Rent, for if the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion had bin in a common per≈øon, he could not di≈øtreyn before demand, nor by con≈øequence have A≈ø≈øi≈øe: And the Rent, notwith≈øtanding the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen, is demandable and payable for to entitle the party unto Petition again≈øt the Queen, and to di≈øtre≈øs again≈øt the ≈øubject when the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen is removed. And ≈øee 7 H. 6. 40. di≈ø≈øei≈øee may make continual claym, although the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land of which he is di≈ø≈øei≈øed be in the King. And 34 H. Br. ≈øei≈øin 48. If the heir at full Age intrude upon the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King, and pays Rent to the Lord of his Land holden of a ≈øubject, the ≈øame is a good ≈øei≈øin, and ≈øhall bind the heir after he hath ≈øued his livery 5 E. 4. 4. and ≈øee 13 H. 7. 15. That di≈øtre≈øs taken upon the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King is not lawful, but ≈øei≈øin obtained during it, is good. So in 21 H. 7. 2.

div.head:
CCLXXII. A≈øhegells and Dennis Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31, & 32 Eliz. In the Com. Pleas. Int. M. 30 & 31. Rot. 458.
div.p: AShegel brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt Dennis, Quare Impedit. 1 Cro. 163. Hob. 304. and the Plaintiff Counted that the Defendant had di≈øturbed him to pre≈øent ad vicariam de D. and ≈øhewed that the Queen was ≈øei≈øed of the Rectory of D. and of the Advow≈øon of the vicaridge of D. and by her letters Patents gave unto the Plaintiff Rectoriam praedictam cum pertinentiis, & etiam vicariam Eccle≈øiae praedict. And it was holden by the whole Court, That the Advow≈øon of the vicaridge by the≈øe words doth not pa≈øs; nor ≈øo in the Ca≈øe of a common per≈øon, much le≈øs in the Ca≈øe of the King: But if the Queen had granted Eccle≈øiam ≈øuam of D. then, by Walme≈øley Iu≈øtice, the Advow≈øon of the vicaridge had pa≈ø≈øed.

div.head:
CCLXXIII. Collman and Sir Hugh Portmans Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31, & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Ejectione firmae by Collman again≈øt Sir Hugh Portman it was found by ≈øpecial verdict,Ejectione firmae That the lands where were holden by Copy of the Manor of D. whereof Sir H. Portman, was ≈øei≈øed, and that the Plaintiff was Copyholder in Fee, and further found, That the ≈øaid Sir H. pretending the ≈øaid Copy-hold lands to be forfeited,Surrender of Copy-holder. entred into Communication with Collman touching the ≈øame, upon which Communication it was agreed betwixt them, That the ≈øaid Collman ≈øhould pay to the ≈øaid Sir Hugh five pounds, which was paid accordingly, & that in con≈øideration thereof, Collman ≈øhould enjoy the ≈øaid Cu≈øtomary lands, except one Wood called Combwood for his life, and al≈øo of Alice his wife, durante ≈øua viduitate, and that Collman ≈øhould have Election whether the ≈øaid lands ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øured unto him and his ≈øaid wife by Copy, or by Bill, &c. & he cho≈øe by Bill, which was made accordingly; and further found, That the ≈øaid Sir H. held and enjoyed in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the ≈øaid Wood, &c. & upon this matter, The Court was clear in opinion, That here is a good ≈øurrender of the ≈øaid lands, and that for life only, and that the ≈øaid Sir Hugh had the Wood di≈øcharged of the cu≈øtomary intere≈øt.

div.head:
CCLXXIV. Thetford and Thetfords Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31, & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt.IN an Action of Debt for Rent, the Plaintiff declared, That Land was given to him, and to T. his wife, and to the heirs of their bodies, and that his wife lea≈øed the Lands to the Defendant, and that the Donees were dead, and that the Plaintiff as heir, &c. for rent arrear, &c. and upon Non demi≈øerunt, the Iury found that the Husband and Wife demi≈øerunt, by Indenture, and afterwards the husband died, and the wife entred, and within the term died: Now upon the matter it ≈øeemed clear to Ander≈øon, that the Iury have found for the Defendant, ≈øcil. Non demi≈øerunt, for it is now no lea≈øe ab initio, becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath not declared upon a Deed.Hutt. 102. Dy. 91. 2 Co. 61. 1 Ma. Dyer 91. and al≈øo the wife by her di≈øagreement to it, and the occupation of the Land after the death of her Husband, hath made it the Lea≈øe of the Husband only.

div.head:
CCLXXV. Rockwood and Rockwoods Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31, & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 163.IN an Action upon the ca≈øe, the ca≈øe was this. The Father of the Plaintiff and Defendant being ≈øick, and in danger of death, and incending to make his Will, In the pre≈øence of both his Sons the Plaintiff and Defendant, declared his meaning to be, To devi≈øe to the Plaintiff his younger Son a Rent of 4 l. per annum, for the term of his life out of his Lands, and the Defendant being the elde≈øt Son (the intention of his Father being to charge the Land with the ≈øaid Rent) offered to his Father and Brother, That if the Father would forbear to charge the Land with the ≈øaid Rent, he promi≈øed he would pay the 4l. yearly to his Brother during the life of his Brother, according to the intention of his ≈øaid Father; Whereupon the Father asked the Plaintiff if he would accept of the offer and promi≈øed of his Brother: who an≈øwered, he would; whereupon the Father relying upon the promi≈øe of his ≈øaid elde≈øt Son, forbore to devi≈øe the ≈øaid Rent, &c. ≈øo as the Land de≈øcended to the Elde≈øt Son di≈øcharged of the Rent: and the opinion of the whole Court in this ca≈øe was clear, that upon the whole matter the action did well lye.

div.head:
CCLXXVI. Petty and Trivilians Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31, & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Livery of ≈øei≈øin. HUmphrey Petty brought Second Deliverance again≈øt William Trivilian, and upon e≈øpecial verdict the ca≈øe was, That A. was ≈øei≈øed of certain Land, and Lea≈øed the ≈øame for years, and afterwards made a Deed of Feoffment unto B. and a Letter of Attorney to the Le≈ø≈øee, C. and D. conjunctim vel divi≈øim in omnia & ≈øingula terras et Tenementa intrate et ≈øei≈øinam inde, &c. ≈øecundum formam Chartae, &c. Le≈ø≈øee for years by him≈øelf makes Livery and ≈øei≈øin in one part of the Land, and C. in another part, and D. by him≈øelf in another part; It was fir≈øt agreed by the Iu≈øtices, that by that Livery by Le≈ø≈øee for years his Intere≈øt and Term is not determined, for what≈øoever he doth, he doth it as an Officer, or Servant to the Le≈ø≈øor. Secondly, It was agreed, That the≈øe ≈øeveral Liveries were good and warranted by the Letter
of Attorney, e≈øpecially by rea≈øon of the≈øe words, In omnia & ≈øingula, &c. So as all of them, and every of them might enter and make Livery in any and every part. And ≈øo it was adjudged.

div.head:
CCLXXVII. Rigden and Palmers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: RIgden brought a Replevin again≈øt Palmer, who avowed for damage fea≈øant in his Freehold: The Plaintiff ≈øaid,Replevin. That long time before that Palmer had any thing, he him≈øelf was ≈øei≈øed, until by A. B. and C di≈ø≈øei≈ø≈øed, again≈øt whom he brought an A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and recovered,Avowry. and the e≈øtate of the Plaintiff was mean between the A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and the recovery in it: The Defendant ≈øaid, That long time before the Plaintiff had any thing, One Griffith was ≈øei≈øed, and did enfeoff him; ab≈øque hoc, that the ≈øaid A. B. and C. vel eorum aliquis aliquid habuere in the Lands, at the time of the Recovery. Walm≈øley Iu≈øtice was of opinion, That the Bar unto the Avowry, was not good, for that the Plaintiff hath not alledged, That A.B. and C. Ter-Tenants tempore recuperationis, and that ought to be ≈øhewed in every recovery, where it is pleaded. And then when the Defendant traver≈øeth that which is not alledged it is not good. Windham contrary: For the A≈ø≈øi≈øe might be brought again≈øt others as well as the Tenants; as again≈øt di≈ø≈øei≈øors: But other real actions ought to be brought again≈øt the Ter-Tenants only, and therefore it needs not to ≈øhew, that they were Ter-Tenants at the time of the Recovery; and al≈øo the traver≈øe here is well enough: Another Exception was taken, becau≈øe the Avowry is, That the place in which, conteineth an 100 Acres of Land, The Plaintiff in bar of the Avowry ≈øaith, that the place in which, &c. conteins 35 Acres, &c. but that Exception was not allowed, for it is but matter of form, & is helped by the Statute of 27 Eliz. Another Exception was taken, as to the hundred of Cattel, and doth not ≈øhew in certain, if they were Ewes,Sty. 71. 264. or Lambs, or how many of each: which al≈øo was di≈ø≈øallowed, for the Sheriff upon Returno habendo may enquire what cattel they were in certain, and ≈øo by ≈øuch means the Avowry ≈øhall be reduced to certainty.

div.head:
CCLXXVIII. RU≈ø≈øell and Prats Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Exchequer Chamber.
div.p:
RU≈øell brought an action upon the ca≈øe again≈øt Prat, and declared, That certain goods of the Te≈øtator ca≈øually came to the Defendants hands; and upon matter in Law Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, ≈øed quia ne≈øcitur quae damna, Error. &c. Ideo a writ of Enquiry of Damages i≈ø≈øued, and now Prat brought a Writ of Error in the Exchequer Chamber upon the Statute of 27 Eliz. cap. 8. But note, That the Iudgment was given before the ≈øaid Statute, but the Writ of Enquiry of Damages was retorned after the ≈øaid Statute,Writ of Enquiry of Damages. & the ≈øaid Statute doth not extend but to Iudgments given after the making of it. And it was moved, That the ≈øaid Iudgment is not to be examined here; but by the clear opinion of Ander≈øon, Manwood, Windham, Walme≈øley, Gent, and Clark, Iu≈øtices of the Common Pleas, and Barons of the Exchequer, the Writ of Error lyeth here by the Statute,1 Cro. 235. for in an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs (as this ca≈øe is) full judgment is not given, until the Writ of damages be retorned; And if before the Retorn of it any of the parties dieth, the Writ ≈øhall abate: and the fir≈øt Iudg ‚Ä¢ ent which is given before Award of the Writ is not properly a Iudgment, but rather a Rule, and order, and ≈øo in a Writ of accompt, where
Iudgment is given that the Defendant computet cum querente, he ≈øhall not have Error upon that matter, for it is not a full Iudgment. See 21 E. 3. 9. So as to the Iudgment in a Writ of Tre≈øpa≈øs, ≈øcil. That no Writ of Error lyeth before the ≈øecond Iudgment after the Return of the Writ of Enquiry of Damages are given: And al≈øo it was holden by all the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices and Barons, That an Executor ≈øhall have an action upon the ca≈øe de bonis te≈øtatoris, ca≈øually come to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of another, Action, de bonis Te≈øtatoris. and by him converted to his own u≈øe in the life of the Te≈øtator, and that by the Equity of the Statute of 4 E. 3. 7. de bonis a≈øportatis in vita Te≈øtatoris.

div.head:
CCLXXVIII. Arrundel and the Bi≈øhop of Glouce≈øters, and Chaffins Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Quare Impedit.SIir John Arrundel brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Glouce≈øter, and Chaffin, and counted upon a di≈øturbance to pre≈øent 1 Novembris. Chaffin, as incumbent pleaded, That 1 Maii next after the ≈øaid 1 Novemb. he him≈øelf was pre≈øented to the Church by the Queen, the pre≈øentment to the ≈øaid Church being devolved unto her by Lap≈øe. Vpon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law: And the plea was holden in≈øufficient, for the Plaintiff counted upon a Di≈øturbance to him 1 Novem. and the Defendant entitleth him≈øelf to an incumbency 1 May after, in which ca≈øe the di≈øturbance ≈øet forth in the Count is not an≈øwered by traver≈øe, nor confe≈ø≈øed, nor avoided: And of that opinion was the whole Court: For the di≈øturbance, of which the Plaintiff hath declared, is confe≈ø≈øed. And afterwards, It was moved by the Queens Serjeants, That the Queen might have a Writ to the Bi≈øhop,Writ to the Bi≈øhop. for the title of the Queen appeareth to be by Lap≈øe which is confe≈ø≈øed, But the whole Court were clear of opinion again≈øt it: For although it appeareth that he was lawfully pre≈øented to the ≈øaid Church, and ≈øo once lawfull Incumbent, yet it appeareth al≈øo, That the title of the Queen is once executed, and ≈øo gon, and nothing remains in the Queen, and now when the Defendant hath lo≈øt his incumbency by ill pleading (as he may) as well as by Re≈øignation or Deprivation, yet the ≈øame ≈øhall not turn to the advantage of the Queen, for where the Queen pre≈øents for laps, and her Clark is in≈øtituted and inducted, the Queen hath no more to do, but the Incumbent mu≈øt ≈øhift as well as he can for the holding of it, for by what manner ≈øo ever he lo≈øeth his incumbency the Queen ≈øhall not pre≈øent again; otherwi≈øe it had been, if the Queen be Patron, and afterwards the Plaintiff had a Writ to the Bi≈øhop.

div.head:
CCLXXIX. The Lord Pagets Ca≈øe, in a Mon≈øtrans de Droit. The Ca≈øe was.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Exchequer Chamber.
div.p:
More 193, 194 1 Co. 154. 1 And. 259. THomas Lord Paget, Father of William Paget, was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Bur≈øton, and divers other Mannors in three ≈øeveral Counties in his deme≈øne as of fee, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed by Indenture, between the ≈øaid Lord of the one part, and Trentham and others on the other part, and in con≈øideration that the ≈øaid Trentham and others, with the profits of the ≈øaid Mannors ≈øhould pay his debts, and ≈øuch ≈øums of money which were contained in ≈øuch a Schedule, and which he ≈øhould appoint by his la≈øt Will, covenanted to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Mannors
to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Trentham of one Eu≈øal, &c. for the term of four and twenty years, and after the Expiration or end of the ≈øaid Term of twenty four years, unto the u≈øe of the ≈øaid William Paget, his Son in tail, with diver≈øe Remainders over: And afterwards the ≈øaid Lord Paget was attainted of high Trea≈øon. It was here holden and agreed by all the Iu≈øtices, and by the Council of both ≈øides, That the u≈øes limited to Trentham, and others are void, for here is not any con≈øideration ≈øufficient to rai≈øe an u≈øe, for the mony which is appointed for the payment of his debts is to be rai≈øed of the profits of the Lands of the ≈øaid Lord,Declaration of u≈øes. which is not any con≈øideration on the part of Trentham and others: But if the con≈øideration had been, That they with the Profits of their own Lands ≈øhould pay the debts, &c. It had been a good Con≈øideration: It was agreed al≈øo, That the term for twenty four years to Eu≈øal is void for want of ≈øufficient con≈øideration: And then it was moved, If this Lea≈øe being void, The u≈øe limited to the ≈øaid William Paget, Son of the ≈øaid Lord Paget ≈øhould being pre≈øently upon the death of the Lord Paget, or ≈øhould expect until the twenty four years were encurred after the death of the Lord Paget, or not at all. And it was argued, That an u≈øe to be rai≈øed upon an impo≈ø≈øibility ≈øhould never ri≈øe, as if I covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of B. and his Heirs, after the end of the term for years, which I.S. hath in the Mannor of D. whereas in truth, I. S. hath not any term in it, the ≈øaid u≈øe ≈øhall never ri≈øe: ≈øo here,U≈øe cannot ri≈øe out of a po≈ø≈øibility. No u≈øe to the Son can ri≈øe, for the lea≈øe for twenty four years ≈øhall never end, for it never can begin for want of ≈øufficient con≈øideration as is afore≈øaid; and if the ≈øaid u≈øe in tail ≈øhould at all ri≈øe, it ≈øhould not ri≈øe before the expiration of the ≈øaid twenty four years. As if I covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands to your u≈øe when my Son and Heir ≈øhall come to the age of one and twenty years, now if my Son dieth before ≈øuch age, The u≈øe ≈øhall not begin before the time in which my Son (if he ≈øhall live) ≈øhould attain unto his ≈øaid age. Egerton the Queens Solicitor, V≈øes may be limited to begin at times certain before which they ≈øhall not begin: and ≈øo in our ca≈øe, the u≈øe in tail in limited to begin when the term of twenty four years, is ended, and therefore until the Term be ended no u≈øe ≈øhall ri≈øe: and the u≈øe is limited to ri≈øe upon the end of the time or term of four & twenty years, and not upon the end of the e≈øtate; and ≈øo William Paget hath begun his Mon≈øtrans de Droit before his time. The Lord Paget had but an e≈øtate for life; and if ≈øo, Then the Remainders are not continggent u≈øes, but ve≈øt pre≈øently: as if a man covenant, That after his death his Son and Heir ≈øhall have his Lands, now the Father hath but an e≈øtate for life, and the inheritance is ve≈øted in the Son. Cook, I covenant, That after twenty four years ended, I and my Heirs will ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of my Son, &c. there the u≈øe in Fee doth ve≈øt in my Son pre≈øently: So I covenant, That after my death, I and every one who ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed, &c. ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Land to the u≈øe of my Brother, the ≈øaid u≈øe ≈øhall ri≈øe to my Brother pre≈øently: I devi≈øe‚ñ™ That after the death of ≈øuch a Monk, I.S. ≈øhall have the Land, nothing pa≈ø≈øeth to I.S. till the death of the Monk; but if Land be devi≈øed to a Monk for life, and afterwrds to another in Fee, the Devi≈øee in Fee ≈øhall have the Land pre≈øently. Manwood, A devi≈øe or u≈øe limited to one for life, the Remainder in tail, the fir≈øt devi≈øee doth di≈øagree. Cook, the Remainder doth ve≈øt pre≈øently. Manwood, I devi≈øe lands unto one until my Son comes of full age. Cook, The remainder doth ve≈øt pre≈øently. Manw. A u≈øe limited to one to begin at Mich. next, the remainder over, if in the mean time the Le≈ø≈øee obtain the good will of I.S. which he cannot obtain, the ≈øame remainder is not good. And if one covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of Salisbury plain, for the life of I. S. and after the remainder to A, it is a plain ca≈øe, That he in the remainder ≈øhall take pre≈øently, 37 H. 6. 36. Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe willed, That his Feoffees ≈øhould make an e≈øtate to A. for life, the remainder to C. in fee, & A. would not take the e≈øtate, C. ≈øhall
have a Subpoena again≈øt the Feoffees after the death of A. See there the ca≈øe; And if Land devi≈øeable, be devi≈øed to one for life, the Remainder over to another in Fee, and the Devi≈øee for life doth refu≈øe; Quaere, if the Devi≈øee in Remainder ≈øhall enter pre≈øently, See Fitz. Subpoena; And al≈øo he put the Ca≈øe, where Land is devi≈øed to a Monk for life, the Remainder over to another in Fee, he in the Remainder ≈øhall enter pre≈øently, ≈øee the ≈øame Ca≈øe in Perkins 108. for the Monk never took any thing by the devi≈øe, & notwith≈øtanding that there is not any particular e≈øtate upon which a Remainder can depend, yet the intent of the Devi≈øor ≈øhall be ob≈øerved in as much as it may, and the particular e≈øtate limited to the Monk is meerly void, of which every ≈øtranger ≈øhall take advantage, &c. And it was re≈øembled to a Ca≈øe in Baintons Ca≈øe, where an u≈øe in Remainder limited upon good con≈øideration ≈øhall be good in Law, although the particular u≈øe be not grounded upon good con≈øideration, & ≈øo faileth: And he urged a Ca≈øe alleadged by Popham in the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Bedford, that if in Cranmers Ca≈øe, the e≈øtate for years limited to the Executors,2 Le ‚Ä¢ . 5. 6. had been limited to Admini≈øtrators, it had been meerly void, and the u≈øe in tail limited in tail ≈øhould begin pre≈øently, & that was by rea≈øon of the interval betwixt the death of Cranmer, & the taking of the Letters of Admini≈øtration, in which mean time there is not any per≈øon capable, and therefore the Remainder ≈øhall ve≈øt pre≈øently, which is a fit ca≈øe to prove the Ca≈øe at Bar: And he remembred that in the Argument of Cranmers Ca≈øe, Lovelace Serjeant, would have an Occupancy in the Ca≈øe of ≈øuch a Term limited to Admini≈øtrators, quod omnes Ju≈øticiarii negaverunt: and in the ≈øaid Ca≈øe of Cranmer, it was holden that the Lea≈øe for years being void, the e≈øtate in the Remainder did begin pre≈øently, without expecting the effluxion of the years, &c. And truly, a Term imports in it ≈øelf an Intere≈øt, but if the limitation had been after the Term of twenty four years, &c. the ≈øame implyeth but a bare time: And to that purpo≈øe he cited the Ca≈øe 35 H. 8. Br. Expo≈øition, 44. A. Lea≈øeth to B. for ten years, & it is covenanted betwixt them, that if B. pay unto A. within the ≈øaid ten years one hundred pounds, that then he ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of B. in Fee, B. ≈øurrenders his Term to A. and within the ≈øaid ten years pays the one hundred pounds to A. here B. ≈øhall have Fee, for the years are certain; contrary, if the Covenant had been, If he pay within the Term.

Popham Attorney General Contrary, The u≈øe ≈øhall not go beyond the Contract, & here the Term doth not ve≈øt, in that it was Limited for want of ≈øufficient con≈øideration, of the Lord Paget, & the intent was not that his ≈øon ≈øhould have po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the land before the term of 24. years expired.

U≈øe what it is.A u≈øe is a thing in Con≈øcience, according to confidence to be guided by the intent of the parties: & upon ≈øuch Ca≈øe at the Common Law W. Paget ≈øhould not have a Subpoena before the years expired, and this word (Term) doth not alter the Ca≈øe; and there is a great difference betwixt an u≈øe rai≈øed by Feoffment and an u≈øe rai≈øed by Covenant, For in the fir≈øt ca≈øe the Feffor doth dipo≈ø≈øe≈øs him≈øelf utterly, & if it takes not effect to one purpo≈øe it ≈øhall take effect to another purpo≈øe: But in the Ca≈øe of a Covenant it is otherwi≈øe, for the u≈øe ri≈øeth according to the contract & not otherwi≈øe, & here the Contract is, That W. Paget ≈øhall have the Land not immediatly after the death of his Father, but after the 24 years expire.

Owen Serjeant, It hath been agreed of both ≈øides, That every u≈øe ≈øhall go according to the intent of the parties, and here it appeareth, That it was the intent of the Lord Paget, to put all the u≈øe out of him≈øelf, and I ≈øee not any difference betwixt an u≈øe rai≈øed by Covenant and a u≈øe rai≈øed by Feoffment.
