For a u≈øe limited utrovis modo to Pauls Steeple for the life of A. and after to the u≈øe of B. in Fee, the fir≈øt u≈øe is void, but the ≈øecond good; and here the meaning of the Lord Paget plainly appears, for there is a Provi≈øo in the Indenture, That after the ≈øaid debts and legacies paid, the u≈øe limited for 24 years ≈øhall cea≈øe, and
it is expre≈øtly averred, that they are paid 11. H. 4. A. lea≈øeth for life, the remainder in tail to him≈øelf, the Remainder over to a ≈øtranger in Fee, the mean Remainder limited by A. to him≈øelf is void, and the remainder over ≈øhall be immediate to the e≈øtate for life. Egerton, The words of the Indenture, and the intent of the parties are the rules of u≈øes, The fir≈øt u≈øe is void, For the intent of the Lord Paget was void, becau≈øe contrary to the Law, and Eu≈øal, to whom the u≈øe for years was limited, could not take pre≈øently, for his e≈øtate is limited to begin after the death of the Lord Paget; and there is a great difference betwixt u≈øes rai≈øed by Covenant, and by Feoffment, For when a u≈øe is rai≈øed by Feoffment, there all is out of the Feoffor, the land is gone, the u≈øe is gone, the tru≈øt is gone, nothing remaineth but a bare authority to rai≈øe u≈øes out of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Feoffees, & being new u≈øes, there although ≈øome of them be void, yet the other ≈øhall ≈øtand; but where a u≈øe is rai≈øed by way of Covenant there the covenantor continues in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, there the u≈øes limited, if they be according to Law, ≈øhall rai≈øe & draw the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion out of him, but if not, the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall remain in him, until a lawful u≈øe ≈øhall ari≈øe, which before its time ≈øhall not ri≈øe for any defect in the precedent u≈øe. And here is no Term, therefore no end, for that which hath not a begining hath no ending, And if there be no e≈øtate, then no Term, & if there be ≈øo, then it is to be taken for the time of 24. years, which is not as yet expired, and then was there in the Lord Pawlet an e≈øtate de≈øcendable for 24 years, which by the Attainder doth accrue unto the Queen. And he cited the Ca≈øe of 13 Eliz. Dyer. 300. Feoffment to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of a woman which he entendeth to marry, until the i≈ø≈øue which he ≈øhould beget on the ≈øaid woman ≈øhould come unto the age of 21. years, and then to the u≈øe of the woman during her widow-hood; They are married, the Husband dieth without i≈ø≈øue, the Wife ≈øhall hold the land: But by him, if this u≈øe had bin rai≈øed by way of Covenant it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe. Coke Admit that all the u≈øes be good, yet his meaning was, That the debts and legacies being paid W. Paget ≈øhould have his land, for it is provided by the Indenture, That when the debts & legacies are paid, the e≈øtate for 24. years ≈øhall cea≈øe. Manwood, The payment of the debts cannot end that which never was, and as to the two fir≈øt e≈øtates, they were never out of him, therefore they came unto the Q. by his attainder. Coke, After debts and legacies paid all other e≈øtates but the e≈øtate of W. Paget cea≈øe, therefore William Paget ≈øhall have the Land. And the rule of Shelly 35 H. 8. 56 is worthy to be received, ≈øcil. That learning is hone≈øt, & wi≈øhed to be u≈øed, that every man learned in the Law, do con≈øtrue Deeds according to the meanings of the makers. Manwood, A Feoffment to the u≈øe of Salisbury Plain for the life of I. S. the Remainder over, the ≈øame u≈øe ≈øhall come into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pre≈øently, for there is not any per≈øon capable of the particular e≈øtate, but where the fir≈øt u≈øe is limited to a Ba≈øtard, the remainder over, there, the Remainder ≈øhall not come into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pre≈øently, for the Ba≈øtard is a per≈øon capable, but not by ≈øuch form of conveyance in con≈øideration of natural affection. Popham, In the ca≈øe of Ba≈øtard, there was an e≈øtate for life executed to the Father in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, & then a Remainder to a Ba≈øtard, the Remainder to the Sons lawfully begotten; but here in our Ca≈øe no e≈øtate is created to precede the e≈øtate of William Paget, upon which the Remainder can depend.

At another day, It was argued by Coke, It is to be agreed on both ≈øides, That the e≈øtate for four and twenty years is meerly void, and al≈øo the fir≈øt u≈øe limited to Trentham and others, and it is not rea≈øon, that the u≈øe limited to William Paget, ≈øhould expect until the four and twenty years be expired by effluxion of time, and to that purpo≈øe he cited Cranmers Ca≈øe, where an e≈øtate in u≈øe was limited to Cranmer for life, the Remainder to his Executors for one and twenty years, the Remainder over in tail to his Son
and Heir, &c. Cranmer is attainted of Trea≈øon and Here≈øy, ≈øo as he could not make a Will, or Executors, there it is holden, That the term is void, becau≈øe no Executors, and that the Remainder in u≈øe ≈øhould ve≈øt pre≈øently, and ≈øhould not expect until the ≈øaid number of years expire by effluxion of time. And difference hath been put betwixt the ca≈øe of Cranmer, and the Ca≈øe at Bar, becau≈øe in Cranmers Ca≈øe there was a po≈ø≈øibility at the beginning that the Term for years might be good, for the term became void by matter ex po≈øt facto, ≈øci. By the attainder of him, which di≈øabled him to make Executors, but in the Ca≈øe at Bar, the term for twenty four years was expre≈øly void ab initio: But that difference is without rea≈øon, for what rea≈øon is there, That the Remainder ≈øhould be father off the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion when the e≈øtate for years is originally void, than when it becomes void by matter ex po≈øt facto? Suppo≈øe that the Lord Paget had by Indenture covenanted as above for the two fir≈øt u≈øes, (being in truth void in Law) and afterwards by another Indenture, reciting, That whereas he had covenanted, That in con≈øideration That A. with the profits of his Lands ≈øhould pay his debts, &c. to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Lands for his own life: Now he covenants, to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of William Paget, and his Heirs, ≈øhould not he pre≈øently be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of William Paget, and his Heirs, although the words be, That then and from thenceforth? For I hold it a clear ca≈øe, that his e≈øtate begins pre≈øently, being limited, to begin upon a void e≈øtate, althouh the limitation be by words de futuro. And to this purpo≈øe he cited the ca≈øe 3 E. 6. Br. Lea≈øe 62. A man lea≈øeth for years, Habendum po≈øt dimi≈ø≈øionem inde fact. to J.S. finitam, where no ≈øuch demi≈øe is made, the ≈øame Lea≈øe ≈øhall begin pre≈øently: If an Indenture be made to a Monk, and another, Habend. to the Monk for one and twenty years, and after the end of that, to the other for one and twenty years, the other ≈øhall have it pre≈øently. And he put a Ca≈øe 7 E. 3. in the new Impre≈ø≈øion 19. and in the old Impre≈ø≈øion 317. Where one Maud brought a Formedon in the Remainder, and counted that one Hamond was ≈øei≈øed, and gave the ≈øaid Tenements to one Robert, &c. in tail, and that for want of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, that the Tenements ≈øhould return to the ≈øaid Hamond for life, the Remainder to the Demandant in Fee, and counted further, That Robert is dead without i≈ø≈øue, and that Hamond is al≈øo dead, &c. It was holden, although that the Remainder re≈øerved to the Donor, be void, yet the Remainder over in Fee is good, &c. And in that ca≈øe although that the Remainder in Fee was future, ≈øci. After the death of Hamond, & the e≈øtate re≈øerved to Hamond meerly void, & that originally, & not by matter ex po≈øt facto, yet the Remainder in Fee was good, and ≈øhould begin pre≈øently upon the death of Robert without i≈ø≈øue, and ≈øhould not expect the death of Hamond. Mr. Attorney hath given a Rule, That the intent of the parties is the Direction of u≈øes, as al≈øo of Wills, and therefore I will put one Ca≈øe of Wills, 37 H. 6. 17. If a man devi≈øe Lands to a Monk for four and twenty years, and after the ≈øame ended to another in Fee, here the Monk being a dead per≈øon cannot take the e≈øtate limited to him, & therefore it is void: but the Fee limited to the other is good, and ≈øhall take effect pre≈øently: If it be ≈øo in a Will, why not ≈øo al≈øo in u≈øes? For the intents of the parties do direct the con≈øtructions of both: And our ca≈øe here is a ≈øtronger ca≈øe than the ca≈øe cited 37 H. 6. 36. for there where Land is devi≈øed to a Monk for life, there may be colour of an Occupant during the life of the Monk, who might take it, although the Monk him≈øelf cannot take it, and ≈øo the Remainder doth not take effect pre≈øently as to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but ≈øhall ≈øtay till after the death of the Monk; But here is not any colour of an Occupancy, for the e≈øtate here is a Lea≈øe for years, which cannot admit an Occupant. And ≈øee al≈øo 37 H. 6. 36. If a man devi≈øe that his Feoffees ≈øhall make an e≈øtate to I. S. for life, the Remainder over to C. in Fee, and I. S. will not take his e≈øtate, C. ≈øhall
have a Sub-poena again≈øt the Feoffees to make an e≈øtate to him, leaving out I. S. and ≈øee Amy Town≈øends Ca≈øe in the Commentaries, where the Husband ≈øei≈øed in the Right of his Wife, makes a Feoffment in Fee to the u≈øe of him≈øelf, and his wife for their lives, the Remainder over to another, the husband dyeth, the wife refu≈øeth the e≈øtate limited to her by the Husband, ≈øhe brings Sur cui in vita, not again≈øt the heir, but again≈øt him in the Remainder, to whom the Land doth accrue by the refu≈øal of the wife; not again≈øt the heir of the Feoffor; and I grant, That where an e≈øtate in u≈øe, or otherwi≈øe is to begin upon a condition precedent which is impo≈ø≈øible, or again≈øt the Law, the e≈øtate ≈øhall never ri≈øe or begin. And here the Ca≈øe of the Lord Borroughs, 35 H. 8. Dy. 55. was cited, Where the Father covenanted in con≈øideration of marriage of his Son, that immediately after his death his elde≈øt Son ≈øhall have the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or u≈øe of all his Lands according to the ≈øame cour≈øe of inheritance, as then they ≈øtood, and that all per≈øons now ≈øei≈øed, or to be ≈øei≈øed, ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed to the ≈øaid u≈øe and intent, and it was holden, That upon that matter no u≈øe is changed: But if the Words had bin Immediately after his death, they ≈øhould remain, then although the words of the Limitation be In futuro, the u≈øe of the Fee ≈øhall re≈øt in the Son pre≈øently; and the words In futuro ought not to be interpreted, but in benefit of him to whom the u≈øe, and e≈øtate is limited, 9 Eliz. Dyer. 261. A. Lea≈øeth for thirty years, and four years after the beginning of the ≈øaid term he makes another Lea≈øe for years by the≈øe words, Noverint, &c. dictis 30 annis finitis & completis, demi≈øi≈ø≈øe omnia praemi≈ø≈øa, to the ≈øaid, &c. Habendum & tenendum a die confectionis prae≈øentium, termino praedict finito, u≈øque ad finem 30 annorum. And by the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices, This new Lea≈øe ≈øhall commence in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at the end of the former term, and not before, and if it ≈øhould not be expounded, the ≈øecond Lea≈øe ≈øhould be in effect an e≈øtate; but for ten years, which was not the intent of the parties, and every grant ≈øhall be expounded mo≈øt ≈øtrongly for the grantee, and to his advantage, to which purpo≈øe he ≈øaid he had vouched this Ca≈øe. Al≈øo by him there is not any difference, where the u≈øe is limited by way of covenant, or upon a Feoffment: And if a man enfeoffeth B. upon condition that he ≈øhall enfeoff C. now if he offer to enfeoff C. and he refu≈øeth, the Feoffor may re-enter. But if the condition were to give to C. in tail, then upon ≈øuch refu≈øal of C. the Feoffor ≈øhall not re-enter. See 2 E. 4. 2. 19 H. 6. 34. E. ≈øi Equitas ≈øit adhibenda in con≈øtruction of conditions a multo fortiori in ca≈øe of V≈øes: A Feoffment in Fee upon condition, that the Feoffee ≈øhall grant a Rent charge to J. S. who doth it, but J. S. refu≈øeth, the Feoffor ≈øhall not re-enter, for that was not the intent of the condition: If in the principal ca≈øe,Po≈øt. 266. the limitation of the u≈øe had been after the expiration of twenty four years, then no u≈øe ≈øhould ri≈øe before the twenty four years expire, but where, not the time, but the e≈øtate is material, there, if the e≈øtate be void, the u≈øe ≈øhall go to him in the Remainder pre≈øently, and ≈øhall not ≈øtay the time,1 Co. 154. &c.

Egerton Solicitor, fir≈øt it is to ≈øee, if the u≈øe limited to William Paget be good; ≈øecondly, if William Paget doth not come before his time to ≈øhew his Right: If this u≈øe limited to William Paget be a Remainder or an e≈øtate to begin upon a contingent, or a pre≈øent e≈øtate, the e≈øtates formerly limited being void; and he conceived, that it is not a Remainder, for there is not any e≈øtate upon which it may depend; And the words are after the e≈øtate for twenty four years ended or expired, that then and from thenceforth to the u≈øe of William Paget, &c. ≈øo that no u≈øe is limited to him before the particular e≈øtate is ended, therefore no Remainder, for a Remainder ought to begin when the particular e≈øtate begins. Without doubt that was not the intent that William Paget ≈øhould have the Land during the life of his Father, and yet the u≈øe limited during the life of his Father, was void, and if the Remainder ≈øhould take effect during the ≈øaid twenty four years again≈øt Eu≈øall
and his companions, wherefore ≈øhould it not al≈øo take effect again≈øt Trentham and the others, to who≈øe u≈øe it was limited during the life of the Lord Paget: And here, the u≈øe limited to William Paget is to begin upon a collateral contingent, upon which if it cannot ri≈øe, it ≈øhall not ri≈øe at all; and I conceive that the u≈øe limited to William Paget, ≈øhall never ri≈øe, or begin, for it is limited to begin when the term of twenty four years is ended, and that is never, for that which cannot begin, cannot end, and this Term is meerly void, Ergo, it cannot begin, Ergo, it cannot end, then this thenceforth cannot be, and ≈øo this contingent can never fall. H. 6. & 7. E. 6. A Lea≈øe was made for years upon condition, that if the Le≈ø≈øee do not pay ≈øuch a ≈øum of money, that he ≈øhould lo≈øe his Indenture, the meaning and ≈øen≈øe of the≈øe words is not that he ≈øhould lo≈øe the Indenture in parchment, but that he ≈øhould lo≈øe his Term: The Iudgment in an Eectjone firmae, is, Quod querens recuperet terminum ≈øuum, that is to be under≈øtood, not the time, but his Intere≈øt in the Land for the Term (And Coke ≈øecretly ≈øaid, that in that ca≈øe there is not any contingent, for the e≈øtates precedent never began.) And as to the Ca≈øe cited before by Coke, Br. Lea≈øes 62. If the la≈øt Lea≈øe be made by Indenture, reciting the former Lea≈øe, certainly the ≈øecond Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall not be concluded to claim the Land demi≈øed pre≈øently, but ≈øhall tarry until the years of the fir≈øt Term be expired by effluction of time. And as to Mawnds Ca≈øe cited before, there is an e≈øtate upon which a Remainder may depend, ≈øcil. the e≈øtate tail alledged to Robert, &c. If ≈øuch as now is limited to William Paget had been limited at the Common Law to a younger Son, the elde≈øt Brother ≈øhould have the Land in the Interim di≈øcharged of any u≈øe, and now after the Statute, no u≈øe limited to William Paget, before the contingent; where, therefore, is it in the mean time? In the Lord Paget, who being attainted, it accrues to the Queen; and out of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Queen, this u≈øe ≈øhall never ri≈øe, although that the contingent be performed, for now the u≈øe is locked up; A u≈øe doth con≈øi≈øt in privity of the e≈øtate and confidence of the per≈øon, if the≈øe be ≈øevered, the u≈øe is gone: And here, if the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion be in the Queen, ≈øhe cannot be ≈øei≈øed to another u≈øe. Note by Godfrey, that the opinion in Baintons Ca≈øe, 8 Eliz. Dyer 37. is not Law, and ≈øo hath the Law been taken of late. Popham contrary; If before the Statute of 27 H. 8. the Father covenant in con≈øideration of Advancement of his Son to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of I. S. for life, and after the death of I. S. to the u≈øe of my Son in Fee, here the e≈øtate of I. S. in the u≈øe is void, and yet the e≈øtate in the u≈øe limited to my Son, ≈øhall not take effect before the death of I. S. for the e≈øtate of my Son is not limited to take effect till after the death of I.S and therefore the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Father is not charged with the u≈øe during the life of I.S. But if by way of Feoffment I.S. had refu≈øed, the Son ≈øhould have it pre≈øently, and the Father ≈øhould not have it, for he by his Livery hath put all out of him, and it was not the intent of the Feoffment, that the Feoffee ≈øhould have the Land to his own u≈øe. Popham allowed the difference mentioned before out of 2 E. 4 & 19 H. 6. betwixt a Feoffment upon condition to enfeoff a ≈øtranger, and to give in tail to a ≈øtranger, and that is grounded upon the intent of the parties. And Owen Serjeant put the Ca≈øe cited before 1. 3 Eliz. Dyer 330. A Feoffment is made by the Husband to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of one Ann, whom he intended to marry, for, during, and until the Son which he ≈øhould beget on the body of the ≈øaid woman had accompli≈øhed the age of thirty one years, and after ≈øuch time that ≈øuch Son ≈øhould come unto ≈øuch age unto the u≈øe of the ≈øaid woman, quamdiu ≈øhe ≈øhould live ≈øole, they entermarry, the Husband dyeth without I≈ø≈øue, the wife entreth immediately, and continues ≈øole, and her Entry was adjudged lawful, and the e≈øtate in Remainder good, although ≈øhe never had any Son, and thereupon a Writ of Error was brought, and the fir≈øt Iudgment was affirmed
(& note by Tanfield, and others at the Bar, that that was the mo≈øt apt ca≈øe to the purpo≈øe in the Law) and the rea≈øon of ≈øuch Iudgment was, becau≈øe they took it, that Deeds ought to be expounded according to the meaning of the parties, and e≈øtates in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: I grant there ought to be a particular e≈øtate, upon which a Remainder may depend, but the ≈øame is not nece≈ø≈øary where the Conveyance is by way of u≈øe: And if I covenant that A. ≈øhall have my Lands to him & his Heirs, to pay my Debts and Legacies, the ≈øame is by way of bargain and ≈øale, and nothing pa≈ø≈øeth without Enrolment. And here the Attainder doth not prevent the u≈øe, as it hath been objected by Ma≈øter Solicitor, for the u≈øe doth ri≈øe before the Attainder, for William Paget had a Remainder in tail, in the life of his Father, upon the fir≈øt limitation, &c. Periam Iu≈øtice, I lea≈øe my Lands to you, to begin after the expiration of a Lea≈øe which I have made thereof to I.S. and in truth he hath not any Lea≈øe, the ≈øame Lea≈øe ≈øhall never begin. Manwood chief Baron, I lea≈øe my Lands to you, or grant a Rent to you to begin after the death of Pri≈øoit Serjeant at Law, when ≈øhall that begin? Coke, Pre≈øently. Manwood, cujus contrarium e≈øt Lex.

div.head: CCLXXX. The Queen again≈øt the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, Fane, and Hud≈øon. Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Rot. 1832.
div.p:
THe Queen brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter and Hud≈øon, Quare Impedit. 4 Len. 107. Hob. 303. 175. Owen. 155. and counted that John A≈øhburnham was ≈øei≈øed of the advow≈øon of Burwa≈øh, & was outlawed in an action of Debt, during which Out-lawry in force, the Church voided, for which it belongs to the Queen to pre≈øent. The Arch-Bi≈øhop and Bi≈øhops plead, that they claim nothing but as Metropolitan and Ordinary, Fane pleaded that King E. 4. Ex gratia ≈øua ≈øpeciali, &c. and in con≈øideration of faithful ≈øervice, &c. did grant to the Lord Ha≈øtings the Ca≈øtle and Barony of Ha≈øtings, and Hundred, &c. Et quod ip≈øe haberet omnia bona & catalla tenentium, re≈øidentium & non re≈øidentium, & aliorum re≈øidentium quorumcunque hominum, de & in Ca≈øtro Baronia, &c. or within the ≈øame, pro munero debit. &c. tam ad ≈øectam Regis, &c. quam, &c. Ut legatorem, & quid ip≈øe faceret, per ≈øe vel per his ≈øufficient Deputies, &c. And from him derived to the now Earl of Huntington as Heir; and the ≈øaid Earl ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, and the ≈øaid A≈øhburnham ≈øei≈øed of the advow≈øon as appendant to the Manor of A≈øhburnham, holden of the ≈øaid Barony, the Church afore≈øaid during the Out-lawry afore≈øaid, became void, For which the ≈øaid Fane, ad dictam Eccle≈øiam u≈øurpando pre≈øentavit the ≈øaid Hud≈øon, who was admitted and in≈øtituted, &c. with this, That idem T.C. verificare vult, that the ≈øaid Church of Burwa≈øh is, and at the time of the grant was, within the Precinct, Liberty, and Franchi≈øe afore≈øaid, and that the ≈øaid Manor of A≈øhburnham, at the time of the grant afore≈øaid was holden of the ≈øaid Barony: and the Incumbent pleaded the ≈øame Plea: & if by that grant of King Edward the fourth, to the Lord Ha≈øtings, ≈øcil. omnia bona & catalla, &c. The pre≈øentment to the Church ≈øhould pa≈øs or not, was the que≈øtion. Shutleworth Serjeant, argued for the Queen, he confe≈ø≈øed that the King might grant ≈øuch pre≈øentment, but it ought to be by ≈øpecial and ≈øufficient words, ≈øo as it may appear by them, that the intent of the King was to grant ≈øuch a thing, for the general words (omnia bona & catalla) will not pa≈øs ≈øuch ≈øpecial Chattel in the Kings grant: And he conceived that by the ≈øub≈øequent words, no Goods or Chattels ≈øhall pa≈øs by ≈øuch Grants, but ≈øuch which may be ≈øei≈øed, which
the avoidance of a Church cannot be, & quod ip≈øe liceret, per ≈øe vel mini≈øtros ≈øuos ponere ≈øe in ≈øei≈øinam, 8 H. 4. 114. 15. the King granted to the Bi≈øhop of London, that he ≈øhould have Catalla felonum & fugitivor, de omnibus hominibus & tenentibus de & in terris & feodis praedict. and of all re≈øiants within the Lands and Fees afore≈øaid, Ita quod, ≈øi praedict. homines, tenentes & re≈øidentes de & in terris & feodis praedict‚ñ™ ≈øeu aliqui eorum, ≈øeu aliquis alius infra cadem terra & feodis pro aliqua tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione, &c. vid. librum, &c. and by Tirwit, By that Grant the goods of tho≈øe who are put to Pennance ≈øhall not pa≈øs; ≈øo of the goods of one Felo de ≈øe, vid. 42 E. 3. 5. One being impanelled on the Grand Enque≈øt before the Iu≈øtices of Oyer and Terminer, pleaded the charter of the King of exemption from Enque≈øts, and becau≈øe in the ≈øaid charter was not this clau≈øe,More. 126. licet tanget nos & haeredes no≈øtros, upon challenge, it was rejected, and the party charged and ≈øworn: And if the King grant to me to appropriate an advow≈øon, which in truth is holden of the King, ≈øuch a grant is void, if there be not ≈øpecial words by which it might appear that the King had notice of it, and that his intent was that the grant ≈øhould extend unto it, 16 E. 3. Grants 58. & 33 E. 3. Grants 103. So here the Pre≈øentment is a ≈øpecial chattel, and is not u≈øually intended or thought upon, when men ≈øpeak generally of goods and chattels. But admit that it be, yet the Plea doth not lye in the Defendants to plead, for they do not derive any Intere≈øt under this grant, but are meer ≈øtrangers to it, and therefore they ≈øhall not take any advantage, by laying this grant in the Queens way, for the Q. hath good title again≈øt all per≈øons but tho≈øe who claim under the grant, but that is nothing to the Defendants, for one cannot cro≈øs the title of the King, if he do not make a title to him≈øelf, As 39 E. 3. 18. 37 E. 3. 11. If the title of the King be found by a fal≈øe Office, the party grieved cannot traver≈øe the Kings title without making title to him≈øelf found by Office, and then the King may choo≈øe whether he will maintain his own title found by Office, or traver≈øe the title of the other. Walme≈øley, contrary: This Title of Pre≈øentment is a Chattel, Rex habebit omnia catalla felonum, &c. A Term of years is a Chattel, ≈øo the I≈ø≈øues and Profits of the Lands of men outlawed for Felony, ≈øo a right of Action for Goods, Therefore a Title to pre≈øent; and if ≈øuch a Title accrue to the King, by ≈øuch general words they ≈øhall pa≈øs from the King. And as to that which hath been objected, That the Gra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of King Edward the fourth doth not extend but only to ≈øuch Goods and Chattels which may be ≈øei≈øed, he cited the Ca≈øe of 39 H. 6. 35. b. Where the Grantee of a Rent for Term of years granted omnia bona & catalla ≈øua, tam viva quam mortua, the Rent doth pa≈øs, and yet the Grantor cannot put him in ≈øei≈øin of it, but ought to expect the day of payment of it. And this Title to pre≈øent is not a thing in action, for if no di≈øturbance be made, the party may have the benefit of it without any action. Ander≈øon conceived, That this Title to pre≈øent cannot pa≈øs by tho≈øe general words (bona & catalla) for they do not extend to Rights, or things in Action, for ≈øuch things only which are commonly known and under≈øtod, ≈øhall pa≈øs by ≈øuch words: By grant of Goods, Chattels real will not pa≈øs; for when men ≈øpeak of Goods, Hou≈øehold-≈øtuff, mony, and ≈øuch per≈øonal things only are under≈øtood: So a man cannot be ≈øaid to have a Chattel but where he is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of it, and here this Intere≈øt is but jus prae≈øentandi.
Periam, This Intere≈øt is a Chattel, for if the Church become void, and before pre≈øentment the Patron dieth, the Executors ≈øhall have the pre≈øentment, for it was a Chattel ve≈øted in the Te≈øtator: It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCLXXXI. Jones Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. Rot. 1527. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: HEn. Jones had ≈øtolen the Plate of Trinity Colledge in Oxford, and by mediation of his friends it was concluded and agreed, that no Evidence ≈øhould be given again≈øt him at the Sute of the Colledge, and that the Colledge ≈øhould be recompenced for the lo≈ø≈øe, and two of his Friends, Brien and Brice were bound uto Doctor Underhil, Rector of Lincoln Colledge in Oxford, (but unto the u≈øe of the Ma≈øter and Scholrs of Trinity Colledge) upon condition that if the ≈øaid Obligor paid forty pounds within ≈øix months after, the ≈øaid Hen. Jones ≈øhould be acquitted & relea≈øed of the troubles wherein he now is, with the ≈øafety of his life, that then, &c. In debt upon the Obligation The Defendants pleaded that he was indicted at the A≈ø≈øi≈øes at Ox. & arraigned upon it, ≈øcil. for the ≈øtealing of the ≈øaid Plate, and found guilty thereof, and had his Clergy, and was burned in the hand, & he demanded Iudgment of this Action, upon which there was a Demurrer: Wind. If the words had been to pay the money, after that Henry Jones ≈øhould be relea≈øed and acquitted of the troubles in which he now is without any more, the Defendants had been bounden to pay the mony. Periam, If the words of the condition had been, that after Henry Jones ≈øhould be acquitted of the Felony, then no mony payable, but here the words are with ≈øafety of his life: but here he conceived, that the intent of the Obligation was, that no Evidence ≈øhould be given, and ≈øo to ≈øave his life from the Gallows, for which the Defendants might have ≈øhewed the ≈øpecial matter,Ante. 73. and averred that the Obligation was made for the di≈øcharge of a Felon, and ≈øo again≈øt the Law, &c. but now, they cannot take advantage of it, and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCLXXXII. Ca≈øtle and Oldmans Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øc. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
CA≈øtle brought Debt again≈øt Oldman for a pain ‚Ä¢ o≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in a Court Baron,Debt. 2 Roll. 106. 3 Cro. 79. 2 In≈øt. 143. and declared That the Defendant was pre≈øented at the Court Baron for ≈øuch an offence, and if he did not amend it before the next Court, he ≈øhould pay ≈øuch a pain: And at the next Court it was pre≈øented, That the Defendant had not amended it, and ≈øo he had incurred the pain upon which the Action is brought, and now the Defendant would wage his Law, and it was much doubted whether wager of Law lay in the Ca≈øe. Shutleworth, 13. H. 7. 31. Vpon a Recovery in a Court Baron, wager of Law lyes not, by Conisby, which Periam denyed; And by him upon an account by another hand, it doth not lye, for it is a matter of which the Country may have Conu≈øance; ≈øo here the matter is notorious, whi ‚Ä¢ h lyeth in the knowledge of all the Iurors who pre≈øented it: And by him, the pain ought to be afferred, which Ander≈øon denied. For there is a difference betwixt an amercement and a pain, which Windham granted. And ≈øee for the amerciament in the Leet, 10 H. 6. 7. 12 R. 2 Ley. 43. But in a Court Baron, becau≈øe it is not a Court of Record; ≈øo in Debt upon an Arbitrament, the Law lyeth. And Waler one of the Secondaries ≈øhewed unto the Court a Pre≈øident, 6 Eliz.
Where debt was brought by Sir Thomas Tyndal, upon a pain forfeited for the breaking of a By-law in a Court Baron again≈øt Tyler; and the party was received to Wage his Law.

div.head:
CCLXXXIII. Thetford and Thetfords Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Wa≈øt the Plaintiff declared, upon the demi≈øe of the moyety of the Manor, whereof part of the Tenants were Copy-holders, and part Freeholders, and that A. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor, and had „Äà‚óä„Äâ two Daughters, and dyed ≈øei≈øed, the Daughters entred, and made partition of the Demeans only, but the Services of the Free-holders and Copy-holders did remain in Common; One of the Daughters took Husband the Husband and the Wife make a Lea≈øe of the moyety of the Manor to the Plaintiff for years by word, rendring Rent, the Le≈ø≈øee entred into the Demeans allotted to the Wife of the Le≈ø≈øor.Partition. The Husband died, and the Wife brought an Action of Wa≈øt. Ander≈øon, By the partition the Demeans are now become in gro≈øs, and ≈øevered from the Manor; And if partition be made of a Manor, ≈øo as the Demeans be allotted to one Si≈øter, and the Services to the other, now the Mannor is di≈ø≈øolved, yet if the other Si≈øter dieth without i≈ø≈øue, and her part de≈øcendeth to the other, now it is become a Manor again, which Windham and Periam granted,6 Co. 64. See 12. H. 4. 271. And Ander≈øon was of opinion, that the moyety of the Demeans did not pa≈øs by the words of the moyety of the Manor, as if one ≈øei≈øed of a Manor maketh a Feoffment in Fee of part of the Demeans, and afterwards re-purcha≈øeth them, and then makes a Feoffment of the whole Manor, the Demeans repurcha≈øed will not pa≈øs thereby, for they were once ≈øevered from the Manor, and not re-united by the purcha≈øe. Periam, Although that in truth it is not a Manor nor any part of a Manor, yet if it hath beeen reputed the moyety of the Manor, it ≈øhall pa≈øs by ≈øuch name, which Ander≈øon grant, ed, but it is not like to our Ca≈øe. Periam, This is an ancient partition, as appeareth by the Verdict, ten years pa≈øt, and al≈øo it hath been reputed the moyety of the Manor, therefore it ≈øhall pa≈øs. Windham conce≈ø≈øit Periam, The intent of the Grantor is the be≈øt Interpreter of the≈øe words, without relying ≈øtrictly upon the words. Ander≈øon, If we ≈øhall take the intents of men for Law, we ≈øhall fall into many confu≈øions in our proceedings, but the Law is to judge of the meanings of men by their words. Ever in the con≈øtructions of Wills, the intent of the Te≈øtators have not had further favour than the words have given leave. As to the other point: It was argued by Walm≈øley, that the Lea≈øe made by the Husband and Wife without Deed was void, See 1 Ma. Dyer. 91. And if the Wife after the death of her Husband accepts the Rent upon ≈øuch a Lea≈øe re≈øerved, it ≈øhall not bind her, for the con≈øent of the Wife ought to be at the beginning of it, which cannot be without Deed. Ander≈øon conceived that the Lea≈øe is not meerly void, See 15 Eliz. Smith & Stapletons Ca≈øe, Plowd. 431. Periam, The matter is clear, for although the Plaintiff declares generally of a Lea≈øe made by the Husband & Wife, yet the Iury hath found, that it was by Indenture, and that is pur≈øuant enough. And if the Husband and Wife make a Feoffment of the Wives Land, it is the Feoffment of doth of them; which Walme≈øley granted: It was adjorned.

div.head: CCLXXXIV. Smalwood amd others, again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Lichfeild and others, Quare Impedit. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: HUmphrey Smalwood, Richard Say, and Thomas Say, Executors of VVilliam Say, Quare Impedit. 1 Cro. 241. brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfeild, and M. Incumbent, quod permittat prae≈øentare ad Archidiaconatum de Derby, which was void, Et ad prae≈øentationem Te≈øtatoris in vita ≈øua, & nunc in retardationem executionis Te≈øtamenti, did belong to the Executors: Exception was taken becau≈øe the≈øe words (In retardationem executionis Te≈øtament) could not be applied to a di≈øturbance in the life of the Te≈øtator. Windham, There is not any Writ in the Regi≈øter of Quare Impedit, upon a di≈øturbance made to the Te≈øtator. Ander≈øon, What then? therefore no remedy becau≈øe no Writ according to his ≈øpecial matter, 25 E. 3. 25. Goods are taken out of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Te≈øtator, upon which the Executors brought Tre≈øpa≈øs, In retardationem executionis Te≈øtamenti, Writ abated, for it ought to be where the Executors them≈øelves were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Periam, The Advow≈øon it ≈øelf is valuable, not the pre≈øentment, therefore it cannot be ≈øaid in retardationem. Periam, Before the Statute of 4 E. 3. 73. In Ca≈øe were damages were only to be recovered, the Action moritur cum per≈øona, but where the thing it ≈øelf was to be recovered, there the Action accrued to the Executors. Ander≈øon, 7 H. 4. 73. Ejectione firmae of an Ejectment made unto the Te≈øtator was maintained by the Executors be equity of the Statute of 4 E. 3 cap. 6. And by the opinion of the whole Court, the Executors might have a Quare Impedit upon a di≈øturbance made to the Pre≈øentment: It was objected al≈øo, that a Quare Impedit doth not lye of an Archdeaconry-≈øhip, for it is not local, nor any Indenture made of it, but is only a matter of function, but it was not allowed, for ‚Ä¢ iii Archdeacon hath Locum in Coro: And by the Statute a Quare Impedit lyeth of a Chappel, and by the equity of it, of a Prebend, &c. See the Statute of We≈øt. 2. Quare Impedit of a Chappel, Prebend, &c. It was moved, if the Executors had pre≈øented after the death of the Te≈øtator, whether the Archdeacon ought to receive the Clark of the Te≈øtator, or of the Executors, and the opinion of the Court was, That the Bi≈øhop ≈øhould have election therein: And afterwards Iudgment was given, that the Writ ≈øhould abate, for the di≈øturbance to the Te≈øtator cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed new matter (In retardationem executionis Te≈øtamenti) But yet it was agreed, that the Executors might have their ≈øpecial Writ upon their Ca≈øe for the ≈øaid di≈øturbance.

div.head: Trin. 31 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
IN an Action brought again≈øt one as Executor, who pleaded that he refu≈øed, upon which the parties were at I≈ø≈øue: The Bi≈øhop did certifie,1 Cro. 81. 3 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 2 Len. 180. quod non recu≈øavit, whereas in truth he had refu≈øed before the Commi≈ø≈øary: Tenner Serjeant moved to have the advice of the Court upon that matter, and argued that the Court ought to write to the Commi≈ø≈øary: Which was denyed by the whole Court, for he is not the Officer unto the Court to that purpo≈øe, but the Bi≈øhop him≈øelf is the Officer: And the party cannot aver again≈øt the Certificate of the Bi≈øhop, no more than again≈øt the Retorn of the Sheriff: The Court was al≈øo of opinion, that the only remedy for the Defendant was by Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt the Bi≈øhop for his fal≈øe Certificate: But it was moved, That the I≈ø≈øue joyned upon the refu≈øal ought to be tryed
by Iury, and not by the Certificate of the Bi≈øhop, and ≈øo was the opinion of Windham and Walme≈øley. Periam, Where the I≈ø≈øue is whether the Executor did refu≈øe before ≈øuch a day, or after, there the tryal ≈øhall be by Iury; contrary where the I≈ø≈øue is upon refu≈øal generally, becau≈øe the refu≈øal is before him as a Iudge, as al≈øo is Re≈øignation.

div.head:
CCLXXXVII. Sutton and Holloway and Dickons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae by Richard Sutton again≈øt Robert Holloway, and Thomas Dickons, S ‚Ä¢ vil. 99. Owen. 96. Co. 1 In≈øt. 227. a 3 Cro. 77. upon not guilty pleaded, the Iury found this ≈øpecial matter, ≈øcil. That the ≈øaid Thomas Dickins had not any thing in the Lands in que≈øtion at the time of the making of the Lea≈øe, upon which the Action is brought, ≈øcil. Who lea≈øed by Indenture to the Plaintiff for certain years, who entred, and afterwards the ≈øaid Thomas Dickins, contra Indenturam ≈øuam praedictam intravit upon the Plaintiff, and, If the ≈øame ≈øhould be a good Lea≈øe by E≈øtoppel was the que≈øtion; the Iury having found the truth of the matter, ≈øcil. That the Le≈ø≈øor had not any thing at the time of the demi≈øe; Walme≈øley objected, That the Iury ought not to find the Indenture, becau≈øe it was not pleaded, for the Plaintiff doth not declare upon any Indenture;Hob. 227. but the Exception was not allowed, but in old time the Law was ≈øuch, 22 E. 3. but at this day the Law is otherwi≈øe, See Schola≈øtica's Ca≈øe, 14. Eliz. Plowd. 411. But where a Relea≈øe or other writing ought to be pleaded, there it ought to be ≈øhewed to the Court. VValme≈øley, In rei veritate, the Lea≈øe is void, for a man cannot let Land in which he hath not any thing: but in re≈øpect of the parties them≈øelves, the Le≈ø≈øors and Le≈ø≈øee both are concluded to ≈øay, That is no Lea≈øe, for none of them can ≈øay to the contrary: But here the Iury which is a third per≈øon,E≈øtoppel. is not e≈øtopped to ≈øay the truth, but they may find the ≈øpecial matter and the truth of the Ca≈øe, and the E≈øtoppel hath not place there; but the truth of the matter appearing to the Iudges, the Iudges ought to adjudge upon the ≈øame, ≈øcil. If a man may make an effectual lea≈øe of Lands, in which he hath not any thing. At another day it was moved by Shu ‚Ä¢ l. Although that the Iury be not e≈øtopped, yet the parties them≈øelves are e≈øtopped, for the Law makes the E≈øtoppel betwixt the parties, and the Law will not permit a man to ≈øay any thing again≈øt his own Deed being indented, nor any matter contained in it. Periam and Ander≈øon clearly for the Plaintiff, That it is a Lea≈øe by E≈øtoppel; and by Periam, It hath been adjudged in the Kings Bench, That the Iury in ≈øuch ca≈øe are compellable upon pain of Attaint to find the E≈øtoppel: VValme≈øley, Here the E≈øtoppel is out of Doors, for the truth of the matter di≈øclo≈øed by the Verdict, not by the parties only maketh the E≈øtoppel, & he much replied upon the ca≈øe of Littleton, 149. a. A woman ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Fee, taketh a Husband, who alieneth to another in Fee, the Alienee lea≈øeth to the Husband and Wife for their lives, now the Wife is remitted, and ≈øei≈øed in Fee as before, here if the Alienee, i. e. the Le≈ø≈øor, brings an Action of Wa≈øt again≈øt the Husband and Wife, the Husband cannot bar the Plaintiff by the truth of the matter; ≈øcil. the Remitter of his Wife; for he is e≈øtopped to ≈øay again≈øt his own Feoffment, and his retaking of the particular e≈øtate to him≈øelf and his Wife: But if in an Action of Wa≈øt, the Husband make default at the Grand Di≈øtre≈øs, and the Wife prayeth to the received, ≈øhe may well ≈øhew the whole matter: So here the Iury: VVindham, The Plaintiff ought to have demurred upon the Evidence: Periam, What if the Defendant will not joyne with the Plaintiff in the Demurrer? VVindham, there the Court ought to over-rule them, & if
the parties had demurred upon the Evidence, we ≈øhould have adjudged upon that Evidence, that a man cannot lea≈øe lands in which he hath not any thing: And here, the E≈øtoppel could not be pleaded, for the Defendant hath pleaded the general I≈ø≈øue, but if he had pleaded Non demi≈øit, then the E≈øtoppel ≈øhould have holden place.

div.head:
CCLXXXVII. Mills and Snowballs Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: A Iury did ≈øurmi≈øe at the Bar, that he was a Tenant in Ancient deme≈øne, and had his Charter in his hand,Priviledge of Exemption from Juries. 1 Cro. 142. and prayed to be exempted from the Iury and di≈øcharged, but the Court did not regard it, but cau≈øed him to be ≈øworn. And Windham ≈øaid, that he might have his remedy again≈øt the Sheriff; and Nel≈øon Prothonotay ≈øaid, if he had made default and lo≈øt I≈ø≈øues, he might ≈øhew his Charter in the Exchequer upon the Amercement e≈øtreated, and there he ≈øhould be di≈øcharged: In that Ca≈øe, it was holden by the Court, That if a Feoffment be made of a Hou≈øe, and the Deed be delivered in the Hou≈øe without other circum≈øtance, the ≈øame doth not amount to a Livery of ≈øei≈øin, but if he do any act by which the intent of the Feoffor appeareth that the Feoffee ≈øhould have Livery and Sei≈øin;Livery of ≈øei≈øin. as if the parties go of purpo≈øe to the place intended to pa≈øs, to the intent that the Deed may be delivered in that kind, the ≈øame doth amount to a Livery, by Ander≈øon, and the whole Court.

div.head:
CCLXXXVIII. Brad≈øtocks Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: RObert Brad≈øtock ≈øei≈øed in Fee of certain Lands, made a Feoffment in Fee to the u≈øe of him≈øelf in tail,E≈øtates. and for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue to the u≈øe of John Brad≈øtock, his Brother in tail, and for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue to the u≈øe of Henry Brad≈øtock, another Brother in tail,Conditions. Provided always, That if the ≈øaid John or Henry do go about to avoid any e≈øtate or demi≈øe by Copy, made or to be made of the Premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, that then his e≈øtate ≈øhould cea≈øe. Robert died without I≈ø≈øue, John entred and levyed a Fine, Sur conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. of the Land: And the opinion of the whole Court was, That this Fine was not any offence again≈øt the ≈øaid Provi≈øo; for the≈øe words (made or to be made) do not extend to e≈øtates made or limited by the ≈øaid Feoffment, but only to e≈øtates before made, and to be made afterwards.

div.head:
CCLXXXIX. Long and Hemmings Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
IN a Quare Impedit by Long again≈øt Hemming and the Bi≈øhop of Glouce≈øter, or the Church of Frombillet, upon the pleading the I≈ø≈øue was,Quare Impedit. 1 Cro. 209. If Tho. Long Father of the Plaintiff did enfeoff the Plaintiff of the Manor of From. to which the Advow≈øon of the ≈øaid church was appendant before he granted the Advow≈øon to one Strengtham who granted it to the Def. or not. And the Iury gave a ≈øpecial Verdict, ≈øcil. That the Abbot of S. was ≈øei≈øed of a capital Me≈ø≈øuage in Frombillet, & of one hundred
Acres of Land there, And that there was a Tenancy holden of the ≈øaid capital Me≈ø≈øuage by ≈øuch Services, and that the ≈øaid capital Me≈ø≈øuage had been known time out of mind, by the name of the Manor of Frombillet, and that the Advow≈øon was appendant to it, and conveyed the ≈øaid capital Me≈ø≈øuage and Advow≈øon to the King by the di≈ø≈øolution, and from the King, to the ≈øaid Thomas Long, who ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, without any Deed did enfeoff the Plaintiff of the ≈øaid Manor, and made Livery and Sei≈øin upon the Deme≈ønes, And that the ≈øaid Thomas Long by his Deed made a grant of the ≈øaid Advow≈øon, to the ≈øaid Strengham, and afterwards the Free-holder attorned to the Plaintiff: And by the clear opinion of the whole Court, here is a ≈øufficient Manor to which an Advow≈øon may be well appendant, and that in Law the Advow≈øon is appendant to all the Manor, but mo≈øt properly to the Deme≈ønes, out of which at the commencement it was derived, and therefore by the attornment afterwards, within con≈øtruction of the Law ≈øhall have relation to the Livery, the Advow≈øon did pa≈øs included in the Livery: And the grant of the advow≈øon made me≈øne between the Livery and the attornment was void; and afterwards Iudgment was given, and a Writ to the Bi≈øhop granted for the Plaintiff.

div.head: CCXC. Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Ban ‚Ä¢ o.
div.p: Debt. A Made a Bill of Debt to B. for the payment of twenty pounds at four days, ≈øcil. five pounds at every of the ≈øaid four days, and in the end of the Deed, covenanted and granted with B. his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, that if he make default in the payment of any of the ≈øaid payments, that then he will pay the re≈øidue that then ≈øhall be un-paid; and afterwards A. fails in the fir≈øt payment, and before the ≈øecond day B. brought an action of Debt for the whole twenty pounds, It was moved by Puckering Serjeant,S ‚Ä¢ y. 31. 32. 1 Cro. 797. That the Action of Debt did not lye before the la≈øt day encurred; And al≈øo if B. will ≈øue A. before the la≈øt day, that it ought to be by way of covenant, not by Debt: But by the whole Court, the action doth well lye for the manner, for if one covenant to pay me one hundred pounds at ≈øuch a day, an action of Debt lyeth, a fortiori, Owen. 42. 1. 2 Rol. 523. when the words of the Deed are covenant and grant, for the word covenant ≈øometimes ≈øounds in covenant, ≈øometimes in contract, ≈øecundum ≈øubjectum materiae.

div.head:
CCXCI. Lanca≈øters Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
Roll. Tit. Covenant pl. 72.AN Information was again≈øt Lanca≈øter for buying of pretended Rights & Titles upon the Statute of 32 H 8. And upon not guilty pleaded, It was found for the Plaintiff, & it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, becau≈øe the Informer had not pur≈øued the Statute, in this, that it is not ≈øet forth, that the Defendant nor any of his Ance≈øtors, or any by whom he claimed, have taken the profits, &c. and the ≈øame was holden a good, and material Exception by the Court: & although it be layed in the Information, that the Plaint. him≈øelf hath been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land by twenty years before the buying of the pretended Title, for that is but matter of argument, & not any expre≈øs allegation, for in all penal Stat. the Plaintiff ought to pur≈øue the very words of the Stat. and therefore by Ander≈øon, It hath been adjudged by the Iudges of both Benches, that if an Information be exhibited upon the Stat. of V≈øury, by which the Defendant is charged for the taking of twenty pounds for the Loan and forbearing of one hundred pounds for a year, there the Information is not good, if it be not alledged
in it, that the ≈øaid twenty pounds was received by any corrupt or deceitful way or means: And in the principal Ca≈øe, for the Cau≈øe afore≈øaid, Iudgment was arre≈øted.

div.head:
CCXCII. Bag≈øhaw and the Earl of Shrewsburies Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33. Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p: BAg≈øhaw brought a Writ of Annuity again≈øt the Earl of Shrewsbury, for the arrerages of an Annuity of twenty Marks per annum, Annuity. granted by the Defendant to the Plaintiff, Pro Con≈øilio impen≈øo & impendendo, The Defendant pleaded, that before any arrerages incurred, he required the Plaintiff to do him Service, and he refu≈øed: The Plaintiff by replication ≈øaid, that before the refu≈øal, ≈øuch a day and place the Defendant di≈øcharged the Plaintiff of his Service, &c. And the opinion of the Court was, that the Plea in Bar was not good, for he ought to have ≈øhewed for what manner of Service to do, the Plaintiff was ≈øo retained, and for what kind of Service the Annuity was granted; and then to have ≈øhewed ≈øpecially what Service he required of the Plaintiff, and what Service the Plaintiff refu≈øed. Another matter was moved, If the di≈øcharge ≈øhall be peremptory, and an ab≈øolute di≈øcharge of the Service of the Plaintiff, and of his attendance, ≈øo that as afterwards the Defendant cannot require Service of the Plaintiff. And by Walme≈øly Iu≈øtice, it is a peremptory di≈øcharge of the Sevice, for otherwi≈øe how can he be retained with another Ma≈øter; and ≈øo he ≈øhould be out of every Service. VVindham contrary, For here the Plaintiff hath an Annuity for his life, and therefore it is rea≈øon that he continue his Service for his life, as long as the Annuity doth continue, if he requirreth: But where one is retained but for one or two years, then once di≈øcharged, is peremptory and ab≈øolute.

div.head:
CCXCIII. Mathe≈øon and Trots Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32. Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p:
BEtwixt Mathe≈øon and Trot the Ca≈øe was, Sir Anthony Denny ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands in and about the Town of Hertford, 2 Len. 190. holden in Socage, and of divers Mannors, Lands, and Tenements in other places holden in chief by Knights-≈øervice, and having I≈ø≈øue two Sons, Henry and Edward, by his la≈øt Will in writing, devi≈øed the Lands holden in Hertford to Edward Denny his younger Son in Fee,Devi≈øes. and died ≈øei≈øed of all the Premi≈ø≈øes, Henry being then within age: After Office was found without any mention of the ≈øaid Devi≈øe; the Queen ≈øei≈øed the Body of the Heir, and the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all the Lands whereof the ≈øaid Sir Anothony died ≈øei≈øed, and lea≈øed the ≈øame to a ≈øtranger, during the Minority of the Heir; by force and colour of which Lea≈øe the Le≈ø≈øee entred into all the Premi≈ø≈øes, and did enjoy them according to the Demi≈øe. And the Heir at his full age ≈øued Livery of the whole, and before any entry of the ≈øaid Edward in the Land to him devi≈øed, or any entry made by the ≈øaid Henry, the ≈øaid Henry at London, lea≈øed the ≈øaid Lands by Deed indented to I.S. for years, rendring Rent, by colour of which the ≈øaid I.S. entred, and paid the Rent divers years to the ≈øaid Henry: And afterwards by ca≈øualty the ≈øaid Henry walked over the Grounds demi≈øed by him, in the company of the ≈øaid I. S. without any ≈øpecial entry or claim there made, I.S. a≈ø≈øigned his Intere≈øt to I.D. who entred in the Premi≈ø≈øes, and paid the Rent to the ≈øaid Henry, who died, and afterwards the Rent was paid to the Son and Heir of Henry: And after four and twenty years after
the death of the ≈øaid Sir Anthony, the ≈øaid Edward entred into the Land to him devi≈øed by the ≈øaid Devi≈øe; and lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Plaintiff,De≈øcent, where tokes away entire. &c. And it was moved here, if this dying ≈øei≈øed of Henry of the Lands in Hertford, and de≈øcent to his Heir, ≈øhould take away the Entry of Edward the Devi≈øee. And by Ander≈øon cleerly, If here upon the whole matter be a de≈øcent in the Ca≈øe, then the Entry of Edward the Devi≈øee is taken away, although that the Devi≈øee at the time of the de≈øcent had not any Action or other remedy, for it ≈øhall be accounted his folly that he would not enter, and prevent the de≈øcent. But VVindham, Periam, and VValme≈øly Iu≈øtices,2 Len. 147. 1 Cro. 920. 3 Cro. 145. Owen. 96. were of a contrary opinion, For a Devi≈øee by a Devi≈øe hath but a Title of Entry, which ≈øhall not be bound by any De≈øcent, as Entry for Mortmain, for Condition broken. And after long deliberation they all agreed that there was not any De≈øcent in the Ca≈øe, for by the Devi≈øe, and death of the Devi≈øor, the Frank-tenement in Law, and the Fee was ve≈øted in the Devi≈øee Edward: And then when the Queen ≈øei≈øed, and lea≈øed the ≈øame during the Nonage of Henry, and the Le≈ø≈øee entred, he did wrong to Edward, and by his Entry had gained a tortions E≈øtate in fee, although he could not be ≈øaid properly a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, nor an Abator: And afterwards when Henry after his full age, when by his Indenture he lea≈øed without any ≈øpecial Entry, ut ≈øupra, and by colour thereof the Le≈ø≈øee entred, now he is a wrong-doer to Edward the Devi≈øee and by his Entry had gained a wrongful Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in Fee: and then the paying of the Rent to Henry, nor the walking of Henry upon the Land without any ≈øpecial claim, did not gain any Sei≈øin to him: and ≈øo he was never ≈øei≈øed of the Land, and could never dye ≈øei≈øed, and then no De≈øcent; and then the Entry of Edward was lawful, and the Lea≈øe by him made to the Plaintiff was good: And ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCXCIV. Greenwood and Weldens Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p: Replevin.IN a Replevin between Greenwood and VVelden; The Defendant made Conu≈øans as Bayliff to John Cornwallis, & ≈øhewed how that ≈øeven acres of Land called Pilles, is locus in quo: and at the time of the taking were holden of the ≈øaid Cornwallis by certain Rent, and other Services: And for Rent arrear he made Conu≈øans, as Bayliff to Cornwallis. The Plaintiff pleaded out of the Fee of Cornwallis, upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue: And it was found that the Plaintiff is ≈øei≈øed of ≈øeven acres called Pilles, hoden of Cornwallis, ut ≈øupra: But the Iury ≈øay, That locus in quo doth contain two acres, which is called Pilles, and the≈øe two acres are, and then were, holden of Agmonde≈øham of the Middle-Temple: And if upon the whole matter, videbitur Curiae, &c. And by the opinion of the whole Court, out of his Fee upon that matter is not found, for although it be found, that the two acres be holden of Agmonde≈øham, yet it may be that they are within the Fee of Cornwallis, for it may be that Cornwallis is Lord Paramount, and Agmonde≈øham Me≈øne, and then within the Fee of Cornwallis: And therefore for the incertainty of the Verdict, a Venire facias de novo was awarded.

div.head:
CCXCV. Bi≈øhop and Harecourts Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33. Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 210.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, The Plaintiff declared, that the 5 Junij, 30 Eliz. the Defend, (in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff the ≈øame day and year, ≈øold and delivered to the Defend‚ñ™ a Hor≈øe) did promi≈øe to pay the
Plaintiff a hundred pounds in Trinity Term then next en≈øuing, and ≈øhewed that the Term began 7 Junij after: And upon Non a≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, it was found for the Plaintiff. And it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That it appeareth upon the Declaration, that the Plaintiff hath not cau≈øe of Action, for the Trinity Term intended is not yet come, for the day of the A≈ø≈øump≈øit is the fifth of June, and the fourth day was the fir≈øt day of the ≈øaid Term, ≈øcil. the day of E≈ø≈øoins, and the ≈øeventh day 4. die po≈øt, and then the promi≈øe being made at the day afore≈øaid, after the Commencement of the ≈øaid Term, the ≈øame is not the Term intended, but the Plaintiff mu≈øt expect the performance of the promi≈øe until a year after: And of that opinion was Ander≈øon, but the three other Iu≈øtices were ≈øtrongly again≈øt him to the contrary, for by common intendment among≈øt the people, the Term ≈øhall not begin until 4. die po≈øt, and ≈øo it is ≈øet down u≈øually in the Almanack; And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: CCICVI. Mich. 32 & 33. Eliz. In the Common-Bench.
div.p: COoper Serjeant came to the Bar, and ≈øhewed that A. Tenant in tail, the Remainder over to B. in Fee.Co. 2 In≈øt. 483. 484. 1 Cro. 323. 471. 567. Hob. 496. 3 Cro. 224. A. for a great ≈øum of mony ≈øold the Land to I. S. and his Heirs, and for a≈ø≈øurance, made a Feoffment in Fee, and levied a Fine to the ≈øaid I. S. to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid I. S. and his Heirs: And note that by the Indenture of Bargain and Sale, A. covenanted to make ≈øuch further A≈ø≈øurance within ≈øeven days, as the ≈øaid I. S. or his Heirs, or their Council ≈øhould devi≈øe: And ≈øhewed, that before any further a≈ø≈øurance was made, the ≈øaid I. S. died, his Son and Heir being within age: And now by advi≈øe of Council, and of the Friends of the Infant, it was devi≈øed that for ≈øuch further a≈ø≈øurance and cutting off the Remainder, a common Recovery ≈øhould be ≈øuffered, in which the ≈øaid Infant ≈øhould be Tenant to the Praecipe, and ≈øhould vouch the Vendor,Common Recovery ≈øuffered by an Infant by his Guardian. and becau≈øe that the ≈øaid Term of ≈øeven years is almo≈øt expired, and that the ≈øaid Recovery is intended to be unto the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Infant and his Heirs, it was prayed that ≈øuch a Recovery might be received and allowed. And two Pre≈øidents in ≈øuch Ca≈øe were ≈øhewed in the time of this Queen: one the Ca≈øe of the Earl of Shrewsbury, and the other one VVi≈øemans Ca≈øe: But the Iu≈øtices were very doubtful what to do; But at la≈øt upon good a≈ø≈øurance of people of good Credit, that it was unto the u≈øe of the Infant and upon the appearance of a good and ≈øufficient Guardian for the Infant in the Recovery, who was of ability to an≈øwer to the Infant if he ≈øhould be deceived in the pa≈ø≈øing of that Recovery; and upon con≈øideration had of the two Pre≈øidents, and upon Affidavit made by two Witne≈ø≈øes, that the ≈øaid intended Recovery was to the u≈øe of the Infant, the Recovery was received, and allowed.

div.head:
CCICVII. Cottons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p:
IT was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, that Berwich and Te≈ødel ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands, conveyed the ≈øame to Sir Thomas Cotton for life,Fines levied to u≈øe. Co. 2 In≈øt. 519. 1 Cro. 219. the Remainder to VVil. Cotton, & primogenito filio ≈øuo, & haeredi ma≈øculo, & ≈øic de primogenito ad primogenitum dict. VVilliam, the Remainder to the right Heirs of the body of Sir Tho. Cotton, and VVil. Cotton lawfully i≈ø≈øuing, the Remainder to the right Heirs of Sir Tho. Cotton: VVil. had I≈ø≈øue a Son born here in Eng. and went beyond Sea to Antwerp, and there continuing, and his Son being within age in England, Sir Thomas Cotton
levied a Fine of all the Land, ≈øur conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. And afterwards by Indenture convenanted to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of Rober Cotton his Son in Fee: William died at Antwerp, his ≈øaid Son being within age in England, Sir Tho. Cotton died, Robert entred, and lea≈øed the Lands for years to Sary, and the Infant Son and Heir of William lea≈øed the Land to one Chewn at Will, who entred and ou≈øted Sary, who thereupon brought Ejectione firmae. It was here holden by the Court, that Sir Tho. Cotton was Tenant for life the,E≈øtates. Remainder to William for term of his life, the Remainder to the Heirs of both their bodies i≈ø≈øuing: So as unto one Moyety Sir Thomas Cotton had an E≈øtate tail dependant upon the ≈øaid E≈øtates for life; and ≈øo the Fine levied by him was a Bar to the I≈ø≈øue of William for a Moyety. And as to the other Moyety they held that the ≈øaid Fine was not any Bar, but that the party intere≈ø≈øed at the ≈øame time might avoid the Fine at any time during his Nonage, & five years after, for Wil. his Father was not bound by the Statute of 4 H. 7. becau≈øe at the time of the Fine levied, he was beyond the Seas, and although he never returned but died there, yet by the equity of the Statute his I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall have five years after his death to avoid the Fine, if he were of full age, and if he were within age, then during his Nonage, and five years after. At another day the Ca≈øe was argued and put in this manner, viz. Lands were given to Sir Thomas Cotton for life, without Impeachment of Wa≈øt, the Remainder over to Cheny Cotton his elde≈øt Son, & primogenito filio & haeredi Ma≈øculo, of the ≈øaid Cheny, & ≈øic de primogenito filio in primogenitum filium, the Remainder to the Heirs Males of the body of the ≈øaid Cheny, & for want of ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, the Remainder to Wil. Cotton his ≈øecond Son, & primogenito filio, in primogenitum filium, the Remainder over to the ≈øaid Sir Thomas, and the ≈øaid William, and the Heirs Males of their bodies lawfully begotten. Cheny Cotton died without I≈ø≈øue, William having I≈ø≈øue, went beyond the Sea, Sir Thomas Cotton, 19 Eliz. levied a Fine with Proclamation, and afterwards William the Father died in Antwerp, his Son being within age, Sir Thomas by Indenture limited the u≈øe of the Fine to him≈øelf for life, the Remainder over to Robert Cotton his third Son in Tail, Sir Thomas died (but it doth not appear at what time) William the Son being yet within age entred (but non con≈øtat quando) and 31 Eliz. lea≈øed the Lands to the Defendant at Will. Drue Serjeant argued for William Cotton. And he conceived, that William the Father had an E≈øtate-tail, and then the entry of William the Son was congeable for the whole: But admitting that it is not an E≈øtate-tail in VVilliam the Father for the whole, yet he hath by the ≈øecond Remainder an E≈øtate-tail in the Moyety, and then his Entry good as to one Moyety; and then Robert being Tenant in Common of the other Moyety,Tails. his Le≈ø≈øee without an actual Ou≈øter cannot maintain an Ejectionae firmae again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øee of his Companion. And he conceived here is a good E≈øtate-tail in VVilliam Cotton by virtue of the Limitation to William, & primogenito filio & haeredi Ma≈øculo ip≈øius Guliel. & ≈øic de primogenito filio in primogenitum filium, &c. for according to the Statute of VVe≈øt. 2. the will of the Donor ought to be ob≈øerved, and here it appeareth that the intent of the Donor was to create an E≈øtate-tail, although the words of the Limitation do not amount to ≈øo much. And the E≈øtates mentioned in the Statute afore≈øaid, are not Rules for Entails, but only Examples, as it is ≈øaid by Trew, 33 E. 3 F. Tail 5. & ≈øee Robeiges Ca≈øe, 2 E. 2. 1 Fitz. Tail: and 5 H. 5. 6. Land given to A. and B. uxori ejus, & haeredibus eorum & aliis haeredibus dicti A. ≈øi dict. haeredes de dictis A. & B. exeuntes obierint ≈øine haeredibus de ≈øe, &c. and that was holden a good Entail; ≈øo a gift to one and his Heirs, ≈øi haeredes de carne ≈øua habuerit, & ≈øi nullos de carne ≈øua habuerit revertatur terra, and adjudged a good tail: So 39 E. 3. 20. Land given to Husband and Wife, & uni haeredi de corpore ≈øuo ligitime procreat. & uni haeredi ip≈øius haeredis tantum, And that was holden
a good Tail; and ≈øo he conceived in this Ca≈øe, that although the words of the Limitation are not apt to create an E≈øtate-tail according to the phra≈øe and ≈øtile of the ≈øaid Statute of VVe≈øt 2. yet here the intent of the Donor appears to continue the Land in his Name and Blood, for VVilliam the Son could not take with his Father by his Limitation, for he was not in rerum natura, and therefore all ≈øhall ve≈øt in VVilliam the Father, which ≈øee 18 E. 3 Fitz. Feoffments & Fait. 60. Now it is to ≈øee, if upon the Limitation to Sir Thomas Cotton and VVilliam his Son, by which the Remainder is limited to Sir Thomas Cotton and VVilliam, and the Heirs Males of their bodies i≈ø≈øuing, the ≈øaid Sir Thomas Cotton & Wil. have a joynt E≈øtate-tail; in re≈øpect that the I≈ø≈øue of the body of the Son, may be Heir of the Body of the Father: and ≈øo becau≈øe they might have one Heir which ≈øhall be inheritable to his Land, it ≈øhall be one entire E≈øtate-tail in them: But he conceived that they are ≈øeveral E≈øtates-tail, and that they are Tenants in Common of an E≈øtate tail, 3 & 4 Phil. & Mar. Dyer 145. Land given to the Father and Son, and to the Heirs of their two Bodies begotten, the Remainder over in Fee, the Father dieth without other I≈ø≈øue than the Son only, and afterwards the Son dieth withou I≈ø≈øue, a ≈øtranger abates: Or if the Son hath made a Di≈øcontinuance, if he in the Remainder ≈øhall have but one or two ≈øeveral Formedons was the Que≈øtion. And by Saunders, Brook, and Brown, but one Formedon, and Quaere left of it; yet admitting that, yet notwith≈øtanding that, it might be that they had ≈øeveral E≈øtates-tail, 17 E. 3. 51. 78. Land given to a man and his Si≈øter, and to the Heirs of their two Bodies i≈ø≈øuing, they have ≈øeveral E≈øtates tail, and yet one Formedon. And ≈øee 7 H. 4. 85. Land given to a man and his Mother, or to her Daughter in Tail, here are ≈øeveral Entails And here in the principal Ca≈øe, Sir Thomas Cotton hath one Moyety in Tail expectant upon his E≈øtate for life: and therefore as to the Moyety of Sir Thomas Cotton he is bound by the Fine. And the other Moyety is left in the Son, who may enter for a Forfeiture upon the alienation made by his Father, as well in the life of the Father, as afterwards. Now after this Fine levied, the entry of VVilliam the Son by virtue of his Remainder is lawful after the death of Sir Thomas, although that VVilliam the Father was beyond the Sea at the time of the Fine levied, and there afterwards died, VVilliam the Son being within age. The words of the Statute of 4 H. 7. are, Other than Women Covert, or out of this Realm, &c. ≈øo that they or their Heirs make their Entry, &c. within five years after they return into this Land, &c. So that by the bare letter of the Act, VVill. the Son hath not remedy, nor relief by this Act again≈øt the Fine, becau≈øe that William, the Father died beyond the Sea, without any return into England; yet by the Equity of the Statute he ≈øhall have five years to make his Claim, although his Father never return, for if ≈øuch literal con≈øtruction ≈øhould be allowed, it ≈øhould be a great mi≈øchief, and it ≈øhould be a hard Expo≈øition, for this Statute ought to be taken by Equity, as it appeareth by diver≈øe Ca≈øes, 19 H. 8. 6. My Vncle doth di≈ø≈øei≈øe my Father, and afterwards levies a Fine with Proclamations; my Father dieth, and after within five years my Vncle dies, that Fine is no Bar to me, yet the Exception doth not help me, for I am Heir to him that levied the Fine, and ≈øo privy to it, but my Title to the Land, is not as Heir to my Vncle but to my Father: So if an Infant after ≈øuch a Fine levied, dieth before his full age, his Heir may enter within five years after, and yet that Ca≈øe is out of the Letter of the Statute. And by Brown and Sanders, If the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee dieth, his Wife en≈øeint with a Son, the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor levieth a Fine, the Son is born, although this Son is not excepted expre≈ø≈øly by the words, becau≈øe not in rerum natura at the time of the Fine levied, &c. yet ≈øuch an Infant is within the equity and meaning of the ≈øaid Statute. See the Ca≈øe betwixt Stowel and Zouch, Plow. Com. 366. And by him,
It was holden, 6. Eliz. that an Infant brought a Formdon within age, and adjudged maintainable, although the words of the Statute be, That they ≈øhall take their Actions or lawful Entries within five years after they come of full age: And he al≈øo argued, that here, when Sir Thomas being Tenant for life, levyed a Fine, which is a Forfeiture, he in the Remainder is to have five years after the Fine levyed, in re≈øpect of the pre≈øent forfeiture, and al≈øo five years after the death of the Tenant for life: And that was the ca≈øe of one Some adjudged accordingly in the Common Pleas: It hath been objected on the other ≈øide, That the Defendant entring by color of the Lea≈øe at Will made to him by William who was an Infant, that he was a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor as well to the Infant as to the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, who had the Moyety as Tenant in common with the Infant, and then when the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff entred upon the Defendant, and lea≈øed to the Plaintiff, and the Defendant enentred and ejected the Plaintiff, he is a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor; to which he an≈øwered, That the Defendant when he entred by the Lea≈øe at Will, he was no Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, for ≈øuch a Lea≈øe of an Infant is not void, but only voidable, &c. and then a ≈øufficient Lea≈øe again≈øt the Plaintiff, although not again≈øt the Infant. Beaumont Serjeant, to the contrary; By this manner of gift, William the Son took nothing, but the e≈øtate ≈øetled only in William the Father, but not an e≈øtate tail, by the words, haeredi ma≈øculo, &c. And voluntas Donatoris, without ≈øufficient words cannot create an e≈øtate tail; but where the intent of the Donor is not according to the Law, the Law ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued according to his intent: But this intent ≈øhall be taken according to the Law. And he held that Sir Thomas and VVilliam had ≈øeveral e≈øtates in tail, and ≈øeveral Moyeties, and not one entire e≈øtate, and here, upon all the matter, Sir Thomas is Tenant for life of the whole, the Remainder of one moyety to him in tail, the Remainder of the other moyety unto VVilliam in tail, and, rebus ≈øic ≈øtantibus, Sir Thomas levying a Fine of the whole, now as to one moyety which the Conu≈øor had in tail, the Fine is clearly good, and ≈øo as to that, Robert the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff had a good Title, as to the ≈øaid moyety; and as to the other moyety he conceived al≈øo, that VVilliam is bound, for this Statute ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued by Equity, but ≈øhall bind all who are expre≈øly excepted, and that is not VVilliam the Son, for his Father never returned, and then his Heir is not releived by the Statute ‚Ä¢ Al≈øo VVilliam had a Right of Entry at the time of the Fine levyed, ≈øcil. for the Forfeiture, and becau≈øe he hath ≈øurcea≈øed the time, for the ≈øaid Right of Entry, he ≈øhall not have now five years after the death of Tenant for life, for he is the ≈øame per≈øon, and the ≈øecond ≈øaving which provides forfuture Rights, extends to other per≈øons than tho≈øe who are intended in the fir≈øt ≈øaving, and he who may take advantage of the fir≈øt ≈øaving, cannot be releived by the ≈øecond ≈øaving, for no new title doth accrue to him in the Rever≈øion or Remainder, by the death of Tenant for life, for that title accrued to him by the forfeiture, ≈øo as the title which he hath by the death of the Tenant for life, is not the title which fir≈øt accrued unto him: Al≈øo by this Forfeiture, the e≈øtate for life is determined, as if Tenant for life had been dead; for if Tenant for life maketh a Feoffment in Fee, the Le≈ø≈øor may have a Writ of Entry ad terminum qui praeterijt. Fitz. 201. which proves, that by the Forfeiture the e≈øtate is determined, and then no new title doth accrue to him in the Remainder, by the death of the Tenant for life, but that only which he had before the alienation, ≈øo that his non-claim after the five years ≈øhall bind him. Then, when VVilliam the Infant having a Right to a moyety, and Robert the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff a Right to the other moyety, and the Infant lea≈øeth unto the Defendant at Will, who entreth, now is he a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor as well to Robert as to the Infant: Then if the Defendant be Di≈ø≈øei≈øor and hath no title by the Infant, Robert who hath Right in a moyety may well enter into the whole, for he hath the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion per my & per
tout by his Entry, and then when the Defendant doth eject him, he hath good cau≈øe of Action. And after at another day the Ca≈øe was moved, and it was agreed, That for one moyety the Infant is bound, for Sir Thomas had an e≈øtate tail in a moyety, for he was I≈ø≈øue of the body of the Comi≈øor: But for the other moyety, the Fine levyed by Tenant for life, William the Father being then Tenant beyond the Sea, It was holden by Ander≈øon, Windham, and Walme≈øly, that the Infant was not barred, notwith≈øtanding the objection above≈øaid, That William the Father never returned into England, and notwith≈øtanding the words of the Statute of 4 H. 7. And by Walme≈øley, If an infant make his claim within age it is ≈øufficient to avoid the Fine, and yet the ≈øaid Statute ≈øeems to appoint to him time within five years after his full age, ≈øo that according to the very words, a claim made before or after ≈øhould be vain, yet in Equity, although he be not compel≈øable to make his claim until the time allowed by the Statute, yet if he make it before, it is good enough. And by Ander≈øon, Although that VVilliam the Father did not return, yet if he makes not his claim within five years after the death of his Father being of full age, and without any impediment, &c. he ≈øhall be barred. If in ≈øuch ca≈øe a man hath many impediments, he is not compellable to make his claim when one of the impediments is removed, but when they are all removed. So if the Ance≈øtor hath one of the ≈øaid impediments, and dieth before it be removed, and his Heir is within age, or hath other impediment, he is not bound to make is claim till five years after his impediment is removed. And Somes ca≈øe cited before was holden and agreed to be good Law, for the Forfeiture may not be known unto him. And as to the objection again≈øt the Lea≈øe at Will, becau≈øe it was made by an Infant, and no Rent re≈øerved upon it, nor the Lea≈øe made upon the Land, and therefore the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould be a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, To that it was an≈øwered, Be the Defendant a Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, or not, it is not material here, for if the Plaintiff had not title according to his Declaration, he cannot recover,1 Cro. 220. 1 Cro. 438. whether the Defendant hath title or not, for it is not like unto Tre≈øpa≈øs where the very po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion without other title is good, contrary in Actions again≈øt all who gave not title; but in Ejectione firmae, if the title of the Plaintiff be not good and ≈øufficient, be the title of the Defendant good or not, he ≈øhall not recover: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Defendant, Hill. 33. Eliz.

div.head:
CCXCVIII. Cheny and Smiths Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae by Cheny and his Wife again≈øt Smith: The Plaintiffs declared upon a Lea≈øe made by the Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øe or Colledge of S. Thomas of Acons in London to I.S. who a≈ø≈øigned it over to Knevit, who by his Will devi≈øed the ≈øame to his Wife, whom he made al≈øo his Executrix, and dyed, and afterwards ≈øhe took to Husband one VVaters, and died; VVaters took Letters of Admini≈øtration of the Goods and Chattells of his Wife, and afterwards lea≈øed to the Plaintiffs: And upon not guilty they were at I≈ø≈øue. And it was given in Evidence That the Lea≈øe given in Evidence, was not the Lea≈øe whereof the Plaintiffs have declared, for the ori ‚Ä¢ inal Lea≈øe ≈øhewed in Court, is, Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øe, or Ho≈øpital, where the Lea≈øe ≈øpecified in the Declaration is, Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øe or Colledge, 38 E. 3. 28. And ≈øome of the Iu≈øtices conceived that there is not any material Variance (but if the parties would, it might be found by ≈øpecial Verdict) For by them Colledge and Ho≈øpital are all one. And afterwards the Court moved the Plaintiffs to prove if the wife were in as Executrix, or as Legatee,
for by Ander≈øon, and Periam, until election be made he ≈øhall not be ≈øaid to have it as Legatee, e≈øpecially if it be not alledged in fact, that all the debts of the Te≈øtator are paid: And Ander≈øon doubted, although that it be alledged, that the debts be paid, If the Executor ≈øhall be ≈øaid to have the ≈øaid Lea≈øe as a Legacy, before ≈øhe hath made Election, vid. Weldens Ca≈øe, and Paramours Ca≈øe in Plowd. And afterwards it was given in Evidence, That the wife after the death of the Husband had repaired the Banks of the Land, and produced Witne≈ø≈øes to prove it, as if the ≈øame ≈øhould amount to claim it as a Legacy; and the Court ≈øaid, that that matter ≈øhould de referred to the Iury:1 Roll. 620. And it was further ≈øhewed in Evidence, that the ≈øaid Wife Executrix, and her ≈øaid Husband Waters formerly made a Lea≈øe by Deed, reciting thereby, that where the Husband was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in the right of his ≈øaid Wife as Executrix of her fir≈øt Husband, &c. And by the opinion of the whole Court, the ≈øame was an expre≈øs claim as Executrix; and then when the Wife died, if the Husband would have advantage of it, he ought to take Letters of Admini≈øtration of the Goods of her fir≈øt Husband, and not of the Wife; but if ≈øhe had claimed the Land and the Term in it as Legatee, and had not been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, Admini≈øtration taken of the Rights and Debts of the Wife, had been good as to that intent, that his Wife was not actually po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of it, but only had a Right unto it, and of ≈øuch things in Action, the Husband might be Executor or Admini≈øtrator to his Wife, but here they have failed of their title: The Admini≈øtration being taken of the goods of the Wife, where it ≈øhould be of the Goods of the Te≈øtator the fir≈øt Husband; And for this cau≈øe the Plaintiffs were non-≈øuit, and the Iury di≈øcharged. And it was agreed by all the Iu≈øtices, that if the Wife before Election had taken Husband, that the Husband might have made the Election in the Ca≈øe afore≈øaid.

div.head:
CCXCIX. The Lord Cobham and Browns Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p:
THe Ca≈øe between the Lord Cobham and Brown, was, that the Abbot of Grace was ≈øei≈øed of the Mannor of Grave≈øend in the County of Kent, which Mannor doth extend to the Pari≈øhes of Grave≈øend, and Milton, and that the ≈øaid Abbot and all his Predece≈ø≈øors, &c. time out of mind, &c. have had a Water-Court within the ≈øaid Mannor, which Court had been holden at Grave≈øend Bridge in the end of it, and that all the Inhabitants within the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes, which have Boats either entirely or joyntly with others, and have u≈øed to tran≈øport or carry pa≈ø≈øengers from Grave≈øend to London, & e contra, and have u≈øed to fa≈øten their Boats at the ≈øaid Bridge of Grave≈øend, have u≈øed to do ≈øuit at the ≈øaid Court, and there have u≈øed to enquire of all mi≈ø-orders, and mi≈ø-demeanors of Water-men there, and that the ≈øaid Abbots, &c. have u≈øed to have the Fines and Amercements of the ≈øame Court, and conveyed the ≈øaid Mannor to the Plaintiff, and that at a Court there holden, The Defendant being ≈øworn with the re≈øidue of the Enque≈øt to enquire of ≈øuch di≈ø-orders, refu≈øed to give his Verdict, for which for the ≈øaid contempt, the Defendant, by the then Steward was amerced twenty ≈øhillings, for the which Amercement the Plaintiff brought an Action of Debt: It was moved by Beaumount Serjeant; That the Action did not lye, for the Pre≈øcription upon which the Action is grounded is not good; fir≈øt, he claims to have this Court within his Mannor, and as a thing appertaining to it, and yet he claims ≈øuit at his Court of all the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid two Pari≈øhes, & to have them Suitors at it, being meer ≈øtrangers to the Mannor, & which do not hold of it, for although it be alledged, that the ≈øaid Mannor doth extend
in the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes, yet the ≈øame doth not prove that every part of the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes is within the ≈øaid Manor, and if it be not ≈øo, the Pre≈øcription may extend as well to all the County of Kent, as well as to the ≈øaid two Pari≈øhes, for ≈øuch a Pre≈øcription cannot bind but tho≈øe which are Tenants of the ≈øaid Manor, and cannot extend to ≈øtrangers, which ≈øee 21 H. 7. 40. The Ca≈øe of Pound-breach. Secondly, it is not alleadged here, that the Steward ought and had u≈øed to a≈ø≈øe≈øs Amercements, for by the common Law no Steward hath authority to a≈ø≈øe≈øs Amercements or Fines in a Court Baron, for there the Suitors are Iudges & not the Steward; & that this Water-Court is a Court Baron, it appeareth by the Declaration, for there it is ≈øaid that it is a Court belonging to ≈øuch a Manor, and that prima facie ≈øhall be meant a Court Baron, if the contrary be not ≈øhewed, vi. Fitz. 75. g. Thirdly it is not ≈øhewed that the Amercement was affered, which ≈øee ib. 75. Harris Serjeant, to the contrary: This Court upon the whole matter is in nature of a Leet for the reformation of mi≈ø-orders between the Watermen, and the pre≈øcription here will warrant ≈øuch a Court well enough, And there are many Courts in England which are not Court Barons, but grounded upon Pre≈øcription, 40 E. 3. 17. The Court before the Chancellor of Oxford, Pre≈øcription to have Swan mote, and it is rea≈øon that this Pre≈øcription ≈øhould hold place, for here is quid pro quo, for Watermen receive their carriage and loading at this Bridge, and al≈øo di≈øcharge their loading there, and they u≈øe to fa≈øten their Boats there, and therefore in lieu of that benefit, it is rea≈øon that they be attendant at the Court which is upon the ≈øaid Bridge, and upon that rea≈øon is the Pre≈øcription of Toll Traver≈øe, 5 H. 7. 9. And to have a Land Bird, 2 R. 3. 15. And Toll of every Ve≈ø≈øel which pa≈ø≈øeth the River, 21 H. 7. 16.
