And this Court may be a Court within the Manor, and yet no Court Baron, but in the nature of a Leet, and the Pre≈øcription ≈øhall be good in Law by rea≈øon of the recompence to the Suitors, and then, if it be not a Court Baron, but rather in the nature of a Leet, then it follows, that the Suitors are not Iudges but the Steward; and it behoves not to pre≈øcribe for the Amercement, for that is incident to a Court Leet, for otherwi≈øe how can the Suitors be compelled to do their ≈øuit at it, or their defaults, or contempts at the ≈øame be puni≈øhed? and as to the affering of the Amercement, it needs not here, for it is a Fine for the open contempt, and de≈øpite done unto the Court, and not an Amercement, and it may well be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Steward alone, vi. 23 H. 8. Br. Leet, 37. Drill Serjeant, to the contrary: For this Pre≈øcription is not rea≈øonable, to drive ≈øtrangers to do ≈øuit at a Court Baron, for there is ≈øufficient con≈øideration in the Ca≈øe of Tenants of the Manor; for it may be at the beginning, the Tenancies were given upon ≈øuch con≈øideration to do ≈øuch ≈øuit: But in the principal ca≈øe, the Pre≈øcription is their ground, and therefore unrea≈øonable, becau≈øe without con≈øideration, 22 E. 4. 43. ≈øee the ca≈øe there, and 21 H. 7. 20. A cu≈øtom alleadged, that if any Tenant di≈øtrain the Bea≈øts of another Damage Fea≈øant, That he ought to bring ≈øuch Bea≈øts to the pound of the Lord of the Manor; and if not, That at the next Court he ≈øhould be amerced twelve pence, and the ≈øame was holden no good cu≈øtom, becau≈øe again≈øt common Right and common Law. Puckering Serjeant: If this Court ≈øhall be reputed in Law a Court Baron, then the Pre≈øcription, for the maner of it is not good, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe, the Amercement cannot be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Steward; But he held, that this Court is in the nature of a Court Leet, and not a Court Baron, and all Inhabitants within the Precinct of it, are bounden to do their ≈øuit at it by rea≈øon of their Re≈øiancy, & their trade there, if they have Boats, or ≈øhares in Boats, and ≈øuch Court is for the better government of ≈øuch Watermen, and the exerci≈øe and practi≈øe of their trade, and for the redre≈ø≈øing of mi≈ødemeanors betwixt them, and ≈øo this Court hath a rea≈øonable commencement, being
in≈øtituted for the publick good, and if cu≈øtoms which concern the private benefit of any be allowable; as the Mayor and Burge≈ø≈øes of a Town pre≈øcribe to have of every Tun which cometh in any Ship into their Port, and put upon the Land 6.d. for Toll. See 21 H. 16. A fortiori, a Cu≈øtom or Pre≈øcription which concerns the publick good, is good: & it is not ≈øtrange that ≈øuch Court hath been maintained by Pre≈øcription, for the Court of Stanneris is ≈øo without any commencement or erection, but by Cu≈øtom. And although that Toll cannot be paid at any Market for things brought to Market, but for things ≈øold, yet by cu≈øtom Toll ≈øhall be paid for every thing brought to Market, and for the ≈øtanding of the Seller there; for the ≈øale of Victuals is for the good of the Commonwealth, which thing is the ground of the Pre≈øcription in the principal Ca≈øe, & therefore the Pre≈øcription in the manner of it is good: and if the pre≈øcription be good for the Court, then to have a Steward to keep the Court, to a≈ø≈øe≈øs Fines for contempts and di≈øorders is good without any ≈øpecial pre≈øcription, for it is incident to it. Periam Iu≈øtice, If it be a Court-baron then cannot the Steward impo≈øe or a≈ø≈øe≈øs any Fine: which Windham granted; but he ≈øaid it is not a Court-baron, but a Court by pre≈øcription. Periam, If the Plaintiff claim it as belonging to his Manor, it ≈øhall be intended a Court-baron, but yet a man may have a Court within his Manor by pre≈øcription, which is not a Court-baron. Ander≈øon was of opinion that it is not a Court-baron, for although it be appertaining to the Manor, yet that is not any proof that it is a Court-baron: For a Leet may be appertaining to a Manor. It was adjourned.

div.head:
CCC. Green and Edwards Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
1 Cro. 216. 217.BEtween Green and Edwards the Ca≈øe was this, Land is demi≈øed to A. for nine years, if he ≈øhall ≈øo long live, and if he die within the Term, that B. his Wife ≈øhall have it durante toto re≈øiduo termini praedict. The Hu≈øband dieth during the Term: If the Wife ≈øhall have the re≈øidue of the Term was the Que≈øtion. And by Periam & Walme≈øly Iu≈øtices, by the death of the Husband the Term is determined, & thereupon nothing can remain, e≈øpecially by way of grant, but by way of Devi≈øe it might be. See 9 Eliz. 253. A Lea≈øe for forty years to A. if he ≈øhall live ≈øo long, and if he die within the Term, that E. his Wife ≈øhall have the re≈øidue of the years: Where it was holden, that by the death of A. the Term is determined, and then there is no re≈øidue, and ≈øo the Limitation is void, vide 3 & 4 Phil. & Mar. 150. Ander≈øon, If the Husband and Wife had been parties to the Deed of Demi≈øe, then the re≈øidue of the Term ≈øhould go to the Wife after the death of the Husband: and this word (Terminum) ≈øhall not be taken for the Intere≈øt which is given to the Husband, but for the time, ≈øo it is as much as to ≈øay, that if the Husband die before forty years expired, that then his Wife ≈øhall have the re≈øidue for forty years; and it is rea≈øon to make ≈øuch con≈øtruction rather than to con≈øtrue the ≈øaid part of the Deed to be void: For if in the con≈øtruction of this Grant, the Term ≈øhall be taken for the Intere≈øt, then the Limitation ≈øhall be void. And in all Grants, the Deeds ≈øhall be taken mo≈øt beneficially for the Grantee, and mo≈øt ≈øtrongly again≈øt the Grantor, e≈øpecially ut res magis valeat quam pereat: And here are ≈øeveral Grants and ≈øeveral Terms: But if ≈øuch matter be limited to the Wife not named in the Deed, all is void, for it is incertain when the Term ≈øhall begin, & it cannot ve≈øt during the particular E≈øtate, and it is not certain, whether the Husband ≈øhall ≈øurvive the Term, or not. And by Walme≈øly & Windham the ≈øaid Limitation is meerly void: As if a Termer grants all his Term for ≈øo many years as ≈øhall be behind after his death, the ≈øame is a void Grant, for the Le≈ø≈øee may over-live all the Term, and then
it is incertain when it ≈øhall begin: And in this Ca≈øe this word, Term, ≈øhall be taken for the Intere≈øt, and not for time, vide 35 H. 8. Br. Conditions 203. vide Co. 1. part, in the Rector of Chedingtons Ca≈øe, this Ca≈øe vouched.

div.head:
CCCI. Gawton and the Lord Dacres Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p:
IN Debt upon Surplu≈øage of an Accompt by Gawton, again≈øt George Lord Dacres; It was ≈øaid by Periam Iu≈øtice, and not denied by any, that if I make J. S. my Auditor, generally to take Accompts of all my Bayliffs and Receivors, that he is not a ≈øufficient Auditor without a Patent; for when a man is made an Auditor generally, he is an Officer, and an Officer cannot be without a Deed. But if a Bayliff, or Receiver be accomptable to me, it is as cleer on the other ≈øide, that I may appoint one to be my Auditor to take the accompt of him, pro hac vice by word; which Ander≈øon granted: But if he afterwards takes an accompt of any by force or colour of the ≈øaid Warrant without my Commandment, he is not a ≈øufficient Auditor to ≈øuch intent, either to take the accompt, or to a≈ø≈øe≈øs the arrerages if the accomptant be found in arrear, or to make allowance if he be found in Surplu≈øage: And by him. If one become my Bayliff of his own wrong, without my appointment, he is accomptable to me, but I am not compellable to make him any allowance for his Expences about my bu≈øine≈øs. And if I a≈ø≈øign to ≈øuch Bayliff of his own wrong an Auditor, he cannot make allowance of ≈øuch Expences. Ander≈øon, If my Auditor make allowance to my Bayliff for any collateral Expences, which he hath expended in my affairs, which do not concern my Manor, whereof he is Bayliff, ≈øuch allowance ≈øhall not bind me. And note, that in this Action the Plaintiff declared that he was Bayliff to the Defendant of certain Manors, Receiver of certain monies, and ≈øo retained, ad diver≈øa negotia procurandum: And upon accompt the allowance was made unto him for his Board-wages, and other Expences in riding Circa negotia. And by Ander≈øon, 3 Len. 149. the≈øe allowances ≈øhall not bind the Defendant; for as Bayliff of a Manor, no Expences ≈øhall be allowed unto him, but tho≈øe which the Bayliff hath expended within the Manor: And if I retain one to go about my bu≈øine≈øs he is not accomptable. Windham, If I retain one to follow my bu≈øine≈øs, and deliver to him mony to disbur≈øe in ≈øuch bu≈øine≈øs, he is accomptable. Ander≈øon, It is ≈øo truly, but it is not in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid Retainer,Devi≈øes. but as he was Receiver, and if he expend more than he hath received, he doth it without Warrant and no allowance ≈øhall be made unto him. If the Bayliff be found in Surplu≈øage in the conclu≈øion of the accompt, the Auditor ought to enter. Allocatur ≈øuper determinationem Compt. in ≈øurplu≈øagiis, ≈øo much for ≈øuch and ≈øuch Expences, allocatis allocandis upon the next accompt: But in this Ca≈øe it appeared upon the Evidence, that the Entry upon the foot of the accompt was, And ≈øo he is in Surplu≈øage upon the determination of this accompt twenty ≈øix pounds: But the Auditor being examined, ≈øaid, that it was not his meaning to allow unto him ≈øo much, but only to find and expre≈øs the certainty of the whole accompt, and ≈øo refer the allowance of it to the Defendant to whom he was Auditor: and upon that the Court ≈øaid to the Iury, if they believed the Auditor, that they ≈øhould find again≈øt the Plaintiff, for upon the matter here is not any accompt, and ≈øo no allowance; for the allowance if it had been according to Law ought to be entred, before Allocatur, &c. and ≈øuch allowance is as a Iudgment, but here is not any allowance, for the Auditor did refer the ≈øame to the Defendant: But if the Iury doth not give credit to the Auditor, then the Court moved the Iury to find
it ≈øpecially that the party was Auditor without Deed, and the finding of the accompt as it is ≈øet down in the Declaration, and the manner of the conclu≈øion of it. viz. That the Plaintiff was in Surplu≈øage upon the determination of the accompt for his Expences in riding Circa negotia defendentis, and for his Board-wages twenty ≈øix pounds.

div.head:
CCCII. Chamberlayns Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p: IN this Ca≈øe it was moved, whether Bea≈øts taken in Withernam, might be u≈øed and worked by the party as his proper Bea≈øts:Owen. Rep. 124. 2 Cro. 148. And it was ≈øaid by the Court, that Bea≈øts di≈øtrained, as Cows, could not be milked, nor Hor≈øes wrought, but they ought to be put in the Pound open, and there the Owner might milk them and fodder them. But if Cows be taken in Withernam, becau≈øe they are delivered to the party in lieu of his own Cattel,Cattel taken in Withernam, worked. 3 Leu. 235. 236. he may milk them, or if they be Oxen, or Hor≈øes, rea≈øonably work them, otherwi≈øe he ≈øhould be at great charges of keeping and pa≈øturing of them, and no profit, or con≈øideration for it. Ander≈øon, It ≈øhould be a great inconvenience to the Common-wealth: For if the Cows are not milked, the milk is lo≈øt, and al≈øo the Cows impaired thereby.

div.head:
CCCIII. Byne and Playnes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Common Bench.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 218.IN an action upon the ca≈øe by Byne again≈øt Playne, the Plaintiff declared, that whereas he him≈øelf had recovered again≈øt Thomas Ward in the Court of the Queen in Southwark, holden before Ome≈øley Steward there for the Mayor of London, the ≈øum of twenty pounds, and had obtained out of the ≈øaid Court a Levari facias directed to the Bayliff to do execution upon the Goods of the ≈øaid Thomas Ward, which then were in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Plaintiff; and where the ≈øaid Bayliff by vertue of the ≈øaid Writ was ready to have done execution of the ≈øaid Goods, the Defendant came to the now Plaintiff, and a≈ø≈øumed to him, that in con≈øideration that the ≈øaid Plaintiff would deliver to the Defendant the ≈øaid Goods, that he would in fourteen days after Michaelmas next pay to the Plaintiff twenty pounds, or otherwi≈øe deliver to him the ≈øaid Goods again, if in the mean time no other makes Title unto them, and prove them to be his own Goods. And further, that the Plaintiff ≈øhall have free ingre≈øs and regre≈øs to a Chamber in the hou≈øe of the Defendant in the mean time. And upon Non-a≈ø≈øump≈øit pleaded, it was found by the Iury, that ≈øuch a Recovery was in the ≈øaid Court, and that the Defendant did a≈ø≈øume, &c. But they further ≈øay, that before the ≈øaid Recovery, the ≈øaid Thomas Ward was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid Goods as of his own proper goods: And, by Deed indented, ≈øold them to his Brother R. W. in con≈øideration of a certain ≈øum of mony, with a Provi≈øo, that the ≈øaid Tho. Ward, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid ≈øale ≈øhould have the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them for four years, which are not yet expired, paying to the ≈øaid R. VVard twenty ≈øhillings by the year, and if, at the end of the ≈øaid four years, the ≈øaid Thomas did repay the ≈øaid ≈øum of mony to the ≈øaid R. VVard, that then the ≈øaid ≈øale ≈øhould be void. And they further ≈øay, that the ≈øaid Robert VVard made Title to the ≈øaid goods by vertue of the ≈øaid ≈øale. Exception was taken to the Declaration, becau≈øe it was not ≈øhewed by what Authority or Title the Court was holden; Al≈øo it ≈øheweth, that the Bayliff was ready to do Execution upon the ≈øaid Goods, but doth
not ≈øhew where the ≈øaid goods then were, but the exceptions were not allowed, for the≈øe matters are but inducement and conveyance to the action, and not the matter, or ≈øub≈øtance of it. Another exception was taken, becau≈øe the reque≈øt is not ≈øufficiently alleadged, Licet ≈øaepius requi≈øitus, but that exception was not allowed, for here the A≈ø≈øump≈øit is to pay at a certain day, and then the reque≈øt is not material; but where a Reque≈øt is parcel of the A≈ø≈øump≈øit,Reque≈øt. there an expre≈øs Reque≈øt ought to be taxed, as if the payment ≈øhould be upon Reque≈øt. As to the matter in Law, here is not any con≈øideration, for the goods were not ≈øubject to execution, for Thomas Ward had but a ≈øpecial property in them, but the general property was in R. VVard, and ≈øo no cau≈øe to deliver them back to the Plaintiff; and here by the Verdict the forain title is proved; for proof ought to be by Verdict, which ≈øee Perk. 154. a. & 7. R. 2. Tit. Bar. 241. For it appeareth, before the ≈øaid Recovery, Thomas ≈øold the goods with promi≈øe, ut ≈øupra. Owen, Although it be found that R. VVard had the general property, yet Thomas had the ≈øpecial and pre≈øent property, and that again≈øt R. VVard him≈øelf, ≈øo that during the ≈øaid four years R. VVard could not entermeddle with the goods; and though that no execution can be had again≈øt him who hath ≈øuch a ≈øpecial property, yet that is not the ca≈øe here, for here one who hath the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of certain goods, delivers them to another, and in con≈øideration thereof, he to whom the delivery is made, promi≈øeth to re-deliver them unto the Bailee, or to pay ≈øo much mony, this is a good con≈øideration, when a lawful property or title he hath who makes the Delivery. And of that opinion were all the Iu≈øtices, for it appeareth, that the Plaintiff had a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid goods, and that the ≈øaid Thomas Ward had a ≈øpecial property, and becau≈øe of ≈øuch po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was chargeable to an action of the ≈øaid Thomas Ward, be it that the Plaintiff comes to the ≈øaid goods by baylment or Trover, for by Periam, if goods come to another by Trover, and he delivereth them over, he is an≈øwerable to him who hath right unto them: The Delivery of the≈øe goods to the Defendant, is a good con≈øideration, and the Defendant hath benefit by the u≈øe of them, and the property of the goods is not to be argued in this ca≈øe, but the Delivery to the Defendant is the only matter: And becau≈øe the Delivery of the goods to the Defendant, and the A≈ø≈øump≈øit upon it, it was holden, although the goods were not liable to execution, yet the A≈ø≈øump≈øit was good, and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCIV. Vandrink and Archers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p:
VAndrink brought an action upon the ca≈øe again≈øt Archer, and declared,Trover and conver≈øion. that whereas he him≈øelf was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of twenty Ells of Linnen cloath, as of his own goods, the ≈øame came to the hands of the Defendant by Trover, and he knowing the ≈øaid goods to be the goods of the Plaintiff, ≈øold them unto per≈øons unknown, and the mony thereof proceeding did convert to his own u≈øe: The Defendant pleaded, that as to twenty four Ells of the ≈øaid Linnen cloath, long time before the lo≈øing, one Copland was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof, ut de bonis ≈øuis proprijs, Ante. 189. and ≈øold them to the Defendant, who before any notice that they were the goods of the Plaintiff, & before any reque≈øt, ≈øold them to per≈øons unknown: And as to the other three Ells, he was always ready to deliver them to the Plaintiff, and yet is, and upon the≈øe Pleas, the Plaintiff did demur in Law. Owen Serjeant, for the Plaintiff, That both Pleas are in≈øufficient, the fir≈øt Plea is not an an≈øwer but by argument, for the Plaintiff declares of a commi≈ø≈øion of his own goods, and the Defendant an≈øwers to a commi≈ø≈øion of his own goods, 33 H. 8. Br. Action
≈øur le ca≈øe, 109. In an action upon the ca≈øe the Plaintiff declares, that the Defendant found the goods of the Plaintiff, and delivered them to per≈øons unknown, Non deliberavit modo & forma, is no Plea, but he ought to plead not guilty; and in an action upon the ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared, that he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of certain goods, ut de bonis ≈øuis proprijs, and the Defendant found them, and converted them to his own u≈øe; It is no Plea for the Defendant to ≈øay, that the Plaintiff was not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid goods as of his proper goods, but he ought to plead not guilty to the mi≈ø-demeanor, and give in Evidence, that they were not the goods of the Plaintiff, and 4 E. 6. Br. action upon the ca≈øe 113. The Plaintiff declared that he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of certain goods as of his proper goods and lo≈øt them, and the Defendant found them and converted them to his own u≈øe; the Defendant pleaded, that the Plaintiff pawned the ≈øaid goods to the Defendant for ten pounds, for which he detained them according to the ≈øaid pawn, and traver≈øed the conver≈øion; and by ≈øome it was holden, that he ought to plead not guilty, & give the e≈øpecial matter afore≈øaid in Evidence; and 2 & 3. Phil. and Ma. Dyer 121. The ca≈øe of the Lord Mountegle, in an action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared upon a Trover of a Chain of Gold, and that the Defendant had ≈øold it to per≈øons unknown, the Defendant pleaded, That ip≈øe non vendidit modo & forma, & upon that the Plaintiff did demur in Law. And ≈øee 27 H. 8. 13. Where goods come to one by Trover, he ≈øhall not be charged in an action, but for the time he hath the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; But that is to be intended in an Action of Detinue, and not in an action upon the Ca≈øe, for ≈øuch action upon the Ca≈øe is not grounded upon the Trover, but upon the mi≈ø-demeanor, that is, the Conver≈øion. And as to the other Plea it is utterly in≈øufficient, for the Plaintiff declares of a Conver≈øion, and he pleads a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, that he is always ready, and ≈øo doth not an≈øwer to the point of the action. Yelverton Serjeant, to the contrary, and he conceived for the fir≈øt Plea, that it is a direct an≈øwer, for he hath ju≈øtified his ≈øale to per≈øons unknown, for that he hath bought the goods of one Copland who≈øe goods they were, and becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath demurred upon the Plea, he hath confe≈ø≈øed the truth of the matter contained in it, ≈øcil. that the property of the goods was to Copland, and ≈øo in Defendant by the ≈øaid ≈øale, and then he hath good cau≈øe to convert them to his own u≈øe by ≈øale or otherwi≈øe; And he conceived, that there is a difference, 27 H. 8. 13. betwixt Baylment, and Trover, for in ca≈øe of Trover, the parry is not chargeable but in re≈øpect of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which being removed, the action is gone again≈øt the Finder, for he who findeth goods is not bound to keep them, nor to give an account for them. And he put the ca≈øe reported by Dyer, 13 & 14 Eliz. 306, 307. R. Fines brought an action upon the ca≈øe, and declared, he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Hawk, as of his proper goods at W. and ca≈øually lo≈øt it at B. and that it afterwards ca≈øually came to the hands of the Defendant by Trover, and that he knowing it to be the Plaintiffs Hawk, ≈øold the ≈øame for mony to per≈øons unknown; The Defendant pleaded that the Hawk fir≈øt after the lo≈øing of it came to the hands of one Jeoffryes, who ≈øold it to one Rowly, who gave it to the Defendant at A. who ≈øold it to Poulton, and the ≈øame was found a ≈øufficient Bar; and it is hard where goods, as Oxen or Hor≈øes come to another by Trover, that he ≈øhould be charged to keep them and pa≈øture them until the Owner claimeth them, and therefore it is not rea≈øon but that he di≈øcharge him≈øelf by the quitting of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them. And as to the other Plea, the matter of the Plea is good enough, and the defect is but in the form, which becau≈øe the Plaintiff upon his Demurrer hath not ≈øhewed to the Court according to the Statute, he ≈øhall not take advantage of it, but the matter of the Plea is ≈øufficient, ≈øcil. the finding, and the offer to deliver it to the Plaintiff. Ander≈øon Iu≈øtice, For the examination of the in≈øufficiency of this Plea, the nature of the action, and
the cau≈øe of it is to be con≈øidered; the nature of the action, it is an action upon the ca≈øe, the cau≈øe, the Trover, and conver≈øion; Then for the latter Plea his readine≈øs, to deliver it, It cannot be any an≈øwer to the Declaration of the Plaintiff: For this action is not Debt or Detinue, where the thing it ≈øelf is to be delivered, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe, the Plea had been good, but the Conver≈øion is the ≈øpecial cau≈øe of this Action, which by this is not an≈øwered, and for the other Plea, the Declaration is not an≈øwered by it. But here is ≈øome matter of ju≈øtification, for when a man comes to goods by Trover, there is not any doubt but by the Law he hath liberty to take the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them, but he cannot abu≈øe them, kill them, or convert them to his own u≈øe, or make any profit of them, and if he do, it is great rea≈øon that he be an≈øwerable for the ≈øame, but if he lo≈øe ≈øuch goods afterwards, or they be taken from him, then he ≈øhall not be charged, for he is not bound to keep them, and ≈øo he conceived Iudgment ought to be for the Plaintiff. Windham Iu≈øtice, neither Plea is good; as to the fir≈øt Plea, he confe≈ø≈øeth the conver≈øion, but hath not conveyed unto him≈øelf a ≈øufficient title to the goods by which he might ju≈øtifie the Conver≈øion, for the Plaintiff declares of a conver≈øion of his own goods, and the Defendant ju≈øtifies, becau≈øe the property of the goods was in a ≈øtranger who ≈øold them to him, which cannot be any good title for him without a Traver≈øe, unle≈øs he had ≈øhewed, that he bought them in an open Market, and then upon ≈øuch matter he might well have ju≈øtified the Conver≈øion. And as to the other Plea, the ≈øame is naught al≈øo, for the goods are not in demand, and their the ≈øaid Plea is not proper to ≈øay, that he is ready to deliver them, for damages only for the conver≈øion are in demand, and not the goods them≈øelves, and therefore the ≈øame is a Plea but by Argument, ≈øcil. He is ready to deliver, Ergo, he hath not converted, and yet the ≈øame is not a good argument, for if a man find my Hor≈øe, and rides upon him, or hereby he becomes Lame, or otherwi≈øe by exce≈ø≈øive travel mi≈øu≈øeth him, ≈øo as my Hor≈øe is the wor≈øe thereby; He may be ready to deliver me my Hor≈øe, and yet this action will ly, for ≈øuch an abu≈øing of the Hor≈øe is a Conver≈øion to his own u≈øe. Periam Iu≈øtice,Po≈øt. 224. The latter Plea clearly is in≈øufficient, for it amounteth but to Not guilty, but for the fir≈øt Plea, he doubted of it, for fir≈øt the property is not traver≈øable, nor the knowing; but upon the general I≈ø≈øue pleaded, ≈øuch matter may be given in Evidence. And he conceived, That where a man buyes goods of one who comes to them by Trover, that he may ≈øell them, and ≈øhall not be an≈øwerable for them. And although it may be ≈øaid, that the ≈øaid matter may be given in evidence, yet it is not good to put the ≈øame to the people, but to refer the matter to the Iudgment of the Court. Walm. Iu≈øtice, The latter Plea is clearly in≈øufficient, but for the fir≈øt he doubted of it, for he conceived that the ≈øale of the goods is not a Conver≈øion. Ander≈øon, The fir≈øt Plea is, ut ≈øupra, and nothing in that is material or traver≈øable, for all the Plea may be true, and yet the Defendant is guilty, for it may be that the Defendant him≈øelf ≈øold them to the Plaintiff, or to another who ≈øold them to the Plaintiff, and that afterwards the Defendant found them, and here the Conver≈øion is confe≈ø≈øed, and not ≈øo voided by ≈øufficient ju≈øtification, and by him, the ≈øale to per≈øons unknown is no good Plea, for his ≈øale is his own Act, and it cannot be but he mu≈øt have notice of the buyers, and therefore he ought in his Plea to ≈øhew their names. Periam, Contrary to that matter as to the naming of the buyers, for it ≈øhould be an infinite thing for a Draper to take notice of every on who buyeth and Ell of Cloath of him. And afterwards the ≈øame Term Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff upon the in≈øufficiency of the Plea.

div.head: CCCV. Walgrave again≈øt Ogden. Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Trover and Conver≈øion. 1 Cro. 219.AN action upon the ca≈øe was brought upon a Trover and conver≈øion of twenty barrels of Butter, and declared, that by negligent keeping of them, they were become of little value, upon which there was a Demurrer in Law: And by the opinion of the whole Court upon this matter, no action lieth; For a man who comes to Goods by Trover, is not bound to keep them ≈øo ≈øafely, as he who comes to them by Baylment. Walme≈øley, If a man find my Garments, and ≈øuffereth them to be eaten with Moths by the negligent keeping of them, No Action lieth:Ante 223. but if he weareth my Garments it is otherwi≈øe, for the wearing is a Conver≈øion.

div.head:
CCCVI. Alexander and the Lady Gre≈øhams Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In Communi Banco.
div.p: Debt for arrerages of annuity. ALice Alexander, Admini≈øtratrir to her la≈øt Husband, brought an Action of Debt for the arrerages of an Annuity, again≈øt the Lady Gre≈øham, Executix of Sir Thomas Gre≈øham her late Husband, incurred in the life-time of her late Husband Sir Thomas Gre≈øham: The Defendant pleaded, that ≈øhe had fully admini≈øtred; The Plaintiff replyed, A≈ø≈øets, ≈øcil. That the Defendant had divers Goods in her hands not admini≈øtred, which were the goods of the ≈øaid Sir Thomas at the time of his death, upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue. And it was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, that Sir Thomas Gre≈øham being ≈øei≈øed of divers Manors and other Lands in Fee, devi≈øed them by his la≈øt Will to his Wife the Defendant,Devi≈øes. to u≈øe at her own plea≈øure: And by his ≈øaid Will reque≈øted his Wife to pay his Debts and Legacies: and further it was found, that at the Parliament holden 22 Eliz. a private Act was made,2 Cro. 139. Ante. 87. by which it was enacted, that the ≈øaid Lady ≈øhould take upon her the charge of all her Husbands Debts, and for the di≈øcharge thereof, ≈øhe ≈øhall ≈øell ≈øo much Land as will yield ≈øo much mony as will ≈øerve for the payment of the ≈øaid Debts, and if ≈øhe ≈øhall fail therein, that then certain Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall be appointed for the ≈øale of ≈øo much Land, &c. and for all ≈øuch Debts as the ≈øaid Lady ≈øhould not acknowledge to be good & true Debts, that then the Creditors to whom they were due, ≈øhould repair to the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, and they ≈øhould determine both of the certainty of the ≈øum of the due Debts, and of the Damages for the forbearing thereof: and that afterwards the ≈øaid Creditors ≈øhould have their remedy again≈øt the ≈øaid Lady for ≈øuch ≈øums of mony ≈øo agreed upon by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners: and found the Statute at large, and that the ≈øaid Lady Gre≈øham had ≈øold certain Lands parcel of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Sir Thomas, by which ≈øale ≈øhe had received the ≈øum of twenty thou≈øand pounds, which yet is unadmini≈øtred for the greate≈øt part of it. And if upon the whole matter the ≈øaid ≈øum of twenty thou≈øand pounds be A≈ø≈øets, then they find for the Plaintiff, but if not, then for the Defendant.

And it was moved by Hammon Serjeant, that here is A≈ø≈øets upon this matter, and that by the Common Law, for it appeareth upon the Will, that the Lands were devi≈øed to the Lady, to the intent that ≈øhe ≈øhould pay his Debts. And although the words of the Charge are, that the Te≈øtator reque≈øts the Lady to pay his Debts, the ≈øame in a Will doth amount to a Condition, and ≈øo the meaning of the Devi≈øor appeareth to be, that the money
which is levied by ≈øuch ≈øale ≈øhall be A≈ø≈øets, &c. 2 H. 4. 21, 22.A≈ø≈øets. A man makes a Feoffment in Fee to divers per≈øons, upon condition that they ≈øell the Land, and the money thereof coming di≈øtribute for his Soul; The Feoffor dieth, the Feoffees (who were al≈øo Executors of the Feoffor) ≈øell the Lands, the mony thereof coming is adjudged A≈ø≈øets. And ≈øee 3 H. 6. 3. And although it be not A≈ø≈øets by the Common Law,Roll. part 1. 920. yet it is A≈ø≈øets by the ≈øpecial Statute, which ordains, that he ≈øhall be charged with the Debts, and that the Lands ≈øhall be ≈øold. And it was found by the Verdict, that ≈øuch Lands were ≈øold, and ≈øuch money levied upon the ≈øale, which are admini≈øtred. And although the ≈øaid twenty thou≈øand pounds were never the Goods of the Te≈øtator, yet as the Ca≈øe is, 3 H. 6. 3. If Executors recover Damages in tre≈øpa≈øs of Goods taken away in the life of the Te≈øtator, ≈øuch Damages ≈øo recovered are A≈ø≈øets. So if Executors redeem a Pledge with their own proper Goods, the ≈øame is A≈ø≈øets in their hands, by King≈ømill, V ‚Ä¢ va≈øour, and Fi≈øher, 20 H. 7 42. And where the Executors took of one who was indebted to their Te≈øtator in a ≈øimple Contract, the ≈øame is A≈ø≈øets, 31 E. 3. And ≈øee many Ca≈øes of ≈øuch ≈øpecial A≈ø≈øets, 7 Eliz. in Plowdens Comment. in Chapman and Daltons ca≈øe, 292. It hath been obiected, that the ≈øpecial A≈ø≈øets enacted by Parliament, do not maintain the general A≈ø≈øets intended in the I≈ø≈øues but he conceived the ≈øame is well enough. As 27 H. 8. 21. In an Action upon the Statute of 21 H. 8. for that the Defendant hath occupied Land to farm again≈øt the Statute. The Defendant pleaded, Non tenuit ad firmam contra formam Statuti: And gave in Evidence, that he had taken to Farm for the maintenance of his hou≈øe, the ≈øame is a good Evidence, and ≈øhall maintain the I≈ø≈øue, for he did not occupy again≈øt the form of the Statute: for there is a clau≈øe in the Statute to that purpo≈øe. Puckering Serjeant to the contrary, That it cannot be ≈øaid A≈ø≈øets by the Statute, and that the Plaintiff upon this general I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall not take advantage of the ≈øpecial A≈ø≈øets enacted by Parliament: And here the Plaintiff hath not pur≈øued the Statute, for in ca≈øe the Defendant will not confe≈øs the Debt, by the Statute the Commi≈ø≈øioners ought to determine of it, and a≈ø≈øe≈øs damages for the forbearing and then the party is to have her remedy for all as ≈øhall be ≈øo determined by the Commi≈ø≈øioners by action of Debt: and becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath not followed the ≈øaid Statute, tho≈øe twenty thou≈øand pounds ≈øhall not be A≈ø≈øets as to her, for they are not agreed of the Debt, nor of the Damages for it; but the Commi≈ø≈øioners are to appoint ≈øale of the Lands, ≈øo as the money ari≈øing of the ≈øale of any Lands, ≈øhall not be A≈ø≈øets but of ≈øuch Lands which have been appointed to be ≈øold by the order of the Commi≈ø≈øioners. And as to the Common Law, the ≈øame is not A≈ø≈øets; but where Lands devi≈øed to be ≈øold by the Executors for the payment of Debts and Legacies, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the money ari≈øing of ≈øuch ≈øale is A≈ø≈øets. And ≈øee 9 Eliz. 264. Dyer, A man devi≈øed his Lands to be ≈øold by his Executors, and that the money thereof coming ≈øhall be di≈øpo≈øed in payment of Legacies expre≈ø≈øed in his Will, the Land is ≈øold; by Catlin, Dyer and Sanders, the money thereof coming is A≈ø≈øets: but 4, & 5 Ph. & Mar. Dyer 152. the Law was otherwi≈øe taken. Where a man devi≈øed that his Executors ≈øhould ≈øell his Land, and that his Daughters ≈øhould have ≈øuch portions out of the monies thereof coming, the Land is ≈øold accordingly, the Daughters ≈øued the Executors in the Spiritual Court. In that Ca≈øe a Prohibition lieth, for it is not a Legacy Te≈øtamentory, but out of the Land, &c. And al≈øo in the principal ca≈øe, the Lands are not devi≈øed to be ≈øold; but there is only a Reque≈øt to his Wife, that ≈øhe would pay his Debts without any condition, or expre≈øs direction, or limitation, 30 H. 8. Land devi≈øed to Executors to ≈øell and the money thereof coming to be divided between his Children: the money ≈øhall not be A≈ø≈øets, and if it be not A≈ø≈øets by the Common Law, but ≈øpecial A≈ø≈øets by a ≈øpecial Law, the
Plaintiff ought to have ≈øhewed the ≈øame in his Declaration, and then to have maintained again≈øt the Defendant the ≈øaid ≈øpecial A≈ø≈øets upon the Statute: As if in Debt upon an Obligation, the Defendant will plead, Non e≈øt factum, and give in Evidence the Statute of 23 H. 6. the ≈øame ≈øhall not maintain his Plea of Non e≈øt factum; but he ought to have pleaded the ≈øpecial matter in Bar. And ≈øee 4 H. 7. 8. So the Plaintiff here ought to have in her Replication ≈øhewed the e≈øpecial matter upon the Statute. Ander≈øon and Walme≈øly conceived, that the ≈øame is A≈ø≈øets within the Stat. and that the Defendant is chargable as Executrix, otherwi≈øe there is no remedy, and the Act confirms her to be Executrix, and ordains, that ≈øhe ≈øhall take upon her the charge of payment of Debts, and that the Goods and all the Monies which come by ≈øale of the Lands and Woods ≈øhall be A≈ø≈øets. And becau≈øe that by the ≈øaid Act the money coming by ≈øale of Woods and Lands are joyned together with the Goods of the Te≈øtator in the ≈øame plight, all are in the ≈øame degree, and both equally A≈ø≈øets. Periam did not ≈øpeak to that; but Windham held, That the≈øe A≈ø≈øets found by the Verdict, are not A≈ø≈øets intended in the Will, and that the Plaintiff hath not pur≈øued the Statute, which makes ≈øuch matter A≈ø≈øets. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCVII. The Queen and the Bi≈øhop of Yorks Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Quare Impedit. 1 Cro. 240.THe Queen brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of York, and one Monck; and counted upon a Pre≈øentment made by him, Hen. 8. in the right of his Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, and ≈øo conveyed the ≈øame to the Queen by de≈øcent: The Bi≈øhop pleaded, that he and his Predece≈ø≈øors have collated to the ≈øaid Church, &c. and Monck pleaded the ≈øame plea,Collation gains not the Patronage of the King. 6 Co. 50. a. upon which there was a Demurrer. And it was moved by Beaumont Serjant, That the plea is not good, for a Collation cannot gain any Patronage, and cannot be an V≈øurpation again≈øt a common Per≈øon, much le≈øs again≈øt the Queen, to whom no Lap≈øes ≈øhall be a≈øcribed; and although the Queen is ≈øei≈øed of this Advow≈øon in the right of her Dutchy; yet when the Church becomes void, the Right to pre≈øent ve≈øts in the Royal per≈øon of the Queen: and yet ≈øee the old Regi≈øter 31. Quando Rex prae≈øentat non in jure Coronae tunc incurrit ei tempus. Hammon Serjeant, By the≈øe Collations the Queen ≈øhall be put out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and put to her Writ of Right of Advow≈øon; but the ≈øame ought to be intended not where the Bi≈øhop Collates as Ordinary, but where he Collates as Patron, claiming the Patronage to him≈øelf, for ≈øuch a Collation doth amount to a Pre≈øentation; and here are two or three Collations pleaded, which ≈øhould put the Queen out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, although ≈øhe ≈øhall not be bound by the fir≈øt during the life of the fir≈øt Incumbent. Vide Br. Quare Impedit 31. upon the abridging of the Ca≈øe of 47 E. 3. 4. That two Pre≈øentments the one after the other ≈øhall put the King out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and put him to his Writ of Right of Advow≈øon, which Ander≈øon denied. And it was holden by the whole Court, Here is not any Pre≈øentation, and then no po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion gained by the Collations: and although the Bi≈øhop doth collate as Patron, and not as Ordinary, yet it is but a Collation. And there is a great difference betwixt Collation and Pre≈øentation, for Collation is a giving of the Church to the Par≈øon, and Pre≈øentation is a giving and offering of the Par≈øon to the Church, and that makes a Plenarty, but not a Collation. And although that the Queen hath the Advow≈øon by the right of her Dutchy, yet that makes not any matter, for the per≈øon of the Queen priviledgeth all her Capacities:Plenarty no Plea again≈øt the ≈øting. and therefore Plenarty is no plea again≈øt the Queen, be ≈øhe ≈øei≈øed of the Advow≈øon in the Right of her Crown, or of her Dutchy; but when ≈øhe claims by Lap≈øe, it is otherwi≈øe.
And afterwards Exception was taken to the Writ, becau≈øe it is not ≈øet forth in the Writ how the Queen claimed the Advow≈øon; as where the King had Right to pre≈øent by rea≈øon of the Temporalties of the Bi≈øhop in his hands, the Writ ≈øhall ≈øay, Ratione Archiepi≈øcopatus Cant. nuno Vacant. or Ratione Cu≈øtodiae: And ≈øo becau≈øe this Advow≈øon is parcel of her Dutchy, the Writ ought to ≈øay ≈øo. And Ander≈øon chief Iu≈øtice was of opinion, that the Writ was good enough, notwith≈øtanding the want of that clau≈øe, Ratione Ducatus, for both ways it is good and ≈øufficient, generally or ≈øpecially; as where a man hath an Advow≈øon in the Right of his Wife, and the Husband brings a Quare Impedit, the Writ ≈øhall be general, ad ≈øuam ≈øpecial. Donationem, without the mentioning of his Wife. See the Book of Entries 483. the Writ is general, but the Count is ≈øpecial. And there is the very ca≈øe of the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, and then the Writ is general, but the Count is ratione Ducatus ≈øui Lanca≈øtr. And ≈øuch an avoidance of a Church, parcel of the Dutchy, may be granted under the Great Seal: And ≈øee the ca≈øe of the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter in Plowden to that purpo≈øe; and afterwards a Pre≈øident was ≈øhewed, in An. 32 H. 6. where the Writ was general, and the Count was Ratione Ducatus.

div.head: CCCVIII. Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p: A Man made a Lea≈øe for years to begin at the Fea≈øt of our Lady Mary, for one and twenty years,Lea≈øe. without ≈øhewing the certainty at which Fea≈øts the Annunciation, Purification, &c. yet the Lea≈øe is good enough, and the Le≈ø≈øee may determine the certainty of the beginning of the Term by his Entry, at which of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts the ≈øaid Term ≈øhall begin, by Ander≈øon chief Iu≈øtice; but Periam doubted of it.

div.head:
CCCIX. Blagrave and Woods Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs brought by Blagrave again≈øt Wood, Surrender to the Steward out of Court. Co. 4 Rep. 20. of Lands in Totting in the County of Surrey, concerning a Surrender made to the u≈øe of Sir Thomas Holcroft, by Alice Pagnam, 7 E. 6. before one Forcet then Steward there: The I≈ø≈øue was, If at the time of the ≈øaid ≈øurrender, the ≈øaid Forcet was Steward of the ≈øaid Manor. And the Iury found a ≈øpecial Verdict, ≈øcil. That the ≈øaid Forcet circa 9 Aprilis, 7 E. 6. was retained by one Elizabeth Pagnam, then, before and afterwards Lady of the ≈øaid Manor, to be her Steward there for the keeping of the Courts of the ≈øaid Manor; and this Retainer was only by Word in the Countrey, and no Fee or Annuity given for the exerci≈øe of the ≈øaid Office: and that the ≈øaid Forcet, according to the ≈øaid Retainer, had kept Courts there divers times. And further, that ≈øuch a day and year at St. Dun≈øtans in the Ea≈øt, the ≈øaid Forcet took a Surrender, which was entred in the Rolls the next Court: and that before that and after he took divers Surrenders as well out of Court, as in Court, and had holden divers Courts there. And upon this Verdict, it was moved by Snagg Serjeant, That Forcet upon the matter found by the Verdict is not ≈øuch a Steward, that may take Surrenders out of Court, being retained only by word, although to do other Acts in Court he be a ≈øufficient Steward, for in the Court he is as a Iudge, and no body is to di≈øpute his Authority there. And there is a great difference betwixt a Steward of a Manor, and a Steward of Courts; and a Steward of one Manor hath not as great an authority as the Steward of another Manor, for a Steward of a Manor may take Surrenders in any place, otherwi≈øe it is where a Steward is retained to keep
Courts, for he hath no authority to keep Court, and all his power is within the Court,Vide Co. 4 part. 30. Dame Holcr ‚Ä¢ fts Ca≈øo. and not without. See 8 Eliz. Dyer 248. Drew Serjeant to the contrary. Here Forcet upon this Retainder was Steward at the Will of the Lady of the Manor, which Will ≈øhall not be ≈øaid to be determined, until the Lady doth di≈øcharge him: and the difference which hath been taken betwixt Steward of Courts, and a Steward of a Manor is nothing to the purpo≈øe, for there is not any rea≈øon in it: and it is true, an A≈ø≈øi≈øe cannot be brought of ≈øuch an Office, without a Patent of it, for it cannot pa≈øs for life without a Deed; and although a Steward in the Courts of Copyholders be a Iudge, yet he may be appointed without Deed: as where two ≈øubmit them≈øelves to the arbitration of others, now the Arbitrators are Iudges as to that intent, and yet they may be appointed Arbitrators, and di≈øcharged without Deed, 19 H 6. 6. 5 E. 4. 3. 21 H. 6. 30. but they cannot by their award transfer Free-hold from one to another, 21 E. 3. 26. 14 H. 4. 18. and 17. by Culpeper and Skreen; and ≈øee as to a Steward retained by word, 8 Eliz. 248. and ≈øee 12 H. 7. 25, 26, 27. where a Bayliff of a Manor may be appointed without Deed, and ≈øo of an under-Sheriff, and yet he is a Iudge. Owen Serjant contrary, Here Forcet at the time of this Surrender was not Steward, but the Retainer void. 1. No Fee is allowed unto him for the exerci≈øe of the ≈øaid Office, 3 H. 6. A Labourer may be retained without promi≈øe of any Sallary in certain, for it is appointed by the Law. 2. He is not retained by Deed, and although he may be retained without Deed to hold Court, pro hac vice, yet if the Retainer be for life, or for years, it ought to be by Deed. 3. He was retained to keep the Court, but not to be Steward, which ≈øhall be intended to hold Court, and then when that is pa≈øt his authority ≈øhall cea≈øe, and then all which he doth afterwards is void. But if he had been retained to be Steward of the Manor, then the Surrender taken out of Court had been well enough. 4. There is not any cu≈øtom found by the Verdict, to warrant ≈øuch a Surrender taken out of Court, and then if the Surrender be not warranted by their cu≈øtom it is void. Yelverton to the contrary, In all ca≈øes in real actions which concern Lands, the Suitors are the Iudges; but in per≈øonal actions under the ≈øum of forty ≈øhillings the Steward is Iudge: and although he be a Iudge, yet he may be appointed without Deed. And whereas it hath been objected, that no Fee is appointed for the exerci≈øing of the Office, the ≈øame is not material as to the Grant, but the party is not compellable without a Fee to do the ≈øervice: and a man may be con≈øtituted Bayliff of ≈øuch a Manor without Deed, and yet more doth appertain to the Office of the Bayliff, than to the Steward: as if the Lord of a Manor be beyond the Sea,More 1 Rep. the Writ of Right ≈øhall be directed to the Bayliff of the Manor: and ≈øee 21 H. 7. 36, 37. Where the Sheriff, or Steward of a Manor may be without Deed: and here in the principal ca≈øe, the Retainer is not to keep one Court, but to keep the Courts of the Lady of the Manor, ≈øcil. all her Courts, until he be di≈øcharged. It was adjourned.

div.head:
CCCX. A≈øcew and Fuliambs Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Andita Querela. 1 Cro. 233. AScew was bounden by Statute to Fuliamb, and there was not two Seals put to the Statute, and Execution was ≈øued upon the ≈øaid Statute, the Conu≈øor brought an Audita Querela, and they were at I≈ø≈øue, if two Seals were to the ≈øaid Statute, and tried for the Plaintiff in an Audita Querela by the Sheriff of the City of Lincoln; And it was moved by Glanvil Serjant, That the I≈ø≈øue ought to have been tryed
by the Certificate of the Mayor of Lincoln, before whom the acknowledgment was, and not by Iury, which was denyed, for the I≈ø≈øue is not whether any ≈øuch Statute was acknowledged or not, but whether the Statute in que≈øtion hath two Seals or not, and that is not recorded by the Mayor, as the Statute it ≈øelf is: Another Exception was taken, It appeareth by the Margent of the Record, that the I≈ø≈øue was tryed by the County of Lincoln, where it ought to be tryed by the County of the City of Linc. for Linc. only is in the Margent. But to that it was ≈øaid, that ≈øuch is the u≈øual form, to which the Preignothories agreed, and the Book of 18 E. 3. 25. was urged, where execution of Lands of the Conu≈øor was awarded upon a Statute Merchant, and the Statute was to pay, &c. 16 E. 3. But the Original Writ which i≈ø≈øued to take the body of the Conu≈øor was 14 E. 3. And upon that Error brought: And the Court agreed that ca≈øe, but the≈øe two ca≈øes do differ, for there the Proce≈øs was mi≈øawarded, not ≈øo here: And although a Writ of Error may lye, yet the ≈øame doth not prove, but that an Audita Querela may lye al≈øo: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCXI. Jennings and Gowers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN the Ca≈øe betwixt Jennings and Gower, the words were;1 Cro. 219. That if the wife of the Devi≈øor would permit one Wats to enjoy ≈øuch a Term for the Term of three years next following, that then ≈øhe ≈øhould have all the re≈øidue of his Goods and Chattels as his ≈øole Executrix, &c. Ander≈øon chief Iu≈øtice conceived, That ≈øhe ≈øhould not be Executrix; For ≈øhe is to be Executrix, upon a condition precedent to be performed before that ≈øhe be Executrix: And the condition is impo≈ø≈øible to be performed, and then ≈øhe ≈øhall never be Executrix, for where an e≈øtate is to be created upon a condition impo≈ø≈øible to be performed, there the e≈øtate ≈øhall never come in e≈ø≈øe, and here the condition is impo≈ø≈øible, for how can ≈øhe ≈øuffer Wats to enjoy the Term for 3. years, next following, & the 3. years ought to be pa≈øt before ≈øhe hath any power, either to permit, or re≈øi≈øt, for until the three years be encurred, ≈øhe cannot be Executrix, nor before the three years expired can ≈øhe bring any action as Executrix, for her authority doth not begin before the three years be expired. Walm. Peri. & Wind. contrary; Although a grant upon a condition precedent doth not take effect until the condition be performed, yet ≈øuch a con≈øtruction ought not to be u≈øed in this ca≈øe, ≈øo the intent of the Devi≈øor in this ca≈øe ≈øhall ≈øtand: If the condition had been, that if the wife will find meat and drink to ≈øuch a per≈øon until his death, That then ≈øhe ≈øhall be Executrix, ≈øhall not the Wife be Executrix till after the death of ≈øuch party? truly yes, for otherwi≈øe ≈øhe ≈øhould never be Executrix, which is utterly again≈øt the meaning of the Te≈øtator; for it was not his intent that the Ordinary ≈øhould commit Admini≈øtration of his goods in the mean time: And afterwards Ander≈øon changed his opinion, and agreed with the other Iu≈øtices: Periam, The ≈øub≈øequent words prove directly, that the meaning of the Te≈øtator was, to make his Wife Executrix immediately, until ≈øhe were di≈øturbed by the ≈øaid Wats, for the words are, that if ≈øhe refu≈øe to ≈øuffer the ≈øaid Wats to enjoy, &c. Then his Son ≈øhall be his Executor, which words imply, that by a di≈øturbance made by the Wife her Executor-≈øhip ≈øhould cea≈øe, and that the Son ≈øhould have it, which cannot properly be if ≈øhe was not Executrix from the beginning. And it is the u≈øual cour≈øe in the con≈øtruction of Wills, to con≈øider all the clau≈øes of the Will, and to judge upon all the words of the Will, and not upon one part only, and ≈øuch con≈øtruction the Iudges u≈øed in the ca≈øes of Param. and Yardley, and Welden, and Elhing And afterwards at
another day Iudgment was given for the Wife; That ≈øhe was Executrix pre≈øently, and her authority ≈øhould not expect until the three years were expired, if not that any actual di≈øturbance can be proved to be or have been made by the Wife again≈øt the Will of the Devi≈øor, and the words of the Will, will receive ≈øuch con≈øtruction, that ≈øhe ≈øhall be Executrix until an actual di≈øturbance of Wats.

div.head:
CCCXII. Palmes and the Bi≈øhop of Peterboroughs Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33. Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p: Quare Impedit. 1 Cor. 241.IN a Quare Impedit by Margaret Palmes again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Peterborough, who pleaded, That the Plaintiff did pre≈øent unto him one I. S. of whom the Bi≈øhop asked if he were within Orders; and if he had his Letters of orders, and becau≈øe the Pre≈øentee could not ≈øhew the Bi≈øhop his Orders, he refu≈øed him: And commanded him to come another time and ≈øhew to him his Orders, and that the Pre≈øentee did never do it, nor offered to the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop his ≈øaid Orders, without that he did di≈øturb him in other manner. And by Periam and Ander≈øon it is no Plea, for upon his own ≈øhewing the Defendant is a di≈øturber:Refu≈øal of the Bi≈øhop. Degg. 75. For although that the Statute of 13 Eliz. requires that no man ≈øhall be admitted to a Benefice with cure of ≈øouls, if he be not a Deacon, yet the Statute doth not extend, to compel the Clark to ≈øhew his Orders, and therefore when he for ≈øuch a frivilous cau≈øe doth refu≈øe to admit him, the ≈øame is a di≈øturbance; And afterwards exception was taken to the Count, becau≈øe that the Plaintiff being Tenant for life of the Advow≈øon of the gift of her Husband,Co. 5 Rep. 57. had not alleadged any Pre≈øentment in her Husband, or any of his Ance≈øtors, but only in her ≈øelf: But that was not allowed, for that point hath been lately over-ruled in this Court, in the ca≈øe betwixt Specot and the Bi≈øhop of Exeter, & 8 H. 5. 4. adjudged accordingly, Vi. 9 H. 7. 23. And the clear opinion of the Court was, that the Count was good notwith≈øtanding that exception: As to the matter of the Plea the Court doubted of it, for the Plea was, that the Bi≈øhop demanded, of the clerk pre≈øented, his Letters of Orders, and Letters Te≈øtimonial, of his good behaviour, and his Letters Mi≈ø≈øive, and he did not ≈øhew them but reque≈øted of the Bi≈øhop the ≈øpace of a week, to ≈øatisfie the Bi≈øhop in tho≈øe points, which was allowed unto him, but he never returned, for which cau≈øe the Bi≈øhop afterwards refu≈øed, &c. And it was ≈øaid upon that Plea, that the Clark who is pre≈øented, ought to make proof to the Bi≈øhop that he is a Deacon, and that he hath Orders; otherwi≈øe by the Statute of 13 Eliz. the Bi≈øhop is not bound to admit ≈øuch Clark,Degg. 75. but the Statute doth not compel the Clark to ≈øhew his Orders, for perhaps he hath lo≈øt them, but how his Orders ≈øhould be proved, it was much doubted: Ander≈øon, The Bi≈øhop may examine him upon oath, if he hath Orders or not; But as to the Letters Te≈øtimonial of his good behaviour and ≈øufficiency, the Bi≈øhop ought to examine the ≈øame him≈øelf, and if he give day and defer the Admi≈ø≈øion becau≈øe he is not re≈øolved therein, he is a Di≈øturber if the Clark come to him in a convenient time: And the Bi≈øhop cannot refu≈øe a Clark for the want of Letters Te≈øtimonial.

div.head:
CCCXIII. Linacers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33. Eliz. in the Common Pleas.
div.p:
2 Leon. 96. Co. 5. Rep. 86.IN an Audita Querela brought by Linacer, It was ≈øaid by Ander≈øon chief Iu≈øtice, That if a man be in execution by his Body and Lands
upon a Statute; If the Sheriff permit the Conu≈øor to go at Liberty, yet the Execution of the Land is not di≈øcharged; But if he go at large by the con≈øent of the Conu≈øee, then the whole Execution is di≈øcharged: And the Conu≈øor ≈øhall have his Land again pre≈øently.

div.head:
CCCXIV. Brown≈øall and Tylers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was, that Tenant in tail brought a Writ of Entry, Sur di≈ø≈øei≈øin and the Writ was general, and it was moved, if the Writ was good, and 21 H. 6. 26. was vouched, where it is holden, that the Writ ought to be ≈øpecial, ≈øcil. to make mention of the tail: But it was holden by the Court, that the general Writ is good enough. And then the Count ought to be ≈øpecial. Vi. Fitz. 191.

div.head:
CCCXV. Ward and Knights Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared,Toll. 1 Cro. 227. That whereas Lo≈øtock parcel of the Mannor of E. in the County of Suffolk is an ancient Town, and ancient Deme≈øn of the Crown of England, and that, time out of mind, &c. all the men, and Tenants of ancient Deme≈øn ought to be quitted of Toll in all places within the Realm, for them, their Goods and Chattels, &c. And whereas the Queen by her Letters Patents the tenth of September, the nineteenth of her Reign, commanded all Mayors, Bayliffs, Con≈øtables, &c. to permit and ≈øuffer the men and Tenants of ancient Deme≈øn, to be quit of Toll, Murage, and other exactions throughout the whole Realm; And whereas the Plaintiff was an Inhabitant, and Tenant in Lo≈øtock afore≈øaid, and ≈øuch a day and year carried his Goods to Yarmouth in the ≈øaid County, the Defendant not ignorant thereof, had taken and carried away a Cable of the Plaintiffs goods, of the value of eight pounds for Toll, to dis damage, &c. The Defendant pleaded by Prote≈øtation, that Lo≈øtock was not ancient Deme≈øn, and by Prote≈øtation that the Tenants of ancient Deme≈øn ought not to be quit of Toll, he ≈øaid. That the Town of Yarmouth is an ancient Borough,Pre≈øcription. and that they had been incorporated by the name of Bayliff and Burge≈ø≈øes, &c. And that they have had, time out of mind, &c. an Officer called a Water-Baly, and that, time out of mind, &c. they and their Predece≈ø≈øors have had and taken Toll of the Tenants and Inhabitants of Lo≈øtock, for any of their goods brought thither to Merchandize with, and if it be not paid, they have u≈øed time out of mind, to di≈øtrain for it by their Water-Bayly: And ≈øaid, that the Plaintiff ≈øuch a day brought to the ≈øaid Town of Yarmouth, two thou≈øand weight of Cable Ropes to ≈øell, for which there was due for Toll ≈øix pence, for Murage ≈øix pence, for Thronage four pence, and the Defendant being Water-Bayly demanded of the Plaintiff the ≈øaid ≈øum which he refu≈øed to pay, for which he took the ≈øaid Cable, nomine di≈øtrictionis, for the ≈øaid Thronage, &c. Golding for the Plaintiff, the Defendant hath not ≈øet forth in him≈øelf any authority to demand the duty: For he ≈øhews, that they have u≈øed to di≈øtrain by their Water-Bayly, but not that they have u≈øed to demand it by him, and it may be, that they have ≈øeveral Officers, one to demand it, and another to di≈øtrain for it. And always when a man demands a thing again≈øt common Right, he is
to ≈øhew authority expre≈øs in the whole: And as to the matter in Law, ≈øcil. The Pre≈øcription to have Toll of the Tenants in ancient Deme≈øn, it cannot have a lawful beginning: As 21 H. 7. 40. The Lord of a Mannor ≈øays, that he hath had a Pound within his Mannor, time out of mind, &c. And that he hath u≈øed to have of every one who breaks his Pound, three pounds, the ≈øame is a void cu≈øtom to bind a ≈øtranger, for it cannot have a lawful beginning, and ≈øee 5 H. 7. 9. b. One pre≈øcribed, that if any Cattel be taken in ≈øuch a place, Damage Fea≈øant, that he might di≈øtrain them and put them in Pound until the Owner had made amends, at the will of him who di≈øtrained them, the ≈øame is a void Pre≈øcription, for it cannot have a lawful beginning, and time cannot make ≈øuch a thing to be good. The King may grant Tollage, Pontage, &c. but not to the prejudice of another, as 22 E. 3. 58. The King cannot grant to one Thorough-toll to pa≈øs by Highways, for it is an oppre≈ø≈øion to the people, for every High-way ≈øhall be common to every one, ≈øee 16. E. 3. Grants 53. and here the Tenants of ancient Deme≈øn are quit of Toll by the common Law, and not by Pre≈øcription, which ≈øee Fitz. 14. and ≈øuch Tenants have an Inheritance in ≈øuch Liberties, which the King by his grant cannot take away, and then if it cannot have a lawful beginning, it cannot be good by Pre≈øcription: al≈øo this Pre≈øcription is again≈øt the Common-wealth, therefore it is a void Pre≈øcription, and the Common-wealth is much re≈øpected in Law, and things which in them≈øelves are ju≈øtifiable by rea≈øon, are not ju≈øtifiable if they be injurious to others, as 21 E. 4. & 8 E. 4. 18. Fi≈øhers may pre≈øcribe to dry their Nets upon the Lands of others, and none can pre≈øcribe again≈øt ≈øuch a Pre≈øcription; ≈øo here, all Lands which are ancient Deme≈øn, are holden in Socage, ≈øo as they were all Husbandmen, who manured their Lands for the ≈øu≈øtentation of the Kings Subjects, to which they had ≈øuch ≈øuch priviledges to be the better able to follow their Husbandry, and therefore to di≈øable ≈øuch profitable Subjects, and to pre≈øcribe again≈øt the≈øe Liberties and Priviledges, is to take away the name of ancient Deme≈øn, and to make their Lands at the common Law. Hobart contrary: To ≈øhew the authority to demand is not nece≈ø≈øary, for our Pre≈øcription is not upon demand to di≈øtrain: For the common Officer hath authority to demand, for they ought to demand it, who ought to take the thing demanded, and tho≈øe are the Bailiffs and Burge≈ø≈øes, and then when their Water-bayly doth it, it is as much as if it had been done by the corporation, which ≈øee 48 E. 3. 17. The Mayor and comminalty of Lincoln, brought an action of covenant again≈øt the Mayor and comminalty of Derby, and declared, that the Mayor and comminalty of Derby had covenanted with the Mayor and comminalty of Lin. that they ≈øhould be quit of Murage, Pontage, Cu≈øtom and Toll within the Town of Derby, of all Merchandi≈øes of tho≈øe of the Town of Lin. and further declared, That I.W. and H.M. two Burge≈ø≈øes of the Town of Derby, had taken certain Toll of certain Burge≈ø≈øes of the Town of Lin. &c. Exception was taken to this Declaration, becau≈øe they had alleadged the taking of ≈øuch Toll, not by the corporation of Derby, but by I. and H. two of the Burge≈ø≈øes of it, in which ca≈øe the Plaintiffs might have an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt the Burge≈ø≈øes, for the act of any of the corporation is not the breaking of the covenant, made by the comminalty, but it was not allowed; for if the common Officer of the Town doth any thing for their common u≈øe, as it is intended ≈øuch thing was done by the Officer, it is rea≈øon all the Town be an≈øwerable for it, and the whole comminalty by intendment cannot come at one time to take, &c. and ≈øo in our ca≈øe, for as much as the corporation ought to make the demand, and their common Officer doth it to their u≈øe, the ≈øame is the act of the whole corporation. As to the matter in Law, we have pleaded ≈øpecially; That we took Toll only of tho≈øe things which are brought by Sea by Merchants, and not otherwi≈øe, and I conceive that Tenants in ancient Deme≈øn, are not di≈øcharged of Toll, for
all things, but only for ≈øuch which ari≈øe out of their Tenements, or are bought for their Tenements or Families there, and their ≈øu≈øtentations, according to the quantity of their Tenements, 9 H. 6. 25. 19 H. 6. 66. They ≈øhall be quit of Toll, of all things ≈øold and bought coming of their Lands, or for the manurance of their Lands: And 7 H. 4. 111. Tenants of ancient Deme≈øn, ought to be quit of Toll for Oxen or Bea≈øts bought and ≈øold for tillage, and manurance of their Lands, and for their ≈øu≈øtenance and maintenance of their Families, and for putting them to Pa≈øture to make them fat and more vendable, and ≈øo to ≈øell them, &c. And ≈øee accordingly, F.N.B. 224. D. See Crook 138. 139. 28 Eliz. A Iudgment was given for the ≈øaid parties, for the Plaintiffs: but there the Plaintiff declared generally, and the Defendant did demur in Law generally, wherefore by common intendment, the Cattel were bought for the tillage and manurance of their Lands: For there it was not ≈øhewed (as it is here) that it was to Merchandize: Al≈øo we have ju≈øtified, not only for Toll, but al≈øo for Trouage, and that they have not ≈øhewed, and therefore as to the Trouage our ju≈øtification is good enough, for their priviledge ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued to extend beyond the words of it: As the priviledge of the Law is, That if I leave my hor≈øe at a Smiths Forge to be ≈øhod, there my hor≈øe cannot be di≈øtrained, but if I or my Servant take the Saddle from the Hor≈øes back, and lay it in the Smiths Forge, the Saddle may be di≈øtrained. Then here are two cu≈øtoms meeting together, and to begin together, and the one was not before the other, then the particular cu≈øtom ≈øhall ≈øtand: And I conceive that by the Writ, de exoneratione ≈øect. Fitz. N. B. 161. b. The Tenants in ancient Deme≈øn, have not always ≈øuch priviledges, for the Writ ≈øaith, quod ≈øi ita ≈øit, then, &c. and ni≈øi ip≈øi, & eorum antece≈ø≈øores tenentes de eodem manerio venire con≈øueverunt temporibus retroactis, and ≈øee the ≈øame matter in the Regi≈øter, 181. And afterwards Iudgment was given, quod querens nihil capiat par billam, for the Iu≈øtices were of opinion, that the Tenants in ancient Deme≈øn ≈øhould pay Toll for their Merchandizes.

div.head:
CCCXVI. Lanca≈øter and Lucas Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. in the Kings Bench.
div.p:
TRe≈øpa≈øs was brought for entring into the Par≈øonage-hou≈øe of Ringhall, and divers Lands appertaining to it:Lea≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The Defendant being Farmor of the Par≈øonage, pleaded, Not guilty; and the Iury found, that one Tybbin was Par≈øon of the ≈øaid Church, and that one A≈øh and Dorothy his Wife, Wivell and Drausfield were Patrons of the ≈øaid Church, ≈øcil. A≈øh and his Wife in the Right of his Wife, Wivell as Tenant by the Curte≈øie, the Rever≈øion to his Son, and Drausfield al≈øo as Tenant by the Curte≈øie, but without I≈ø≈øue by his Wife, &c. ≈øo as the Inheritance of the ≈øaid Par≈øonage was in Wivell and A≈øh; and afterwards the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter being Ordinary, the Par≈øon and Patron, 4 E. 6. joyned in a Lea≈øe of the Rectory (which Lea≈øe was void as to the Wife of A≈øh) to S. who a≈ø≈øigned it to the Defendant. All the Le≈ø≈øors dyed: and further found, that A≈øh and Wivell were Heirs of the Patronage, and that the Church being void, the Pre≈øentment came to the Bi≈øhop by rea≈øon of Lap≈øe, and that the Succe≈ø≈øor of the Bi≈øhop had Collated his Clark. Cook argued, And he conceived that the ≈øame now Incumbent ≈øhould avoid the Lea≈øe in toto; and the ca≈øe is but
this: Three Coparceners Patrons of an Advow≈øon, or Tenants in Common, the Par≈øon, three Patrons, and the Ordinary joyn in a Lea≈øe (where the one of them is a Feme-covert, and ≈øo her Act void) If the Succe≈ø≈øor of the Incumbent being pre≈øented by Lap≈øe ≈øhall avoid it in all: And he conceived that he ≈øhould, for all three have intere≈øt in the Par≈øonage, and all three ought to agree, but the agreement of the one is worth nothing: But it hath been ≈øaid, that that is but matter of a≈ø≈øent, and that the a≈ø≈øent of the one is as ≈øtrong as the a≈ø≈øent of them all;Atto ‚Ä¢ nment. As if many Ioynt-tenants hold by certain Services, and the Lord granteth the Services to a ≈øtranger, and one of the Ioynt-tenants attorneth to the Grant, the ≈øame is as ≈øufficient as if they had all attorned, Lit. 128. 566. Otherwi≈øe it is of a Rent-charge, for there all the Ioynt-tenants of the Lands charged upon the grant of the ≈øaid Rent ought to attorn to the Grant; for the Ter-tenant ought to attorn, and one of them is not Ter-tenant: And in ca≈øe of a Rent-charge, the Avowry is upon the Lands: but Attornment differs from our ca≈øe, for Attornment is but a bare a≈ø≈øent, without any intere≈øt in him who attorns, for an Abator may do it; but here is matter of Intere≈øt, and in Attornment, Attornment for one acre is effectual for all, 18 E. 3. Fitz. variance 63. but otherwi≈øe it is in ca≈øe of Confirmation for one acre, the ≈øame doth not extend to the re≈øt, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe an Intere≈øt pa≈ø≈øeth. So here, the one of them is not Patron, therefore all of them ought to concur, 31 E. 3. Grants 61. That ≈øuch act of the Patron ≈øhall not bind but according to the E≈øtate of the Patron, which ≈øee Lit. 112. 528. as if Tenant in Tail confirm, the ≈øame ≈øhall not bind the Pre≈øentee of the i≈ø≈øue, See Fitz. Grants 104 In R. 2. The ca≈øe was that the Bi≈øhop of Covent. and Lichfeild had two Chapters, one of Coventry, the other of Lichfeild, and he made a conveyance, but one Chapter only did confirm it, the ≈øame doth not bind the Succe≈ø≈øor, for both are but one Chapter in re≈øpect of the Bi≈øhop, and ≈øee the ca≈øe abridged by Statham Title A≈ø≈øize, for if the Bi≈øhop is cho≈øen by both Chapters, there a confirmation mu≈øt be of them both: The ca≈øe in Dyer 11 Eliz. 282. Thark, Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, hath two Deans and Chapters, the one ≈øurrendreth without the a≈ø≈øent of the Bi≈øhop, and afterwards the other Dean and Chapter confirmeth a Lea≈øe made by the Bi≈øhop, the ≈øame is good: I confe≈øs that; for the Surrender was by Act of Parliament, and ≈øo one ≈øole Chapter remained: And in our ca≈øe, the Lea≈øe cannot be good in part, and void for the re≈øidue, for all are but one Patron, as 22 H. 6. 47. Two Coparcenes are, they make compo≈øition to pre≈øent by Turns, a Writ of Annuity is brought again≈øt the Incumbent, he ≈øhall have aid of both. And ≈øee the Ca≈øe betwixt Gore and Dawbney in the Exchequer Chamber upon a Writ of Error, where two are accountable, an Account made by the one is not good, for both the Accountants ≈øhall make but, one account, and therefore the Account of the one cannot be good: And the Lord Ander≈øon put this Ca≈øe, two Ioynt-tenants of a Manor, the one of them doth grant a Copy, the ≈øame is void, for he is not Dominus pro tempore: And ≈øee as to the a≈ø≈øent of them all, &c. 3 Eliz. 190. Dyer. But it hath been objected, That now the Incumbent comes in by the Ordinary, and not by the Pre≈øentment of the Patron, and the Ordinary is bound by the confirmation of his Predece≈ø≈øor, ≈øo that the collation of the Bi≈øhop by Lap≈øe, is in the right and ≈øted of the Patron, and as the Pre≈øentee of the Heir of the Patron ≈øhall avoid, &c. ≈øo al≈øo of the Ordinary: and 20 E. 3. Br. Pre≈øentment 12. The Patron ≈øhall have a Writ of Darrein-pre≈øentment upon the pre≈øent‚ñ™ of the Bi≈øhop for Lap≈øe, and 22 H. 6. If a man can recover an Advow≈øon, and after the Bi≈øhop collate for Lap≈øe, the ≈øame is an Execution of the Iudgment, and will make a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øio fratris, as Moyle ≈øaith: And in our ca≈øe this confirmation is void in all, becau≈øe Non ≈øunt concurrentes ii qui in hac parte concurrere debuerant: And it is an entire Act, and cannot be avoided in part, and ≈øtand for the re≈øidue, and the Pre≈øentee
comes in in the right of the Heir, for which he may avoid it, &c. Popham contrary, it is to be here con≈øidered, if the Ordinary hath Intere≈øt in the Church by this Lap≈øe, or only an authority; for if he hath an Intere≈øt, then it will follow, that every one of his Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhall be bound by his Confirmation, and al≈øo their Pre≈øentees: It hath been objected, that there ought to be a full and entire Patron who makes ≈øuch a Lea≈øe, otherwi≈øe it is void: But that is not ≈øo, as if the Patron be Tenant for life, his Lea≈øe or Confirmation ≈øhall not be void in all, but ≈øhall be good during his life, which ≈øee 31 E. 3. Grants 61. and 19 Eliz. 356. A Par≈øon makes a Lea≈øe for forty years, the Bi≈øhop being Patron and Ordinary confirms it, the Patron dyeth, the Bi≈øhop pre≈øents, and afterwards is tran≈ølated, this Lea≈øe ≈øhall ≈øtand during the life of the Bi≈øhop, and of the new Incumbent who found the Church charged, and then ≈øuch Lea≈øe may be good for part, and void for part. See for the ≈øame, 2 E 3. 8. If the Advow≈øon of a Church be appropriated unto a Prior and his Succe≈ø≈øors, if afterwards the wife of the Grantor be endowed of it, and pre≈øent her Clerk, the Church is become di≈ø-appropriated during the life of the Wife, but afterwards ≈øhall ≈øtand. See the ca≈øe cited to the contrary, 29 Eliz. in the ca≈øe of the Earl of Bedford 7 Co. 8. At the beginning the Patron was not re≈øtrained to any time to pre≈øent his Clerk, but the ≈øix months was appointed at the in≈øtance and ≈øuit of the Ordinaries by a Canon, confirmed in the councel of Lateran, before which time, the Ordinaries had not any Lap≈øes, but after the ≈øaid Canon, they had an Intere≈øt in the Church, and this appeareth in the Regi≈øter: And ≈øee F.N.B. 37. f. that after the Ordinary is entituled to Lap≈øes, The Plaintiff in a Quare Impedit cannot have a Ne admittas, for now the Ordinary hath an Intere≈øt: And if the Bi≈øhop hath Title to pre≈øent by Lap≈øe, and before Pre≈øentment he dyeth, ≈øo as his temporalties come to the King, the King ≈øhall pre≈øent, which proves that it is an Intere≈øt, and the Civilians call it, Intere≈ø≈øe caducum & conditionale: And in our ca≈øe the confirmation of the Coparcener ≈øhall bind the other Coparceners; in a Nativo habendo, ≈øhall bind them all, and the villain ≈øhall be free for ever. And it was moved al≈øo, if an u≈øurper, or the Clerk who is in by him ≈øhall avoid this clau≈øe, and by the words of the Statute of We≈øt. 2. Si tempus ≈øeme≈øtre tran≈øierit per impedimentum alicujus, ita quod Epi≈øcopus Eccle≈øiam conferat, & verus Patronus ea vice prae≈øentationem ≈øuam amittat, adjudicentur damna ad valorem Eccle≈øiae pro duobus annis; Wherefore what the Patron lo≈øeth, the Ordinary hath the ≈øame, therefore it is an Intere≈øt, and in lieu of that lo≈øs the Statute gives damages to the Patron, &c. And the ca≈øe was adjorned to be further argued at another day, &c.

div.head:
CCCXVIII. Pet and Baldens Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33. Eliz. Rot. 392. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN a prohibition the Plaintiff declared,Prohibition. 1 Cro. 274. that whereas Michael Pett was ≈øei≈øed of divers Lands, and made his Will, by which he made the Plaintiff his Son his Executor, and thereby devi≈øed unto A. his Wife one hundred pounds, in con≈øideration and recompence of her Dower of all his Lands, and dyed, and the ≈øaid A. took to Husband the Defendant: And that after betwixt the Plaintiff and Defendant, colloquium quoddam habebatur, &c. upon which conference and communication,
the Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff promi≈øed to pay to him the ≈øaid one hundred pounds, promi≈øed to make to him a di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid one hundred pounds, and al≈øo of the Dower of his Wife, and ≈øhewed further, that notwith≈øtanding that the ≈øaid Pett was ready, and offered the ≈øaid one hundred pounds, and Dower al≈øo, yet, &c. Vpon which there was a Demurrer in Law; It was moved by Tan. that here is not any cau≈øe to have a prohibition, for the agreement upon the communication is not any cau≈øe, for it doth not appear that it was performed. Coke, A Prohibition lieth, for the Wife cannot have both, money, and Dower, for that was not the meaning of the Devi≈øor, and therefore it hath been holden, that if a man devi≈øeth a Term for years to his Wife, in ≈øatisfaction and recompence of her Dower, if ≈øhe recovereth Dower, ≈øhe hath lo≈øt her Term; Al≈øo here is modus and conventio which alters the Law, ≈øcil. mutual agreement: So if the Par≈øon and one of the Pari≈øhioners agree betwixt them that for forty ≈øhillings per annum he ≈øhall retain his Tithes for three years, &c. as it was in the Ca≈øe betwixt Green and Pendleton, &c. it is good.

div.head:
CCCXIX. Martingdall and Andrews Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33. Eliz. In Banco Regis.
div.p: Action upon the ca≈øe for Wa≈øtIN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared, that one Mildmay was ≈øei≈øed of a Hou≈øe in A. and that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate, &c. time out of mind, &c. have had a way over certain Lands of the Defendants called C. pro quibu≈ødam averiis ≈øuis, and ≈øhewed, that the ≈øaid Mildmay enfeoffed him of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, and that the Defendant ≈øtopt the ≈øaid way, to his damage, &c. And it was found for the Plaintiff, and it was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, that the title to the way is not certainly ≈øet forth, i.e. pro quibu≈ødam averiis ≈øuis, quod omnes Ju≈øticiarii conce≈ø≈øerunt: But Gawdy Iu≈øtice conceived, that the ≈øame was no cau≈øe to ≈øtay Iudgment: For it appeareth to us, that the Plaintiff hath cau≈øe of Action, although that the matter be incertainly alleadged, and of this incertainty the Defendant hath lo≈øt the advantage, having ≈øurcea≈øed his time by pleading to it, as 20 E. 3. Tre≈øpa≈øs for taking and carrying away of Charters, the Defendant pleaded Not guilty, and it was found for the Plaintiff to the damage, &c. And Error was brought, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had not ≈øet down in his Declaration, the certainty of the Lands comprized in the Charters: But non allocatur, for the Defendant ought to have challenged that before, and al≈øo 47 E. 3. 3. In a Writ of Covenant the Plaintiff declared of a Covenant, by which the Defendant covenanted with the Plaintiff to a≈ø≈øure to him all his Lands and Tenements which he had in the Counties of Glouce≈øter and Lincoln, and declared, that at a certain day he required the Defendant to make him a≈ø≈øurance of all the Lands, &c. And the Writ of Covenant was general, quod teneat conventionem de omnibus terris quas habeat in, &c. And it was objected (as here) that the Writ wanted certainty, as how many Acres, or ≈øuch a Mannor, but non allocatur, for here the Plaintiff is not to recover Land, but only Damages, and the Writ was awarded good. Fenner Iu≈øtice, the Ca≈øes are not like to the Ca≈øe at Bar, for in the ≈øaid Ca≈øes, the certainty is not needful, but for the taxing of the Damages; but here, the certainty of the number of the Cattel is part of the title.

div.head:
CCCXX. Beale and Taylors Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: UPon Evidence to a Iury,Lea≈øes. 1 Cro. 222. it was holden by Gawdy and Clench Iu≈øtices, that if a Lea≈øe for years be made, and the Le≈ø≈øor covenants to repair during the Term; if now the Le≈ø≈øor will not do it, the Le≈ø≈øee him≈øelf may do it, and pay him≈øelf by way of Retainer of ≈øo much out of the Rent, which ≈øee 12 H. 8. 1. 14 H. 4. 316.Retainer of Rent. A Lea≈øe for years by Indenture, and the Le≈ø≈øor, covenants to repair the Hou≈øes, and afterwards the Le≈ø≈øor commands the Le≈ø≈øee to mend the Hou≈øes with the Rent, who doth it accordingly, and expends the Rent in the charges, &c. So 11 R. 2. Bar. 242. The Le≈ø≈øor covenants, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall repair the Tenements when they are ruinous, at the charge of the Le≈ø≈øor: In debt for the Rent, the Le≈ø≈øee pleaded that matter, and that according to the Covenant he had repaired the Tenements being then ruinous with the Rent, and demanded Iudgment, if action,Jones 242. Yelv. 43. &c. and good. Fenner Iu≈øtice contrary, for each ≈øhall have action again≈øt the other, if there be not an expre≈øs Covenant to do it. Quaere, If the Le≈ø≈øor covenant to di≈øcharge the Land lea≈øed, and the Le≈ø≈øee, of all Rent-Charges i≈ø≈øuing out of it. If a Rent-charge be due, if the Le≈ø≈øee may pay it out of his own Rent to the Le≈ø≈øor, ad quod non fuit re≈øpon≈øum.

div.head:
CCCXXI. Offley and Salting≈øton, and Paynes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: OFfley and Salting≈øton, late Sheriffs of London, E≈øcape. 1 Cro. 237. brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Payne, becau≈øe that he being in Execution under their cu≈øtody for fifty three pounds, in which he was condemned at the Suit of one Spicer, made an e≈øcape, the debt not ≈øatisfied, by rea≈øon whereof they were compelled to pay the money; The Defendant confe≈ø≈øed all the matter, but further pleaded, that after the E≈øcape Spicer had acknowledged ≈øatisfaction (being after the E≈øcape) upon Record of the ≈øum recovered, upon which there was a Demurrer: Owen Serjeant argued, that the acknowleding of ≈øatisfaction, being after the E≈øcape, was not any Plea, for when the Plaintiffs Sheriffs have paid the money recovered, there was no rea≈øon that Spicers acknowledging ≈øatisfaction ≈øhould ≈øtop the Sheriffs of their Remedy again≈øt Payne. It was holden by the Iu≈øtices, that the Plaintiffs in this Action ought to ≈øhew, that they had been impleaded by him who recovered, for they cannot have this Action before they are ≈øued. For perhaps the Plaintiffs who recovered mu≈øt be contented to hold them≈øelves to the Defendant, and to be ≈øatisfied by him. It was ≈øaid by Glanvil Serjeant, that by the E≈øcape the Debt was ca≈øt upon the Sheriffs, and the Defendant di≈øcharged: and that it was the Ca≈øe of Sir Gervas Clyfton, who being Sheriff ≈øuffered him who was in Execution, and in his cu≈øtody, to go and ≈øee a Play, and the ≈øame was adjudged an E≈øcape, and the party could not be in Execution again: And then he ≈øaid, that this acknowledgment of ≈øatisfaction could not be any Bar to the Plaintiffs. At another day the Ca≈øe was moved again. And then it was the clear opinion of the whole Court, that the Action was maintainable, although that the Plaintiff in the fir≈øt Action had acknowledged ≈øatisfaction: And it hath been adjudged here in this Court, in the Ca≈øe betwixt Hill and Hill, that notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction, that the Action lieth. See F.N.B. 130. b. for the payment after doth not take away the Action, but mitigate the damages only, for the Act of a third per≈øon ≈øhall not take away an Action once ve≈øted.

div.head:
CCCXVII. Greenliff and Bakers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 193.THe Plaintiff declared, that whereas he was bound to the Defendant in an obligation of forty pounds for the payment of twenty pounds, the Defendant the ≈øecond of No. after, in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff at the Reque≈øt of the Defendant had paid the ≈øaid twenty pounds without ≈øuit at Law, promi≈øed to deliver to the Plaintiff before ≈øuch a day an Obligation, by which one A. was bounden to the Defendant in forty pounds, with a Letter of Attorney to demand the ≈øame of the ≈øaid A. and to ≈øue for it in the name of the Defendant, which he had not done, and in that matter the Plaintiff had Iudgment, and thereupon the Defendant brought a Writ of Error; Fir≈øt, here is not any con≈øideration; for the payment of the mony is no more than he ought to do, and which he was compeliable to do, &c.
