Secondly, the ≈øame is no benefit to the Plaintiff, but only a matter of charge to ≈øue the ≈øaid Bond again≈øt A. Thirdly, upon the Venire facias, the Sheriff returned but twenty three Iurors. As to the fir≈øt Error it was the opinion of Gawdy and Fenner Iu≈øtices, that here is not any con≈øideration, for the Defendant hath not any benefit by it, and the Plaintiff doth no more than he ought to do, and the payment was in re≈øpect of the Debt, and not of the Defendants Reque≈øt. And by Gawdy, upon this promi≈øe an action doth not lye, for the Plaintiff is not to have any benefit by it, but travel. Fenner contrary, and that the Action lieth for that; as to the third Error, the ≈øame is helped by the Statute of 32 H. 8. and the Statute of 18 Eliz. of imperfect and in≈øufficient return of any Sheriff: Fenner, Not only the return is naught, but al≈øo the Pannel is in≈øufficient. And it was moved by Tanfield, that it was adjudged in this Court, Pa≈øch. 25 Eliz. betwixt Cook and Huet, that where A. was bounden to B. in forty pounds, B. promi≈øed to A. that if A. would pay the mony without ≈øuit he would deliver him the ≈øaid Bond, by which he is bound to the ≈øaid B. and it was holden a good con≈øideration, Quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum per totam Curiam; but that is not like to the ca≈øe at Bar, and it was holden in the ≈øame Plea, That if the Obligor pay the duty at the day and place, that if the Obligee will not deliver the Bond, yet the Obligor ≈øhall not have the Detinue for it.

div.head:
CCCXII. Guildfords Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Indictment upon the Statute of 23 Eliz.
GUilford was Indicted upon the Statute of 23 Eliz. cap. 1. for withdrawing divers per≈øons, her Maje≈øties Subjects, from the Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed in England to the Roman Religion, and to promi≈øe obedience to the Church of Rome, and for that he him≈øelf was with-drawn from the obedience of the Queen. Coke took Exception to the Indictment, becau≈øe that the Indictment was not found within the year after the offence committed. In the ≈øaid Act there is a Provi≈øo, That all offences again≈øt the Act, ≈øhall and may be enquired of within the year and day after the offence committed. Popham Attorney General, This ca≈øe is not within that Provi≈øo, but doth depend upon other Statutes before, viz. 1, 5, & 13 Eliz. touching the acknowledging of her Maje≈øties ≈øupream Government in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øtical, or other matters touching the ≈øervice of God, or coming to Church, or e≈øtabli≈øhing of true Religion within this Realm, ≈øhall and may be enquired as well before the Iu≈øtices of the Peace, as other Iu≈øtices named in the ≈øaid Statute,
within one year and a day after ≈øuch offence committed: And he ≈øaid, the≈øe words in the Provi≈øo refer only to ≈øuch offences contained in the ≈øaid Act, which toucheth the Supremacy and cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øtical, &c. and ≈øuch offences ought to be enquired within the year and day: But this Indictment here doth con≈øi≈øt upon other matter, for withdrawing him≈øelf from the obedience of the Queen, which is an offence out of the compa≈øs of the ≈øaid Provi≈øo, and therefore the enquiry of it not re≈øtrained unto any time; and the Statute of 13 Eliz. extends to Bills, Writings, In≈øtruments, &c. and not to the words (with-drawing by words) which is ≈øupplied by 13 Eliz. (with-drawing by other means) and the re≈øtraint of the Enquiry at the time, goes to the hearing of Ma≈øs, and ≈øaying of Ma≈øs, and not (repairing to the Church;) but as to with-drawing, the ≈øame is at large, not re≈øtrained by that Statute: And he ≈øaid, that this Indictment doth con≈øi≈øt upon many offences, ≈øome to offences within the Provi≈øo, and as to tho≈øe the Indictment is void: Some to other offences, as Trea≈øon, the offence of with-drawing, the Enquiry of which is not re≈øtrained, and therefore this Indictment ≈øhall ≈øtand: Al≈øo it was the intent of this Statute, not to re≈øtrain this Court, but only the Iu≈øtices of Peace, for they are ≈øpecially named. Coke conceived, that this word Touching, &c. did not extend to any thing contained in the Statute of 23 Eliz. but only to offences within the Acts of 1, 5, & 13 Eliz. which were incertain before; al≈øo this Provi≈øo is in the Di≈øjunctive, again≈øt this or again≈øt the Acts of 1, 5, or 13 Eliz. ≈øo as that which follows is to be applied to the la≈øt Di≈øjunctive, and not to the whole ≈øentence; and always when a thing is named certain, and after general things, the words ≈øub≈øequent ≈øhall be referred to the general words, and not to that which is certain. Al≈øo if (Touching, &c.) doth refer to this Statute, the ≈øentence would have begun with it; but here it begins with the Supremacy, of which nothing is ≈øpoken in this Statute, and therefore it ought to be referred to the Statute which begins it, and that is 1 Eliz. and then it ≈øhall be prepo≈øterous to come after 23 Eliz. and the≈øe words (≈øhall and may) ought to be ≈øo con≈øtrued, (≈øhall) is re≈øtrictive of it ≈øelf, and (may) ≈øhall be referred to that which was re≈øtrained before, as the proceedings upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. cap. 2. were re≈øtrained to the next Sheriffs; And he conceived, that this Court is as well re≈øtrained to Time as any other Court, for the words are as well before Iu≈øtices of the Peace, as before other Iu≈øtices named in the ≈øaid Statutes, and in the Statute of 5 Eliz. this Court is e≈øpecially named: Wray, This Provi≈øo begins with Iu≈øtices of the Peace, therefore it doth not extend to offences which are Trea≈øon; and the meaning of this Statute of 23 Eliz. was to enlarge the Statutes of 1, & 5 Eliz. for where the offence again≈øt the Statutes before was to be enquired at the next Se≈ø≈øion, and the other within ≈øix Months; now by this Statute it may be enquired at any time within the year and day, but it doth not extend to re≈øtrain the proceedings again≈øt offences of Trea≈øon, for the words of the Statute are, That ≈øuch offences ≈øhall be inquired before Iu≈øtices of Peace within a year, &c. But in the next clau≈øe, the Iu≈øtices of Peace may puni≈øh all offences again≈øt this Act, but Trea≈øon, by which it appeareth that no offences are re≈øtrained to time, but tho≈øe which the Iu≈øtices of the Peace have authority to hear and determine, and that is not Trea≈øon: Gawdy to the ≈øame purpo≈øe: For all the Provi≈øo is but one ≈øentence, and there the whole ≈øhall be referred to ≈øpiritual offences, as the not coming to Church, &c.

div.head:
CCCXXIII. Filcocks and Holts Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Exchequer, Error.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øump≈øit.IN an Action by Filcocks again≈øt Holt, Admini≈øtrator of A. the Plaintiff declared, how that the Husband of the Defendant, who died inte≈øtate, was indebted to the Plaintiff in ten pounds by Bill, and that the Defendant in con≈øideration, that the Plaintiff would permit the Defendant to take Letters of Admini≈øtration, and give to her further day for the payment of the ≈øaid ten pounds, promi≈øed to pay the ≈øaid ten pounds to the Plaintiff, at the day: And upon a Writ of Error brought in the Exchequer, upon a Iudgment in the Kings Bench, in that ca≈øe, It was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that here is not any con≈øideration, for by the Law ≈øhe is to have Admini≈øtration, being wife of the Inte≈øtate; and as to the giving of further day for the payment of the ten pounds, the ≈øame will not make it good, for it doth not appear that ≈øhe was Admini≈øtratrix at the time of the promi≈øe made, and then ≈øhe is not chargeable, and then, &c. And ≈øuch was the opinion of the Court. And it was ≈øaid by Periam Iu≈øtice, and Manwood chief Baron: That the Bi≈øhop might grant Letters of Admini≈øtration to whom he plea≈øed, if he would forfeit the penalty limited by the Statute:
‚Ä¢ atch. 67, 68. Al≈øo it was ≈øaid, where an Executor or Admini≈øtrator is charged upon his own promi≈øe, Iudgment ≈øhall be given de boni ‚Ä¢ propriis, for his promi≈øe is his own act.

div.head:
CCCXXIV. Adams and Bafealds Ca≈øe.
Mich. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Action upon the Ca≈øe.AN Action upon the Ca≈øe was brought, and the Plaintiff declared, That where ≈øuch an one, his Servant, departed his ≈øervice without cau≈øe or licen≈øe, the Defendant knowing him to be his Servant, did retain him in his Service, and ≈øo kept him. Tanfeild, The Action doth not lye, for if my Servant depart out of my ≈øervice, and another doth retain him, an Action doth not lye at the Common Law, if he do not procure him to leave my ≈øervice, and afterwards retain him, or immediately taketh him out of my ≈øervice. And this Action is not grounded upon any Statute. See 11 H. 4. 176. 47 E. 3. 14. 9 E. 4. 32. Gawdy, The Action lieth, for here is damage and wrong done to the Plaintiff. Fenner contrary, For the wrong is in the departure, and not in the Retainer; and upon the Statutes it is a good Plea to ≈øay for the Defendant, that the party was vagrant at the time of the Retainer, and the (≈øciens) doth not alter the matter.

div.head:
CCCXXV. Na≈øh and Mollins Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Prohibition. 1 Cro. 206. Tithes. NA≈øh and U≈øher ≈øued a Prohibition again≈øt Mollins, for that the Defendant had libelled again≈øt them in the Spiritual Court, for Tithes of Wood, growing in Barking Park in E≈ø≈øex; the other did ≈øurmi≈øe, that the Lands were parcel of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Prior and Covent of Cree Church, and that the ≈øaid Prior, and his Succe≈ø≈øors, time out of mind, &c. had held the ≈øaid Lands di≈øcharged of Tithes, and held them ≈øo at the time of the Di≈ø≈øolution, &c. and the other part traver≈øed it, whereupon they were at I≈ø≈øue, if the Prior, &c.
held the Land di≈øcharged, tempore Di≈ø≈øolutionis, &c. And now on the part of the Plaintiff in the Prohibition certain old per≈øons were produced, who remembred the time of the Mona≈øteries, and that they did not pay any Tithes then, or from thence: Exception was taken to the ≈øugge≈øtion by Coke, that here is nothing el≈øe than a Pre≈øcription, de non Decimando, for here is not ≈øet forth any di≈øcharge, as compo≈øition, unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, priviledge of order, as Templarii, Ho≈øpitiarii, &c. ‚Ä¢ enner Iu≈øtice: Spiritual per≈øons may pre≈øcribe in non Decimando, for it is not any prejudice to the Church: Wray, Although it is not ≈øet down the ≈øpecial manner of di≈øcharge, yet it is well enough, for we ought to take it that it was by a lawful means, as compo≈øition, &c. or otherwi≈øe: For the Statute is, that the King ≈øhall hold di≈øcharged as the Abbot, &c. and we ought to take it, that it was a lawful di≈øcharge of Tithes tempore di≈ø≈øolutionis: And afterwards the Iury found for the Plaintiffs in the Prohibition: But no Evidence was given to prove, that the Defendant did pro≈øecute in the Spiritual Court, contrary to the Prohibition.

div.head:
CCCXXVI. Sheldons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32, & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: SHeldon, Talbot, and two other, four per≈øons in all,Indictment upon the Statute of 23 Eliz. were Indicted upon the Statute of 23 Eliz. of Recu≈øancy; the words of the Indictment were, Quod illi nec eorum uterque venerunt to any Pari≈øh Church, &c. It was moved by Atkin≈øon, That the Indictment is not good, for uterque doth refer unto one of them, and not where they are many, as here, and ≈øo is an in≈øen≈øible word, and ≈øo upon the matter there is no offence laid to their charge. And the Iu≈øtices doubting of it, demanded the opinions of Grammarians, who delivered their opinions, that this word (uterque) doth aptly ≈øignifie one of them,Expo≈øition of words. and in ≈øuch ≈øignification it is u≈øed by all Writers: Gawdy, I conceive, that the opinions of the Grammarians is not to be asked in this ca≈øe; But I agree, that when an unu≈øual word in our Law comes in que≈øtion, for the true con≈øtruction of it, then the opinion of Grammarians is nece≈ø≈øary: But (uterque) is no unu≈øual word in our Law, but hath had a rea≈øonable Expo≈øition heretofore, which we ought to adhere unto, which ≈øee 28 H. 8. 19. Three bound in an Obligation: Obligamus nos & utrumque no≈øtrum, and by the whole Court (uterque) doth amount to quilibet: And ≈øee 16 Eliz. Dyer 337, 338. Three Ioyntenants in Fee, and by Indenture Tripartite each of them covenanteth and granteth to the others, & eorum utrique, to make a≈ø≈øurance, and there it was holden that the word (uterque) doth amount to quilibet. Wray, Admit it ≈øhall be ≈øo taken in a Bond, yet it ≈øhall not be ≈øo taken in an Indictment: As if a man make a Lea≈øe for years, rendring Rent payable at the day of St. Martin, although there be two days of St. Martin in the year, yet the re≈øervation is good, and the Rent ≈øhall be taken payable at the mo≈øt u≈øual day of St. Martin there in the Country: But in an Indictment, if an offence he laid to be done on St. Martins day, without ≈øhewing which in certain, it is not good. Fenner, The word uterque is matter of ≈øurplu≈øage, and therefore ≈øhall not hurt the Indictment.

div.head:
CCCXXVII. Blunt and Whiteacres Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Error. A Writ of Error was brought upon a Iudgment given in the Common Pleas in a Replevin, where the Defendant did avow as Fermor of the Manor of F. in the County of Berks, to St. Johns Colledge in Oxford, and laid a Pre≈øcription there in him and his Fermors to di≈øtrain for all Amercements in the Court of the ≈øaid Manor,Amercement. and ≈øhewed that the Plaintiff in the Replevin was pre≈øented by the Homage for not repairing of a Hou≈øe, being a cu≈øtomary Tenant of the ≈øaid Manor, according to a pain impo≈øed upon him at a former Court, for which he was amerced by the Steward to ten ≈øhillings, and was al≈øo pre≈øented for not ringing of his Swine, for which he was amerced three ≈øhillings four pence, and for the≈øe Amercements he di≈øtrained: And upon Nihil dicit Iudgment was given for the Avowant to have return, upon which a Writ of Error was brought: And Error a≈ø≈øigned, in that there is not any Pre≈øcription laid in the Avowry for the Lord to amerce the Tenants, and of common Right he cannot do it. See 48 E. 3. And ≈øuch Amercement is Extortion, for the Lord cannot be his own Iudge, and therefore he ought to enable him≈øelf to di≈øtrain by Pre≈øcription; Another Error, becau≈øe the Fine is laid to be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Steward,1 Cro. 748. 886. whereas by the Law it ought to be by the Suitors, for they are Iudges, and not the Steward: Another, becau≈øe that in the Avowry it is ≈øet down, quod prae≈øentatum fuit, that he had not repaired a certain Hou≈øe; but he doth not ≈øay, in facto & categorice, &c. that he had not repaired, for that is matter traver≈øable. 4. Here is no offence, for a Copy-holder is not bound to repair by the Common Law, if it be not by Pre≈øcription, for he cannot have Hou≈øe-boot upon the Land as a Termor may, if it be not alledged a cu≈øtom. Fenner, The Steward may a≈ø≈øe≈øs Fines for a contempt; but not Amercements if not by Pre≈øcription. Gawdy, The Lord of a Mannor cannot a≈ø≈øe≈øs Amercements for a Tre≈øpa≈øs done to him≈øelf upon his own Lands; but otherwi≈øe it is of a common Tre≈øpa≈øs, or a Tre≈øpa≈øs done in the Land of another; but for the Di≈øtre≈øs he ought to pre≈øcribe, and the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head:
CCCXXVIII. Page and Fawcets Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 29 Eliz. Rot. 121. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Error. 3 Cro. 227.ERror was brought upon a Iudgment given in Lyn, where by the Record it appeareth, that they pre≈øcribe to hold Plea every Wedne≈øday, and it appeared upon the ≈øaid Record that the Court was holden, 16 Feb. 26 Eliz. which was dies Dominicus, and that was not a≈ø≈øigned for Error in the Record; but after in Nullo e≈øt erratum pleaded, it was a≈ø≈øigned at the Bar: And Almanacks were ≈øhewed to the Court in proof of it, and it was holden clearly to be Error; but the doubt was, if it ≈øhould be tried by Iury, or by the Almanacks, and it was ≈øaid, that the Iu≈øtices might judicially take notice of Almanacks, and be informed by them, and that was the Ca≈øe of one Robert in the time of the Lord Catline, and by Coke; ≈øo was the Ca≈øe betwixt Galery and Bunbury, and afterwards the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head:
CCCXXIX. Geofries and Coites Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IT was found by ≈øpecial Verdict,1 Cro. 25 ‚Ä¢
that one Avice Trivilian was Tenant for life, the Remainder to her Son in tail, the Remainder over; Tenant for life, and he in the Remainder in tail make a Lea≈øe for life, the Remainder for life rendring Rent; Tenant for life dieth, he in the Remainder dieth, and his Son accepteth of the Rent of the Tenant for life in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, who dieth. The I≈ø≈øue in tail entreth, he in the Remainder for life entreth, &c. And it was conceived, that this acceptance of the Rent of the Le≈ø≈øee for life doth affirm al≈øo the Remainder. See Litt. Sect. 521. and ≈øuch was the opinion of Gawdy and Fenner Iu≈øtices.

div.head:
CCCXXX. The Lord Mordant and Vaux Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
THe Lord Mordant brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt George Vaux, and declared of a Tre≈øpa≈øs done in quodam loco, 1 In≈øt. 225. 1 Cro. 269. called N. parcel of the Manor of Hawarden. The Ca≈øe was, William Lord Vaux was ≈øei≈øed thereof, and thereof levied a Fine to the u≈øe of the Lord Vaux, which now is, for life, and after his decea≈øe to the u≈øe of Ann and Muriel Daughters of the Lord Vaux and their A≈ø≈øigns, until Ambro≈øe Vaux ≈øhould return from the parts beyond the Seas, and ≈øhould come to the Age of 21 years, or dye, if they ≈øhould ≈øo long live: And after the return of Ambro≈øe from beyond the Seas, and the age of 21 years, or death, which≈øoever of the ≈øaid days or times ≈øhould fir≈øt happen, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Ambro≈øe and the Heirs of his body begotten, with divers Remainders over. Ambro≈øe returned,Plow. Com. 376. 2. Ante 18. 76. and 31 Eliz. before he came of full age (for it is not pleaded that he was of full age) levied a Fine to the u≈øe of George Vaux, the Defendant in tail, with divers Remainders over. Afterwards the Lord Vaux being Tenant for life, enfeoffed the Lord Mordant in Fee, upon whom the ≈øaid George Vaux entred for a forfeiture, upon which Entry the Lord Mordant brought the Action. Buck argued for the Plaintiff. Amb. Vaux had nothing in the Lands in que≈øtion until his return from beyond the Seas, and his full age, and the e≈øtate doth not begin until both be pa≈øt; and he ≈øaid, that no u≈øe did ari≈øe to Ambro≈øe until the time incurred, for the time of the beginning is uncertain and upon a Contingent, as 13 Eliz. Dyer 301. A. makes a Feoffment in fee to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and after to the u≈øe of B. who he intendeth to marry, until the I≈ø≈øue which he ≈øhall beget on her ≈øhall be of the age of 21 years, and after the I≈ø≈øue ≈øhall come of ≈øuch age, then unto the u≈øe of the ≈øaid B. during her Widowhood, the Husband dieth without I≈ø≈øue, the Wife entreth, and her Entry holden lawful. But Error was brought upon it; And al≈øo Calthrops ca≈øe was cited to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, 16 Eliz. Dyer 336. This e≈øtate limited to Ambro≈øe doth refer to the e≈øtate limited to Muriel and Ann, and not to the time, for ever the fir≈øt e≈øtate is to be re≈øpected, as 23 Eliz. Dyer 371. He in the Remainder in Fee upon an e≈øtate for life devi≈øeth it to his Wife, yielding and paying during her natural life yearly 20 ≈øhillings, and dieth, living Tenant for life, the Rent ≈øhall not begin until the Remainder falleth: So as the general words refer to the beginning of the e≈øtate, although the words imply that the Rent ≈øhall be paid pre≈øently: And ≈øee al≈øo ≈øuch con≈øtruction, 9 Eliz. 261. A Lea≈øe was made for thirty years, and four years after the Le≈ø≈øor makes another Lea≈øe by the≈øe words, Nos dictis 30 annis finitis, dedi≈ø≈øe & conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe, &c. Habend. & tenend.
a die confectionis prae≈øentium, termino praedict. finito, u≈øque terminum, &c. And although, prima facie, the beginning of this Term ≈øeems incertain, yet the Iu≈øtices did re≈øpect the former e≈øtate, and ≈øo the Le≈ø≈øee hath the Intere≈øt of the Term from the making of the Deed, but no e≈øtate until the fir≈øt Term expire: Then Ambro≈øe before his age of 21 years levying a Fine, the Fine ≈øhall not bind the Feoffee, for it enures only by way of conclu≈øion, and ≈øo binds parties and privies, but not a ≈øtranger: And the party needs not to plead again≈øt this Fine, quod partes to the Fine Nihil habuerunt, for that appeareth upon their own ≈øhewing. Wiat contrary; The ≈øtate of Ambr. accrues and ri≈øes when any of the ≈øaid times come, fir≈øt full age, return, death, for the words are, And after the return of Ambro≈øe from beyond the Seas, and the age of 21 years, or death, &c. This word (or) before (death) di≈øjoyns all, and makes the ≈øentence in the Di≈øjunctive, and he cited a ca≈øe lately judged in the Common Pleas: A Lea≈øe was made to Trewpeny and his Wife for one hundred years, if he and his Wife, or any Child or Children betwixt them begotten ≈øhould ≈øo long live; the Wife died without I≈ø≈øue, the Husband held the Land, &c. for the Di≈øjunctive before (Child) made the ≈øentence Di≈øjunctive. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, That had been Law if no ≈øuch word had been in the Ca≈øe. And Wiat ≈øaid, That although the return be incertain, yet it is certain enough that he ≈øhall come to the age of 21 years, or dye. And al≈øo this is by way of u≈øe, which needs not to depend upon any e≈øtate, and if the Remainder ≈øhall ve≈øt pre≈øently upon his return, then it would be doubtful what Remainder it is, if it be a Remainder depending upon the e≈øtate for the life of Ann and Muriel, or for years, i.e. until Ambro≈øe ≈øhall come of the age of 21 years: But be it incertain, yet the Fine is good, for here is a Remainder in Ambro≈øe, and both are but particular e≈øtates, and there is not any doubt, but that one may convey by Fine, or bar by Fine ≈øuch contingent u≈øes, for which ≈øee the Statute of 32 H. 8. All Fines to be levied of any Lands intailed in any wi≈øe to him that levieth the Fine, or to any his Ance≈øtors in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, rever≈øion, &c. which word (u≈øe) goes to contingent u≈øes, for at the time of the making of that Statute, there was no other u≈øe. Fenner Iu≈øtice remembred the Ca≈øe adjudged M. 30 & 31 Eliz. betwixt John≈øon and Bellamy, 2 Len. 36. which ruled this Ca≈øe. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, Here is a certainty upon which the Remainder doth depend, i. e. the death of Ambro≈øe; but the Ca≈øe had been the more doubtful if no certainty at all had been in the Ca≈øe. Atkin≈øon contrary; Here the Lord Vaux is Tenant for life, the Remainder to George in tail; now when the Lord Vaux levies a Fine, this is a forfeiture, and then the Entry of George is lawful. It hath been objected on the other ≈øide, that this Remainder was future and contingent, and not ve≈øted, therefore nothing pa≈ø≈øed to George by Ambro≈øe. The words are (quou≈øque Ambro≈øe ≈øhall return.) This word (quou≈øque) is a word of Limitation, and not of Condition, and then the Remainder may well ri≈øe when the Limitation hapneth. It hath been ≈øaid, that this Remainder is contingent, and then the Remainder which is to ve≈øt upon a contingency, cannot be granted or forfeited before that the contingent hapneth: And he cited the Ca≈øe of 14 Eliz. 314. Dyer. A Fine is levied to A. to the u≈øe of B. for life, the Remainder to E. in Tail, the Remainder to B. in fee. Provi≈øo, That if B. ≈øhall have I≈ø≈øue of his Body, that then after ≈øuch I≈ø≈øue, and 500 l. paid to, &c. within ≈øix months after the birth of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Lands, after the death of the ≈øaid B. and the ≈øaid ≈øix months expired, ≈øhall be to the ≈øaid B. and the heirs of his body: And it was holden, that before the ≈øaid contingent hapneth, B. had not any e≈øtate tail, for there it was incertain if the ≈øaid contingent would happen; but in our ca≈øe, the contingents or ≈øome of them will happen, or run out by effluxion of time, and that makes the Remainder certain in Ambro≈øe. And he al≈øo argued, that the Limitations are ≈øeveral, by rea≈øon of the Di≈øjunctive,
and the la≈øt part of the ≈øentence, and that the ≈øaid ≈øentence is in the Disjunctive appeareth by the ≈øub≈øequent words (which of the ≈øaid days or times ≈øhall fir≈øt happen) And then the return of Ambro≈øe (for that fir≈øt hapned) ve≈øts the Remainder in him, and therefore the Plaintiff ought to be barred. Buckley contrary: The e≈øtate of the Daughters doth depend upon a Copulative, i.e. the return of Ambro≈øe and his full age, and both is but one Limitation; it is clear, that the fir≈øt Limitation is upon a contingent, and the remainder cannot ve≈øt until both are performed. And as to that which hath been ≈øaid, that there is a certain Limitation, i. e. the return of Ambro≈øe, 18 Eliz. the Ca≈øe was, Lands were given to Husband and Wife, the Remainder to ≈øuch of them as ≈øhould ≈øurvive the other, for years, the Husband makes a Lea≈øe for years and dieth, it was holden, that although the Limitation was upon a certain e≈øtate, yet becau≈øe it is not known in which of the parties the e≈øtate ≈øecondly limited ≈øhall begin, the Lea≈øe is void; So here it is not certainly appointed when the e≈øtate limited to Ambro≈øe ≈øhall begin, upon the return, full age, or death of Ambro≈øe, and he ≈øaid, that here are but two times of Limitation, fir≈øt return and full age, ≈øecond death; return and full age determines the e≈øtate of the Daughters, and al≈øo the death, if it ≈øhall fir≈øt happen, and if the≈øe three times ≈øhall be con≈øtrued in the Disjunctive,2 Len. 2 ‚Ä¢ . the ≈øame would overthrow the e≈øtate of the Daughters, which is an e≈øtate for years determinable, upon the death of them≈øelves or Ambro≈øe. The la≈øt words of the Limitation do not di≈øtingui≈øh or disjoyn it, but re≈øpect the e≈øtate precedent. And by Clench Iu≈øtice, If the u≈øe limited to Ambro≈øe, ≈øhall depend only upon the Limitation of his death, the ≈øame ≈øhould be void, for then he ≈øhould not he in e≈ø≈øe to take. But the other Iu≈øtices were of a contrary opinion, and that the u≈øe is good, 7 H. 4. Gawdy, Although that here be three things, yet but two times; for the words are not (or) at ≈øuch of the ≈øaid days or times, as ≈øhall fir≈øt happen, for that would alter the ca≈øe: But here the≈øe words ought to be intended as if they were ≈øpoken before in the Limitation of the e≈øtate to the Daughters, and cannot divide the former Limitation: and he ≈øaid, that if by rea≈øon, that the Limitation upon the death, which is certain, it ≈øhall ve≈øt in Ambro≈øe pre≈øently, then if after the other Limitation ≈øhall fall, then his Remainder which ve≈øted in him upon the ≈øaid certain Limitation ≈øhould be deve≈øted, and ≈øhould now accrue to him upon the other Limitation, which ≈øhould be ab≈øurd and inconvenient, &c. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCXXXI. Thomas and Wards Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN Ejectione firmae, by Thomas again≈øt Ward, Ejectione firme. 1 Cro. 102. upon a Lea≈øe made to him of the Manor of Middleton Cheney by one Chambers, the Defendant pleaded, that long time before the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff had any thing, the Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter was ≈øei≈øed, and lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Defendant: the Plaintiff by Replication ≈øaid, that the ≈øaid Lea≈øe was upon condition, viz. The Le≈ø≈øee by the Indenture of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, did covenant that he would not put out, or di≈øturb any of the Tenants inhabiting within the ≈øaid Manor out of their Tenancies, doing their duties according to the cu≈øtom of the ≈øaid Manor; and ≈øhewed, that the Defendant had put out one Ann Green a Tenant dwelling there upon a Tenement parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, late in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and occupation of the ≈øaid Ann, and that the Bi≈øhop had re-entred for the condition ≈øo broken, and made a lea≈øe to the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, upon which Replication, the Defendant hath demurred in Law:
Tanfeild argued for the Defendant, that the Bi≈øhop had no cau≈øe to re-enter, for there is not any condition in the Ca≈øe, but only a Covenant, for it comes in only on the part of the Le≈ø≈øee, and they are words of Covenant only, whereas every condition ought to be the words of the Le≈ø≈øor, and the Bi≈øhop hath ≈øufficient remedy by Action of Covenant: But if the words had been indifferent and ab≈øolute without depending on the Le≈ø≈øor or Le≈ø≈øee, then it had been otherwi≈øe, as 3 E. 6. Dyer, 65. Non licebit, to the Le≈ø≈øee, dare, concedere, vel vendere ≈øtatum vel terminum, without the Licence of the Le≈ø≈øor, under pain of forfeiture, the ≈øame is a good condition, but here it is meerly a Covenant, and it cannot be both. Haughton. Although the words ≈øound in Covenant, and be the words of the Le≈ø≈øee, yet the Lea≈øe being made by Indenture, the ≈øame is the Deed of both, and every word in it is ≈øpoken by both parties, and although that he may have an Action of Covenant, yet he cannot thereby overthrow the Lea≈øe, as by Entry, by condition broken, and yet by the words it ≈øeems the meaning of the Indenture was, that by the breach of this Covenant, the e≈øtate ≈øhould be defeated, for ≈øo are the words, ≈øub poena forisfactur. And here by way of Action he cannot have the benefit of the whole Covenant, and therefore he ≈øhall have it by way of condition: And ≈øee the ca≈øe betwixt Browning and Be≈øton, Plow. 132. If it happen the Rent to be behind, that then the Le≈ø≈øee Covenants, that although the Rent be not demanded, that the ≈øaid Lea≈øe ≈øhould be utterly extinct, void, and of no effect; and 24 Eliz. there was a ca≈øe betwixt Hill and Lockham, where by the Indenture of Lea≈øe, the Le≈ø≈øee Covenanted to grind all his Corn at the Mill of the Le≈ø≈øor, and afterward in the end of the ≈øaid Indenture, the Le≈ø≈øee covenanted to perform all the Covenants, ≈øub poe ‚Ä¢ a ≈øorisfactur. and by the opinion of the whole Court, the ≈øame was a condition: And ≈øee 21 H. 6. 51. where in an Obligation where A was bound to B. the condition is written in this manner, Praedict. B. vult & concedit, That if the ≈øaid A. doth ≈øtand to the Arbitrament of ≈øuch a one that then, &c. the ≈øame is a good condition, although they are the words of the Obligee, and the Deed of the Obligor, and ≈øo here is a good condition. And ≈øuch was the opinion of Wray and Gawdy, and Fenner did not contradict it: Wherefore Tanfeild ≈øaid, Admit here it is a condition, yet here is not any breach of it ≈øufficiently ≈øet forth, for the breach is a≈ø≈øigned becau≈øe he had put out a woman, unam tenentem, & inhabitantem, out of certain Lands parcel of the ≈øaid Manor, late in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and occupation of the ≈øaid woman, and that might be, that ≈øhe was but Tenant at Will, and the Covenant doth refer only to Copy-holders: And it may be al≈øo, that ≈øhe had di≈ø≈øei≈øed one of the Tenants of the Manor, in which ca≈øe, the putting out of ≈øuch a Tenant being in by wrong, is no breach of condition. Al≈øo it is not averred in facto, that Ann was Tenant of any part of the Mannor: Al≈øo the Replication is, That the ≈øaid Defendant had ou≈øted the ≈øaid Ann, where ≈øhe had done her duty, fecit debitum ≈øuum, before the Ou≈øter, and that might be, that ≈øhe had done her duty once, but not after, and therefore he ought to have ≈øaid, that ≈øhe had done her duty always, before her putting out, and this word (duly) being ≈øingle, is too general, for it may be under≈øtood of curte≈øie, where the words in the Indenture are (Doing their duty according to the cu≈øtom of the Manor.) And al≈øo it might be, that Ann Green was Tenant and Inhabitant, but was not put out of the Land which was parcel of the Manor. And Wray ≈øaid, that the≈øe Exceptions were incurable: And therefore Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCXXXII. Harvy and Thomas Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. Rot. 414. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was,Lea≈øes. 1 Cro. 216. Husband and Wife ≈øei≈øed of Lands in the Right of the Wife, the Husband alone makes a Lea≈øe by word for years: Afterwards the Husband and Wife levy a Fine, and after the Wife and Husband both dye, It was holden clearly by the whole Court, that the Conu≈øee ≈øhould avoid the Lea≈øe.

div.head:
CCCXXXIII. Sly and Mordants Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32. Eliz. Rot. 314 In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared,1 Cro. 191. 2 Len. 103. 3 Len. 174. Dy. 250. 1 Cro. 198, 199. that whereas he was ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands, the Defendant had ≈øtopped a Water-cour≈øe, by which his Land was drowned, and found for the Plaintiff, It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that it appeareth upon the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing, that the Plaintiff hath the Free-hold, and therefore he ought to have an A≈ø≈øize, but the ≈øame was not allowed, and therefore the Plaintiff had Iudgment.

div.head:
CCCXXXIV. Ken≈øam and Redings Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was,Grants of the King 1 Cro. 244. Hob. 170. That the Queen by her Letters Patents granted the Site of the Manor of Brokeley lying in W. and all the Lands, Pa≈øtures, Woods, Vnder-woods, and Hereditaments, parcel or appertaining to the ≈øaid Site, exceptis omnibus gro≈ø≈øis arboribus, bo≈øcis & maremio; and further in the ≈øaid Letters Patents there was a Provi≈øo, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have ≈øufficient Hou≈øe-boot, and Hedge-boot, &c. And if, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Exception, the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have the Vnderwoods, was the que≈øtion: And it was argued, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have ≈øubbois, i. e. Vnderwoods, for that is granted by expre≈øs words, and the exception extends only gro≈ø≈øis arboribus, for this word (gro≈ø≈øis) in the exception extends to all that which follows: Gawdy Iu≈øtice, If it were in the ca≈øe of a common per≈øon, it is clear, that upon ≈øuch matter the Vnderwoods are not excepted, 7 E. 6. Dyer, 79. A Lea≈øe is made of a Mannor except Timber and great Woods, the Vnderwoods ≈øhall pa≈øs. Fenner Iu≈øtice, The Provi≈øo, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have Hou≈øe-boot, ≈øhews the Queens intent, that the Vnder-woods ≈øhould not pa≈øs. Wray, If this word (bois) in the exception ≈øhould not extend to Vnder-woods, it ≈øhould be vain and ≈øignifie nothing, which ≈øhould be hard in the Ca≈øe of the Queen.

div.head: CCCXXXV. Trin. 33. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared of Trover and of a Bag of mony, and the conver≈øion of it,Trover and Conver≈øion. 1 Cro. 97. 201, 555, 693. The Defendant pleaded, that the Bag of mony was delivered to him as a pawn to keep until A. and B. were agreed, which of them ≈øhould have it, and pleaded further, that A. and B. were not yet agreed, who of them ≈øhould have it, for which cau≈øe he kept it, ab≈øque hoc, that
he converted it to his own u≈øe, upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law; It was moved that the Conver≈øion is never traver≈øable. Wray, Generally Conver≈øion is not traver≈øable, but upon ≈øuch ≈øpecial matter as is here: Or if A. lend money to B. and B. delivereth a thing of the value to A. in pawn, now the Conver≈øion is traver≈øable; ≈øee the ≈øame ca≈øe, 4 E. 6. Br. Action upon the Ca≈øe, 113. ≈øo here. Fenner agreed with Wray.

div.head:
CCCXXXVI. The Bi≈øhop of Lincoln and Cowpers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 33. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Prohibition.THe Bi≈øhop of Lincoln ≈øued a Prohibition again≈øt Cowper, who had libelled again≈øt him in the Spiritual Court for Tithes out of the Manor of D. Tithes. 1 Cro. 216. Po≈øt. 331, 332. And the Bi≈øhop did ≈øugge≈øt, that he and all his Predece≈ø≈øors had been ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor, and that as long as it was in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, had been di≈øcharged of Tithes, and ≈øhewed, that in the time of E. 6. the ≈øaid Manor was conveyed to the Duke of Somer≈øet in Fee, and afterwards was re-granted to the Bi≈øhop and his Succe≈ø≈øors; It was moved, That the Pre≈øcription was not good, becau≈øe de non decimando; And admit that the Pre≈øcription be good, that ≈øame is interrupted by the ≈øei≈øin of the Duke of Somer≈øet; and although that the Manor be re-a≈ø≈øured to the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, yet the Pre≈øcription is not revived: as Homage Ance≈øtrel if it be once in a Forrain Sei≈øin, although it be re-a≈ø≈øured, yet it is not revived. But by Wray, Gawdy, and Fenner, The Pre≈øcription is good in the Ca≈øe of a Spiritual per≈øon, but not in the ca≈øe of a common per≈øon. And they all were clear of opinion, that the Pre≈øcription is not gon by this Interruption, for Tithes are not i≈ø≈øuing out of the Lands, neither can Vnity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion extingui≈øh them, neither are they extingui≈øhed, by a relea≈øe of all right of Land, &c. See for this Ca≈øe, Co. 11. part of his Reports in the Ca≈øe of Pridle and Napper.

div.head: CCCXXXVII. Dethick, King of Arms Ca≈øe. 33. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Indictment. 1 Cro. 224. Yelv. 34. Noy 250. Mi≈øno≈ømer in an Indictment. WIlliam Dethick, again≈øt Garter King of Arms, was indicted upon the Statute of 5 E. 6. for ≈øtriking in the Church-yard: For that the ≈øaid Dethick in Pauls Church-yard in London, ≈øtruck I.S. It was moved; If Cathedral Churches be within the meaning of the Statute: The Court was clear of opinion, that they were. And afterwards the Defendant pleaded, that before the Indictment found, he was created and crowned by the Letters Patents of the Queen which he ≈øhewed, chief and principal King of Arms, and it was granted by the ≈øaid Letters Patents, that he ≈øhould be called Garter, and that that name is not in the Indictment, and demanded Iudgment: The Kings Attorney by Replication ≈øaid, That by the Law of Arms and Heraldry, every one who is made King of Arms before he receives his Dignity ought to be led betwixt two Officers of Arms, by the Arms, before the Earl Mar≈øhal of England, or his Deputy, and before him are to go four Officers of Arms, whereof the one is to bear his Patent, another a Collar of E≈ø≈øes, the third a Coronet of Bra≈øs double guilt, fourthly a Cup of Wine, and his Patent ≈øhall be read before the Earl Mar≈øhal; and afterwards his Coronet ≈øhall be ≈øet upon his Head, and the Collar of E≈ø≈øes about his neck, and afterwards the Wine poured upon his Head: And that the Defendant had not received the≈øe Ceremonies, for which cau≈øe he is not King of Arms, nor to be
called upon, to which the Defendant did demur in Law. Broughton argued for the Defendant, and he took Exception to the Replication, becau≈øe it is pleaded there, that ≈øecundum legem Heraldorum, Garter upon his Creation ought to receive, &c. of which Law this Court cannot have Conu≈øance, and therefore the Replication ought to be, ≈øcil. Secundum legem Angliae: If in Appeal the Defendant wage Battel, although that belongs unto Arms and Heraldry, yet it ≈øhall be pleaded according to the Law of the Land, and ≈øhall not ≈øpeak of the Law of Arms. So if an Infant be made a Knight, and he be to plead in di≈øcharge of his Ward≈øhip, he ≈øhall plead according to the Law of the Land, and yet the degree of a Knight belongs to the Law of Arms, 11 E. 3. Dower again≈øt the Earl of Richmond, who was al≈øo Duke of Britain, who pleaded to the Writ, That he was Duke of Britain, and not ≈øo named in the Writ; but the Court did not regard it, for they cannot have knowledge of it, ≈øo not here of the Law of Heraldry: Al≈øo this Court cannot write to the Heralds to certifie it, as they may to the Mar≈øhal of the King, or to the Bi≈øhop: But we have ≈øufficiently ≈øhewed our matter, ≈øcil. That we have Letters Patents of the Queen, and that we were ≈øworn in the ≈øaid Office, and ≈øo we are King of Heralds by matter of Record, again≈øt which is pleaded only matter in defect of ceremony and circum≈øtance, which is not material. An Earl is created with the ceremonies of putting a Sword broad-wi≈øe about his Body, and a Cap with a Coronet upon his Head. Yet the King may create an Earl without ≈øuch ceremonies: And may al≈øo create an Earl by word, if the ≈øame be after Recorded; when a Knight is made, Spurs ought to be put upon his Heels, yet without ≈øuch ceremony ≈øuch degree may be conferred to and upon another, for ≈øuch ceremonies are or may be u≈øed, or not u≈øed at the Kings plea≈øure. Afterwards it was objected, that the ≈øame is but a name of Office, but not a name of Dignity. To which it was an≈øwered, that this word Coronamus always imports Dignity, and this is a Dignity and Office, as Earl, Marque≈øs, &c. Fenner Iu≈øtice, The Patent is, Nomen tibi imponimus, and therefore (Garter) is parcel of his Name: And therefore he ought to be Indicted by ≈øuch Name. And it ≈øhould be hard, to tye E≈øtate and Degrees to ceremonies. Gawdy was of opinion, That this is but a name of Office, and therefore the Indictment good, as 1 Mar. Writ of Summons of Parliament i≈ø≈øueth without the≈øe words (Supream Head) and the Writ was holden good, for it is not parcel of the Name, but addition only: So here, Fenner and Wray contrary, for the words are Creamus, Coronamus, Nomen imponimus, Ergo, part of his Name, which Clench al≈øo granted, and afterwards Dethick was di≈øcharged.

div.head:
CCCXXXVIII. Strait and Braggs Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 32 Eliz. Rot. 318. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs,2 Len. 1 ‚Ä¢ 9 for breaking his Clo≈øe in H. the Defendant pleaded, that long before the Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Dean and Chapter of Pauls were ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of C. in the ≈øaid County of H. in Fee, in the Right of their Church, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed King Edward the Fourth by his Letters Patents, Dat. An. 1. of his Reign, granted to them all Fines pro licentia Concordandi, of all their Homagers and Tenants, Re≈øiants, and Non-re≈øiants within their Fee, and ≈øhewed, that 29 Eliz. A Fine was levied in the Common Pleas, betwixt the Plaintiff and one A. of eleven Acres of Lands, whereof the place where is parcel, and the Po≈øt-Fine was a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed to 15 s. and afterwards Scambler the Forain Oppo≈øer did allow to them the ≈øaid 15 s. becau≈øe the ≈øaid Land was within their Fee: And afterwards, in behalf of the ≈øaid Dean and Chapter, he demanded of the Plaintiff the ≈øaid fifteen ≈øhillings,
who refu≈øed to pay it, wherefore he in the Right of the ≈øaid Dean, &c. And by their commandment took the Di≈øtre≈øs as Baily, &c. for the ≈øaid 15 s. and afterwards ≈øold it, upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. It was moved, that it is not averred that the Land whereof the Fine was levied was within their Fee; but they ≈øay that Scambler allowed it to be within their Fee, and the ≈øame is not a ≈øufficient Averment; which the Court granted. And it was the opinion of the Court, that the Dean and Chapter cannot di≈øtrain for this matter, but they ought to ≈øue for it in the Exchequer, as it appeareth 9 H. 6. 27. In the Dutche≈øs of Somer≈øets Ca≈øe. Gawdy, This Grant doth not extend to the Po≈øt Fine, for Fine pro licentia Concordandi, is the Queens Silver, and not the Po≈øt Fine. Wray, All ≈øhall pa≈øs by it, for it is about one and the ≈øame matter, and they were of opinion to give Iudgment for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCXXXIX. Sherewood and Nonnes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. Rot. 451. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Covenant.IN an Action of Covenant, the Plaintiff declared, that Charles Grice and He≈øter his Wife were ≈øei≈øed of certain Tenements calle Withons, with divers Lands to the ≈øame appertaining, and of another parcel of Land called Dole, containing eight Acres, to them and the heirs of the body of the ≈øaid Charks on the body of the ≈øaid He≈øter his wife lawfully begotten, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, 15 Eliz. lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Defendant by Indenture for years, by which Indenture the Le≈ø≈øor covenanted, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have ≈øufficient Hou≈øe-boot, Fencing-wood, and Hoop-wood upon the Lands during the Term; and that further the Le≈ø≈øee covenanted for him, his Executors and A≈ø≈øigns, with the Le≈ø≈øor, &c. That it ≈øhould be lawful for them to enter upon the Lands during the ≈øaid Term, and to have egre≈øs and regre≈øs there, and to cut down and di≈øpo≈øe of all the Wood and Timber there growing, leaving ≈øufficient Hou≈øe-boot, Fencing-wood and Hoop-wood to the Le≈ø≈øee, upon the Lands called the Dole, for his expences at Withons; and further, that he would not take any Wood or Timber upon the Premi≈ø≈øes, without the a≈ø≈øent or a≈ø≈øigment of the Le≈ø≈øor or his A≈ø≈øigns, otherwi≈øe than according to the Indenture and true meaning thereof. And further declared, That the ≈øaid Charles and his Wife ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, levied a Fine of part of the Land to R. S. and his heirs, to whom the Defendant attorned, and that the ≈øaid R.S. afterwards devi≈øed the ≈øame to I. his Wife, the now Plaintiff for years, the Remainder over to another, and died, and that the Defendant had felled and carried out of the Lands called Withons, twenty loads of Wood without the a≈ø≈øent and a≈ø≈øignment of the Le≈ø≈øor or his A≈ø≈øigns, for which the Plaintiff as A≈ø≈øignee brought the Action. The Defendant pleaded, That after the Lea≈øe John Grice and others by a≈ø≈øignment of He≈øter had cut down and carried away fifty loads of Wood in the ≈øaid Lands called the Dole, and ≈øo they had not left ≈øufficient Woods for his expences at Withons according to the Indenture, for which cau≈øe he took the ≈øaid twenty loads of Wood upon Withons for his expences, upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. Godfrey, The Plea is not good; This Plea is no more, but that ≈øufficient Wood was not left upon the Dole for his expences, and although there be not, yet the Defendant cannot cut Wood el≈øewhere, for he hath re≈øtrained him≈øelf by the Covenant. Al≈øo the Covenant of the Le≈ø≈øor is, That the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall have ≈øufficient Wood upon the Dole for his expences at Withons, but in his ≈øatisfaction he doth not alledge, that he had need of Wood for to ≈øpend at Withons, nor doth aver that he hath ≈øpent it there, for otherwi≈øe he hath not cau≈øe to take, &c. And the meaning was, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould have ≈øufficient Wood when he had need of it. Hobart for the Defendant, He would not ≈øpeak to the Plea in
Bar; but he conceived that the Declaration was not good, for here no breach of Covenant is a≈ø≈øigned, for the Covenant is in the Di≈øjunctive, ≈øcil. That the Defendant ≈øhould not take Wood without the a≈ø≈øent or a≈ø≈øignment of the Le≈ø≈øor or his A≈ø≈øigns: And the Plaintiff chargeth the Defendant with cutting of Wood without the a≈ø≈øent and a≈ø≈øignment of the Le≈ø≈øor, ≈øo he would compel us to prove more than we ought, for if he did it with their a≈ø≈øent only, or by their a≈ø≈øignment only, it is ≈øufficient; but if the Covenant had been in the copulative, both was nece≈ø≈øary: And for the nature of Copulatives he cited the Ca≈øe, where two Churchwardens bring an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Defendant pleads, That the Plaintiffs are not Churchwardens, upon which they are at I≈ø≈øue. The Iury find, That the one was Churchwarden, and the other not, and for that the Plaintiffs could not have Iudgment, for if the one of them be not Churchwarden, then the Plaintiffs are not Churchwardens, for the copulatives ought not to be disjoyned: And he cited the ca≈øe lately ruled in the Common Pleas betwixt Ognel and Underwood concerning Crucifield Grange, A. lea≈øed unto B. certain Lands for forty years, B. lea≈øed part of the ≈øame to C. for ten years. A. grants a Rent-charge out of the Lands in tenura & occupatione B. It was re≈øolved, That the Lands lea≈øed to C. ≈øhould not be charged with that Rent, for although it was in tenura B. yet it was not in his occupation, and both are exqui≈øite becau≈øe in the copulative: So here, the Le≈ø≈øee may cut Wood with the a≈ø≈øent of the Le≈ø≈øor without any a≈ø≈øignment. Al≈øo here, the ≈øub≈øtance of the covenant cannot charge the Defendant, for although it be in the Negative, yet it is not ab≈øolute in the Negative, but doth refer unto the covenant precedent; for the words are, That the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall not cut Woods, aliter quam, according to the intent of the Indenture, where the covenant precedent is not, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall not cut Woods but in the Dole, but that the Le≈ø≈øor might cut down any Trees in the Dole leaving ≈øufficient for the Le≈ø≈øee, which covenant in it ≈øelf doth not re≈øtrain the Le≈ø≈øee to cut down any Trees in any part of the Lands demi≈øed, nor abridgeth the power which the Law giveth to him by rea≈øon of the demi≈øe. Then when this la≈øt covenant comes, i. e. That the Le≈ø≈øee will not cut, aliter, then according to the meaning of the Indenture without the a≈ø≈øent, &c. the ≈øame doth not re≈øtrain him from the power which the meaning of the Indenture gives, and ≈øo no breach of covenant can be a≈ø≈øigned in this. For by virtue of the Lea≈øe, the Le≈ø≈øee of common Right may take nece≈ø≈øary Fuel upon any part of the Land lea≈øed: Al≈øo this fir≈øt covenant being in the Affirmative doth not abridge any Intere≈øt, as 28 H. 8. 19. The Le≈ø≈øor covenants, That the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhall have ≈øufficient Hedge-boot by a≈ø≈øignment of the Baily. It is holden by Baldwin and Shelley, That the Le≈ø≈øee may take it without a≈ø≈øignment, becau≈øe there are no Negative words, & non aliter. So 8 E. 3. 10. A Rent of ten pounds was granted to Husband and Wife, and if the Husband overlive his Wife that he ≈øhall have three pounds Rent, and if the Wife do overlive the Husband, ≈øhe ≈øhall have forty ≈øhillings, there it was holden that the Rent of ten pounds continued, not re≈øtrained by the ≈øeverance of any of them. And although peradventure it appeareth here, that the meaning of the parties was, That the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould not cut down any Wood but in the Dole, yet fora≈ømuch as ≈øuch meaning doth not ≈øtand with the Law, it ≈øhall be rejected, as it was holden to be in the ca≈øe betwixt Benet and French, where a man ≈øei≈øed of divers Lands, devi≈øed parcel of it called Gages, to the erecting of a School, and another parcel unto B. in fee, and all his other Lands unto one French in Fee, The devi≈øe of Gages was holden void, becau≈øe too general, for no per≈øon is named; and it was further holden, that it pa≈ø≈øed by the general devi≈øe to French, and yet that was not the meaning of the Devi≈øor: Al≈øo the Plaintiff is not A≈ø≈øignee but of parcel of the Rever≈øion, for if
the Rever≈øion is granted to him for years,Owen Rep. 152. 1 Co. 215. and ≈øuch A≈ø≈øignee cannot have an Action of Covenant, for a Covenant is a thing in Action, and annexed to the Rever≈øion, ≈øo that if the Rever≈øion doth not continue in its fir≈øt cour≈øe as it was at the time of the creation of the Covenant, but be altered or divided, the Covenant is de≈øtroyed, and therefore it was holden, 32 H. 8. betwixt Wi≈øeman and Warringer, where a Lea≈øe for years was made of one hundred Acres of Lands, rendring ten pound Rent, and afterwards the Le≈ø≈øor granted fifty Acres of it, that the Grantee ≈øhould not have any part of the Rent, but all the Rent was de≈øtroyed. So in our ca≈øe here, the Grantee hath but parcel of the e≈øtate, a Term for years, and ≈øo is not an A≈ø≈øignee intended, as the ca≈øe betwixt Randal and Brown in the Court of Wards:
‚Ä¢ Co 96 ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Randal being ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands, covenanted with B. that if he pay unto him, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, five hundred pounds, that then he and his Heirs would ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid B. and his Heirs. Randal devi≈øed the Land to his Wife during the minority of his Son, the Remainder to his Son in Fee, and died, having made his Wife his Executrix. Brown at the day and place tendred the money generally, the Wife having but an e≈øtate for years in the Land took the money. It was holden, that the ≈øame was not a ≈øufficient tender, for the Wife is not A≈ø≈øignee, for ≈øhe hath an Intere≈øt but for years, and here the Son is to bear the lo≈øs, for by a lawful Tender the Inheritance ≈øhall be deve≈øted out of him, and therefore the Tender ought to be made to him and not to his Wife. Al≈øo as the ca≈øe is here, he is no A≈ø≈øignee, for although Charles Grice and his Wife hath the Rever≈øion, to them and the Heirs of the body of Charles, and levy a Fine without Proclamations, nothing pa≈ø≈øeth but his own e≈øtate, and then the Conu≈øee hath not any e≈øtate,Raph. Rep. 91. ‚Ä¢ C ‚Ä¢ o. 804. ‚Ä¢ 05. but during the life of Charles, and then when a man is ≈øei≈øed to him and his Heirs during the life of another, he hath not ≈øuch an e≈øtate as he can devi≈øe by the Statute, and then when he devi≈øeth it to his Wife for years, it is void, &c. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCXL. Smith and Hitchcocks Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øump≈øit. ‚Ä¢ C ‚Ä¢ o. 201.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared, that whereas the Defendant was indebted to him, 19 Maii 30 Eliz. The Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff would forbear to ≈øue him until ≈øuch a day after, promi≈øed at the ≈øaid day to pay the debt. The Defendant pleaded, how that 29 Maii 29 Eliz. he was indebted unto the Plaintiff in the ≈øaid ≈øum, for a≈ø≈øurance of which afterwards he acknowledged a Statute to the Plaintiff, upon which he had Execution, and had levied the money, ab≈øque hoc, that he was indebted to the Plaintiff, antea, vel po≈øt, the ≈øaid day, aliquo modo, upon which the Plaintiff did demur. It was argued that the Traver≈øe was not good, for the con≈øideration in A≈ø≈øump≈øit is not traver≈øable, becau≈øe it is but conveyance, and amounts to the general I≈ø≈øue, as in debt upon the ≈øale of a Hor≈øe, it is no Plea for the Defendant to ≈øay, that no ≈øuch Hor≈øe was ≈øold to him. Patridge, If the conveyance be the ground of the Suit it is traver≈øable; an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt an Ho≈øtler, it is a good Plea that he is not an Ho≈øtler, 2 H. 4 7. See 26 H. 8. Br. Traver≈øe 341. In an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared, that whereas the Defendant, habuit ex deliberatione of the Plaintiff certain goods, the ≈øaid Defendant in con≈øideration of ten ≈øhillings, A≈ø≈øump≈øit & eidem querenti promi≈øit ≈øalvo Cu≈øtodire, &c. Non habuit ex deliberatione, is a good Plea. Godfrey, The Defendant doth not an≈øwer the point of our Action, which is the A≈ø≈øump≈øit, but only by way of Argument, 11 E. 4. 4. In Tre≈øpa≈øs upon the Statute of 5 R. 2. by the Ma≈øter of a Colledge and his confreers,
the Defendant doth ju≈øtifie by rea≈øon of a Lea≈øe made by a Predece≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff, and his Confreers, by their Deed under their Common Seal, the Plaintiff, Replicando ≈øaith, That at the time of the making of the Lea≈øe there was no ≈øuch Colledge, and it was holden no Plea, for it is no an≈øwer but by Argument. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, In all ca≈øes where the Defendant may wage his Law, there the conveyance is traver≈øable. Wray, The cau≈øe of the Action is the A≈ø≈øump≈øit, therefore the con≈øideration is not traver≈øable, for it is not the point with which the Plaintiff is charged: And it is common here, that the Declaration in ≈øuch Action upon the Ca≈øe,Traver≈øe. in con≈øideration of divers ≈øums of money, without any more certainty is good, which ≈øhould not be good if the con≈øideration were traver≈øable, but the con≈øideration is to be given in Evidence; and it is al≈øo common, that in an Action upon the Ca≈øe in Trover and Conver≈øion, the Trover is not traver≈øable, for the Conver≈øion is the point of the Action. Fenner Iu≈øtice, The debt here is no cau≈øe of the Action, but only the A≈ø≈øump≈øit. In debt upon Arbitrament, the Arbitrament is traver≈øable: So in debt for Rent upon a Demi≈øe, the Demi≈øe is traver≈øable,Antea 189. for the Arbitrament and Demi≈øe is the cau≈øe and ground of the Action. At another day it was moved again, and Gawdy, mutata opinione ≈øaid, that con≈øideration Executory is traver≈øable; As where one in con≈øideration that he may marry my Daughter, or of ≈øervice promi≈øeth to pay, the ≈øame con≈øideration is traver≈øable, contrary of a Con≈øideration executed. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCXLI. E≈øtons Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33 Eliz. In the Court of Wards.
div.p: ESton was ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Fee holden of the King in chief,1 Cro. 243. and took a Wife ≈øei≈øed of other Lands holden in Socage, they have Inne, and the Husband dieth; and afterwards the Wife dieth. Owen Serjeant conceived, That the Queen ≈øhould not have the Ward≈øhip of the Land of the Wife, or the primer ≈øei≈øin of it: And if the Husband had ≈øurvived his Wife being Tenant by the Curte≈øie, the Queen ≈øhould not have Primer ≈øei≈øin of it after his decea≈øe. Wray, If the Father be ≈øei≈øed of Lands holden in Soccage, and the Mother of Lands holded in Knights ≈øervice, and the Husband over-lives his Wife being Tenant by the Curte≈øie the King ≈øhall have all. Ander≈øon denied that, and he conceived, That the opinion of Stamford is not Law; and yet ≈øee 13 H. 4. 278. Where the Father is ≈øei≈øed of Lands in chief, and the Mother of other; and the Father dieth, and afterwards the Mother dieth, both ≈øhall be in ward. And it was ≈øaid, That if there be Grandfather, Father, and Son, and the Father dieth ≈øei≈øed of Lands holden in Socage; and afterwards the Grandfather dieth ≈øei≈øed of Lands in Knights ≈øervice, the Lands in Socage ≈øhall not be in ward. Ander≈øon held ≈øtrongly, That the Queen ≈øhould have Primer ≈øei≈øin of the Lands of the Mother. Wray contrary. Quaere.

div.head:
CCCXLII. Ellis Hartops Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33 Eliz. In the Court of Wards.
div.p:
ELlis Hartop was ≈øei≈øed of divers Lands, whereof part was holden of the King in Knights ≈øervice, and devi≈øed two parts thereof to W. Denham and his Heirs, to the u≈øe of T. his brother, and his wife, and afterwards to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid T. and his Heirs males. T. died in the life
of the Devi≈øor, and afterwards a Son is born; Fir≈øt it was agreed that a Devi≈øe might be to the u≈øe of another; Then, when Ce≈øty que u≈øe dyeth in the life of the Devi≈øor, the Devi≈øee ≈øhall take it, and when a Son is born, it ≈øhall go to him: But if the u≈øe be void, then the Devi≈øee ≈øhall have it to his own u≈øe, for every devi≈øe doth imply a con≈øideration: Coke was of opinion, That the Son takes by de≈øcent, when Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, to whom Land is devi≈øed, doth refu≈øe the u≈øe, the Devi≈øee cannot take it, for he ≈øhall not have it to his own u≈øe, for if the u≈øe be void, the devi≈øe is al≈øo void: And the u≈øe is void, for Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe died in the life of the Devi≈øor, which ≈øee Bret and Rygdens ca≈øe. A man ≈øei≈øed of three Acres, bargains and ≈øells one of them, without ≈øhewing which, and that before the Statute of 27 H. 8. The Bargainee dyeth before Election, no Election de≈øcends to the Heir, for then he ≈øhould be a Purcha≈øor: And by Wray, and Ander≈øon, The devi≈øe is void, and it is all one with Brett and Rigdens ca≈øe. And by Ander≈øon, a man devi≈øeth Lands to the u≈øe of one, which u≈øe by po≈ø≈øibility is good, and by po≈ø≈øibility not good; If afterwards Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe cannot take, the Devi≈øe ≈øhall be to the u≈øe of the Devi≈øor and his Heirs.

div.head:
CCCLXIII. We≈øton and Garmons Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øize. 1 Cro. 226.AS≈øize was brought of a Rent of fifty pounds per annum, and the Plaintiff made his plaint to be di≈ø≈øei≈øed of his Free-hold in H. E. and H.W: And ≈øhewed, that John Vaughan and Amy his Wife, who before was the wife of one We≈øton, and Mother of Sir Henry We≈øton, the Plaintiff in the A≈ø≈øize was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manors of H.W. and H.E. lying in Barton and Kinton in Fee. And 18 Eliz. a Fine was levied betwixt Robert Vaughan, and Miles Whitney Complainants, and the ≈øaid John Vaughan and Amy his Wife, and Francis their Son Deforceants of the ≈øaid two Manors, inter alia per nomen of the Manors of H.E. and H.W. and of fifty Me≈ø≈øuages, three hundred Acres of Lands, two hundred Acres of Meadow, cum pertinentiis, in the ≈øaid Towns, by which Fine the ≈øaid Deforceants, did acknowledge the right of the ≈øaid Manors and Tenements, to be the Right of the Complainants, come ceo, &c. with warranty, of the ≈øaid Husband and Wife, for which the Complainants did render a Rent of fifty pounds, per annum, with clau≈øe of di≈øtre≈øs, in dictis Manerijs, to the ≈øaid, John & Amy, & the Heirs of Amy, and al≈øo rendred the Tenements afore≈øaid, with the Appurtenances to the ≈øaid John and Amy for their lives, the Remainder to the ≈øaid Francis their Son in tail, the Remainder to the ≈øaid Amy and her Heirs; and that John and Amy dyed, by force whereof the ≈øaid Rent de≈øcendeth to the ≈øaid Plaintiff, as Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Amy, and that the ≈øaid Francis entred into the ≈øaid Mannors as in his Remainder, and was ≈øei≈øed in tail, and was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Rent by the Hands of the ≈øaid Francis, and afterwards thereof did enfeoff the ≈øaid Garmons the Defendant, &c. The Tenant pleaded, That the Plaintiff was never ≈øei≈øed ≈øo as he could be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and if, &c. Nul tor. nul di≈ø≈øei≈øin, which was found for the Plaintiff who had Iudgment and Execution, upon which the Tenant brought a Writ of Error: Stephens a≈ø≈øigned Error, Fir≈øt, the Fine is levyed of two Manors, inter alia, ≈øo as no other Lands pa≈ø≈øed by the Fine be≈øides the Manors, and ≈øo the Rent is granted out of the ≈øaid Lands and Manors, and no other Lands which pa≈ø≈øed by the Fine, and then upon the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing it appears, that all the Tenants of the Lands charged with the Rent in demand, are not named in the A≈ø≈øize: Second Error: This Rent is granted only out of the E≈øtate tail, for Amy hath Fee in both, as well the Rent as the Land, and then when the
E≈øtate tail is determined, the Rent is al≈øo determined, and he hath not averred the life of the Tenant in tail, or any of his I≈ø≈øue, wherefore it ≈øhall be intended that he is dead without i≈ø≈øue, and then the Rent is gone, and then he hath not any cau≈øe to have A≈ø≈øi≈øe: Bourchier, As to the fir≈øt conceived and argued that it is not Error, for although the≈øe words (inter alia, &c.) yet it ≈øhall not be intended that the Conu≈øor had any other Lands, or that the Rent is i≈ø≈øuing out of other Lands than tho≈øe two Manors which are expre≈ø≈øed, & not inter alia: As to the ≈øecond, the continuance of the tail needs not to be averred, for the Tenant in tail hath enfeoffed the Tenant of the Land, by which the e≈øtate tail is di≈øcontinued; And although the Tenant in tail be dead without i≈ø≈øue, yet the Rent doth remain until Recovery of the Land by Formedon in the Remainder. Fenner Iu≈øtice was of opinion,Vaugh. Re ‚Ä¢ 175. That the Per nomen ≈øhould go unto the Mannors only, and ≈øhould not extend to the inter alia: For if a man in pleading ≈øaith, that J.S. was ≈øei≈øed of twenty acres of Land, and thereof (inter alia) did enfeoff him per nomen of Green-wead, the ≈øame ≈øhall not have reference to the inter alia, but only to the twenty acres: And the averment of the continuance of the Tail needs not, for the E≈øtate-tail is di≈øcontinued. Gawdy Iu≈øtice was of opinion, That the per nomen ≈øhould go as well to the inter alia, as to the two Manors, and then all the Ter-tenants are not named in the A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and the ≈øame not to be pleaded, for it appears of the Plaintiffs own ≈øhewing, and there needs no averment of the continuance of the Tail for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid. Clench Iu≈øtice, The per nomen doth refer to all, which ≈øee by the Fine, which ≈øhews that other Lands pa≈ø≈øed by the Fine, than the ≈øaid two Manors. And as to the ≈øecond point he ≈øaid, There needed no averment. Gawdy, As to the fir≈øt Error, the ≈øame cannot be ≈øaved by any way, but to ≈øay, That the Conu≈øor was not ≈øei≈øed of any other Lands than the ≈øaid two Manors, and then the Fine doth not extend unto it, and then no Rent is granted out of it. Fenner, In the Common Pleas, in the great ca≈øe of Fines, it was holden, that in pleading of a Fine, it needs not to ≈øay, That the Conu≈øor was ≈øei≈øed, for if the Conu≈øor or Conu≈øee were ≈øei≈øed, it is ≈øufficient: for ≈øuch pleading is contrary in it ≈øelf; for a Fine, ≈øur conu≈øance de droit come ceo, &c. doth ≈øuppo≈øe a precedent Gift: It was al≈øo objected, That here is a confu≈øion in this Fine, for the Rent is rendred to the Husband and Wife, and to the Heirs of the Wife, and the Land is rendred to the Husband and Wife for their lives, the Remainder to Francis in Tail, the remainder to the Wife and her Heirs: And the≈øe matters cannot ≈øtand together in a Fine, but the one will confound the other: But as to that, it was ≈øaid, that the Law ≈øhall Mar≈øhall the≈øe two renders, ≈øo as they both ≈øhall ≈øtand; And it is not like unto a Rent-≈øervice, for a Rent-≈øervice i≈ø≈øueth out of the whole E≈øtate: And therefore if a Remainder upon an E≈øtate for life E≈øchears, the Seigniory is gone even during the life of the Tenant for life; which ≈øee, 3 H. 6. 1. contrary of a Rent-charge: For if the Grantee of a Rent in Fee purcha≈øeth the remainder of the Land out of which it is depending out of an E≈øtate for life, he ≈øhall have the Rent during the life of the Tenant for life. And of that opinion were all the three Iu≈øtices, for the Conu≈øors took by ≈øeveral Acts, and the E≈øtate is charged, for it cometh under the Grant. Fenner Iu≈øtice, There is a difference betwixt a Rent ≈øervice and a Rent-charge, or Common, for that ≈øhall charge only the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but a Rent-charge ≈øhall charge the whole E≈øtate: And therefore if he who hath a Rent-≈øervice relea≈øeth to him in the Remainder upon an E≈øtate-tail, or for life, the Rent is extinct; which Gawdy denied: And this Ca≈øe was put, The Di≈ø≈øei≈øee doth relea≈øe to the Le≈ø≈øee for years of his Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, nihil operatur: But if the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor and Di≈ø≈øei≈øee joyn in a Relea≈øe to ≈øuch Le≈ø≈øee, the ≈øame is good, for fir≈øt it ≈øhall enure as the Relea≈øe of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, and then of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee, &c.

div.head:
CCCXLIV. Tedca≈øtle and Hallywels Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Debt. 2 Roll. 594. 1 Cro. 234, 235.IN Debt upon a Bond, the Defendant pleaded, That the Condition was, That whereas John Hallywel had put him≈øelf to be an Apprentice to the Plaintiff, if the Defendant John Hallywel during his Apprentice≈øhip, or any other for him, by his con≈øent or agreement take, or riotou≈øly ≈øpend any of the Goods of his ≈øaid Ma≈øter the Plaintiff: If then the Defendant within one month after notice thereof given to him, do pay and ≈øatisfie the Plaintiff for all ≈øuch ≈øums of Monies, Wares, &c. ≈øo taken or riotou≈øly ≈øpent by the Defendant, or by any other by his procurement or con≈øent, the ≈øame being ≈øufficiently proved; that then, &c. The Defendant by prote≈øtation; Quod nec ip≈øe, nor any other by his procurement or con≈øent had taken, or riotou≈øly ≈øpent the Goods of the Plaintiff: for Plea ≈øaith, That the Plaintiff before the Writ brought had not ≈øufficiently proved, that the ≈øaid John Hallywel took, or riotou≈øly ≈øpent any of the Plaintiffs Goods: Vpon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. It was argued by Daniel, That the proof is ≈øufficient and good for the time, if it be tried in the Action upon this Obligation: and the proof intended is proof by twelve men, for it is not ≈øet down before what per≈øon it ≈øhall be proved, nor any manner of proof appointed, and therefore it ≈øhall be tried according the Law of the Land: which ≈øee 10 E. 4. 11. 7 R. 2. Bar. 241. Godfrey contrary, This ca≈øe is not like to the ca≈øes before, for here is a further matter. Fir≈øt warning, and a month after Notice pay, &c. And if the proof ≈øhall be made in this Action, the Defendant ≈øhall lo≈øe the benefit of the Condition, which gives time to pay it within a month after, for in all ≈øuch ca≈øes the precedent Act of the Obligee is traver≈øable, as 10 H. 7. 13. I am bound by Obligation to enfeoff ≈øuch a per≈øon of ≈øuch Lands as the Obligee ≈øhall appoint. In an Action brought again≈øt me, I ≈øhall ≈øay-that the Plaintiff hath not appointed, &c. And here ought to be Notice fir≈øt, and proof ought to precede the Notice by the meaning of the Condition, and ≈øo this differs from the other ca≈øes put, for here proof is not the ≈øub≈øtance of the whole: Owen Serjeant, It is the folly of the Defendant to put him≈øelf to ≈øuch an inconvenience, for now he ought to pay the mony without delay of any month: And here the Defendant ought to plead, That he hath not imbezelled any goods of the Plaintiff, and the Plaintiff Replicando ≈øhall ≈øay, and ≈øhew the Special matter that he hath given Notice to him thereof. See 15 E. 4. 25.

div.head: CCCXLV. Manning and Andrews Ca≈øe. 18 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Devi≈øe. 4 Len. 2.IN Ejectione firmae, the Iury found by ≈øpecial Verdict: That Richard Hart, and Katharine his Wife, and divers other per≈øons, 1 H. 8. were ≈øei≈øed of the Lands in que≈øtion, to the u≈øe of Richard and his Heirs, ad per implend. ultimam volunt. dict. Rich. who the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt, 8 H. 8. by his Will in writing devi≈øed, That his Feoffees ≈øhould be from thenceforth ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of his ≈øaid Wife for her life, and after to the u≈øe of W. H. his Son for his life, without impeachment of Wa≈øt, and after the death of the ≈øaid Katharine his Wife, William his Son, and Joan Wife of the ≈øaid William, his Feoffees ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of the next Heir of the Body of the ≈øaid William and Joan lawfully begotten, for the term of the life of the ≈øame Heir,
and after the decea≈øe of the ≈øame Heir, to the u≈øe of the next heir, of the ≈øame heir lawfully begotten, and for default of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, to the u≈øe of the heirs of the body of the ≈øaid William and Joan lawfully begotten, for the term of life or lives of every ≈øuch heir, or heirs,More Rep. 368. and for default of ≈øuch heirs to the u≈øe of the heirs of the body of the ≈øaid William, and for default, &c. to the right heirs of William. And further he willed, That if any of the ≈øaid heirs ≈øhall ≈øet, alien, ≈øay to mortgage, the right, title and intere≈øt which they or any of them ≈øhall have in or out of the ≈øame Lands, or by their con≈øent or a≈ø≈øent ≈øuffer any Recovery to be had again≈øt them, &c. or do any other Act, whereby they or their heirs, or any of them may or ought to be di≈øinherited; that then the u≈øe limited to ≈øuch heir ≈øo doing ≈øhall be void and of no effect during his life: And that his ≈øaid Feoffees ≈øhall be thenceforth ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of the heir apparent of ≈øuch Offender, as though he were dead. Richard Hart died, William had i≈ø≈øue by the ≈øaid Joan his wife a Son named Thomas, and died, and afterwards 31 H. 8. Joan died, Katharine died, Thomas entred, and had i≈ø≈øue Francis and Percival. Thomas by Deed indented, 1 Augu≈øt 4 Eliz. bargained and ≈øold to Andrews, and levied a Fine to him with warranty: And afterwards 6 Eliz. Francis levied a Fine to the ≈øaid Andrews, Sur conu≈øans de droit come ceo: And further by the ≈øaid Fine relea≈øed to him with warranty, at the time of which Fine levied Percival was heir apparent to the ≈øaid Francis, Francis after had i≈ø≈øue I. and F. who are now living. The heir of the Survivor of the Feoffees within five years after the age of Percival, and ≈øeven years after the Fine levied, enter to revive the u≈øe limited to Percival, who entred, and lea≈øed to the Plaintiff. This ca≈øe was argued by the Iu≈øtices of the Kings Bench, &c. Fir≈øt, It was agreed by the whole Court, That Richard Hart being ≈øei≈øed with ≈øeven others, unto the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his heirs, might well devi≈øe all the u≈øe,U≈øe ≈øu≈øpended. yet the Land devi≈øed. although his u≈øe was in part ≈øu≈øpended, becau≈øe he was joyntly ≈øei≈øed with ≈øeven others to his own u≈øe, and ≈øo the u≈øe for the eighth part ≈øu≈øpended, for when this Devi≈øe is to take effect, i. e. at the time of his death, all the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land by the Survivor pa≈ø≈øeth from the u≈øe, and then the u≈øe being withdrawn from the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall well pa≈øs. And by Wray, A u≈øe ≈øu≈øpended may be devi≈øed: As if Feoffees to u≈øe before the Statute of 27 H. 8. be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, by which di≈ø≈øei≈øin the u≈øe is ≈øu≈øpended, and afterwards during the di≈ø≈øei≈øin, Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, by his Will devi≈øeth, That his Feoffees ≈øhall re-enter, and then make an e≈øtate to I. S. in Fee, the ≈øame is a good devi≈øe, for by that di≈ø≈øei≈øin the tru≈øt and confidence repo≈øed by Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe in the Feoffees, is not ≈øu≈øpended: Secondly, It was holden that here a u≈øe implied was limited to Joan the wife of William, although there be not any expre≈øs devi≈øe of it, according to the Book of 13 H. 7. 17. Thirdly, when a u≈øe is limited to the Heir of the body of William and Joan lawfully begotten for life, and afterwards to the Heir of the body of the ≈øame heir for life, &c. Geofry Iu≈øtice was of opinion, That here is in effect an e≈øtate tail, for the e≈øtates limited are directed to go in cour≈øe of an e≈øtate tail; for he wills, That every heir of the body of his Son ≈øhall have the Land, and the ≈øpecial words ≈øhall not make another e≈øtate to pa≈øs, but that which the Law wills: As if Lands be given to one for life, the Remainder after his death to the Heirs of his body lawfully begotten, notwith≈øtanding that the words of the limitation imply two ≈øeveral e≈øtates, yet becau≈øe the Law ≈øo wills, it is but one e≈øtate. Gawdy Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That every i≈ø≈øue begotten betwixt William and Joan ≈øhould have an e≈øtate for life ≈øucce≈ø≈øive, and a Remainder in tail expectant as right heir of the body of William, A Contingent ≈øhall hinder the execution of an e≈øtate in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. and this e≈øtate tail ≈øhall not be executed in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by rea≈øon of the me≈øne Remainder for life limited to the heir of the body of William and Joan, and although that the≈øe me≈øne Remainders are but upon a contingent, and not in e≈ø≈øe, yet ≈øuch regard ≈øhall be had to them, that
they ≈øhall hinder the execution of the e≈øtates for life, and in tail in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: As if an e≈øtate be made to A. for life, the Remainder to the right heirs of B. in tail, the Remainder in Fee to A. although the e≈øtate tail be in abeyance, and not in e≈ø≈øe during the life of B. yet in re≈øpect thereof the Free-hold and Fee ≈øhall not be conjoyned. Southcote Iu≈øtice, To the ≈øame purpo≈øe: And he put a ca≈øe lately adjudged betwixt Vaughan and Alcock: Vaughan and Alcocks ca≈øe. Land was devi≈øed to two men, and if any of them dieth, his heirs ≈øhall inherit, the≈øe devi≈øees are Tenants in common, becau≈øe in by devi≈øe, but contrary if it were by way of Grant: Lands are devi≈øed to A. and B. to be betwixt them divided, they are Tenants in common. Wray, William and Thomas have but for life, for they are purcha≈øors by the name (heir) in the ≈øingular number, but when he goes further, and ≈øays, for want of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue to the heirs of the body of William, in the plural number, now Will. hath an Inheritance: And if a devi≈øe be made to one for life, and then to his heir for life, and ≈øo from heir to heir in perpetuum for life, here are two e≈øtates for life, and the other Devi≈øees have Fee, for e≈øtates for life cannot be limited by general words from heir to heir, but by ≈øpecial words they may: And here, Thomas being next heir of the body of William and Joan, hath an e≈øtate for life, and al≈øo being heir of the body of the ≈øaid William, hath a Remainder in tail to him limited, & the me≈øn remaineth limited to others, i. e. to the next heir of the body of Thomas being in abeyance,Co 11. Rep. 80. becau≈øe limited by the name heir, his Father being alive, ≈øhall not hinder the execution of the≈øe e≈øtates, but they ≈øhall remain in force according to the rules of the common Law: Then Thomas ≈øo being ≈øei≈øed levyeth a Fine again≈øt the Provi≈øion of the Will, by which Thomas hath forfeited his e≈øtate for life, and ≈øo his next heir ≈øhall have the Land during his life: And a great rea≈øon wherefore the heirs, ut ≈øupra, after the two fir≈øt limitations ≈øhall have tail, is, becau≈øe that if every heir ≈øhould have but for life, they ≈øhould never have any Intere≈øt in the Lands by the≈øe limitations, for by the expre≈øs words of the devi≈øe, none ≈øhall take but the heir of the fir≈øt heir for ever, i. e. When Thomas aliens, by which the u≈øe ve≈øts in Francis, and when afterwards Francis levieth a Fine, then the u≈øe ve≈øts in Percival H ‚Ä¢ rt, being next heir of the ≈øaid Francis at the time of the Fine levyed (notwith≈øtanding that afterwards Francis had a Son which is his next heir) and therefore the u≈øe in Percival by the birth of the ≈øaid Son in Francis ≈øhall not be deve≈øted,E≈øtate ve≈øted, ≈øhall not be deve≈øted. becau≈øe it was a thing ve≈øted in him before by purcha≈øe, 9 H. 7. 25. A enfeoffs B. upon condition on the part of A. to be performed,1 Cro. 61. and dyeth, having i≈ø≈øue a Daughter, the Daughter performs the condition, and afterwards a Son is born, the Daughter ≈øhall hold the Lands again≈øt the Son: So 5. E. 4 6. A woman hath i≈ø≈øue a Daughter, and afterwards con≈øents to a Ravi≈øher, the Daughter enters, and afterwards a Son is born, yet the Daughter ≈øhall hold the Lands for ever, i. e. And Geofries Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, Francis being in by force of the Forfeiture, ≈øhall not be ≈øubject to the limitation of the Will, i. e. to any forfeiture if he alien, for the e≈øtate which Francis hath for his life is but an e≈øtate gained by the offence of his Father, and the u≈øe was limited to him upon the Will of Richard, and then the ≈øaid e≈øtate is not ≈øubject to the Provi≈øo of the Will, and then hath not Francis committed any forfeiture: And admit Francis ≈øhall forfeit, yet Percival ≈øhall get nothing thereby, but the e≈øtate which Francis had at the time of the Fine levied, ≈øcil. the Free-hold only, for no e≈øtate of Inheritance was in him living his Father. As to the regre≈øs of the Feoffees, Geofries was of opinion, That where an u≈øe is limited to a per≈øon certain, and thereupon ve≈øted in the per≈øon to whom it is limited, That the Entry of the Feoffees in ≈øuch ca≈øe is not requi≈øite, notwith≈øtanding that the fir≈øt e≈øtates be di≈øcontinued, but where the u≈øe (as in our ca≈øe) is not limited to a per≈øon certain in e≈ø≈øe, but is in abeyance, not ve≈øted in any per≈øon upon the limitation of it, ≈øome e≈øtate ought to be left in the Feoffees to maintain that u≈øe, and to render it according to the limitation,
and in our ca≈øe, the≈øe u≈øes not in e≈ø≈øe at the time of the making of the Statute of 27 H. 8. could not be executed by the ≈øaid Statute, but now at the appointed time by the limitation ≈øhall be rai≈øed and revived by the Entry of the Feoffees, but here by the Fine and Non-claim, the Feoffees are bound, and their Entry taken away, and ≈øo no u≈øe can accrue to Percival Hart by ≈øuch Entry. Southcote Iu≈øtice was of opinion, that the Feoffees cannot enter at all, becau≈øe that by the Statute of 27 H. 8. nothing is left in them at the time of the making of the Statute, which ≈øaves the right of every per≈øon, &c. other than the Feoffees, ≈øo as no right is ≈øaved to them but all is drawn out of them by the operation of the Statute, and the ≈øecond ≈øaving of the Statute, ≈øaves to the Feoffees all their former Right, ≈øo as the Right which the Feoffees had by the Feoffment to the u≈øe is utterly gone. But Percival Hart may well enter, for he is not bound to the five years after the Fine levied, for he had not right at the time of the Fine levied, but his right came by the Fine.
