Wray chief Iu≈øtice, The Feoffees are not to enter, for the Statute of 27 H. 8. hath two branches, 1. gives the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe in ≈øuch manner as he hath in the u≈øe. 2. takes away all the right out of the Feoffees, and gives it to Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, ≈øo as nothing at all remains in the Feoffees; for if an Act of Parliament will give to me all the Lands, whereof my brother Southcote is ≈øei≈øed, and that I ≈øhall be in the Sei≈øin thereof, now is the actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in me without my Entry: ≈øo where an u≈øe is often executed by the Statute, Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe without any Entry hath an actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. i. As to the u≈øes contingent, nothing remains in the Feoffees for the ≈øetling of them when they happen, but the whole e≈øtate is ≈øetled in Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, yet ≈øubject to ≈øuch u≈øe, and he ≈øhall render the ≈øame upon contingency: And if any e≈øtate ≈øhould remain in the Feoffees, it could be but an e≈øtate for life, for the Fee ≈øimple is executed in Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, with an e≈øtate in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and then the Feoffees ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed to another u≈øe than was given them by the Livery. Al≈øo if a Feoffment be made unto the u≈øe of the Feoffor, and his heirs, until J.S. hath paid unto the Feoffor 100 l. from thenceforth the Feoffor and his heirs ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid J.S. and his heirs, if upon ≈øuch Feoffment any thing ≈øhould remain in the Feoffees before the payment by I.S. the ≈øame ≈øhould be a Fee-≈øimple, and then there ≈øhould be two Fee-≈øimples of one and the ≈øame Lands, one in the Feoffor, and the other in the Feoffees, which ≈øhould be ab≈øurd, and therefore the be≈øt way to avoid ≈øuch inconveniences is to continue the Statute, that it draws the whole e≈øtate of the Land, and al≈øo the confidence out of the Feoffees, and repo≈øeth it upon the Lands, the which by the operation of the Statute, ≈øhall render the u≈øe to every per≈øon in his time according to the limitation of the parties: And al≈øo if any Intere≈øt doth remain in the Feoffees, Then if they convey to any per≈øon upon con≈øideration who hath not notice of the u≈øe, then the ≈øaid u≈øe ≈øhall never ri≈øe, which is utterly again≈øt the meaning of the ≈øaid Statute, and the meaning of the parties, and therefore, to con≈øtrue the Statute, to leave nothing in the Feoffees will prevent all ≈øuch mi≈øchief: And if a Feoffment in fee be made to the u≈øe of the Feoffor for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of his wife which ≈øhall be for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of the right Heirs of the Feoffor; The Feoffor enfeoffeth a ≈øtranger, taketh a wife, now cannot the Feoffees enter during the life of the Feoffor, and after his death they cannot enter, becau≈øe they could not enter when the u≈øe to the wife was to begin upon the intermarriage, and then if the Entry of the Feoffees in ≈øuch ca≈øe ≈øhould be requi≈øite, the u≈øe limited to the wife by the Act of the Feoffor ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed again≈øt his own limitation, which is ≈øtrong again≈øt the meaning of the Act afore≈øaid, for by the ≈øaid act, the Land is credited with the ≈øaid u≈øe, which ≈øhall never fail in the performance of it. And ≈øuch contingent e≈øtates in Remainder may be limited
in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, a Fortiori in u≈øe, which ≈øee 4. E. 6. Coithir≈øts ca≈øe, 23. And Ple≈øingtons ca≈øe, 6 R. 2. And it is true, at the common Law, the Entry of the Feoffees was requi≈øite, becau≈øe the wrong was done unto them by rea≈øon of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion which they then had; but now by the Statute, all is drawn out of them, and then there is no rea≈øon that they medle with the Lands wherein they have now nothing to do, and the ≈øcope of the Statute is, utterly to di≈øable the Feoffees to do any thing in prejudice of the u≈øes limited, ≈øo as the Feoffees are not to any purpo≈øe but as a Pipe to convey the Lands to others; So as they cannot by their Relea≈øe or confirmation, &c. bind the u≈øes which are to grow and ari≈øe by the limitation knit unto the Feoffment made unto them, which ≈øee Br. 30. 30 H. 8. Feoffments to u≈øes 50 A. covenants with B. That when A. ≈øhall be enfeoffed by B. of three Acres of Lands in D. that then the ≈øaid A. and his Heirs ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed of Land of the ≈øaid A. in S. to the u≈øe of B. and his Heirs, and afterwards A. enfeoffeth a ≈øtranger of his Lands in S. And afterwards B. enfeoffeth A. of his Lands in D. now the Feoffee of A. ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of B. notwith≈øtanding that the ≈øaid Feoffee had not notice of the u≈øe, for Land is bound with the u≈øe in who≈øe hands ≈øoever it come: And ≈øee the like ca≈øe, ibid. 1. Ma. 59. Vpon the rea≈øon of which ca≈øes many a≈ø≈øurances have been made, for it is the common manner of Mortgage, i. e. If the Mortgag or pay ≈øuch a ≈øum, &c. that then the Mortgagee and his Heirs ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed after ≈øuch payment, to the u≈øe of the Mortgagor and his Heirs; In that ca≈øe although that the Mortgagee alien, yet upon the payment, the u≈øe ≈øhall ri≈øe well enough out of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Alienee, and the Lands ≈øhall be in the Mortgagor without any Entry: For the Mortgages could not enter again≈øt his own alienation, to revive the u≈øe which is to ri≈øe upon the payment, and therefore without any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øuch Entry, it ≈øhall ari≈øe: As at the Common Law, Land is given to A. in tail, the Remainder to the right heirs of B. A. levies a Fine, makes a Feoffment, ≈øuffers a Recovery, &c. although the ≈øame ≈øhall bind the I≈ø≈øues, yet if B. dyeth, and afterwards A. dyeth without i≈ø≈øue, now notwith≈øtanding this Fine, &c. The right Heir of B. may enter: And always a u≈øe ≈øhall ≈øpring out of the Land at his due opportunity, and it is a collateral charge which binds the Lands by the fir≈øt Liberty, and cannot be di≈øcharged, vi. 49. A≈ø≈ø. 8. & 49 E. 3. 16. I≈øabell Goodcheapes ca≈øe: A man devi≈øeth, that his Executors ≈øhall ≈øell his Lands, and afterwards dyeth without heir, ≈øo as the Land e≈øcheats to the King, yet the authority given to the Executors ≈øhall bind the Lands in who≈øe hands ≈øoever it comes, &c. And ≈øo a title of Entry continues notwith≈øtanding twenty alienations: But an u≈øe is a le≈øs thing than a Title of Entry, e≈øpecially an u≈øe in contingency, and an u≈øe as long as it is in contingency cannot be forfeited: As if the Mortgagor be attainted and pardoned mean betwixt the Mortgage and the day of Redemption, &c. Then when Thomas levies a Fine, Francis may well enter; And Thomas before the Fine had an e≈øtate tail executed to his Free-hold, and therefore by the Fine he gave an e≈øtate of Inheritance to the Conu≈øee, and then no right of entail remained in Francis, but he took an e≈øtate for life only, and that as a Purcha≈øor by the limitation of the Will, and then when Francis levied a Fine, his e≈øtate was gone (which was but for life) and then the right of the entail, and all the other e≈øtates which are e≈øpecially limited are al≈øo gone, and ≈øo Percival Hart, to whom no e≈øtate was ≈øpecially limited hath not any cau≈øe to enter, &c. And it was further ≈øaid by Wray: Husband and Wife Tenants in ≈øpecial tail, the Husband levies a Fine with Proclamations and dieth, the Wife enters, the i≈ø≈øue in tail is barred, but if the Wife enter after the death of her Husband, and before the Proclamations pa≈øs, the i≈ø≈øue is not bound by the Fine: And if Tenant in Tail granteth totum ≈øtatum, and after levieth a Fine thereof with Proclamations, come ceo, &c. The I≈ø≈øue is barred; contrary where the Fine is upon a Relea≈øe, &c.

div.head: CCCXLVI. Henningham and Windhams Ca≈øe. 18 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: ARthur Henningham brought a Writ of Error again≈øt Francis Windham upon a common Recovery had again≈øt Henry his Brother,Error. Owen Rep. 68. and the Ca≈øe was, That Land was given in ≈øpecial tail to Thomas Henningham, Father of the ≈øaid Henry and the ≈øaid Arthur, the Remainder in general tail (the e≈øtate tail in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was to him and the Heirs Mairs of his body) Thomas had i≈ø≈øue the ≈øaid Henry and three Daughters by one woman, and the ≈øaid Arthur and two other Sons by another woman, and dyed ≈øei≈øed. Henry entred, and made a Feoffnent, a common Recovery is had again≈øt the Feoffee, in which Henry is vouched, who vouched over the common Vouchee according to the u≈øual cour≈øe of common Recoveries. Henry dyed without i≈ø≈øue,Error and Attaint, by him to whom the Land is to de≈øcend. and Arthur brought a Writ of Error being but of the half blood to Henry: And it was re≈øolved by the whole Court, That Error and Attaint always de≈øcends to ≈øuch per≈øon to whom the Land ≈øhould de≈øcend: If ≈øuch Recovery, or fal≈øe oath had not been; As if Lands be given to one and the Heirs Females of his body, &c. and ≈øuffers an erronious Recovery and dyeth, the Heir female ≈øhall have the Writ of Error: So upon Recovery of Lands in Borough Engli≈øh, for ≈øuch Action de≈øcends according to the Land, quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum per totam Curiam: But it was objected on the Defendants part: That becau≈øe that the Feoffee being Tenant to the Praecipe is to recover in value a Fee-≈øimple, and ≈øo Henry is to yield a Fee-≈øimple which ≈øhould de≈øcend to the heir at the Common Law if this Recovery had not been, therefore he to whom the ≈øame ≈øhould de≈øcend, ≈øhould have the Writ of Error, for he hath the lo≈øs: But the ≈øaid Exception was not allowed: And it was ≈øaid, That Tenant in tail upon ≈øuch a Recovery, ≈øhall recover but an e≈øtate in tail, ≈øcil. ≈øuch e≈øtate which he had at the time of the warranty made, &c. And afterwards Iudgment was given that the Action was maintainable: So if a man hath Lands of the part of his mother, and lo≈øeth it by erronious Iudgment and dyeth; That the Heir of the part of the Mother ≈øhall have the Writ of Error.

div.head: CCCXLVII. Fo≈øter and Pitfalls Ca≈øe. 18 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Ejectione firmae the Ca≈øe was:1 Cro. ‚Ä¢ . Brook devi≈øed Lands to his Wife in general Tail, the Remainder over to a ≈øtranger in Fee, and dyed, he took another Husband, and had i≈ø≈øue a Daughter: The Husband and Wife levyed a Fine to a ≈øtranger: The Daughter as next Heir by 11 H. 7. entred: It was agreed by the whole Court, That an e≈øtate devi≈øed to the wife, is within the words. but not within the meaning of the Statute: Secondly, It was re≈øolved, That no e≈øtate is within the meaning of the Statute, unle≈øs it be for the Ioynture of the Wife: Thirdly Re≈øolved, That the meaning of the Statute was, That the wife ≈øo preferred by the Husband ≈øhould not prejudice the i≈ø≈øues or heirs of her Husband; and here nothing is left in the I≈ø≈øues or heirs of the Husband, ≈øo as the Wife could not prejudice them, for the Remainder is limited over.

div.head: CCCLXVIII. Greenes Ca≈øe. 18 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Acceptance of Rent. 1 Cro. 3. 3 Co. 64. b. GReene made a Lea≈øe for years rendring Rent with clau≈øe of Re-entry, and the Rent due at the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation was behind being demanded at the day, which Rent the Le≈ø≈øor afterwards accepted, and afterwards entred for the condition broken, and his Entry holden lawful,Entry. Plow. Com. in Browning and Be≈øtons Ca≈øe. for the Rent was due before the condition broken; but if the Le≈ø≈øor accepts the next Quarters Rent, then he hath lo≈øt the benefit of Re-entry, for thereby he admits the Le≈ø≈øee to be his Tenant. And if the Le≈ø≈øor di≈øtrain for Rent due at the ≈øaid Fea≈øt of the Annunciation after the forfeiture, he cannot afterwards re-enter for the ≈øaid forfeiture, for by his Di≈øtre≈øs he hath affirmed the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Le≈ø≈øee: So if he make an Acquittance for the Rent as a Rent, contrary, if the Acquittance be but for a ≈øum of mony, and not expre≈øly for the Rent, all which tota Curia conce≈ø≈øit.

div.head: CCCXLIX. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
THe Ca≈øe was, Le≈ø≈øee for life, the Remainder for life, the Remainder in tail, the Remainder in fee: The two Tenants for life make a Feoffment in fee. Dyer, A woman Tenant for life in Ioynture, the Remainder for life, the Remainder in fee; the Tenants for life joyn in a Feoffment,Entry for Forfeiture. the Entry of him in the Remainder in fee is lawful by 11 H. 7. And if Tenant for life be impleaded, and he in the Remainder for life will not pray to be received, he in the la≈øt Remainder may; and ≈øo in our ca≈øe, ina≈ømuch as he in the Remainder for life was party to the wrong, he in the Remainder in tail ≈øhall enter: Which Harper and Mun≈øon granted,Dyer 339. a. i. e. Manwood, Although that this Feoffment be not a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin to him in the Remainder in tail, yet it is a wrong in a high degree; as by Littleton, A Di≈ø≈øei≈øor lea≈øeth for life to A. who aliens in fee, the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee relea≈øeth to the Alienee; it is a good Relea≈øe, and the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor ≈øhall not enter although the Alienation was to his di≈øinheritance, Lit. 111. which Dyer granted: And if Tenant for life alieneth in fee, and the Alienee enfeoffeth his Father, and dieth, the ≈øame de≈øcent ≈øhall not avail him no more than in ca≈øe of Di≈ø≈øei≈øin.Livery of Sei≈øm. It hath been objected, that this is the Livery of the fir≈øt Tenant for life, and the confirmation of him in the Remainder for life. Dyer was of opinion, That by this Livery the Remainder for life pa≈ø≈øeth, and this Livery ≈øhall be as well the Livery of him in the Remainder as of the Tenant in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and although where an e≈øtate is made lawfully by many, it ≈øhall be ≈øaid the Livery of him only who lawfully may make Livery: Yet where an e≈øtate is wrongfully made it ≈øhall be accounted in Law, the Livery of all who joyn in it. And in this, the Remainder for life is extingui≈øhed by the Livery in the Feoffee, and the Livery of him in the Remainder for life ≈øhall be holden a void Livery, e≈øpecially when he joyns with ≈øuch a per≈øon who hath not authority to make Livery; As if the Lord and a Stranger Di≈ø≈øei≈øe the Tenant, and make a Feoffment over, the whole Seigniory is extinct, as if he ≈øolely had been ≈øei≈øed: ≈øo if he in the Rever≈øion, and a Stranger di≈ø≈øei≈øe for life, and make a Feoffment over, the Seigniory is gone, and yet it is the Livery of the Le≈ø≈øee only. And although it be but the confirmation of him in the Remainder for life, yet thereby the Remainder is gone and extinct. And afterwards Iudgment was given, that the Entry of him in the Remainder in tail was lawful: And it was ≈øaid by the L. Dyer, That if Tenant for life be, the Remainder for life, the Remainder in fee,
Tenant for life in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion alieneth in fee, that he in the Remainder in fee cannot enter, for it was not to his di≈øinheri ‚Ä¢ in.

div.head: CCCL. 20 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was, That a Capias ad Satisfaciend was delivered to the Sheriff,5 Co. 88, 89. and after the Sheriff did arre≈øt the party again≈øt whom the Capias i≈ø≈øued, by force of a Capias Utlagatum, and then the party in the Capias came to the Sheriff, and prayed that the party remain in Execution for his debt al≈øo, and notwith≈øtanding that the Sheriff let the Pri≈øoner go at large, and upon both Writs returned, Non e≈øt inventus. It was the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices, That the Sheriff was not bound in point of E≈øcape to detain the Pri≈øoner for the Debt of the Plaintiff; and it is not like where one is in the Fleet in Execution, there (if other condemnations in other Courts be notified to the Warden of the Fleet) he ≈øhall be chargeable with them all. It was holden al≈øo, per Curiam, That if the Body had been returned by Capias Utlagatum, that the Court at the prayer of the party would grant that the Pri≈øoner might remain in Execution for the debt as in ca≈øe of a Capias pro fine.

div.head: CCCLI. The Lord Saint John and the Counte≈øs of Kents Ca≈øe. 19 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Evidence given to the Iury in an Action of Debt brought by the Plaintiff again≈øt the Defendant:Grants of Executors of omnia bona ≈øua. 1 Cro. 6. It was ≈øaid by Dyer and Manwood Iu≈øtices, That if Executors grant omnia bona ≈øua, that the goods which they have as Executors do not pa≈øs, which ≈øee 10 E. 4. 1. b. by Danby: but the contrary was holden by Wray chief Iu≈øtice of the Kings Bench, and by Plowden. in Bracebridges ca≈øe, P. 18 Eliz. and they denied the opinion of 10 E. 4. to be Law, for by ≈øuch Grant made by Executors, the goods of the Te≈øtator do pa≈øs.

div.head: CCCLII. 19 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: NOte, It was ≈øaid by Dyer and Manwood, Iu≈øtices, That if one be condemned in an Action upon the Ca≈øe,Abatement of Writ. 3 Len. 68. or Tre≈øpa≈øs upon Nihil dicit, or demurrer, &c. And a Writ i≈ø≈øueth forth to enquire of the Damages, and before the return of it the Defendant dieth, that the Writ ≈øhall not abate, for the awarding of the ≈øaid Writ is a Iudgment. And it was ≈øaid by Manwood, Account. In a Writ of Account the Defendant is awarded to account; if the Defendant account, and be found in Arrearages and dieth, the Writ ≈øhall not abate, but Iudgment ≈øhall be given that the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover, and the Executor ≈øhall be charged with the Arrearages, and yet account doth not lye again≈øt them.

div.head: CCCLIII. 19 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
A. Did recover in Debt again≈øt B. whereupon a Fieri facias i≈ø≈øued to the Sheriff of Devon; and the Defendant, ≈øeeing the Writ of Execution in the Sheriffs hands,Attachment of Goods after the Money is in the Sheriffs hand, is void. ≈øaid to him, that he would pay the Debt recovered at Exeter ≈øuch a day to ≈øatisfie the Execution, at which day the Defendant paid the mony accordingly, and pre≈øently came an Officer of the City of Exeter, and attached the mony in the Sheriffs hand, ≈øuppo≈øing the ≈øaid A. to be indebted ≈øo much to one C. in who≈øe name he made the Attachment,Antea 29. 1 Cro. 6 ‚Ä¢
and now on the behalf of the ≈øaid A. a Certiorare was prayed to remove the Attachment hither; and it was therefore holden by the whole Court, that the Attachment was void, and a Certiorare granted: And Wray ≈øaid, If it can be proved by Oath, that if the Defendant did procure, or was a≈ø≈øenting to the ≈øaid Attachment, that Proce≈øs of Contempt ≈øhould i≈ø≈øue again≈øt him; and the Sheriff demanded of the Court what return he ≈øhould make, becau≈øe the monies were attached in his hands, and taken from him by force; to which Wray an≈øwered, That the Sheriff ought to an≈øwer the monies to the Plaintiff, which were once in his hands by force of the Execution, and that it was his folly to ≈øuffer the mony to be taken from him by colour of the ≈øaid Attachment, and if the mony was taken by force, the Sheriff had his remedy by an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs; for the Attachment was void, but the Sheriff at the return of the Writ ought to an≈øwer for the Mony.

div.head: CCCLIV. 19 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: TEnant for life bargained and ≈øold his Lands to A. and his Heirs, and afterwards levied a Fine to the Bargainee,Forfeiture. 4 Len. 124. ‚Ä¢ Len. 60, 65. Sur conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. It was holden by the Court, that it was a forfeiture committed by the Bargainee, not by the Bargainor, who at the time of the Fine had nothing to forfeit; and it was ≈øaid by Manwood Iu≈øtice, That if Tenant for life be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and takes a Fine, ut ≈øupra, of a Stranger, it is a forfeiture, and yet he in the Rever≈øion hath but a right in Rever≈øion; ≈øo that if Tenant for life be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor commits Wa≈øt, he in the Rever≈øion ≈øhall have an Action of Wa≈øt again≈øt Tenant for life; and if two Tenants for life be di≈ø≈øei≈øed by two, A. and B. and one of the Tenants for life doth relea≈øe unto A. and the other Tenant for life doth re-enter, he hath the Moiety in common with the other to whom the Relea≈øe was made, and he hath reve≈øted the intire Rever≈øion in him, in whom the Rever≈øion was before, &c.

div.head: CCCLV. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Bracebridges Ca≈øe.
div.p:
THe Ca≈øe was, Thomas Bracebridge ≈øei≈øed of a Manor in Fee, lea≈øed a Me≈ø≈øuage, parcel of it to one Curtes for 21 years, and afterwards 35 H. 8. lea≈øed the ≈øame to one Moore for 26 years, to begin after the expiration of the former Lea≈øe; and afterwards 5 E. 6. he enfeoffed Griffith and others to the u≈øe of the Feoffees them≈øelves, and their Heirs, upon condition, That if the Feoffees did not pay to the ≈øaid Thomas Bracebridge 2000 l. within 15 days after, that then immediately after the ≈øaid 15 days, the Feoffees ≈øhould ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor
to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Thomas Bracebridge, and Joyce his wife, for their lives, without impeachment of Wa≈øt, and afterwards to the u≈øe of T. B. their ≈øecond Son in tail, with divers Remainders over, the Feoffees do not pay the ≈øaid mony within the ≈øaid 15 days, afterwards Curties attorns to the Feoffees. It was moved, if the Rever≈øion of the Lands pa≈ø≈øed to Curties, pa≈ø≈øeth by the Feoffment of the Manor without attornment, which ≈øee Littleton 133, 134. 2.Attornment. If by the attornment of Curties, after the 15 days the u≈øes can ri≈øe to Bracebridge and his wife, &c. and it was ≈øaid, That the Ca≈øe 20 H. 6. Avowry 11, 12. If a Manor be granted for life, the remainder over in Fee; Tenant for life dieth, if the Tenants attorn to him in the Remainder, the ≈øame is good; and if a Rever≈øion be granted to two, and one of them dieth, attornment to the ≈øurvivor is good; and if a Rever≈øion be granted to Hu≈øband and Wife in ≈øpecial tail, the Wife dieth afterwards without i≈ø≈øue, Attornment to the Husband is good; and if a Rever≈øion be given in Frank-marriage, and afterwards the Husband and Wife are divorced, and afterwards the particular Tenant attorns to the Wife, the ≈øame is good; and by Manwood, If a Man ≈øei≈øed of a Manor, the deme≈øns of which extends into two Counties, and hath i≈ø≈øue a Son and a Daughter by one woman, and a Son by another woman, and dieth, the elde≈øt Son enters into the Deme≈øns in one County only, and takes the profit in one County only, and dieth without i≈ø≈øue, the Daughter ≈øhall have and inherit the Deme≈øns or Services whereof her Brother was ≈øei≈øed, and the Son of the half-blood the re≈øt: And by Manwood, the attornment of Curties, who was the fir≈øt Le≈ø≈øee, ≈øhall bind Moore the ≈øecond Le≈ø≈øee, for he ought to attorn, again≈øt whom lieth the Quid juris clamat: And if a Lea≈øe for years be made of a Manor, and the Rever≈øion of it be granted to another in fee, if the Le≈ø≈øee for years attorneth it ≈øhall bind the Tenants of the Manor, 18 E. 2. A man ≈øei≈øed of a Manor in the right of his Wife, lea≈øed parcel of it for years without his wife, the Rever≈øion thereof is not parcel of the Manor; contrary if the Lea≈øe had been made by Husband and Wife. And by Dyer, if Tenant in tail of a Manor lea≈øeth parcel for years, and afterwards makes a Feoffment of the whole Manor, and makes Livery in the Deme≈øns not lea≈øed, the Rever≈øion of the Land lea≈øed doth not pa≈øs; for by the Feoffment a wrong is done to the Le≈ø≈øor, which the Law ≈øhall not further enlarge than appeareth by the Deed; contrary in ca≈øe of Tenant in fee of a Manor, and that without Deed with Attornment. And it was the Ca≈øe of one Kellet, 25 H. 8. Kellet was Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe before the Statute of 27 H. 8. of divers Lands by ≈øeveral Conveyances, the u≈øe of ≈øome being rai≈øed upon Recovery, of ≈øome upon Fine, and of ≈øome upon Feoffment, and he made a Feoffment of all the≈øe Lands by Deed, with a Letter of Attorney to make Livery; the Attorney entred into part of the Land, and made Livery in the name of the whole, and it was agreed by all the Iu≈øtices, that the Lands pa≈ø≈øed, notwith≈øtanding in others po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, i.e. other Feoffees: And by Dyer, If the Tenants of a Manor pay their Rents to the Di≈ø≈øei≈øor, they may refu≈øe again to pay them; and if a Lea≈øe be made for years, the Remainder for life, if the Le≈ø≈øor will grant over his Rever≈øion, the Le≈ø≈øee for years ≈øhall Attorn, and his attornment ≈øhall bind him in the remainder for life; and if a Lea≈øe be made to one for years, the remainder over for life, the remainder to the Le≈ø≈øee for years in Fee. Now if the Le≈ø≈øee for years grant all his intere≈øt, &c. there needs no attornment: and if Grantee of a Rent in fee lea≈øeth for life, and afterwards grants the Rever≈øion to another, the Attornment of the Ter-tenant is not requi≈øite, but only of the Grantee for life. It was al≈øo holden,Relation. That this Attornment by Curties two years after the Livery was ≈øufficient, for it ≈øhall have relation to the Livery to make it parcel of the Manor, but not to puni≈øh the Le≈ø≈øee for wa≈øte done mean between the Livery and
the Attornment, but betwixt the Feoffor and the Feoffee it ≈øhall pa≈øs ab initio. It was holden al≈øo, That although the u≈øes for it limited are determined by the default of payment within the 15 days, yet the Feoffees ≈øhall take the Rever≈øion by this Attornment to the ≈øecond u≈øes;2 Len. 222. and if I enfeoff one upon condition to enfeoff J.S. who refu≈øeth, now the Feoffee ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to my u≈øe; but if the condition were to give in tail, contrary: So here is a Limitation beyond the fir≈øt u≈øe, which ≈øhall not be defeated for want of Attornment to the fir≈øt u≈øes; and here it was not the meaning of Bracebridge to have the Lands again upon breach of the condition in his former e≈øtate, but according to the ≈øecond u≈øe; and Iudgment was given in the principal ca≈øe according to the re≈øolutions of the Iudges, as afore≈øaid. And it was ≈øaid by Harper Iu≈øtice, That if a Feoffment in Fee be made to J. S. upon condition that he ≈øhall grant to A. a Rent-charge, who refu≈øeth it, J.S. ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to his own u≈øe.Antea 199.

div.head: CCCLVI. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was this, Lord and Tenant by ≈øervice to pay every year ≈øuch a quantity of Salt; but ≈øince 10 H. 7. the Tenant hath always paid the money for Salt. The que≈øtion was, If the Lord might re≈øort to the fir≈øt ≈øervice,Sei≈øin. and if the money be Sei≈øin of the Salt. And Manwood took this difference, i.e. where the Lord takes a certain ≈øum of money for the Salt, the ≈øame is not any Sei≈øin, for the ≈øervice is altered, as at the fir≈øt, Socage Tenure was a work done by labor, i.e. Plowing; but now it is changed into certain Rent, and the Lord cannot re≈øort to have his Plowing; and in Kent divers Tenants in ancient time have paid Barley for their Rent, but the ≈øame afterward was paid in a certain ≈øum of money, ≈øo as now the Lord of Canterbury, who is Lord of ≈øuch Tenements cannot now demand his Barly, &c. but if the ≈øum which hath been u≈øed to be paid be incertain one year ≈øo much, according to the price of Salt, then ≈øuch a payment of money is a ≈øufficient Sei≈øin of the Salt. Quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum per Curiam.

div.head: CCCLVII. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Accompt, brought by an Heir Copyholder, for the profits of his Copyhold Lands taken during his Nonage, the Defendant pleaded, That by the Cu≈øtom of the ≈øaid Manor,Accompt by the Heir of a Copyholder. the Lord of the Manor might a≈ø≈øign one to take the profits of a Copyhold de≈øcended to an Infant, during his Nonage to the u≈øe of the A≈ø≈øignee, without rendring an accompt, and the ≈øame was holden to be a good Cu≈øtom, as a Rent granted to one and his Heirs,Cu≈øtom to cea≈øe during the Nonage of every Heir; but admitting that the Cu≈øtom were void, yet this Action doth not lye, for the Defendant hath not entred and taken the profits, as Prochein amy, in which Ca≈øe although he was not Prochein amy, &c. he is chargeable,O ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Rep. 36, ‚Ä¢ 3, 84. as Prochein amy according to his Claim; but here he claimeth by the Cu≈øtom and Grant of the Lord, and not in the right of the Heir; and therefore it was adjudged in this time of this Quaere, that if one entreth into Lands claiming by Devi≈øe, where in truth the Land devi≈øed is entailed, he ≈øhould not be charged in accompt, &c.

div.head: CCCLVIII. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: NOte, It was holden by the whole Court,Expo≈øition of the Statute, of 32 and 34. Of Wills. That the Statute of 32 & 34 H. 8. of Wills, did not extend to Lands in London, but that the devi≈øe of the whole is good: And if Hou≈øes in London, parcel of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of Abbies came to the Crown by Di≈ø≈øolution, and he grants them over to hold in chief by Knights ≈øervice, the≈øe Lands are devi≈øable: But it was holden, That the ≈øaid Statutes as Acts executed, extended to Lands in London, and ≈øhall be good but for two parts: And if a man hath Lands in tail, and in Fee-≈øimple, which are of double the value of the Lands in tail, and devi≈øeth all his Lands, all the Land in Fee-≈øimple ≈øhall pa≈øs. Dyer, One ≈øei≈øed of three Manors, the one in Capite in Fee, and two in Socage in tail, and devi≈øeth all his Land in Capite, it is good again≈øt the King for all Capite Land, and he ≈øhall be tied to have the Lands in Socage, but it ≈øhall not bind the Heir: And a devi≈øe of the third part (where all is devi≈øed) is void as well again≈øt the Heir as again≈øt the King. And he ≈øaid, That if a man be ≈øei≈øed of twenty Acres in Socage, and ten Acres in Capite, and devi≈øeth two parts of his Lands, it is rea≈øonable to ≈øay, That all the Socage Lands ≈øhall pa≈øs; but if the devi≈øe was of two parts of all his Lands, it is otherwi≈øe, for this word (All) implies, that the two parts ≈øhall be per my & per tout, as well Capite as Socage, i. e. It was argued by Fenner, That the Lands in London are now devi≈øable as they were before the Statute, for if the Devi≈øee of Lands in London be di≈øturbed, he ≈øhall have Ex gravi Querela, otherwi≈øe it is of Lands at the Common Law; and if an A≈ø≈øize of Mortdance≈øter be brought of Lands in London, it is a good Plea to ≈øay, That the Lands are devi≈øable: But in an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Mortdance≈øtor of Lands at the Common Law, it is not any Plea: And if a man gives Lands at the Common Law, i. e. not devi≈øable by the Common Law, he cannot devi≈øe the Rever≈øion, for the Statute ≈øhall not do wrong to the per≈øon, i.e. to the Donee, who there ≈øhall lo≈øe his Acquittal: But of Lands devi≈øable by cu≈øtom, it is otherwi≈øe; And if Land in a Burrough was devi≈øable for life by the Cu≈øtom, and afterwards came the Statute of 23 H. 8. which made all Lands devi≈øable, now that Land is devi≈øable for life by the Cu≈øtom, and the Rever≈øion by the Statute.

div.head: CCCLIX. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Action of Wa≈øt, of Wa≈øt a≈ø≈øigned in a Wood,Wa≈øt. the Iury viewed the Wood only without entring into it: And it was holden that the ≈øame was ≈øufficient, for otherwi≈øe it ≈øhould be tedious for the Iury to have had the view of every ≈øtub of a Tree which had been felled. Yet Meade Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That if Wa≈øt be a≈ø≈øigned in ≈øeveral corners of the Wood, then the Iury is to have the view of every corner; but contrary where Wa≈øt is a≈ø≈øigned in the whole Wood:Vie ‚Ä¢ . And if Wa≈øt be a≈ø≈øigned in every Room of a Hou≈øe, the view of the Hou≈øe generally is ≈øufficient. And Dyer Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That if Wa≈øt be a≈ø≈øigned in ≈øeveral places, and of ≈øome of them the Iury had not the view, of that they may find no Wa≈øt done.

div.head: CCCLX. Sir Thomas Lees Ca≈øe. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IT was holden per Curiam, That whereas Sir Thomae Lee was ≈øei≈øed of a Manor,Election. and aliened the Manor, except one Clo≈øe parcel of the ≈øaid Manor called Newdick, and there were two Clo≈øes parcel of the ≈øaid Manor called Newdick, the one containing nine Acres, and the other containing three Acres; That the Alienee ≈øhould not chu≈øe which of the ≈øaid Clo≈øes he would have; but the Alienor or Feoffor ≈øhould have the Election which of the ≈øaid Clo≈øes ≈øhould pa≈øs.

div.head: CCCLXI. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: TEnant in tail, the Remainder in tail, &c. Tenant in tail, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion,Fines levied by Tenant in tail in Remainder. 3 Cro. 211. makes a Lea≈øe for three lives, according to the Statute of 32 H. 8. and afterwards dieth without i≈ø≈øue, he in the Remainder before any Entry levieth a Fine, the ≈øame is good; for by the death of Tenant in tail without i≈ø≈øue, the Free-hold is ve≈øted in him in the Remainder in tail: And of that opinion was the whole Court.

div.head: CCCLXII. Ferrand and Ram≈øeys Ca≈øe. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae brought of a Hou≈øe in London, the Defendant pleaded, That long time before the Le≈ø≈øor of the Plaintiff had any thing, &c. One Ann Ram≈øey was ≈øei≈øed in Fee, and died ≈øei≈øed, and that the ≈øame de≈øcended to William Ram≈øey as Son and Heir to the ≈øaid Ann, who was di≈ø≈øei≈øed by I≈ørael Owen, who lea≈øed to the Plaintiff, upon whom the ≈øaid William Ram≈øey did re-enter: The Plaintiff Replicando, That the ≈øaid Ann did not die ≈øei≈øed, ≈øaid, That before the Ejectment one Robert Owen was ≈øei≈øed, and died ≈øei≈øed, and from him de≈øcended the ≈øaid Hou≈øe to I≈ørael Owen as Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Robert, ab≈øque hoc, that the ≈øaid I≈ørael did di≈ø≈øei≈øe the ≈øaid Ann, upon which they were at i≈ø≈øue, and at Ni≈øi prius in London, it was given in Evidence of the Defendants part: That Crofton and Langhton were ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, and by Deed indented conveyed it to one John Ram≈øey, Robert Dakins, and four others and their Heirs, upon condition that the ≈øaid Feoffees, their Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns ≈øhould pay to the ≈øaid Ann and her Heirs, ≈øix pounds thirteen ≈øhillings and four pence: And al≈øo ≈øhould enfeoff the ≈øaid Ann, if to the ≈øame they were required by the ≈øaid Ann in her life, or within four days next following ≈øuch Reque≈øt in Fee unto the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Ann and her Heirs, cum & quando ad hoc per eandem Annam requi≈øit. fuerint, and if the ≈øaid Ann died before ≈øuch Reque≈øt, that then the ≈øaid Feoffees or their Heirs ≈øhould enfeoff ≈øuch i≈ø≈øues of the ≈øaid Ann, or ≈øuch other per≈øons which the ≈øaid Ann ≈øhould name, cum & quando ad hoc per eandem Annam requi≈øit. fuerint, or within four days after ≈øuch Reque≈øt, the ≈øaid Feoffees or their Heirs ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Ann and her Heirs. Afterwards the ≈øeventh of April, 16 Eliz. Ann demanded of William Ram≈øey, Son and Heir of John Ram≈øey, ≈øix pounds thirteen ≈øhillings and four pence, being due to the ≈øaid Ann, ut ≈øupra, the which ≈øum the ≈øaid William Ram≈øey did refu≈øe to pay, by force of which, and by the Statute of 27 H. 8. the ≈øaid Ann Ram≈øey was thereof ≈øei≈øed, and died ≈øei≈øed, and from her de≈øcended the ≈øaid Hou≈øe
to William Ram≈øey. The Plaintiff confe≈ø≈øed the Feoffment to Crofton and Langhton, to John Ram≈øey and others, and ≈øhewed further, That the ≈øaid Ann required the ≈øurviving Feoffees to enfeoff one Robert Owen of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, who three days after made the Feoffment accordingly, Robert Owen enfeoffed John Owen, who died thereof ≈øei≈øed, and from him the ≈øaid Hou≈øe de≈øcended to I≈ørael Owen. Crafton died, Langhton having i≈ø≈øue two Daughters died; All the Feoffees but one died, Ann the time afore≈øaid demanded the ≈øaid ≈øix pounds thirteen ≈øhillings and four pence of the ≈øaid William Ram≈øey in another Hou≈øe in London, due at the Fea≈øt of St. Michael la≈øt before, who denied to pay it; the ≈øecond Daughter of Langhton entred, and thereof enfeoffed the ≈øaid I≈ørael Owen, Rents. 3 Cro. 210, 211. who lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Plaintiff, and upon that Evidence the Defendant did demur in Law: And fir≈øt it was re≈øolved by the whole Court, That the ≈øaid ≈øum to be paid to the ≈øaid Ann was not a Rent, but a ≈øum in gro≈øs, becau≈øe re≈øerved to a ≈øtranger, &c. which ≈øee Lit. 79.Rever≈øion. And by Mun≈øon Iu≈øtice, If the words of the re≈øervation had been twenty Nobles Rent, yet it had been but a ≈øum in gro≈øs, but otherwi≈øe it had been by devi≈øe. Al≈øo there is not any condition for the payment of it, but only a Limitation, for the word ≈øub≈øequent which limits the future u≈øe, takes away all the force of the words of the Condition, as 27 H. 8. 24. Land given in tail upon condition that the Donee and his Heirs ≈øhall carry the Standard of the Donor when he goes to battel; and if he fail thereof, then the ≈øame to remain to a ≈øtranger, the limiting of the Remainder hath taken away the condition, and hath controlled it, and now the Condition is become a Limitation; But where the words ≈øub≈øequent are again≈øt Law, as if upon failer, that then it ≈øhall be lawful for a ≈øtranger to enter,Feoffments upon condition. &c. the≈øe words becau≈øe they are again≈øt Law (for a Rent cannot be re≈øerved to a Stranger, &c.) do not de≈øtroy the Condition, by Mead, contrary by Mun≈øon, for the Condition is utterly gone. And by Mead, Feoffment in Fee upon condition, That if the Feoffor ≈øhall do ≈øuch a thing that he ≈øhall re-enter and retain the Land to the u≈øe of a ≈øtranger, the u≈øe is void,1 Cro 401, 402: and the Feoffor ≈øhall hold the Land to his own u≈øe. A Feoffment in Fee upon condition, That the Feoffee ≈øhall marry my Daughter, and if he refu≈øe to marry her, that then he ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of I.S. the ≈øame is not a Condition, but a Limitation; and in all ca≈øes afterwards of a Condition, where an Intere≈øt is limited to a ≈øtranger, there it is not a Condition, but a Limitation. And Mead ≈øaid, That the ≈øaid annual ≈øum is not demandable, but the party ought to pay it at his peril, Lit. 80. But by Mun≈øon, it ought to be demanded, for ≈øo this word (Refu≈øe) doth imply:Regula. And when at the Reque≈øt of Ann the Feoffment is made, by Mun≈øon, Mead, and Windham, the Rent is gone; but Dyer contrary, unle≈øs the Feoffment be made to Ann her ≈øelf: And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, Hil. 19 Eliz. Rot. 748. There was a Ca≈øe betwixt Shaw and Norton.
Shaw and Nortons Ca≈øe One Green devi≈øed his Lands to A. and devi≈øed al≈øo, the ≈øaid A. ≈øhould pay a Rent to B. and that B. might di≈øtrain for it; and if A. fail of the payment of it, that the Heirs of the Devi≈øor might enter, the ≈øame is a good Di≈øtre≈øs, and a good Condition. And by Mun≈øon, Demand ought to be made of the Rent, for the words are (Refu≈øe) which cannot be without Demand or Reque≈øt: And it was certified, That ≈øuch a Clerk refu≈øed to pay his Tenths, and becau≈øe it was expre≈øly ≈øet down in the Certificate, that he was reque≈øted, &c. for that cau≈øe he was di≈øcharged. And it was al≈øo holden, That if Reque≈øt be nece≈ø≈øary, that in this ca≈øe Reque≈øt is to be made, That it ought to be made to the ≈øurviving Feoffee, or his heir, and not to the heirs of any of the Feoffees who are dead.

div.head:
CCCLXIII. Lacyes Ca≈øe.
Hill. 25. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Indictments Co. 13. Rep. 53. LAcy was indicted of the death of a man upon Scarborough Sands, in the County of York, between the high water-mark, and the low water-mark, and the ≈øame Indictment was removed into the Kings Bench, and being arraigned upon it, he ≈øhewed, that the ≈øaid Indictment was ≈øued by vertue of a Commi≈ø≈øion which i≈ø≈øued the fir≈øt day of May, directed to the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize, and other Iu≈øtices of Peace in the ≈øaid County,Commi≈ø≈øion repealed. to enquire of all Murders, Felonies, &c. and pleaded further, That the ≈øecond day of May afore≈øaid, i≈ø≈øued another Commi≈ø≈øion directed to the Lord Admiral and others upon the Statute of 28 H. 8. cap. 15. by force of which the ≈øaid Lacy was indicted of the ≈øame murder, whereof he was now arraigned, and the ≈øaid la≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion was, ad inquirendum, tam ≈øuper altum mare, quam ≈øuper littus maris, & ubicunque locorum infra juri≈ødictionem no≈øtram maritimam: And that the ≈øaid Indictment taken before the Admiral, was taken before this, upon which he was arraigned, and upon the whole matter prayed to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed: And the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices was, that the fir≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion was repealed by the ≈øecond, and ≈øo the Indictment upon which he was arraigned, taken, coram non Judice, 10 E. 4. 7. If a Commi≈ø≈øion for the Peace i≈ø≈øueth into one County and afterwards another Commi≈ø≈øion i≈ø≈øueth to a Town within the ≈øame County and parcel of it, the fir≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion is repealed, which Gawdy granted, if notice be given, &c. but Wray denied it; but the whole Court, by this la≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion to the Lord Admiral, the fir≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion, as to the Iurisdiction in locis maritimis is determined and repealed; for the≈øe two Commi≈ø≈øions, are in re≈øpect of two ≈øeveral Authorities, the fir≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion meerly by the Common Law, the other by the Statute afore≈øaid, and thereupon the party was di≈øcharged again≈øt the Queen, as to that Indictment. Note, that in the Argument of this Ca≈øe, it was ≈øaid by Coke, and agreed by Wray, That if a man be ≈øtruck upon the high ≈øea,2 Co. 93. whereof he dieth in another County afterwards. that this murder is di≈øpuni≈øhable, notwith≈øtanding the Statute of 2 Ed. 6.

div.head:
CCCLXIV. The Queen and Braybrooks Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 25 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
3 Co. 1, 2, &c.THe Queen brought a Writ of Error again≈øt Braybrook, The Ca≈øe was this, That King Ed. 4. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Mar≈øton, and gave the ≈øame to Lionel Lord Norris, and A.M. and the Heirs of the body of the Lord, the Remainder to H. Norris in Tail, L and A. entermarry, L. ≈øuffered a common Recovery again≈øt him≈øelf only, without naming the ≈øaid A. Hen. Norris is attainted of high Trea≈øon by Act of Parliament, and by the ≈øame Act all his Lands, Tenements, Hereditaments, Rights, Conditions, &c. the day of the Trea≈øon committed, or ever after, &c. Hen. Norris is executed, Lionel dieth without i≈ø≈øue, the Queen fal≈øified the ≈øaid Recovery for one moiety by Scire facias, becau≈øe Anne who was joint-tenant with Lionel was not named party to the ≈øaid Recovery: and afterwards the Queen granted to the Lord Norris, Son of the ≈øaid Hen. Norris, Manerium ≈øuum de Mer≈øton, & omnia jura in eodem, and now upon the ≈øaid Recovery, the Queen brought a Writ of Error, and it was argued by Egerton the Queens Sollicitor, that this right to a Writ of Error is ≈øuch a right as is transferred to the Queen by the Act of Parliament, for the words are, omnia jura ≈øua quaecunque, and here is a right, although not a pre≈øent
right, yet a right although in futuro, ≈øo it is a right of ≈øome quality, as A. Tenant in Tail, the Remainder in Tail to B.A. makes a Feoffment in Fee, B. is attainted of high Trea≈øon, and by ≈øuch Act all his Lands, &c. given to the King. A. dieth without i≈ø≈øue, the Queen ≈øhall have a Formedon in the Remainder; and although the Queen hath granted to the Lord Norris, Manerium ≈øuum de Mer≈øton, & omnia jura in eodem, yet by ≈øuch general words, a Writ of Error doth not pa≈øs, which See 32 H. 8. Br. Patents 98. And al≈øo this Action re≈øts in privity of record, and cannot be di≈øplaced from thence, but by Act of Parliament, ≈øee Br. Cho≈øe in Action 14. 33 H. 8. for when the King will grant a thing in Action, he ought in his Patent to recite all the circum≈øtances of the matter, as the Right, and how it became a Right, and becau≈øe the Queen here doth not make mention of this Right, as of the Entail, the Recovery, and the Attainder, for that cau≈øe the Right doth not pa≈øs. The Ca≈øe betwixt Cromer and Cranmer, 8 Eliz. the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee was attainted of Trea≈øon, the Queen granted to the Heir of the Di≈ø≈øei≈øee all the Right which came unto her by the Attainder of his Ance≈øtor, nothing pa≈ø≈øed, Cau≈øa qua ≈øupra: And always where the King grants any thing, which he cannot grant, but as King, that ≈øuch a grant without ≈øpecial words, is to no purpo≈øe. Coke contrary, & he agreed the Ca≈øe put by Egerton, for at the time of the Attainder, B. had a Right of Remainder; but in our Ca≈øe Hen. Norris had not any Right, but a po≈ø≈øibility of a Right of Action, i.e. a Writ of Error; And he ≈øaid that this Writ of Error is not forfeitable (for it is an Action which re≈øts in privity) no more than a condition in gro≈øs, as a Feoffment in Fee is made upon condition of the party of the Feoffor who is attainted ut ≈øupra: This word (Right) in the Act of Attainder ≈øhall not transfer this Condition to the Queen, and of the Act of Attainder to Hen. Norris, it is to be conceived That the makers of the Act did not intend, that by the word (Right) every right of any manner, or quality what≈øoever ≈øhould pa≈øs to carry a Condition to the Queen, and therefore we ought to conceive, that the makers of the Act did not intend to touch Rights which re≈øted in privity: And as to the Grant of the Queen, to the Lord Norris of the Mannor of Mer≈øton, Et omnia jura ≈øua in eodem, he conceived, that thereby the Right of the Writ of Error did pa≈øs; for it is not like Cranmers Ca≈øe, but if in the ≈øaid Ca≈øe, the Land it ≈øelf had been ≈øet down in the Grant, it had been good enough, as that Cranmer being ≈øei≈øed in Fee of the Manor of D. was there of di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and ≈øo being di≈ø≈øei≈øed was attainted of high Trea≈øon: now the Queen grants to his Heirs totum jus ≈øuum in his Manor of D, &c. and ≈øo in our Ca≈øe, the Queen hath granted to the Lord Norris, Manerium ≈øuum de Mer≈øton & omnia jura ≈øua in eodem, &c. at another day it was moved by Plowden, that this Right of Writ of Error was not transferred to the Queen by the Act, but ≈øuch Right might be ≈øaved to a ≈øtranger, &c. the words of the Act are, omnia jura ≈øua, and this word (≈øua) is Pronomen po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionis, by which it is to be conceived, that no Right ≈øhould pa≈øs, but that which was a pre≈øent Right, as a Right in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but this Right to a Writ of Error, was not in Hen. Norris at the time of his Attainder, but it was wholly in him again≈øt whom the erroneous Iudgment was had: and therefore if in a Praecipe quod reddat, the Tenant vouch and lo≈øeth, and Iudgment is given, and before Execution, the Tenant is attainted by Act of Parliament, by words ut ≈øupra, and afterwards he is pardoned, the Demandant ≈øueth for Execution again≈øt the Tenant, now notwith≈øtanding this Attainder, the Tenant may ≈øue Execution again≈øt the Vouchee, and afterwards Wray chief Iu≈øtice openly declared in Court, the opinion of him≈øelf and all his companions Iu≈øtices, and al≈øo of all the other Iu≈øtices to be, That by this Act of Parliament, by which all Lands, Tenements, Hereditaments, and all Rights of any manner and quality what≈øoever Henry Norris had, the day of his Attainder, or ever after, Lionel then being alive, and over-living the ≈øaid Hen. Norris,
that this Writ of Error was not transferred to the Queen: And that the ≈øaid Act by the words afore≈øaid could not convey to the King this po≈ø≈øibility of right, for at the time of the Attainder, the Right of the Writ of Error was in Lyonel, and Hen. during the e≈øtate tail limited to Lyonell had not to do with the Land, nor any matter concerning it: And Iudgment was given accordingly; And it was holden, That he in the Rever≈øion, or Remainder upon an E≈øtate tail might have a Writ of Error by the common Law, upon a Recovery had again≈øt Tenant in tail in Rever≈øion.

div.head: CCCLXV. Mich. 25, & 26. Eliz. In the common Pleas.
div.p: Copy-holder.IN Tre≈øpa≈øs brought by a Copy-holder again≈øt the Lord for cutting down and carrying away his Trees, &c. It was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, That the place where, &c. was Cu≈øtomary lands of the Plaintiffs, holden of the Defendant, and that the Trees whereof, &c. were Chery Trees, de magnitudine ≈øufficienti e≈ø≈øendi maremium, and that the place where they growed, was neither Orchard, nor Garden: It was ≈øaid by the Court, That by the Cu≈øtom the Copyholder could not cut down ≈øuch Trees, but the Lord might, and that the cutting down of ≈øuch Trees which were not Wa≈øt, the Copy-holder might ju≈øtifie without puni≈øhment: but becau≈øe by the Verdict it did not appear that the Trees for which the Action was brought were Timber in facto, but only de magnitudine effendi maremium, the Plaintiff had Iudgment.

div.head:
CCCLXVI. The Lord Staffords Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25, & 26. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Extent.UPon Recovery in debt again≈øt the Lord Stafford, certain Lands of the Lord were extended by Elegit; The Queen becau≈øe the Lord Stafford was endebted unto her, by Prerogative ou≈øted the Tenant by Elegit: Fleetwood Serjeant moved the Court in the behalf of him who recovered, and ≈øurmi≈øed to the Court that the Queen was ≈øatisfied, and therefore prayed a Re-extent; but the Court would not grant it, becau≈øe they were not certain of the matter, but advi≈øed the party to ≈øue a Scire facia; again≈øt the ≈øaid Lord Stafford, to know and ≈øhew cau≈øe, why a Re-extent ≈øhould not i≈ø≈øue forth, the Queen being ≈øatisfied, &c.

div.head:
CCCLXVII. Gibbs and Rowlies Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25, & 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Tithes. SYmon Gibbs Par≈øon of Beddington, Libelled in the Spiritual Court again≈øt Rowlie, for Tithe Milk, Rowlie upon ≈øurmi≈øe of a Pre≈øcription, de modo Decimandi, obtained a Prohibition, which was again≈øt Symon Gibbs, Rectorem Eccle≈øiae parochial, de Nether Beddington, and the parties were at I≈ø≈øue upon the Pre≈øcription,Prohibition. and it was found for Rowlie. Egerton Solicitor moved again≈øt the Prohibition, becau≈øe the Libel is again≈øt Gibbs, Rectorem Eccle≈øiae paroch. de Beddington, and the Prohibition was, de Nether Beddington, and it was not averred that Beddington in the Libel, and Nether Beddington, is unum & idem, & non diver≈øa; It was ≈øaid by the Court, That upon the matter there is not any Prohibition again≈øt Rectorem Eccle≈øiae de
Beddington only, and therefore ≈øaid to the Plaintiffs Coun≈øel, let the Par≈øon proceed in the Spiritual Court at his peril.

div.head:
CCCLXVIII. Ru≈ø≈øell and Handfords Ca≈øe.
Mich. 25, & 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: RU≈ø≈øell brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Handford, and declared, Quod cum quoddam molendinum ab entiquo fuit erectum, upon ≈øuch a River,Nu≈øance. de quo, one Thomas Ru≈ø≈øell who≈øe Heir the Plaintiff is, was ≈øei≈øed in his Deme≈øn as of Fee, and dyed thereof ≈øei≈øed, after who≈øe death the ≈øame de≈øcended to the Plaintiff, by force of which the Plaintiff was ≈øei≈øed in his Deme≈øn as of Fee, and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, The Defendant upon the ≈øame River had levyed a new Mill, per quod cur≈øus aquae praedict. coarctatus e≈øt, and upon Not guilty, It was found for the Plaintiff: It was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, That it is not layed in the Declaration, that his Mill had been a Mill time out of mind, &c. And then if it be not an ancient Mill time out of mind,Words of Pre≈øcription. &c. it was lawful for the Defendant to erect a new Mill; And it was ≈øaid, That the≈øe words (ab antiquo) are not fit or ≈øignificant words to ≈øet forth a Pre≈øcription, but the words, A tempore cujus contrarii memoria hominum non exi≈øtit, are the u≈øual words for ≈øuch a purpo≈øe: See the Book of Entries 10, 11. See 11 H. 4. 200. If I have a Mill and another levies another Mill there, and the Miller hinders the Water to run to my Mill, or doth any ≈øuch Nu≈øance,Roll. 140. an Action lyeth without any Pre≈øcription, as it ≈øeems by the Book in 22 H. 6. 14. The Plaintiff declared, That he was Lord of ≈øuch a Town, and that he and all his Predece≈ø≈øors, Priors of N. Lords of the ≈øame Town, have had, within the ≈øame Town, four Mills time out of mind, &c. And that no other per≈øon had any Mill in the ≈øaid Town, but the Plaintiff and his Predece≈ø≈øors, the ≈øaid four Mills, and that all the Tenants of the Plaintiff within the ≈øame Town, and all other Re≈øiants there, &c. ought, and time out of mind, &c. had u≈øed to grind at the ≈øaid Mills of the Plaintiff, and that the Defendant, one of the Tenants of the Plaintiff, had erected and ≈øet up a Hor≈øe Mill within the ≈øaid Town, and there the Re≈øiants grinded, &c. And it was holden, That peradventure upon ≈øuch matter an Action lyeth, becau≈øe the Defendant being one of the Tenants of the Plaintiff is bound by the Cu≈øtom and Pre≈øcription, ≈øo as he hath offended again≈øt the privity of the Cu≈øtom and Pre≈øcription. And as to the Ca≈øe in que≈øtion, It was the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices,Hob. 189. Ante 168. 1 Cro. 415. That if the Mill whereof the Plaintiff hath declared, be not an ancient Mill, that this Action doth not lye upon the matter, eo quod cur≈øus aquae coarctatur: But yet at la≈øt, it was holden by the Court to be good enough, notwith≈øtanding the Exception. Another Exception was taken to the Declaration, becau≈øe that here is ≈øet forth the ≈øei≈øin of the Father of the Plaintiff, and the De≈øcent to the Plaintiff, by force of which he was ≈øei≈øed in his Deme≈øn, &c. without ≈øhewing that after the death of the Father that he entred into the ≈øaid Mill,Sei≈øin in fact; and in Law. &c. ≈øo as no ≈øei≈øin in fact is alleadged, but only a ≈øei≈øin in Law, and if the Plaintiff was not ≈øei≈øed in fact, he cannot puni≈øh this per≈øonal wrong, but the Exception was di≈øallowed, for ≈øuch a ≈øei≈øin in Law is ≈øufficient for the maintenance of this Action. And afterwards the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover his Damages. See for the Action it ≈øelf contained in the Declaration. 8 Eliz. Dyer 248.

div.head:
CCCLXIX. Cleypools Ca≈øe.
Mich. 26. Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p: Informations, upon the Statute of 5 Eliz. of Tillage.INformation in the Exchequer again≈øt Cleypool, upon the Statute of Tillage, 5 Eliz. ≈øetting forth, That the Defendant hath converted three hundred Acres of arable Lands of Tillage, to pa≈øture, and the ≈øame conver≈øion hath continued from 15 Eliz. unto the two and twentieth of Eliz: The Defendant as to the Conver≈øion pleaded Not guilty, and as to the Continuance, the general Pardon by Parliament, 23 Eliz. upon which the Attorney general did demur in Law. It was argued, That that pardon did not extend to the continuance of the ≈øaid Conver≈øion: And fir≈øt the Barons were clear of opinion, That if A. be ≈øei≈øed of Arable Lands, and converts the ≈øame to pa≈øture, and ≈øo converted, lea≈øeth it to B. who continues it in pa≈øture as he found it, he ≈øhall be charged by that Statute: And it is not any good Con≈øtruction, where the Exception in the pardon is, excepting the converting of any Land from Tillage to Pa≈øture, made, done, committed, or permitted, that the Conver≈øion excepted out of the pardon ≈øhall be intended and con≈øtrued the bare Act of Conver≈øion, but the whole offence, i. the continuance and practi≈øe of it is under≈øtood: As if by general pardon all intru≈øions are excepted, now by that, the in≈øtant Act of Intru≈øion, i. the bare Entry is not only excepted, but al≈øo the continuance of the Intru≈øion, and the perception of the profits: And note, The words of the Statute are (conver≈øion permitted) and Conver≈øion continued is Conver≈øion permitted: And the ≈øaid Statute doth not puni≈øh the Conver≈øion, but al≈øo the continuance of the Conver≈øion, for the penalty is appointed for each year in which the Conver≈øion continues: And Egerton Solicitor put this Ca≈øe, 11 H. 8. It was enacted by 3 H. 7. cap. 11. That upon Recovery in Debt, if the Defendant in delay of Execution ≈øues a Writ of Error, and the Iudgment be affirmed, he ≈øhall pay damages, now the ca≈øe was, That one in Execution brought ≈øuch a Writ of Error, and the fir≈øt Iudgment is affirmed, he ≈øhall pay damages, and yet here is not any delay of the Execution, for the Defendant was in Execution before, but here is an Interruption of the Execution, and the Statute did intend the Execution it ≈øelf, i. the continuance in Execution, ibidem moraturus quou≈øque: It was ≈øaid on the other ≈øide, That the conver≈øion and continuance thereof are two ≈øeveral things, each by it ≈øelf, and ≈øo the conver≈øion only being excepted in the pardon, the continuance thereof remains in the grace of the pardon: And it appeareth by the Statute of 2, and 3. Ph. & Ma. That conver≈øion, and continuance are not the ≈øame, but alia, atque diver≈øa, and di≈øtinct things in the con≈øideration of the Law; for there it is enacted, That if any per≈øon ≈øhall have any Lands to be holden in Tillage according to the ≈øaid Statute, but converted to Pa≈øture by any other per≈øon, the Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c. have authority by the ≈øaid Statute to enjoyn ≈øuch per≈øons to convert ≈øuch Lands to Tillage again, &c. And in all ca≈øes in the Law, there is a great difference betwixt the beginning of a wrong, and the continuance of it: As if the Father levyeth a Nu≈øance in his own Lands to the offence of another and dyeth; an A≈ø≈øize of Nu≈øance doth not lye again≈øt the Heir for the continuance of that wrong, but a Quod permittat, See F.N.B. 124. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCLXX. Powley and Siers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: POwley brought Debt again≈øt Sier Executor of the Will of A: Debt The Defendant demanded Iudgment of the Writ, for he ≈øaid, That one B. was Executor of the ≈øaid A. and that the ≈øaid B. did con≈øtitute the Defendant his Executor, ≈øo the Writ ought to be brought again≈øt the Defendant as Executor of the Executor, and not as immediate Executor to the ≈øaid A. The Plaintiff by Reply ≈øaid, That the ≈øaid B. before any probate of the Will, or any Admini≈øtration dyed, and ≈øo maintained his Writ. Wray Iu≈øtice was again≈øt the Writ, for although here be not any probate of the Will of A. or any other Admini≈øtration, yet when B. made his Will, and the Defendant his Executor, the ≈øame is a good acceptance in Law of the Admini≈øtration and Execution of the fir≈øt Will, for the Defendant might have an Action of Debt due to the fir≈øt Te≈øtator: Gawdy and Ayliff Iu≈øtices, The Writ is good: See Dyer, 1 Cro. 211. 212. 23 Eliz. 372. again≈øt Wray.

div.head: CCCLXXI. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was: A ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands,Bargain and ≈øale of Trees. bargained and ≈øold by Indenture all the Trees there growing, Habendum, ≈øuccidendum, & exportandum, within twenty years after the date of the ≈øaid Indenture, the twenty years expire; The Bargainee cuts down the Trees, A. brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs for cutting down the Trees: And by Wray, Iu≈øtice, The meer property of the Trees ve≈øts in the Bargainee,Po≈øt. 288. and the Limitation of time which cometh after is not to any purpo≈øe but to ha≈øten the cutting of the Trees within a certain time, within which, if the Vendee doth not cut them, he ≈øhould be puni≈øhed as a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor as to the Land, but not as to the Trees: Gawdy contrary; And that upon this Contract, a conditional property ve≈øts in the Vendee, which ought to be pur≈øued according to the direction of the condition, and becau≈øe the condition is broken, the property of the Trees is ve≈øted in A.

div.head:
CCCLXXII. Curriton and Gadbarys Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN in Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared,Lea≈øes. That the Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff ≈øhould make a lea≈øe for life to the Defendant of certain Lands, Habendum after the death of A. before the tenth of Augu≈øt next following, promi≈øed to pay the Plaintiff ten pounds, the fir≈øt day of May next after the promi≈øe which was before the tenth of Augu≈øt: And the truth was, That the ≈øaid ten pounds was not paid at the day, ut ≈øupra, nor the ≈øaid Lea≈øe made: And now both ≈øides being in default, the Plaintiff brought an Action; It was ≈øaid by Wray Iu≈øtice, If the Plaintiff had made the Lea≈øe according to the con≈øideration, and in performance thereof the action would have lyen, but now his own default had barred him of the Action: But for another cau≈øe, the Declaration was holden in≈øufficient, for here is not any Con≈øideration, for the promi≈øe is, in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff ≈øhall lea≈øe to the Defendant for life, Habendum after the death of A. which cannot be good by way of lea≈øe, but ought to enure by way of grant of the Rever≈øion, ≈øo as here is no lea≈øe, therefore no con≈øideration, and notwith≈øtanding
that if a Lea≈øe be made for life, Habendum after the death of A. the Habendum is void, and the Lea≈øe ≈øhall be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion according to the Premi≈øes, yet the Law will not give ≈øuch con≈øtruction to the words of a Promi≈øe, Contract, or A≈ø≈øump≈øit, but all the words ought to be wholly re≈øpected according to the Letter, ≈øo as becau≈øe that no Lea≈øe can be made according to the words of the Con≈øideration, no ≈øupply thereof ≈øhall be by any favorable con≈øtruction: And ≈øo it was adjudged: But before the ≈øame imperfection was e≈øpied, Iudgment was entred, and therefore, the Court awarded that there ≈øhould be a ce≈ø≈øet executio, entred upon the Roll, for it is hard as it was ≈øaid by Wray to drive the party to a Writ of Error in Parliament, becau≈øe Parliaments are not now ≈øo frequently holden as they have u≈øed to be holden, and the Execution was ≈øtaid accordingly.

div.head:
CCCLXXIII. Willis and Crosbys Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Error.IN a Writ of Error, It was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, That whereas in the fir≈øt Action, the parties were at i≈ø≈øue, and upon the Venire facias one G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
gory Tomp≈øon was returned; But upon the Habeas Corpora, George T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
≈øon was returned, and the Iury was taken, and found for the Plaintiff ‚Ä¢ and Iudgment given accordingly;Amercement. It was argued on the part of the Plaintiff in the fir≈øt Action; that the ≈øame is a thing amendable: As 9 E. 4. 14. A Iury was impannelled by the name of I.B. and in the Habeas Corpora he was named W.B. and by ≈øuch name ≈øworn, &c. And upon Examination of the Sheriff, it was found that he was the ≈øame per≈øon who was impannelled, and it was amended and made according to the Pannel; But the opinion of the whole Court was, That as this ca≈øe is it was not amendable, and it is not like the ca≈øe of 9 E. 4. For there the Examination was before the Verdict when the Sheriff was in Court, but here it is after Verdict, and the Sheriff is out of Court, and cannot be examined, and for the≈øe cau≈øes the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head:
CCCLXXIV. Ognell and the Sheriffs of Londons Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
OGnell brought Debt upon an E≈øcape by Bill in the Exchequer again≈øt the Sheriffs of London, E≈øcape. 1 Cro. 164. the Ca≈øe was, That one Crofts was bound to the now Plaintiff in a Recogni≈øance, and afterwards committed for Felony to the Pri≈øon of Newgate, of which he was attainted and remained in Pri≈øon in the cu≈øtody of the Sheriffs: Afterwards Ognell ≈øued a Sc. fac. upon the ≈øaid Recogni≈øance again≈øt Crofts, the Sheriffs returned a Cepi, and the e≈øpecial matter afore≈øaid, and after Iudgment given again≈øt Crofts for Ognell, Crofts got his pardon, and e≈øcaped: It was argued, That notwith≈øtanding this Attainder, Crofts is ≈øubject to the Execution obtained upon the Recognizance: See the ca≈øe of E≈øcape betwixt Maun≈øer and Anne≈øley, 16 Eliz. in Bendloes ca≈øe, 2 E. 4. 1. It is ≈øaid by Watman, That a man out-lawed for Felony ≈øhall an≈øwer, but ≈øhall not be an≈øwered: See 6 E. 4. 4. One condemned in Redi≈ø≈øei≈øin, was taken by a Capias pro fine, and committed to Pri≈øon, and afterwards out-lawed of Felony, the King pardons the Felony, yet he ≈øhall remain in Execution for the party, if he will; But if the party be once in Execution for the party, and then out-lawed of Felony, it ≈øeems by 6 E. 4. Fitz. Execution, 13. that the Execution is gone. And all the Barons were clear of opinion
in the principal ca≈øe for the Plaintiff. And they al≈øo ≈øaid, That if one who hath a Protection from the King be taken in Execution, and E≈øcape, the Gaoler ≈øhall an≈øwer for the E≈øcape, and that was one Hales Ca≈øe. And afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, Hales Ca≈øe. and one of the cau≈øes of the Iudgment was, becau≈øe that the Sheriffs had returned C ‚Ä¢ pi upon the Proce≈øs.

div.head:
CCCLXXV. Bi≈øhop and Redmans Ca≈øe.
Hill. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: BI≈øhop, a Doctor of the Civil Law, brought an Action of Covenant again≈øt Redman Archdeacon of Canterbury, and declared upon an Indenture, by which the Defendant did con≈øtitute the Plaintiff Offici ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ em ≈øuum of his Archdeaconcy for three years, and gave to him by the ≈øaid Indenture, Authoritatem admittendi, & inducendi quo≈øcunque Clericos ad quaecunque beneficia Eccle≈øia≈øtica infra Archidiaconatum praedict', and al≈øo Probate of Wills; and further granted to him, omnem & omnim ‚Ä¢ dam Archidiaconatum Juri≈ødictionem ≈øuam praedict' ab≈øque impetitione, de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ egatione, re≈øt ‚Ä¢ ictione, &c. after which Doctor Young was created Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, which is in the Iurisdiction of the ≈øaid Archdeaconry; and the Defendant took upon him to enthronize the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop in his ≈øaid Church, and took of him for his Fee twenty Nobles, whereupon the Plaintiff brought this Action. It was moved for the Defendant, that upon the matter the Action doth lye; for the Office of enthronizing or en≈øtalling of a Bi≈øhop doth not pa≈øs by the ≈øaid Indenture, nor is there any word in the Indenture that doth extend unto it, for the Bi≈øhop is not a Clark, and the Plaintiff by the Indenture hath not to do but with Clarks, not with Bi≈øhops; and it appeareth by the Grant of Sub≈øidies, by the Clergy in Parliament, that a Bi≈øhop and a Clark are di≈øtinct things. See In≈øtrumentum hereof, Praelatus & Clericus, &c. Al≈øo the Plaintiff hath not to do with a Bi≈øhoprick, but with Benefices, and a Bi≈øhoprick is not a Benefice, but a higher thing: And further the Plaintiff hath power to admit and induct, which doth not extend to in≈øtalling, or inthronization, for that belongs to a Bi≈øhop; and the Court was clear of opinion, That by this Grant there did not pa≈øs any power to in≈øtal or inthronize Bi≈øhops; and the general words, i.e. omnem & omnimodam juri≈ødictionem Archidiaconatum praedictam, Words which amount to Covenant. did not mend the matter, for the word (Praedictam) doth not re≈øtrain the words, Omnem, & omnimodam, &c. but admitting that; It was moved, If upon this Indenture Covenant lieth, for there is not any expre≈øs Covenant, yet the words ab≈øque impetitione, denegatione, re≈øtrictione, do amount to ≈øo much, to make the Defendant ≈øubject to his Action, if the matter in it ≈øelf would have ≈øerved for him, and ≈øo was the opinion of the Court.

div.head:
CCCLXXVI. Lady Lodges Ca≈øe.
Hill. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
THe Lady Laxton of London by her Will bequeathed to Matthew Luddington, and Andrew Luddington, Prohibition. Poph. 11. Dyer 59. ≈øeveral Legacies in monies to be paid to them re≈øpectively at their ≈øeveral ages, &c. and made the Lady Lodge her Daughter her Executrix and died, Andrew died before his full age, Matthew took Letters of Admini≈øtration of the goods of Andrew, and ≈øued the Lady Lodge in the Spiritual Court for the Legacy
bequeathed to Andrew; before which Suit begins, the Lady Lodge, with Sir Thomas her Husband, gave all the goods which ≈øhe had as Executor of the ≈øaid Lady Laxton to Sir William Cordel Ma≈øter of the Rolls, and to William Lodge Son of the ≈øaid Sir Thomas and his Lady, depending which Suit the Lady Lodge died, after which ≈øentence was given again≈øt her being dead, and now a Citation was out of the Spiritual Court again≈øt William Lodge Executor of the ≈øaid Lady Lodge, to ≈øhew cau≈øe why the ≈øentence given again≈øt the ≈øaid Lady Lodge ≈øhould not be put in Execution again≈øt him; and ≈øentence was given again≈øt the ≈øaid William Lodge, who appealed to the Delegates, and there the ≈øentence was affirmed. And now came William Lodge into the Kings Bench, and ≈øet forth the grant of the ≈øaid Lady Lodge, as afore≈øaid, and that the ≈øame was not examinable in the Spiritual Court, and thereupon prayed a Prohibition: And Awbrey, Doctor of the Civil Law, came into Court to inform the Iu≈øtices, what their Law was in certain points touching the Ca≈øe in que≈øtion; and as to the ≈øentence given again≈øt the Lady Lodge, after her death he ≈øaid, That if the Defendant died before i≈ø≈øue joyned, which is called Litis conte≈øtationem, the Suit ≈øhall cea≈øe, but if he dieth after Litis conte≈øtationem, it is otherwi≈øe, for in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Suit ≈øhall proceed; for after Litis conte≈øtationem, the right of the Suit is ≈øo ve≈øted in the Proctor,Swinburn 212. that he is a per≈øon ≈øuable until the end of the Suit: and al≈øo he reported their Law to be,Bro. Devi≈øe 27. 45. Office of Exce. 347. Sh ‚Ä¢ p. Touch≈øtone &c. 454. Plowd. 345. Orphans Legacy 281. Note, It was adjudged contrary to this, Mich. An. Dom. 1653. in the Kings Bench. in Do ‚Ä¢ mlowes Ca≈øe. Poph. 11. That if a Legacy be bequeathed to an Infant to be paid when he ≈øhall come to the Age of twenty one years, if ≈øuch a Legatory dieth before ≈øuch age, yet the Executor or Admini≈øtrator of ≈øuch Legator ≈øhall ≈øue for the ≈øaid Legacy pre≈øently, and ≈øhall not expect until the time, in which if the Infant had continued in life he had attained his full age. And as to the Prohibition it was argued by Egerton Solicitor General, That the Grant afore≈øaid is not triable in the Spiritual Court: As if the ≈øaid Lady Lodge had ≈øuffered a Recovery to be had again≈øt her as Executor by Covin, &c. the ≈øame is not examinable in the Spiritual Court, but belongs to the temporal Conu≈øans, and therefore he prayed a Prohibition: But on the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, That if the Prohibition be allowed, the Legatory hath no remedy; but that was denied, for the party might ≈øue in the Chancery. And after the Prohibition granted, the Court awarded a ≈øpecial Con≈øultation, quatenus non extendat ultra manus Executoris, & quatenus non agitur de validitate facti, i. the Grant afore≈øaid.

div.head:
CCCLXXVII. Huddy and Fi≈øhers Ca≈øe.
Hill. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Debt.DEbt was brought upon a Bond, the Condition of which was for the performance of Covenants, Grants and Agreements in an Indenture: And in the Indenture it was recited, That in con≈øideration that the ≈øaid Huddy ≈øhould build a Mill upon the Land demi≈øed by the Defendant to the Plaintiff by the ≈øame Indenture,Attaint. and a Water-cour≈øe by the Land demi≈øed, the Defendant lea≈øed the ≈øaid Land to the Plaintiff, and the Lea≈øe was by the words Dedi & conce≈ø≈øi. And the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned the breach of the ≈øaid Covenant in Law, in that the Defendant had ≈øtopped the ≈øaid Water-cour≈øe ≈øo made by the Plaintiff, upon which they were at I≈ø≈øue, and it was found for the Plaintiff, upon which the Defendant brought Attaint, and the fal≈øe oath was found; and it was moved in Arre≈øt of Iudgment, That here is no I≈ø≈øue, and then by con≈øequence no Verdict, and then no fal≈øe Oath, and then no cau≈øe of Attaint; for here the I≈ø≈øue is taken upon the ≈øtopping of the Water-cour≈øe, which upon the ≈øhewing of the party is not any cau≈øe of Action, for in the Indenture there is not any
expre≈øs Covenant, Clau≈øe, or Agreement, that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould enjoy the Water-cour≈øe ≈øo to be made, only there is a Covenant in Law ri≈øing upon the≈øe words Dedi & conce≈ø≈øi, which cannot extend to a thing not in e≈ø≈øe at the time of the making the Indenture. Coke, who argued for the Defendants in the Attaint re≈øembled this ca≈øe to the ca≈øe in 23 E. 3. Garr. 77. Where it is holden, that the warranty knit to the Manor ≈øhall not extend to the Tenancy e≈øcheated: And 30 E. 3. 14. The Recovery in value ≈øhall not be in larger proportion than the Land warranted was at the time of the warranty made. So in our ca≈øe, this Covenant ≈øhall not extend to any thing which was not in e≈ø≈øe at the time of the Covenant made: And ≈øee 25 A≈ø≈ø. 2. where the Court ≈øhall reject a Verdict, or part of a Verdict, &c. And becau≈øe the now Plaintiff might after the Verdict have alledged the ≈øame in arre≈øt of Iudgment, which he did not, he ≈øhall not be helped by Attaint, but it ≈øhall be accounted his folly that he would not for his own ea≈øe, and to avoid circuity of Action ≈øhew the matter in ≈øtay of Iudgment: As 9 E. 4. 12. by Littleton: If a man be Indicted of Felony, if the Iudgment be in≈øufficient, but he takes not advantage of it, but pleads the general I≈ø≈øue, and is acquitted, he ≈øhall never after have a Writ of Con≈øpiracy, &c. And for another cau≈øe Iudgment ought not to be given in this Ca≈øe, becau≈øe it doth not appear that Execution hath been ≈øued, and then here is no party grieved: And then this Action being conceived upon the Statute of 23 H. 8. Cap. 3. which gives it to the party grieved doth not lye, for a party grieved cannot be intended without Execution ≈øued. See 21 H. 6. 55. by Pa≈øton; Fal≈øe oath, Iudgment, and Execution do entitle the party grieved to Attaint. And ≈øee the Stat. of 23 H. 8. which enacts, That the party ≈øhall be re≈øtored to as much as he hath lo≈øt therefore he ought to lo≈øe (by Execution) before he be a per≈øon able „Äà‚óä„Äâ bring this Action: But as to that matter, ≈øee the Statute of 1 E. 3. 6. by which it is Enacted, That the Iu≈øtices ≈øhall not leave to take Attaint for the damages not paid, ≈øo as before the ≈øaid Statute no Attaint lay before Execution, 33 H. 6. 21. by Pri≈øoit 5 H. 7. 22. t. E. 1. Attaint 70. 8 E. 2. A≈ø≈øize 396. And it was moved, That for another cau≈øe the Attaint doth not lye, as it is pur≈øued in Proce≈øs upon it, for the Plaintiff hath not pur≈øued the Statute, upon which the Attaint is grounded, for the ≈øaid Statute gives ≈øpecial Proce≈øs in this ca≈øe again≈øt the Petit Iury, Grand Iury, and the party, viz. Summons, Re-≈øummons, and Di≈øtre≈øs infinite; but in this Ca≈øe the Plaintiff hath ≈øued otherwi≈øe, which is again≈øt the direction of the Statute. And that was taken to be a material Exception by Clench and Gawdy Iu≈øtices, for the Verdict doth not ≈øave the matter of Proce≈øs in this ca≈øe by the Statute of 18 Eliz. which doth not extend to proceedings in penal Cau≈øes; w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch ≈øee, by the words of the Statute, by an expre≈øs Provi≈øo: But Quaere, If it be a penal Statute, becau≈øe a le≈ø≈øer puni≈øhment is enacted by it, than that which was before inflicted upon ≈øuch offenders: And as to the matter of Execution, Quaere, If the Plaintiff be not pars gravata in hoc only, that he is ≈øubject to the ≈øaid Iudgment, and ≈øo liable to Execution.

div.head:
CCCLXXVIII. Penruddock and Newmans Ca≈øe.
Hill. 28 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Ejectione firmae, Execution. 2 Len. 49. the Plaintiff declared upon a Lea≈øe made by the Lord Morley, and upon Not guilty pleaded, this ≈øpecial matter was found, that William Lord Mountegle, ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. whereof &c. became bounden in a Statute in ≈øuch a ≈øum to A. who died, the Executors of A. ≈øued Execution again≈øt the ≈øaid Lord, i. upon the Extendi facias, a Libertate i≈ø≈øued forth, upon which the ≈øaid Manor was
delivered to the ≈øaid Executors, but was not returned. It was further found, That the ≈øaid Executors being ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor, the ≈øaid Lord commanded a Court Baron to be holden there, which was holden accordingly by the ≈øufferance of the Executors, and the ≈øaid Executors were al≈øo pre≈øent, at which time the Executors in the pre≈øence of the ≈øaid Lord ≈øaid the≈øe words, viz. We have nothing to do with this Manor. Return of the Sheriff. 4 Co. 67. And upon this Verdict two things were moved, If becau≈øe the Liberate was not returned, the Execution was good: And as to that divers Books were cited, 21 H. 6. 8. 18 E. 3. 25. And it was ≈øaid that there was a difference betwixt a Liberate, and a Capias ad Satisfaciendum, and a Fieri facias, for the≈øe Writs are conditional, Ita quod Habeas Corpus, &c. Ita, quod habeas denarios hic in Curia, 3 H. 7. 3. 16 H. 7. 14. But contrary in the Writ of Liberate, Habere facias ≈øei≈øinam, for in ≈øuch Writs there is not ≈øuch clau≈øe, and therefore if ≈øuch Writs be not returned, the Execution done by virtue of them is good enough: And ≈øee 11 H. 4. 121. If the Sheriff by force of an Elegit delivers to the party the moiety of the Land of the Defendant, and doth not return the Writ; if now the Plaintiff will bring an Action of Debt de Novo, the Defendant may plead in Bar the Execution afore≈øaid, although the Writ of Execution were not returned, and yet the Execution is not upon the Record. And ≈øee the ca≈øe there put by Hankford: And it is not like to the ca≈øe of Partition made by the Sheriff, the ≈øame ought to be returned, becau≈øe that after the return thereof, a new and ≈øecondary Iudgment is to be given, i. Quod partitio praedicta firma & ≈øtabilis maneat in perpetuum, firma & ≈øtabilis in perpetuum teneatur, ≈øee the Book of Entries 114. And Egerton Solicitor cited a ca≈øe lately adjudged betwixt the Earl of Leice≈øter and the Widow Tanfeild, Earl of Leice≈øter and Tanfeilds Ca≈øe. That ≈øuch Execution without return was good enough. Another matter was moved; Admit, that here be a good Execution, if now the Executors being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Manor by force of that Execution, and permitting and ≈øuffering the Conu≈øor to hold a Court there in the Manor-hou≈øe, and ≈øaying in his pre≈øence the words afore≈øaid, if the ≈øame doth amount to a Surrender by the Executors to the ≈øaid Conu≈øor,Surrender. or not. And Wray chief Iu≈øtice ≈øaid, That here upon this matter is not any Surrender, for here the words are not addre≈ø≈øed to the ≈øaid Conu≈øor who is capable of a Surrender, nor to any per≈øon certain: And it is not like to the ca≈øe of 40 E. 3. 23, 24. Chamberlains A≈ø≈øize, where Tenant for life ≈øaith to him in the Rever≈øion, That his will is that he enter, the ≈øame is a good Surrender, for there is a per≈øon certain who can take it; but contrary in this ca≈øe, for here it is but a general ≈øpeech. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCLXXIX. Baskervile and the Bi≈øhop of Herefords Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 28 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Quare Impedit.IN a Quare Impedit by Walter Baskervile, again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Hereford, &c. The Plaintiff counted, That Sir Nicholas Arnold was ≈øei≈øed of the Advow≈øon as in gro≈øs, and granted the ≈øame to the ≈øaid Baskervile and others, to the u≈øe of him≈øelf for life, and afterwards to the u≈øe of Richard Arnold his Son in tail; Provi≈øo, That if the ≈øaid Nicholas die, the ≈øaid Richard being within age of twenty three years, that then the Grantees and their Heirs ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed to them and their Heirs until the ≈øaid Richard hath accompli≈øhed the ≈øaid age: Nicholas dieth, Richard being of the age of fourteen years, by force of which the Grantees were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid Advow≈øon, and afterwards the Church became void, and ≈øo it belonged to them to pre≈øent: And Exception was taken to the Count, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had not averred the life of
Richard, upon who≈øe life the Intere≈øt of the Plaintiffs doth depend.Averment. And Gawdy Serjeant, likened it to the Ca≈øe of the Par≈øon which hath been adjudged, That where the Le≈ø≈øee of a Par≈øon brought an Ejectione firmae, and it was found for him, and in arre≈øt of Iudgment exception was taken to the Declaration, becau≈øe that the life of the Par≈øon was not averred, and for that cau≈øe Iudgment was ≈øtayed. Ander≈øon chief Iu≈øtice: Vpon the dying of Sir Nicholas Rich, being but of the age of fourteen years, an ab≈øolute Intere≈øt for nine years ve≈øts determinable upon the death of Richard, or rather, they are ≈øei≈øed in fee determinable upon the coming of Richard to the age of twenty three years.
