Rhodes and Windham contrary: That here is an Intere≈øt in the Grantees, determinable upon the death of Richard within the Term, for if Richard dieth without i≈ø≈øue within the Term, the Remainder is limited over to a ≈øtranger. And as to the Exception to the Count,Dyer 304. ‚Ä¢ . 2 Cro. 622, 637. 10 Co. 59. it was argued by Puckering Serjeant, that the Count was good enough,; for although the life of Richard be not expre≈øly averred, yet ≈øuch averment is ≈øtrongly implied, and ≈øo ≈øupplied: For the Count is, That dictus Nicholas obiit dicto Ric. being of the age of fourteen years, & non amplius, by force of which the Plaintiff was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid Advow≈øon, quo quidem ≈øic po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionato exi≈øtente, the Church became void, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed he could not be, if the ≈øaid Richard had not been then alive, and the ≈øame is as ≈øtrong as an Averment. See 10 E. 4. 18. In Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking his Clo≈øe, the Defendant pleads, That A. was ≈øei≈øed, and did enfeoff him; to which the Plaintiff ≈øaid, That long time before A. had any thing, B. was ≈øei≈øed and lea≈øed to the ≈øaid A. at will, who enfeoffed the Defendant, upon which B. did re-enter, and lea≈øed to the Plaintiff at will, by force of which he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed until the Defendant did the Tre≈øpa≈øs, and the ≈øame was allowed to be a good Replication, without averring the life of B. who lea≈øed to the Plaintiff at will, for that is implied by the words, i. Virtute cujus; 1 Cro. 766. the Plaintiff was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed until the Defendant did the Tre≈øpa≈øs. And ≈øee al≈øo 10 H. 7. 12. in an A≈ø≈øize of Common, The Plaintiff makes title, that he was ≈øei≈øed of a Me≈ø≈øuage, and of a Carve of Land, to which he and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate, &c. have had Common appendant, &c. And doth not ≈øay, that he is now ≈øei≈øed of the Me≈ø≈øuage: But this Exception was di≈øallowed by the Court, for ≈øei≈øin ≈øhall be intended to continue until the contrary be ≈øhewed. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCLXXX. Caries Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 28 Eliz. In the Exchequer.
div.p:
IN an Information in the Exchequer, by the Queen again≈øt Cary, Tithes. More Rep. 222. the Ca≈øe was this; A man grants ≈øitum Rectoriae cum decimis eidem pertinent. Habend. ≈øitum praedict. cum ≈øuis pertinentiis, for twenty years, the fir≈øt Grantee dieth within the Term. If now becau≈øe the Tithes are not expre≈øly named in the Habendum, the Grantee ≈øhall have them for life only, was the Que≈øtion. It was moved by Popham Attorney General, That the Grantee had the Tithes but for life, and to that purpo≈øe he cited a Ca≈øe adjudged 6 Eliz. in the Common Pleas: A man grants black Acre and white Acre, Habendum black Acre for life, nothing of white Acre ≈øhall pa≈øs but at will; and in the argument of that ca≈øe, Anthony Browne put this ca≈øe; Queen Mary granted to Roche≈øter ≈øuch ≈øeveral Offices, and ≈øhewed them ≈øpecially, Habendum two of them, and ≈øhewed which in certain, for forty years. It was adjudged that the two Offices which were not mentioned in the Habendum, were to Roche≈øter but for life, and determined by his death: And ≈øo he ≈øaid in this Ca≈øe, The Tithes not mentioned in
the Habendum ≈øhall be to the Grantee for life, and then he dying, his Executors taking the Tithes are Intrudors: But as to that, It was ≈øaid by Manwood chief Baron, That the ca≈øes are not alike, for the Grants in the ca≈øes cited are ≈øeveral, intire, and di≈øtinct things, which do not depend the one upon the other, but are in gro≈øs by them≈øelves. But in our Ca≈øes, The Tithes are parcel of the Rectory, and therefore for the nearne≈øs betwixt them, i. the Rectory and the Tithes, the Tithes upon the matter pa≈øs together with the ≈øite of the Rectory for the term of twenty years, and Iudgment was afterwards given accordingly.

div.head:
CCCLXXXI. The Lord Darcy and Sharpes Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Common Pleas, Mich. 27 & 28 Rot. 2432.
div.p: Debt. THomas Lord Darcy, Executor of John Lord Darcy, brought Debt upon a Bond again≈øt Sharpe, who pleaded that the Condition of the Bond was, That if the ≈øaid Sharpe did perform all the Covenants, &c. contained within a pair of Indentures, &c. By which Indentures the ≈øaid John Lord Darcy had ≈øold to the ≈øaid Sharpe certain Trees growing, &c. And by the ≈øame Indentures Sharpe had covenanted to cut down the ≈øaid Trees before the ≈øeventh of Augu≈øt, 1684. and ≈øhewed further, That after the ≈øealing and delivery of the ≈øaid Indenture, the ≈øaid Lord Darcy now Plaintiff,Razure of Deeds 11 Co. 27. cau≈øed and procured I. S. to raze the Indenture, quod penes praedict. Querentem remanebat, and of 1684. to make it 1685. and ≈øo the ≈øaid Indenture become void: And the opinion of the whole Court was clear again≈øt the Defendant, for the razure is in a place not material, and al≈øo the razure trencheth to the advantage of the Defendant him≈øelf who pleads it; and if the Indenture had become void by the razure, the Obligation had been ≈øingle and without Defea≈øance.

div.head:
CCCLXXXII. Roll≈øton and Chambers Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 28 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Co≈øts where Damages are given. 2 Len. 52. ROll≈øton brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs upon the Statute of 8 H. 6. of forcible Entry again≈øt Chambers, and upon I≈ø≈øue joyned it was found for the Plaintiff, and Damages a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Iury, and co≈øts of ≈øuit al≈øo, and co≈øts al≈øo de incremento were adjudged; And all were trebled in the Iudgment with this purclo≈øe, quae quidem damna in toto ≈øe attingunt ad, &c. and all by the name of Damages. It was objected again≈øt this Iudgment, that where damages are trebled, no co≈øts ≈øhall be given, as in Wa≈øt, &c. But it was clearly agreed by the whole Court, That not only the co≈øts a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Iury, but al≈øo tho≈øe which were adjudged de incremento ≈øhould be trebled, and ≈øo were all the Pre≈øidents, as was affirmed by all the Prothonotaries, and ≈øo are many Books, 19 H. 6. 32. 14 H. 6. 13. 22 H. 6. 57. 12 E. 4. 1. And Book of Entries 334. and Iudgment was given accordingly. And in this ca≈øe it was agreed by all the Iu≈øtices, That the party ≈øo convicted of the force at the ≈øuit of the party ≈øhould be fined, notwith≈øtanding that he was fined before upon Indictment for the ≈øame force.

div.head:
CCCLXXXIII. Jennor and Hardies Ca≈øe.
Hill. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas. Intrat. Trin. 27 Eliz. Rot. 1606.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was, Lands were devi≈øed to one Edith for life, upon condition that ≈øhe ≈øhould not marry; and if ≈øhe died, or married,Devi≈øes. that then the Land ≈øhould remain to A. in tail, and if A. died without I≈ø≈øue of his body in the life of Edith, that then the Land ≈øhould remain to the ≈øaid Edith, to di≈øpo≈øe thereof at her plea≈øure: And if the ≈øaid A. did ≈øurvive the ≈øaid Edith, that then the Lands ≈øhould be divided betwixt the Si≈øters of the Devi≈øor, A. died without I≈ø≈øue living Edith. Shutleworth Serjeant; Edith hath but for life; and yet he granted, That if Lands be devi≈øed to one to di≈øpo≈øe at his will and plea≈øure without more ≈øaying, That the Devi≈øee hath a Fee-≈øimple; but otherwi≈øe it is when tho≈øe words are qualified and re≈øtrained by ≈øpecial Limitation: As 15 H. 7. 12. A man devi≈øeth, that A. Goldsb. 135. Shepherds Touch-≈øtone 439. ≈øhall have his Lands in perpetuum during his life, he hath but an e≈øtate for life, for the words (During his life) do abridge the Intere≈øt given before. And 22 Eliz. one devi≈øeth Lands to another for life, to di≈øpo≈øe at his will and plea≈øure, he hath but an e≈øtate for life: And the≈øe words, (If A. dieth without I≈ø≈øue in the life of Edith, That then the Lands ≈øhould remain to Edith to di≈øpo≈øe at her plea≈øure) ≈øhall not be con≈øtrued to give to Edith a Fee-≈øimple, but to di≈øcharge the particular e≈øtate of the danger, penalty, and lo≈øs, which after might come by her marriage, ≈øo as now it is in her liberty. And al≈øo he ≈øaid, That by the Limitation of the latter Remainder, i. That the Lands ≈øhould be divided betwixt the Daughters of his Si≈øter, the meaning of the Devi≈øor was not, that Edith ≈øhould have a Fee-≈øimple, for the Remainder is not limited to her Heirs, &c. if A. dieth in the life of the ≈øaid Edith; for the Devi≈øor goeth further, That if A. overlives Edith, and afterwards dieth without I≈ø≈øue, that the ≈øaid Land ≈øhould be divided, &c. Walme≈øley contrary: And he relyed much upon the words of the Limitation of the Remainder to Edith, Quod integra remaneat dictae Edithae, and that ≈øhe might di≈øpo≈øe thereof at her plea≈øure,Ante 156. for the ≈øaid divi≈øion is limited to be upon a Contingent, i. if A. ≈øurvive Edith, but if Edith ≈øurvive A. then his intent is not that the Lands ≈øhould be divided, &c. but that they ≈øhall wholly remain to Edith, which was granted by the whole Court, and the Iu≈øtices did rely much upon the ≈øame rea≈øon; and they were very clear of opinion, That by tho≈øe words Edith had a Fee-≈øimple: And Iudgment was given accordingly. Ander≈øon conceived, That it was a Condition; but although that it be a Condition, ≈øo as it may be doubted, if a Remainder might be limited upon a Condition, yet this devi≈øe is as good as a new devi≈øe in Rever≈øion upon the precedent Condition, and not as a Remainder, quod Windham conce≈ø≈øit; but Periam was very ≈øtrong of opinion, That it is a Limitation. Two Ioyntenants of a Term, A. and B. A. grants his part to B. nothing pa≈ø≈øeth by it, for (as a Grant) it cannot be good;Owen 102. 1 Cro. 314. 1 In≈øt. 186. for as one Ioyntenant cannot enfeo≈øt his Companion, no more can he ve≈øt any thing in him by grant, for he cannot grant to him a thing which he hath before; for Ioyntenants are ≈øei≈øed and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the whole, all which was granted per Curiam; and Ander≈øon ≈øaid, That if Lands be granted to A. and B. and the Heirs of A. B. cannot ≈øurrender to A. for a Surrender is as it were a grant; And as a Relea≈øe it cannot enure, for a Relea≈øe of a Right in Chattels cannot be without a Deed.

div.head:
CCCLXXXIV. Holling≈øhed and Kings Ca≈øe.
Hill. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt. HOlling≈øhed brought Debt again≈øt King, and declared, That King was bounden to him in a Recognizance of two hundred pounds before the Mayor and Aldermen of London, in interiori Camera de Guildhall London, upon which Recognizance the ≈øaid Holling≈øhed heretofore brought a Scire facias before the ≈øaid Mayor, &c. in exteriori Camera, and there had Iudgment to recover, upon which Recovery he hath brought this Action; and upon this Declaration the Defendant did demur in Law, becau≈øe that in ≈øetting forth of the Recognizance he hath not alledged, That the Mayor of London hath Authority by Pre≈øcription or Grant to take Recognizances, and if he hath not, then is the Recognizance taken Coram non Judice, and ≈øo void: And as to the Statute of We≈øt. 2. cap. 45. It cannot be taken to extend to Recognizances taken in London, which ≈øee by the words, De his quae recordat. ≈øunt coram Cancellario Domini Regis & ejus Ju≈øticiariis qui Recordum habent, & in Rotulis eorum Irrotulatur, &c. And al≈øo at the time of the making of that Statute,1 Cro. 186, 187. London had not any Sheriffs, but Bayliffs; and the ≈øaid Statute ordains, that Proce≈øs ≈øhall go to Sheriffs, &c. But the whole Court was clear of a contrary opinion, for they ≈øaid, We will know that tho≈øe of London have a Court of Record, and every Court of Record hath an Authority incident to it to take Recognizances, for all things which concern the Iurisdiction of the ≈øaid Court, and which ari≈øe by rea≈øon of matters there depending. Another matter was objected, for that the Recognizance was taken in interiori Camera, but the Court was holden in exteriori Camera, and therefore not pur≈øuant. But as to that, it was ≈øaid by the Lord Ander≈øon, That admit that the Recognizance was not well taken, yet becau≈øe that in the Scire facias upon it, the Defendant did not take advantage then thereof, he ≈øhall be bounden by his ≈øaid admittance of it, as if one ≈øue forth a Scire facias, as upon a Recognizance, whereas in truth there is not any Recognizance, and the party pleads admitting ≈øuch Record, and thereupon Iudgment is given again≈øt him, it is nor void, but voidable. Fleetwood, Recorder of London, alledged many Ca≈øes, to prove that the Courts of the King are bounden to take notice,Priviledges of London. That they of London have a Court of Record, for if a Quo warranto i≈ø≈øueth to Iu≈øtices in Eyre, it behoves not them of London to claim their Liberties, for all Courts of the King are to take notice of them. And at la≈øt, after many motions, the opinion of the Court was for the Plaintiff. And it was ≈øaid by Ander≈øon, and in manner agreed by the whole Court, That if depending this Demurrer here, the Iudgment in London upon the Scire facias be rever≈øed, yet the Court here mu≈øt proceed, and not take notice of the ≈øaid Rever≈øal.

div.head:
CCCLXXXV. Bedingfeild and Bedingfeilds Ca≈øe.
Hill. 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Dower.DOwer was brought by Anne Bedingfeild again≈øt Thomas Bedingfeild. The Tenant out of the Chancery purcha≈øed a Writ, De circum≈øpecte agatis, ≈øetting forth this matter, That it was found by Office in the County of Norfolk, that the Husband o ‚Ä¢ the Demandant was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of N. in the ≈øaid County, and held the ≈øame of
the Queen by Knights Service in chief, and thereof dyed ≈øei≈øed, the Tenant being his Son and Heir of full age, by rea≈øon whereof the Queen ≈øei≈øed as well the ≈øaid Manor as other Manors, and becau≈øe the Queen was to re≈øtore the Tenements, tam integre, Primer ≈øei≈øin. &c. as they came to her hands, it was commanded the Iudges to ≈øurcea≈øe, Domina regina incon≈øulta: It was re≈øolved, per Curiam, That although the Queen be entituled to have Primer ≈øei≈øin of all the Lands, whereof the Husband of the Demandant dyed ≈øei≈øed, yet this Writ did not extend unto any Manors not found in the Office, for by the Law, the Queen cannot ≈øei≈øe more Lands than tho≈øe which are contained in the Office: And therefore as to the Land not found by the Office, the Court gave day to the Tenant to plead in chief: And it was argued by Serjeant Gawdy for the Tenant, That the Demandant ought to ≈øue in the Chancery, becau≈øe that the Queen is entituled to have her Primer Sei≈øin, and cited the ca≈øe of 11 R. 2. and 11 H. 4. 193. And after many motions, It was clearly agreed by the Court, That the Tenant ought to an≈øwer over, for the Statute, De Bigamis Cap. 3. provides that in ≈øuch ca≈øe, The Iu≈øtices ≈øhall proceed notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch ≈øei≈øin of the King, and where the King grants the cu≈øtody of the Tenant him≈øelf, 1 H. 7. 18, 19. 4 H. 7. 1. A Multo fortiori again≈øt the Heir him≈øelf where he is of full age, notwith≈øtanding the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King for his Primer ≈øei≈øin: By the Statute of Bigamis after the Heir was of full age, the Wife could not be endowed in the Chancery: But now by the Prerogative of the King, ≈øuch wives may be endowed there, Si viduae illae voluerint, and after many motions, The Court awarded, That the Tenant ≈øhould plead in chief at his peril, for the Demandant might ≈øue at the common Law if ≈øhe plea≈øed.

div.head: CCCLXXXVI. Hill. 28 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was,Exchange. The Husband was ≈øei≈øed of Lands in the right of his Wif, the Husband and his Wife both joyned in exchange of the Lands with a ≈øtranger for other Lands, which exchange was executed, the Husband and the Wife ≈øei≈øed of the Lands taken in exchange, aliened the ≈øame by Fine, It was holden by Rhodes and Windham Iu≈øtices, That the Wife after the death of her Husband might enter into her own Lands notwith≈øtanding that Fine; And Rhodes re≈øembled it to the ca≈øe reported by my Lord Dyer, 19 Eliz. 358. The Husband after marriage a≈ø≈øured to his Wife a Ioynture, they both levy a Fine,1 In≈øt. 36. b. Sur Conu≈øans de droit come ceo que il ad of the gift of the Husband; that the ≈øame is not any Bar to the Wife of her Dower, for the Election is not given to the VVife to claim her Ioynture, or her Dower, until after the Death of her Husband: And ≈øo in the principal ca≈øe Iudgment was given for the VVife.

div.head:
CCCLXXXVII. Le es Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
NIcholas Lee by his will devi≈øed his Lands to William his ≈øecond Son;Devi≈øe. 1 Cro. 26. 3 Len. 106. And if he depart this VVorld not having i≈ø≈øue; Then I will that my Sons in Law ≈øhall ≈øell my Lands, the Devi≈øor at the time of his devi≈øe having ≈øir Sons in Law, dyed, William had I≈ø≈øue John, and dyed, John dyed without I≈ø≈øue, one of the Sons in Law of the Devi≈øor dyed, the five ≈øurviving Sons in Law ≈øold the Lands: Fir≈øt it was clearly re≈øolved by the whole Court, That although the words of
the Will are (ut ≈øupra) If William my Son depart this world not having I≈ø≈øue, &c. And that William had I≈ø≈øue who dyed without I≈ø≈øue; here, although it cannot be litterally ≈øaid, That William did depart this World not having i≈ø≈øue, yet the intent of the Devi≈øor is not to be re≈øtrained to the letter, that ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhall be made, That when≈øoever William dyeth, in Law, or upon the matter without I≈ø≈øue, that the Land ≈øhall be ≈øubject to ≈øale, according to the authority committed by the Devi≈øor to his Sons in Law: And now upon the matter William is dead without I≈ø≈øue: As in a Formedon in Reverter or Remainder, although that the Donee in tail hath i≈ø≈øue, yet if after the e≈øtate tail be ≈øpent, the Writ ≈øhall ≈øuppo≈øe that the Donee dyed, without I≈ø≈øue, a fortiori in the Ca≈øe of a Will, or Devi≈øe, ≈øuch con≈øtruction ≈øhall be made. As to the other point, concerning the ≈øale of the Lands, Wray asked, If the Sons in Law were named in the Will, and the Clerks an≈øwered, No: See 30 H. 8. Br. Devi≈øe, 31. and 39 A≈ø≈ø. 17. Executors, 117. ≈øuch a ≈øale good in ca≈øe of Executors: See al≈øo 23 Eliz. Dyer, 371. and Dyer 4, & 5. Phil. and Mary, Lands devi≈øed in tail, and if the Devi≈øee ≈øhall dye without I≈ø≈øue, that then the Land ≈øhall be ≈øold, pro optimo valore, by his Executors, una cum a≈ø≈øen≈øu A. if A. dyeth before ≈øale, the power of the Executors is determined: And afterwards it was clearly re≈øolved by the whole Court, That the ≈øale for the manner was good, and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head:
CCCLXXXVIII. Sir Gilbert Gerrard and Sherringtons Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 20 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: SIr Gilbert Gerrard Ma≈øter of the Rolls, Libelled in the Spiritual Court, again≈øt Sherrington, and A. his Servant for Tithes parcel of a Rectory, whereof the ≈øaid Sir Gilbert was Fermor to the Queen; It was moved by Egerton Solicitor General, That again≈øt the Kings Fermor a Prohibition doth not lye: But the opinion of the whole Court was, That a Prohibition doth lye, and ≈øo it hath been adjudged before. And afterwards, Exception was taken to the ≈øurmi≈øe, becau≈øe the ≈øaid Sir Gilbert had Libelled again≈øt the ≈øaid Sherrington and his Servant ≈øeverally,Owen Rep. 13. Yelv. Rep. 128. and now in the Kings Bench they both had made a joynt ≈øurmi≈øe, whereas they ought to have ≈øevered in their ≈øurmi≈øes according to the ≈øeveral Libels: And it was ≈øo adjudged by the Court, and therefore they were driven to make ≈øeveral ≈øurmi≈øes: And afterwards Exception was taken, becau≈øe the ≈øaid Sherrington and his Servant, had delivered their ≈øurmi≈øes and ≈øugge≈øtions by Attorney, where they ought to be in proper per≈øon: See the Statute of 2 E. 6. cap. 13. The party ≈øhall bring and deliver to the hands of ≈øome of the Iu≈øtices of the ≈øame Court, &c. the true Copy of the Libel, &c. ≈øub≈øcribed or marked with the hand of the Party, &c. and under the Copy ≈øhall be written the ≈øurmi≈øe or ≈øugge≈øtion; And although it was affirmed by the Clerks of the Court, that the common u≈øe and practice for twenty years had been, not to exhibit ≈øuch ≈øurmi≈øes or ≈øugge≈øtions by Attorney: Yet it was re≈øolved by the whole Court, that it ought to be by Attorney.

div.head:
CCCLXXXIX. Short and Shorts Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit to pay mony to the Plaintiff upon Reque≈øt: It was agreed,Reque≈øt. That the Plaintiff by way of Declaration ought to alledge an actual Reque≈øt, and at what place, and at what day the Reque≈øt was made: And it is not ≈øufficient to ≈øay, as in an Action of Debt, Licet ≈øaepius requi≈øitus, &c. and ≈øo it was adjudged.

div.head: CCCXC. Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: ONe was Endicted in the County of Linc‚ñ™ upon the Statutes of W ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. Indictment upon the Statute of news. 1. Cap. 33. and 2 R. 2. Cap. 5. of News, and the words were, That Campian was not executed for trea≈øon, but for Religion, and that he was as hone≈øt a man as Cranmer; the Bill was endor≈øed, Billa vera, but whether, i≈øta verba prolata fuerunt, malitlo≈øe, ≈øeditio≈øe, or e contr. ignoramus: The ≈øame Indictment being removed into the Kings Bench, the party, for the cau≈øes afore≈øaid, was di≈øcharged.

div.head:
CCCXCI. Cole and Friend≈øhips Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN Ejectione firmae, the Ca≈øe was, That Fricarroo ‚Ä¢
was ≈øei≈øed,Lea≈øes. 4 Len. 64. and by Indenture betwixt him≈øelf of the one part, and one Friend≈øhip, his Wife and the Children betwixt them begotten at the A≈ø≈øignment of the Husband of the other part, lea≈øed the ≈øaid Land to the ≈øaid Husband his Wife and their Children, at the A≈ø≈øignment of the Husband, for years, they having at the time of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe but one Child, ‚Ä¢ . a Son;A≈ø≈øignment. afterwards they had many Children, the wife dyed, the Husband by his will a≈ø≈øigned his ≈øecond Son born after the making of the Lea≈øe, to have the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid Term, and by the opinion of the Court nothing can come to the ≈øaid Son by that Lea≈øe, or by that a≈ø≈øignment, for if the Intere≈øt doth not ve≈øt at the beginning, it ≈øhall never ve≈øt; And afterwards is was moved, In as much as nothing could ve≈øt in any of the Children born after the Lea≈øe made, if the≈øe words (At the A≈ø≈øignment of the Husband) ≈øhould be void, and then the ca≈øe ≈øhould be no more, but that Land is devi≈øed to the Father and Mother, and their Children: At another day, viz. Trin. 26 Eliz. the ca≈øe was moved again, and as to the fir≈øt Point, the Court was of opinion as before, That the Child a≈ø≈øigned after the Lea≈øe made, ≈øhould not take: And then it was moved, That becau≈øe Friend≈øhip and his Wife at the time of the making of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe had one Son, that he ≈øhould take with his Father and Mother; and that the words (at the A≈ø≈øignment of Friend≈øhip) ≈øhould be void, is matter of ≈øurplu≈øage, and the word Children a good name of purcha≈øe: But the whole Court was again≈øt that conceit, for the≈øe words in the ca≈øe, At the A≈ø≈øignment of Friend≈øhip are not void, but ≈øhew what per≈øon ≈øhould take, if the intent of the party ≈øhould take effect, i. he who the Father by A≈ø≈øignment ≈øhould enable, for no Child ≈øhall take but he who the Father ≈øhall a≈ø≈øign, that is part of the contract; and although by ≈øuch A≈ø≈øignment no title accrues to the Child a≈ø≈øigned, yet without A≈ø≈øignment no Child is capable, for by the Lea≈øe the Father hath ≈øuch Liberty that he may a≈ø≈øign what Child he will: And
by Wray, If the words of the Lea≈øe had been (at the a≈ø≈øignment of the Father within one month) and the Father ≈øurcea≈øe his month,Antea 275. the Intere≈øt ≈øhould not ve≈øt in any of the Children: And by Ayliff Iu≈øtice, If the words of the Lea≈øe had been (to the Husband and wife and their Son John, where his name is William) nothing ≈øhould ve≈øt: And peradventure in this ca≈øe at the Bar, if the Father had a≈ø≈øigned his Son then born, and had a≈ø≈øigned him before or at the time of the Lea≈øe, i. the delivery of the Lea≈øe, it had been well enough: Note that this Action was brought by Cole Le≈ø≈øee of the Son of the Husband and VVife born at the time of the Lea≈øe made: And afterwards Wray, with the a≈ø≈øent of all the re≈øt of the Iu≈øtices, gave Iudgment that the Plaintiff Nihil capiat per Billam.

div.head: CCCXCII. Pa≈øch. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Execution where joynt, where ≈øeveral.NOte, It was agreed by the whole Court and affirmed by the Clerks: That if Debt be brought upon an Obligation again≈øt two upon a joynt Praecipe, and the Plaintiff hath judgment to recover, that a joynt Execution ought to be ≈øued again≈øt them both: But if the ≈øuit were by one Original and ≈øeveral Praecipes, execution might be ≈øued again≈øt any of them.

div.head: CCCXCIII. Trin. 26 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Replevin.IN a Replevin, The Defendant doth avow for Damage Fea≈øant, and ≈øhewed that the Lady Jermingham was ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch a Mannor whereof, &c. and lea≈øed the ≈øame to the Defendant for years, &c. The Plaintiff ≈øaid, That long befor King H. 8. was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor, and that the place where is parcel of the ≈øaid Manor demi≈øed and demi≈øable by copy, &c. and the ≈øaid King by his Steward demi≈øed and granted the ≈øaid parcel to the Ance≈øtor of the Plaintiff who≈øe Heir he is, by copy in fee, &c. upon which it was demurred, becau≈øe by this Bar to the Avowry, the Lea≈øe ≈øet forth in the Avowry is not an≈øwered, for the Plaintiff in the Bar to the Avowry, ought to have concluded, and ≈øo was ≈øei≈øed by the cu≈øtom, until the Avowant, praetextu of the ≈øaid Term for years entred: And ≈øo it was adjudged.

div.head:
CCCXCIV. The Lord Dacres Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Ante 227. Steward≈øhip of a Manor: Office of Tru≈øt. Grants per Copy, Deputy Steward.IN Ejectione firmae, the ca≈øe was, That the Lord Dacres was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Ever≈øham, and that I.S. held the place where of the ≈øaid Manor by copy for term of his life, and the ≈øaid Lord granted the Steward≈øhip of the ≈øaid Manor to the now Marque≈øs of Winche≈øter, who appointed one Chedle to be his Deputy to keep a court, & ad traden dum, the ≈øaid Lands (I.S. being now dead) to one Wilkins by copy for life, afterwards, the ≈øaid Chedle commanded one Hardy his Servant to keep the ≈øaid court, and grant the ≈øaid Land by copy, ut ≈øupra, which was done accordingly, the copy was entred, and the Lord Dacres ≈øub≈øigned it & confirmed it: It was further found, That Hardy had many times kept the ≈øaid court both before and after, and that the cu≈øtom of the Manor was, that the Steward of the ≈øaid Manor for the time being, or his Deputy might take Surrenders,1 Co. 48. 49. and grant e≈øtates by copy: And if this e≈øtate ≈øo granted by Hardy were good or not, was the que≈øtion, becau≈øe by the Servant of the Deputy, whereas the cu≈øtom found did not extend
further than the Deputy: It was argued that the e≈øtate granted, ut ≈øupra, was void, for a Deputy cannot transfer his authority over, for it is an office of tru≈øt: See 39 H. 6. 33, 34. 14 E. 4. 1. and 6 Eliz. it was adjudged, That the Duke of Somer≈øet had divers Stewards of his Lands, and they, in the name of the ≈øaid Duke made diver≈øe Lea≈øes of the Lands of the ≈øaid Duke, rendring Rent, and the Duke, afterwards a≈ø≈øented to the ≈øaid Lea≈øes, and received the Rents re≈øerved upon them, and yet after the death of the ≈øaid Duke, the Earl of Hertford his Son and Heir avoided them: So here, the a≈ø≈øent, and the ≈øub≈øignment of the copy by the Lord Dacres, doth not give any ≈øtrength to the copy which was void at the beginning; again≈øt which it was ≈øaid, That to take a Surrender, and to grant an E≈øtate by copy is not any judicial Act, but meerly an Act of ≈øervice, and no matter of tru≈øt is transferred to Hardy, for tru≈øt is repo≈øed in him who may deceive, which can't be in our Ca≈øe, for here is an expre≈øs commandment, which if Hardy tran≈øgre≈øs it is ab≈øolute void, for nothing is left to his di≈øcretion: And the admitting of a Copy-holder is not any judicial Act, for there need not be any of the Suitors there who are the Iudges: And ≈øuch a Court may be holden out of the Precinct of the Manor, for no Pleas are holden, which was conce≈ø≈øum per totam Curiam: And by Ayliff Iu≈øtice, If the Lord of ≈øuch a Manor makes a Feoffment of a parcel of his Manor which is holden by copy for life, and afterwards the Copy-holder dyeth, although now the Lord hath not any Court, yet the Feoffee may grant over the Land by copy again. And the whole Court was clear of opinion, That the grant for the manner of it was good, e≈øpecially becau≈øe the Lord Dacres agreed to it; And Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head:
CCCXCV. Burge≈ø≈øe and Fo≈øters Ca≈øe.
Trin. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN Ejectione firmae, the ca≈øe was,1 Cro. 48, 49. That the Dean and Chapter of Ely were ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Sutton, whereof the place where, &c. is parcel, demi≈øed and demi≈øable by copy according to the cu≈øtom, and by their Deed granted the Steward≈øhip of the ≈øaid Manor to one Adams to execute the ≈øaid office, per ≈øe vel legitimum ≈øuum Deputatum eis acceptabilem: Surrenders. Afterwards Adams made a Letter of Deputation to one Mariot, ad capiendum unum ≈øur≈øum redditionem of one I. W. and I. his Wife, and to examine the ≈øaid I. afore≈øaid, ea intentione, that the ≈øaid I.W. and A. might take back an e≈øtate for their lives, the Remainder over to one John Buck in Fee (Note, the Surrender ought be, de duobus Me≈ø≈øuagiis) Mariot took two ≈øeveral Surrenders from the ≈øaid Husband and Wife, the Remainder over to the ≈øaid John Buck in Fee, upon condition to pay a certain ≈øum of money, &c. It was moved, That the Surrender is void, and without warrant, for the warrant was, ad capiendum unum fur≈øum redditionem, and here are two ≈øeveral Surrenders, and ≈øo the warrant is not pur≈øued, and then the Surrender is void: Another matter was becau≈øe the Remainder to John Buck by the words of the Deputation was ab≈øolute and without Condition, and now in the Execution of it, it is conditional, ≈øo as this conditional e≈øtate is not warranted by the Deputation: But the whole Court was clear of a contrary opinion in both the points, and that all the proceedings were ≈øufficient and well warranted by the Deputation: Another matter was objected, becau≈øe that this Surrender and regrant is entred in the Roll of a Court, dated to be holden the ≈øecond of Maij, and the Letter of Deputation bears date the third of June after: But as to that, The Court was clear of opinion, that the mi≈ø-entry
of the date of the Court ≈øhould not prejudice the party, for this Entry is not matter of Record, but is but an E≈øcape, and if the parties had been at I≈ø≈øue, upon the time of the Surrender made, or of the Court holden, the ≈øame ≈øhould not be tryed by the Rolls of the Manor, but by the Country, and the party might give in Evidence the truth of the matter, and ≈øhould not be bound by the Roll, and according to this Re≈øolution of the Court, Iudgment was given.

div.head: CCCXCVI. Mich. 26, & 27. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Fines levied.THe Ca≈øe was: Tenant in tail lea≈øed for ≈øixty years, and afterwards levyed a Fine to Lee and Loveday, Sur Conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. with a Render to him and his Heirs in Fee; And upon a Scire facias again≈øt the Conu≈øees, ≈øuppo≈øing the Lands to be ancient Deme≈øn, the Defendants made default for which the Fine was avoided, and now the I≈ø≈øue in tail entred upon the Le≈ø≈øee for years, and he brought an Ejectione firmae, Sene facias. ‚Ä¢ Len. 117. and it was found, That the Land was Frank Fee; And all the que≈øtion was, If by the Rever≈øal of the Fine by Writ of Di≈øceit, without ≈øuing forth a Scire facias again≈øt the Ter-Tenant ≈øhould bind him, or ≈øhould be void only again≈øt the Conu≈øee, and not again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øee: Atkin. It ≈øhall not bind the Le≈ø≈øee for years: For a Fine may bind in part, and in part not: as bind one of the Conu≈øees, and not the other, 7 H. 4. 111. A Fine levied of Lands, part ancient Deme≈øn, and part at the common Law, the ≈øame was by Writ of Di≈øceit rever≈øed in part, as to the Land in ancient Deme≈øn, and ≈øtood in force for the re≈øidue, 8 H. 4. 136. And there by award of the Court i≈ø≈øued forth a Scire facias again≈øt the Ter-Tenants, and the Iu≈øtices would not adnul the Fine, without a certificate that the Land was Ancient Deme≈øn, notwith≈øtanding that the Defendant had acknowledged it to be ≈øo, but as to them who were parties to the Fine, the Fine is become void as to the ≈øaid parties, and and he who had the Land before might enter, i. And he ≈øaid it ≈øhould be a great inconvenience, if no Scire facias, or other Proces ≈øhould be awarded again≈øt the Ter-tenant, for he ≈øhould be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and di≈øinherited without privity, or notice of it, where upon a Scire facias he might plead matter of di≈øcharge, in Bar of the Writ of Di≈øceit, as a Relea≈øe, &c. which ≈øee Fitz. N.B. 98. And ≈øo although the Fine be rever≈øed, yet he might retain the Land, and he re≈øembled this ca≈øe to the ca≈øe of 2 H. 4. 16, 17. In a Contra formam collationis again≈øt an Abbot, a Scire facias ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue forth again≈øt the Feoffee, and ≈øo by the ≈øame rea≈øon here: And for the principal matter he ≈øaid, That the Fine ≈øhould be avoided again≈øt the parties, but not again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øee: King≈ømill, The Scire facias brought again≈øt the parties only is good enough, for they were parties to the Di≈øceit, and not the Ter-tenants: It was adjorned.

div.head: CCCXCVII. Mich. 26, & 27. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Error. Appearance by Attorney. Dyer 135. b. A Writ of Error was brought upon a Iudgment in a Quid juris clamat; It was a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that the Tenant did appear by Attorney, whereas he ought not but in per≈øon, becau≈øe he is to do an Act in proper per≈øon, if it be not in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, where the Attorney may be received by the Kings Writ, or plead matter in Bar of the Attornment, as if he claim Fee, &c. or other peremptory matter, after which Plea pleaded he may make Attorney, 48 E. 3. 24. 7 H. 6. 69. 2 ‚Ä¢ . E. 3. 48. 1 H. 7. 27. Another Error was, becau≈øe it is not ≈øhewed in the Quid juris clamat, what e≈øtate the Tenant hath: Another matter was, If the Grantee of the e≈øtate of Tenant in tail after po≈ø≈øibility of i≈ø≈øue extinct ≈øhall be driven to attorn,
‚Ä¢ Len ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . and it was
≈øaid he ≈øhould not, for the priviledge doth pa≈øs with the grant: See 43 E. 3. 1. Tenant in tail after po≈ø≈øibility of i≈ø≈øue extinct ≈øhall not be driven to attorn, 46 E. 3. 13. 27. Ergo, neither his Grantee: Williams contrary, As to the appearance of the Tenant by Attorney, becau≈øe the ≈øame is admitted by the Court, and the Plaintiff, the ≈øame is not Error, which ≈øee 1 H. 7. 27. by Brian and Conisby, 32 H. 6. 22. And he ≈øaid, That the Grantee ≈øhould be driven to attorn, for no other per≈øon can have the e≈øtate of the Tenant in tail after po≈ø≈øibility of i≈ø≈øue extinct, but the party him≈øelf, therefore not the priviledge; and although he him≈øelf be di≈øpuni≈øhable of Wa≈øt, yet his Grantee ≈øhall not have ≈øuch priviledge. As if Tenant in Dower, or by the curte≈øie, grant over their e≈øtates, the Heir ≈øhall have Wa≈øt again≈øt the Grantors for Wa≈øt done by the Grantee, but if the heir granteth over his Rever≈øion, then Wa≈øt ≈øhall be brought again≈øt the Grantees: See Fitz. N.B. 56. And it two Coparceners be, and the one taketh a Husband and dieth the Husband being Tenant by the curte≈øie, a Writ of Partition lyeth again≈øt him, but if he granteth over his e≈øtate, no Writ of Partition lyeth again≈øt the Grantee, 27 H. 6. Stathams Aid.If the Grantee of Tenant after po≈ø≈øibility ≈øhall att ‚Ä¢ rn. Tenant in tail after po≈ø≈øibility of i≈ø≈øue extinct ≈øhall not have Aid, but his Grantee ≈øhall have Aid. Clark, The Grantee of Tenant in tail ≈øhall not be driven to attorn. If Tenant in tail grant totum ≈øtatum ≈øuum, the Grantee is di≈øpuni≈øhaple of wa≈øt; ≈øo if his Grantee grant it over his Grantee is al≈øo di≈øpuni≈øhable, &c. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCXVIII. Gravenor and Ma≈ø≈øeys Ca≈øe.
Mich 26, & 27. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
GRavenor brought a Writ of Error upon a common Recovery again≈øt Ma≈ø≈øey: Error. And in the ≈øaid Recovery four Husbands and their VVives were vouched, and now the Plaintiff brought this Writ of Error as heir to one of the Husbands, and Exception was taken to his Writ, becau≈øe the Plaintiff doth not make him≈øelf heir to the Survivor of the four Husbands. Egerton, The Writ is good enough, for there is a difference betwixt a Covenant per≈øonal, and a Covenant real, for if two be bound to warranty, and the one dyeth, the Survivor and the heir of the other ≈øhall be vouched, and he ≈øaid each of the four and their heirs are charged, and then the heir of each of them being chargeable, the heir of any of them may have a Writ of Error. And afterwards the Writ of Error was adjudged good:Ante 86. And Error was a≈ø≈øigned becau≈øe the Vouchees appeared the ≈øame day that they were vouched by Attorney, which they ought not to do by Law, but they might appear gratis the fir≈øt day without Proces in their proper per≈øons, and ≈øo at the ≈øequatur ≈øub ≈øuo periculo: See 13 E. 3. Attorn, 74. and 8 E. 2. ib. 101. Another Error was a≈ø≈øigned, Becau≈øe the Entry of the warrant of Attorney for one of the Vouchees is po. lo. ≈øuo, I.D. again≈øt the Tenant, where it ≈øhould be again≈øt the Demandant, for pre≈øently when the Vouchee entreth into the warranty, he is Tenant in Law to the Demandant: Coke, As to the fir≈øt Error, Although he cannot appear by Attorney, yet when the Court hath admitted his appearance by Attorney, the ≈øame is well enough, and is not Error: As to the other Error, I confe≈øs it to be Error, but we hope that the Court will have great con≈øideration of this ca≈øe as to that Error, for there are one hundred Recoveries erronious in this point, if it may be called an Error: And then we hope, to avoid ≈øuch a general mi≈øchief, that the Court will con≈øider and di≈øpen≈øe with the rigor of the Law: As their Predece≈ø≈øors did, 39 H. 6. 30. In the Writ of Me≈øne: But I conceive, That the Writ of Error is not well brought, for the Voucher in the ≈øaid Recovery is of four Husbands and their Wives, and when Voucher ≈øhall be intended to be in
the right of their Wives, which ≈øee 20 H. 7. 1. b. 46 E. 3. 28. 29 E. 3. 49. And ≈øo by common intendment, the Voucher ≈øhall be con≈øtrued in re≈øpect of the Wife; So al≈øo the Plaintiff here ought to entitle him≈øelf to this Writ of Error as heir to the Wife: And for this cau≈øe, The Plaintiff relinqui≈øhed his VVrit of Error; And afterwards he brought a new VVrit, and entituled him≈øelf as heir to the wife.

div.head:
CCCXCIX. The Queen, and the Dean of Chri≈øtchurch Ca≈øe.
Mich. 26 & 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Praemunire. 3 Len. 139.THe Queens Attorney General brought and pro≈øecuted a Praemunire for the Queen and Parret, again≈øt Doctor Matthew Dean of Chri≈øtchurch in Oxford, and others, becau≈øe they did procure the ≈øaid Parret to be ≈øued in the City of Oxford, before the Commi≈ø≈øary there in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, by Libel according to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Law, in which ≈øuit Parret pleaded, Son Franktenement, and ≈øo to the Iurisdiction of the Court, and yet they did proceed, and Parret was condemned and impri≈øoned: And after that ≈øuit depended, The Queens Attorney withdrew the ≈øuit for the Queen; And it was moved, If notwith≈øtanding that the party grieved might proceed: See 7 E. 4. 2. b. The King ≈øhall have Praemuire, and the party grieved his Action: See Br. Praemunire 13. And by Brook none can have Praemunire but the King: Coke, There is a Pre≈øident in the Book of Entries 427. In a Praemunire, the words are (ad re≈øpondendum tam Domino Regi, quam R.F.) and that upon the Statute of 16 R. 2. and ib. 428, 429. Ad re≈øpondendum tam Domino Regi de contemptu, quam dict. A. B. de damnis: But it was holden by the whole Court, That if the Kings Attorney will not further pro≈øecute, the party grieved cannot maintain this ≈øuit, for the principal matter in the Praemunire is, The conviction and the putting of the party out of the protection of the King, and the damages are but acce≈ø≈øary, and then the principal being relea≈øed, the damages are gone: And al≈øo it was holden by the Court, That the Pre≈øidents in the Book of Entries are not to be regarded, and there is not any Iudgment upon any of the pleadings there, but are good directions for pleadings, and not otherwi≈øe.

div.head: CCCC. Mich. 26, & 27. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Fines levied. 1 Cro. 35.THe Ca≈øe was, A. gave Lands in tail to B. upon condition. That if the Donee or any of his heirs alien, or di≈øcontinue, &c. the Land or any part of it, that then the Donor do re-enter: The Donee hath i≈ø≈øue two Daughters and dieth: One of the two Daughters levieth a Fine, Sur Conu≈øans de droit come ceo, Forfeiture. to her Si≈øter: Heale Serjeant, the Donor may enter, for although the Si≈øters to many intents are but one Heir, yet in truth they are ≈øeveral Heirs, and each of them ≈øhall ≈øue Livery, 17 E. 3. If one of the Si≈øters be di≈øcharged by the Lord, the Lord ≈øhall lo≈øe the Ward≈øhip of her, and yet the Heir is not di≈øcharged: And if every Si≈øter be heir to diver≈øe re≈øpects, then the Fine by the one Si≈øter is a cau≈øe of Forfeiture: Harris contrary, For conditions which go in defeating of e≈øtates ≈øhall be taken ≈øhortly,Conditions. and here both the Si≈øters are one Heir, and therefore the di≈øcontinuance by the one, is not the Act of the other: Clench Iu≈øtice, The words are, Or any of his heirs, therefore it is a forfeiture, quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum per totam Curiam: And Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head: CCCCI. Mich. 26 & 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. Hutt. Rep. 34. Hob. 284. A Woman ≈øei≈øed of a Rent-charge for life took Hu≈øband, the Rent was arrear; the wife died, the Tenant of the Land charged, promi≈øed to pay the Rent in con≈øideration that the Rent was behind, &c, and ≈øome were of opinion, Becau≈øe that this Rent is due and payable by a Deed, that this Action of the Ca≈øe upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit will not lye, no more than if the Obligor will promi≈øe to the Obligee to pay the mony due by the Obligation,3 Cro. 5. an Action doth not lye upon the Promi≈øe, but upon the Obligation. But it was holden by the whole Court, That the Action did well lye, for here the Husband had remedy by the Statute of 32 H. 8. And then the con≈øideration is ≈øufficient, and ≈øo Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCII. Williams and Blowers Ca≈øe.
Hill. 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
REignold Williams and John Powell brought a Writ of Error again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Hereford and Blower, Error. upon a Recovery had in a Writ of Di≈øceit by the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop and Blower again≈øt the ≈øaid Williams and Powell, for that the ≈øaid Williams had before brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the ≈øaid Blower and the Bi≈øhop,Dyer 353. b. 354. and had recovered again≈øt them by default, whereupon Williams had a Writ to the Metropolitan to admit his Clerk, and in the Writ of Di≈øceit Iudgment was given for the Plaintiffs: For it was found, That the Summons was the Friday to appear the Tuesday after, and ≈øo an in≈øufficient Summons, and in that Writ of Di≈øceit the Defendants, Williams and Powell pleaded, That Blower the Incumbent was deprived of his Benefice in the Court of Audience, which ≈øentence was affirmed upon Appeal before the Delegates; and notwith≈øtanding that Plea, Iudgment was given again≈øt Williams and Powell Defendants in the ≈øaid Writ of Di≈øceit: And upon that Iudgment this Writ of Error is brought. Beaumont a≈ø≈øigned four Errors, Fir≈øt,1 Cro. 65. becau≈øe the Bi≈øhop and Blower joyned in the Writ of Di≈øceit, for their Rights are ≈øeveral, 12 E. 4. 6. Two cannot joyn in an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs upon a Battery done at one time to them: So if one di≈øtrain at one and the ≈øame time, the ≈øeveral Goods of divers per≈øons, they according to their ≈øeveral properties ≈øhall have ≈øeveral Replevins, 12 H. 7. 7. By Wood. So if Lands be given to two, and to the Heirs of one, and they lo≈øe by default in a Praecipe brought again≈øt them, they ≈øhall have ≈øeveral Writs, the one Quod ei deforceat, Joynder in Action. the other a Writ of Right: 46 E. 3. 21. A Fine levied to one for life, the Remainder to two Husbands and their Wives in tail, they have I≈ø≈øue and die; Tenant for life dieth, the I≈ø≈øues of the Husbands and Wives ≈øhall have ≈øeveral Scire facias's to execute the Fine by rea≈øon of their ≈øeveral Rights: Lands in ancient Deme≈øn holden ≈øeverally of ≈øeveral Lords are conveyed by Fine, the Lords cannot joyn in a Writ of Di≈øceit, but they ought to have ≈øeveral Writs; ≈øo here the Plaintiffs in this Writ of Di≈øceit, and the Bi≈øhop claims nothing but as ordinary, and he lo≈øeth nothing in the Quare Impedit, and therefore by the Writ of Di≈øceit he ≈øhall be re≈øtored to nothing. The ≈øecond Error was, Becau≈øe the Bar of the Defendants in the Writ of Di≈øceit was good, i. the deprivation, &c. and the Court adjudged it not good, for the Clerk being deprived, he could not enjoy the Benefice, if the Iudgment in the Qu. Impedit had been rever≈øed, Regul ‚Ä¢ . Po≈øt 330. and where a man cannot have the effect of his ≈øuit, it is in vain to bring any Action. Le≈ø≈øee for the life of another lo≈øeth
by erronious Iudgment; Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe dieth, his Writ of Error is gone, for if the Iudgment be rever≈øed he cannot be re≈øtored to the Land, for the e≈øtate is determined, 31 E. 3. Incumbent 6. The King brought a Quare Impedit again≈øt the Incumbent and the Bi≈øhop, the Bi≈øhop claimed nothing but as Ordinary: The Incumbent traver≈øed the title of the King, again≈øt which it was replyed for the King, That the Incumbent had re≈øigned pendant the Writ, ≈øo as now he could not plead any thing again≈øt the title of the King, for he had not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øo could not counterplead the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King. And here in our Ca≈øe, by this deprivation the Incumbent is di≈øabled to maintain this Action of Di≈øceit, 15 A≈ø≈ø. 8. If the Guardian of a Chappel be impleaded in a Praecipe for the Lands of his Chappel, and pendant the Writ he re≈øign, the Succe≈ø≈øor ≈øhall have a Writ of Error, and not he who re≈øigns, for he is not to be re≈øtored to the Lands, having re≈øigned his Chappel. So in our Ca≈øe, A deprivation is as ≈øtrong as a Re≈øignation. The third Error, becau≈øe in the Writ of Di≈øceit, it is not ≈øet forth that Blower was Incumbent, for the Writ of Di≈øceit ought to contain all the ≈øpecial matter of the Ca≈øe; as an Action upon the Ca≈øe, 4 E. 3. Di≈øceit 45. The fourth Error, That upon ≈øugge≈øtion made after Verdict, that Blower was Incumbent, and in, of the pre≈øentment of the Lord Stafford, Deprivation. and that he was removed; and Griffin in by the Recovery in the Quare Impedit by default, a Writ to the Bi≈øhop was awarded without any Scire facias again≈øt Griffin, for he is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, and ≈øo the Statute of 25 E. 3. calls him, and gives him authority to plead again≈øt the King,6 Co. 52. and every Relea≈øe or Confirmation made to him is good, 18 E. 3. Confirmation made by the King after Recovery again≈øt the Incumbent is good: And 9 H. 7. If a Recovery be had in a Contra formam collationis, the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor ≈øhall not be ou≈øted without a Scire facias, ≈øo in Audita Querela upon a Statute Staple,Scire facias. Scire facias ≈øhall go again≈øt the A≈ø≈øignee of the Conu≈øee, 15 E. 3. Re≈øpon. 1. See al≈øo 16 E. 3. Di≈øceit 35. 21 A≈ø≈ø. 13. A Fine levied of Lands in Ancient Deme≈øn ≈øhall not be rever≈øed without a Scire facias again≈øt the Ter-tenant. Walme≈øley contrary, The ca≈øe at the Bar differs from the ca≈øe put of the other ≈øide, for they are ca≈øes put upon original Writs, but our ca≈øe is upon a judicial Writ, and here nothing is demanded, but the Defendant is only to an≈øwer to the di≈øceit and fal≈øhood. And in this Ca≈øe the I≈ø≈øue is contained in the Writ which is not in any original Writ, and the Iudges ≈øhall examine the i≈ø≈øue without any plea or appearance of the Tenant, and here the Defendant is not to plead any thing to excu≈øe him≈øelf of the wrong: And here the Iudgment is not to recover any thing in demand, but only to re≈øtore the party to his former e≈øtate and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and if he hath nothing, he ≈øhall be re≈øtored to nothing; And he put many ca≈øes where per≈øons who have ≈øeveral Rights may joyn in one Action, as a Recovery in an A≈ø≈øize again≈øt ≈øeveral Tenants, they may joyn in one Writ of Error, 18 A≈ø≈ø. Recovery in A≈ø≈øize again≈øt Di≈ø≈øei≈øor and Tenant, they ≈øhall both joyn in Error, why not al≈øo in Di≈øceit? 19 E. 3. Recovery again≈øt two Coparceners, the Survivor and the heir of the other ≈øhall joyn in Error. As to the ≈øecond Error, Williams and the Sheriff ought not to joyn in the Plea, and al≈øo the Plea it ≈øelf is not good, for the Writ of Di≈øceit is, That Williams an≈øwer to the Di≈øceit, and the Sheriff ≈øhall certifie the proceedings, and therefore he ≈øhall not plead: and al≈øo the Plea it ≈øelf is not good, for although the intere≈øt of the Incumbent be determined in the Church, yet his Action is not gone; as if in a Praecipe quod reddat, the Tenant alieneth pendant the Writ, and afterwards the Demandant recovereth, yet the Tenant although his Intere≈øt be gone by the Feoffment, yet he ≈øhall have a Writ of Error, and ≈øo here; and as to the Scire facias, there needs none here again≈øt the new Incumbent, for he comes in pendant
the Writ, and that appears by the Record; but if it had been in before the Writ brought, then a Scire facias would lye. See 9 H. 6. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCCIII. Flemmings Ca≈øe.
Mich. 26 & 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: FLemming was Indicted upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. becau≈øe he had given the Sacrament of Bapti≈øm in other form than is pre≈øcribed in the ≈øaid Statute, and in the Book of Common Prayer,Indictment upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. and the ≈øaid Indictment was before the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize. Wray and Ander≈øon, Of ≈øuch offence done before, and now he is Indicted again; for which it was awarded, that he ≈øuffer Impri≈øonment for a year; and ≈øhall be adjudged ip≈øo facto, deprived of all his Spiritual promotions: And upon the Indictment Flemming brought a Writ of Error, and a≈ø≈øigned Error, becau≈øe in the ≈øecond Indictment no mention is made of the fir≈øt Indictment, in which ca≈øe the ≈øecond Indictment doth not warrant ≈øuch a Iudgment. Wray Iu≈øtice, If the fir≈øt Indictment be before us, then is a ≈øecond Iudgment well given; contrary, if it be before other Iu≈øtices. Clench, The ≈øecond Indictment ought to recite the fir≈øt conviction; and if one be Indicted for a Rogue in the ≈øecond degree, the fir≈øt conviction ought to be contained in ≈øuch Indictment; in an Indictment the day and time are not material as to true recovering in facto: And it might be, that this la≈øt Indictment was for the fir≈øt offence for any thing appeareth. Coke, who argued to the ≈øame intent, compared it to the Ca≈øe of 2 R. 2. 9. and 22 E. 4. 12. 12 H. 7. 25. Indictment certified to be taken coram A.B. Ju≈øticiariis Domini Regis ad pacem, &c. without ≈øaying, necnon ad diver≈øas felonias, &c. is void, and if a man hath been once convicted, he ≈øhall not have his Clergy if it appeareth upon Record before the ≈øame Iu≈øtices, that he had his Clergy before.

div.head:
CCCCIV. The Mayor of Lynns Ca≈øe.
Hill. 27 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Mayor of Lynn was Indicted,Indictments. for that he had received twenty four ≈øhillings of one A. for giving of Iudgment in an Action of Debt, depending before him again≈øt one B. and he was indicted thereof as of Extortion, In contemptum dictae Dominae Reginae, & contra formam Statuti. Coke, The Indictment is in≈øufficient, for there is not any Statute to puni≈øh any Iudge for ≈øuch a matter: For the Statute of We≈øt. 1. Cap. 26. is made again≈øt Sheriffs, Cap. 27. Clerks of Iu≈øtices, Cap. 30. The Mar≈øhal and his Servants, Statute 23 H. 6. again≈øt Sheriffs,3 In≈øt. 145. and other Statutes again≈øt Ordinaries: But no Action lies again≈øt a Iudge, for that which a Iudge receives is Bribery and not Extortion, Et ≈øatis poenae e≈øt, judici quod Deum habeat ultorem, and therefore he ≈øaid the party indicted ought to be di≈øcharged. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, If in the Indictment there be words of Extortion or Bribery, although ≈øuch an offence in a Iudge be not materially Extortion, if the≈øe words, contra pacem, &c. had been in the Indictment, it had been good, quod Clench conce≈ø≈øit: And afterwards the party was di≈øcharged.

div.head:
CCCCV. Cri≈øp and Goldings Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28 & 29 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 50. 2 Len. 71.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe by Cri≈øp again≈øt Golding, the Ca≈øe was, That a Feme ≈øole was Tenant for life, and made a Lea≈øe to the Plaintiff for five years, to begin after the death of Tenant for life, and afterwards the 18. of October made another Lea≈øe to the ≈øame Plaintiff for 21 years, to begin at Michaelma≈øs next before; and declaring upon all the ≈øaid matter, he ≈øaid, Virtute cujus dimi≈ø≈øionis, i. e. the later Lea≈øe, the Plaintiff entred and was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Cra≈øt. Fe≈øt. S. Mich. which was before the Lea≈øe made; and further declared, that in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff had a≈ø≈øigned to the Defendant the≈øe two Lea≈øes, the Defendant promi≈øed, &c. and upon non A≈ø≈øump≈øit it was found for the Plaintiff, and damages taxed 600 l. Coke argued for the Plaintiff again≈øt the Solicitor General, who had taken divers exceptions to the Declaration, i. Where two or many con≈øiderations are put in the Declaration, although that ≈øome be void, yet if one be good the Action well lieth, and damages ≈øhall be taxed accordingly; and here the con≈øideration that the Plaintiff ≈øhould a≈ø≈øign totum ≈øtatum, titulum, & intere≈ø≈øe ≈øuum quod habet in terra praedict'. 2. Exception, that the Lea≈øe in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was made after Michaelma≈øs, i. 18 October, and the Declaration is, Virtute cujus dimi≈ø≈øionis, the Defendant entred Cra≈øtino Mich. and then he was a di≈ø≈øei≈øor, and could not a≈ø≈øign his intere≈øt and right, which was ≈øu≈øpended in the tortious di≈ø≈øei≈øin, and ≈øo it appeared to the Iudges; and he ≈øaid there was not here any di≈ø≈øei≈øin, although that the Le≈ø≈øee had entred before that the Lea≈øe was made; for there was an agreement and communication before of ≈øuch purpo≈øed and intended Lea≈øe, although it was not as yet effected, and if there were any a≈ø≈øent or agreement that the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould enter, it cannot be any di≈ø≈øei≈øin, and here it appeareth that the Lea≈øe had his commencement before the making of the Lea≈øe, and before the entry: But put ca≈øe it be a di≈ø≈øei≈øin, yet he a≈ø≈øigned all the Intere≈øt quod ip≈øe tunc habuit, according to the words of the con≈øideration, and he delivered both the Indentures of the ≈øaid Demi≈øes, and quacunque via data, be the a≈ø≈øignment good or void it is not material as to the Action, for the con≈øideration is good enough. Egerton Solicitor contrary. In every Action upon the Ca≈øe, upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit, there ought to be a Con≈øideration, promi≈øe, and breach of promi≈øe, and here in our Ca≈øe the Con≈øideration is the a≈ø≈øignment of a Lea≈øe, which is to begin after the death of the Le≈ø≈øor, who was but Tenant for life, which is meerly void, and that appeareth upon the Record; and as to the ≈øecond part of the Con≈øideration, and the a≈ø≈øignment of the ≈øecond Lea≈øe, it appeareth, that the Plaintiff at the time had but a Right; for by his untimely entry before the making of the Lea≈øe, he was not to be ≈øaid Le≈ø≈øee, but was a wrong-doer, &c. in 19 Eliz. in the Kings Bench this difference was taken by the Iu≈øtices there, and delivered openly by the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice, i. When in an Action upon the Ca≈øe, upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit, two Con≈øiderations or more are laid in the Declaration, but they are not collateral, but pur≈øuant, as A. is indebted to B. in 100 l. and A. promi≈øeth to B. that in con≈øideration that he oweth him 100 l. and in con≈øideration that B. ≈øhall give to A. 2 s. that he will pay to him the ≈øaid 100 l. at ≈øuch a day, if B. bring an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon this A≈ø≈øump≈øit, and declares upon the≈øe two promi≈øes, although the con≈øideration of the 2 s. be not performed, yet the Action doth well lye: But if they be collateral con≈øiderations, which are not pur≈øuant, as if I in con≈øideration that you are of my Coun≈øel, and ≈øhall ride with me to York, promi≈øe to give to you 20 l. in this ca≈øe all the con≈øiderations ought to be proved, otherwi≈øe the Action
cannot be maintained: So in our ca≈øe, the con≈øiderations are collateral, and therefore they ought to be proved; and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCVI. Fooly and Pre≈øtons Ca≈øe.
Hill. 28 and 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe the Plaintiff declared,1 Cro. 200. 2 Len. 105. That whereas John Gibbon was bound unto the Plaintiff in quodam ≈øcripto obligatorio, ≈øigillo ≈øuo ≈øigillat. and coram, &c. recognito in forma Statuti Stapul. The Defendant in con≈øideration that the Plaintiff would deliver to him the ≈øaid Writing to read over, promi≈øed to deliver the ≈øame again to the Plaintiff within ≈øix days after, or to pay to him 1000 l. in lieu thereof, upon which promi≈øe the Plaintiff did deliver to the Defendant the ≈øaid Writing; but the Defendant had not, nor would not deliver it back to the Plaintiff, to the great delay of the Execution thereof, and the Defendant did demur in Law upon the Declaration. It was objected, that here is no ≈øufficient con≈øideration appearing in the Declaration upon which a promi≈øe might be grounded; but it was the opinion of the whole Court, that the con≈øideration ≈øet forth in the Declaration was good and ≈øufficient; and by Ander≈øon, it is u≈øual and frequent in the King Bench: If I deliver to you an Obligation to rebail unto me, I ≈øhall have an Action upon the Ca≈øe without an expre≈øs A≈ø≈øump≈øit; and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCVII. Wallpool and Kings Ca≈øe.
Hill. 28 and 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: WIlliam Wallpool was bound to King by Recognizance in the ≈øum of 400 l. and King al≈øo was bound to Wallpool in a Bond of 100 l. Wallpool according to the Cu≈øtom of London, Attachment in London. affirmed a Plaint of Debt in the Gulldhall London again≈øt the ≈øaid King, upon the ≈øaid Bond of 100 l. and attached the debt due by him≈øelf to Wallpool in his own hands, and now King ≈øued Execution again≈øt the ≈øaid Wallpool upon the ≈øaid Recognizance, and Wallpool upon the matter of Attachment brought an Audita querela, and prayed allowance of it; and by Gawdy Serjeant, ≈øuch a Writ was allowed in ≈øuch ca≈øe, 26 Eliz. Ander≈øon at the fir≈øt doubted of it; but at la≈øt the Court received the ≈øaid Writ de bene e≈ø≈øe, and granted a Super≈øedeas in ≈øtay of the Execution, and a Scire facias again≈øt King; but ea lege, that Wallpool ≈øhould find good and ≈øufficient Sureties, that he would ≈øue with effect, and if the matter be found again≈øt him, that he pay the Execution.

div.head: CCCCVIII. Hill. 28 and 29 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: A Copy-holder with licen≈øe of the Lord lea≈øed for years,Copyholder. Surrender. Hob. 177. 1 Roll. 294 3 Len. 197. and afterwards ≈øurrendred the Rever≈øion with the Rent, to the u≈øe of a ≈øtranger, who is admitted accordingly. It was moved, if here need any Attornment, either to ≈øettle the Rever≈øion, or to create a Privity; and Rhodes and Windham Iu≈øtices were of opinion, that the ≈øurrender and admittance are in the nature of an Inrolment, and ≈øo amount to an Attornment, or at lea≈øt do ≈øupply the want of it.

div.head:
CCCCIX. Ruddall and Millers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 28 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Devi≈øe.IN Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Ca≈øe was this, William Ruddall Serjeant at Law, 18 H. 8. made a Feoffment in Fee to divers per≈øons to the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his Heirs, and 21 H. 8. declared his Will, by which he devi≈øed his Lands to Charles his younger Son, and to the Heirs Males of his body, the Remainder to John his elde≈øt Son in Fee, upon condition, That if Charles or any of his i≈ø≈øue ≈øhould di≈øcontinue or alien, but only for to make a Ioynture for their wives for the term of their lives, that then, &c. and died; The Statute of 27 H. 8. came, Charles made a Lea≈øe to the Defendants for their lives, according to the Statute of 33 H. 8. And levied a Fine with Proclamation, Sur Conu≈øans de droit come ceo, &c. to the u≈øe of him≈øelf and his wife, and the heirs Males of their two bodies begotten, the Remainder to him≈øelf and the heirs Males of his body, the Remainder to the right heirs of the Devi≈øor. John the elde≈øt Son entred for the Condition broken upon the Defendants, who re-entred, upon which Re-entry the Action was brought. Gawdy, Fleetwood, and Shuttleworth Serjeants for the Plaintiffs: This Condition to re≈øtrain unlawful di≈øcontinuance is good,Conditions. as a Condition to re≈øtrain Wa≈øt, or Felony. See 10 H. 7. 11. 13 H. 7. 23. And before the Statute of Quia Emptores terratum: If A. had enfeoffed B. upon Condition, That B. nor his heirs ≈øhould alien, the ≈øame was a good Condition by Fleetwood (which was granted per Curiam.) And this Condition was annexed to good purpo≈øe, or the Serjeant well knew, that Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe might have levied a Fine, or ≈øuffered a Recovery by the Statutes of 1 R. 3. 4 H. 7. And this Condition annexed or tied to the u≈øe by the Will is now knit to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which is transferred to the u≈øe by the ≈øaid Statute: Although it may be objected, that the Condition was annexed to the u≈øe, and now the u≈øe is extinct in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and by con≈øequence the Condition annexed unto it, as where a Seignory is granted upon Condition, and afterwards the Tenancy e≈øcheats, now the Seignory is extinct, and ≈øo the Condition annexed to it: But as to that it may be an≈øwered, That our Ca≈øe cannot be re≈øembled to the Ca≈øes at Common Law, but re≈øts upon the Statute of 27 H. 8. ≈øcil. Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe ≈øhall ≈øtand and be ≈øei≈øed, deemed and adjudged in lawful ≈øei≈øin, e≈øtate and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of and in ≈øuch Lands to all intents, con≈øtructions and purpo≈øes in Law, of an in ≈øuch like e≈øtates as he had in the u≈øe, and that the e≈øtate, right, title, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion that was in the Feoffee ≈øhall be clearly deemed and adjudged to be in Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, after ≈øuch quality, manner, form and condition as he had in the u≈øe: And therefore in the common a≈ø≈øurance by bargain and ≈øale by Deed enrolled, if ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance be made upon Condition: As in ca≈øe of Mortgage, the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is not rai≈øed by the Bargainee; but by the Bargain an u≈øe is rai≈øed to the Bargainee, and the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion executed to it by the Statute, and the Condition which was annexed to the u≈øe only is now conjoyned to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øo it hath been adjudged. So if the Feoffees to u≈øe before the Statute had made a Lea≈øe for life, the Le≈ø≈øee commits Wa≈øt, the Statute comes, now Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe which was, ≈øhall have an Action to Wa≈øt, as it was ajudged in Iu≈øtice Southcotes ca≈øe: Southcotes ca≈øe. So a Title of Ce≈ø≈øavit in the Feoffees ≈øhall be executed by the Statute. So if the King grants to the Feoffees in u≈øe, a Fair, Market, or Warren, the≈øe things ≈øhall be executed by the Statute, Clerentius ca≈øe. as it was holden in the Ca≈øe of Clarentius. As to the Condition, they conceived, That it is broken; for where the Devi≈øor had allowed to the Devi≈øee to di≈øcontinue for life, to make a
Ioynture to his Wife, now he hath exceeded his allowance, for he might have made a Ioynture to his wife indefei≈øable by Fine upon a Grant upon a Render for life, &c. But this Fine with the Proclamations is a Bar to the former entail which was created by the Devi≈øe, and hath created a new entail, and the former tail was barred by the Fine again≈øt the intent of the Devi≈øor: Al≈øo by this Fine he hath created a new Remainder, ≈øo as his I≈ø≈øue inheritable to his new entail might alien and be unpuni≈øhed, which was again≈øt the meaning of the Devi≈øor: And as to the Lea≈øe for lives to the Defendants, the ≈øame is not any breach of the Condition, for that is warranted by the Statute of 32 H. 8. which enables Tenant in tail to make ≈øuch a Lea≈øe, ≈øo as it cannot be ≈øaid Di≈øcontinuance, which Ander≈øon and Periam granted: But the Fine levied after is a breach of the Condition, and then the Re-entry upon the Le≈ø≈øees, who have their e≈øtates under the Condition is lawful: As where the wife of the Feoffee upon Condition is endowed, and afterwards the Condition is broken, now by the Re-entry of the Feoffor the Dower is defeated. And Shutleworth put this ca≈øe, A Feoffment is made upon Condition, that the Feoffee ≈øhall lea≈øe the Lands to A. for life, and afterwards grant the Rever≈øion to B. in Fee, the Feoffor may re-enter, for by this Conveyance he in the Rever≈øion is immediate Tenant to the Lord, where, by the intended a≈ø≈øurance, the particular Tenant ought to be. Puckering, Fenner, and Walme≈øley contrary: And by Walme≈øley, By this devi≈øe the u≈øe only pa≈ø≈øeth, and not the Land it ≈øelf, for the Statute of 1 R. 3. extends only to Acts executed in the life of Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, and not to devi≈øes which are not executed till after the death of the Devi≈øor, which ≈øee 4 Ma. Dyer 143. Trivilians ca≈øe. See al≈øo 6 E. 6. Dyer 74. The Lord Bourchiers ca≈øe; but 10 H. 7. Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe devi≈øeth, That his Executors ≈øhall ≈øell the Land, now by the ≈øale of the Land in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, for the ≈øame is in a manner an Act in his life, for the Vendee is in by Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe, and here is a Condition, and not a Limitation, for the nature of a Condition is to draw back the e≈øtate to the Feoffor, Donor, or Le≈ø≈øor; but a Limitation carrieth the e≈øtate further. And he conceived, That the Condition is not broken by this Act, for the intent of the Devi≈øor is pur≈øued, for his meaning was, That the wife ≈øhould have a Ioynture indefei≈øable again≈øt the i≈ø≈øue in tail, and that the inheritance ≈øhould be pre≈øerved; that both ≈øhould be ob≈øerved: And he ≈øaid, that this Fine being levied by him in the Rever≈øion upon an e≈øtate for life is not any di≈øcontinuance, but yet ≈øhall bar the e≈øtate Tail. And the Iu≈øtices were clear of opinion, that the Condition is broken, and al≈øo that the intent of the Condition is broken; for it might be that Charles had i≈ø≈øue by a former wife, which by this Fine ≈øhould be di≈øinherited, and a new Entail ≈øet on foot again≈øt the meaning of the Devi≈øor, &c. and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCX. Simmes and We≈øcots Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31 Eliz. Rot. 355. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared,1 Cro. 147. That in con≈øideration, that he would marry the Defendants Daughter, the Defendant promi≈øed to give him 20 l. and al≈øo to procure him all the Corn growing upon ≈øuch Lands, and to provide nece≈ø≈øaries for the wedding dinner; the Defendant did confe≈øs the communication betwixt them, and that he promi≈øed to give the Plaintiff 20 l. ≈øo as he would procure a Lea≈øe of certain Lands to his Daughter for her life ab≈øque hoc. that he promi≈øed modo & forma: The Iury found the promi≈øe of the 20 l. but not any other thing; it was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, that
the A≈ø≈øump≈øit whereof the Plaintiff hath declared, although it con≈øi≈øt of divers things, yet it is entire, and if the whole is not found nothing is found; and the Ca≈øe of 21 E. 4. 22. was cited touching variance of Contract, as where an Action of Debt is brought upon a Contract of a Hor≈øe, and the Iury found a Contract for two Hor≈øes, the Plaintiff ≈øhall never have Iudgment; On the other ≈øide it was ≈øaid, That the Plaintiff ≈øhall recouer damages for the whole that is found, i. for the 20 l. See 32 H. 8. Br. I≈ø≈øue 90. In an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared, that the Defendant did promi≈øe to deliver four Woollen-cloaths; the Defendant pleaded, That he did promi≈øe to deliver four Linnen-cloaths, ab≈øque hoc, that he promi≈øed, &c. the Iury found, That the Defendant did promi≈øe to deliver two Woollen-cloaths, and the Plaintiff did recover damages for the two. So in Wa≈øt, the Wa≈øt is a≈ø≈øigned in ≈øuccidendo 20 Oaks, upon which they are at I≈ø≈øue, the Iury find but ten Oaks, the Plaintiff ≈øhall have Iudgment for ≈øo much, and ≈øhall be amerced for the re≈øidue. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, Here are ≈øeveral A≈ø≈øump≈øtis in Law, as Br. 5. Ma. Action ≈øur le Ca≈øe 108. a man in con≈øideration of a Marriage a≈ø≈øumes to pay 20 l. per Annum for four years, two years incur, the party brings an Action upon the Ca≈øe for the arrearages of the two years. Wray, In an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff ought not to vary from his Ca≈øe, as if a promi≈øe be grounded upon two con≈øiderations,Ragula. and in an action upon it, the Plaintiff declares upon one only, he ≈øhall never have Iudgment, and here the Iury have not found the ≈øame promi≈øe. Clench, If promi≈øe be made to deliver a Hor≈øe and a Cow, and the Hor≈øe is delivered, but not the Cow; the party ≈øhall have an Action for the Cow, but he ≈øhall declare upon the whole matter and afterwards Iudgment was given, quod querens nihil capiat per billam.

div.head:
CCCCXI. Stile and Millers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Tithes. 1 Cro. 161, 578. 11 Co 13. A Par≈øon Lea≈øed all his Glebe Lands for years, with all the profits and commodities, rendring 13 s. 4 d. pro omnibus exaction ibus & demandis, and afterwards libelled in the Spiritual Court again≈øt his Le≈ø≈øees for the Tithes thereof, the Le≈ø≈øee obtained a Prohibition. See 32 H. 8. Br. Di≈ø. 17. 8 E. 2. Avowry 212. Wray, Tithes are not things i≈ø≈øuing out of Lands, nor any ≈øecular duty, but ≈øpiritual; and if the Par≈øon doth relea≈øe to his Pari≈øhioner all demands in his Lands, his Tithes thereby are not extinct, and afterwards a Con≈øultation was granted.

div.head:
CCCCXII. Lee and Curetons Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. Rot. 902. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Debt. 1 Cro. 153.IN Debt upon an Obligation the Defendant pleaded Non e≈øt factum, and it was found for the Plaintiff, and Iudgment given, and afterwards the Defendant brought Error, and a≈ø≈øigned for Error, that the Declaration was per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum obligat. Error. without ≈øaying, hic in Guria prolat. to which it was an≈øwered by Coke, that the ≈øame was but matter of form, for which a Iudgment ought not to be rever≈øed, for that the Clark ought to put in without in≈øtruction of the party, and ≈øo it was holden in a ca≈øe betwixt Barras and King, 1 Cro. 768. 778. 3 Cro. 22. M. 29 & 30 Eliz. Another Error was a≈ø≈øigned, becau≈øe the Iudgment is entred de fine nihil quia perdonat. where it ≈øhould be quod capiatur, although the Plea were pleaded after the General pardon, and for that cau≈øe the Iudgment
was rever≈øed, for if the pardon be not ≈øpecially pleaded, the Court cannot take notice of it, as it was holden in Serjeant Harris Ca≈øe.

div.head:
CCCCXIII. Lacy and Fi≈øhers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN a Replevin, the taking is ≈øuppo≈øed in S. which Land is holden of the Manor of E≈øthall; the Defendant made Conu≈øans, as Bailiff of the Lord of the Manor afore≈øaid, and i≈ø≈øue was taken upon the Tenure,Trial. and it was tryed by a Iury, out of the Vi≈øne of E≈øthall only. Tanfield, The trial is good, for the i≈ø≈øue ought not to have been tried by both Vi≈ønes, S. and E≈øthall, for two things are in i≈ø≈øue. If it be holden, or not. 2. If it be holden of the Manor of E≈øthall, for which cau≈øe the Vi≈øne ought to be from both places; and the opinion of the Court was, That for the manner of it, it was not good, as if an i≈ø≈øue be joyned upon common for cau≈øe of vicinage, it ≈øhall be tried by both Towns, See 39 H. 6. 31. by Littleton and Danby, and the ca≈øe in 21 E. 3. 12. was cited in a per quae ≈øervitia, the Mannor was in one county, and the Lands holden in another county, the Tenant pleaded, that he did not hold of the Conu≈øor, and that he was tried by a Iury of the County where the Land was, See 2 H. 4. Gawdy denied the Book cited of 21 E. 3. to be Law, and the rea≈øon wherefore the Vi≈øne ≈øhall come from both places, is becau≈øe it is mo≈øt likely, that both the Vi≈ønes may better know the truth of the matter, than the one only. Another Exception was taken,Expo≈øition of Stat. 21. H. 8. cap. 19. becau≈øe the Conu≈øans (as it ≈øeems) is made according to the Statute of 21 H. 8. 19. and yet the party doth not pur≈øue the ≈øaid Statute through the whole Conu≈øans: for by the Statute in Avowry or Conu≈øans, the party needs not to name any per≈øon certain to be Tenant to the Land, &c. nor to make Avowty or Conu≈øans upon any per≈øon certain; and now in this Conu≈øans he hath not made Conu≈øance upon any per≈øon certain, but yet he hath named a per≈øon certain to be Tenant, &c. and in as much as this Conu≈øans is not made, either according to the Common-Law, or according to the Statute, it cannot be good. But that Exception was di≈ø≈øallowed by the Court, for if the Statute remedieth two things, it remedieth one, and the Conu≈øance made in form as above, was well enough by the opinion of the whole Court.

div.head:
CCCCXIV. Dier≈øly and Nevels Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Defendant pleaded Not-guilty, 2 Roll. 682. and if he might give in evidence, That at the time of the Tre≈øpa≈øs, the Freehold was to ≈øuch an one, and he as his ≈øervant, and by his Commandment entred was the que≈øtion; and it was ≈øaid by Coke, That the ≈øame might ≈øo be well enough, and ≈øo it was adjudged in Trivilians Ca≈øe; for if he by who≈øe commandment he entreth hath Right, at the ≈øame in≈øtant that the Defendant entreth the Right is in the other, by rea≈øon whereof he is not guilty, as to the Defendant, and Iudgment was given accordingly.

div.head:
CCCCXV. Savage and Knights Ca≈øe.
Mich. 29 and 30 Eliz. Rot. 546. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Error. Ante 185. 1 Cro. 106. 2 Cro. 109. 654. Sty. 91. Yelv. 164. Sty. 115. A Writ of Error was brought upon a Iudgment given in Leice≈øter, in Debt. Tanfield a≈ø≈øigned for Error, becau≈øe in that ≈øuit there was not any Plaint, for in all inferior Courts, the Plaint is as the Original at the Common Law, and without that no Proce≈øs can i≈ø≈øue, and here upon this Record nothing is entred, but only that the Defendant ≈øummonitus fuit, &c. and the fir≈øt Entrie ought to be, A. B. queritur ver≈øus C, &c. Clench Iu≈øtice, a Plaint ought to be entred before Proce≈øs i≈ø≈øueth forth, and this Summons which is entred here, is not any Plaint, and for that Cau≈øe the Iudgment was rever≈øed.

div.head:
CCCCXVI. Rawlins Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking his Clo≈øe by Rawlins, with a continuando, It was moved by Coke, that the Plaintiff needed not to ≈øhew a Regre≈øs to have Damages for the continuance of the fir≈øt Entry, ≈øcil. for the mean profits, and that appears by common experience at this day. Gawdy Iu≈øtice, what≈øoever the experience be, I well know that our books are contrary, and that without an Entry he ≈øhall not have damages for the continuance, if not in ca≈øe where the Term or e≈øtate of the Plaintiff in the Land be determined, and to ≈øuch opinion of Gawdy, the whole Court did incline, but they did not re≈øolve the point, becau≈øe a Regre≈øs was proved, See 20 H. 6. 15. 38 H. 6. 27.

div.head:
CCCCXVII. Harris and Bakers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Accompt. Damages. 3 Len. 192. Collet and Andrews Ca≈øe. 2 Len. 118. 3 Len 149.IN an accompt damages were given by the Iury, and it was moved that damages ought not to have been given by way of damages, but the damages of the Plaintiff ≈øhall be con≈øidered by way of Arrearages, but ≈øee the Ca≈øe, H. 29 Eliz. in the Common Pleas, betwixt Collet and Andrews, and ≈øee 10 H. 6, 18. In Accompt the Plaintiff ≈øhall count to his damage, but ≈øhall not recover damages, vide 2. H. 7. 13. 21 H. 6. 26. The Plaintiff ≈øhall not recover damages expre≈øly, but the Court ≈øhall ad ‚Ä¢
quoddam incromentum to the Arrearages. Coke, It hath been adjudged, that the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover damages ratione implicationis, non Retentionis.

div.head: CCCCXVIII. Mich. 26. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
THe words of the Statute 32 H. 8. cap. 37. of Rents are, that the Executor of a Grantee of a Rent-charge may di≈øtrain for the arrearages of the ≈øaid Rent incurred in the life of the Te≈øtator, ≈øo long as the Land charged doth continue in the Sei≈øin or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Tenant in Deme≈øn, who ought immediately to have paid the ≈øaid Rent ≈øo behind to the Te≈øtator in his life, or in the Sei≈øin or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of any other per≈øon
or per≈øons claiming the ≈øaid Lands only by and from the ≈øaid Tenant, by Purcha≈øe, Gift, or Di≈øcent, in like manner as the Te≈øtator might or ought to have done in his life time. And now it was moved to the Court. If A. grant a Rent-charge to B. the Rent is behind, B. dyeth A. infeoffeth C. of the Lands in Fee, who diver≈øe years after infeoffeth D. who divers years after infeoffeth E. It was holden by Walme≈øey, Periam, and Windham Iu≈øtice, again≈øt Ander≈øon Lord chief Iu≈øtice, that E. ≈øhould be chargeable with the ≈øaid arrearages to the Executors of A. But they all agreed, That the Lord by E≈øcheat, Tenant in Dower, or by the curte≈øie, ≈øhould not be charged, for they do not claim in by the party only, but al≈øo by the Law.

div.head:
CCCCXIX. Wigot and Clarks Ca≈øe.
Hill. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Writ of Right by Wigot again≈øt Clark for the Mannor of D. in the County of Gloce≈øter, the four Knights gladiis cincti did appear,Writ of Right. and took their corporal Oath, that they would choo≈øe 12, &c. ad faciendum magnam A≈ø≈øi≈øam, and by direction of the court they withdrew them≈øelves into the Exchequer chamber, and there did return in Parchment the names of the Recognitors, and al≈øo their own names, and at the day of the return of the Pannel by them made, the 4 Knights and 12 others were ≈øworn to try the i≈ø≈øue, and it was ordered by the Court, That both the parties, ≈øcil. the Demandant and the Tenant, or their Attornies, attend the ≈øaid 4 Knights in the Exchequer chamber, and to be pre≈øent at the making of the Pannel, ≈øo as each of them might have their challenges, for after the return of the Pannel, no challenge lieth, and thereupon the ≈øaid 4 Knights went from the Bar, and within a ≈øhort time after, ≈øitting the Court, they returned the Pannel written in Parchment, in this form, Nomina Recognitorum, &c. inter A. petentem, & B. tenentem, and ≈øo ≈øet down their names, ≈øix other Knights, ten E≈øquires, and four Gentlemen, and the Iu≈øtices did commend them for their good and ≈øufficient Pannel, and thereupon a Venire facias was awarded again≈øt the ≈øaid parties.

div.head:
CCCCXX. Pory and Allens Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. Rot. 611. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: THe ca≈øe was, That Le≈ø≈øee for 30 years, lea≈øed for 19 years,1 Cro. 173. Owen 97. Po≈øt. 322, 323.
