Surrender. 1 Cro. 302. and then the fir≈øt Le≈ø≈øee, and one B. by Articles in writing made betwixt them, did conclude and agree, That the Le≈ø≈øee for 19 years ≈øhould have a Lea≈øe for three years in the ≈øaid Lands and others, and that the ≈øame ≈øhould not be any ≈øurrender of his fir≈øt Term, to which Articles the ≈øaid Le≈ø≈øee for 19 years did after agree and a≈ø≈øent unto, and it was the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices of the Court, that the ≈øame was not any ≈øurrender, and they al≈øo were of opinion, That one Termor could not ≈øurrender to another Termor.

div.head:
CCCCXXI. Glanvil ane Mallarys Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. Rot. 321. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
GLanvil was Plaintiff in Audita Querela, Audita Quer ‚Ä¢
la. 1 Cro. 2 ‚Ä¢ 8, again≈øt Mallary upon a Statute Staple, for that the conu≈øor was within age at the time of the acknowledging of it, it was moved for the Defendant, that
the Court ought not to hold Plea of this matter, becau≈øe there was no Record of the Statute remaining here, and therefore by Law he was not compellable to an≈øwer it, &c. and a Pre≈øident was di≈øallowed 5 H. 8. where ≈øuch a pleading was allowed, and judgment given, that the Defendant eat ≈øine die, Loves Ca≈øe. Dudley and Skinners Ca≈øe. vide 16 Eliz. Dier 332. But on the other ≈øide divers pre≈øidents were ≈øhewed, that divers ≈øuch Writs had been ≈øhewed in the Common Pleas, as 30 Eliz. Loves ca≈øe, and the Lord Dudley and Skinners ca≈øe, and thereupon it was adjudged that the Action did well lye in this Court.

div.head:
CCCCXXII. Pet and Callys Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt.IN Debt upon a Bond for performance of covenants, the ca≈øe was, I. S. by Indenture covenanted with I.D. that ≈øuch a woman, viz. R.S. at all times at the reque≈øt and charges of I.D. ≈øhould make, execute, and ≈øuffer ≈øuch rea≈øonable a≈ø≈øurances of ≈øuch Lands to the ≈øaid I.D. or his heirs as the ≈øaid I. D. or his heirs ≈øhould rea≈øonably devi≈øe or require. I.D. devi≈øed a Fine to be levied by the ≈øaid Woman, and required her to come before the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe to acknowledge it, and the woman came before the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices to that intent, and becau≈øe the ≈øaid woman at that time was not compos mentis the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices did refu≈øe to take the Conu≈øans of the ≈øaid Fine, and this was averred in the pleading in an Action brought upon the ≈øaid Bond for performance of Covenants, where the breach was a≈ø≈øigned in not acknowledging of the ≈øaid Fine, and upon the ≈øpecial matter the party did demur in Law, and the opinion of the whole Court was, that the condition was not broken, for the words are general to make ≈øuch rea≈øonable a≈ø≈øurances which, &c. but if the words had been ≈øpecial to acknowledge a Fine, there if the Iu≈øtice doth refu≈øe to take ≈øuch acknowledgment, the Bond is forfeited, for the party hath taken upon him that it ≈øhould be done.

div.head:
Wangford and Sextons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 22 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: 1 Cro. 174. Kel. 87. a.THe Plaintiff had recovered again≈øt the Defendant in an Action of Debt and had execution: The Defendant after the day of the Te≈øte of the Fierifacias, and before the Sheriff had medled with the execution of the Writ, bona fide for money ≈øold certain goods and chattels, and delivered them to the buyers; it was holden by the Court, that notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Sale, that the Sheriff might do execution of tho≈øe goods in the hands of the buyers;Executions‚ñ™ for that they are liable to the execution, and execution once granted or made ≈øhall have relation to the Te≈øt. of the Writ.

div.head:
CCCCXXIV. Wilmer and Oldfields Ca≈øe.
Trin. 29 Eliz. Rot. 2715. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Award.IN Debt upon a Bond, the Condition was to perform the Award of I.S, Antea 140. &c. the Arbitrators make Award, That the Defendant before ≈øuch a day ≈øhall pay to the Plaintiff 1000l. or otherwi≈øe procure one A. being a ≈øtranger to the Bond to be bound to the Obligee for the payment of 12 l. per annum to the Plaintiff for his life, the Defendant pleaded the performance of the Award generally, the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned
the breach of the Award in this, That the ≈øaid A. had not paid the ≈øaid 100 l. without ≈øpeaking of the cau≈øe of the award of the 12 l. per annum, upon which the Defendant did demur in Law; it was holden by the whole Court, that the Replication was good, for the Award, as to the ≈øecond point was meerly void, as if no ≈øuch Award at all had been, becau≈øe A. was a ≈øtranger to the Award and the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion;1 Cro. 4. but as to the point of the 100 l. the ≈øame is good, and ≈øhall bind the parties, and the Plaintiff had Iudgment to recover, vide 21 E. 475. 18 E. 4. 22, 23.

div.head:
CCCCXXV. Fabian and Wind≈øors Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31, and 32. Eliz. Rot. 814. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for entring into his hou≈øe or Inn at Uxbridge, Lea≈øes. 1 Cro. 209. it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, That the Plaintiff lea≈øed to the Defendant the ≈øaid hou≈øe for ≈øeven years, rendring Rent at the Fea≈øts of the Annunciation of our Lady and Saint Michael, &c. with condition, that if the ≈øaid Rent ≈øhall be behind by the ≈øpace of ten days, &c. that it ≈øhall be lawful to the Le≈ø≈øor to re-enter: And afterward at the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation, 31 Eliz. the Rent was behind, and the tenth day after the Le≈ø≈øor came to the ≈øaid Hou≈øe a quarter of an hour before the ≈øun ≈øetting and demanded the rent in the≈øe words, I demand three pound ten ≈øhillings for a half years rent of this Hou≈øe now due, and there continued till the Sun was ≈øet, but no Rent was paid: But note, that the I≈ø≈øue was, If he came to the Hou≈øe half an hour before Sun ≈øet, and there continued demanding the half years Rent of the Premi≈øes due at the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation of our Lady then la≈øt pa≈øt. It was moved by Fenner, That upon this Verdict the I≈ø≈øue is not found for the Plaintiff, i. the I≈ø≈øue was upon the half hour, and the quarter part of the hour was found, 2. the I≈ø≈øue was, If the demand were of the Rent due at the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation pa≈ø≈øed, and the Verdict is for Rent due at the time of the demand, &c. And it was the opinion of Ander≈øon, Periam, and Walme≈øley, Demand of Rent. That as to the fir≈øt point the Verdict was good enough for the Plaintiff: Windham contrary. But it was agreed by them all, That if in demand of Rent (ut ≈øupra) the Le≈ø≈øor, or any on his part doth demand one penny more or le≈øs than is due, or in his demand doth not ≈øhew the certainty of the Rent, and the day of payment of it, and when it was due, the demand is not good,Conditions taken ≈øtrictly. for a condition which goes in defeazance of an e≈øtate is odious in Law, and no re-entry in ≈øuch Ca≈øe ≈øhall be given, unle≈øs the demand be preci≈øely and ≈øtrictly followed.

div.head:
CCCCXXV. Elmes and Meldcalfes Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32. Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IT was holden for Law by the whole Court,1 Cro. 189. That if one of the witne≈ø≈øes after the Iury are departed from the Bar, doth repeat unto the Iury the ≈øame Evidence which he gave before and no more, That that doth make the Verdict to be void.

div.head:
CCCCXXVII. Carter and Claycoles Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 & 33 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Lea≈øes More 593. 4 Co 76.IN Ejectione firmae by Carter again≈øt Claycole, the Plaintiff declared upon a Lea≈øe made by the Wardens and Fellows of All-≈øouls Colledge, 1. July, 10 Eliz. And it was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, That Overden Warden of the ≈øaid Colledge, and the Fellows, &c. lea≈øed unto the Plaintiff, To have and to hold from the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation next following, to the end of twenty years, and made a letter of Attorney to one to enter into the ≈øaid Manor, and to ≈øeal and deliver the Deed of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe in their names to the Plaintiff, who by force thereof entred into part of the demi≈øed Premi≈øes, and there did ≈øeal and deliver the ≈øame, &c. But it was not found that any rent was re≈øerved thereupon; And if this Lea≈øe were goo ‚Ä¢ , Then the Iury found for the Plaintiff; but if not, then for the Defendant: Cooper Serjeant, It hath been objected, That this Lea≈øe being but for twenty years, is not warranted by the Statute of 13 Eliz. Cap. 10. For the words of the Statute are, Other than for the term of 21 years;5 Cr. 6. as to that, It was not the intent of the Statute, but only to abridge the great and long Lea≈øes heretofore made by Colledges, and to limit ≈øuch Lea≈øes to a certain mea≈øure of time, ut ≈øupra, for twenty one years or three lives, & non ultra, but on this ≈øide as much as they would, which was granted by the whole Court: Another matter was becau≈øe it is not found, That the due rent was re≈øerved upon the ≈øaid Lea≈øe (accu≈øtomed yearly rent or more) and yet the ≈øame is good enough,1 Cro. 707. 708. Po≈øt. 333. for if the other party will take advantage of ≈øuch defect he ought to ≈øhew the ≈øame, otherwi≈øe it ≈øhall be intended, becau≈øe it is found that ≈øuch Lea≈øe was made, that it was made according to the Statute: For if a man is to make title to him≈øelf by a conditional Lea≈øe, he is not to plead the condition, but only the Lea≈øe; and if the other party will defeat the Lea≈øe by the Condition, he ≈øhall ≈øhew the ≈øame. And in this Ca≈øe, The Defendant al≈øo ought to have ≈øhewed the Statute: by which ≈øuch defective Lea≈øes are made void: Al≈øo it hath been objected, That by the Statute of 18 Eliz. the third part of the Rent ought to be re≈øerved in Corn, and here is not found any Corn; as to that, It is to be con≈øidered, that the ≈øaid Statute is not a general Law,Special Statutes ought to be pleaded. whereof the Iudges are bounden to take notice, but it ought to be pleaded, for it extends but to four places, viz. Cambridge Oxford, Winche≈øter, and Eaton, and therefore ≈øuch a Statute ought to be pleaded, or given in Evidence, and found by Verdict: As where a man pleads a general pardon, in which divers per≈øons are excepted, he ought to plead it ≈øpecially, and ≈øhew, that he is not any of the per≈øons excepted, 8 E. 4. 7. 28 H. 7. So ≈øpecial cu≈øtoms ought to be pleaded, Gavelkind, Borough-Engli≈øh, 21 E. 4. 55. 36. The King grants to the Citizens of Norwich, &c. And afterwards by Act of Parliament, all their Liberties, &c. are confirmed by a general confirmation to all Cities and Boroughs, this is a ≈øpecial Act, and ought to be pleaded; by Brian, 59, 13 E. 4. 8. The Lord Saies ca≈øe, an Act of Parliament, That all Corporations made by the King H. 6. ≈øhall be void, is a ≈øpecial Act, and ought to be pleaded: And ≈øee 28 H. 8. 27. & 28. Dyer. If the Statute of 21 H. 8. cap. 13. Of Lands taken to Form by Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øons be a ≈øpecial Law: Yelverton contrary; The Statute of 13 Eliz. is a ≈øpecial Law and ought to be pleaded, but the Statute of 13 Eliz. is now a general Law, which ≈øee Hollands ca≈øe, 39 Eliz. and Damports ca≈øe, 45 Eliz. And this Act of 13 Eliz. is general in re≈øpect of time, for it extendeth to all time after (from henceforth) and to all per≈øons to whom ≈øuch Lea≈øes ≈øhall be made, the words the Statute are, ≈øcil. To any per≈øon or
per≈øons, in re≈øpect of per≈øons who ≈øhall lea≈øe, all ≈øpiritual per≈øons: General in re≈øpect of the end, which is the maintenance of learning, which extends to the common profit, &c. Drew Serjeant, That this act of 13 Eliz. is general in re≈øpect of re≈øtraint only, and extends only to ≈øpiritual per≈øons, and therefore ought to be pleaded, for otherwi≈øe the Court ≈øhall not take notice of it; As the Statute of 23 H. 6. of Sheriffs ought to be pleaded, which ≈øee in the Ca≈øe of Dive and Manningham, Plowden, 64, 65.Co. 1 In≈øt. 45. And although the Statute ought to be pleaded, Yet this Lea≈øe is not void again≈øt the Warden who made it, but again≈øt his Succe≈ø≈øor, although no rent be re≈øerved upon it, notwith≈øtanding that the perclo≈øe of the Statute be (utterly void and of none effect, to all intents, con≈øtructions, and purpo≈øes) So upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. concerning Lea≈øes made by Bi≈øhops, the Law had been ≈øo taken in the ca≈øe of the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfeild upon a Grant of the next Avoidance, That although it doth not bind the Succe≈ø≈øors, yet it ≈øhall bind the Grantor him≈øelf. So here this Lea≈øe being made by the pre≈øent Warden and Fellows of the Colledge afore≈øaid, although it be not ≈øufficient to bind the Succe≈ø≈øor, yet it ≈øhall bind the Warden who made the Lea≈øe. Puckering contrary; And as to the ca≈øe of 13 E. 4. 8. the rea≈øon there is, becau≈øe there is an Exception in the ≈øaid Statute of divers Grants made by King H. 6. and therefore the ≈øaid Act ought to be ≈øpecially pleaded: And ≈øee 34 H. 6. 34. by Pri≈øoit: But in this Act of 13 Eliz. there is not any Exception, and although it be a general Act with a Re≈øtraint, yet ≈øuch an Act ought not to be pleaded, and therefore 27 H. 8. 23. in an Action upon the Statute of 21 H. 8. for taking of Lands to Ferm by ≈øpiritual per≈øons, he need not make mention of the Statute: And afterwards, the Iu≈øtices did advi≈øe upon this point, whether the Lea≈øe be ≈øo void, that it be void again≈øt a ≈øtranger: So as the Defendant who doth not claim under the Colledge, and who hath no title to the Land may avoid it. And Periam Iu≈øtice denied the Ca≈øe put by Puckering: A. morgages Lands to B. upon a u≈øurious contract for one hundred pounds, and before the day of payment B. is ou≈øted by C. again≈øt whom B. brings an Action, C. cannot plead the Statute of V≈øury, for he hath no title: For the e≈øtate is void again≈øt the Mortgagor. Another Exception was taken to the Declaration, becau≈øe the Plaintiff had declared, upon a Lea≈øe by the Warden and Fellows, without naming any name of the Warden, 13 E. 4. 8. 18 E. 4. 8. In Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant doth ju≈øtifie, becau≈øe that the Free-hold was in the Dean and Chapter, and he as Servant, and by their commandment entred; And Exception was taken to that Plea, becau≈øe he hath not ≈øhewed the name of the Dean, ≈øcil. the proper name: So if a Lea≈øe be made by Dean and Chapter in the≈øe words, Nos Decan. & Capituli, the ≈øame Lea≈øe is void, which was granted by the Court: and 12 H. 4251. A Provo≈øt granted an Annuity by the name of Provo≈øt of ≈øuch a Colledge, without any name of Bapti≈øm, and afterwards the Grantee brought a Writ of Annuity again≈øt the Succe≈ø≈øor of the ≈øaid Provo≈øt; and by Hull, The Writ is well enough, but the Chri≈øtian name ought to be ≈øet down in the Writ: So here, becau≈øe that the name of Bapti≈øm of the Warden is not in the Declaration, the ≈øame is not good: But the opinion of the whole Court was, That the Declaration is good enough, and they did rely e≈øpecially upon the Book of 21 E 4. 15, 16. Where Debt is brought by the Dean and Chapter without any Chri≈øtian name, and the Writ holden good: Ander≈øon: It ≈øtands with rea≈øon, That for as much as the Colledge was incorporated by the name of Warden and Fellows, and not by any Chri≈øtian name that they may purcha≈øe and lea≈øe by ≈øuch name without any Chri≈øtian name, and may be impleaded, and implead others by ≈øuch name, and as the Fellows in ≈øuch ca≈øe need not to be named by their Chri≈øtian names, no more ought the Warden: But of a Par≈øon, Vicar, Chauntry Prie≈øt, it is otherwi≈øe, for in ≈øuch ca≈øe the name of Bapti≈øm ought to be added:
It was al≈øo objected, That becau≈øe the Letter of Attorney was to enter in the Manor, and all the Lands and Tenements of the Colledge in ≈øuch a Town, and to ≈øeal the Indenture of Lea≈øe in the name of the Le≈ø≈øors, and to deliver it to the Plaintiff as their Deed; now the Attorney in executing of this Warrant hath not pur≈øued it, for he hath only entred into the Lands, but it is not found that he entred into the Manor, and ≈øo the Lea≈øe is void. And it was ≈øaid by Puckering, That if I lea≈øe two Acres in two ≈øeveral Counties, rendring for the one Acre 10 s. and for the other Acre 10 s. and make a Letter of Attorney to make Livery in both; if the Attorney entreth into one Acre and makes Livery, the ≈øame is void, for the Attorney hath not pur≈øued his authority, for peradventure I would not have lea≈øed the Acre whereof Livery is made for ≈øuch rent of 10 s. being perhaps of greater value, but with the other Acre which was of le≈ø≈øer value, and ≈øo the mi≈ø-executing of my warrant ≈øhall prejudice me. Windham, Perhaps if one entire Rent had been re≈øerved out of both Acres, it may be that by the Livery in one Acre all is void: But by Puckering, one entire Rent cannot be re≈øerved upon ≈øuch a Lea≈øe of two Acres in ≈øeveral Counties. Walme≈øley denied the Ca≈øe put by Puckering, for the authority is executed well enough, for it doth not appear upon the Verdict, but that the Colledge was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at the time of the Lea≈øe made, and then there needed not any ≈øuch Entry, but the bare ≈øealing and delivery of the Attorney is good enough. And al≈øo it doth not appear by Verdict, That the Colledge hath any Manor, and therefore it ≈øhall be ≈øo intended; and then the Ca≈øe is no other but that, A man lea≈øeth a Manor, and certain Lands in D. and makes a Letter of Attorney to make Livery of them, where he hath nothing in the Manor, and the Attorney makes Livery of the Land without medling with the Manor, the ≈øame is a good Livery, and the authority duly executed: But if it had been expre≈øly found, that the Colledge had ≈øuch a Manor there, then the Entry in the Land only, without medling with the Manor, and the Livery made accordingly, ≈øhould not be good: But yet afterwards he ≈øeemed to be of other opinion. And as to that which hath been objected, That the Lea≈øe is void to all intents and purpo≈øes, according to the words of the Statute (for by ≈øome it cannot be re≈øembled to the ca≈øe cited before, of the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfeild, that ≈øuch a Grant ≈øhould bind him and not his Succe≈ø≈øors;) for if this Grant in our Ca≈øe ≈øhall not be void pre≈øently, it ≈øhall never be void; for the Colledge never dieth no more than Dean and Chapter, Mayor and Commonalty. To that it was an≈øwered by Drew, That although there be ≈øome difference betwixt ≈øuch Corporations, and that the words of the Statute are general (void to all intents, con≈øtructions, and purpo≈øes,) yet they ≈øhall con≈øtrued according to the meaning of the makers of the Act, who≈øe ≈øcope was to provide for the Succe≈ø≈øors, and not for the pre≈øent Incumbent, and to the utter impoveri≈øhing of all Succe≈ø≈øors, without any re≈øpect to the party him≈øelf, as it appeareth by the preamble of the ≈øaid Statute; where it is ob≈øerved, That by long and unrea≈øonable Lea≈øes, the decay of Spiritual Livings is procured; for the remedying and preventing of which long Lea≈øes this Act was made, and that the Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhould not be bound thereby. And the≈øe Lea≈øes are not void, ≈øimpliciter ≈øed ≈øecundum quid, i. e. as to the Succe≈ø≈øors: As upon the Statute of 11 H. 7. cap. 20. Di≈øcontinuances made by Women, &c. ≈øhall be void and of none effect; yet ≈øuch a Di≈øcontinuance made is good again≈øt the Woman her ≈øelf: So upon the Statute of 1 Eliz. concerning Bi≈øhops. See now Coke, Lincoln Colledge Ca≈øe, 37 Eliz. in the third Reports 60. A Lea≈øe made by Dean and Chapter not warranted by the ≈øaid Statute, ≈øhall not be void untill after the death of the Dean, who was party to the Lea≈øe. So upon the Statute of 13 Eliz. of fraudulent Conveyances, ≈øuch fraudulent Conveyance is
not void again≈øt the Grantor, but again≈øt tho≈øe who are provided for by the ≈øaid Statute, and that the Lea≈øe in the principal ca≈øe is not void, but voidable, all the Iu≈øtices agreed to be avoided by the Colledge, or any other who claim by it; and by Ander≈øon, If ≈øuch a Lea≈øe ≈øhould be void, then great mi≈øchief would fall to the Colledge, for who≈øe benefit this Statute was made, for if ≈øuch Lea≈øe be made rendring a ≈ømall Rent, then if before the defect be found or e≈øpied the Rent was arrear, the Colledge could not have remedy for the ≈øaid Rent. Al≈øo by Periam, Such a Le≈ø≈øee might have an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt a ≈øtranger, who entreth upon the Land, which proves that the Lea≈øe is not void, but voidable; and afterwards notwith≈øtanding all the Objections, Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, and the chief Authority which moved Periam Iu≈øtice to be of ≈øuch opinion was Lemans ca≈øe, cited before 28 H. 8. Dyer 27. where a Lea≈øe was made to a Spiritual per≈øon again≈øt the Statute of 21 H. 8. and a Bond or Obligation for performance of covenants, and thereupon an Action was brought, and the Plaintiff therein had Iudgment and recovered, which could not have been if the Lea≈øe were utterly void again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øor and Le≈ø≈øee, as the very words of the Statute are, and although it is not alledged in the Book, that that was any cau≈øe of the Iudgment, yet in his opinion it was the greate≈øt cau≈øe of the Iudgment in that ca≈øe.

div.head:
CCCCXXVIII. Bighton and Sawles Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 35 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN an Action upon the ca≈øe, it ws agreed by the whole Court,1 Cro. 235. That where Iudgment is given, that the Plaintiff ≈øhall recover, and becau≈øe it is not known what damages, therefore a Writ i≈ø≈øueth to enquire of the damages, That the ≈øame is not a perfect Iudgment before the damages returned and adjudged, and therefore they al≈øo agreed, that after ≈øuch award, and before the damages adjudged, that any matter might be ≈øhewed in Court in arre≈øt of the Iudgment; and by Periam Iu≈øtice, the difference is, where damages are the principal thing to be recovered, and where not; for if damages be the principal, then the full Iudgment is not given until they be returned; but in Debt where a certain ≈øum is demanded it is otherwi≈øe.

div.head:
CCCCXXIX. Maidwell and Andrews Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
MAidwell brought an Action of Covenant again≈øt Andrews, Covenant. and the Ca≈øe was this, That R. was ≈øei≈øed of Lands, and lea≈øed the ≈øame for life, rendring Rent; and afterwards devi≈øed the Rever≈øion to his wife for life, and died. Andrews the Defendant took to wife the wife of the Devi≈øor, the Devi≈øee of the Rever≈øion; afterwards Andrews bargained and ≈øold the ≈øaid Rever≈øion to one Marland and his heirs during his own life, and afterwards granted the Rent to the Plaintiff, and covenanted that the Plaintiff ≈øhould enjoy the ≈øaid Rent during his Term, ab≈øque aliquo legitimo impedimento of the ≈øaid Andrews, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, or any other per≈øon, claiming from the ≈øaid Marland. Marland died ≈øei≈øed, and the ≈øame de≈øcended to B. his heir, and the breach of the Covenant was a≈ø≈øigned, in this, i. in the heir of Marland, who hath the Rent by rea≈øon of the Grant of the Rever≈øion to Marland, ut ≈øupra, the Defendant pleaded the Grant of the Rever≈øion to Marland, per ≈øcriptum (without ≈øaying, Sigillo ≈øuo ≈øigillat. & hic in Curia prolat.) ab≈øque hoc, that the ≈øaid Rever≈øion and Rent de≈øcended to B. and thereupon the Plaintiff did demur in Law, and the cau≈øes of the Demurrer was a≈ø≈øigned by Yelverton Serjeant. 1. The Grant of
the Rever≈øion is pleaded per ≈øciptum, and he doth not ≈øay (≈øigillat.) for a Rever≈øion cannot pa≈øs without Deed, although it be granted but for years; and a bare writing is not a Deed without ≈øealing of it, and therefore the pleading ought to be per ≈øcriptum ≈øuum ≈øigillat. or per factum ≈øuum; for factum ≈øuum implies the en≈øealing and delivery. 2. It ought to be pleaded hic in Cur. prolat. for the Court is to ≈øee ≈øuch Deed, to the end they may know if it be a lawful Deed,Traver≈øe. 1 Cro. 278. without razure, interlining, or other defects. 3. The Defendant hath traver≈øed the de≈øcent, where he ought to have traver≈øed the dying ≈øei≈øed; for of every thing de≈øcendable the dying ≈øei≈øed is the ≈øub≈øtance, and the de≈øcent is but the effect: And although the Grant of the Rever≈øion was but for the life of the Grantor, yet the e≈øtate granted is de≈øcendable, as 27 E. 3. 31. Tenant by the Courte≈øie lea≈øeth his e≈øtate to one and his heirs, the Grantor dieth, his Heir entreth, and a good Bar again≈øt him in the Rever≈øion; and ≈øee 14 E. 3. Action 56. Annuity granted to one and his Heirs for the term of another mans life, the Grantor dieth, living Ce≈øtuy que vie, the Heir of the Grantor brings a writ of Annuity, and it was holden maintainable; and he ≈øaid, that were the dying ≈øei≈øed is confe≈ø≈øed and avoided by the other ≈øide, there the De≈øcent is traver≈øable, and not the dying ≈øei≈øed, and that was the Ca≈øe betwixt Vernon and Gray.
Vernon and Grays Ca≈øe. In an Avowry Vernon conveyed the Lands from the Lord Powes to him, as next Heir to him, becau≈øe the Lord Powes died ≈øei≈øed in his Deme≈øn as of Fee without i≈ø≈øue, and the Plaintiff conveyed from the ≈øaid Lord Powes by Devi≈øe, and traver≈øed the De≈øcent to the Avowant, for the dying ≈øei≈øed was confe≈ø≈øed and avoided by the Devi≈øe, 22 Eliz. Dyer 366. See 21 H. 7. 31. In Tre≈øpa≈øs the Defendant ≈øaith, That T. was ≈øei≈øed, and died ≈øei≈øed, and that the Lands de≈øcended to him as Son and Heir, and that he entred; the Plaintiff ≈øaid, That T. was ≈øei≈øed, and took to wife K. and they had i≈ø≈øue the Plaintiff, and died ≈øei≈øed, and the Land de≈øcended to him, and teaver≈øed the de≈øcent to the Defendant; and ≈øee Sir William Merings Ca≈øe, 14 H. 8. 22, 23. But if the parties do not claim by one and the ≈øame per≈øon, or the dying ≈øei≈øed be not confe≈ø≈øed and avoided, there the dying ≈øei≈øed ≈øhall be traver≈øed, and not the de≈øcent. Glanvil Serjeant, Be the Bar in≈øufficient or not, if the Declaration be not ≈øufficient, the Plaintiff ≈øhall not have Iudgment, and here is not any breach of Covenant, viz. that the Plaintiff ≈øhall enjoy it without any lawful impediment of the Defendant, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, or any claiming by Marland, and then if the Heir of Marland cannot make any lawful claim, then there is not any breach of Covenant a≈ø≈øigned; and he ≈øaid, becau≈øe it is not ≈øhewed that the Land is not holden in Socage, the Devi≈øe is not good, for it may be that the Land is holden in Capite: but admit the Devi≈øe good, that when Andrews bargains and ≈øells unto Marland, and the Tenant never attorns, then nothing pa≈ø≈øeth, and then the Heir of Marland cannot make any lawful claim or lawful impediment. Periam Iu≈øtice, Here Marland was a≈ø≈øignee of Andrews, and if he or his heirs make claim, although that the a≈ø≈øignment be not ≈øufficient in Law, yet becau≈øe he hath colour by this a≈ø≈øignment his claim is lawful, and ≈øo there is a breach of the Covenant; and although it is not alledged, that the Land devi≈øed is holden in Socage, yet the Devi≈øe is good for two parts of the Land. Ander≈øon Iu≈øtice, If it be good but for two parts, then is the Rever≈øion apportioned, and the Rent de≈øtroyed, and ≈øo Marland hath not any Rent by his purcha≈øe of the Rever≈øion, and ≈øo he can't lawfully di≈øturb the Plaintiff. The Law doth create his apportionment, which grows by the Devi≈øe, and therefore the Rent ≈øhall not be de≈øtroyed; but if it had been done by the Act of the party, it had been otherwi≈øe; and I would willingly hear, if the Heir of Marland be a≈ø≈øignee of Andrews, for otherwi≈øe he is not within the words of the Covenant, for Marland hath an e≈øtate to him and his heirs for the life of another:
Now after the death of Marland, his heir is a ≈øpecial occupant, and vide H. 26 Eliz. Rot. 560. in the Common Pleas, ≈øuch an Heir ≈øhall not have his age.

div.head:
CCCCXXX. Oglethorpe and Hides Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 liz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Debt upon a Bond for the performance of Covenants,Debt. it was holden by the whole Court, That if the Defendant pleaded generally the performance of the Covenants, and the Plaintiff doth demur generally upon it without ≈øhewing cau≈øe of Demurrer: Iudgment ≈øhall be given according to the truth of the cau≈øe, for that default in pleading is but matter of form, and is aided by the Statute of 27 Eliz. But if any of the Covenants be in the disjunctive, ≈øo as it is in the Election of the Covenantor to do the one or the other, then it ought to be ≈øpecially pleaded, and the performance of it, for otherwi≈øe the Court cannot know what part hath been performed.

div.head:
CCCCXXXI. Tracy and Ivies Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Dower by Margaret Tracy again≈øt Ivie, the Ca≈øe was,Dower. That John Finch was ≈øei≈øed, and enfeoffed Shipton and others of two parts of the Lands to the u≈øe of him≈øelf and the Defendant his then wife, and their heirs for ever, with Condition, That if his ≈øaid wife did ≈øurvive him,Co. 4. Vernons Ca≈øe. ≈øhe ≈øhould pay ≈øuch ≈øums of mony not exceeding two hundred pounds, to ≈øuch per≈øons which the Feoffor by his la≈øt Will ≈øhould appoint; and afterwards he declared his Will, and thereby appointed certain ≈øums of mony to be paid to divers per≈øons, amounting in the whole to the ≈øum of one hundred and fifty one pounds, and by his ≈øaid Will devi≈øed the re≈øidue of his Lands to divers of his Kindred, having no i≈ø≈øue, and died; The wife married Tracy, and they brought Dower again≈øt the Devi≈øees, who pleaded the Feoffment afore≈øaid, and averred the ≈øame was made for the Ioynture of the Demandant. And becau≈øe that no other matter or circum≈øtance was proved to verifie the Averment, the Court incited the Iury to find for the Demandant, which they did accordingly.

div.head:
CCCCXXXII. Bond and Richard≈øons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Debt upon a Bond,Debt. 1 Cro. 142. the Condition was to pay a le≈ø≈øer ≈øum ≈øuch a day, and at ≈øuch a place the Defendant pleaded payment according to the Condition, upon which they were at i≈ø≈øue. And it was found by Verdict, That the le≈ø≈øer ≈øum was paid ≈øuch a day before the day contained in the Condition of the Bond, and then received; and upon this Verdict Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff, for the day is not material, nor the place, but the payment is the ≈øub≈øtance.

div.head:
CCCCXXXIII. Mar≈øhes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Trover had Conver≈øion.GOods came to a Feme covert by Trover, and ≈øhe and her Hu≈øband did convert them to their own u≈øe. It was holden per Curiam, That the Action upon the Ca≈øe ≈øhall be brought again≈øt the Husband and Wife, and not again≈øt the Husband only, for the Action doth ≈øound in Tre≈øpa≈øs, and it is not like unto Detinue; for upon a Detainer by the Wife, the Action lieth again≈øt the Husband only.

div.head:
CCCCXXXIV. Corbets Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt. 2 Len. 60.AN Action of Debt was brought by Original Writ again≈øt an Admini≈øtrator in another County than where the Admini≈øtrator was commorant, and before notice of the Suit he paid divers Debts of the Inte≈øtate due by ≈øpecialty, and ≈øo he had not A≈ø≈øets to pay the Debt in demand, having A≈ø≈øets at the day of the Te≈øte of the Original. And now,Plainment Admini≈øtred. 1 Cro. 793. the Defendant appearing, pleaded this ≈øpecial matter, and concluded, ≈øo he had nothing remaining in his hands. And it was holden per Curiam, to be a good Plea. See 2 H. 4. 21, 22.

div.head:
CCCCXXXV. Gillam and Lovelaces Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Admini≈øtration. KAtharine Gillam, Admini≈øtratrix of John Gillam, brought Ejectione firmae again≈øt Leonard Lovelace, and upon not guilty pleaded, it was found for the Plaintiff. It was moved for the Defendant in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That the Declaration was not good, becau≈øe the granting of Letters of Admini≈øtration is ≈øet forth in this manner, viz. Admini≈øtratio commi≈ø≈øa fuit Querenti per Willielmum Lewen Vicarium generalem in ≈øpiritualibus Epi. Roff. without averring, that at the time of the granting of the Letters of Admini≈øtration, the Bi≈øhop was in remotis agendis, for a Bi≈øhop pre≈øent in England cannot have Vicarium: But as to that, it was ≈øaid by the whole Court, That the Vicar general in Spiritualibus, amounts to a Chancellor, for in truth the Chancellor is Vicar general to the Bi≈øhop. Another Exception was, becau≈øe the Declaration is not Epi. Roff. loci illius Ordinarii; but that was not allowed, for all the pre≈øidents and cour≈øe of the Court is, That by way of Declaration ≈øuch allegation needs not, but by way of Bar it is nece≈ø≈øary. Another Exception was taken, becau≈øe the Plaintiff hath declared of an Ejectment, and al≈øo quod bona & catalla ibidem invent. cepit, &c. And here, in the Verdict the damages, as well for the Ejectment as for the Goods and Chattels, are entirely taxed. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCCXXXVI. Greeves Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Replevin,Replevin. the Defendant made Conu≈øans as Bayliff to one Greeves and Rockwood, &c. and ≈øaid, That A. was ≈øei≈øed of the Lands, and 6 Eliz. enfeoffed certain per≈øons in fee to the u≈øe of his la≈øt Will, by which he willed, that his Feoffees ≈øhould ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Lands,Devi≈øes. Poph. 188. until the ≈øaid Greeves had levied of the profits of the ≈øaid Lands the ≈øum of one hundred pounds. It was objected again≈øt this Conu≈øans, that here is no devi≈øe, for A. at the time of the devi≈øe had not any Feoffees; but the Exception was di≈øallowed by the Court: And they cited the ca≈øe of 15 Eliz. Dyer 323. Lingens ca≈øe, A. made a Feoffment in fee to his u≈øe, and afterwards devi≈øed that his Feoffees ≈øhould be ≈øei≈øed to the u≈øe of his Daughter, that the ≈øame was a good devi≈øe of the Land. See 29 H. 8. Br. Devi≈øes 48.

div.head:
CCCCXXXVII. Kempton and Coopers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking of his Clo≈øe, the Defendant pleaded,Bar. 3 Len. 194. that before this he had brought an Ejectione firmae again≈øt the now Plaintiff and recovered, and had Execution, &c. Iudgment, if Action, &c. And by Periam, Windham and Ander≈øon Iu≈øtices, the ≈øame is a good Bar, and the conclu≈øion of the Plea is al≈øo good. Iudgment, if Action, without relying upon the E≈øtoppel.

div.head:
CCCCXXXVIII. Leigh and Okeley and Chri≈øtma≈øs Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
OLiphe Leigh Fermor of the Queen of a Wood called Meerher≈øt Wood in Warple≈øden in the County of Surrey, brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Henry Okeley and Robert Chri≈øtma≈øs for breaking of the ≈øaid Wood, and therein entring and cutting down of two hundred loads of Wood, and carrying away the ≈øame, &c. The Defendants pleaded, That before the time in which the Tre≈øpa≈øs was ≈øuppo≈øed, &c. That King H. 8. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of Warple≈øden, Cu≈øtom. whereof the ≈øaid Wood was parcel, of which Manor a Clo≈øe called Withybod containing eleven Acres, eidem bo≈øco adjacent. was parcel, and that the ≈øaid Wood is, and time out of mind, &c. was clo≈øed and ≈øeparated with Hedges and Ditches from the ≈øaid eleven Acres, which ≈øaid Hedges and Ditches, per totum tempus praedict. fuerunt & adhuc ≈øunt praedict. bo≈øco ≈øpectant. & pertinent. And that the ≈øaid eleven Acres are, and time out of mind we ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cu≈øtomary Lands, parcel of the Manor afore≈øaid, and demi≈øed and demi≈øable in Fee-≈øimple: And that the ≈øaid King H. 8. at a Court holden 38 H. 8. by his Steward demi≈øed the ≈øaid eleven Acres by copy, to John Goring and his Heirs, and that within the ≈øaid Manor there is this Cu≈øtom, That every Copyholder, Tenant of the ≈øaid eleven Acres, &c. hath u≈øed and accu≈øtomed, per ≈øe vel ≈øervientes ≈øuos per eorum praecept. ≈øuccidere, capere, & a≈øportare ≈øubbo≈øcum in praedict. bo≈øco in quo, &c. pro reparatione praedictarum ≈øepium & defen≈øionum inter praedict. bo≈øcum in quo, &c. and the ≈øaid eleven Acres, &c. quandocunque eaedem ≈øepes & defen≈øiones in deca≈øu extiterint; and ≈øhewed further, That at the time of the Tre≈øpa≈øs, &c. the ≈øaid
Hedges and Fences were in decay, and ≈øo ju≈øtified: Vpon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. It was argued by Godfrey, That the Pre≈øcription is not good; for it appeareth, that this cu≈øtomary Land is contigue adjacens to the ≈øaid Wood, i. where the Tre≈øpa≈øs was done: And of common Right, the making of the Hedge doth appertain to the Owner of the Wood: And the Pre≈øcription is no more, but to take Wood in the Lands of another adjoyning to my Land, to make the Hedges of the ≈øame Land in which the Wood groweth, which cannot be a good Pre≈øcription, for it ≈øounds in charge, and not to the profit of him who Pre≈øcribes: Which ≈øee 22 E. 3. Pre≈øcription 40. Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt an Abbot, becau≈øe where the Plaintiff was Farmor of the King of his Hundred of D. and by rea≈øon thereof he might make Attachment, and di≈øtrain for the Debts of the King within the ≈øaid Hundred, and where for a certain debt of the King he di≈øtrained the Bea≈øts of one A. and the Abbot made Re≈øcous; to which the Abbot ≈øaid, That he was Lord of the Manor of D. within which Manor there was this cu≈øtom, &c. That if any Di≈øtre≈øs be taken within the ≈øaid Manor, that the ≈øame ≈øhould be put into the Pound of the ≈øaid Abbot of the ≈øame Manor, and not driven out of the Manor, and there ought the Di≈øtre≈øs to remain three days, ≈øo that if the party would agree within the three days, that then he ≈øhould have his Bea≈øts; and he ≈øaid, That the Plaintiff would have driven the ≈øaid Bea≈øts out of the ≈øaid Manor, and that he would not ≈øuffer him, upon which there was a demurrer, becau≈øe it is not any profit to the Abbot, but a charge to keep the Bea≈øts of another. Al≈øo he ≈øaid, That the King ≈øhall not be bound by ≈øuch a cu≈øtom as another per≈øon ≈øhall, whereupon Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff: So here in the principal ca≈øe, There ≈øhall be no damage to the Defendant if the Wood be not fenced; for if his Cattel e≈øcape into the Wood he may ju≈øtifie it, becau≈øe it is in default of the Plaintiffs inclo≈øure: And if the Bea≈øts of the Plaintiff e≈øcape into the Lands of the Defendant, he may take them Damage Fea≈øant for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid, 21 H. 7. 20. A Cu≈øtom is pleaded, That if any Tenants of the Manor ≈øhall take the Cattel of any one Damage Fea≈øant, and ≈øhall therefore di≈øtrain them, that then the Tenant ≈øo di≈øtraining them ought to bring them to the Lords Pound, which if he ≈øhall not do, at the next Court he ≈øhall be amerced in a certain ≈øum to the Lord of a Manor to be paid, and that was holden no good cu≈øtom, becau≈øe it is again≈øt common Right, and the common Law; for by the common Law and common Rea≈øon, every one finding Cattel in his own Land Damage Fea≈øant may impound them in his own Land, and the Lord is not damnified thereby: So it is of a By-law, That every one who holdeth ≈øo many Acres of Lands in ≈øuch a Town, ≈øhall yearly pay a certain ≈øum of mony to the Church of the ≈øame Town, and ≈øhall forfeit for every default of payment thereof twenty pounds, ≈øuch By-law, although it hath continued time out of mind, yet it is not of any validity, becau≈øe for not payment of the ≈øaid ≈øum to the Church, the Lord of the Manor is not damnified, and therefore he ≈øhall not have any gain; contrary if the penalty had been limited to the Church-wardens, becau≈øe they are bound to repair the Church. Another Exception was taken to the form of the Pre≈øcription (Quandocunque eaedem ≈øepes & defen≈øiones in deca≈øu extiterint) and that is too general, for ≈øo they might be in decay by his own default, as if he him≈øelf wrongfully pull up the Hedges, in which ca≈øe there is no rea≈øon but that he ≈øhould repair them at his own co≈øts and charges, and therefore he ought to have pleaded cum in de ca≈øu extiterint in the default of the Tenant of the Wood. Another Exception was taken, becau≈øe that here this cu≈øtom is pleaded particularly, and appropriated to the eleven Acres only, and is not extended to the whole Manor; and to that purpo≈øe the ca≈øe of 40 E. 3. 27. was cited, where a cu≈øtom is applied to
one part of a Town, as to ≈øay that ≈øuch a Hou≈øe within ≈øuch a Town is of the nature of Gavelkind, and the re≈øt of the Town is guildable. See 21 Eliz. Dyer 363. It was adjorned, &c.

div.head:
CCCCXXXIX. Hare and Okelies Ca≈øe.
Hill. 20 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: MIchael Hare, and others,Tre≈øpa≈øs. brought an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt Okelie for breaking of their clo≈øe, and carrying away their corn; And upon Not guilty, it was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, That the ≈øaid Michael Hare was ≈øole ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Clo≈øe, where, &c. and ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, expo≈øuit ad culturam, Anglice, did put forth to Tillage the ≈øaid Land to the other Plaintiffs in form following, viz. That the ≈øaid Michael ≈øhould find one half of the Corn ≈øowed, and the other Plaintiffs the other half, and that the ≈øaid Land ≈øhould be ploughed and tilled, and the Corn thereof coming ≈øhould be reaped and cut at the charges of the other Plaintiffs, and ≈øo cut ≈øhould be divided by the Shock, and the ≈øaid Michael to have the one half, and the other Plaintiffs the other half, &c. And it was the opinion of the whole Court, That notwith≈øtanding the≈øe words (expo≈øuit ad culturam) that no e≈øtate in the ≈øoil pa≈ø≈øed to the other Plaintiffs,Expo≈øition of words. but the ≈øaid Michael did remain ≈øole ≈øei≈øed as before; but by Ander≈øon, upon the ≈øeverance of the Corn, peradventure a property in the ≈øaid Corn might be in all the Plaintiffs: But becau≈øe it appeareth, that Michael was ≈øole ≈øei≈øed, and the other Plaintiffs had not any thing in the Land: Therefore it was adjudged, that they could not joyn in the Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking of the Clo≈øe; and therefore it was awarded by the Court, that the Plaintiffs nihil Cap. per breve.

div.head:
CCCCXL. Beares Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Formedon by Beare, Formedon. the Defendant pleaded in Bar a warranty with A≈ø≈øets: And upon the I≈ø≈øue nothing by de≈øcent, it was found, That the Ance≈øtor of the Defendant who≈øe warranty was pleaded in Bar, was ≈øei≈øed of Land in the nature of Gavelkind,Bar. and by his Will devi≈øed the ≈øame to his two Sons (whereof the Defendant was the Elde≈øt) and their heirs equally between them to be divided; and it was adjudged no A≈ø≈øets, wherefore the Defendant had Iudgment to have ≈øei≈øin of the Land.

div.head:
CCCCXLI. Au≈øtin and Smiths Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: THe Ca≈øe was,Copyholder of Grants. That Au≈øtin being a Copyholder by Licen≈øe of the Lord lea≈øed his Copyhold to Smith for years, rendring rent, and afterwards by Deed granted the rent to another, to have during the Term, &c. to which Grant the Le≈ø≈øee did attorn,Rents. 1 Cro. 637. 651. 895. 1 Roll. 598. 1 In≈øt. 317. a. Litt. 151. b. 152. a. and paid the Rent to the Grantee: It was holden by Gawdy Iu≈øtice, That the Grant was good, but now it is but a Rent-≈øeck: And it was ≈øaid by ≈øome, That the Le≈ø≈øor cannot ≈øurrender ≈øuch a Rent, unle≈øs he ≈øurrender the Rever≈øion al≈øo. Quaere, if the Grantee may have an Action of Debt for it. It was conceived he could not, for he is not party nor privy to the Contract, nor hath the Rever≈øion.

div.head:
CCCCXLII. Underhill and Savages Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: SAvage was pre≈øented to a Benefice, and afterwards was pre≈øented to another,Pluralities. and then purcha≈øed a Di≈øpen≈øation (which was too late) and then was qualified, and afterwards accepted the Archdeaconry of Glouce≈øter: And Underhill who had the Archdeaconry libelled in the Spiritual Court again≈øt the ≈øaid Savage, where it is holden that all Eccle≈øia≈øtical Promotions in ≈øuch ca≈øes are void, and now Savage ≈øued a Prohibition.Prohibition. It was argued by Atkin≈øon, That the Prohibition did lye, for the Patron hath his remedy by our Law, by a Writ of Right of Advow≈øon. See 29 E. 3. 44. If Avoidance be by Ce≈ø≈øion or Deprivation, and the next Pre≈øentment come in que≈øtion, it ≈øhall be determined by the Kings Court; and here when he accepteth of another Benefice, it is ce≈ø≈øion by the Common Law, but there ought to be a Sentence; but now there needs not any Sentence, for by the Statute of 21 H. 8.Archdeaconry. 13. the Church is ip≈øo facto void. But it was objected, An Archdeaconry is not within the Statute, for it is not any Cure with Souls: al≈øo an Archdeaconry is a late Promotion, and therefore it cannot be void by the Statute. Lewknor contra. The Patronage here doth not come in debate; but if the Defendant in the Spiritual Court will plead, That the Plaintiff is not Patron, but ≈øuch an one, then a Prohibition lieth: withal the Iu≈øtices granted, and it was ≈øaid by Wray, That a Doctor of the civil Law had been with him, and affirmed to him that their Law is, That if one having a Benefice with cure of Souls accepts an Archdeaconry, the Archdeaconry is void; but he ≈øaid, That he conceived that upon the Statute of 21 H. 8. the Law is qualified by rea≈øon of a Provi≈øo there, ≈øcil. Provided that no Deanry, Archdeaconry, &c. be taken or comprehended under the name of a Benefice, having Cure of Souls, in any Article above ≈øpecified.

div.head: CCCCXLIII. Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ dONe was bounden to ≈øtand to the award of two Arbitrators, who award that the party ≈øhall pay unto a ≈øtranger or his a≈ø≈øigns 200 l. before ≈øuch a day, the ≈øtranger before the day dieth, and B. takes Letters of Admini≈øtration; and if the Obligor ≈øhall pay the mony to the Admini≈øtrator, or that the Obligor ≈øhould be di≈øcharged was the Que≈øtion; and it was the opinion of the whole Court, that the mony ≈øhould be paid to the Admini≈øtrator, for he is A≈ø≈øignee: and by Gawdy Iu≈øtice, If the word A≈ø≈øignee had been left out, yet the payment ought to be made to the Admini≈øtrator, quod Coke affirmavit.

div.head: CCCCXLIV. Pa≈øch. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: ONe ≈øued in the Kings Bench for Co≈øts given upon a Suit depending in the Hundred Court, and the ≈øum of the Co≈øts was under 40 s. and the Plaintiff declared,Steward. That at the Court holden before the Steward, ≈øecundum con≈øuetudinem Manerii praedict. It was objected, that the Steward is not Iudge in ≈øuch Court, but the Suitors; to which it was an≈øwered by the Iu≈øtices, That by a Cu≈øtom in a Hundred Court a Steward may be Iudge, and ≈øo it hath been holden; and here the Plaintiff hath declared upon the Cu≈øtom, for the Declaration is ≈øecund. con≈øuetudinem Manerii, al≈øo the Subject may ≈øue here in the Kings Bench for a le≈ø≈øer ≈øum than 40 s. as if 10 s. Co≈øts be given in any Suit here, Suit to ≈øuch co≈øts lieth here in this Court.

div.head:
CCCCXLV. Pigot and Harringtons Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: PIgot brought a Writ of Error upon a Fine levied by him within age,Error. 1 Cro. 11. the Ca≈øe was, That the Husband and Wife were Tenants for life, the Remainder to the Infant in Fee, and they three levied a Fine, and the Infant only brought the Writ of Error. It was objected by Tanfield, that they all three ought to joyn in this Writ, and the Husband and Wife ought to be ≈øummoned and ≈øevered. Atkin≈øon contrary, for here the Husband and Wife have not any cau≈øe of action, but the Infant only is grieved by the Fine, 35 H. 6. 19, 20, 21, &c. In con≈øpiracy again≈øt many, it was found for the Plaintiff, and one of the Defendants brought Attaint, and a≈ø≈øigned the fal≈øe oath in omnibus quae dixerunt, but afterwards abridged the a≈ø≈øignment of the fal≈øe oath, as to the damages, and ≈øo the attaint well lies. Two women are Ioynt-tenants, they take Husbands, the Husbands and their Wives make a Feoffment in Fee,Attaint. the Husbands dye, the Wives ≈øhall have ≈øeveral Cui in vita's, for the coverture of the one was not the coverture of the other, 7 H. 4. 112. In Appeal again≈øt four, they were outlawed, and two of them brought Error upon it, and good, 29 E. 3. 14. In A≈ø≈øize again≈øt three Coparceners, they plead by Bailiff, nul tenent de Franktenement, &c. and found that two of them were di≈ø≈øei≈øors and Tenants, and that the third had nothing, and afterwards the three Coparceners brought attaint, and after appearance, the third Si≈øter, who was acquit, was non≈øuit, and afterwards by Award the Writ did abate. Tanfield, Although that the cau≈øe be ≈øeveral, yet the erronious act was joynt, and the receiving of the Fine, and that Record being entire, ought to be pur≈øued accordingly, and then the Husband and Wife ≈øhall be ≈øummoned and ≈øevered, and it is not like to the ca≈øe of 29 E. 3. cited before, for there the third coparcener had not any cau≈øe of attaint, for no verdict pa≈ø≈øed again≈øt her. Wray, As the Error is here a≈ø≈øigned, the Writ is well brought, for the Error is not a≈ø≈øigned in the Record, but without it in the per≈øon of the Infant,Fine upon an Infant rever≈øed. and that is the cau≈øe of the Action by him and for no other. Two Infants levy a Fine, although they joyn in Error, yet they ought to a≈ø≈øign Errors ≈øeverally, and they may ≈øue ≈øeveral Writs of Error; and afterwards it was holden by the Court that the Writ was good, and the Fine rever≈øed as to the Infant only.

div.head:
CCCCXLVI. Scovell and Cavels Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN Ejectione firmae by Scovell again≈øt Cavel, Lea≈øes. 1 Cro. 89 the Declaration was general upon a Lea≈øe made by William Pain, and it was found by ≈øpecial verdict, That William Lever≈øedge was ≈øei≈øed of the Lands, &c. and lea≈øed the ≈øame to Stephen Cavel, John Cavel, and William Pain, habend. to them for their lives and for the life of the ≈øurvivor of them, Provided always, and it was covenanted, granted and agreed betwixt the parties, that the ≈øaid John Cavel, and William Pain, ≈øhould not take any benefit, profit or commodity of the Land, during the life of Stephen Cavel, and further that the ≈øaid William Pain ≈øhould not take any benefit, &c. during the life of John Cavel, &c. Stephen Cavel died, John Cavel entred, and afterwards William Pain entred, and made the Lea≈øe to the Plaintiff, upon whom the Defendant entred; and if the Entry of William Pain were lawful was the Que≈øtion.
Gawdy Serjant, his Entry is not lawful. It will be agreed, That if a man lea≈øe to three for their lives, they are Ioynt-tenants, but if by the habendum the e≈øtate be limited to them by way of Remainder, the joynt e≈øtate in the Premi≈øes is gone, and the Land demi≈øed ≈øhall go in Remainder; and I agree that in deeds Poll, the words ≈øhall be taken ≈øtrong again≈øt the grantor, contrary in the Ca≈øe of Indentures, the words there ≈øhall be taken according to the intent of the parties, for there the words are the words of both: See Browning and Bee≈øtons Ca≈øe 2. and 3. Ma. Plowd. 132. where by Indenture the Le≈ø≈øee covenanted to render and pay for the Land Lea≈øed ≈øuch a Rent, the ≈øame is a good re≈øervation, although it be not by apt words, and here in our Ca≈øe, this Provi≈øo and Covenant, Grant and Agreement doth amount to ≈øuch a limitation by way of Remainder, e≈øpecially when ≈øuch a clau≈øe followeth immediately after the Habendum. Coke contrary: The Office of the Habendum is to limit and explain the e≈øtate contained in the premi≈øes, and here the Habendum hath done its Office, and made it a joynt e≈øtate, and therefore the Clau≈øe afterward comes too late, and in truth is repugnant and utterly void, as to ≈øuch purpo≈øe; but perhaps an action of Covenant lies upon it. Wray, It hath been by me adjudged, if a Lea≈øe be made to three Habendum ≈øucce≈ø≈øive, the ≈øame is a void word, and the Le≈ø≈øees are joynt-tenants; contrary of Copyhold by rea≈øon of Cu≈øtom; and here the provi≈øo and the clau≈øe following, is contrary to the Habendum, and repugnant, and ≈øo void, as to the dividing of the e≈øtate by way of Remainder, which Gawdy Iu≈øtice granted. Heale Serjeant, this ca≈øe hath been adjudged, 16 Eliz. A Lea≈øe to three Habendum to the u≈øe of the fir≈øt for life, and after to the u≈øe of the ≈øecond for life, and after to the u≈øe of the third for life, the ≈øame is good. Clench Iu≈øtice, this provi≈øo follows the Habendum, and is a ≈øentence to explain the ≈øentence. Wray, & Shute, it is another ≈øentence, although it immediately follows the Habendum. Clench, if the words had been provided, that although it be limited, (ut ≈øupra) in the Habendum, ≈øcil. the fir≈øt named ≈øhall have the Lands to him≈øelf for life, &c. it had been good by way of Remainder. Wray, Our ca≈øe at Bar, is not that any per≈øon ≈øhall take the Remainder, but that any of them ≈øhall not take the profits during the life of the other. Tanfield took exception to the verdict, becau≈øe the life of Pain is not found in the verdict. Coke, this is a verdict and no pleading, and the opinion of the Court was, that the verdict was good, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Exception, and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCXLVII. Hud≈øon and Leighs Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31. Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Appeal of Maheim. 4 Co. 43. RObert Hud≈øon brought an appeal of Mayhem again≈øt Robert Leigh for maiming his right hand, and for cutting of his veins and ≈øinews, which by that means are become dry, ≈øo as thereby he hath lo≈øt the u≈øe of his fingers. To which the Defendant pleaded, that heretofore the Plaintiff had brought again≈øt him an Action of A≈ø≈øault and Battery, and wounding, and therein had Iudgment to recover, and Execution was ≈øued forth by Scire facias, and ≈øatisfaction acknowledged upon Record,Damages. of 200 Marks a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Iury for the damages, and 11 l. 10 s. de incremento by the Court, with averment of all identities. Cooper Serjeant, the ≈øame is a good Bar, and although that an Appeal, and an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs are diver≈øe Actions in nature, and in many circum≈øtances, yet as to the recovery of Damages, the one ≈øhall bind the other, See 38 E. 3. 17. a good ca≈øe. In Tre≈øpa≈øs for breaking of his Clo≈øe and Battery, the Defendant pleaded, that before that the Plaintiff by Bill in the Mar≈øhal≈øey hath recovered his Damages for the
≈øame Tre≈øpa≈øs, &c. and vouched the Record, and the Record was ≈øent, the which was varying from the Record pleaded; for the Record vouched, was only of Battery without any thing of breaking of the Clo≈øe: and al≈øo the Battery is taxed at another day, &c. and with averment; yet as to the Battery it was holden good enough with averment, and as to the breaking of the Clo≈øe the Plaintiff had Iudgment, See 41 E. 3. brev. 548. 12 R. 2. Coronae 110. and the Ca≈øe betwixt Rider Plaintiff and Cobham Defendant, Pa≈øch. 19 Eliz. Rot. 74. it was clearly holden and adjudged, that after a Recovery in Tre≈øpa≈øs an Appeal of Maheim doth not lie; and the Book which deceives the Plaintiff is 22 E. 3. 82. where it is ≈øaid by Thorp, That notwith≈øtanding Recovery in Appeal of Maheim, yet he may after recover in Tre≈øpa≈øs, but Non dicite contra. Popham contrary, the Plea in Bar is not good, for the Averment is, that the ≈øtroke and the wounding ≈øuppo≈øed in the Writ of Tre≈øpa≈øs, and in his Appeal of Maheim are all one, but it is not averred that any damages were given for the Maheim, or that the Maheim was given in Evidence; for it might be, that there was not any Maheim when the Tre≈øpa≈øs was brought, but that after by the drying of the wound it became a Maheim, and then the Action did ri≈øe; as if a man upon a Contract promi≈øeth to pay me 10 l. at Michaelmas, and other 10 l. at Chri≈øtmas, if he doth not pay the 10 l. at Michaelmas, I may have an Action upon the promi≈øe for the not payment of that 10 l. and afterwards I may have another Action and recover damages for the not payment of the 10 l. at Chri≈øtmas, but if I do not begin any Action before Chri≈øtmas, I cannot recover damages but once, for the whole promi≈øe, and damages ≈øhall be given in Evidence; and if I be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, I may recover damages for the fir≈øt Entry, and notwith≈øtanding that I ≈øhall have an A≈ø≈øi≈øe, and if I do reenter, I ≈øhall have Tre≈øpa≈øs and recover damages for the mean profits,Ante 302. and the damages recovered for the fir≈øt Entry ≈øhall be recouped; and the Book cited before Fitz. Coronae 110, doth not make for the Defendant, but rather for the Plaintiff, for there it is averred, that the Maheim was given in Evidence, in the Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, which it is not in our Ca≈øe. Egerton Solicitor, we have ≈øhewed, That ≈øucci≈øio venarum, in this appeal ≈øpecified is eadem ≈øucci≈øio & vulneratio mentioned in the Tre≈øpa≈øs. Coke, Although the identity of the wounding and cutting of the veins are averred, yet it is not averred, that the damages recovered in the Tre≈øpa≈øs were given for this Maheim. Wray chief Iu≈øtice, The Iurors are to take con≈øideration of the wound in an action of Tre≈øpa≈øs, and to give damages according to the hurt, and we ought to think that they have done accordingly, and if they have not ≈øo done, the party may pray that the Court by in≈øpection would adjudge upon it, and ≈øo increa≈øe the damages: But now when the Iury hath given great damages, ≈øcil. 200 Marks, with which the party hath been contented, it ≈øhould be hard to give the Plaintiff another Action, and if there be any ≈øuch ≈øpecial matter, that it was not become a Maheim at the time of the Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs brought, but it is become a Maheim of later time by drying, the Plaintiff ought to have ≈øhewed the ≈øame to the Court, and ≈øo have helped him≈øelf, for otherwi≈øe it ≈øhall not be ≈øo intended, but that the averment made by the Defendant, is good enough to ou≈øt the Plaintiff of this Action; and the Iudgment cited 19 Eliz. before, was given by me, after I was con≈øtituted chief Iu≈øtice, and this Bar as I conceive was drawn out of the pleading in 19 Eliz. and afterwards Iudgment was given again≈øt the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCXLVIII. Cro≈øman and Reads Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Intermarriage 1 Cro. 114.THe Ca≈øe was, that I.S. made his wife his Excutrix and dyed, I. D. being then endebted to the Te≈øtator in ≈øixty pounds upon a ≈øimple Contract, the Wife Executrix took to Husband the ≈øaid I.D. I.D. made his Executor and dyed, a Creditor of I.S. brought an Action of Debt again≈øt the Wife Executrix of I.S. and upon the pleading, the matter in que≈øtion was,Debt by Executors. If by the entermarriage of the wife with the Debtor of the Te≈øtator, the ≈øame was a Deva≈øtavit or not: And if the ≈øaid Debt of ≈øixty pounds due by I.D. ≈øhould be A≈ø≈øets in her hands: And per Curiam, It is no Deva≈øtavit, nor A≈ø≈øets, as is ≈øuppo≈øed: For the woman may have an Action again≈øt the Executor of I.D. And it was agreed by the Court, that if a man makes his Debtor and a ≈øtranger his Executors, and the Debtor dieth, the ≈øurviving Executor may have an Action of debt again≈øt the Executor of the Debtor; and ≈øo it was adjudged in the principal ca≈øe.

div.head:
CCCCXLIX. Wollman and Fies Ca≈øe.
Mich. 31 & 32 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A≈ø≈øump≈øit. 1 Cro. 179.IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe upon A≈ø≈øump≈øit that the Plaintiff ≈øhould enjoy ≈øuch Lands for ≈øo many years: The Defendant pleaded the Statute of 13 & 14 Eliz. becau≈øe the Land is the Glebe Land of ≈øuch a Par≈øonage, and in truth the Defendant did mi≈ø-recite the Statute: For the Statute is, No Lea≈øe after the fifteenth day of May: And (the pleading is hereafter to be made) Secondly, the Statute is of any Benefice with cure (the pleading is of any Benefice:) Thirdly, The Statute is, without ab≈øence above eighty, and the pleading is (without ab≈øence by the ≈øpace of eighty) days: And for the≈øe Cau≈øes the Plaintiff had Iudgment.

div.head:
CCCCL. Frond and Batts Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Debt. Payment to the wife not good.IN debt upon a Bond upon condition to ≈øtand to the Award of I.S. The Defendant pleaded, That the ≈øaid I.S. had Arbitrated, that the Defendant ≈øhould pay to the Plaintiff ten pounds, and he ≈øaid he had paid it to the Plaintiffs wife who received it, upon which the Plaintiff did demur: And Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head: CCCCLI. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Grants of the King of the Office of Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench.THe Queen granted to George Earl of Shrewsbury, An. 15. of her reign, the Office of Earl Mar≈øhal of England, and now came the ≈øaid Earl and prayed, that I. S. one of his Servants, to whom he had granted the Office of Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench might be to it, becau≈øe the ≈øame is an Office incident to his Office, and in his power to grant, and that Knowles, to whom the Queen had granted the ≈øaid Office of Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench by the Attainder of North. be removed: And a Pre≈øident was ≈øhewed 14 & 15 Eliz. Betwixt Gawdy and Verney, where it was agreed, That the
≈øaid office was a ≈øeveral office from the ≈øaid great office, and not incident to it; And as to the Ca≈øe of 39 H. 6. 33, 34. the truth is, the ≈øaid office of Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench was granted expre≈øly by the Duke by expre≈øs words, and ≈øo he had it not as incident to his office of Mar≈øhal of England: On the other ≈øide, there were three Pre≈øidents ≈øhewed, fir≈øt in the time of E. 2. That the office of the Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench was appendant to the ≈øaid office of Mar≈øhal of England: Secondly, 8 R. 2. When the ≈øaid great office was in the King, he granted the ≈øaid office of Mar≈øhal of the Kings Bench: But 20 R. 2. both offices were rejoyned as they were before in ancient time, and there were al≈øo ≈øhewed Latters Patents of 4 E. 4. and 19 H. 8. by which it appeared, That the ≈øaid inferiour office had time out of mind been part of the great office; And it was moved, That when the ≈øaid great office is in the Kings hands, and the King grants the ≈øaid under office, if now this office be not ≈øevered from the great office for ever. Wray, It is no ≈øeverance, for the chief office is an office of Dignity, which may remain in the King, but this under office is an office of nece≈ø≈øity, and the King him≈øelf cannot execute it, by which of nece≈ø≈øity he ought to grant it. Another matter was moved, If the Grant of the King unto the Earl of Shrewsbury were good, becau≈øe in it the Grant to Verney of the ≈øaid under office, is not recited according to the Statute of 6 H. 8. 9. As 26 E. 3. 60. The King ≈øei≈øed of the Honor of Pickring, to which a Forre≈øt was appendant, the Bayliwick of which Forre≈øt he granted in fee rendring rent, and afterwards he granted the Honor with Appurtenances, and afterwards the Bailiff committed a Forfeiture, and that was found in Eyre, the Grantee of the Honor ≈øhall ≈øei≈øe it, yet the King ≈øhall have the Rent: And here the Earl of Shrewsbury ≈øhall have this office in his power to grant; And ≈øo much the rather becau≈øe it was granted but for life.

div.head:
CCCCLII. Michill and Hores Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: MIchil did affirm a Plaint in the Court of the City of Exeter again≈øt Hore for twenty pounds, and upon Nihil returned,Attachment of goods by cu≈øtom of Exeter. it was ≈øurmi≈øed; That Tro≈ø≈øe had certain monies in his hands due to Hore, and according to the cu≈øtom of Exeter the ≈øaid monies were attached in the hands of Tro≈ø≈øe, who appeared upon the Attachment, and pleaded, That he owed nothing to Hore, upon which there was a Demurrer,Error. and Iudgment given again≈øt Tro≈ø≈øe becau≈øe that Tro≈ø≈øe ought to have pleaded, not only that he owed him nothing, but further that he had not any goods of Hores in his hands: And thereupon Tro≈ø≈øe brought a Writ of Error, and a≈ø≈øigned the Error in the principal matter, upon which it was demurred, and Iudgment given again≈øt the Plaintiff, becau≈øe that the Plea of Tro≈ø≈øe (that he owed him nothing) is good enough, for if there be not a Debt, it is not attachable upon ≈øuch Attachment: And it is a good Plea to a common intent, and altogether in u≈øe in London, were ≈øuch cu≈øtom is: Another Error was a≈ø≈øingned, for that Michill had recovered Co≈øts again≈øt Tro≈ø≈øe, where it ought not to be: And al≈øo Iudgment is not given, that Tro≈ø≈øe ≈øhould be di≈øcharged again≈øt Hore; And afterwards the Iudgment given in Exeter was rever≈øed.

div.head:
CCCCLIII. Dennis and Saint Johns Ca≈øe.
Mich. 30 & 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt. 1 Cro. 494.IN Debt upon an Obligation, again≈øt Oliver Saint John, and Alice his wife, as heir of her Father: The Defendants pleaded, Non e≈øt factum of the Father: And it was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, That the Obligation was made by the Father of the Wife to the Plaintiff and another, whereas in truth, The Plaintiff hath declared upon an Obligation made to him≈øelf only without ≈øpeaking of any other joynt Obligee,Non e≈øt factum. and that the Plaintiff as Survivor hath brought the Action, and if upon the matter it ≈øhall be ≈øaid the Deed of the Defendant in manner as the Plaintiff hath declared, the Iury refer unto the Court: And the ca≈øe, 14 E. 4. 1. b. If three enfeoff me, and I plead, That two did enfeoff me and the ≈øame be traver≈øed, it ≈øhall be found again≈øt me, for the Feoffment is a joynt act by them all: But if a man enfeoffeth me and two others, and they dye, ≈øo as I have all by Survivor, in pleading I may ≈øhew the Feoffment was made to me alone: So 46 E. 3. 17. a. Three Joynt-tenants in Fee make a Lea≈øe for life, and afterwards two of the Ioynt-tenants relea≈øe to the third, who brings an Action of Wa≈øt again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øee, and the Writ was, That he held of his Lea≈øe only, and the Writ was awarded good. Walme≈øley, This Plea, Non e≈øt factum, upon this matter is no good Plea, for he hath not pleaded it Re≈øpective as to the Obligation, but generally, Non e≈øt factum ≈øuum, which refers to the Obligor only, and the I≈ø≈øue is not whether he made the Deed to the Plaintiff or not, but generally whether he made it at all: For there is a difference, Nihil debet, for that refers to te Plaintiff, and where he pleads Non e≈øt factum: Which that refers to the Plaintiff, and where he pleads Non e≈øt factum: Which Shutteleworth granted: See 1 Eliz. Dyer, 167. Tawes Ca≈øe, this Plea Non e≈øt factum, hath not any re≈øpect to the Obligee be a Monk, and there is another who bears the name of the Obligee, yet in tho≈øe Ca≈øes, the Obligor cannot ≈øafely plead Non e≈øt factum; but where one is ≈øued who bears the name of the Obligor, there Non e≈øt factum is a good Plea: And ≈øee 10 Eliy. Dyer, 279. W.S. was bound in an Obligation to one H. by the name of I.S. and upon that Obligation an Action was brought again≈øt him by the name of W.S. and he pleaded Non e≈øt factum, and the ≈øpecial matter was found, and it was ruled, that upon that Verdict the Plaintiff ≈øhould not recover, but the be≈øt way for the Plaintiff was, to ≈øue the Defendant by the name by which he is bound, and then if he appear and plead (ut ≈øupra) he ≈øhall be concluded by the Obligation: And the Court was clear of opinion, That the Plaintiff ought to have declared upon the ≈øpecial matter.

div.head:
CCCCLIV. Willis and Whitewoods Ca≈øe.
Hill. 31. Eliz. Rot. 1428 In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
Lea≈øes. Ow. ‚Ä¢ 5. 56. Hutt. 105. Ant. 158. Surrenders.THe ca≈øe was, That A. was ≈øei≈øed of certain Lands holden in Socage, and lea≈øed the ≈øame to I.S. for many years, and dyed, his heir within the age of fourteen years, the wife of A. being Guardian in Socage lea≈øed the ≈øame Land by Indenture to the ≈øame I.S. for years, if the fir≈øt Lea≈øe was ≈øurrendred, or determined was the Que≈øtion: Ander≈øon, Surrendred it cannot be, for the Guardian hath not any Rever≈øion capable of a Surrender, but only an Authority given to her by the Law to take the profits to the u≈øe of the Heir: But yet perhaps it is determined by con≈øequence and operation of Law: As if A. lea≈øe to B. for one hundred years, and afterwards granteth
the Rever≈øion to C. for two years, who lea≈øeth to B. for two years, who accepts the Lea≈øe, the ≈øame is not any Surrender,Ante. 303. for a term of one hundred years cannot be drowned in a Rever≈øion for two years, yet the fir≈øt Lea≈øe is determined, which Periam granted: And by Windham, If a Lea≈øe be made to begin at Michaelmas, and before that time, the Le≈ø≈øor makes a new Lea≈øe to the ≈øame Le≈ø≈øee to begin pre≈øently, the ≈øame is not any Surrender, and yet thereby the fir≈øt Lea≈øe is determined, and ≈øo in the principal ca≈øe, which Ander≈øon granted, but Periam doubted of it; and he ≈øaid, Guardian in Socage hath ≈øuch an e≈øtate in the Rever≈øion that he may enter for a condition broken: Ander≈øon, The ≈øame is not in re≈øpect of any e≈øtate that he hath, but in the name and right of the heir, and not by rea≈øon of any Rever≈øion.

div.head:
CCCCLV. Norwood and Dennis Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the common Pleas.
div.p: IN a Quare Impedit by Norwood again≈øt Dennis, the I≈ø≈øue was,Quare Impedit. If the Advow≈øon was appendant to the Manor of D. or in gro≈øs, and the Iury ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ und that it was appendant, and further found, that the Queen had right, and title to pre≈øent, for ≈øhe had pre≈øented at the two la≈øt Avoidances. Ander≈øon and Periam Iu≈øtices, If it appeareth unto the Court upon the pleading, that the King hath title to pre≈øent. The Court ≈øhall award a Writ to the Bi≈øhop for the King, but here appeareth no title for the the Queen upon the pleading, but only upon the Verdict, ≈øo as the one part or the other may an≈øwer to it: And becau≈øe the Iury have found for the Plaintiff, the title found for the Queen ≈øhall not be re≈øpected, but as a meer Nugation and Surplu≈øage, for the ≈øame was out of their I≈ø≈øue, and their Charge, and it is no more then if one comes into the Court, and informs us of any title for the Queen, there the Court ought not to regard it.

div.head:
CCCCLVI. Green and the Hundred of Buccle-churches Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p:
IN an Action upon the Statute of Huy and Cry, the Ca≈øe was,Action upon the Statute of Huy and Cry. 1 Cro. 14. That Green did deliver a certain ≈øum of money to a Carryer, who put the ‚Ä¢ ame (among≈øt other things) in his Cart, and ≈øent a boy of the age of twelve years with the Cart before, and he him≈øelf ≈øtayed a ≈øhort time in the Inn, and afterwards went his way, and before he could get to the Cart, the Cart was robbed and the money carryed away. The boy made Huy and Cry, and came unto a Iu≈øtice of Peace, and prayed he would examine him, but he would not, but the Carryer him≈øelf would not go to be examined, wherefore Green him≈øelf wen to a Iu≈øtice of Peace to be examined, and ≈øo was, and afterwards brought this Action: And it was holden by the Court; that here the Plaintiff had failed of his Action for want of ≈øufficient examination, for the Servant who was robbed ought to be examined, and the examination of the Ma≈øter or Owner of the goods who was not pre≈øent at the Robbery is not at any purpo≈øe to enable the Plaintiff to this Action, for the party robbed ought to be examined: And it was ≈øaid by ≈øome, That where an Action doth not lye upon the new Statute of 27 Eliz. the party may have an Action upon the old Statute, but others were again≈øt it, for the Statute of 27 Eliz. is in the Negative, ≈øo as if the Action doth not lye upon it, no Action lyeth at all: And it was moved by Periam and Ander≈øon, That the Plaintiff might have an Action upon his Ca≈øe framed upon the ≈øaid. Statute of 27 Eliz. again≈øt the Iu≈øtice of Peace who refu≈øed to examine the boy:
But Windham doubted of it, becau≈øe the Iu≈øtice of Peace is a Iudge of Record, and for ≈øuch thing as he doth as Iudge, no Action lieth: To which it was an≈øwered by Periam and Ander≈øon, That the Examination in ≈øuch ca≈øe is not made by him as Iudge or Iu≈øtice of Peace, but as a Mini≈øter appointed for the examination by the Statute, &c.

div.head:
CCCCLVII. Stevin≈øon Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Common Pleas.
div.p: Debt.IN Debt upon a Bond, the Condition was, That whereas the Plaintiff had covenanted with the Defendant, that it ≈øhould be lawful for the Defendant to cut down good for Fire-boot and Hedge-boot without making any wa≈øt, or cutting more than nece≈ø≈øary: And the Plaintiff a≈ø≈øigned the breach in that Covenant (which is in truth the Covenant of the Plaintiff) that the Defendant had committed wa≈øt in felling wood, &c. And the Condition was to perform all Covenants and Agreements: And Exception was taken becau≈øe that the Condition ought to extend but unto Covenants to be performed on the part of the Le≈ø≈øee; but the Exception was not allowed, for it is the Agreement of the Le≈ø≈øee, although it be the Covenant of the Le≈ø≈øor, the Plaintiff.

div.head: CCCCLVIII. Fo≈øter and Wil≈øon again≈øt Mapes. Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Covenant. Ow. 100. 1 Cro. 212. FO≈øter and Wil≈øon brought an action of Covenant again≈øt Mapes, and declared, That by certain Indentures of Articles, it was agreed betwixt the Plaintiffs and the Defendant, whereof one part was ≈øealed with the ≈øeal of the Defendant, and the other with the ≈øeals of the Plaintiffs, that whereas the Defendant had lea≈øed to the Plaintiffs the Par≈øonage of B, he covenanted, That he would keep the Plaintiffs harmle≈øs concerning the ≈øame again≈øt one N.B: And declared further, That the ≈øaid N.B. had entred upon them; And that at the time of the making of the Indentures, he was Par≈øon of B. The Defendant had pleaded Non e≈øt factum, and it was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, That the Defendant ≈øealed one part of the Indentures, and that one of the Plaintiffs only ≈øealed the other part: Exception was taken to the Declaration becau≈øe there is not ≈øet forth in it any ≈øufficient breach, for when the Defendant Covenants to ≈øave the Plaintiffs harmle≈øs again≈øt B. the ≈øame is to be intended of a lawful Eviction: As in Puttenhams Ca≈øe, 13 Eliz. Dyer, 306. But if the Covenant had been, That the Le≈ø≈øee ≈øhould peaceably enjoy the Term, ≈øine ejectione & interruptione alicujus per≈øonae, upon an unlawful entry of a wrong doer, an action lieth: See 16 Eliz. Dyer, 328. And here the finding of N.B. to be Par≈øon at the time is to no purpo≈øe: And there is not layed any expre≈øs title in N.B. but only by implication, for it might be that the Par≈øon had lea≈øed to the Defendant rendring Rent with clau≈øe of re-entry, and the Par≈øon had entred for the Condition broken, and the Plaintiffs ought to have ≈øhewed, and not generally, that he had entred, and that he was Par≈øon: Al≈øo it is layed, That N. B. was Par≈øon at the time of the Entry, but it is not ≈øhewed, what Entry, which may be taken, that he was Par≈øon at the time the Plaintiffs entred by virtue of their Lea≈øe, and not when the ≈øaid N. B. entred upon the Plaintiffs: Al≈øo the Plaintiffs have not declared, That they had entred by force of the Lea≈øe
afore≈øaid, and if not, then they cannot be ejected, &c. and then no breach of Covenant. Pud≈øey contrary, We have declared, that the Par≈øonage was demi≈øed to us, and that N. B. being Par≈øon hath entred; and the Record was read. i. That where the Defendant had demi≈øed to the Plaintiffs the Par≈øonage of B. It was agreed, That the Defendant always ≈øhould keep harmle≈øs the Plaintiffs and the Premi≈ø≈øes again≈øt N.B. for and concerning omnibus pertinentiis, &c. Tanfield, The breach is well laid, and the words of the Covenants amount to as much, as if he had ≈øaid, that he would keep them from all interruption; and the difference is, when the Covenant is general, i. keep harmle≈øs, &c. the ≈øame doth not extend but to a lawful interruption; but when it is ≈øpecial again≈øt ≈øuch as one, there is extends to any interruption what≈øoever. Gawdy Iu≈øtice conceived, That the breach of Covenant is well laid, i. that N. B. hath entred upon them, and removed them,1 In≈øt. 384. and be it by wrong or by right, the ≈øame is a breach, for he hath not kept harmle≈øs the Plaintiffs for the premi≈ø≈øes and profits of them, again≈øt N.B. 2. E. 4. 15. A Bond was endor≈øed upon condition, That the Obligor ≈øhould defend to the Obligee for ≈øuch a time, ≈øuch Land whereof he had before enfeoffed him; It was holden, That if a ≈øtranger ou≈øteth the Obligee, without any Title, the Bond is forfeited by rea≈øon of the word (Defend,) And although the Plaintiffs have not laid in their Declaration, that they have entred, the ≈øame is not material; for it is not the point of the Action. Fenner Iu≈øtice conceived, That the difference put at the Bar betwixt general Covenant and ≈øpecial, is good Law, and that in ca≈øe of ≈øuch a ≈øpecial Covenant interruption without Title gives an Action: but he conceived, that becau≈øe it is not alledged that the Plaintiffs had entred, that there was no breach of Covenant. See 9 Eliz. Dyer 257. Wray, The words of the Covenant do amount to peaceable enjoying during the Term, and ≈øo to an interruption without Title. Fenner, 18 E. 4. 27. A. is bound to B. to ≈øave B. harmle≈øs from an Obligation made by the Plaintiff to one R. if R. affirm a plaint of Debt again≈øt the ≈øaid Plaintiff upon the ≈øaid Bond, the Bond of A. is forfeit; but here the Plaintiffs cannot be harmed, for they have not entred. Gawdy, The conclu≈øion of the Declaration is, That N.B. entred upon the profits and removed them, ≈øo as they could not take the profits thereof; ≈øo it is implied, that the Plaintiffs had entred, and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCLIX. Mar≈øhes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
MAr≈øh, Executor of one Nichol≈øon, Error by Executors to rever≈øe an Attainder of the Te≈øtator. Owen Rep. 147. 1 Cro. 22. brought a Writ of Error to rever≈øe an Outlawry in Felony had again≈øt his Te≈øtator; the Error a≈ø≈øigned was plain; but it was moved, that this Writ of Error would not lye. Gawdy, The Action will well lye, for by this Suit the Plaintiff intends to rever≈øe, and ≈øo undo the Outlawry, for which cau≈øe this matter ought not to be objected again≈øt him, for the Executor may have this Action as well as the Heir. Fenner Iu≈øtice, Where the principal rever≈øeth the Attainder, the ≈øame ≈øhall extend to the Acce≈ø≈øory. In A≈ø≈øi≈øe again≈øt Tenant and di≈ø≈øei≈øor, each of them may have a Writ of Error, and the rever≈øal by the one ≈øhall make void the Record as to both, and he needs not any Garni≈øhment, for by intendment the King is to have all his goods, and the King is always pre≈øumed pre≈øent in this Court, quod tota Curia conce≈ø≈øit; and therefore there needs not any Garni≈øhment by Scire facias; but Wray ≈øaid, we u≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øes to call the Attorney General of the King to know if he can ≈øay any thing wherefore the Outlawry ≈øhould not be rever≈øed.
The Error a≈ø≈øigned was, That the Exigent i≈ø≈øued forth into London and the Sheriff returned, that he had proclaimed the party de Com. in Com. quou≈øque, &c. where he ought ≈øay, de Hu≈øtingo in Hu≈øtingum, and that was holden by the Court clearly to be Error; and afterwards at another day it was moved by Coke, That a man attainted of Felony could not make Executors, for he is dead in Law, and as Bracton ≈øaith, ≈øolus Deus facit Haeredes & homo nominat Executores, and therefore the Heir only ≈øhall have a Writ of Error: al≈øo an Executor cannot have a Writ of Error, but only upon a Iudgment given in a per≈øonal Action; but this Attainder is a thing of a higher nature: as where a Woman poy≈øoneth her Husband, the Heir ≈øhall not have an Appeal, for Murder is changed into Trea≈øon, and that offence is a thing of a higher nature; ≈øo this Attainder is of a higher nature than in the per≈øonalty.
