Al≈øo it may be mi≈øchievous to the Heir, for the Executor may forthwith bring and pur≈øue his Writ of Error, by which the Iudgment ≈øhall be affirmed, and ≈øo the right of the Heir ≈øhall be bound; al≈øo when Error is brought to rever≈øe an Outlawry of Felony, a Scire facias ought to be ≈øued again≈øt the Lords mediate and immediate, which cannot be here at the Suit of the Executors: al≈øo it was found by Enque≈øt of the Coroner, that the Te≈øtator fugam fecit, ≈øo that thereby if he had been acquitted, he ≈øhall lo≈øe his goods, and then the Executors have not any rea≈øon to bring this Writ of Error; but ≈øee 11 H. 4. Error 51. That Executors ≈øhall have a Writ of Error of an Outlawry pronounced again≈øt their Te≈øtator, and if it be rever≈øed they ≈øhall have re≈øtitution of the goods of the Te≈øtator; but it doth not appear there that it was upon an Indictment of Felony. Altham, As well the Executor as the Heir is a per≈øon able for to ≈øue a Writ of Error in ≈øuch ca≈øe, as 13 E. 4. where a fal≈øe oath is given again≈øt one in A≈ø≈øi≈øe and dieth, the Heir ≈øhall have an Attaint for the Land, and the Executor in re≈øpect of the damages. Popham Attorney General, This Outlawry is a real Iudgment, therefore the Executor cannot have Error upon it. Wray, It is good that this ca≈øe be con≈øidered, for it may be mi≈øchievous, for thereby the Executor ≈øhall avoid the Attainder again≈øt the King and the Lords. Fenner, That cannot be without a Scire facias. Gawdy, The Executors ≈øhall have this Action; and as to that which hath been objected, that the party attainted cannot make Executors, the ≈øame is no rea≈øon, for the Executors do pretend that their Te≈øtator was not lawfully outlawed, and ≈øo by this Suit they do endeavour to take away that di≈øability, and therefore it ought not to be objected again≈øt the Executor; and if the Ca≈øe here be, That the Te≈øtator had not lands, but only goods, there is no rea≈øon but that the Executors ≈øhould have a Writ of Error, otherwi≈øe the goods of the Te≈øtator ≈øhould be lo≈øt; and it was clearly holden by Wray chief Iu≈øtice, That the Executor might have and pur≈øue this Writ of Error, the Outlawry of the Te≈øtator notwith≈øtanding; and afterwards the Outlawry was rever≈øed accordingly.

div.head:
CCCCLX. Tru≈ø≈øels Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Habeas corpus. Owen Rep. 69. ‚Ä¢ Cro. 213, 516. Co. 3 In≈øt. 213, 215. TRu≈ø≈øel was removed out of the Counter of London by Habeas corpus into the Kings Bench. Egerton, The Queens Solicitor moved the Court, that Tru≈ø≈øel was a per≈øon attainted of Felony, and ≈øo had not any lands or goods to ≈øatisfie, &c. and al≈øo his life was not his own; and upon the Return of the Habeas corpus it appeared, that Tru≈ø≈øel was detained in Pri≈øon for an Execution, and for divers Actions; and it was the opinion of the Court,Executions. Po≈øt 329, 330. that as to the Execution he ought not to be di≈øcharged, for then the party ≈øhould lo≈øe his debt for ever; but as to
the other actions, it was the opinion of all the Iu≈øtices, that Tru≈ø≈øel ought to be di≈øcharged of them; for a man ≈øo attainted ought not to be put to an≈øwer, nor taken in Execution, and ≈øo are all our Books; And they ≈øaid that they had conferred with the Iu≈øtices of the Common Pleas, and with the Barons of the Exchequer; which were of a contrary opinion in this ca≈øe upon the very matter, and not upon the manner of the pleading; but yet we will di≈øcharge our Con≈øciences as we have done, for there is not any Book again≈øt us, Egerton ≈øtetit ≈øuper ≈øemitas antiquas, and at la≈øt it was awarded, That Tru≈ø≈øel ≈øhould be di≈øcharged of all Actions brought again≈øt him.

div.head:
CCCCLXI. Sovers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: SOver and others were Indicted upon the Statute of 8 H. 6.Indictments upon the Statute of 8 H. 6. of forcible Entry, becau≈øe they had expul≈øed one A. out of his Land, and di≈ø≈øei≈øed the Mayor and Commonalty of London, who were in Rever≈øion, and the ≈øame being removed hither, Re≈øtitution was prayed thereupon, and White for the City, who was in Rever≈øion; and the Le≈ø≈øor prayed that no Re≈øtitution might be, for they had let the Hou≈øe to another,Re≈øtitution. Yelv. 81. Dy. 141, 142. and that he who had procured this Indictment claimed in by a Cu≈øtom of London, That the Executor of the la≈øt Termor ≈øhould not be put out, if he ≈øhall give as much for it as any other will, whereas in truth there is not any ≈øuch Cu≈øtom, and for that cau≈øe the Re≈øtitution was ≈øtayed; and it was ≈øaid by the Court, that Re≈øtitution ≈øhall be always made to him in the Rever≈øion, and not to the Le≈ø≈øee for years, for he who is di≈ø≈øei≈øed ≈øhall be re≈øtored, and then the Le≈ø≈øee may re-enter.

div.head:
CCCCLXII. Beal and Carters Ca≈øe.
Trin. 31 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.

CCCCLXIII. Cole and Walles Ca≈øe.
Pa≈øch. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: Ejectione Cu≈øtodiae lieth not upon a Copy-hold E≈øtate. 1 Cro. 224.IN an Ejectione Cu≈øtodiae the Plaintiff declared, that A. was ≈øei≈øed of the Manor of D. within which Manor are diver≈øe Copyholds of Inheritance; and that the Cu≈øtom of the Manor is, that if any Copy-holder of Inheritance of the ≈øaid Manor dieth, his heir within the age of 14 years, that then the Lord of the Manor might grant the cu≈øtody of his Body and Lands to whom he plea≈øed; and ≈øhewed, that one Clevertie a Copyholder of Inheritance of the ≈øaid Manor died, his ≈øon and heir within the age of 14 years,Hob. 215. Dyer 302, 303. upon which the Lord of the Manor committed the cu≈øtody of his Body and Lands to the Plaintiff, and the Defendant did eject him, and upon Not guilty it was found for the Plaintiff. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That this Action would not lye upon a Copyhold e≈øtate, Quod tota Curia conce≈ø≈øit; and yet it was ≈øaid, that an Ejectione firmae lieth upon a demi≈øe of Copyhold Land, by Lea≈øe of a Copyholder him≈øelf, but not upon a demi≈øe by the Lord of the Copyhold, Quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum; and afterwards the Ca≈øe was moved on the Plaintiffs ≈øide, and it was ≈øaid, That this was but an Action upon the Ca≈øe, in the nature of an Ejectione firmae, and this intere≈øt is not granted by Copy, but entred only into the Court Roll: ≈øo it is not an intere≈øt by Copy, but by the Common Law, for the words are, Quod Dominus commi≈øit cu≈øtodiam, &c. and doth not ≈øay in Curia; and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCLXIV. Bond and Bailes Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
Judgment upon a Bond where ≈øatisfied before a Statute. ‚Ä¢ Len. 37 ‚Ä¢ . Roll. 926. BOnd brought a Scire facias again≈øt Bailes, Admini≈øtrator of one T. B. upon a Recovery had again≈øt the Inte≈øtate in Action of Debt. The Defendant pleaded, That before the ≈øaid Iudgment given, the Te≈øtator did acknowledge a Statute Staple to one C. and that the Son was not paid in the life of the Te≈øtator nor after, and that they have not in their hands any goods of the Inte≈øtate beyond what will ≈øati≈øfie the ≈øaid Statute; upon which there was a demurrer in Law. And Coke argued, That the Bar is not good, for here is not pleaded any Execution upon the Statute, and then the Iudgment, the Statute being of things of as high nature; that of which Execution is ≈øued ≈øhall be fir≈øt ≈øerved; and if this Action had been brought upon a Bond the Plea had not been good: for although that Brian ≈øaith, 21 E. 4. That Recognizances ≈øhall be paid by Executors before Bonds, yet that it is to be intended when a Scire facias is to be ≈øued upon it, otherwi≈øe not: And 4 H. 6. 8. in a Scire facias upon a Iudgment fully admini≈øtred at the day of the Writ brought is a good Plea; by which it appeareth, That if the Executors had paid the Debt upon the Obligation before the Writ brought, it had been good. See 12 E. 3. Executors 73. in a Scire facias upon a Iudgment in Debt given again≈øt the Te≈øtator, Enquiry ≈øhall be what goods the Executors had the day of the Scire facias: and he ≈øaid, it was moved by Ander≈øon, 20 Eliz. in this Court. In Debt
upon a Bond again≈øt Executors; the Defendant pleaded, that the Te≈øtator was indebted by Iudgment to A. and that they had not more than to ≈øatisfie the ≈øame, and it was holden no plea, if not that he pleaded further, that a Scire facias was ≈øued upon it. Wray ≈øaid, The ≈øame is not Law, and there is a difference when the Iudgment is given again≈øt the Te≈øtator him≈øelf, and where again≈øt the Executors; for where Iudgments are given again≈øt Executors, the Iudgment which was given before ≈øhall be fir≈øt executed; but if two Iudgments be given again≈øt the Te≈øtator, he who fir≈øt ≈øues Execution again≈øt the Executors ≈øhall be fir≈øt ≈øatisfied, becau≈øe they are things of equal nature, and before Suit it is in the election of the Executor which of them he will pay. See 9 E. 4. 12. As if two men have Tallies out of the Exchequer, he which fir≈øt offers his Tally to the Officer ≈øhall be fir≈øt paid; but before that, it is in the choice of the Officer which of them ≈øhall be fir≈øt ≈øatisfied; and therefore 19 H. 6. If the Lea≈øe enrolled be lo≈øt, the Enrolment is not of any effect, and Pa≈øch. 20 Eliz. our very ca≈øe was moved in the Common Pleas, in a Scire facias upon a Iudgment given again≈øt the Te≈øtator; the Executor pleaded, That the Te≈øtator had acknowledged a Statute before not ≈øatisfied, Ultra quae, &c. and it was holden no Plea, for a Statute is but a private and pocket Record, as they called it; and 32 Eliz. betwixt Conny and Barham the ≈øame Plea was pleaded, and holden no Plea. Al≈øo if this Plea ≈øhould be allowed, Conny and Barhams Ca≈øe. great mi≈øchiefs would follow: for then no Debts ≈øhould be ≈øatisfied by the Executors, for it might be that the Statute was made for performance of Covenants, which Covenants perhaps ≈øhall never be broken: and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCLXV. Crew and Bails Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: A Writ of Error was brought upon a Iudgment given in the Common Pleas, Error. 1 Cro. 216. in a Bill of priviledge brought by an Attorney of the ≈øaid Court upon an Obligation; and upon the ≈øaid Iudgment i≈ø≈øued forth proce≈øs of Execution, upon which the Defendant was Outlawed; and the Error was a≈ø≈øigned in this, That upon that Iudgment proce≈øs of Outlawry doth not lie, for Capias is not in the original Action;Priviledge. and ≈øo was the opinion of the whole Court, being upon a Bill of priviledge, and the Outlawry was rever≈øed, and the Error was a≈ø≈øigned in the fir≈øt Iudgment, becau≈øe there were not fifteen days betwixt the Te≈øte of the Venire facias and the return of it; but that was not allowed, for it is helped by the Statute of 18 Eliz. cap. 14.

div.head:
CCCCLXVI. Wade and Pre≈øthalls Ca≈øe.
Trin. 30 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
WIlliam Wade brought an Action of Debt again≈øt Pre≈øthall; the Defendant pleaded, That he was attainted of Trea≈øon,Debt. Ante 326. not re≈øtored, nor pardoned, and demanded Iudgment if he ≈øhould be put to an≈øwer, upon which the Plaintiff did demur. It was argued for the Plaintiff, that the Plea is not good, for the Defendant ≈øhall not take benefit of his own wrong: A per≈øon attainted gives his goods,Plea in di≈øability of him≈øelf not a ‚Ä¢ lo ‚Ä¢
ed. he ≈øhall not avoid it; A Woman takes a Husband, thereby ≈øhe hath abated her own Writ. It is true, That a per≈øon attainted is a dead man, it is ≈øo as to him≈øelf, but not as to others, 33 H. 6. a per≈øon attainted is murdered, his Wife ≈øhall have an Appeal, ≈øo as to all re≈øpects he is
not dead, and although as yet the Plaintiff cannot have any Execution again≈øt the Defendant, yet here is a po≈ø≈øibility to have Execution, if the Defendant get his pardon: As a man ≈øhall have Warrantia Chartae although he be not impleaded, and yet cannot have Execution, but there is a po≈ø≈øibility to have Execution, 22 E. 3. 19. A Rent granted to one in Fee upon condition, that if the Grantee die, his heir within age, that the Rent ≈øhall cea≈øe during the nonage, the Grantee dieth, his heir within age, his Wife brought Dower pre≈øently and recovered, and yet ≈øhe cannot have Execution, but yet there is a po≈ø≈øibility to have Execution, viz. upon the full age of the heir. Coke contr. By his Attainder he hath lo≈øt his Goods, Lands, Life, Degree, for he is now become Terrae filius, and he cannot draw blood from his Father, nor afford blood to his Son or his po≈øterity, ≈øo as he hath neither Ance≈øtor nor Heir; and as to the po≈ø≈øibility the ≈øame is very remote, for the Law doth not intend that he ≈øhall be pardoned; and ≈øee 6 H. 4 64. A man committed a Felony, and afterwards committed another Felony, and after is attainted of one of them, he ≈øhall not be put to an≈øwer to the other; but if he obtain his Charter of pardon, he ≈øhall an≈øwer to the other. See al≈øo 10 H. 4. 227. tit. Coronae. Popham Attorney General; The Defendant ought to an≈øwer, for none ≈øhall have advantage of his own wrong: The Plaintiff is made a Knight pendant the Writ, it ≈øhall abate becau≈øe his own Act; but here Trea≈øons are ≈øo heinous, that none ≈øhall have ea≈øe, benefit, or di≈øcharge thereby: And if the Defendant ≈øhall not be put to an≈øwer until he hath his pardon, then the Action is now ≈øu≈øpended, and an Action per≈øonal once ≈øu≈øpended is gone for ever; and he cited 29 E. 3. 61. in the Book of A≈ø≈øizes, where it is ≈øaid by Sharp, Execution upon a Statute may be ≈øued again≈øt a man attainted; and he ≈øaid,Execution again≈øt a per≈øon Attainted. That if the Enemy of the King comes into England, and becomes bounden to a Subject in twenty pounds he ≈øhall be put to an≈øwer, notwith≈øtanding that intere≈øt that the King hath in him. Harris Serjeant to the ≈øame intent, he conceived by 33 H. 6. 1. That Traitors are to an≈øwer; for if Traitors break the Goal, the Goaler ≈øhall an≈øwer for their e≈øcape, for the Goaler hath remedy again≈øt them, contrary of the Kings Enemies; Burchets Ca≈øe. and he cited the ca≈øe of one Burchet, who being attainted of Trea≈øon ≈øtruck another in the Tower, for which notwith≈øtanding his Attainder he was put to an≈øwer. Egerton Solicitor General: And he ≈øaid, That the Action is not ≈øu≈øpended; but in as much as every Action is u≈øed to recover a thing detained, or to ≈øatisfie a wrong, if it can appear that the party cannot be ≈øatisfied according to his ca≈øe he ≈øhall not proceed: And in this ca≈øe the Plaintiff, if he ≈øhould obtain Iudgment could not have Execution by the Common Law,Ante 213. for he hath no Goods, nor by the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. by Elegit, for he hath no Lands, nor by the Statute of 25 E. 3. by his body, for it is at the Kings plea≈øure, and then to what purpo≈øe ≈øhall the Plaintiff ≈øue; and it is a general Rule,Regula. That in all Actions where the thing demanded cannot be had, or the per≈øon again≈øt whom the thing is demanded cannot yield the thing, that the Writ ≈øhall abate: As in a Writ of Annuity by Grantee of an Annuity for years the term expireth, the Writ ≈øhall abate;Abatement of Writ. Tenant in ≈øpecial tail brings Wa≈øt, and pendant the Writ his i≈ø≈øue dieth, the Writ ≈øhall abate, &c. 2 E. 4. 1. A man Outlawed of Felony pleaded in di≈ø-affirmance of the Outlawry, and yet he was not put to an≈øwer until he had his pardon, and then he ≈øhall an≈øwer: And as to the Ca≈øe of 33 H. 6. 1. It doth not appear that the Traitors were attainted, and then there is good remedy enough: And Burchets Ca≈øe cannot be re≈øembled to our Ca≈øe, for although that by the Attainder the body of the party might be at the Kings plea≈øure, yet his body may be puni≈øhed for another offence, for the example of others. And as to Tre≈ø≈øels Ca≈øe, who in ≈øuch ca≈øe was put to an≈øwer, I grant it, for he concluded Iudgment if Action, and ≈øo admitted him
a per≈øon able to an≈øwer, and then it could not be a good plea in Bar. And in Ognels Ca≈øe, the Retorn of the Sheriff ≈øhall bind them, for upon Proce≈øs again≈øt a per≈øon attainted they returned Cepi, where they ought to have returned the ≈øpecial matter without a Cepi; but now this general Return ≈øhall bind them, and by that he ≈øhall be concluded to ≈øay, that the party was not in Execution: And this Plea is not any di≈øabling of the Defendant; but he informs the Iudges, that he is not a per≈øon able to an≈øwer to the Plaintiff. As in a Praecipe quod reddat the party pleads Non-tenure, the ≈øame is no di≈øabling of his per≈øon, but a ≈øhewing to the Court that he cannot yield to the party his demand: A man ≈øhall not take advantage of his own wrong, i. in the ≈øame thing in which the wrong is ≈øuppo≈øed, or again≈øt him again≈øt whom the wrong is ≈øuppo≈øed to be done; but in other Ca≈øes he ≈øhall take advantage of his own wrong, as Littleton, If a Lea≈øe for life be made, the Remainder over in Fee, and he in the Remainder entreth upon Tenant for life, and di≈ø≈øei≈øeth him, the ≈øame is a good Sei≈øin,Ca≈øes where a man ≈øhall take advantage of his own wrong. Marbery and Worrals Ca≈øe. upon which he may have a Writ of Right, Littleton 112. 35 E. 3. Droit 30. And yet this Sei≈øin was by wrong. And there was a Ca≈øe betwixt Marbery and Worral in the Exchequer, The Le≈ø≈øor entred upon his Le≈ø≈øee for life, made a Feoffment in Fee with clau≈øe of Re-entry, the Le≈ø≈øee re-entred, the Le≈ø≈øor at the day came upon the Land and demanded the Rent which was not paid; it was holden the ≈øame is a good demand of the Rent, and yet he is a Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor to the Le≈ø≈øee. And in another Ca≈øe, A man ≈øhall take advantage of his own wrong, Fitz. N.B. 35. N. An Infant hath an Advow≈øon by de≈øcent, the Church becomes void, he who hath Right paramount u≈øurps, and pre≈øents to the Church, and the 6 months pa≈øs; now by this tortious u≈øurpation he is remitted, and the Infant out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and without remedy: And he cited the Ca≈øe 16 H. 7. 10. A Scire facias out of a Fine was brought again≈øt an Abbot, by which Fine the Predece≈ø≈øor of the Abbot granted to find a Prie≈øt to ≈øing Ma≈øs in ≈øuch a Chappel, &c. and the Abbot pleaded, That the ≈øaid Chappel was become ruinous and decayed, ≈øo as no Prie≈øt could ≈øing Ma≈øs there; and it was prayed on the part of the Plaintiff, that fora≈ømuch as the Covenant is confe≈ø≈øed, that Iudgment be given, but that Execution ≈øhould cea≈øe until the Chappel be rebuilt; but it was not allowed, for this is a good Bar for the time, and no Iudgment ≈øhall be given, for it ≈øhall be in vain, for it cannot be executed becau≈øe there is no Chappel, and it may be the Chappel ≈øhall never be built again: And ≈øo in the principal Ca≈øe, &c. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCCLXVII. Knightley and Spencers Ca≈øe.
Trin. 33 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
IN a Prohibition betwixt Knightley and Spencer, The Ca≈øe was,Prohibition. More Rep. 528. 2 Co. 47, 48. 2 Cro. 452. That Ph. Abbot of Eve≈øham, and all his Predece≈ø≈øors time out of mind, &c. were ≈øei≈øed as well of the Rectory impropriate of B. in the County of N. and al≈øo of the Manor of B. in the ≈øame Pari≈øh, &c. until the di≈ø≈øolution of his Hou≈øe; and that by rea≈øon thereof the ≈øaid Abbot and all the Predece≈ø≈øors had holden the ≈øaid Manor di≈øcharged of payment of Tithes until the di≈ø≈øolution, &c. and ≈øhewed the branch of the Statute of 31 H. 8. And that the ≈øaid Abbot did ≈øurrender the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe to the King, and that the King held the ≈øame di≈øcharged of the payment of Tithes; and that afterwards the King granted unto the Ance≈øtor of Knightley the ≈øaid Manor, and to the Ance≈øtor of Spencer the ≈øaid Rectory, and although the Plaintiff ought de jure to hold the ≈øaid Manor di≈øcharged of Tithes, yet the Defendant ≈øued him in the Spiritual Court, &c. To which the Defendant
confe≈ø≈øing the Impropriation, pleaded, That the ≈øaid Abbot was ≈øei≈øed, ut ≈øupra; but that before the making of the ≈øaid Statute of 31 H. 8. the ≈øaid Abbot demi≈øed Decimas Rectoriae praedict. to one Spencer for 70 years, who made the Defendant his Executor, and died, and that at the time of the ≈øaid Demi≈øe, and di≈ø≈øolution of the ≈øaid Abby, one Goodman and others were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid Manor until the year 1585. which was the year before the Suit began in the Spiritual Court, and that at the time of the di≈ø≈øolution he paid Tithes for it, and now the Plaintiff refu≈øeth to pay, &c. ab≈øque hoc, That the Abbot and his Predece≈ø≈øors held the ≈øaid Manor quit of the payment of Tithes time out of mind, &c. upon which the Plaintiff did demur in Law. Coke, for the Plaintiff, That this Vnity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is a di≈øcharge within the Statute of 31 H 8. the words of which are,Unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion a di≈øcharge of Tithes. That the King and his a≈ø≈øigns ≈øhall have and enjoy the Lands di≈øcharged and acquitted of Tithes, as freely as the ≈øaid Abbot held the ≈øame at the day of the di≈ø≈øolution: And ≈øee before, whereas divers Abbots were acquitted and di≈øcharged of, and for the payment of Tithes; for the Statute doth not intend a real di≈øcharge, as by compo≈øition or ≈øuch manner, which is not here, but only a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, which is not any di≈øcharge in Law; and yet in ≈øpeaking of di≈øcharge ordinarily, an actual di≈øcharge is under≈øtood, As if I be bound by Obligation to di≈øcharge one of ≈øuch a Bond, it is not enough to pay the mony, but I ought to procure an actual Di≈øcharge where it is put generally, but where it is put ≈øecundum quid, as it is here referred to the Di≈ø≈øolution, a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion is a Di≈øcharge intended in the ≈øaid Statute; but where the Statute is indefinite there an actual Di≈øcharge is under≈øtood, but re≈øtrained to a time a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion ≈øufficeth, and truly it is a di≈øcharge within the intent of the Statute; for if the Statute ≈øhall be intended of an ab≈øolute di≈øcharge, and a Di≈øcharge in Law only, the Statute had been ≈øuperfluous, for the Law ≈øaid ≈øo much before; for without ≈øuch provi≈øion the King and his A≈ø≈øigns held di≈øcharged from payment of Tithes. But the makers of the Statute knew well enough, that the Abbot might have ≈øuch di≈øcharge by divers means, and it ≈øhould be infinite for the party intere≈ø≈øed to enquire of them all; and therefore they did enact briefly, That if at the time of the di≈ø≈øolution they were in any manner freed of payment of Tithes the ≈øame ≈øhould be ≈øufficient, and ≈øo here is not any wrong unto any, for the Par≈øon had all as he had before, and the ≈øame is like to the ca≈øe betwixt Wharton and Morley, 7 Eliz. in the Exchequer, the Report of which Mr. Plowden communicated unto me, and it was upon the Statute of 1 E. 6. cap. 14. of Mona≈øteries, That all Grants made to the King by any Provo≈øt, Wharton and Marleys Ca≈øe. Governour, &c. of any Manor, &c. ≈øhall be good, &c. and the Ca≈øe was, That a Prebend of the Church of York ≈øurrendred to the King, but the Surrender was never enrolled, and yet adjudged good upon the Statute; for if it was a lawful Surrender the ≈øame had been good of it ≈øelf, without any aid of the Statute, which was made to ≈øupply in≈øufficient a≈ø≈øurances, and ≈øo in our Ca≈øe for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid, and it ≈øhould be injurious to drive the Iury to enquire of the manner of the Di≈øcharge, if it were by compo≈øition upon the foundation, or by di≈øpen≈øation of the Pope, as Ci≈øtere. Templarii: And here the Plaintiff hath declared of an Impropriation before time of memory; and ≈øo before the Council of Lateran, which was within tho≈øe 400 years; and 25 Eliz. there was a Su≈ø≈øex Ca≈øe, where the Plaintiff declared as here, but they would not proceed; and ≈øee Dyer 10 Eliz. 277, 278. The Prior of St. John hath priviledge from Rome, that he ≈øhall not pay Tithes for any Land quas propriis manibus aut ≈øumptibu ‚Ä¢ excolant, but their Farmers have paid Tithes; and it was holden, that in the hands of the Farmers Tithes ≈øhould be paid, but after the Term ended the Patentee ≈øhould hold di≈øcharged, ≈øo as the Statute hath a favourable con≈øtruction upon this point. Now it is „Äà‚óä„Äâ
if the Lea≈øe of the Rectory by which the Defendants claim be good or not, and then admitting that Tithes are due in this Ca≈øe, yet if his Lea≈øe be void he ≈øhall not have a Con≈øultation, e≈øpecially if it appeareth upon his own ≈øhewing, as it was holden in a Hamp≈øhire Ca≈øe betwixt Sutton and Dowze,
Sutton and Dowzes Ca≈øe. 2 Len. 55. 3 Len. 155, 164. which ≈øee Mich. 25 & 26 Eliz. and in that ca≈øe the Lea≈øe is void, for it was made within a year after the Statute of 31 H. 8. the January before, and the Statute in April after, for he hath not averred, that the u≈øual Rent is re≈øerved, nor that the Land was u≈øually let to farm, for which Lea≈øes otherwi≈øe made within the year are ab≈øolutely void by the ≈øaid Statute: But it will be objected,Ante 306. 1 Cro. 707, 708. Heydons Ca≈øe. That this matter ≈øhall come in of our part, and it is ≈øufficient for them to plead the Ca≈øe; but it is not ≈øo, as it was lately agreed in Heydons Ca≈øe in the Exchequer, where the Ca≈øe was, That the Warden and Canons of the Colledge of Otery lea≈øed certain Lands to Heydon for years, and he in pleading of his Lea≈øe did not ≈øhew that the ancient Rent was re≈øerved, and therefore naught; and ≈øo was the opinion of the Iu≈øtices of the Common Pleas, Lord Cromwel and All-Souls Ca≈øe. in the Ca≈øe betwixt the Lord Cromwel and All-Souls Colledge, upon the Statute of 18 Eliz. cap. 6. upon a branch of it, by which it was provided, that the third part of the Rent re≈øerved upon any Lea≈øe ≈øhould be paid in Corn, &c. and the Lea≈øes made to the contrary ≈øhould be void; and in an Ejectione firmae brought upon ≈øuch Lea≈øe, becau≈øe it was not ≈øhewed in the Declaration, that the Corn was re≈øerved according to the Statute, Iudgment was arre≈øted, and we need not to plead the Statute; for although the Statute be particular, yet becau≈øe the King hath intere≈øt in it, it ≈øhall be holden in Law a general Act, and the Iudges ≈øhall take notice of it, although it be not alledged by the party, as it was ruled in the Lord Barcklays Ca≈øe, 4 Eliz. Plow. 231. but if ≈øuch Rent was re≈øerved, yet the Lea≈øe cannot be good, for the King cannot have his Rent, becau≈øe it is not incident to the Rever≈øion, nor pa≈ø≈øeth by the Grant of the Rever≈øion; for it is not a Rent, but rather a ≈øum due by rea≈øon of contract, which ≈øee 30 A≈ø≈ø. 6. A man lea≈øeth a Hundred, rendring Rent, or grants a Rent out of a Hundred, the ≈øame is not a good Rent, but meerly void; for a Hundred is not Manorable, nor can be put in view, nor any A≈ø≈øize lieth of ≈øuch Rent. See 9 A≈ø≈ø. 24. and in 20 Eliz. in the Ca≈øe betwixt Corbet and Cleer, 7 Co. 5. Corbet and Cleers Ca≈øe. the Dean and Chapter of Norwich lea≈øed a Par≈øonage and common of Pa≈øture, rendring Rent, 1 E. 6. they ≈øurrendred their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to the King, and afterwards the King granted the Par≈øonage without ≈øpeaking of the common of Pa≈øture. It was holden, that the Patentee of the Par≈øonage ≈øhould have all the Rent, and no apportionment ≈øhould be in re≈øpect of the Common; for all the Rent i≈ø≈øueth out of the Par≈øonage, and nothing out of the Common: So here,2 Co. 48. for Tithes are not an Hereditament, which cannot ≈øupport a Rent within this Statute, for which cau≈øe the Lea≈øe is void: Al≈øo he ≈øaid, that the traver≈øe of the Defendant was not well taken, for the Plaintiff hath ≈øaid, That time out of mind, &c. the Abbot and his Predece≈ø≈øors were ≈øei≈øed of the Rectory and Manor afore≈øaid, ≈øimul & ≈øemel, and ratione inde, was di≈øcharged, &c. at the time of the di≈ø≈øolution; the Defendant traver≈øeth ab≈øque hoc, that the Abbot and his Predece≈ø≈øors held di≈øcharged of Tithes time out of mind, &c. which is not good, for he hath traver≈øed our conclu≈øion; for our plea is an argument, where≈øoever is unity time out of mind, &c. there is a di≈øcharge of Tithes, but in the Abbot was ≈øuch an Vnity, ergo he held di≈øcharged of Tithes, as 21 E. 3. 22. In a Praecipe quod reddat, the Tenant ≈øaith, that the Land in demand is parcel of the Manor of D. which is ancient Deme≈øn, and, &c. to which the Plaintiff ≈øaith. That it is Frank-fee, and the ≈øame was not good, for he denies the conclu≈øion; but he ought to plead to the nature of the Manor, that it is not ancient Deme≈øn, or that the Land in demand is not parcel of it. Another matter was, becau≈øe it is pleaded fuit in
tenura & occupatione of Goodman and others; but he did not ≈øhew by what Title, Di≈ø≈øei≈øin or Lea≈øe, or other Title, &c. Buckley contrary, And he ≈øaid, This unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is not any di≈øcharge of Tithes by the ≈øaid Statute; and as to the Ca≈øe cited before, of 3 H. 7. 12. where Tenant in tail of a Rent entreth upon the Tenant of the Land, now is the Rent ≈øu≈øpended, and then after when he makes a Feoffment in fee, by that Feoffment the Rent is extingui≈øhed, which was but ≈øu≈øpended at the time of the Feoffment; and therefore ≈øome have holden, that if after ≈øuch Entry he makes a Lea≈øe for life of the Land, that his Rent or Seigniory is utterly gone in perpetuum, for by the Livery all pa≈ø≈øeth out of him, which he ≈øaid cannot be Law; and ≈øo it ≈øeemed to Gawdy Iu≈øtice, Then upon ≈øuch Feoffment with warranty he could not vouch as of Land di≈øcharged of the Rent generally, but as of Land di≈øcharged at the time of the Feoffment, which proves that the ≈øu≈øpen≈øion is not a di≈øcharge, for it was ≈øu≈øpended before the Feoffment, and di≈øcharged by the Feoffment, and ≈øo ≈øu≈øpen≈øion is not a di≈øcharge, √† fortiori in the Ca≈øe of Tithes, for in the ca≈øe of Common, and Rent, although they are ≈øu≈øpended ≈øo as they cannot be actually taken, yet they are to ≈øome intent in e≈ø≈øe: As where Lands holden of other Lords are in the hands of the King for Primer ≈øei≈øin by rea≈øon of Prerogative, and during ≈øuch ≈øei≈øin of the King the Lord gets ≈øei≈øin, the ≈øame is a good ≈øei≈øin notwith≈øtanding that it was ≈øu≈øpended ≈øo as he could not di≈øtrain: And al≈øo in A≈ø≈øize of Land, damages as to the Rent out of the Land ≈øhall be recouped, therefore the rent in ≈øome ≈øort is in e≈ø≈øe, and √† multo fortiori, this Tithe (which is a thing of common Right) ≈øhall be in e≈ø≈øe, but goes with the Land,A Rent in e≈ø≈øe to ≈øome purpo≈øes, and ≈øu≈øpended to other. and therefore by unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øhall not be ≈øu≈øpended, 35 H. 6. He who hath liberty of Warren in the Lands of another entreth into the Land, the Warren is not ≈øu≈øpended, nor by Feoffment of the Land is extinct; and in this Ca≈øe upon the matter, during the unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the Tithes were paid, although not in ≈øpecie: Al≈øo the Abbot had the Tithes as Par≈øon of B. and the Land as Abbot, and therefore no ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, for the Tithes were always in e≈ø≈øe, although not taken in the manner, as Tithes commonly are, but by way of Retainer, 22 E. 4. 44. A Writ of Annuity is brought again≈øt a Prior, and it appeared, That the Prior and his Succe≈ø≈øors have u≈øed to pay the Annuity as Par≈øon of D. and not as Priors, which Par≈øonage was appointed to the ≈øaid Priory time out of mind, and in the Writ the Defendant was named Prior only, and not Par≈øon, and therefore the Writ was abated. See 14 E. 4. 4. 10 H. 7. 5. In an Action of Wa≈øt: So Bracebridges Ca≈øe, 14 Eliz. Plowd. 420. The Ca≈øe put by Catiline, If the Par≈øon, Patron and Ordinary make a Lea≈øe for years, and afterwards the Le≈ø≈øee becomes there Incumbent, the Term is not extinct, for he hath the Term in his own Right, and the inheritance in the Right of his Church, which ≈øee 30 H. 8. Dyer 43. A Par≈øon purcha≈øeth, and after lea≈øeth his Par≈øonage, he him≈øelf ≈øhall pay Tithes notwith≈øtanding this Vnity; and as to the rea≈øon of the other ≈øide, That if ≈øuch di≈øcharge of Tithes be not intended by the Statute, but only a Di≈øcharge in Law, the Statute ≈øhould be in vain, the ≈øame is not ≈øo; for if the Abbot had been di≈øcharged by way of Relea≈øe of Compo≈øition, for the Mona≈øtery being di≈ø≈øolved the Appropriation had been good, if it had not been ≈øupported by the Statute, and then the Relea≈øe and Compo≈øition of no force, and the King ≈øhould not take advantage of it but by this Statute; and as to Whartons Ca≈øe before cited, the ≈øame cannot be Law, for it hath been holden upon the Statute of 18 Eliz. of Confirmations, That if an Infant maketh a Lea≈øe to the King, the ≈øame is not made good by the Statute, for the ≈øaid Statute extends to imperfections in circum≈øtances, and not in ≈øub≈øtance. And although the Lea≈øe be not good, yet becau≈øe the matter of the ≈øurmi≈øe is naught, although our Bar be naught, a Con≈øultation ought to
be granted, al≈øo our Lea≈øe is well pleaded, and if ≈øuch defect be in it, as hath been objected, the ≈øame ought to come in by Plea on the other ≈øide; and it is not like Heydons Ca≈øe, for there it was found by ≈øpecial Verdict, not to Cromwells Ca≈øe, where ≈øuch defect was in the Declaration, and ≈øo no ground of Action; as to the Traver≈øe it is good enough, as if ≈øpecial Ba≈øtardy be pleaded again≈øt one born before the marriage, and ≈øo Ba≈øtard, the other party ≈øhall traver≈øe generally the Ba≈øtardy, and not the ≈øpecial matter, but for the principal matter, i. this unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, divers rules have been. 5 Eliz. in the Common Pleas, the Ca≈øe was, An Abbot had a Manor within the Pari≈øh of D. and a Compo≈øition was made betwixt the Par≈øon of D. and the ≈øaid Abbot, that the Par≈øon ≈øhould have yearly certain Loads of Wood, out of thirty Acres of the ≈øaid Manor, for, and in recompence of all the Tithes of Wood there, afterwards the Par≈øonage was appropriated to the ≈øaid Abbot, and afterwards the hou≈øe was di≈ø≈øolved, and the Manor granted to one, and the Rectory to another, and it was holden, That the portion of the Tithes was removed, for he had them, ≈øcil. The Manor and the Tithes in ≈øeveral Rights. And Manwood Chief Baron, and Periam Iu≈øtice, to whom a Ca≈øe depending in the Chancery was referred concerning the di≈øcharge of Tithes by unity of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, delivered their opinions, That ≈øuch an Vnity is not any di≈øcharge within the ≈øaid Statute. It was adjorned.

div.head:
CCCCLXVIII. Hoskins and Stupers Ca≈øe.
Mich. 32 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p: IN an Action upon the Ca≈øe, the Plaintiff declared,A≈ø≈øump≈øit. That whereas the Plaintiff had ≈øold to the Defendant 1000 couple of Newland Fi≈øhes to the u≈øe of the Defendant, and in con≈øideration that he ≈øhould ≈øhip, and ≈øhould bring and carry the adventure of them from Bri≈øtol, in portum of Saint Lucar and ≈øhould carry back again the value of the ≈øaid Fi≈øh to London or Bri≈øtoll ≈øecundum u≈øum Mercatorum, The Defendant did promi≈øe, that upon the arrival of the ≈øaid Fi≈øh, in portum of St. Lucar, he would give to the Plaintiff 112 l. and ≈øaid, that he arrived with the ≈øaid Fi≈øh, ad portum of St. Lucar, and that afterwards he arrived with goods of the value of the ≈øaid Fi≈øh, ad portum of London, ≈øecundum u≈øum Mercatorum. It was holden by all the Iudges, that in portum, and ad portum is all one,Expo≈øition of words. as the Statute of Wa≈øt is, Quod vicecomes accedat ad locum va≈øtatum, yet he ought to enter into the Land: So the Writ of accedas ad Curiam, & in plena Curia recordari facias, &c. Another Exception was, becau≈øe he declared, That he returned with goods to the value, and doth not ≈øay, who≈øe goods they were; but the Exception was not allowed, for the≈øe words ≈øecundum u≈øum mercatorum imply that they were the goods of the Defendant, Quod fuit conce≈ø≈øum per Curiam, and afterwards Iudgment was given for the Plaintiff.

div.head:
CCCCLXIX. Walgrave and Agurs Ca≈øe.
Trin. 32 Eliz. In the Kings Bench.
div.p:
SIr William Walgrave brought an Action upon the Ca≈øe again≈øt Agur upon the≈øe words ≈øpoken by the Defendant to a ≈øervant of the Plaintiff,Action for ≈øcandalous words. 1 Cro. 191. It is well known, that I am a true ≈øubject, but thou (innuendo the ≈øaid ≈øervant) ≈øerve≈øt no true ≈øubject, and thine own con≈øcience may accu≈øe thee thereof. It was moved in arre≈øt of Iudgment, That the≈øe words are not actionable, for no ≈ølander comes to the Plaintiff thereby, for perhaps the Party ≈øerved no man, but the Queen, and if
the words may receive ≈øuch ≈øen≈øe, S ‚Ä¢ vage and Cooks Ca≈øe. which is no pregnant proof of infamy, they are not actionable, as in the Ca≈øe betwixt Savage and Cook, The≈øe words; Thou art not the Queens friend, are not actionable, for it might be they were ≈øpoken in re≈øpect of ≈øome ordinary misdemeanours, as in not payment of Sub≈øidies, or the like: Al≈øo it is not averred, that the party to whom the words were ≈øpoken, was the Plaintiffs ≈øervant. Coke, Where a man is touched in the duty of his Office, or in the cour≈øe of life, an Action lieth, although that otherwi≈øe the words are not actionable, and here is ≈øet forth in the Declaration, That the Plaintiff at the time of the ≈øpeaking of the ≈øaid words, was a Iu≈øtice of Peace, and Sheriff of Suffolk, and Captain of a Troop of 120 Hor≈øe to attend the Pre≈øervation of the Queens per≈øon: So in re≈øpect of place and dignity in the Commonwealth, as 2 H. 8. The Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter brought an action upon the Statute of Scandal. Magnatum, upon the≈øe words, My Lord of Winche≈øter ≈øent for me, and impri≈øoned me, until I made a Relea≈øe to J. S. and in re≈øpect of his Place and Dignity the words were holden actionable: and 9 Eliz. Dyer, In an action upon the Ca≈øe by the Lord Aburgaveney again≈øt Wheeler, My Lord of Aburgaveney ≈øent for us, and put ≈øome of us into the Coal-hou≈øe, and ≈øome into the Stocks, and me into a place in his hou≈øe called Little Ea≈øe, and the words were holden actionable: Kin≈øeys Ca≈øe. So in our Ca≈øe, Lewes ≈øaid, It was the Ca≈øe of one Kin≈øey; one ≈øaid to a Bailiff of a Franchi≈øe, Thou did≈øt execute fal≈øe Warrants, without ≈øaying, they were fal≈øified by him, adjudged an Action did not lie. Wray Chief Iu≈øtice, The≈øe words in them≈øelves are not actionable, for the Plaintiff might be untrue in ≈ømall things, which gave no di≈øcredit, but the quality of the per≈øon of whom they were ≈øpoken, may add weight to them, as to call one Bankrupt generally, no action lieth upon it, but to call a Merchant ≈øo is actionable. So to call o ‚Ä¢ e Papi≈øt, no action lieth for it; But if one call the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury ≈øo, an action will lie, for he is Governour of the Church. Thou art an untrue man to the Queen, gives not an action to an ordinary Subject, but ≈øuch words ≈øpoken of one of the Privy Council, are actionable. Corrupt man, in them≈øelves are not actionable, but being ≈øpoken of a Iudge, an action lieth. It was Birchleys Ca≈øe, an Attorney of this Court, Thou art a corrupt man, and deale≈øt corruptly, and it was adjudged per Curiam, that the words were actionable, for that refers to his calling. Gawdy was of opinion, that the words were actionable of them≈øelves, without re≈øpect had to the Quality of the per≈øon of whom they were ≈øpoken, for the words are particular enough; and to touch him in the duty of a Subject, which is to be faithful to his natural Prince, is a great Reproach and Slander. Fenner conceived, that the words were not actionable. Wray, as before, Of them≈øelves they are not actionable, for they are in general, for if he be indicted of Tre≈øpa≈øs, he is not a good Subject.
